title: 3 Men Are Jailed in Glen Ridge Sexual Assault Case
description: The three former Glen Ridge High School football players convicted in the 1989 sexual assault against a mildly retarded childhood acquaintance were taken to jail today for the first time since they were found guilty four years ago.

title: Archeology Team Missing in Mexico Jungle
description: An award-winning Australian archeologist and at least three Mexican colleagues were missing today after residents of a remote rain forest village reportedly attacked them with machetes, driving some of the group into a roaring jungle river, associates of the archeologist said.

title: Murder Rate Is Continuing To Decrease
description: A recent spate of high-profile killings may have given New Yorkers the impression that crime has been rising, but preliminary police statistics obtained yesterday show that it continued to fall throughout the city during the first half of 1997 and that the murder rate was dropping fastest of all.

title: Laughing All the Way To Fund-Raiser On Broadway
description: ''Nothing with gods, nothing with fate, weighty affairs will just have to wait...''

De Bienville of New York, NY. Brother of Belle K. Taylor of Hillsborough, CA and the late Robert S. Kilbourne, III. Also survived by five grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. title: Puberty May Start at 6 As Hormones Surge
description: PUBERTY, usually considered to be the bane and also the thrill of early adolescence, may actually be almost over just when most accounts of human development have it beginning.

title: Empire's Sunset? Not Just Yet.
description: The handover of Hong Kong re-moves from British rule 6.3 million people, reducing Her Majesty's pos-sessions to a scattering of outposts and islands. But it can still be said that the sun does not set on the British Empire. At every moment, at some far-flung corner of the revolv-ing globe, it is daytime in a place where the Union Jack flies.

title: Head of Tiger Management Considers Taking On a Partner
description: Julian H. Robertson Jr., the successful New York investor, is branching out. He is raising a new fund of as much as $1 billion from private investors with the help of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and considering whether to take on a strategic partner for his hedge fund company, Tiger Management.

title: DLB OIL AND GAS PLANS TO SELL ASSETS TO PAY DOWN DEBT
description: DLB Oil and Gas Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Lehman Brothers Inc. to help sell some or all of its assets so it can pay down some of its $80 million debt and pursue new acquisitions. The oil and gas company, which is based in Oklahoma City, has three main businesses: two oil operations and a drilling unit. DLB Oil and Gas is acquiring a controlling interest in the WRT Energy Corporation, a bankrupt oil and gas company, for about $30 million. The shares of DLB Oil and Gas rose 50 cents, to $16.50, giving the company a market capitalization of about $214 million.

title: Messier Relaxes as Free Agency Takes Off
description: It is appropriate that Mark Messier of the Rangers is spending the early summer on a fishing expedition. The National Hockey League's free-agency season began last night at midnight, and Messier might be the biggest catch.

title: Purchase Is Completed
description: Vornado Realty Trust said yesterday that it had completed its purchase of four Manhattan buildings from Dennis Riese, the head of New York's largest restaurant company, for $26 million and had lent him $41 million secured by 10 other properties.

title: Cashing In On Hoopla: A Colony Of Kitsch
description: Samuel Ng slid his latest creation across a table, a sly smile on his face. ''Just for Hong Kong,'' he announced.

title: German Judge Dismisses Criminal Charge Over Internet Link
description: A local judge here dismissed criminal charges today against a 25-year-old student who had provided an electronic link on her Internet home page to a leftist magazine that published articles such as one about how to derail trains.

title: Ruling for Bantam, Poles Halt Publication of Book on the Pope
description: An international duel over a biography of Pope John Paul II has ended in a preliminary victory for an American publishing company, which won an order two weeks ago in a Polish civil court to halt publication of a heavily edited version of the best seller by the investigative reporter Carl Bernstein and an Italian journalist, Marco Politi.

title: Law Allowing Cameras In Courtrooms Expires
description: The New York State law that allows television cameras in state courtrooms expired last night with lawmakers divided over what restrictions they would include to protect victims and witnesses.

title: Clinton Follows the Money From Boston to New York
description: President Clinton set out on a fund-raising spree yesterday to collect more than $2.5 million at three events for the beleaguered Democratic National Committee. These included a Broadway show that saw tickets go for up to $25,000 apiece.

title: One Stacked Deck Against Another
description: It has been almost three years since California voters approved hotly debated Proposition 187, which denied public education and health care to illegal aliens. In ''Fear and Learning at Hoover Elementary,'' Laura Angelica Simon, a fourth-grade teacher at the big school, which serves mostly children from Mexico, Guatemala and El Salvador, takes the losers' side of the debate.

title: Maryland Order Limits Hiring Of People in Workfare Programs
description: Responding to protests that people on welfare were being hired to replace regular workers, Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland signed an executive order yesterday to ban the practice.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Drop, but Brighter Days Are Expected
description: Unlike the robust stock market, which led Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to caution against irrational exuberance, the bond market has been a study in understatement in the second quarter and first half of this year. But there are growing expectations that in the months ahead that could change and bonds could make a move of their own.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the Supreme Court's ruling on the law on buying handguns misstated Justice John Paul Stevens's age. He is 77, not 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, GORDON A.
description: HOPKINS-Gordon A. Age 85 of Whitestone, New York died on June 29, 1997. He was born in Newton, MA., and was in the publishing business in Boston at the Boston Transcript and with Lothrop, Lee and Shepard. His 35-year association with Doubleday in sales and the editorial office in New York and Maine was interrupted by World War II and he retired from the firm in 1967. His wife of 45 years, Myrtle Fredenburg, died in 1980. He is survived by his second wife, Helen, and a beloved niece, Joyce Moisan. There will be no services. Donations, if you wish, to the Whitestone Branch of the Queensboro Library.

title: Corrections

description: In the first large organized backlash against what they call the industrialization of medicine, many doctors of Massachusetts' renowned medical schools and teaching hospitals are calling for a moratorium on corporate takeovers of health services and for curbs on the companies' intrusion into doctors' decision-making.

description: Todd Michael Volpe, a well-known New York art dealer who later moved to California and advised Hollywood celebrities on building their collections, was arrested yesterday on Federal charges that he systematically defrauded his clients of more than $2.5 million in art deals before filing for bankruptcy two years ago.

title: After an 18-Year Campaign, An Ellington Memorial Rises
description: When the cloth drops at noon today at the northeast corner of Central Park, and the new Duke Ellington Memorial rises 25 gleaming bronze feet into the air, Bobby Short will take a slow breath and think back over the 18 years it took him to get the thing built.

title: Nothing Goes Right For Seles In Losing Wimbledon Dream
description: It was a bad sign. There was Monica Seles, relegated to one of Wimbledon's second-fiddle show courts, possibly as a punishment for her continuing inability to add this Grand Slam event to her otherwise well-balanced collection. There was the second-seeded Seles, once feared as the ultimate Grand Slam fighting machine, now unable to summon her killer instinct at match point. She wore her vulnerability on her sleeve, and her opponent took notice.

title: Oh, Aliens: Business As Usual
description: What would be the first question to ask a space alien newly arrived on planet Earth? The dryly clever ''Men in Black'' has a novel answer: ''Carrying any fruits or vegetables?'' This, you see, is business as usual for the film's top-secret police and immigration authorities, dapper black-suited types who keep tabs on stray spacelings in the New York area. There are a lot of these visitors. They come in all shapes and sizes. Some tote cartons of Marlboros for the trip back home.

title: EATON AGREES TO ACQUIRE SEMICONDUCTOR MANUFACTURER
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Fusion Systems Corporation, a maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, for about $292 million. Eaton, a maker of industrial products based in Cleveland, said it would pay $39 a share for each of about 7.5 million Fusion shares outstanding. Fusion shares rose $4.5625, or 13 percent, to $39.5625. Eaton shares gained 50 cents, to $87.3125. Fusion, which is based in Rockville, Md., said that if it was acquired by Eaton or another company and if its 1998 revenue exceeded $122 million, its shareholders would also receive a cash payment of up to $5 a share on March 31, 1999.

description: Soup Kitchen International, 259A West 55th Street, the storefront owned by Al Yeganeh and made famous, or notorious, on the television series ''Seinfeld,'' is planning to expand.

title: The Bright Young Handel, Eager to Break the Mold
description: ''The Triumph of Time and Truth'' is an attractive portrait of Handel as young lion. His first oratorio (its later recomposition was to be his last) describes a man with surprises up his sleeve and an irresistible urge to make them known. In 1707, Handel was 22 years old and in Rome. His subject matter, from a text by Cardinal Pamphili, shares the bucolic fantasies and spacey idealism of the Arcadians, a thriving society of literati and artists dedicated to country life in its most succulent forms.

title: Executive Chages
description: HARLEY-DAVIDSON INC., Milwaukee, named Jeffrey Bleustein president and chief executive. He will retain the responsibilities of chief operating officer for the Harley-Davidson Motor Co. unit.

title: For Stocks, Quarter Was One of the Most Bullish
description: Three months ago, investors were worried about the Big One.

title: New York and New Jersey Battle Anew Over Business
description: Shortly after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman took office in 1994, she and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed to end the economic border war that has always plagued their two governments. New York promised not to steal companies away from New Jersey, and New Jersey said it would keep its hands off New York.

title: American Riffs as an Overlay for Cuban Complexities
description: The Caribbean nations and the United States have so much shared history that the mutual attraction they have for each other culturally is no surprise. Jazz, for example, periodically blossoms with the sound of Afro-Caribbean music, usually from Cuba, and it has done so recently with the often brilliant work of the pianist Danilo Perez, the saxophonist David Sanchez and the drummer Leon Parker. A fourth experimenter is the trumpeter Roy Hargrove, who over the last several years has been spending time in Cuba; he has convened a group, Roy Hargrove's Crisol, made up partly of Cuban musicians, and he has released an album, ''Habana'' (Verve).

title: The Lost Louis and Bix: They Weren't Lost at All
description: In ''The Rediscovered Music of Louis and Bix,'' Friday night's JVC Jazz Festival concert at Kaye Playhouse, the record producer George Avakian and the trumpeter Randy Sandke presented a cache of unknown material written by Louis Armstrong that was recently found in the Library of Congress. And much besides: some pieces Bix Beiderbecke recorded but never released (the masters were destroyed), extra unrecorded strains to a few well-known Armstrong pieces, and the thrill of hearing all this music played on horns owned by Armstrong and Beiderbecke.

title: 'Megan' Notices Can Proceed
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that ''Megan's Law'' is constitutional when applied to sex offenders who have committed their crimes since the law was enacted, The Associated Press reported.

title: After a Night of Parties, Nothing Feels Different
description: In the middle of a crowd that jammed the streets of downtown Hong Kong, Carolina Mak hooted excitedly as the mass of people around her began counting down the final seconds of British colonial rule. Then, in the opening moments of Chinese rule that came after midnight, she hooted again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLOGG, MERCY
description: KELLOGG-Mercy. The MacDougal-Sullivan Garden Association records with sorrow the death of Mercy Kellogg, a lifelong garden resident. We will miss her and extend deep sympathy to her family and friends.

title: Federal Parole Law Proposed
description: A Federal version of ''Joan's Law'' the two-month-old New Jersey law that mandates a life sentence without parole for child molesters who kill their victims -- was proposed here yesterday by Representative Robert D. Franks, a Union County Republican.

title: When Complacency Oozes
description: The first time Gianni Versace ever saw a boxing match, it was on television on Saturday, the night before the Milan men's-wear collections for spring 1998 began. He tuned in because Mike Tyson had come to his shows in the past. When Mr. Tyson bit off a chunk of Evander Holyfield's ear, Mr. Versace compared it to the gladiators in Rome. He described the melee that followed, which was replayed continually on Italian television. ''I had never seen boxing before,'' he said. ''Now, I'm a fan.''

title: Jacob Levitz, 84, Jewish Education Leader
description: Jacob Levitz, an educator and writer in Yiddish, Hebrew and English, died on June 17 at New York University Medical Center. He was 84 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Mayor's Wife Shuns Role In His Re-Election Bid
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's wife, Donna Hanover, said yesterday that she would not be seen in her husband's re-election campaign advertisements or make any public campaign appearances in the imminent future.

title: Death Outside the Constitution
description: The idea of upholding a death sentence imposed after an unconstitutional hearing should trouble even ardent supporters of the death penalty. But in one of the most unjust rulings of the term, the Supreme Court declined, by a 5-to-4 vote, to order a new sentencing trial for a convicted murderer even though his 1988 sentencing proceeding was plainly unconstitutional under a decision the Court issued six years later.

description: Andersen Worldwide said yesterday that its partners had unanimously elected W. Robert Grafton as acting chief executive, hoping to end the wrangling that threatens to split Andersen, the world's largest consulting and accounting firm.

title: Sale of an Indian Fort on L.I. Preserves a Piece of History
description: The deed to the site of a 400-year-old Indian fort, which archeologists say is the best-preserved Indian site on Long Island and perhaps in the Northeast, was passed from private to public hands today, ending a three-decade battle to save it from becoming a housing development.

title: Stocks Decline in Japan
description: Stocks were sharply lower here early today as bank shares dropped and traders hedged their bets on the slim chance that the United States might raise interest rates. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 382.34 points, or 1.86 percent, at 20,222.62. On Monday, the Nikkei index gained 81.21 points.

title: A Bite Out of Boxing
description: The only touch of class in Las Vegas Saturday night was supplied by Mills Lane, the referee who warned Mike Tyson, ''One more time, and you're gone.'' Tyson had just chomped off and spit out part of Evander Holyfield's right ear. When the carnivorous Tyson then bit Holyfield in the left ear, Lane, true to his word, stopped the fight and awarded it to Holyfield.

title: Lake Yields a Benedict Arnold Gunboat
description: Under the cover of an October night in 1776, Benedict Arnold led a daring escape by a tiny colonial fleet that had been pounded hard by the British during a battle on Lake Champlain. Oars muffled with greased rags, his men rowed between blockading British vessels.

title: More Than 20 Years After Viking, Craft Is to Land, and Bounce, on Mars
description: Flat, desolate and dry as red dust, the flood plain of Ares Vallis hardly seems an inviting place to visit on Mars, but scientists think it may well be a reservoir of the planet's early history. So the American robot spacecraft Mars Pathfinder is headed there for a landing on Friday, the Fourth of July.

description: Forty-four years after the Korean War ended with a bitter, tenuous cease-fire, North Korea agreed yesterday to hold talks with South Korea, the United States and China in an effort to negotiate a lasting peace.

title: Auld Lang Syne
description: Maybe the most important point to keep in mind about Hong Kong today is that the heaviest concentration of Chinese troops here is not in the city center to protect the handover ceremony. It's along the border between China and Hong Kong, and those troops are there to keep out the millions of Chinese eager to flock here to become part of Hong Kong. Everything else is just commentary.

title: Prison Chief Encouraged Brutality, Witnesses Report

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYAMS, GEORGE
description: HYAMS-George. The Faculty of New York University School of Medicine deeply mourn the loss of George Hyams, M.D. Dr. Hyamns joined the faculty in 1952, and served for 45 years as an Attending Physician at Bellevue and Tisch Hospitals. He was a physician who cared for patients from all walks of life with expertise and compassion. As a senior physician in Bellevue Intermediate Care Unit, he was a role model for students and younger physicians. Dr. Hyams was a scholar who was devoted to academic learning throughout his medical career. We at NYU will miss him. Bellevue Hospital's patients will miss his congenial and optimistic approach to their care. He was a model of humanistic medicine. The communities of NYU and Bellevue express deep sympathy to his wife Debbie, children Irene, Andy, Vicki, Dean, and grandchildren, Max, Catherine, Ben and Lorenzo. Saul J. Farber, M.D., M.A.C.P. The Frederick H. King, Professor and Chairman, Dept of Medicine

title: Suspicions of some table-tilting in the end-of-quarter game.
description: AS the closing bell rang at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the value of the Coca-Cola Company plunged by $5.6 billion. Just before the bell, Coke traded at $69.75. Then, in the final trade, just a moment later, the price was $67.50.

title: The Crown's Last Jewel
description: Not just a colony ceased to exist as Hong Kong reverted to China early today. An entire imperial epoch all but came to an end, fittingly and with Britain's sure sense of ceremony. The Prince of Wales spoke the right words and saluted as the Union Jack was lowered. The colony's last governor took the prescribed final rides around Government House. Defying drenching rain, bagpipes skirled and Gurkha officers barked their commands for parting precision drill.

title: Benchmarks of Justice
description: It was a Supreme Court term that defied labels and made history.

title: Nuclear Weapons Tests Are Set for Tomorrow
description: The Energy Department said today that it planned to carry out the first in a series of nuclear weapons experiments intended to assure the safety of the United States' aging nuclear arsenal. Department officials said the tests would not violate the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

title: CHINA RESUMES CONTROL OF HONG KONG, CONCLUDING 156 YEARS OF BRITISH RULE
description: In the first moments after midnight, in a ceremony of solemn precision and martial music, China resumed sovereignty over Hong Kong today, ending 156 years of British colonial rule.

title: In Evaluating Cloning Ethics, Begin at the Beginning: Flatbush
description: IT was the final meeting of the Presidential ethics commission before it presented its report on cloning to President Clinton. Most members were dressed in subdued shades, perfect for the television cameras. Then there was Alta Charo. Her dress was a brilliant electric blue.

title: As Mir's Troubles Raise Questions On Joint Effort, Some Seek an Exit
description: EVEN as Russian engineers devise ways to repair the battered Mir space station, some experts are wondering if it should continue to be used.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LUDWIG
description: SCHWARTZ-Ludwig. We deeply mourn the passing of our longtime friend Lou, for more than forty years, who struggled courageously with cancer for many years. He was a devoted husband to his wife Francesca and a loving father to Robert, Monica and Valerie. With deep sorrow, we extend our condolences to a rare and unique individual who touched the hearts of so many persons. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Norman Greenberg and Family

title: So Far, Winning Numbers For Liberty and W.N.B.A.
description: If the turnout for the Liberty's home opener was any indication of whether New York is ready for women's professional basketball, the 17,780 fans who showed up at Madison Square Garden on Sunday answered with a resounding yes.

title: Computer Intruders Disrupt Microsoft Site
description: Twice in the last two weeks the Microsoft Corporation's World Wide Web site has been attacked by unknown computer network intruders. In the most recent instance, today, the intruders were able to deny access to the site for much of the day.

title: Detective Is Arrested
description: A former lieutenant of detectives yesterday became the fourth Palisades Park police officer arrested on charges of helping to run a burglary ring. Federal prosecutors said that the ex-lieutenant, John Giannantonio, 59, made sure he was on duty when two other men committed break-ins, then filed reports pointing the authorities in the wrong direction. The two civilians, Anthony Alders of Palisades Park and Joseph Goodman of Garfield, were also arrested yesterday. All three had been indicted Friday on charges of stealing more than $50,000 from stores and homes between 1991 to 1995. Prosecutors said the three men worked with two other officers who have already pleaded guilty.

title: Ex-Captain In Mafia Says Gigante Ran Genovese Mob
description: A former Mafia captain testified yesterday that his bosses had told him that Vincent Gigante was the head of the powerful Genovese crime family and had once come to a meeting of the city's top Mafia leaders dressed in his trademark bathrobe.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: ARENA FOOTBALL

title: Girl, 7, Says She Was Raped at School
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl told her mother that she was raped last week by an unidentified school employee at Public School 249 in Kensington, the police said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Nobel Peace Prize winner DESMOND TUTU is receiving outpatient treatment for prostate cancer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, The Associated Press reported. The retired Anglican archbishop arrived here yesterday. He had part of his prostate removed in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RUTH BRAUN
description: FRIEDMAN-Ruth Braun, on June 30, 1997. Elegant, gracious, and loving woman; learned, wise and clear thinker; ardent and generous friend of Israel, Hadassah, and of countless charitable causes; patron of the arts; giver of comfort and support to all who knew her. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Isaac S. Friedman & beloved daughter, sister and aunt. We mourn the loss of a truly great lady! Memorial services Wednesday, July 2 at 12:15 PM, at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Graveside service immediately following at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Deutsche Telekom Denies Report of French Plan
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Germany's dominant telephone company, denied yesterday that it was negotiating to swap equity stakes with France Telecom S.A., but the company did say that such a move remained a possibility. ''There are no negotiations,'' said a Deutsche Telekom spokesman, Hans Ehnert. ''We have had an alliance with France Telecom for four years, and we have always said that a stock exchange was possible in the long term.''

title: G.M. Says Strikes Cost $490 Million
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that strikes at its assembly plants in Pontiac, Mich., and Oklahoma City had hurt its earnings by $490 million, or 67 cents a share, so far this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, MICHAEL J.
description: McSHERRY-Michael J. On June 29, 1997. Distinguished restaurant & tavern owner for over 50 years. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Mawn). Loving father of Michael, Sean, Peggy Martino and Susan. Devoted brother of Raymond and Charles McSherry, M.D. and the late Margaret McKay, Patricia Holt and Hugh. Dear father-in-law of Edward Martino and Evelyn McSherry. Cherished grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of three. Also survived by numerous nephews and nieces. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:30AM St. Barnabas Church (Martha Avenue), Bronx. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In liew of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to the Sisters of St. Domonic, 496 Western Highway, Blauvelt, New York 10913.

description: CANTOR-Pearl. On June 29, 1997, in Seattle, WA. Mother of Allan and Jeffrey. Grandmother of Sara, Maya and Milo. Services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, Cargain Funeral Home, 418 Route 6, Mahopac, NY. Interment King David Cemetery.

title: Sunglasses a la Librarian
description: Office workers, librarians and grannies have always hung their reading glasses around their necks on ribbons or chains to keep them handy. Now, fashionable women have adopted the practice, attaching chains of fake tortoise links to their sunglasses so they won't go astray when not in use. If the links are matched to the frames, the effect is attractive enough to replace a necklace. They come in a variety of shades of tortoise as well as black.

Funeral is on Thursday at 10 A.M., at St. Mary's Church, Ridgefield, Connecticut. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. Visitation Wednesday 7-9 at Kane Funeral Home, Ridgefield, Connecticut.

title: Bored With Safaris? Try Ski Trails!
description: Look at the slope here and it is likely that you will see the staff hard at work. They are walking uphill, dragging little sleds full of snow behind them.

title: Taiwan Vows It Won't Be Absorbed
description: The Taiwan Government urged China today to protect freedom in Hong Kong, but reiterated that Taiwan would not be absorbed by Beijing in the same manner.

title: Chinese-Americans Rejoice, Dropping Politics for a Party
description: In June 1989, Chris Chan was one of thousands of Chinese to hit the streets of New York, protesting Beijing's crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Yesterday, Mr. Chan returned to the streets to march for a different reason: to celebrate the return of Hong Kong to China.

title: Nationsbank Confirms a $1.2 Billion Deal for Montgomery
description: The Nationsbank Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to buy Montgomery Securities of San Francisco for $1.2 billion.

title: Wayne Wang Films a Tale of Love and Loss Set Amid Real-Life Uncertainties
description: Filming a street scene in this hustling and bustling city has never been easy, what with all the local gangs of organized criminals who demand protection money virtually every time a camera sets up.

title: Merrill Dismisses Broker in Singapore
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had dismissed one of its top private-banking brokers in Asia, saying that he had falsified client statements and client signatures and that civil and criminal fraud charges had been filed against him. The firm also accused the Singapore-based broker, Kevin Wallace, of unauthorized trading.

description: KOCH-Janet Phillips. On June 30, 1997. Beloved wife of Richard F. Koch. Mother of Richard P. (''Terry'') Koch & Linda P. Koch of San Francisco, CA., and Lewis Koch & Ann T. Services at Temple Emanuel of Lynbrook (opp. Lynbrook RR station), Wed., 11 AM. Visitation beginning 10 AM in the Ballroom. Interment is private. The family suggests contributions to Bard College, Annandale-On-Hudson, NY, 12504 or to Temple Emanu-el, Lynbrook, New York 11563.

title: Petty Officer Testifies on Harassment by Army's Top Sergeant
description: In calm and detailed testimony, a young Navy chief petty officer today described how the Army's senior enlisted soldier repeatedly insisted that she go to his hotel room during a military conference, where he said that he would ''show me passion like I'd never known.''

description: CLARK-Horace P. Retired attorney. Loving husband of Elizabeth (nee Gillespie). Dear brother of the late Sr. Marion. Family will receive friends Tuesday, July 1 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial at Calvary Cemetery Chapel, Wednesday, July 2 at 10:30AM.

description: HICKEY-William. Sunday, June 29. Acclaimed actor, unforgettable teacher, devoted member for over forty years of the Herbert Berghof Studios. Loving brother to Dorothy Finn. Cherished companion to Lilli Afan. Beloved uncle to Brendan & Norah Finn. Reposing John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., Manhattan Tuesday, July 1, 4:30 to 9 PM. Service Wednesday, 11 AM, at the funeral home. Interment Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn. Remembrance celebration will be announced.

title: Girl's Killing in Foster Care Is a Nightmare and a Mystery
description: The two-story house with the wrought-iron fence and the blooming white roses seemed like a good home for foster children. And Patricia Coker seemed like a good foster parent.

title: Orioles Sign Africa Native
description: The Baltimore Orioles agreed to terms yesterday with outfielder NTEMA NDUNGIDI, a third-round draft pick who will become the first African-born player in a major league organization. He agreed to a $500,000 contract.

title: MELLON BANK UNIT TO BUY A BANKERS TRUST PORTFOLIO
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that its Mellon Mortgage Company subsidiary would buy the commercial servicing portfolio of Bankers Trust's Corporate Trust and Agency Group. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Mellon Bank would obtain servicing duties, rights and benefits for a portfolio of 1,843 loans and $7.9 billion in commercial securitized transactions and other special deals. Mellon Bank, a financial services company based in Pittsburgh, has balance-sheet assets of about $42 billion. Bankers Trust, of New York, is a bank holding company with assets of more than $120 billion.

title: Office Depot And Staples Merger Halted
description: Executives of the office supply giants Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc. said today that their proposed merger was almost certainly dead after a Federal judge issued an order temporarily blocking the $4 billion combination.

title: Time Is Added For Financing M.T.A. Deal
description: The companies that won $1.4 billion in contracts to build the next generation of New York City subway trains have given mass-transit officials another 10 days to arrange the financing, but the deal remains tied up in infighting between lawmakers from the city and those from suburban and upstate regions.

title: In Bermuda, It's a Day For Glee And Hope
description: Britannia still rules the waves, at least here in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, in the colony that now becomes the largest in what little is left of the British Empire. And here, they intend to keep it that way.

title: Campbell Soup Chief Says He Will Retire
description: Only nine months after he announced a reorganization of the Campbell Soup Company, and two weeks before the expiration of his contract after seven years on the job, David W. Johnson announced his retirement as the company's chief executive yesterday.

title: Tyson's Probation In Question
description: No charges have been filed yet against Mike Tyson, who bit Evander Holyfield in the ear and took a swing at an unidentified police officer in a Las Vegas, Nev., ring Saturday night. But an Indiana probation office wants Tyson on the telephone.

title: One Nation Under Dome: Expos and Jays Square Off
description: For the first time since baseball began playing the national anthem in the opening days of World War II, a regular-season major league game began tonight without a patriotic American song.

title: Court Gets Rival Plans for USA Network
description: Viacom Inc. and the Seagram Company submitted opposing proposals to a Delaware court yesterday in an effort to end a two-year battle over the USA Network, their jointly owned cable service with 72 million subscribers.

description: To the Editor:

Loving uncle of Walter, Catherine and Mary and great-uncle of Robert and Eugenia Rose. Graduate of St. John's University and Law School, 1943 and Combat Infantryman 29th Division, WWII. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City 7-9 P.M. Tuesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 10 A.M. Wednesday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: As the Wolf Turns: A Saga of Yellowstone
description: EARLY on a crystalline June morning, as sunlight began to brighten the peaks, forests and green meadows of the Northern Rockies, the wolves known as Yellowstone's pack from hell were already at work.

title: Soybean Prices Drop Sharply After Big Planting Is Reported
description: Soybean futures prices plunged yesterday after the Government reported unexpectedly large spring plantings, making it likely that this year's crop will set a record and that supplies will be ample.

title: Albany Budget Endgame
description: With New York State rolling in tax revenues, Gov. George Pataki and the State Legislature are rushing to reach agreement on a budget that will probably include something to please every constituency. The danger is that in doling out tax breaks and spending increases, the parties will approve a budget that worsens the state's financial stability and preserves the same basic inequities that have long damaged New York City's interests. The priorities in the final weeks of the legislative session should be to insure adequate financing for health and education and to avoid tax cuts that the state still cannot afford.

title: Registry Laws Tar Sex-Crime Convicts With Broad Brush
description: A 63-year-old closeted gay man, arrested in the 1950's in San Diego for having oral sex in a parked car with a fellow sailor, suddenly finds his life shattered when a neighbor opens a letter meant for him from the State of California ordering him to be photographed, fingerprinted and registered as a sex offender.

title: Federal Express Aided by Overseas Gains
description: The Federal Express Corporation said yesterday that its net income rose 15 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, fueled by higher profit from its international business.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXCEL REALTY TRUST, San Diego, a real estate investment trust, acquired nine shopping centers in California and Nevada for about $84.5 million.

title: 3 Brokerage Firms Cited in Japan Scandal
description: Three Japanese brokerage firms paid off the reputed racketeer arrested last month and charged with blackmailing the Nomura Securities Company, his lawyer says he was told by the man's brother.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: In Hong Kong, Business Goes On as Rule Changes

title: A new campaign by Leo Burnett will try to promote Prozac directly to consumers.
description: REMEMBER when Johnny Mathis sang ''When Sunny Gets Blue?'' The first campaign for Prozac to be aimed at consumers hopes to reverse that tune.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about complaints by nude-dancing services that their phone calls were being diverted misidentified a company being sued by Hilda Brauer, owner of one of the services. She is suing R. H. Donnelley, which sells advertising for the Las Vegas Yellow Pages, not R. R. Donnelley & Sons, which prints them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARONE, WILLIAM J.
description: CARONE-William J. Of Bayville. On June 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary (Nee DeNatale)). Devoted father of William J. Jr., Elizabeth Peters and Julienne. Loving son of Catherine. The family will receive friends Tuesday 7-9pm and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9pm at the McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, 220 Glen Street, Glen Cove. Funeral Mass St. Gertrude's Church, Thursday 10am. Interment Locust Valley cemetery. Donations in his name may be made to North Shore Hospital, Development Dept., 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, NY 11030.

title: Older Recipients Often Ill and Ill Prepared
description: Often overlooked in the scramble to move young mothers from welfare to work are the nearly 50,000 New York City welfare recipients who are between the ages of 50 and 60 -- a number greater than the combined welfare populations of 10 states.

title: Paterson's Great Falls
description: To the Editor

title: Tour de France to Honor Its First Ironman
description: Jacques Anquetil was the first of four men to win the Tour de France a record five times, and this year's edition of the world's greatest bicycle race will honor him.

title: Chess
description: Why should anyone with a point-and-a-half lead and just three rounds to go in a tourney of top class players work hard to win more games? The Bulgarian grandmaster Veselin Topalov found out in the Madrid International Tournament, which ended in early June. After six rounds, he had set himself at a comfortable pace of draws to cruise safely into solo first place. But he reckoned without the remarkable zeal and energy of the Alexei Shirov, a grandmaster formerly of Latvia who now lives in Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENA, LUCAS
description: PENA-Lucas. June 28, in NYC. He is survived by his first wife, Rosa Pena and her children Dinorah, Rose, Lucas Jr., and his second wife, Yolande B. Pena and her son Reynaldo Pena; his grandchildren Christopher, Amanda, Cynthia, Lucas III, and Leander. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Thursday, at 10 AM, at St. Ignatius Loyola, at 84th St and Park Ave. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, on Tuesday, 7-9 PM and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Clinton Administration Tightens Rules on Supercomputer Sales to 13 Foreign Groups
description: Addressing concerns over the sale of American supercomputers to Russia and China, the Clinton Administration added 13 foreign organizations today to its list of groups that are involved in secretly producing nuclear weapons and will now require special Federal approval to buy American technology.

title: Jeers of Stadium Fans Don't Rattle Rogers
description: Tom Glavine expected to get before the game some of what Kenny Rogers got in the middle of the game.

title: Half-Pint Machine Does Windows
description: IT is the littlest standard Windows 95 computer officially released in America. It is so small that people may soon be reaching into their fanny packs and purses and demanding that you watch their dreaded Powerpoint presentations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEIFER, M. ROBERT, M.D.
description: SCHLEIFER-M. Robert, M.D., age 89, died suddenly in NYC, on June 28. Loving brother of the late Dinah Beres, Joseph L. Schleifer and Sidney L. Schleifer. Brotherin-law of Dr. David Beres, Harriet Schleifer & the late Rita Schleifer. Cherished uncle of Dr. Paul Beres, Robert Beres, Kathi Goldman, Ellen Schleifer and the late Lee Schleifer. Beloved granduncle and great-granduncle. Personal physician to General Douglas MacArthur. Services on Tuesday, July 1, at 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Study Backs Tunnel to Replace the Gowanus
description: Replacing the Gowanus Expressway with a tunnel would be cheaper in the long run than rebuilding the crumbling elevated highway and would revive moribund neighborhoods in southwestern Brooklyn, according to a study by a private planning group.

title: Fed Expected To Hold Line On Rates, at Least for Now
description: The Federal Reserve is likely to hold interest rates steady at its two-day meeting this week, but reports issued today suggest that the economy remains sufficiently strong that the central bank could feel compelled to tighten monetary policy later in the year, economists and investors say.

title: Rain Forest Fringes May Harbor the Engine of Evolution
description: WHILE conservationists have long worked to protect rain forests, they have tended to ignore their ragged edges, where scattered clumps of woodlands give way to neighboring habitats.

title: Ewing Negotiations Not Sure to Be Smooth
description: Patrick Ewing says he wants to stay. The team that drafted him 12 years ago is prepared to do what it can to keep him. All signs point to a quick and painless negotiation, ending with Ewing, the Knicks' franchise center, staying put until he retires.

title: Secret Meeting With Arab Imperils Israeli Cabinet
description: Foreign Minister David Levy put Benjamin Netanyahu on notice today that he may quit the imperiled Government in a new political storm over the disclosure that Ariel Sharon, a Cabinet minister known for his hard-line stance, had met secretly with a senior Palestinian official.

title: Mike Should Still Be Paid Zero
description: APOLOGY or no apology, Mike Tyson ought to receive not a cent for his fight Saturday in Las Vegas, Nev., against Evander Holyfield, the heavyweight championship bout that some people have mistakenly likened to the Roberto Duran ''no mas'' bout. This was more Shakespearean, as when Marc Antony asks, ''Lend me your ears.'' But Tyson is not one to ask for anything. He takes. Ask Desiree Washington, whose rape accusation eventually sent Tyson to prison for three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLIGAN, FATHER NICHOLAS F., O.P., S.T.M.
description: HALLIGAN-Father Nicholas F., O.P., S.T.M. Son of the late Frank and Anna, brother of Father Raymond F. Halligan, O.P. and John E. Halligan. Reposing at Saint Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, on Tuesday 4-8 PM. Office the Dead 7 PM. Mass of Resurrection, Wednesday 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to Saint Vincent Ferrer Church would be appreciated.

title: Cousteau Honored at Service in Notre Dame Cathedral
description: On a rainy morning that sent a foggy light through the stained-glass windows of Notre Dame Cathedral, France paid tribute to Jacques Cousteau today and accorded him a funeral Mass of the kind normally reserved for heads of state.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, ELAINE
description: SCHWARTZ-Elaine. July 1, 1996. A Woman of Valor. My Mother and Best Friend

title: At Tiananmen Square, Exuberance Is Reined In
description: A select crowd of about 70,000 Chinese workers, students, police families and Communist Party members was bused to Tiananmen Square on Monday night for the countdown to the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, which was marked by elaborate fireworks displays and a scripted entertainment extravaganza.

title: Albanian President Admits Defeat but Won't Quit Yet
description: After a turbulent five years of rule that reduced his nation to armed chaos, Sali Berisha conceded the electoral defeat of his Democratic Party today but stopped short of resigning as he had promised publicly and privately.

title: Fake Deaths Abroad Are a Growing Problem for Insurers
description: Swinging his car out to pass on a country road in South America, Javier Mozo found himself in the path of a roaring, smoke-belching cross-country bus. Swerving off the road, the car flipped and rolled. Somehow, Javier crawled out of the wreckage alive. But his brother Ernesto was not so lucky. He died in Javier's arms.

title: GE CAPITAL IN $950 MILLION DEAL WITH LEUCADIA
description: The GE Capital Corporation, the financial arm of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that it would buy the Leucadia National Corporation's Colonial Penn automobile insurance unit for $950 million. Colonial Penn, which has $515 million in annual premiums, insures low-risk drivers who are, on average, 50 years old. It uses direct marketing to sell to them. For Leucadia, an investment company with businesses ranging from manufacturing to banking, the agreement is another step in its effort to divest itself of its insurance holdings. The company said in April that it would sell the Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company and the Providential Life Insurance Company to Conseco Inc. for $460 million. The $1.41 billion Leucadia that will reap on the combined sales is more than 10 times the $130 million it paid the Florida Power and Light Company for the insurance businesses in 1991.

title: Clinton Capital Gains Cuts Would Bypass Rich
description: It is the wealthy who earn most capital gains, and it is normally the wealthy who benefit from cutting tax rates on such gains. But President Clinton yesterday came up with an unusual capital gains proposal, one that would cut capital gains taxes significantly for everyone but the richest taxpayers. It might even raise taxes on some relatively wealthy people.

title: Professors Must Now Make the Most of Life Without Tenure
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Lonely Being a Deficit Hawk
description: I know it's hard for anyone in public office to vote against a tax cut. Nevertheless I was surprised last week when I was the only Republican to vote against the House tax plan.

title: Spontaneous Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Long-Distance Rates Cut and MCI Joins in Move
description: Fulfilling a promise it made in May, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its basic long-distance rates by 5 percent for day and evening calls and 15 percent for night and weekend calls.

title: CYRIX EXPECTS A SIGNIFICANT LOSS FOR SECOND QUARTER
description: The Cyrix Corporation, a maker of computer chips, said yesterday that it would report a second-quarter loss on revenue ''significantly'' below the $75.6 million of the first quarter. The announcement, made after the stock market closed, follows a warning by the leading chip maker, the Intel Corporation, in late May that weak European demand and a decline in orders for older chips would cause second-quarter revenue to fall 5 percent to 10 percent from the first quarter. In its announcement, Cyrix, based in Richardson, Tex., cited overall weak demand and pricing pressures on its non-MMX 6x86, or M1, product line. Non-MMX chips are those without the multimedia performance enhancements Intel pioneered and other chip makers adopted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAISEL, ALFRED
description: MAISEL-Alfred. With deep sorrow we regret the passing on June 29, 1997. Much respected and appreciated employee of Imperial Laces, Inc. for over 35 years. Will be deeply missed by all. Services Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, NY, July 1st, 12:00 Noon.

title: Vice President Pays a Visit
description: In an indication of how much the New Jersey gubernatorial race means to Democrats, Vice President Al Gore came to town yesterday to support James E. McGreevey, whose face-off against Governor Whitman is still four months away. Mr. Gore attended a fund-raiser in Secaucus for Mr. McGreevey, a State Senator from Woodbridge, then helped him host a public meeting on education in Jersey City. Mr. McGreevey talked of his plans for more prekindergarten classes, and Mr. Gore advocated college tuition tax credits. ANDY NEWMAN

title: William Hickey, Actor, 69, Dies; Played a Wise Old Don in 'Prizzi'
description: William Hickey, whose career as an actor on stage and in radio, television and films reached its peak in his portrayal of a decrepit, raspy-voiced Mafia don in the 1985 film ''Prizzi's Honor,'' died on Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 69 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Rogers's Surprise Helps Yankees Outlast the Braves in 10
description: The collective groan stretched from 161st Street to the George Washington Bridge as the Yankees made a player switch in the sixth inning last night. An injured Andy Pettitte hobbled off the mound, and Kenny Rogers hustled in from the bullpen to replace his best friend. The score was 0-0, but the sighting of Rogers made it sound as if the Atlanta Braves had a huge lead in Yankee Stadium.

Cornerstone, a closely held firm based in New York with more than $1 billion in capital under management, sponsors management buyouts of growth companies. Interim, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said proceeds from the sale would be used to reduce debt. About $230 million of Interim's $1.15 billion in 1996 revenue came from its health care unit. Getting a license requires taking an eight-hour safety course or passing a test given by the State Police. Renters do not need a license, but they must now take a safety lesson before gunning out over the waves. According to the State Police, personal watercraft make up only 8 percent of the New Jersey fleet but account for more than 40 percent of boating accidents.

description: In less than two months, Tom Kite will add two players to this year's 12-man United States Ryder Cup team. The choices will be difficult. And as the deadline draws closer, Kite, the United States team captain, feels the pressure.

title: Mayor's Charges Dropped
description: Officials dropped charges Monday against the Mayor of Alpine, Lawrence Manus. Investigators from the Bergen County Prosecutor's office raided the family's store, United Concepts, in Englewood in January 1996 and charged the Mayor, his brother, Kenneth, and their mother, Esther, with trading in counterfeit designer clothing.

title: Persephone, True Daughter Of the City
description: A RAGTAG chorus of witnesses in Alphabet City babbled in disbelief as they watched a frenzied young woman climb a fence in futile flight from her pursuer. She was lost to the underworld, and there was nothing they could do but run back wild-eyed to the girl's mother.

title: John J. Reilly, 84, Ex-New York Judge
description: John J. Reilly, a retired judge of the New York State Supreme Court and a former mayor of Upper Nyack, N.Y., died last Tuesday at Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla., where he had a vacation home. He was 84 and lived in Upper Nyack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABSTEJNEK, ROSE A.
description: RABSTEJNEK-Rose A. On June 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late George J. Rabstejnek, Sr. Devoted mother of Evelyn A. Roquemore, George J. Rabstejnek, Jr. and Nancy P. Nichols. Grandmother of six grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Reposing at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on Wednesday, July 2 from 3:00 P.M.-5:00 P.M. and 7:00 P.M.-9:00 P.M. Funeral Service at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on Thursday, July 3 at 11:00 A.M. Interment following the service at Maple Grove Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHALAK, KARL
description: MICHALAK-Karl, lost consciousness on Monday, June 30 due to cardiac arrythmia. Writer, film critic, artist, cartoonist, costumer, musician, song writer, linguist, activist. Karl fought long & valiantly against all odds. He is survived by Michael his partner of ten years, his parents Katherine and William, his sisters Judith and Kristine, niece Carol, nephews Nick, David and Daniel and many, many people he touched and who loved him. A memorial meeting is being planned for late July. For more information: 212-227-6561.

title: U.N. Says Congo Blocks Investigation of Reported Massacres
description: The Government of President Laurent Kabila is blocking an international investigation of reported massacre sites in eastern Congo, demanding that the team's leader be replaced and its task redefined, United Nations officials said today after a meeting in Kinshasa.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday about President Clinton's fund-raising trip to Boston on Monday misstated the given name of the Mayor of Boston. He is Thomas M. Menino, not Tony Menino.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE end of a special era in the American wine trade drew ever closer last month with the death of Alexander C. McNally. Mr. McNally, who was 62, had been living quietly in retirement in Hartford, largely unknown to a younger generation of wine drinkers and collectors. From 1969 to 1984, however, he was one of the most visible figures in the American wine trade. It was during those years that he ran the annual Heublein Premiere National Auction of Rare Wines.

title: Personal Health
description: DO door frames, telephone poles and the edges of buildings appear bent or crooked, as if you were looking at them through heat waves on a highway?

title: Lighting Up Graveyard With a Smile
description: IN drizzly southwest London, there is the meteorological phenomenon known as Martina Hingis. She lights up the sky with her talent, her smile, her present and her future.

title: What Line Did Tyson Finally Cross?
description: Mike Tyson has entertained us in hilarious and horrible ways since his adolescence. Gnawing off the tip of Evander Holyfield's ear in a title fight on pay-per-view television was merely the most outrageous act he has perpetrated in public. We got what we paid for.

title: Chrysler Sales Were Off 4% in June, Less, Though, Than Expected
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported a 4 percent sales drop for June today, its fifth straight monthly decline, but demand for its pickup trucks and mini-vans was so strong that the overall decline was less than Wall Street analysts had feared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUMBERG, BENJAMIN
description: BRUMBERG-Benjamin, 80. Wonderful, loving, generous and devoted man will be greatly missed by everyone. His wife Thelma of 57 years and his whole family, Eileen and Michael Cohen, Barry, Kitty, David and Matthew Brumberg, Cari, Max, Zack, Ruby and Benjamin Lang, Scot, Julie and Hank Cohen, Jamie Cohen, Edith and Bucky Brumberg, Benji, Dorothy, Robert and Sara Brumberg, loves him very much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, MELVIN F.
description: GROSS-Melvin F. Age 79, on June 27. Beloved husband of Ina and father of Laura Gross. Also survived by two loving stepchildren, Michael Molnar and Myrna Maltz, four grandchildren: Dean and Gary Maltz, Jacqueline and Julia Molnar, and three greatgrandchildren: Daniel, Alexandra and Eric Maltz. A highly-decorated World War II veteran who directed decoding of enemy communications in the Philippines, he was interred with full military honors on June 29 at Cemetery Beth El in Westwood, New Jersey. Scholar of Jewish history and beliefs, and outspoken advocate for what he believed to be right. We bid you sweet farewell and thank you for your contribution to our lives. May you rest in peace.

title: Brutality in Boxing: Where's the Surprise?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shabazz Case Is to Be Open To Reporters, Judge Rules
description: A Westchester County Family Court judge agreed yesterday to allow reporters to cover the legal proceedings involving Malcolm Shabazz, the 12-year-old charged with deliberately setting the fire a month ago that killed his grandmother, Betty Shabazz, the widow of Malcolm X.

title: Gay Pride Marchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPE, HOPE DOUGLAS
description: HOPE-Hope Douglas. Beloved wife of the late Norman L. Hope after a brief illness. Graduated from St. Mary's Academy, Peekskill, N.Y. Longtime volunteer at Roosevelt Hospital; member for 72 years at St. Bartholomew's Church. She loved her name, Hope Hope. Funeral services Wednesday, July 2, 11 AM, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave at 50th St. Memorial contributions to St. Bartholomew's or Roosevelt Hospital, 1000 10th Ave, NY 10019.

description: ROSS-James J. After a long illness. WW II Veteran of U.S. Santee. Member and retired business agent of Steamfitters Local 638. Beloved husband of the late Lorraine (nee Broschart); loving father of Kevin, Karen, Douglas and Roger; grandfather of Meredith; fond brother of Maryjane Verhill; father-in-law of Mel and David Douglas and friend of many. Reposing at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, N.Y., Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, St. Raymond's Church, 10:45 A.M. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWERY, JACK
description: LOWERY-Jack. Fellow and Life Member of the American Society of Interior Designers (ASID). Colleague and guiding force in the world of interior design. Past ASID National President and Past President, N.Y. Metropolitan Chapter of American Institute of Designers (AID). He will be missed by all for his energy, vitality and sage advice. A good friend and associate-loved by all who knew him. This is a great loss for our organization. ASID, N.Y. Metro Chapter Board John Elmo, FASID, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, HARRY
description: LEWIS-Harry. The partners, associates and staff of Peter H. & Hubert J. Brandt note with sorrow the passing of Harry Lewis, father of Willa I. Lewis, our partner and friend. Our deepest condolences to Willa, her mother and her family.

title: Root Beer Made Easy
description: To The Living Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVELL, TOM
description: LOVELL-Tom. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing ofHall of Fame Illustrator, Tom Lovell. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Now in New York: Angels That Rescue New Companies
description: For many new high-tech companies in New York, the search for financing is usually a tale of two extremes. At one end, entrepreneurs extend credit cards and beseech friends and family to provide the money to get the business started. At the other, owners court venture capital firms to pump millions of dollars into their companies to prepare for a possible public offering.

description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: The Media column in Business Day on June 23 about magazines attaching products to newsstand copies to attract sales misidentified a Conde Nast publication that offered such premiums. It was the Italian edition of Glamour, not Vogue.

title: Nike Reports Gains In Sales and Profits
description: Nike Inc. said today that its earnings rose 16.5 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, as sales of its athletic shoes and clothes rose strongly, particularly internationally.

title: UROHEALTH EXPECTS REVENUE WILL NOT MEET ESTIMATES
description: The shares of Urohealth Systems, a maker of medical supplies, fell yesterday after the company said revenue in its first quarter would be less than estimates because demand for its disposable surgical products was lower than expected. Shares fell 92.1875 cents, to $5.0625. The company, which is based in Newport Beach, Calif., said it expected revenue in the quarter ended June 30 to be $24 million to $26 million. The company also restated results for the last three quarters after saying it would delay recognizing about $17.9 million in revenue that had been recorded in the last year.

title: Alien advertising has landed, earthlings, and it is taking over.
description: LOOK! Up in the sky! It's a bird! It's a plane! No, it's a one-eyed, one-horned, flying purple people-eater, trying to sell earthlings anything from automobiles and cereal to cameras and newspapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIN, BOB
description: LAVIN-Bob. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Bob Lavin. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Rebuilding Albania
description: Their country is devastated by riots. Large areas are controlled by bands of marauders. In much of the land there is no state to speak of. Yet Albanians managed to choose a new government on Sunday in elections marked by high turnout and very little violence. International observers could not call the elections free or fair, but even ''adequate'' elections are an achievement. Now, however, the real work of reinventing Albania begins.

title: Board Says F.A.A. Lags On Safety
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the Federal Aviation Administration was not moving quickly enough on recommendations that the safety board made earlier this year to reduce the chance of another explosion on a Boeing 747 like the one that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800 nearly a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, DANIEL
description: ROSENTHAL-Daniel. The Board of Directors and members of the Ocean Beach Club mourn the death of Daniel Rosenthal, 57, son of longtime members the late Charles and Carol Rosenthal. He died after a long bout with MS and will be sorely missed. Contributions can be made to Camp Oakhurst or a charity of your choice. Andy Arno, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about new laws aimed at sex offenders referred incorrectly to action by the New York State Legislature on a bill that would allow the commitment of sex offenders to mental hospitals. The bill was approved recently by the Senate, but has not yet been considered by the Assembly.

title: Board Re-elects President
description: William C. Thompson Jr. was re-elected yesterday to a second one-year term as president of the New York City Board of Education. The vote by the seven-member board was unanimous.

title: Before Prom Night, a Suspect Was the Girl Next Door
description: A month ago, 18-year-old Melissa Drexler was just a quiet, somewhat introverted high school senior who wanted to graduate from Lacey Township High School here, get on with her summer job at a retail store on the beach and hang out with her boyfriend. By all accounts, hers was an undistinguished life, she an ordinary girl. ''Really mellow,'' one friend called her. She'd gone to dancing school. She wanted to be a fashion designer. She liked club music. She was looking forward to the prom, trying on dresses with her friend Rebecca.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Hong Kong, Macao, Then Taiwan, China's President Tells Rally
description: Returning home after reclaiming China's sovereignty over Hong Kong, President Jiang Zemin appeared before a huge crowd at Workers Stadium here tonight and called on Taiwan to be next by taking ''concrete steps'' toward ''the complete reunification of the country.''

title: INSIDE
description: New Fund-Raising Question

description: COHEN-Irwin W., of Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Judith. Devoted father of Ellen & William Seader and Larry & Ilene Cohen. Cherished grandfather ofJamie and Scott Seader and Bari, Kerri, and Andrew Cohen. Services will be held Thurs., July 3, 10:30 A.M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Shuttle Roars Aloft to Complete Mission Interrupted in April
description: Toyed with by off-and-on weather conditions, the shuttle Columbia nonetheless bolted into space today on a mission to complete a series of gravity experiments cut short in April because of a faulty power unit.

title: That's Class Warfare?
description: The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Jim Nicholson, accused President Clinton this week of defending his new tax plan by ''resorting to liberal, old-guard class-warfare rhetoric.'' The truth is that Mr. Clinton soft-pedaled his criticism when the Republicans deserved to be blasted for their enrich-the-rich tax-cut plans. Mr. Clinton proposed a tax plan of his own that is far better than the plans passed by the Republican-dominated House and Senate. But his criticism of the Republican plans was cast so mildly that there is a danger he will be forced to retreat significantly in further bargaining.

title: U.S. to Fill the Void British Left in Asia
description: Britain's retreat from Hong Kong leaves it to the United States to play the role of chief judge of Beijing's behavior there.

title: A Bouquet of Sorts For W. B. Doner
description: Florists' Transworld Delivery, known as F.T.D., has named the Southfield, Mich., office of W. B. Doner & Company to handle its account, which Grey Advertising in New York had handled from April 1995 until resigning last month over what that agency described as philosophical differences.

title: Treasuries Up on Signs of Slower Economy
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday, buoyed by a survey of purchasing managers that provided further evidence of a slowing economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, RUTH BRAUN
description: FRIEDMAN-Ruth Braun, on June 30, 1997. Elegant, gracious, and loving woman; learned, wise and clear thinker; ardent and generous friend of Israel, Hadassah, and of countless charitable causes; patron of the arts; giver of comfort and support to all who knew her. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Isaac S. Friedman & beloved daughter, sister and aunt. We mourn the loss of a truly great lady! Memorial services Wednesday, July 2 at 12:15 PM, at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Graveside service immediately following at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Morgenthau Comments On the Fatal Shooting
description: Following are excerpts from a letter from Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, to Police Commissioner Howard Safir summarizing the District Attorney's inquiry into the shooting of Kevin Cedeno.

title: Neagle Is Outpitching Braves' and N.L.'s Best
description: As far as the rest of baseball is concerned, the Atlanta Braves needed Denny Neagle like Ted Turner needed another cable television outlet.

title: Spanish Police Free 2 Kidnapped by the Basques
description: The police rescued a prison guard today from Basque rebels who kidnapped him 17 months ago. The police struck just hours after the separatists released a businessman whose family reportedly paid a $6 million ransom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, GEORGE
description: SCHNEIDER-George. On July 1, 1997. Devoted father of Charles and the late Keith. Loving grandfather of Beth, Deborah, Jonathan and Jeffrey. Services and interment private.

title: Dominican Rarities, Abundant In Energy
description: Fefita la Grande, a grandmother from the Dominican Republic sporting a silver lame top and unnatural red hair, sang and swiveled her hips as her fingers flew across her button accordion. She was playing merengue tipico, the bullet train of Caribbean dance music, with breakneck two-chord tunes filled by nonstop arpeggios on alto saxophone and accordion, like Minimalism on Methedrine.

title: Accuser Is Criticized in Army Sex Case
description: Lawyers for the Sergeant Major of the Army, who is charged with sexually abusing four women of junior rank, made their defense strategy plain today as they tried to attack the character of one of his accusers.

description: Wimbledon vs. Hong Kong

description: Football

title: Husband Is Sued In Wife's Aided Suicide
description: Lawyers for the estate of Myrna Lebov, whose husband pleaded guilty to assisting in her suicide, announced yesterday that they plan to sue to prevent him from profiting from a book about the crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHMAN, ROSE
description: ROCHMAN-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Morris, devoted mother of Morton and Barbara, Michael and Judy, Toby and Michael Gorelick, adored grandmother of Diane and Rich, David, Larry and Leslie, Joseph, Hillel, Arion, great-grandmother of Paul, Zoe, Max, and Laura. title: In a Reversal, G.O.P. Courts The 'Greens'
description: The environmental movement is so closely identified with the Democrats, the joke goes, that to the Republicans, ''green'' is a place to putt at their country club golf courses.

title: 'Fodder Scam' Could Bring Down a Shaky Indian Government
description: Barely 10 weeks after Prime Minister I. K. Gujral took office with a pledge to provide India with ''clean government,'' he is struggling to hold his ruling coalition together in the face of a corruption scandal that could send one of his most powerful political allies to jail.

title: Group Is Intensifying Its Campaign to Distribute Abortion Pill
description: With the plans to market the French abortion pill in this country in disarray, a tiny New York abortion-rights group is expanding its stopgap effort to make the drug available to American women.

title: Robert Mitchum, 79, Dies; Actor With Rugged Dignity
description: Robert Mitchum, the insouciant actor whose heavy-lidded eyes gazed on the world with cynical amusement as he radiated rugged strength in more than 100 movies, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, H. BARRY
description: HOCHBERG-H. Barry. July 1, 1997. We are shocked and saddened by his untimely death. Beloved husband of Annette, devoted and loved son of Phil and Cyla Hochberg, loving father of Dania, Darrin, Amanda and Justin, dearest brother of Etti and brother-inlaw of Chaim, Michelle and Sam. Cherished uncle of Talia, Noam, Ariel, Eric and David. Funeral will be held on Wednesday, July 2, 10 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva will be held at 9 Howell Drive, W. Orange, NJ and from Saturday night at 1548 Jefferson St., Teaneck, NJ.

title: Nevada Weighing 18-Month Suspension of Tyson
description: Mike Tyson will probably be barred from boxing next week for at least 18 months and ''maybe longer,'' a person close to the Nevada State Athletic Commission said today. But there is dwindling sentiment for a lifetime ban.

title: Researcher Hopes Book Will Close Some Eyes
description: William A. Anthony is one professor who is likely to be understanding when students fall asleep during his lectures.

title: False Resume Is Charged
description: Michael D. Francis, the former chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, faces new charges that he falsified his personal resume for a background investigation before his appointment in 1993, the State Attorney General's office announced yesterday.

title: Three Brothers in Search of Wildlife
description: Child actors don't get more coyly camera-wise than Jonathan Taylor Thomas, the 15-year-old star and narrator of ''Wild America,'' a tepid family adventure film whose grizzly bears appear only slightly more threatening than giant stuffed animals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBLATT, BERNARD
description: WEINBLATT-Bernard. June 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Beulah, devoted father of Ellen, Shelley, Barbara and Stu H., Vivian, Geoffrey and Donna, Shelley and David F. He was a quiet man; an extraordinary man. How we shall miss him! May he rest in peace.

title: A Tropical Addition To Times Square
description: To the honking horns and sirens of Times Square, add the calls of macaws and the chatter of a talking banyan tree. Rainforest Cafe, a chain of jungle-themed restaurants, is expected to open a two-story restaurant in the base of the office tower under construction at the northeast corner of Broadway and 42d Street.

title: The Master of Grass And His Disciple Win
description: Boris Becker, who considers himself the grand old man of Wimbledon's damp lawns and is playing the role of Father Time to the hilt, and his protege, Nicolas Kiefer, who graduated from high school only two weeks ago, arrived at the same place today.

title: America's Colony
description: To the Editor:

title: Blockbuster's Profit Is Now Seen Plunging
description: Confounding Wall Street yet again with unexpected bad news, Viacom Inc. said yesterday that earnings for its Blockbuster Entertainment unit would be far below analyst expectations for the second quarter and for the full year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, JULIUS
description: EDELSTEIN-Julius, on June 30, 1997, in his 99th year. description: SCHEER-Ethel. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Kenneth and Bonnie Scheer, Ellen and Len Sandok. Dear sister of Jenny Dembowitz, Ceil and Irving Rosen. Adored grandmother, cherished great - grandmother. Graveside services on Wednesday 11 A.M., at Cedar Park cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Archeology Team Swims to Safety in Mexico
description: An Australian archeologist and four Mexican colleagues who were reported missing in southern Mexico reappeared late Monday after swimming across a river to escape an attacking mob and hiking through the rain forest to safety.
