description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, EVELYN SAFRAN
description: BARNETT-Evelyn Safran, 87, died on the 29th of June, 1997 in Bethesda, Maryland. A long time resident of New York City, she was a graduate of Barnard College, class of 1930. Devoted wife of Isaac ''Frecks'' Margolis Barnett, cherished mother of Barbara Wing and Patricia Karlsen, adored grandmother of Audrey Lipps, Marjorie Hirsch, Katherine Simon and David Wing, she took great pride in her 9 great-grandchildren. She was a volunteer for Lenox Hill Hospital, New York Public Library and Young Concert Artists. Contributions in her memory may be made to Young Concert Artists, 250 West 57th Street, Suite 1222, New York, New York 10019.

title: Starters' Troubles Highlighted By Jones
description: ''Dead-arm phase'' is the common term for what ails the Mets' starting pitchers, but the affliction is progressing rapidly. This is no longer a phase, this is no longer a stage -- this is a dead-arm era.

title: Agency Was Warned About Foster Mother Charged in Girl's Death
description: The agency responsible for a 4-year-old girl who died in the home of one of the agency's foster mothers had been warned by another agency that the parent had neglected other children, city officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMMET, JANE E.
description: EMMET-Jane E. Died on June 28, 1997, in West Stockbridge, MA., after a brief illness. She was born on May 16, 1908 and is survived by a brother, Winthrop Emmet, and nieces and nephews and their children. Memorial arrangements will be announced at a later date.

title: A New Leader Outlines His Vision for Hong Kong
description: For the first time in Hong Kong's history a Hong Konger, Tung Chee-hwa, stepped before his people as their leader today, explaining in their own dialect of Cantonese how the onset of Chinese rule, and his stewardship of the territory, would change their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, ROLLAND D.
description: THOMPSON-Rolland D., of Boston, on Monday, June 30. Beloved husband of Margaret (Rowland) Thompson and of his late wife, Elizabeth (Stilwell). Devoted father of Peter B. Thompson of Oak Park, IL., Michael G. Thompson of Arlington, MA., and Amy W. Thompson of E. Providence, R.I. Loving step-father of Stephen T. Galvin of N.Y., N.Y. Also survived by four grandchildren: Joanna, Benjamin, Katherine and William Thompson & 3 step-grandchildren Margaret & Jordan Hall of Philadelphia, PA and Christopher Galvin of MD. Mr. Thompson also leaves many cousins, nieces and nephews. Friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend funeral services on Thursday, July 3 in the Church of The Advent, 30 Brimmer Street, Boston, MA., at 11 A.M. Visitation will be at the J. S. Waterman and Sons-EastmanWaring Funeral Home, 495 Commonwealth Ave., Boston, MA. at Kenmore Sq. between the hours of 9-10:30 A.M. on Thursday prior to the Church service. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Harvard Architectural School, Cambridge, MA. Interment will be at the Rock Hill Cemetery in Foxboro, MA.

title: Harry A. McQuillen, 51, Executive in Charge of 63 Magazines
description: Harry A. McQuillen 3d, the chief operating officer of the K-III Communications Corporation, died over the weekend at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 51 years old.

title: On Board and on the Loose
description: On a 10-day cruise that feels longer, Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau offer the comedic equivalent of shuffleboard. In the wake of their ''Grumpy Old Men'' success, not to mention their long history of lovable teamwork, these two stars provide a calculated vacation from summer movie syndrome.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The new leader of Britain's Conservative Party, WILLIAM HAGUE, 36, and FFION JENKINS, 29, are to be married on Dec. 19. They will be taking their vows at the office, so to speak.

title: The $250 Cookie Recipe Exposed
description: BY now, almost everybody has heard the one about the woman and her daughter lunching at the ''Neiman Marcus Cafe'' in Dallas, who enjoyed the chocolate chip cookies so much that they asked for the recipe. For ''only two-fifty,'' the waitress said, it was theirs. But when the charge card bill arrived, the amazed woman found the total near $300. Hard to understand, since she had bought a $20 scarf, two $9.95 salads and a cookie recipe.

title: A few big winners are seen in front-office software stocks.
description: WHAT is the fastest-growing segment of the software industry? Many analysts say that would be so-called front-office applications, like sales force automation and customer support programs. Though the field is crowded, and the stocks expensive, some analysts say investors can still share in this growth if they pick carefully among the contenders.

title: Israel's Ethiopian Challenge
description: A marriageable Ethiopian woman falls in love with a young Ethiopian man in Israel. Both are Jewish, but their parents refuse approval of their marriage because family records show they share a great-great-grandparent.

title: He's Doing All of Verdi (Weather Permitting)
description: As names of organizations go, the New York Grand Opera Company may at first seem a bit too, well, grand. This company isn't even a mom-and-pop operation, since there is only a pop: Vincent La Selva, the stocky, affable 67-year-old American conductor who founded the company 24 years ago, serves as artistic director and essentially runs it alone.

title: Inquiry Aide In the House Quits in Anger
description: The chief counsel to the House committee investigating Democratic fund-raising practices resigned abruptly today after repeated clashes with the committee's top investigator.

title: Fund-Raiser's Moment of Triumph Seems Part of Pattern of Suspicious Gifts
description: On the morning of President Clinton's 50th birthday party at Radio City Music Hall last August, Charlie Trie bounded into the Democratic Party's office in Manhattan and delivered an envelope stuffed with $100,000 in political contributions.

title: A Lawyer For Gigante Lambastes A Witness
description: A lawyer for Vincent Gigante, the reputed Mafia boss, portrayed a prosecution witness testifying at his trial yesterday as a deceitful multiple murderer who lulled his victims with a warm and fuzzy manner.

title: Uncle Sam's New Role: Hong Kong's Advocate
description: The symbol of British sovereignty, Prince Charles, sailed away from Hong Kong early this morning on a tide of nostalgia tinged with dread, leaving the United States as the most credible and influential judge of Beijing's behavior in Hong Kong.

title: Cult of the Individual
description: To the Editor:

title: Dairy Queen Review Is a Winner for Grey
description: International Dairy Queen Inc. in Minneapolis yesterday named Grey Advertising in New York to handle the American portion of its account after 35 years at Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Winners of First Onassis Cultural Prizes
description: After three years and 1,470 entries from 76 countries, the Alexander S. Onassis Public Benefit Foundation has announced the seven winners of its first International Cultural Competition for an original theatrical play. The winners, who will split $800,000 in prize money, were selected by 60 international theater professionals, including critics, directors, actors and teachers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEEKLEY, ELIZA ATLEE QUARRIER
description: BEEKLEY-Eliza Atlee Quarrier, on May 19, 1997. Friends may obtain a copy of her obituary and pictures by writing to her husband W. Mason Beekley, 499 Town Hill Road, New Hartford, CT. 06057.

title: Eating Well
description: THE popularity of the ''wrap,'' that clever marketer's marriage of the burrito and the sandwich, seems to be based on the idea that it is portable, multicultural and, in some unexplained way, healthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINTELL, ANNE LEERBURGER
description: GINTELL-Anne Leerburger, 92, of New York City on July 1, 1997. Wonderful mother of John W. Gintell of Cambridge, MA, beloved widow of Syl W. Gintell. Contributions may be made in her memory to the American Heart Association. At her request, her ashes will be scattered at sea by the Neptune Society. A memorial service will be held in the future.

title: Chancellor of Archdiocese Is Named Auxiliary Bishop
description: Msgr. Robert A. Brucato, the chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was named by Pope John Paul II yesterday to be a new auxiliary bishop of the archdiocese, an appointment that observers said suggests that John Cardinal O'Connor will not retire in the next year or two. The Vatican also said that it had accepted the resignation of the Bishop of Trenton.

title: Motorola to Quit Making One Line of Chips
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it would stop making dynamic random access memory computer chips and would take pretax charges of about $170 million in the second quarter for getting out of the business.

title: In Havana's Latest, It's Stop And Go
description: Sometimes bands come to New York City with a sense of mission; they come to take over, to rule. In the case of the Cuban singer Issac Delgado, whose Havana-based band turned Central Park Summerstage into a huge party on Sunday afternoon, more points had to be made. Cuban pop music is virtually unknown here, with conservative local Latin radio stations refusing to run advertisements for Cuban shows, much less play the music. And Latin audiences are often parochial, listening only to home town favorites.

title: Dealers and Auction Houses Are Terrified as Federal Investigators Ask About Their Private Realm
description: On the heels of one of the most successful auction seasons in years, the rarefied and secretive world of Manhattan art dealers has been shaken by a Federal investigation into possible price fixing. Some of the most prominent dealers, as well as Sotheby's and Christie's, the world's largest auction houses, have been served with subpoenas by the United States Justice Department. As details come to light, what appears to be a wide-ranging antitrust investigation looms larger than dealers first imagined, and some worry that basic ways of doing business are being called into question.

Unfortunately, there is not much evidence that ever really happens. But now Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has a chance to score a minor victory by killing a bill that would eliminate the New York City Police Commissioner's ability to fire corrupt or brutal officers.

title: CAROLINA FIRST OFFERS $65 MILLION FOR FIRST SOUTHEAST
description: The Carolina First Corporation, which is based in Greenville, S.C., said yesterday that it would buy the First Southeast Financial Corporation for $65 million in stock, making it the largest independent bank in South Carolina. Based on Carolina First's closing price on Monday, the deal is valued at $65 million. Carolina First shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $15, while First Southeast rose $3.4375, to $13.4375. First Southeast shareholders would receive one share of Carolina First common stock for each share of First Southeast. First Southeast is the holding company for First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Anderson, S.C.

title: Corrections

Their request is not for frequencies from 1400 to 1427 megahertz, which are vital to radio astronomy, but for the neighboring bands, from 1390 to 1400 and from 1427 to 1432.

description: The large Tudor-style house here where JonBenet Ramsey was killed has been repainted, recarpeted and put up for sale. The girl's parents and brother are spending the summer in Michigan, debating a move to an Atlanta suburb.

title: Board Cites Pilots' Actions as Responsible for Deadly Collision
description: A United Airlines commuter aircraft collided with a private plane on a runway in Illinois last November because the private pilot waited on the ground for more than a minute after announcing his departure and did not answer a radio call from the arriving commuter flight, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Anger but Little Surprise At Failure to Indict Officer
description: Some were sad, some angry and others simply resigned, but no one on Kevin Cedeno's old block in Washington Heights expressed surprise yesterday on learning that the police officer who shot their neighbor in the back had been cleared of criminal wrongdoing.

title: AT&T AND STET SPA PLAN TO ANNOUNCE AN ALLIANCE TODAY
description: The AT&T Corporation and Stet S.p.A., Italy's state phone company, plan to announce an alliance today to offer phone and data services to companies worldwide. Stet, which has been in talks since early this year with AT&T, confirmed yesterday that it would outline the accord today. While Stet declined to be more specific, analysts said an alliance could include a stake by Stet in AT&T's Unisource venture with the telephone companies of the Netherlands, Switzerland and Sweden. An alliance would be Stet's first big partnership with a large international phone company and is seen as a key to the Italian government's plan to sell its controlling stake in October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONG, WOODBRIDGE

Husband of Julie DeViry Strong. Father of Alan, Harmon, Timothy and Benjamin Strong. Brother of Robert L and Philip L Strong. Also survived by 5 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. title: IRI of Italy to Get $2.2 Billion Credit
description: Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, the Italian state holding company, said yesterday that it would receive a credit of 3.875 trillion lire ($2.2 billion) from the Treasury for ceding its 61.3 percent stake in Stet S.p.A., the Italian state telecommunications company. IRI said the credit would lower its debts to the level set in an agreement with the European Union.

title: Sexual Issues Fan Parents' Fears
description: PARENTS always worry about sexual experimentation in adolescents, and that concern has come to the surface recently with publicity about girls' private secondary schools in New York City where some students have announced that they are lesbians.

title: Hotel Sales Are Completed
description: The American General Hospitality Corporation has acquired three hotels in Texas and Florida for $125 million. The three hotels are the Marriott Galleria/West Loop Hotel in Houston; the Radisson Twin Towers Hotel in Orlando, Fla., and the Hilton Oceanfront Hotel in Cocoa Beach, Fla. The purchase gives the Dallas-based real estate investment trust 25 hotels, closer to its goal of owning 30 full-service hotels by the end of the year.

title: An Exception For Battered Women
description: Violent offenders have not been allowed to participate in New York's prison work-release program since 1995, when Gov. George Pataki decided that too many violent criminals were committing new crimes while on furlough. Mr. Pataki was right to rein in the program, but his decision to exclude all those defined as violent offenders was too broad.

title: The Prom, Proper as a Corsage
description: Today the phrase ''senior prom'' is bound to bring to mind teen-age mothers and dead babies. Melissa Drexler, the New Jersey high school senior who gave birth at her prom and has been accused of killing the infant there, has been such a constant subject on news programs lately that she becomes a shadowy, disturbing presence hovering over ''The Senior Prom,'' a perky documentary that follows two groups of students from the fall through prom night. This special was started long before the Drexler case entered the news, and ignores any hint of such teen-age anguish. Still, ''Senior Prom'' comes across as an unconvincing good-news rebuttal.

title: BELL SOUTH AGREES TO DROP STAKE IN AUSTRALIAN COMPANY
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 24.5 percent stake in Optus Communications Pty. of Australia to Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for $735 million. BellSouth, a telecommunications company based in Atlanta, said it expected to post an extraordinary gain in the third quarter, ending on Sept. 30, as a result of the Optus sale. It also said Cable and Wireless would transfer to BellSouth its 22.3 percent interest in the Colombian cellular company Occidente y Caribe Celular S.A. BellSouth's stock rose 81.25 cents, to $47.1875.

title: PHILIP MORRIS'S KRAFT UNIT SELLS ITS SYRUP BUSINESS
description: The Philip Morris Companies' Kraft Foods unit has sold its Log Cabin syrup business to Aurora Foods Inc. for $220 million in cash. The sale, which was completed on Tuesday, includes Log Cabin maple-flavored syrup, the Country Kitchen retail brand and the Wigwam food service brand. The closely held Aurora Foods, formerly known as MBW Foods, also owns the Mrs. Butterworth's brand. The company, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, was formed in 1996 to make acquisitions in the grocery products business.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY TO ACQUIRE REST OF QUINTA
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the remaining part of the Quinta Corporation that it does not own for as much as $325 million. Seagate, the world's largest independent maker of disk drives, will pay $230 million in cash for the closely held Quinta, which develops technology that enhances the performance of computer disk drives. Quinta could get as much as $95 million more if it meets development goals. Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., will take a charge of $180 million to $215 million for Quinta's research on its technique to use lenses and lasers to help write, read and track data on the storage devices. Seagate already owns a minority stake in Quinta, which is based in San Jose, Calif. Seagate's shares rose $1.875, to $36.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Spaceships? No, Just Chandeliers
description: SPARKLING chandeliers, like upside-down wedding cakes, on Fifth Avenue? A brick bench shaped like a curved sofa? These visions of what New York City could look like are on display in two exhibitions at the Municipal Art Society of New York. ''A Long Look at Fifth Avenue,'' which runs through Sept. 8, shows ideas for improving Fifth Avenue from Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village to 143d Street in Harlem. ''Fifth Avenue is an episodic street, and the chandeliers are for the fashion retail district,'' from Lord & Taylor to Bergdorf Goodman, said Ken Smith, a landscape architect in Manhattan, who collaborated with Alice Adams, a sculptor from the Bronx, on the design, shown at left.

title: Restaurant Adds Elbowroom
description: THE Union Pacific restaurant (111 East 22d Street) will open this month on a site once occupied by C. T., Claude Troisgros's restaurant, which closed last year. ''C.T. was long and narrow, and we've tried to give the space width and breadth and to make every seat a good seat, not just the ones under the skylight,'' said Larry Bogdanow, the Manhattan architect who designed Union Pacific with his partner, Warren Ashworth. Among Union Pacific's Pan-Asian references: a gently arched bridge, leading to the dining room, over a shallow pond filled with water that trickles from above. The restaurant's dining room is washed by light diffused through a white-on-white gauzy cotton, which, inserted between wood and steel trusses, hides the skylight. The owners -- Steve Scher, Jeff Kadish and Paul Zweben -- are also partners in Main Street and Rain, two Upper West Side restaurants; the chef is Rocco DiSpirito.

FPA Medical shares jumped $2, to $25.875, in Nasdaq trading.

A detailed report from the Manhattan District Attorney shows that Officer Pellegrini had reason to fear for his life and fired his weapon in accordance with both the law and police policy.

The festival was started in 1953, but because there were a handful of summers when it was not held -- the last was 1995, when cutbacks in state support left it unable to meet its budget -- the current series of classical music and jazz concerts is the 39th instead of the 45th.

title: WESTERN RESOURCES WITHDRAWS TENDER OFFER FOR ADT
description: Western Resources Inc. said yesterday that it was withdrawing its tender offer for ADT Ltd. and stands to gain $710 million on its ADT shares. Western Resources' 38 million shares of ADT, a home security company in Bermuda, are valued at more than $1.3 billion. Since an initial investment in December 1995, Western Resources has spent $590 million on ADT shares. Western, a utility in Kansas City, Mo., made a hostile takeover bid of $22.50 a share for ADT in December. ADT later accepted a friendly offer from Tyco International Ltd. of 0.48 of a share of Tyco stock for each ADT share. Western Resources said it was pursuing legal action in Bermuda that would allow it to receive cash for its ADT shares instead of stock. ADT's shares closed up $2.50, at $36.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: How the Absence of Limits May Itself Be a Limitation
description: In most of the Western world, electronic music has become the realm of composers at the edges of regular musical life: professors, commercial musicians and amateurs. In Paris, though, the Institute of Musical-Acoustical Research and Coordination still pursues the grand ideal proposed by its founder, Pierre Boulez, more than 20 years ago. Its concern is with art. It therefore accepts a responsibility to present its output of electronic works publicly, both through concerts and through recordings, and to train fresh generations of composers and technicians. Hence, the annual Summer Academy, of which the latest took place in the last week of June. Two old institute hands from abroad, Magnus Lindberg of Finland and Ivan Fedele of Italy, were there to give composition classes, and six concerts displayed a fair range of possibilities.

title: Riga Ghetto Survivors Await A Book They Can Embrace
description: Lore Oppenheimer was 15 in December 1941 when the Nazis rousted her family and other Jews from their homes in Hanover, Germany, and put them on trains to Riga, Latvia. The ghetto that awaited them had been hastily cleared: thousands of Latvian Jews had been massacred to make room. ''There was still food on some of the tables,'' Mrs. Oppenheimer recalled. ''In our house we knew they had been Jews because we found Hanukkah candles.''

title: Blessings Of Design In Public Housing
description: ''GOOD design can help create good low-income housing,'' said Blair Kamin, the architecture critic of The Chicago Tribune. Mr. Kamin and The Tribune photographer Bill Hogan visited 25 public housing projects in eight cities in 1994 and 1995. Their findings, including 100 images, are on exhibit in ''Sheltered by Design,'' at the National Building Museum in Washington, through Aug. 17.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANTOR, B. GERALD
description: CANTOR-B. Gerald. Bernie darling, a year has passed. Your legacy lives on. I love you and I miss our precious moments together. You will always be in my heart and never forgotten. Iris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROBERT S.
description: SCHWARTZ-Robert S., of New York City, died on June 28, 1997 at age 69 due to complications following heart surgery after a long and valiant struggle. Devoted husband of Mary. Father of David and Matthew. Beloved family man, grandfather of three and friend to all. He leaves a large hole in the lives of everyone he knew. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the Zoot Sims Scholarship Fund at The New School 66 West 12th Street, New York, NY would be appreciated. Services were private and a Memorial service will be held at a later date. J.S. Waterman & Sons-EastmanWaring Funeral Service, Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Hospital Change Is Opposed
description: A coalition of nurses, health care advocates and families of patients at Bergen Pines Hospital said yesterday that handing over management of the state's largest public hospital to a private company would threaten the quality of care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONZEN, SHIRLEY O'NEILL
description: CONZEN-Shirley O'Neill, 62, died of cancer July 1, 1997 in Lynchburg, Virginia. A graduate of the University of Vermont and Columbia Law School. She had a distinguished career in law as an attorney specializing in estates and trusts. First with the firm of Sullivan and Cromwell in New York and later with Riker, Danzig, Scherer, Hyland and Perretti of Morristown, New Jersey where she was made a partner. She retired from the Riker, Danzig in 1990. She was a member of and vice chairman of the Supreme Court of New Jersey Disciplinary Review Board from 1981 to 1991. A resident of Montclair and Verona, New Jersey for many years. She was a former trustee of the Montclair Art Museum. Born January 25, 1935 in Rutland, Vermont. Her parents were Vincent Joseph O'Neill and Gertrude Mayhew O'Neill. She is survived by her husband Willibalb H. Conzen of Lynchburg, Virginia and her stepdaughters Elizabeth Conzen Zellner of Lynchburg and Suzanne D. Conzen of Chicago. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Columbia University. Memorial donations may be directed to the George Adams Ellis Scholarship Fund at Columbia Law School, Box A2, 435 West 116 Street, New York, New York 10027.

title: Parking Rules Changed To Be Less Complicated
description: New York City transportation officials announced plans yesterday to standardize the rules on when alternate-side-of-the-street parking is suspended, hoping to end some of the confusion that has resulted in countless tickets for New Yorkers.

title: Giuliani Proposes Requiring Prompt and Public Reports From Lobbyists
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would present legislation to the City Council to strengthen disclosure rules for lobbyists in New York City, requiring them to file prompt and detailed reports about their activities. The reports would then be quickly posted on the city's Internet site.

title: Gold Price Sinks as the Fed Stands Pat on Interest Rates
description: Gold fell to its lowest price on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange in more than four years yesterday after Federal Reserve policy makers left United States interest rates unchanged.

title: New Yorkers Need a Constitutional Convention
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, EPHRAIM ARYEH LEIBESH
description: KATZ-Ephraim Aryeh Leibesh. The Orthodox Union is deeply saddened by the passing of the father of Marcos D. (and Adina) Katz, Chairman of our Board of Governors. Mr. Katz was a leader in the international Jewish community and a true baal tzedakah. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the Katz family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mandell I. Ganchrow, M.D. President Rabbi Raphael B. Butler Executive Vice President Marcel Weber, Chairman of the Board of Directors

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHARLES F. C. RUFF, who is the White House counsel, is normally preoccupied with issues like the Whitewater investigation and campaign finance these days. But he will put all that aside on Sunday when his daughter CHRISTY RUFF, 28, is married to NATHANIEL WAGNER, 27, at the Audubon Society in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: WEYERHAEUSER BUYS WOOD PRODUCTS UNIT IN NEW ZEALAND
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it had bought a unit of Fletcher Challenge Ltd. of New Zealand for $190 million. The Fletcher unit, Tasman Forestry (Nelson) Ltd., owned 51 percent of an existing joint venture that holds 193,000 acres of lumber on the northern end of the South Island. Weyerhaeuser, now the 51 percent partner in the joint venture, is responsible for management and marketing. The remaining interest is still held by RII New Zealand Forests I, a unit of Union Bank of Switzerland. Weyerhaeuser is a forest products company based in Tacoma, Wash.

title: Molinari Says He Has Cancer of Prostate
description: Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, said yesterday that he was suffering from prostate cancer. Mr. Molinari, 67, said he was informed by his doctors on Monday of the presence of cancer and that he was undergoing tests to determine the prognosis and treatment.

title: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
description: After considering evidence that growth is slowing from its torrid pace early in the year, the Federal Reserve decided today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy could continue to enjoy low unemployment without inflation.

title: Court Approves Original Panel for Implant Case
description: A Federal judge in Detroit has overturned a ruling in the Dow Corning bankruptcy case that had threatened to unravel months of negotiations by requiring the appointment of a new committee to negotiate on behalf of women claiming damages for injuries from the company's silicone breast implants.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WASHINGTON MUTUAL INC., Seattle, completed its merger with Great Western Financial Corp., of Chatsworth, Calif., creating the nation's largest savings and loan.

title: Campaign Money Pipeline
description: At last we may be getting a clearer map of the pipeline that carried tainted campaign money from Asian businesses to the Clinton re-election effort. The Democrats have conceded that the money was suspect, returning $2.2 million of the nearly $4 million raised by John Huang and Charlie Trie. In a significant story this week, Don Van Natta Jr. and Christopher Drew of The Times reported that investigators are looking at $470,000 in money transfers to Mr. Trie from an account in Macao. The money came in just as Mr. Trie was showing up at campaign offices with envelopes of money, some from donors who cannot now be found.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: The Sunflower Defense

title: Sampras Survives in Five Sets; Krajicek Dethroned by a Briton
description: Wimbledon lost its defending champion today, but nobody except Richard Krajicek seemed sorry to see Richard Krajicek flounder in the Round of 16. That is because the David who sent this particular Goliath packing was Tim Henman, the cowlick kid whose quest to become Britain's first male champion since 1936 has an entire nation galvanized.

title: Custody Trial Opens in Case Of Adopted Girls Hit on Plane
description: Testimony began yesterday in Family Court in Queens in the custody trial of an Arizona couple who are accused of beating their newly adopted children on a flight from Moscow to New York City last May.

title: Maddux Makes Quick Work Of the Yankees
description: The Yankees shuffled to the plate with trepidation against Greg Maddux, the perfectionist in a gray uniform, and were embarrassed, mesmerized and baffled. Batter after batter trudged back to the sullen dugout, passed the next victim and mumbled scant advice: try to hit it to the outfield, they whispered, or maybe just try to hit it.

title: Japan Battles Huge Oil Spill Off Tokyo With 130 Ships
description: Japan mobilized more than 130 ships today to battle a major oil spill from a tanker that ran aground in Tokyo Bay on Wednesday, spreading a huge slick through the heavily traveled waterway and sending fumes into Tokyo and its suburbs.

title: Blair Gains Tax Cut for Business, But the Rest of Britain Must Wait
description: The new Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair gained passage of its first budget in Parliament today, giving top priority to a tax cut that will give British big business the lowest tax rate of any Western industrial country.

title: Latest Defense: The Sitcom Made Me Do It
description: If you haven't been watching Court TV over the last week or so, you've been missing a real-life sitcom that begins and ends with a television show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARISH, IRIS
description: BARISH-Iris. The Congregation of the Malverne Jewish Center mourns the passing of our dear member Iris Barish. Sincerest condolences to her husband Phil, her children, and grandchildren. Barry J. Chesler, Rabbi Murray Greenspan, President

title: CRESTAR TO ACQUIRE RIVAL CANADIAN OIL AND GAS CONCERN
description: Crestar Energy Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Grad & Walker Energy Corporation, a rival Canadian oil and gas producer, for $336.2 million (Canadian), or $243.6 million (United States). Crestar said it would pay $13.5 (Canadian) in cash or 0.509 of a Crestar share for each Grad & Walker common share. A maximum of five million Crestar shares will be available for the transaction. The offer will be contingent on holders of at least two-thirds of the Grad & Walker shares supporting the acquisition. Both companies are based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Sharpton Goes to Washington To Urge Rights Case in Killing
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton flew to Washington yesterday and delivered a letter addressed to Attorney General Janet Reno from the family of Kevin Cedeno, formally requesting that the Federal Government determine if the teen-ager's civil rights were violated when he was shot to death by a New York City police officer in April in Washington Heights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASS, PAULINE (NEE BENOWITZ)
description: KASS-Pauline (nee Benowitz). Wife of the late Sam. Mother of Charlotte Levine and Audrey Stone. Sister of Betty Waldman. Grandmother of Bruce, Alan and Lawrence Levine, Marc & Susan Stone. Great-grandma of Daniel, Joanna & Russell Levine. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, New Jersey, Thursday 1 PM.

title: Art and Tax Breaks
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia College Dean Is Forced to Resign
description: The dean of Columbia College, who heads the university's undergraduate school, has been forced to resign, apparently in a struggle over the college's future direction. The situation, however, remained in flux yesterday as the dean continued to meet with the university president, George E. Rupp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, REGINALD LEE
description: JOHNSON-Reginald Lee of Riverdale, NY on July 1, 1997. Beloved father of Dorothy Truscott and William Johnson, and adored by his six grandchildren and 16 greatgrandchildren. Retired Vice President Johns Manville Corp. Services 10 AM Tuesday, Christ Church, 252 Street & Henry Hudson Pkwy., Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Adirondack Nature Conservancy, Main St, Keene Valley, N.Y. 12943 appreciated.

title: Courtship Leads to Marriage And Maybe Officer's Ouster
description: Born on the same day 27 years ago, Rhonda and William R. Kite Jr. believe that fate brought them together.

title: Sad Tale of Motherhood, to Prod Church Fathers
description: Few issues are as politically delicate in Poland as abortion, so when a distinguished writer wrote an impassioned short story that criticized the Pope's abortion stance, it was bound to cause a stir.

title: East and West In Wet Meeting
description: A CHINESE temple can also be a pool house, as shown above, on an estate in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. ''We call it Bauhaus meets Mao-house,'' said Peter Levenson, a partner at Kibel Levenson Jagger, an architectural firm in Manhattan, which designed the cabana. From the front, the 400-square-foot pavilion looks Chinese, with green glazed roof tiles and red lacquered columns. Its interior and rear are Western in style, with the shower situated within an opaque curved glass brick wall. The pavilion, which includes two changing rooms and two bathrooms, glows at night from within (via the glass brick) and from without (copper lanterns are hung on each column). The stucco, teak and mahogany pool house was completed last autumn. Mr. Levenson declined to reveal the names of the owners, nor would he divulge the cost.

title: INSIDE
description: Inhalers Tied to Cataracts

title: Stymied, SBC Seeks to Void Portion of Law
description: One week after being rebuffed from entering the long-distance telephone business, SBC Communications Inc. sued the Government yesterday seeking to overturn a critical provision of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, ERNA
description: LANDAU-Erna. The Hebrew Academy of Long Beach notes with profound sorrow the passing of Erna Landau, Eshet Hayil, P.E. Wife and helpmate of Emil Landau, A.H., founding Chairman of the Board of Directors and elder statesman of HALB during its formative years. May the Almighty console the bereaved family among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Dr. Armin H. Friedman, Dean Emeritus Rabbi Dr. Heshy T. Glass, Principal Jerry Williams, President Rabbi Zvi H. Friedman, Exec. Dir.

title: New Hong Kong Chief's Top Priority: Affordable Housing
description: As he settled into his job as Hong Kong's new Chief Executive today, Tung Chee-hwa made clear where his priority lies: real estate.

title: Calendar: Tours Into History
description: Late, Late Walk

title: Turmoil and Opportunity in Israel
description: Little over a year has passed since Benjamin Netanyahu became Israel's Prime Minister, but it must seem like a decade to him. The uneasy peace between Israel and the Palestinians has been ruptured, repaired and ruptured again. Now Mr. Netanyahu is struggling to hold together a divided Cabinet and parliamentary majority. It would be a service to his country if Mr. Netanyahu ended the turmoil.

title: Who Doesn't Love a Parade? Some of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: A Portrait Found in the Trash And the Hopes It Aroused
description: You never know what you might turn up in New York City's trash. On a wintry day in February, when John W. Nichols discovered a discarded painting sticking out of a pile of trash bags in front of 55 East 65th Street, a few doors from his office, his thoughts ran immediately to its potential value, either in the market or to a museum. So far, all the painting has provided is a bit of an education about the art world.

title: German Effort On Digital TV Moves Ahead
description: Germany's troubled efforts to introduce digital television received an important boost today, as the nation's dominant cable provider and the two biggest German entertainment companies agreed to end years of feuding and support a common system.

title: Connors Nearly Ready to Play
description: JIMMY CONNORS, who had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee six weeks ago, will return to tennis July 14 against GUILLERMO VILAS of Argentina. The exhibition match in Mahwah, N.J., will precede the A&P Tennis Classic, a women's tournament scheduled for July 15-20 at the same complex. Connors, 44, and Vilas, 45, are regulars on the Nuveen senior tour.

title: Sell Suicide Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Francis Byrnes, 79, Influential Expert on Russia
description: Robert Francis Byrnes, a professor emeritus of history at Indiana University who founded and directed the Russian and East European Institute, died on June 19 at the Columbia Brunswick Hospital in Ocean Isle, N.C. He was 79 and lived in Bloomington, Ind.

title: Cars, Loaded With Incentives, Are Most Affordable in Years
description: Car shoppers might not notice it without looking closely at the ads, but the auto industry is in the thick of a price war, with more rebates, cut-rate loans, cheap lease deals and other discounts than ever. And with family incomes rising at a hefty clip, these discounts have made new cars more affordable than they have been in nearly a generation.

title: Asia's Hope for Hong Kong: More Business as Usual
description: For some Asian countries that were once British colonies themselves, the end of Britain's 156-year rule over Hong Kong was a proud moment. And in South Korea, which faces hostile North Korea across a heavily armed border, there was a tinge of envy that China and Hong Kong could be reunited so peacefully.

title: Lobo and Liberty Continue Winning With Defeat of Comets
description: It has been so long since she last lost a game that Rebecca Lobo, the Liberty's 6-foot-4-inch forward, said she was not even aware of the streak. Maybe it's just as well.

title: CINAR FILMS OF CANADA TO BUY SCHOOL SUPPLIES CONCERN
description: Cinar Films Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Carson-Dellosa Publishing Company and its affiliates for $40.5 million. Cinar, a Canadian producer of children's television programming, said it would pay $24.5 million in cash and $16 million in class B subordinated voting shares. Carson-Dellosa, a privately held company based in Greensboro, N.C., sells specialty school supplies and classroom materials, mainly aimed at the elementary school market. Last year, it had $21 million in revenue. Cinar Films had revenue of $57.9 million (Canadian), or $41.9 million (United States), in 1996.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Rally Pushes Some Indexes to Records

title: Bridge
description: As a result of playoffs in Hyannis, Mass., last month, two strong American women's teams will be battling the rest of the world and each other in the World Championships in Tunisia in October. One team -- Marinesa Letizia, Lisa Berkowitz, Tobi Sokolow, Mildred Breed, Randy Montin and Jill Meyers -- has plenty of national experience but relatively little at world level. Meyers, who won the Venice Cup in 1991, is the only one in the group with a world title.

title: Utilities May Bear Brunt Of New Clean Air Rules
description: To judge from the furious reactions of lobbying groups in Washington, much of American industry is overwhelmingly opposed to the new clean air regulations announced last week by the Clinton Administration. Auto makers, truckers, petrochemical producers, utilities and other trade organizations are poised to campaign in Congress and the courts to delay, limit or kill the proposed new rules.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, RICHARD H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Richard H. Your 52nd birthday. You've never left us. You touched the lives of all who knew you. Love you. Mom.

title: Glover Leaves 'Bring In da Noise' Early
description: Savion Glover has left ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk'' two and a half weeks before his scheduled departure. Mr. Glover, who helped create the musical and whose choreography for the show earned a Tony Award in 1996, gave his last performance on Friday after nearly two years with the show.

title: Final Credits
description: This country's sense of identity is so wound up in the movies of the 1930's and 40's that it is hard to accept that the actors who made them are slipping away. James Stewart was the last of the great male stars of Hollywood's golden age, an era when film icons like John Wayne, Henry Fonda, Cary Grant and Spencer Tracy each embodied some cherished aspect of the national self-image. But of them all, Mr. Stewart's persona was closest to what Americans liked to believe Americans were like. He portrayed the regular guy, a part of the community, the scoutmaster or savings and loan president. But he maintained a stubborn, gawky individuality. When the crowd ran wrong, Mr. Stewart's characters were always ready to stand alone for right.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILHELM, KATHRYN E.
description: WILHELM-Kathryn E. 8/10/036/29/97. Wife of the late Harry Wilhelm. Mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, Georgetown native, lover of music, gardening, and the New Jersey shore. Please send any contributions to Historical Society of Washington, D.C.

title: Stocks Surge as Fed Holds Rates Steady
description: Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy could continue to enjoy low unemployment without an acceleration in inflation.

title: False Starts and Failures Thwart Quest for Safe Cigarette
description: When the Philip Morris Companies marketed a cigarette called Next in 1989, it never mentioned what a former company scientist says was an apparent advantage to the product: it had fewer cancer-causing compounds than a typical cigarette.

title: Looking for New Wildernesses to Tame.
description: Living Octagonally for a Change

title: A Bitter End
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Girl Scores an Impressive Victory in the Astoria
description: If that was the champion 2-year-old filly out there at Belmont Park yesterday winning the 91st running of the Astoria, her name is Jersey Girl, she is a husky chestnut granddaughter of the renowned Danzig and she has won two of three starts.

title: Varied Influences Converge In the New Country Music
description: Two different pop traditions come together in the high craft of the Cicadas, a new band formed by the country-music singer and songwriter Rodney Crowell that played at the Bottom Line on Monday night. Mr. Crowell's new songs lead back to the Band and the Byrds, those summations and storehouses of Americana sounds. But at the same time they show a deep influence of the crisply written English pop made by Squeeze and Elvis Costello.

title: A Mansion Not Ready for Prime Time
description: When your attic has 20,000 square feet of floor space and 13-foot ceilings, you naturally don't want the roof to leak. After all, the bowling alley, the doll museum and the gift-wrapping room might get wet. So what's a homeowner to do? Sue the contractor, of course.

title: The Thai Gamble: Devaluing Currency to Revive Economy
description: The central bank of Thailand's decision yesterday to devalue the currency, which caused it to tumble as much as 20 percent against the dollar, represents a gamble by Thai policy makers to shore up the country's faltering economy.

title: Officials Reopen Beaches on Sound in Westchester That Were Closed After Spill
description: Beaches on Long Island Sound in Westchester County were reopened yesterday after county health officials determined that the water was no longer contaminated by the remnants of a sewage spill in the Bronx.

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, as the Federal Reserve opted to keep monetary policy unchanged and more economic data pointed to a slowing economy, with low inflation.

title: Britain Convicts 6 of Plot to Black Out London
description: Six men, including a former American military explosives specialist, were convicted today of having plotted to black out London and most of southeastern England in a series of bombings of electrical power stations by the Irish Republican Army a year ago.

title: President of Blood Center Resigns Abruptly
description: The president and chief executive officer of the New York Blood Center, the largest independent blood supplier in the country, resigned yesterday amid an ongoing Federal investigation at the center.

title: Library's Storied Sanctuary Will Be Shut For Next 2 Years For High-Tech Renovations
description: It is a great room, a grandiose room, the largest uncolumned space in New York City, not to mention the gateway to a vast underground store of knowledge, and since 1911 it has been open to anyone -- anyone with a yen to read, to carry out a secret (silent) liaison, to pursue an intellectual obsession, to come in out of the cold (or the heat), to grab a furtive nap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALL, RAE
description: PALL-Rae. In her 102nd year. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Devoted mother of Arthur, Arnold & David. Cherished grandmother. Dear sister of Fannie Gittleman. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Ave (at Prospect Park)Bklyn, Sun 12 noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, ERNA
description: LANDAU-Erna. The Jerusalem College of Technology-Machon Lev family extends its sincere sympathy to Hannah and Edward Low, cousin of our Founder and first president, Professor Zeev Lev, and to their entire extended family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Yosef Bodenheimer, President Eli Hoffman, President AFJCT Jonathan Feldstein, Executive Director

title: From Taiwan, a Blend More Asian Than Western
description: The return of Hong Kong to China this week, for better or worse, closes a chapter in modern Asian history. But the fate of another contested entity, Taiwan, still lies in the balance. That island nation, with its distinctive dialects and customs, is considered by many to be a part of China but has maintained its independence since 1949. And because it has long been one of Asia's capitalist superstars, Western influence is strong.

title: Conducting A Search For Origins Of 'One Fare'
description: New York's two leading elected officials -- who know enough to stay away from trouble -- are never seen on the city's buses and overcrowded subways, but as city transit takes its biggest economic leap forward in 50 years this week, both of them have stepped forward to accept the public's gratitude for the long-anticipated introduction of free transfers.

description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon:

description: LUNZER - Shoshana B. (nee Skidelsky), July 2, 1997. Beloved wife of Julius Peter. Loving mother of Benjamin, Jay, Francesca & David. Cherished grandmother, dear sister. Services were held. Shiva through Wednesday morning, July 9, 1997 at home.

description: To the Editor:

title: BAA of Britain Will Buy Duty Free International
description: BAA P.L.C., seeking to remain competitive in the growing market for duty-free products, said today that it had agreed to buy Duty Free International Inc. of the United States for $674 million.

title: The Ultimate In Pianism Of the Serene
description: More than any other pianist in jazz, Abdullah Ibrahim makes music that is still, calm, deliberate. Along with Duke Ellington's quietest solo or duo work from the early 1950's, it is the ultimate expression of the drawing-room or parlor esthetic in jazz.

title: New Video Releases
description: Vegas Vacation

title: Neither Ballots Nor Bullets Solve Political Puzzle in Albania
description: A gun battle erupted outside the central election commission's office at midday today, and inside, the senior official, appointed by President Sali Berisha, stopped work, two of the latest developments in the President's apparent campaign to thwart formation of a new Socialist Government.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Nick and Toni's is the hippest place in the Hamptons, one of the first restaurants on the East End to understand the power of simplicity. With its menu of fresh food cooked in a wood-burning oven, fine salads and excellent wine list, it quickly became one of those places where it was impossible to get a seat.

title: Inside Art
description: The Getty's 'Richer Mix'

title: Love Is Young Again
description: Yan Chen and Angel Corella united fine dancing with passionate acting when they made their debuts in the leading roles of Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Because they made the doomed lovers likable and believable young people, American Ballet Theater's production became unusually poignant.

title: Taiwan Plans to Drop a Fig Leaf; China May Grumble
description: With the world's eyes focused on Hong Kong, and China on its best behavior, Taiwan appears to be taking advantage of the moment to take a step that could lead to a nasty confrontation with China.

title: Headgear a Must
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying To Sound Like a Hero
description: Sometimes musicians pick odd roles for themselves. Leroy Jones, who is to play at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, Greenwich Village) through Sunday, is from New Orleans, and he plays trumpet and sings. Mr. Jones models himself after Louis Armstrong; he has released an album of songs related to Mr. Armstrong. But he's an unlikely Armstrong. He plays without much volume and has a thin, clear sound. And his ebullience seems to hide an introspective side that might be served by more advanced material.

title: Marlins Put Away Reynoso Early
description: It is a long season, Manager Bobby Valentine quickly pointed out when asked for his thoughts on the recent struggles of the Mets' starting pitchers. But that hopeful reply came before Armando Reynoso matched the shortest start by a Mets pitcher this season in last night's 10-4 loss to the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium.

title: Fireworks on Mars, and Other Dates
description: By accident and design alike, NASA has seen a number of its space spectaculars fall on noteworthy dates.

title: Echoes of the Young Sinatra, but With a Shy Romanticism
description: Tom Postilio, an engaging young cabaret singer from Long Island, has already earned comparisons to the young Frank Sinatra. And it's true that when he punches out a number like Cole Porter's ''At Long Last Love,'' his carefully syncopated phrasing and exuberance suggest a softened echo of the late-50's Sinatra in his swinging mode.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFA, HOWARD W.C.
description: YAFFA-Howard W.C., Major USA ret, died June 28 at Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Formerly of Nyack, NY and New Canaan, CT. Survived by loving wife Eunice, children William and Lynne, grandchildren, nieces, nephews, stepchildren. Brother of Lawrence Yaffa, Alpine, NJ.

title: Ordeal of a Champion
description: For 24 years Mary Decker Slaney has been America's best female distance runner. In the course of her career she has undergone at least 20 surgeries on her legs and, at age 38, recently began a comeback. For 24 years Slaney has always tested clean of drugs.

title: Lender Loses Fraud Appeal
description: Lending institutions can be held liable for violations of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: A Swan Song: Becker Waves Goodbye to Center Court
description: The king of these lawns is gone.

title: A Chance to Survive
description: Michael Molloy, a 29-year-old advertising salesman from Allentown, Pa., is a gravely ill patient at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Mr. Molloy was diagnosed with melanoma in August 1995. The disease has spread relentlessly since then, advancing to his lungs and most recently to his brain. The situation is desperate. With standard treatment, Mr. Molloy might survive another four or five months. With luck, maybe until Christmas.

title: 645 Modular Houses Going Up in Brooklyn
description: Over the next three years, 645 homes for low- and moderate-income families will go up for 25 blocks west of Pennsylvania Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. But instead of being constructed using traditional techniques, they are being manufactured in a factory five miles away and assembled at the construction site.

title: Annie Fratellini, 64, Clown And Founder of School, Dies
description: Annie Fratellini, who wiggled, waddled and waltzed through big tops in Europe before she opened a college for aspiring circus performers who wanted to follow in her outsized, floppy footsteps, died on Tuesday in Paris. She was 64.

title: Free From Toil and Braving Traffic
description: The Fourth of July weekend began yesterday not with the bang of fireworks but with the unheard, unofficial starter's gun that sent thousands upon thousands of people rushing out of offices and brokerage houses with visions of sun-washed beaches, emerald golf courses and succulent barbecues dancing in their heads.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawyer For Accused Teen-Ager
description: A Delaware judge yesterday dismissed the lawyer for the New Jersey teen-ager charged with murdering her newborn son at a Delaware motel last November because he made comments about the case on ABC's ''20/20'' show, including an assertion that she was innocent.

title: Central Park Killer Disciplined in Drug Case
description: A prison disciplinary board placed Robert E. Chambers Jr. in nearly round-the-clock confinement yesterday after guards found heroin in his cell, prison officials said.

title: Laughing In Beijing
description: How delightful it must be these days to be a member of the Chinese Communist Politburo! Every time they get together they must laugh and laugh and laugh.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about President Clinton's capital gains tax proposal misstated the potential impact it would have on some wealthy taxpayers. Some taxpayers could receive no cut at all in capital gains taxes, but it would not cause anyone to pay more taxes.

title: No Headline
description: ''I love the cast of characters. The people who show up every day, they're like an extended family, people you see only at a wedding. The lady who reads the newspaper but can only concentrate if she's got something -- a nose plug, or a disconnected electric plug -- stuck into her ear or her nose. I call her the orifice lady. Or another guy who brings out this stack of books, these arcane philosophy books, and sets them down and promptly falls asleep.''

title: Clinton Adamant: 3 New NATO Members Now
description: As he prepared for next week's NATO summit meeting in Madrid, President Clinton today reaffirmed his intention to limit the first round of NATO expansion to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic and suggested that the alliance's position on additional members could be examined in 1999.

title: 13 Injured When Subway Car Derails in Harlem
description: The rear car of a southbound A train derailed in a subway tunnel in Harlem last night as the train passed through the 135th Street station at St. Nicholas Avenue, injuring 13 people, knocking over support pillars in the station and twisting the rear car into a jumbled wreck of sheared metal, police and fire officials said.

title: Ford Might Build New Asia Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company and its Japanese affiliate, the Mazda Motor Corporation, may set up a new Asian auto plant, expanding their production in the region, company officials said today.

title: A Man, a Plan, Water: Manipulating the World
description: Grand visions and base motives; engineering feats and political shenanigans; prosperity for some, ruin for others; the creation of a great city at the expense of small communities; human drive and nature's revenge. Such are some of the elements flowing through ''Cadillac Desert: Water and the Transformation of Nature,'' a four-part account on PBS about the coming of water in America's parched West and how it changed everything.

title: Cordero Told of Suspension
description: Wil Cordero, who has been kept out of 16 of Boston's last 22 games because of allegations of domestic violence, learned yesterday that he apparently has been suspended for half of those missed games.

title: Spacecraft Lands Today On the Planet of Dreams
description: For the first time in 21 years, a spacecraft from Earth is about to land on Mars, largely because human beings hope they are not alone.

title: Swiss Freeze the Assets of Four Argentines Accused in Spain
description: Switzerland has agreed to freeze the bank accounts and other assets of four Argentine military officers who have been charged in Spain with responsibility for the secret kidnapping and killing of Spanish nationals during the repression of leftist insurgents in Argentina in the 1970's.

title: Lukas Bounces Back As Time Limit Wins
description: After winning seven of eight Triple Crown races over a three-year run of record-breaking success, D. Wayne Lukas was shut out of the spring classics this year. But the trainer may have started the road back yesterday when his 2-year-old colt Time Limit won the Tremont at Belmont Park and was projected as a contender for the Kentucky Derby next year.

title: Art in Review
description: Lynda Grimm

title: Peso Crisis Bites Into Mexico's Long-Ruling Party
description: Teresa Lasso, who owns a beauty parlor and is married to a veterinarian, intends to vote for a leftist candidate when Mexico elects a new Congress on July 6. To explain why, she grabs a pencil to scribble the disturbing arithmetic of their $79,000 bank loan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEROSA, CARL JOHN
description: GEROSA-Carl John of New Rochelle, NY. On July 2, 1997. Husband of Joan L. Brennan Gerosa and the late Yola R. Gerosa. Father of Carl J., Jr., Patricia Margotta, Robert S., and the late John L. Gerosa. Brother of Emelia Colaneri, Margaret San Fan Andre, Francis X. and the late John J. Gerosa. Grandfather of 13. Great grandfather of 3. Also survived by two step-daughtersand five stepgrandchildren. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 7-9PM Thursday and 2-4 & 7-9, Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, Holy Family Church, New Rochelle, Saturday July 5 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, Tuckahoe, New York.

title: New York Skyscrapers As Ancient Temples
description: IMAGINE the death of Manhattan. It is far off, perhaps a millennium distant. The center of gravity has shifted away from this queer and querulous lozenge of real estate and settled in another part of the world, a cyberworld maybe, maybe a world still unimagined -- or unimaginable. Time and wind and water have ravaged the natural and the man-made alike, and the city's familiar face has eroded in some places to the skeleton underneath. Manhattan strikes the future observer the way ancient Athens or ancient Rome strikes us now -- as fragmentary, enigmatic, a memento mori at once powerful and poignant.

title: Web Sites Set to Transmit Images From Mars After a Craft's Landing Today
description: If all systems are go when the Pathfinder spacecraft comes to rest on the surface of Mars today and begins sending back images, millions of people will be able to watch what is happening live on the suddenly interplanetary World Wide Web.

title: With the Old Hatreds, Ulster Faces New Marching Season
description: The sashes and tassels and epaulets and deep-throated bass drums are moving off the shelves of Victor Stewart Regalia and Band Uniform Manufacturers faster than the owner of the store in this County Armagh town can ever remember. In most places this brisk commerce would carry the tuneful promise of fun and festivity.

description: HERZBERG-Maurice. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of Maurice Herzberg, father of Harriet Weissman and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Judith Schindler, Assoc. Rabbi

title: Yankees Near Trade Of Duncan And Rogers
description: The Yankees are on the verge of dealing two of George Steinbrenner's favorite whipping boys -- Kenny Rogers and Mariano Duncan -- to the Padres for the power-hitting outfielder Greg Vaughn and a minor leaguer, a person familiar with the trade talks in San Diego said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANNING, E. WILSON (BILL)
description: LANNING-E. Wilson (Bill). Age 80 of Chestertown, NY. Survived by 8 of his 9 children, including Mary Lanning of NYC. Memorial contributions to Adirondack Tri-County Healthcare Center, North Creek, NY 12853. Visiting hours Saturday & Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., BartonMcDermott Funeral Home, 9 Pine Street, Chestertown, New York.

title: Craft to Mars Closes In On History
description: An American robotic spacecraft, Mars Pathfinder, gathered speed today as it came under the power of Martian gravity and closed in for a landing on the planet on Friday, the first in more than two decades and the opening of what is being called the second era of Mars exploration.

title: Lab Cancels Beagle Tests
description: A drug laboratory declined yesterday to turn over 36 beagles to Kim Basinger, the actress and animal rights advocate, who had initiated a highly publicized effort to adopt them. But Alan Staple, the president of the laboratory, Huntington Life Sciences, of Franklin Township, announced that the medical tests -- in which the dogs' legs were to be broken -- have been canceled by Yamanouchi U.S.A. Inc., the drug company, and said the dogs would eventually be given up for adoption. Ms. Basinger said in a statement that she was disappointed but would continue to fight for the dogs' release.

title: Bunzl of Britain To Buy Filtrona
description: The British paper and plastics maker Bunzl P.L.C. has agreed to buy the American Filtrona Corporation, a maker of bonded fibers and plastics, for $46.52 a share, or $178 million.

title: Testimony Implicating Gigante Is Called Hearsay
description: A lawyer for Vincent Gigante, the reputed Mafia boss, sought yesterday to convince a jury that a former top mobster who had implicated Mr. Gigante in murders was just repeating unreliable gangster hearsay.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a French decision to bow to President Clinton's wish to limit the initial phase of NATO expansion to Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary misstated the source of the information. The decision was described by French officials who spoke on condition of anonymity, not announced in a French Government statement issued on Wednesday.

title: Body Is Found in Park; May Be a Missing Girl's
description: Police detectives found a badly decomposed body in Seton Falls Park in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, and investigators said it may be that of a girl who was reported missing by her mother earlier this week.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Trockadero and Trinity Replace Feld at Joyce
description: The Joyce Theater has announced that Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo and the Trinity Irish Dance Company will perform during two weeks in August originally booked by Eliot Feld's Ballet Tech company for its annual summer preview season. The Trockadero will appear from Aug. 4 to 9. The Chicago-based Trinity company will present ''A Celtic Odyssey'' from Aug. 11 to 16. Information: (212) 242-0800.

title: Sacramento and Charity End Homeless Aid Battle
description: Settling an embarrassing legal squabble, the City of Sacramento, Calif., and a local Roman Catholic charity have agreed to drop their lawsuits against each other and form a task force to help resolve the dispute.

title: Gold Plunges as Central Bank In Australia Sells 167 Tons
description: Gold prices plunged yesterday to an 11 1/2-year low on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange after Australia's central bank said it had sold 167 metric tons from its reserves.

title: Some U.S. Cities Team Up to Attract Overseas Dollars
description: With its many cultural institutions, fine dining, elegant 19th-century architecture and daily nonstop flights to five European cities, Cincinnati would seem to have much of what it takes to become a prime destination for international tourists -- a record 46.3 million of whom visited the United States last year.

title: A Good Day For U.S. Crews
description: On a wet and blustery day on the River Thames, American entrants competed in nine races of the Henley Royal Regatta today. They won seven, lost two and dominated the Diamond Challenge Sculls by placing three scullers in Friday's quarterfinals.

title: Moving to Times Square
description: Tennessee Mountain restaurant, which has been serving barbecue chicken and ribs and smoked meats on Spring Street in SoHo for 16 years, is opening a branch in the Times Square area later this year.

title: Eurotunnel Shares Rise on Rosy Prediction
description: The shares of Eurotunnel rose again yesterday after the channel tunnel company's chairman said operating profit this year was exceeding forecasts. In Paris, the shares rose to 7.65 francs, up 1, after touching 7.80, the highest in six months. The shares have surged 25 percent in the last four sessions, helped by expectations that shareholders will approve a plan to restructure its $:8.5 billion ($14 billion) in bank debt. In London, Eurotunnel shares rose a penny, to 77 pence. They have risen 21 percent this week.

title: Using Advice Of Psychic, Police Hunt For a Body
description: Investigators from the New York City Police Department and the F.B.I. have spent the last two days tearing apart a field along the East River in Brooklyn, searching for the body of a police officer's wife who vanished almost four years ago, law enforcement officials said yesterday. They said they were led to the site, in part, by a psychic.

title: You Gotta Believe
description: Since baseball season began April 1, the performances of the Dow Jones industrial average and the New York Mets have looked eerily similar, on graph paper anyway. Coincidence?

title: A Spaniard Who Has Carved a Niche Beyond Modern and Minimal
description: CRISTINA IGLESIAS, a sculptor from the Basque region of Spain, is making her New York City debut on a very big stage: the upper regions of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Perhaps this is as it should be. Although Ms. Iglesias has never had a solo show here, she has already had, at the age of 41, nearly 30 solo shows in Europe and elsewhere (including Greece, Canada and Seattle). Among those were exhibitions at important museums in Amsterdam, Dusseldorf, Germany, and Bordeaux, France, as well as in the Venice Biennale, where she represented Spain in 1993.

description: Agnes Denes

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed. Most foreign markets, however, will be open.

title: In a Quest for New Voters, Politicians Fight the I.N.S.
description: A Federal immigration agency said it wanted to stay so far away from politics that it ended voter registration at naturalization ceremonies in the New York district, but it reversed course yesterday after politicians called.

title: Days and Nights With Fireworks, and More
description: Events from outdoor Shakespeare to indoor Sousa are planned this weekend in celebration of Independence Day. A sampling in the three-state metropolitan region follows. Unless noted, events are free.

title: The Latest Battle of Gettysburg
description: When Abraham Lincoln said of Gettysburg that ''the brave men, living and dead, who struggled here, have consecrated it, far above our poor power to add or detract,'' he did not reckon on the power of 20th-century developers.

title: Report Links Brain Disease To an Illness Found in Cows
description: A study conducted at the Yale Medical School lends new support to the theory that the mysterious agent that causes mad cow disease is also capable of causing a deadly brain disease in people.

title: Keep in Mind
description: INDEPENDENCE DAY AT SUNNYSIDE, recreating July 4, 1855, at the former home of Washington Irving. With period music and dancing, political speeches, a slack-rope walker and juggler and a pie-eating contest. Today from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at Sunnyside, West Sunnyside Lane, Tarrytown, N.Y. Admission: Adults, $8; the elderly, $7; children 6 to 17, $4; children 5 and under, free. Information: (914) 591-8763.

title: Running in a Class of His Own
description: Daniel Komen of Kenya, who has emerged as the world's premier distance runner, lives on a strict budget even though he has won a king's ransom in prize money. But when it comes to world records, he's going for broke.

description: There seems to be no end to the good news on Wall Street.

description: For a Brooklynite and a maker of very small black-and-white movies, he certainly kicked up a stir in international film circles. ''Our New Wave would never have come into being if it hadn't been for the young American Morris Engel, who showed us the way to independent production with his fine movie 'Little Fugitive,' '' Francois Truffaut reflected years ago.

title: American Images In a Grand Parade
description: NOTHING beats cleaning out your closets to make unexpected discoveries. And when the Brooklyn Museum of Art burrowed deep in its American paintings storerooms not long ago, it came up with pretty good finds.

title: Felix Rutledge, 79; Developed a Cancer Specialty
description: Dr. Felix N. Rutledge, a gynecologic surgeon who is credited with developing the medical specialty dealing with cancer in the female genital tract, died on June 21 at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 79 and lived in Geneva, Tex.

title: Johnny Copeland, 60, Who Sang Texas Blues and Played Guitar
description: Johnny Copeland, one of the foremost Texas blues singers and guitarists of the 70's and 80's, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Congressional efforts to persuade Federal health officials to suspend an investigation into possible fraud at the nation's teaching hospitals misquoted a letter from Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut. The letter said that because of the nature of the investigation, ''inspector misconduct is likely,'' not ''unlikely.''

description: Even here, where shootouts with the police are a fact of life, the tale of Julio Mirabal stands out.

description: ALPERT-Ferd. Past away on June 30th. Beloved husband and best friend of Gladys, father of Sandra Shulak of Scottsdale, Az, Bruce Alpert and Robert Alpert of Houston, Tx, brother of Dr. Joseph Alpert of Savannah, Georgia and grandfather of four.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SEARCH FOR BODY -- With the help of a psychic, the authorities searched for the body of a police officer's wife who vanished in 1993. B3.

title: Patient-Shifting Practices At Center Are Scrutinized
description: Federal prosecutors are investigating charges that doctors at Kings County Hospital Center routinely defrauded the city by diverting insured patients from the public hospital to the state-run University Hospital of Brooklyn across the street, where the doctors could make more money doing the same procedures, the president of the city's public hospitals agency said yesterday.

title: Torstar to Buy Children's Books Unit
description: The Torstar Corporation of Canada will buy Troll Communications, a publisher and distributor of children's books and other educational materials, including a 49 percent stake held by Pearson P.L.C.

description: Morris Graves

title: Sun Life of Canada Settles Policyholder Suit
description: The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada said today that it would pay $65 million (Canadian), or $47 million (United States), to settle a class-action lawsuit involving 400,000 holders of its life insurance policies.

title: Smaller Slick, After All, The Japanese Discover
description: Fears of an environmental and economic disaster from an oil spill in Tokyo Bay receded somewhat today after the Japanese Government sharply reduced the estimated size of the leakage and cleanup efforts made headway.

title: Jefferson, Real and Imagined
description: There's something unbelievable about ''Thomas Jefferson,'' the icon. He's either a national hero or a national disgrace, a champion of American liberty in all imaginable forms or a hypocrite who refused to free his slaves. Even his accomplishments easily pass into the world of myth. You almost feel sorry for the real-life Thomas Jefferson, except that he helped create ''Thomas Jefferson'' -- and at some cost to us.

title: Police Say Man Killed Runaway, 15, in 3-Way Lover's Quarrel in Brooklyn
description: A 15-year-old runaway who the police said had been trying to persuade her best friend to stop dating a 33-year-old reputed gang member was shot and killed late Wednesday night in Highland Park in Brooklyn. The police arrested the boyfriend early yesterday morning and charged him with her murder.

title: Police Lieutenants Reject a Tentative Pact
description: Rebuffing their union leaders and the Giuliani administration, the members of the union representing New York City's police lieutenants have overwhelmingly rejected a tentative contract -- a move that could complicate the city's standoff with the much larger Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Acting Alone, Mississippi Settles Suit With 4 Tobacco Companies
description: In a move that could affect the proposed nationwide tobacco settlement, four major cigarette producers agreed yesterday to pay Mississippi $3.4 billion over 25 years to resolve a lawsuit over health-care costs associated with smoking.

title: Blair Birdsall, 90, Master of Civil Engineering
description: Blair Birdsall, a civil engineer whose expertise in suspension bridges and other cable systems stretched from the Golden Gate in California to the East River to one of the world's engineering marvels, now being built in Denmark, died on June 25 at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 90 and lived in Allendale, N.J.

title: British Telecom Shares Hit a 3 1/2-Year High
description: The shares of British Telecommunications P.L.C. rose to a three-and-a-half-year high yesterday after the British Government said the company must pay less than half the bill that analysts had been expecting under a one-time ''windfall'' tax. The shares rose as high as 485 pence before closing at 479.5, up 22 pence.

description: The recent words of Bobby Valentine do not exactly take the form of a plea, but they soon might.
