title: Card Halves Cost for Double-Fare Riders
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority today halved the cost of commuting for hundreds of thousands of riders accustomed to paying two fares to get where they're going, pushing the fabled subway token toward extinction and creating an election-year boon for politicians.

title: Keep the Mall as It Is
description: The Mall in Washington has somehow survived the caprices of shifting tastes, changing Administrations and scores of muddle-headed efforts to improve it. Its spacious vistas and monumental eloquence realize the audacious promise of the Federal city's original plan, as sketched in 1791 by Maj. Pierre L'Enfant. So do we really need or want a World War II memorial inserted between the Washington Monument and Lincoln Memorial?

title: Man Is Killed in Robbery
description: What began as a lovers' stroll ended with the slaying of a Perth Amboy man early Wednesday as he pleaded with teen-age robbers to spare his girlfriend's life, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Art for Art's Sake and for All Those 'Little People'
description: Jean-Luc Godard's 1996 film, ''For Ever Mozart,'' is chock-full of chewy mouthfuls of cinematic theory, most of them in the mind of an aging French director who is the movie's occasional narrator and its obvious stand-in for Mr. Godard.

title: Ford Posted 4.7% Sales Rise In June in Contrast to Rivals
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its United States domestic car and truck sales rose 4.7 percent in June, helped by rebates and other incentives, providing a bright spot in one of the auto industry's worst sales months of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, CYNTHIA H.
description: WALLACH-Cynthia H. Beloved wife of Edward. Loving mother of Charles, Elizabeth and Robert Marcotte, Roger and Mary. Dear sister of Michael Hollins. Cherished grandmother of Nathan Marcotte. Service today, 9:45 AM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: It's Just a Replay of the Bite, Right? But Oh, the Sore, Sore Feelings
description: The deal was to be quiet, left unannounced until the right time. The secret: CBS would pay Showtime Networks $750,000 to replay last Saturday night's pay-per-view Evander Holyfield-Mike Tyson rematch.

title: Lockheed Will Acquire Northrop for $11 Billion
description: NEW YORK  One of the final consolidations of the post-Cold War U.S. defense industry was announced Thursday when Lockheed Martin Corp. said it would acquire Northrop Grumman Corp. for $11.18 billion in stock and assumed debt.

title: Stocks of Cereal Companies Up on Possible Price Rises
description: Stock prices of companies that make ready-to-eat breakfast cereals jumped yesterday in reaction to a decision by General Mills Inc. to raise prices. Investors viewed the move as the end of a three-year cereal price competition that has done little to increase profits or consumption.

title: No Subpoena For Tyson At Hearing
description: The Nevada State Athletic Commission decided yesterday not to subpoena Mike Tyson for the hearing next Wednesday in Las Vegas that will outline his boxing future.

title: Cease-Fire in Governor's Race
description: The gubernatorial race between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey has barely begun, but the two sides have called a timeout, starting today, while they take vacations out of state. The Governor will be in northern California with her family for a week of bike riding, hiking and kayaking. Mr. McGreevey, who is separated from his wife, Kari, is flying to Vancouver to visit his 5-year-old daughter, Morag. Both candidates are expected back on the campaign trail on July 14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMIEL, CLAIRE
description: KAMIEL-Claire. On July 2, 1997. 88 years old. Beloved wife of the late Max L. Kamiel. Cherished mother to Rosalind and Bob Rosenblum, Silvia and the late Jerome Rolnick, Harriet & Oscar Levine, & Lillian and Robert Fabrikant. Dear sister to Irving and Ruth Laub. Adoring grandmother to 9 grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Loved for her compassion, generosity, wit & vivacity. A successful business person, leader in many religious and charitable organizations. Formerly RW Matron in the Order of the Eastern Star. She will be sorely missed by her family. Services Friday, July 4, 10 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave., at 65th Street. We love you, mom. Rest in Peace.

title: Bowing to Pressure, Columbia President Reinstates Dean
description: Just days after forcing the resignation of the popular dean of Columbia University's undergraduate college, President George E. Rupp bowed to pressure from alumni and reinstated him yesterday.

title: Now About The Ones That Didn't Get Away
description: LORD BYRON had it right. ''Man marks the earth with ruin,'' he wrote in ''Childe Harold's Pilgrimage,'' but ''his control stops at the shore.''

title: Indexing Capital Gains: Its Virtues, and Cost
description: While President Clinton is talking compromise on taxes, the White House has made no secret of its bitter opposition to a handful of provisions in the bills generated by the House and Senate. High on the Administration's 10-worst list is an item in the House version that would index capital gains after 2001 to offset the effects of inflation.

title: TRANSWORLD HEALTHCARE UNIT TO ABSORB ALLIED MEDICARE
description: Transworld Healthcare Inc.'s British unit said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Allied Medicare Ltd., a British provider of home health care services, for $60.1 million. Transworld, based in Clark, N.J., said the purchase would complement the home health care services of Omnicare P.L.C., a unit recently acquired by Transworld's British subsidiary. Transworld provides ''alternate site'' health care services, including care in the home. It also operates a specialized mail order pharmacy and provides medical supplies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEE, ALICE (NEE GANG)
description: YEE-Alice (nee Gang) of Cresskill N.J. on July 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Marilyn Chin, Pamela Peale and Nancy. Dear sister of Frances Anrig, Florence Wong, Helen Young, Dorothy Ton, Edward, Rose and Robert. Loving Grandmother of Russell Edward Chin. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive Tenafly, N.J. on Fri 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Sat 9AM. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery Hawthorne, NY. Memorials to Englewood Hospital Coronary Care Unit Englewood, NJ 07631 appreciated.

description: A FIRING OFFENSE

title: With Makeover A Big Success, Avon Turns A Lot of Heads
description: Until recently, Avon Products Inc. had become as outdated as the frosty blue eyeshadow it sold to a dwindling number of stay-at-home mothers. But the company is in the middle of a turnaround, brought about largely by the six executives who are now in line to become its next leader.

description: Dan Walsh

title: The Fourth of July
description: FIREWORKS

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the art patron Evelyn Fortune Bartlett yesterday misidentified her first husband, Eli Lilly. He was the grandson and namesake of the founder of Eli Lilly & Company, not the founder.

title: TIME WARNER IN TV RIGHTS DEAL WITH SPAIN'S SOGECABLE
description: Time Warner Inc.'s Warner Brothers studio said yesterday that it would sell long-term television rights to ''Space Jam,'' ''The Bridges of Madison County'' and other films in Spain to Sogecable. The agreement, said to be worth about $1 billion, is similar to ones Time Warner signed with the Kirch Group in Germany and Canal Plus S.A. in France and may include an option for Time Warner to take an equity stake in Sogecable's satellite television service. The agreement includes Warner Brothers films released in 1995 and after. The films will be shown on pay-per-view on Canal Satellite Digital; on Sogecable's premium pay-television channel, Canal Plus Spain, and on Cinemania, another movie channel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, DORIS N.
description: HAFT-Doris N. On July 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harold Haft. She died as she lived with dignity, fortitude and grace. A cum laude graduate of Cornell University, she also earned an MBA from Columbia University. She lived her adult life in Manhattan and was an Account Executive for many years with Josephthal, Lyon and Ross. Contributions in her name are suggested to Mount Sinai Hospital. A Memorial Service will be 1:15PM, on July 7 at the Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A 15,000-Worker Presence in the Region
description: The name Grumman, because of its long and deep role in the New York region's economy, still has a mystique -- especially on Long Island, where the company was founded. Lockheed Martin, while quieter and more dispersed, now has a comparable presence.

title: Air Force Chief Delays Decision in Sex Case
description: Air Force Secretary Sheila A. Widnall has delayed a decision on whether or how to punish an Air Force officer awaiting trial by court-martial on charges of fraternization and lying, as lawmakers weighed in on his side.

title: Gadfly Praises Nuclear Energy Over Wind, Solar and the Rest
description: Hans Blix was not afraid to say the two words no one wanted to hear last week at a conference on the global environment: nuclear energy.

title: South Korean Banks Get New Flexibility
description: South Korean banks will be allowed to set their own interest rates on savings deposits of less than three months starting on Monday, as part of the fourth stage of interest rate liberalization, the Bank of Korea said yesterday.

title: Ennobling the Printer in the Belle Epoque
description: Tucked away in one of the least seductive spaces of the Museum of Modern Art is an archetypal summer show called ''Paris -- The 1890's.'' Drawn entirely from the museum's own collections, it consists of prints by Toulouse-Lautrec, Redon, Bonnard, Vuillard and others. Many of them are among the most famous images of their date. Some of them, in reproduction, can by now look very tired. But in pristine state their magic remains intact.

title: 10 Are Arrested in Raids Over Counterfeit Tapes
description: Ten people were arrested and more than 10,000 counterfeit videotapes of movies were seized at eight video stores and a bootlegging ''factory'' in Queens, the borough's District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday.

title: Students Put Energies Into a Futuristic Car
description: As a Government-industry partnership seeks the car of the future -- an almost-magic vehicle that is supposed to be clean and superefficient but no smaller, no slower and no more costly than today's version -- outsiders ask if it will be driven by electricity or by fossil fuels.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an article yesterday about tensions in Albania after last Sunday's election misspelled the interim Prime Minister's surname in some editions. He is Bashkim Fino, not Ceno.

title: Unexpected Rise in Jobless Rate Spurs a Rally for Bonds
description: An unexpected jump in the unemployment rate sparked a rally in the Treasury market yesterday, as the jobs report eased concerns that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates any time soon.

title: Wells Adds to a String Of Sharp Performances
description: The Yankees might be looking to add some power to their lineup. But right now, they sure don't need any pitching.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 5%
description: The nation's unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in June, to 5 percent, easing the tightest labor market in a quarter century, Government figures showed today. A moderate 217,000 jobs were added to payrolls.

title: Russian Space Station Has Navigation Flaws
description: The navigation system of the Mir faltered today, creating a new problem for Russian space officials and astronauts as they prepared for a tricky mission to repair the stricken space station.

title: Racial Politics Lets Flawed Candidate Find Allies
description: As President Clinton spoke at a rally at the Daley Plaza here, days before his re-election last November, a senior White House aide groused privately that the President had had no choice but to share the stage with Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, once the pride of the Democratic Party and now one of its bigger embarrassments.

title: KMART IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE 20 VENTURE DISCOUNT STORES
description: Venture Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would sell 20 stores to the Kmart Corporation for an undisclosed price. The deal includes ten stores in Houston, five in Dallas, two in Indianapolis and one each in Tulsa, Okla., and Des Moines and Waterloo, Iowa. The sales should be completed this month, but Venture said Kmart would not assume occupancy until inventory sales are held, by Sept. 15. Venture, a discount retailer based in O'Fallon, Mo., said it was selling the stores to raise money for a restructuring program. The sale will leave Venture with 93 stores in nine states. Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., has more than 2,100 stores.

title: Art in Review
description: Charles Henri Ford and Allen Frame

title: New York Can Take It
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: I didn't much like Balthazar when it opened in April. Oh, of course I liked the look of the place; its bold, sassy bistro airs were enchanting. So was the buzz: celebrities were everywhere and it was fun to walk around the enormous room trying to figure out why each of them had been seated in that particular place. One night it was a special thrill to leave the restaurant and find a panhandler staring resentfully at Jerry Seinfeld's disappearing back. But after I'd eaten my way through the bread basket (the bread is spectacular) and downed an oyster or two, I was always ready to leave; the food just wasn't very good.

title: Man Is Cleared in Death
description: A grand jury found no criminal wrongdoing in the death of a Bronx man who died last July in a struggle with his ex-wife's companion, prosecutors said yesterday. Gowkarran Dyal went to the Hackensack home of Radica Dyal, fired a shot into her bedroom and hit her companion, Jeff Diamond, with an ax, said Sharon Peiffer, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor. But after Mr. Diamond placed Mr. Dyal in a headlock, he lost consciousness and never revived, the prosecutor said.

title: INSO STOCK PLUMMETS AFTER WARNING ON REDUCED PROFIT
description: The shares of the Inso Corporation lost nearly half their value yesterday after the company, a Boston-based software maker, said its second-quarter earnings would be less than a third of what analysts expected as a result of lower-than-expected revenue and a charge for restructuring and job cuts. Inso shares fell $9.6875, to $11.0625, in trading of 8.9 million shares on the Nasdaq market. The stock traded as high as $63 last October. Inso licenses reference guides to CD-ROM makers and on-line services and makes proofreading software used in publishing. Its earnings shortfall springs from lower royalty revenue from its reference line as it faces competition from the Internet, lower demand from on-line services and slack CD-ROM sales.

title: Veba of Germany to Buy Wyle Electronics
description: Veba A.G. said today that it had agreed to buy Wyle Electronics of the United States for $609 million to increase its worldwide share of the electronics distribution market.

title: Cable-TV Ruling Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court upheld a lower court ruling yesterday that had barred Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani from forcing Time Warner to carry Rupert Murdoch's 24-hour news channel on its cable television systems in New York City. The Mayor's aides said he was considering abandoning the legal battle but moving the fight to another arena: the negotiations with Time Warner next year over the renewal of its franchise agreements with the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, LILLIAN ROSE
description: RUBENSTEIN-Lillian Rose. July 2. Loving wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Richard Hemley and Marsha Handelman. Grandmother of Seth, Cindy, Jeffrey, Erica, Andrea, Steven and Debbie. We will miss Lillian's zest for life.

title: Charter School Is Delayed
description: Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City, who began his second full term Tuesday, said yesterday that he would not be able to open his proposed 500-student charter school until September 1998. The Golden Door Charter School was one of only 2 of the 16 applicants to be rejected last month for state money. Mr. Schundler is chairman of the school's trustees. The Mayor said the school's opening was being delayed because setting up a temporary school would require $2.5 million up front, while building a new school would cost $4.5 million spread over several years. Mr. Schundler helped to write the law authorizing the charter schools, which are publicly financed but independently run.

title: How to Master Metrocard? Practice
description: With the end of the two-fare zones, more and more riders are forsaking tokens for Metrocards, and they are finding out that zooming through the turnstiles is an art form that requires a hefty dose of patience and dexterity.

title: The Disposal: Coming Soon to a Sink Near You?
description: It is one of those inexplicable, only-in-New-York things: a city that prides itself on being a world capital of round-the-clock consumer convenience, that features home delivery of everything from dry cleaning to dry martinis if one knows whom to call, has a law against an appliance that defines convenience: the garbage disposal.

title: TWO GIANTS JOIN A MERGER PARADE IN ARMS INDUSTRY
description: In what is expected to be the final chapter in the dizzyingly rapid consolidation of big American military contractors, the Lockheed Martin Corporation announced yesterday that it was buying the Northrop Grumman Corporation for $8.3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, EPHRAIM
description: KATZ-Ephraim. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the father of its long-time distinguished chaver, Marcos Katz, a leader in the international Jewish community. Heartfelt sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPP, HILDEGARDE M.
description: RAPP-Hildegarde M. On July 2, 1997. Beloved wife of Leo Rapp. Dear sister of Lottie M. Loeb. Services Sunday, July 6, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: Washington Slept There, Too

title: Household Spending Slips in Japan
description: Japanese household spending slid in May for the second straight month as a sales tax increase kept more consumers out of department stores, supermarkets and restaurants, the Government said yesterday. Average spending fell 2.2 percent in the month from a year earlier, to 312,345 yen ($2,716), the eighth decline in the last 12 months, the Management and Coordination Agency said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lockheed Martin to Buy Northrop for $8.3 Billion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, JONATHAN SCOTT
description: MORRIS-Jonathan Scott. On June 23, 1997. Memorial services were held on June 25, 1997, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family of Jonathan Scott Morris has requested that any donations made in his honor be made to the Jonathan Morris Jerusalem Middle East Peace Theatre Foundation. Contributions should be sent to Dr. Robert H. Morris, 1040 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

title: Becker Uses Home Court To Retire
description: IN a typically self-effacing gesture, the tournament committee placed the two great British hopes, Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski, in the relative Siberia of Court 1 yesterday. This decision was a tribute to the female semifinalists, of course, and also to Pete Sampras, but mostly to Sampras's opponent, Boris Becker, who had left his thick contours all over the pressed grass of Wimbledon for more than a decade.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: When Biking to N.J., Hop a Ferry
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Repay Bilked Co-ops Is Challenged
description: Three years after a criminal investigation uncovered widespread corruption in the management of hundreds of Manhattan cooperatives and condominiums, a plan to return some of the money to the victims of the kickback schemes is in jeopardy.

title: $25 and Under
description: The mid-1990's have been boom years for the classic New York pizza. After a decade of neglect in favor of the individual designer pie, pizzerias specializing in these pies have been opening all over the city.

title: Savoring a Sweet Taste Of Southern Summers
description: They put sweet iced tea in a can, now. Stores sell it in the soft drink section, beside 7-Up and Diet Coke and Evian. People pop the top and savor the brisk chemical bite and the imitation lemon aftertaste.

title: PATRICK INDUSTRIES SAYS IT RECEIVED A TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Patrick Industries said yesterday that it had received a takeover proposal that the company's board was considering. The company, a maker of component products used in manufactured housing, recreational vehicles and furniture, is based in Elkhart, Ind. It received ''a proposal for the acquisition of all the shares'' of the company, it said in a statement. It did not say who had made the offer. The company is in talks with the bidder, but there are no assurances an agreement will be reached, Patrick said. The company made the announcement after trading in its stock was halted; its shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $16.625.

title: Clinton Denies Claim In Paula Jones Case
description: President Clinton responded to Paula Corbin Jones's sexual harassment lawsuit by filing a motion for dismissal of the case and a memorandum in Federal court here ''adamantly'' denying her accusation that he propositioned her in a Little Rock, Ark., hotel room in 1991 when he was Governor of Arkansas.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: Crimes of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Storms Kill 10 in Michigan and Leave Wide Damage
description: A sudden storm on Wednesday turned a family picnic deadly in this Detroit suburb and cut a crooked swath of destruction across the region.

title: Pepsico Selling California Pizza Kitchens to Investment Fund
description: Pepsico Inc. has agreed to sell its California Pizza Kitchen chain of casual-dining restaurants to a Manhattan-based investment fund for an undisclosed price, a spokeswoman for the restaurant chain said yesterday.

title: Hingis Ho-Hums Her Way to the Final
description: Although they had promised not to act their age, there was petulance and precocity in abundance on Center Court this afternoon as Martina Hingis and Anna Kournikova, the teen-agers deemed most likely to carry women's tennis into the millennium, displayed their wares in the semifinal round at Wimbledon.

title: Deal Is Expected to Win U.S. Seal of Approval
description: The proposed merger of Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman is unlikely to face a serious regulatory challenge, experts said today, because of a Clinton Administration policy of explicitly supporting the consolidation of military suppliers.

title: Goodbye, Mr. Stewart
description: I met James Stewart on a number of occasions, but I could never bring myself to call him Jimmy, only Mr. Stewart. Calling him Jimmy would have been like calling Woodrow Wilson ''Woodie.''

title: Lord Stormont Wins Trot
description: The high season of harness racing, a sport once defined by state fairs and Dan Patch, began its run in the metropolitan area last night with the first leg of trotting's Triple Crown at Yonkers Raceway and the elimination heats for next Friday's $1 million Meadowlands Pace.

title: Anti-Drug Tax Lifts Kansas City
description: When weekends turn rowdy, Preston Washington arranges for his clients to leave home and move temporarily into a halfway house to avoid violating their parole.

title: Giant Reinsurer to Move Into Primary Sales
description: Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurance company, said today that it would merge two subsidiaries with Victoria Holding A.G., creating a primary insurance group that would compete with Allianz A.G.

title: Let Scientists Do Their Job
description: A scientist at the National Institutes of Health was suspended last month in connection with his outspoken criticism of the Lyme Disease Foundation, a powerful advocacy group for people with the disease. The scientist, Edward McSweegan, had taken issue with the group's aggressive efforts to influence Federal research.

title: Mayoral Rivals Invade Parade Long the Turf Of Giuliani
description: The hamlet of Travis, Staten Island, has thrown itself a brass-band parade for 87 consecutive Fourths of July, and for the last 8 of those years, Rudolph W. Giuliani has been its sole possessor. Until yesterday.

title: Army Cuts Its Beer Ration, And Brewers Are Furious
description: When the United States Army slashed beer rations for the 37,000 G.I.'s in South Korea this year, commanders said the edict was intended to stamp out a pesky vice.

title: Officer Hurt in Bronx In Clash With Crowd
description: Police officers moving to confiscate fireworks and arrest a man in the Bronx last night were confronted by an angry crowd of about 150 people who fought the officers and hurled rocks and firecrackers at them, the police said. One officer suffered a minor head injury and at least five people were arrested.

title: Dozing Driver Dies in Crash
description: A motorist from Queens was killed yesterday when he fell asleep on the Garden State Parkway and drove into a tree, The Associated Press reported. The man, Guo H. Liang, 26, was driving about 8 A.M. when he crossed both northbound lanesand slid sideways into the tree, said State Police Trooper James Puhalski. Mr. Liang was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Demand for Single-Family Homes Helps Fuel Inner-City Resurgence
description: M. C. and Debra Hampton plan to move next week to their corner of the American Dream: a newly built house in a well-kept, middle-class neighborhood, the kind of home that for decades here has meant moving to the suburbs.

title: 15 in Accord on Computer Disk Standard
description: Fifteen of the world's biggest electronics manufacturers, including Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, the LSI Logic Corporation of the United States and Philips Electronics N.V. of the Netherlands, said today that they had agreed on standards for a powerful new computer disk.

title: Police Ban on Firecrackers Makes for Quieter Holiday
description: In the simmering Fourth of July sun yesterday afternoon, the most fiery items for sale on Mulberry Street were the chili peppers at the Sun Chung Lee vegetable stand in Chinatown and the pasta fra diavolo at Il Palazzo restaurant a few blocks away in Little Italy.

title: New Twist Makes Corporate Stock Options Even Sweeter
description: With the bull market going strong, stock options have become one of the sweetest deals available in the board rooms and corner offices of corporate America. And they are supposed to be good for outside investors, too, by encouraging directors and executives to generate big profits for the company so that they can generate big gains for themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, RICHARD
description: COHN-Richard, on July 4, 1997. Devoted husband of Mildred (nee Elias). Beloved father of William S. and Kenneth E.. Adored fatherin-law of Janet. Loving uncle of Deborah, Tom and Lisa. 12:00PM Service on Sunday, Temple Israel, Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Nature Conservancy, Lower Hudson Chapter, 265 Chestnut Ridge Road, Bedford Hills, New York. Information: the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Wildwood Workers Picket
description: Beachgoers going to Wildwood yesterday were greeted by a large contingent of city employees standing along Route 47, the main road into the city. While the workers welcomed travelers to Wildwood's beaches and amusements, they also had a more important message to impart: they want a raise.

title: In Financial Arena, Merger Is the Game
description: As the securities, banking, insurance and money management industries continue their rapid consolidation, some of the biggest names in finance are on the prowl for acquisitions on Wall Street -- or have recently made the plunge. The main decision they all face is which firm will give them the biggest lift as they seek to build a global financial business.

title: Nature's Wrath at a Gentle Tanglewood
description: Nature did not take kindly to the Boston Symphony's all-Strauss program on Thursday night. The Tanglewood Festival was beginning its summerlong hegemony over these soft green hills and tree-lined lanes, but the elements made contemptuously clear who was boss.

title: Third Parties in Pennsylvania
description: Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania did democracy a service when he vetoed an amendment overwhelmingly approved by the State Legislature that would have given the state one of the most restricted ballots in the country. The legislation would have immediately benefited the Governor, who is running for re-election next year and has faced third-party threats before.

title: The Mets Need to Make A Bold Move
description: SOMETIME during the next few weeks, the Mets' owners should study the 45-by-65-foot image of Jackie Robinson on the scoreboard at Shea Stadium. The famous 1949 photo shows Robinson taking a daring lead off third base, taunting the pitcher.

title: The Two General McCaffreys
description: Since his appointment as the White House drug czar in February 1996, Gen. Barry McCaffrey has consistently said the right thing about drugs. He stresses that increased treatment, not law enforcement, is the best way to reduce drug usage. In January, he acknowledged that world production of cocaine and opium was increasing. ''If you want to fight a war on drugs, sit down at your own kitchen table and talk to your own children,'' he told National Public Radio last week.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5

title: Summer Agenda: Unity and Church-State Issues
description: For many people, the start of summer means being able to enjoy the grace of leisure time, focusing on the beach or backyard barbecue, and putting weightier matters aside. But for several religious organizations, the coming weeks promise to be ambitious, rather than indolent.

title: Craft Arrives on Mars and Relays Images
description: After a smooth seven-month journey, an American spacecraft came to a bouncing, rolling landing on Mars today to begin intensive studies of what the planet is made of and whether life could have possibly arisen there in its distant past.

title: Du Pont Sells Unit to Genstar Capital
description: Genstar Capital L.L.C. has purchased the NEN Life Sciences unit of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for as much as $118 million and named the former head of the Pharmacia & Upjohn Company, John Zabriskie, to head it.

title: British Auto Maker and Unions Sign Deal
description: Rover Group Ltd., the British auto maker owned by BMW of Germany, said today that it had reached agreement on a three-year pay package after almost a week of talks with its joint trade unions.

title: Jerome Machlin, 83, Bridge Event Official
description: Jerome Machlin, one of America's most prominent directors of bridge tournaments, died on Tuesday in a nursing home near his home in Wheaton, Md. He was 83.

title: The Grateful Dead's Legacy: A Firmament of Bands
description: Bands had an easy way to rouse the crowd when the seven-hour, eight-act Furthur Festival played Forest Hills Tennis Center in Queens on Thursday. All they had to do was play a Grateful Dead song, or just a tiny bit of one, and the audience of 13,000 redoubled its dancing and started to sing along. One more time, Dead Heads had taken out their old tie-dyed T-shirts and gathered to commemorate the fondly remembered and imagined pleasures of the late 1960's, as nearly every band opened a time capsule.

title: INSIDE
description: Charles Kuralt Dies

title: Writer With a Roadshow
description: The recent decision by HarperCollins to cancel more than a hundred books that it had under contract is just the latest bit of bad news in publishing. Independent bookstores are being squeezed out, and superstore chains are selling display space. As a result, young writers like me are forced to go to new lengths to find readers for their books.

title: Leslie Gaines, 85, a Leading Tap Dancer
description: Leslie (Bubba) Gaines, a noted tap dancer and leading member of the Copasetics tap group, died on Monday at the Veterans Hospital in Manhattan after a short illness. He was 85 and lived in Harlem.

title: Charles Kuralt, 62, Is Dead; Chronicler of the Country
description: Charles Kuralt, the CBS newsman who turned basic curiosity into a prize-winning journalistic ethos as he ranged across the country to interview the overlooked and explore the underappreciated, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 62.

title: Police Charge Bronx Woman In Death of Officer Slain in May
description: A Bronx woman was charged yesterday in the slaying of an off-duty police officer who was shot while driving through the Bronx en route to his Westchester County home in May, the police said yesterday.

title: Where Were the Boomers on Medicare Reform?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheers for Medicare?
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Staten Island Ferry, Illusory 'Free Ride' Is Reality
description: The sun was sweet, the breeze was gentle and Tyrone Muldrow was in an unimaginably expansive mood. He had the holiday off from his job as a taxi dispatcher, and he was standing on the bow of the Staten Island Ferry, an arm slung around his 11-year-old son, Tyrone Jr. He was calculating aloud the money he would save on his six-day-a-week commute from Staten Island to Williamsburg, Brooklyn -- $21 a week -- and promising his boy the moon.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 9 about political contributions by Maria L. Hsia misstated the size and timing of donations made to Representative Howard L. Berman, Democrat of California, in the early 1980's. Mr. Berman received a total of $800 from a law firm with which Ms. Hsia was associated, not several thousand dollars. He received the contribution several months after corresponding with the Immigration and Naturalization Service on the firm's behalf, not before writing to the agency.

title: Bosnian Serb Leader Is Said to Fear for Life
description: Officials close to Biljana Plavsic, president of the Bosnian Serb Republic, said tonight that she feared for her life and was considering fleeing if she loses her power struggle with Radovan Karadzic, her predecessor, who is charged with war crimes.

title: Fiat Unit's Fast Cars Take Back Seat to Licensing Fees
description: For Walter Mittys the world over, Ferrari is a symbol of speed and guilt-free excess. For Luca di Montezemolo, chief executive of the boutique auto maker here in the northern Italian industrial heartland, it is a business whose past glory does not guarantee survival.

title: In Surge to Be Americans, Thousands Take Oath
description: Inspired by a love of America and a fear of her fickleness toward immigrants, more than 5,000 people from 108 countries raised their right hands today to take the oath of citizenship on a sun-drenched football field here on Long Island. They are part of a historic wave of citizenship seekers whose numbers have quintupled in five years to an anticipated high of 1.8 million this year.

title: Radiation Prompts Meetings
description: When a 16-year-old Union boy exposed himself to radiation in May by cracking open one of three signs he had stolen from a local demolition site, nuclear regulators went looking for the sign's original owner. This Thursday, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission plans to meet with three different companies that have owned the site over the past 20 years to discuss possible violations of agency rules.

title: A Landmark Hotel Reopens
description: The Flanders Hotel, a Jersey Shore landmark that was nearly razed last year, reopened yesterday after being closed for extensive renovations. The hotel's 214 rooms have been transformed into 95 condominium suites, James M. Dwyer, a developer who bought the hotel last year, said Thursday. When a suite's owners are not there, the suite can be rented to the public, and the management splits the rent with the owner.

title: Clinton and Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Like New, a Rollicking Landmark
description: American Ballet Theater billed its performance of ''Fancy Free,'' part of an imaginative holiday program on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, as a ''revival premiere.'' It was an odd but fitting designation: the performance had the freshness of a first night.

title: Profit Up 8% at Germany's Biggest Utility
description: RWE A.G., Germany's largest diversified utility, said today that profit and sales each had risen 8 percent in the latest fiscal year, slightly higher than expectations.

title: Bosnian Serb Leader Said to Fear for Life
description: The president of the Bosnian Serb Republic fears for her life and may flee if she loses a power struggle with her predecessor, associates of the leader, Biljana Plavsic, said. ''This is a battle we will probably lose,'' one of her allies said, ''but it is a battle to save the Serb Republic.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, FRANCIS J.
description: GALLAGHER-Francis J. On July 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Ann. Also survived by five children, five grandchildren and 3 siblings. Friends may call 2-5 and 7-10PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park. Funeral Mass Monday 9:45 A.M., at Our Lady of the Snows Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paroled Rapist Is Charged With Killing Girl
description: A man on parole for a rape has been arrested on charges that he murdered a Bronx girl whose decomposed body was found in Seton Falls Park in the Bronx on Thursday afternoon, the police said yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: Bridge
description: The first appearance of bridge in an Olympic-type setting occurred last week at the University of Rhode Island. It was the World Scholar-Athlete Games, in which about 2,000 high-school students from 144 countries took part in a wide variety of sports and cultural activities. All were required to have good academic records.

title: Colombia Cuts Domestic Coffee Price
description: Colombia, the world's second-largest coffee exporter, is reducing its domestic coffee price 10 percent in keeping with variations in international prices.

title: Hingis Is Chasing History
description: Not that she is taking it for granted, but Martina Hingis is right where she expected she would be, in the final of her third Grand Slam event in 1997. With a victory Saturday in the ladies' final, she can become Wimbledon's youngest champion since Lottie Dodd wowed the crowd as a 15-year-old prodigy in 1887.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, DORIS N.
description: HAFT-Doris N. On July 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harold Haft. She died as she lived with dignity, fortitude and grace. A cum laude graduate of Cornell University, she also earned an MBA from Columbia University. She lived her adult life in Manhattan and was an Account Executive for many years with Josephthal, Lyon and Ross. Contributions in her name are suggested to Mount Sinai Hospital. A Memorial Service will be 1:15PM, on July 7 at the Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: On Clean Air, Environmental Chief Fought Doggedly, and Won
description: It was the final night of the budget crisis of 1996, and top White House and Congressional negotiators wrangled over whether to pass a sweeping spending bill or to shut down the Federal Government yet again.

title: Skip Away Casts Aside All Doubts in Suburban
description: Skip Away confirmed yesterday that he has risen to the top of his class, battling back to win in the homestretch over Will's Way and Formal Gold in the 111th running of the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: She May Offer Cookies, But She Still Wields A Ferocious Golem
description: Behold Puttermesser. She is back: Cynthia Ozick's dowdy literary surrogate plugging away at her boring job in the New York City Department of Receipts and Disbursements. Lovably awkward, overeducated, put-upon Puttermesser is the heroine of Ms. Ozick's book ''The Puttermesser Papers,'' a collection of previously published stories turned into a novel. It is Ms. Ozick's first book of fiction in 10 years. And watch out! Puttermesser may seem compliant, but cross her, and she will create a golem and wreak havoc upon the municipality.

title: Authority vs. Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBIFKER, MARILYN
description: ROBIFKER-Marilyn. Beloved wife of the late Burt. Devoted mother of Gail, Steven and Dara. Loving sister of Edna & Arthur Schechter, and Ruth Kaplan. Dear sister-inlaw of Fred Robifker. Fond aunt of Lori Schechter. Services Sunday 10 AM at ''Gutterman's,'' (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Blvd., corner 66th Avenue., Forest Hills.

title: Add 2 More to the Mob on Majorca: the Clintons
description: The bay of Palma and its sunlit sentinels, the medieval watchtowers, the ancient windmills and a soaring, sandstone cathedral with massive buttresses, have long received illustrious visitors.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: USING THE CARD With the official end of the two-fare zones, Metrocard use surged despite the doubts of some. Page 27.

title: Britain Showed Bad Faith on Hong Kong Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Board Challenges Federal Aviation Agency
description: Amid charges of politics and indifference, the nation's top crash investigators are in unusually open dispute with the airline safety agency about how to prevent crashes like that of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 a year ago.

title: New Battle Over Beach Fees
description: With summer in full swing, the battle over whether beaches should be free is heating up again. Last week two Democratic State Assemblymen, Neil M. Cohen and Wilfredo Caraballo, introduced a bill that would distribute $9 million a year among the state's shore towns but forbid them to charge beach fees. Daily fees are as high as $5.50 -- in Avon -- while season badges range from $15 in Cape May to $61 in Spring Lake.

title: Betsy's Place: An Oasis Fit for Bogart
description: In Casablanca, everybody went to Rick's. In Tbilisi, they go to Betsy's Place.

title: 6-Player Swap Nets Yankees A Power Hitter
description: In one bold swoop today, the Yankees unloaded two players that the owner, George Steinbrenner, could not wait to get rid of and added the power-hitting left fielder that Manager Joe Torre could not wait to get. Kenny Rogers, Mariano Duncan and a minor league pitcher were traded to the San Diego Padres for Greg Vaughn and two minor league pitchers, both right-handers.

title: Newest Met Is a Hit In a Hurry
description: Before last night's game, Manager Bobby Valentine scratched his head when someone asked where Todd Pratt had played before he was signed by the Mets organization before this season. Valentine admitted that he was not sure, but added that he did know the scouting report on the catcher, who was called up from Norfolk, the Mets' Class AAA affiliate, a day earlier.

title: A Memorial to Jewish Small-Town Immigration
description: Russian-Jewish immigration to the United States at the turn of the century did more than fill the huge urban centers of America.

title: Brahms Swallowed Whole In a Decorous Lunch Hour
description: By and large, the fine noonday concert programs at Trinity Church and St. Paul's Chapel in lower Manhattan are too easy to take for granted. But Trinity Church, armed with an anonymous donation ''to the glory of God and in honor of Johannes Brahms,'' has just raised the stakes with a sizable festival, Brahms on Broadway, which runs throughout the summer in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the composer's death.

title: Class Action May Give Green Light To Anti-Smoking Forces in Europe : British Court Allows Major Tobacco Suit
description: BRUSSELS  Britain's High Court gave the go-ahead Friday for the country's first class-action lawsuit by cancer victims against cigarette manufacturers, a move that could unleash a wave of American-style litigation against European tobacco companies.

title: Sampras Is Golden, Advancing to Wimbledon Final With Pioline
description: Here at Wimbledon, like every place else he goes, Pete Sampras strives and almost succeeds in keeping a low profile despite being a three-time champion on the brink of his 10th career Grand Slam title.

title: Canal Sells Pay-TV Stake
description: Canal Plus S.A. said today that it would record a one-time gain of $508 million from the sale of its stake in the German pay-TV channel Premiere. Canal Plus, Europe's biggest pay-TV operator, signed agreements on Thursday to sell its 37.5 percent stake in Premiere to the Kirch Group of Germany and to buy Kirch's 45 percent stake in Telepiu S.p.A., Italy's only pay-TV company.

title: As Strike Wears On, Town's Life Ebbs
description: Archie Wilfred, a bartender at the Schutzen Club, was sweeping the sidewalk and said he had not served a customer all day. Sitting in a corner of the Hometown Luncheonette, which she runs with her husband, Thelma Peterson wondered if the July 4th Special for $3.50 -- one hamburger or two hot dogs, plus macaroni salad, potato salad and baked beans -- would draw any customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURALT, CHARLES
description: KURALT-Charles. We shall remember his humanity, his voice, his wit, his smile, his friendship and generosity. Buzz Hartshorn Cornell Capa Int'l Center of Photography

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANELLI, UMBERTO
description: ROMANELLI-Umberto, 89, on June 30. A graveside service was held on July 2 at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Mr. Romanelli is survived by his wife of 58 years, Nedda of New York City; his daughter, Rosanna Frank of Chappaqua, NY; two sons, Joseph of Jerusalem, Israel, and Daniel of Los Angeles; seven grandchildren and a great-grandchild. Donations in his memory are being accepted by The Jewish National Fund at 42 East 69th St., New York, NY 10021

title: In Congo, Drivers Find They Can't Get There From Here
description: In a country that may have the worst roads in the world, Sam Onzima was busy doing what drivers often do here in Congo. He was stretched out beneath his Land Rover in the middle of the jungle, hammering away and going nowhere.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Panel Opposes Takeover by Boeing

title: AIDS Adviser Criticized for Suggestions on Curtailing Spread of H.I.V.
description: An appointee of Gov. George E. Pataki who serves on the panel that advises the state on AIDS policy has suggested that people infected with H.I.V. have sex only with other people who have the virus as a way to end the epidemic.

title: Liberty Stays Unbeaten, But It Was Rough
description: The Women's National Basketball Association wanted a big-time rivalry, and it has it. Call it a preview of the Eastern Conference playoffs, and pass the ice packs.

title: Dollar Up in Foreign Trading; Stock Prices Abroad Are Mixed
description: The dollar rose against major currencies yesterday in trading that was kept thin by the Fourth of July holiday in the United States. Against the German mark, the dollar touched its highest level in nearly 41 months.

title: Mosquitoes
description: A mosquito lies on its back, dead, on a sheet of white paper on a desk. Its banded legs are thinner than script from the nib of any pen, and they point straight toward the ceiling. Under a magnifying lens, the mosquito -- a female -- resolves into a hairy thoracic ball, delicately fringed wings, a segmented, countershaded abdomen (dark above, light below), a pair of antennae, some mouthparts called palps, and eyes that seem to focus, cross-eyed, on the tip of the needle-like proboscis. She looks like what she is: a drilling rig with wings.

title: Japan Banks Said to Carry $240 Billion in Bad Loans
description: Japanese banks are still struggling to rid themselves of the bad loans that have plagued them since the collapse of the real estate market earlier this decade.

title: Beaches Are Reopened In Darien and Stamford
description: Beaches in Darien and Stamford, Conn., reopened yesterday after concerns over a sewage spill in the Bronx had kept them closed for four days. The spill, which was caused by a ruptured gauge at a sewage-treatment plant in the Bronx, had also closed Westchester County beaches earlier in the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSELL, JOHN M.
description: CASSELL-John M., of Irvington, NY. Beloved husband of Ginny. Loving father of Kristina, Irene, Beth and John W. Caring brother of Maureen Guttridge and Pat Cooper. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday 10 AM, Church of the Immaculate Conception, Irvington. Visiting Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, on Sunday 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M.

title: Newspaper Group Expands in England
description: Mirror Group P.L.C., seeking a stronger foothold in central England, said today that it had agreed to buy Midland Independent Newspapers P.L.C. for $:297 million, or $496 million.

title: Clattering And Blazing Into Spain's Proud Past
description: Dancers were partnered by history in ''Homenaje '97,'' the lively panorama of Spanish dance that brightened the Miller Theater on Thursday night.

title: 2 Japanese Bank Officials Are Indicted
description: Tokyo prosecutors said today that they had indicted a former vice president of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd., Ichiro Fujita, and a former managing director, Tateo Fukushima, in connection with illegal loans that the bank purportedly made to a corporate racketeer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SYMONDS, FRIEDA
description: SYMONDS-Frieda. Died July 5, 1986 at the age of 90. In loving memory. Your son Martin.

title: Goldman, Sachs Fills Europe Post
description: Goldman, Sachs Group L.P. has hired Simon Robertson, the former chairman of Kleinwort Benson Group P.L.C. and one of London's top investment bankers, to be president of Goldman Sachs Europe.

title: Fourth Sizzles, Corn Fizzles
description: There were fireworks and flags galore, but one crucial ingredient of a New Jersey Fourth of July was missing yesterday: fresh local sweet corn. The cold, wet spring set the crops back, and Sandra Mitchell, who usually begins selling New Jersey corn in time for holiday barbecues at her stand in Wall Township, was still selling Florida corn yesterday. Ms. Mitchell and other produce vendors will probably not have New Jersey corn until late next week. Jersey tomatoes, another holiday mainstay, will probably not come in until the middle of the month.

title: Jess Meeker, 85, Music Director Of Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival
description: Jess Meeker, a composer, accompanist and musical director at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, died on Wednesday at Toledo Hospital in Toledo, Ohio. Mr. Meeker was 85 and lived in Toledo.

title: Suit vs. Caremark Settled by Coram
description: The Coram Healthcare Corporation has settled a two-year-old fraud and breach-of-contract lawsuit against Medpartners Inc.'s Caremark International Inc. and Caremark Inc. subsidiaries.

title: No Headline
description: ''This boat ride is free now, Junior, and we don't got to pay double for the subway and the bus, either. And that savings goes into your pocket, son. I'm talking sneakers. New sneakers.''

title: In Wheat Country, Sympathetic Congressman Can Give Farmers Little Comfort
description: The Republicans called it the ''Freedom to Farm Act'' when they abolished price supports and crop and acreage restrictions last year.

description: To the Editor:

title: Will Mexico Break Free?
description: In pre-Hispanic Mexico, the Aztec emperor, the tlatoani, ''he who speaks,'' was considered to be almost a god. And from the Spanish conquest in 1521 to the achievement of Mexican independence in 1821, 63 viceroys ruled New Spain, on behalf of a distant king who never once crossed the ocean. They were administrators, judges, commanding generals, ''fathers to their people.'' From both these sources came a tradition of centralized, divinely sanctioned power that has lasted -- under different forms -- almost to the present day.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Young Criminals, Focus Is Saving, Not Punishing
description: First it was a fade haircut, then a tattoo. A couple of absences from school spiraled into truancy. The sociable joint on weekends became an obliterating cloud of marijuana smoke.

title: Out Of The Past
description: He was a guy who'd been one too many places. Who prowled the night, after what was left of the day went away like a pack of cigarettes you'd smoked. With rain hammering at the window, with a sloe-eyed brunette and a ravenous redhead both working to frame him, he wondered just how big a chump he could get to be. He didn't want to die, but if he had to, he'd die last.

description: To the Editor:

description: McDERMOTT-Dermod P. Of New York City. Died July 3, 1997. Age 62 years. Lifetime of generous devotion to improving quality of life in the South Bronx and Lower East Side communities. Loving husband of Shukuko. Beloved son of Thomas and Mary Jane McDermott. Devoted father of Daniel, George, Victor, Jose and Miguel Flores. Adoring grandfather of Danielle, Deana, Elan, Gilda, Sofia, Victor, Joseph, Jose and Katie Flores. Beloved brother of Thomas P. and Geraldine McDermott Pender. Brother-in-law of Sean Pender and Maria F. McDermott. Reposing 3 PM-8 PM on Sunday July 6, at St. Emeric's Church, 185 Avenue D (at 12th St.), Manhattan. Mass of Christian Burial 9 AM, Monday, July 7, at St. Emeric's Church, followed by interment at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital, NYC.

title: YELTSIN DECLARES ECONOMIC DECLINE HAS BEEN STOPPED
description: An unusually calm and apparently forthright Boris N. Yeltsin, speaking to the Russian people on the anniversary of his re-election as President, asserted today for the first time that the battered Russian economy had finally emerged from its stark, five-year plunge into darkness.

title: Retail Cooperative Acquires Swiss Chain
description: The Federation of Migros Cooperatives agreed today to buy Magazine zum Globus A.G., a department store chain, for 705 million Swiss francs, or $493.5 million, cementing its position as the dominant Swiss retailer.

title: Power of a Hymn
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribe Starts New Business: Gambling Site On Internet
description: French traders called the tribe of American Indians in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains the Coeur d'Alenes, ''those with hearts like an awl,'' because each year the tribe demanded, -- and received -- better deals for its furs. Now the tribe has found a new business opportunity, starting what members believe is the first legal Internet gambling site based in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHER, MALCOLM L.
description: FLEISCHER-Malcolm L. Died July 4, 1997. Beloved father of Susan Fleischer, Stuart and Penny Fleischer. Cherished grandfather of Hilary and Lauren. Devoted brother to Natalie Tannen, Gilbert and Terry Fleischer. Services at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Sunday, July 6, 1997 at 12 noon.

description: To the Editor:

title: The New Humanitarian Dilemmas
description: In a sense, the years of the cold war were the halcyon days of humanitarian aid. Most conflicts were fought over ideology by parties whose leaders worried about world public opinion and had read the Geneva Conventions. The people who died tended to be combatants. Relief agencies had limited missions of caring for the wounded and refugees, and could do their work largely unmolested.

title: Bones Now Seem to Prove That Che Is Dead
description: In a six-foot-deep pit, the body of Che Guevara lies exposed to the Bolivian skies. Experts who have unearthed a mass grave in this small Bolivian mountain town said today that the grave contains the remains of Guevara and six of his guerrilla comrades.

title: Japan Fills Key Currency Policy Post
description: Eisuke Sakakibara, a Japanese bureaucrat whose influence on the currency markets is so strong that he is known as ''Mr. Yen,'' was appointed today to the post of vice finance minister for international affairs.

title: Bertelsmann Mum on Compuserve Rumor
description: Bertelsmann A.G. declined to comment today on a report that it was joining with America Online Inc. to acquire Compuserve Inc., its nearest rival in on-line computer services.

title: Tiny Rover, Built on the Cheap, Is Set to Explore Mars
description: Space probes used to cost $1 billion a pop. No more. Struggling to slash costs while raising quality, NASA has built an unassuming gadget the size of a child's riding toy to rove across the dry Martian landscape, doing exploration on the cheap.

title: Not 'Eye for an Eye'
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Years Later, the Red Hook Waterfront Still Awaits Revival
description: LIKE actors brushing past the curtains, Michael Dreher and his friends took turns holding back a flap of chain-link fence as they clambered onto a worn ledge of concrete and asphalt on New York Bay. They savored the sunset from the Brooklyn waterfront, as the light dimmed over the sweeping views of the Statue of Liberty, Governors Island and the Oz-like towers of lower Manhattan.

title: A Bitter Pill to Swallow For Sluggish Yankee Hitters
description: Greg Vaughn, the slugging left fielder acquired today by the Yankees, is not scheduled to join the team until after the All-Star Game break next week, according to Manager Joe Torre, assuming, of course, Vaughn passes his physical this weekend.

title: Bettman Will Arbitrate Quarrel Over the Islanders' Sale
description: Commissioner Gary Bettman of the National Hockey League has agreed to arbitrate the bizarre and bitter dispute over the sale of the Islanders, according to a league official.

title: Investigators Seek Clues to Explain Subway Train Derailment
description: Investigators looking into Thursday night's subway derailment in Harlem are focusing on why seven cars of a southbound A train rolled smoothly over a track switch near the 135th Street station while the back wheels of the eighth car ended up on an adjacent spur, transit officials said yesterday.

Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey and Ottie Levine, Marc and Debbie Levine, David and Nori Levine, James Sperber, Jill and David Chernoff, Ellen and Ron Wides, Mindy Shankman, Jon and Helen Shankman and loving great grandmother of seventeen.

title: One Fare Zone, With Transfers for All
description: Ayana Brown, a 15-year-old high-school sophomore, climbed out of a grey Plymouth Voyager, spat on the sidewalk and then lighted a cigarette. She had just gotten off an illegal van, her ride to the No. 4 train at the Woodlawn subway station in the Bronx. ''All my friends take these vans,'' said Miss Brown, her nose pierced in three places, her blue baseball cap turned backward. ''When I can't find a bus, I have to use a van, like after 3 o'clock,'' she said, when school closes.

title: Man Is Shot to Death On Coney Island Walk
description: A young man was shot to death on the Boardwalk in Coney Island in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon while the beach area was crowded with people celebrating the Fourth of July, the police said.

title: Kidnappers in Mexico Seize Son of a Former Governor
description: The son of a controversial Mexican politician has been kidnapped, according to Mexican press reports, in the latest in a series of unresolved abductions of public figures in the weeks before national elections on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMIEL, CLAIRE
description: KAMIEL-Claire. Memories of her joy of life are everlasting. Our condolences to all her loved ones. Alice and Mort

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July. Government offices, banks and many businesses were also closed. Most foreign markets, however, were open.

title: Man Missing After Leap From Staten Island Ferry
description: A passenger on a Staten Island ferry bound for Manhattan jumped overboard early yesterday after he got into a fight with several fellow ferry riders, the police said. After three hours of looking for the man in the harbor's waters, the police suspended their search at 5:45 A.M.

title: Sitting Out the Sidewalk Dance
description: IT'S lunch hour and you're late for your therapy appointment (again). You rush out of your office and dive right into the street, weaving in and out: through the mob, around the tables of fake Rolex watches, over the homeless man and his dog -- when it happens.

title: Buyout Package Brings a New Business
description: THE best time to start a business is when you have a job, as illustrated by the experience of Roy R. Westmoreland, a former human resources training consultant at International Business Machines.

title: Traffic Accident Ends In Slaying, Police Say
description: A minor traffic accident on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive turned deadly after one driver stabbed another driver, the police said.

title: Yeltsin & Yeltsin
description: The bad news for Boris Yeltsin these days is that his popularity is still so low that he needs a full-time image maker. The good news is that not even the howling of his Communist opponents prevented his daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko, from taking the job.

title: Theresa Lustria, Arthur Mariano
description: Theresa Penaflor Lustria and Arthur Gregory Mariano, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Cecilio T. Moraga performed the ceremony at the Immaculata, a church on the University of San Diego campus.

title: Late-Night Clubs, Bars and Restaurants Renew White Plains
description: WHEN Benjamin Feder was a child in the 60's, his parents called this city's downtown Little Fifth Avenue. Fancy shops flourished alongside high-end department stores, customers strolled the main streets and money flowed.

title: Club and Builder Feud Over Everything Including the Kitchen Sink
description: It may be the most bizarre dispute in the 106-year history of a Park Slope social club known more for promoting social order than social conflict.

title: A Winning Mix of Warmth and Whimsy
description: NOT the old Spring Close House again. A half-dozen restaurants have been in and out of that East Hampton spot over the last decade and none of them has been better than mediocre. Now it is the Farmhouse and things are different.

title: New Rules On Custody: Will They Aid Children?
description: Two months after the State Supreme Court released sweeping revisions to New Jersey's child custody guidelines, experts are at odds over what the effects will be. Some say the changes could actually harm the children they were intended to protect.

title: All Hail The Great Greenspan Bull Market
description: Alan's Army marches on.

title: Marching Along Together at the Mall
description: IT is shortly after 7 A.M. on a weekday but already the wide corridors of Westfarms -- the big mall that straddles the West Hartford-Farmington town lines -- are filling up with people marching, marching, marching along.

title: A Man of Dissonance
description: VIRGIL THOMSON

title: In Hartford, Recitals of Beethoven
description: THIS summer, the Chamber Music Plus ensemble's 15th season, works by Beethoven and others are being offered during three recitals at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.

title: Moscow, We Have a Problem
description: Many people are now wondering what is to be done about the Russian space station Mir, which collided last week with a supply ship. Is repairing the Mir a good idea? If a repair is successful, should other crews be sent to man it?

title: The Joy of Hats: Tools of Allure and Illusion Makers
description: AMONG women, the world is divided as to what is the crowning glory for the head. Is it the hair, which gleams, curls enticingly and says, ''Stroke me''? Or is it the hat, which to some is far more than a mere covering for the head, shelter against wind, rain and snow? For the maven, a hat, whether made of tulle, straw or felt, is nothing less than a crown that can transform a person's character, not to mention posture.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Getting the Goods on Missing Goods
description: Q. I know that my late grandfather had several bank accounts, but he left no records. Is there a way I can find them?

title: Opponent Calls Pirro A Publicity Seeker
description: CLAIMING that the county needs a District Attorney who is more interested in the cause of justice than the media, Joanne Naughton, a retired attorney/lieutenant in the New York City Police Department advocate's office, recently began what she calls a no-frills campaign to unseat Jeanine Pirro.

title: Working Out The Bugs
description: YOU'RE relaxed at last. You're finally home from work; the martini is in your hand, beautiful in its chilled magnificence, and you're looking out over the lawn, your lawn, your empire -- oh, yes, it is an empire, whether it is a postage-stamp plot or an acre expanse -- and you have this sense of well being, of richness. The look and smell of the grass (not to mention the taste of the juniper berries) stir in you a primeval feeling of being one with the earth.

title: Easy Money From Your House (If It's Paid Back)
description: TRADITIONALLY, the equity in one's home was seen as an invisible, intangible asset -- a long-term growth fund that increased in value with every monthly mortgage payment. For many, equity in the home closely approximated total net worth, and having such a significant investment in sticks and stones was considered as safe and secure as the shelter provided by the structure itself.

title: Sanjukta Panigrahi, Indian Dancer, 65
description: Sanjukta Panigrahi, a classical dancer from India who toured the United States as a foremost exponent of the Orissi style, died on June 24 at her home in Bhubaneshwar in the Indian state of Orissa. She was 65.

title: Hewitt Dispute And Dan's Papers
description: Dan's Papers learned early on that Don Hewitt was in a dispute with Telemark Construction over repairs to this house, but we never wrote an article about it, feeling it was not appropriate to publish he-said-this and they-said-that articles about an unresolved private dispute while it was still in the courts. We did, however, in our South of the Highway column, note that there was such a dispute going on.

title: Making Friendly Wagers In the Skies
description: THE term ''high roller'' is about to take on a literal meaning, for in-flight gambling has begun. There are at least two airlines that have systems in the air and two more testing it on the ground. By the end of this year, as many as 70 international flights are expected to offer ways to lose more than your luggage.

title: Real Men Don't Bite? Just Step in This Ring
description: The reaction to Mike Tyson's ending a heavyweight boxing match by biting off the ear of Evander Holyfield was loud and seemingly universal outrage. One of the most layered views came from Mr. Tyson's old neighborhood, the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, which has its own reputation for toughness.

title: ARMOR ALARM
description: The United States Senate is considering a bill that would provide stricter penalties for ''any crime in which the defendant used body armor.'' Why? Because criminals often wear bulletproof vests made of lightweight materials like Kevlar. When two bank robbers shot it out with the police in Los Angeles last February, both had bulletproof vests. One of them, Larry Eugene Phillips Jr., had customized body armor wrapped around his arms and legs; though hit repeatedly and wounded nine times, he managed to keep going. Meanwhile, technology is definitely helping the good guys. Last year, for the first time, more police officers were saved by bulletproof vests (150) than were killed on duty (116). The Survivors Club, a group of officers who survived thanks to body armor, says the protection has saved 2,056 lives since 1973.

title: Jane Karlen And Simon Walsh
description: Jane Marie Karlen, a daughter of Ursula and Glenn Karlen of Punta Gorda, Fla., was married yesterday to Simon Lockwood Walsh, the son of Joan and George Walsh of Brooklyn. The Rev. Stanley J. Krempa officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Alexandria, Va.

title: The Doll Houses That Sheltered So Many Dreams
description: THE POST-MODERNISTS took the podium, adjusted their mikes and announced that we were not really living. Instead, we were watching television and going to movies and taking mud baths in the media.

title: The Underground Isn't Over
description: THE MOST-TALKED-ABOUT film in Belarus, a forlorn little country sandwiched between Poland and Russia, has never been shown in a Belarussian movie theater or on state television.

title: Tightly Knit, With Old-Fashioned Values
description: ON Friday, in conjunction with the Fourth of July Parade, many residents took part in the annual house-decorating contest -- the kind of traditional activity that defines Travis, a community on Staten Island's west shore. Neighbors tried to outdo each other with banners, signs, bunting and flags.

title: Fighting Erupts Between Cambodia's Two Rival Leaders
description: Heavy fighting broke out near the Phnom Penh airport early Saturday, with the sounds of mortars and rockets jolting the capital and signaling the collapse of the coalition Government put in place four years ago with the help of the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, DAVID
description: COHEN-David. My beloved Grandpa, you are always in my heart. I miss you everyday. Freya

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: When in Need . . .
description: SOME people prefer Burger King. Others McDonald's.

title: The Drive-In Lives!
description: The first outdoor screen went up in 1933 in Camden, N.J. By 1958, there were more than 4,000. It has been mostly downhill since. But there are still 826 scattered across the country, with at least one in every state except Alaska and New Jersey. The 'auto theater' survives in country hillsides, along lonely roads - and in memory.

title: Longtime Numbers King of New York Goes Public to Clear His Name
description: As a bright high school graduate too poor to attend college, Raymond Marquez began searching for a job with a future. With little hesitation, he chose a profession that he was confident would bring him wealth and respectability: the illegal numbers business.

title: Old-Fashioned Quilts With Newfangled Angles
description: QUILTS ARE AS AMERICAN AS apple pie. Which probably explains why these traditional bedcovers are often shortchanged in the public mind. Popular opinion is clear: quilts are cozy on a winter's night, but how many of these superficially formulaic objects are imbued with depth-charge artistry, the true creative spark? Actually, a great deal more than one would imagine.

title: Trying to Rescue Songs Once Held Dear
description: THERE IS A DERELICT crooner who haunts subway platforms on the Upper West Side of Manhattan singing like Nat (King) Cole. Though the fellow misses the mark by a mile, his concertizing is as close as many people are likely to come to Cole's vocal artistry, above ground or below. The same may be said of the songs that Cole once sang so caressingly, the standards of the American popular song book. In the culture's clamorous subway roar, they are just an echo.

title: Tracing a Songsmith's Symphonic Journey
description: THERE IS MUCH MORE to Schubert the symphonist than conventionally meets the ear. Indeed, some listeners may be shocked to discover that Schubert did not begin his symphonic catalogue with the treasured Fifth Symphony. Four very fine and appealing works came before it. And though he left only sketches for a Seventh Symphony in the sequence that runs to Nine, spanning the years 1813 to 1826, he definitely produced a Sixth.

title: In Scarsdale, Seasonal Italian Dishes
description: AFTER what seemed like a lapse in inspiration and boredom with the enterprise, Steven DePietro, Il Cigno's chef and owner, appears to be getting a second wind. His menus draw from the vast encyclopedia of Italian cuisine, which he reinvents, making the old new again. Although slip-ups still occur, more attention is obviously being paid to careful basic food preparation, a step Mr. DePietro's style and vision deserves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, ELIZABETH, PH.D.
description: MINTZ-Elizabeth, Ph.D. Died after after a long illness on June 23rd, at the age of 83. A psychotherapist in private practice in New York City, she was a leader in the human potential movement. She authored numerous articles in professional publications and two books. She was the widow of Alexander Mintz, Ph.D., Professor of Psychology at City College of The CUNY and is survived by her son Harvey Mintz of Hastings on Hudson, NY and her daughter Ann Mintz Wagner of Harrisburg, PA. She will be mourned by her family and her many friends. Memorial service Wed., July 16, 7PM NPAP Meeting Rm 150 West 13th st. NYC

title: Grand Illusionist
description: Claudio Bravo, the Chilean-born realist artist who has a knack for making a crumpled piece of wrapping paper look like a 17th-century religious relic, came to success early in life. By 1972, at the age of 35, he was a well-established, sought-after portraitist living in Madrid, a darling of society. That year, lacking neither confidence nor funds, he traded in the high life for a monkish existence in Tangier, where he passed long ascetic days of work and solitude amid the luminous surroundings of his newly acquired seaside mansion. The paintings and drawings he produced there, many imbued with the color and texture of the Arab world, make up the bulk of the more than 200 reproductions in CLAUDIO BRAVO: Paintings and Drawings (Abbeville, $95). Arranged in more or less chronological order, the book traces his use of color, which seems to become more extravagant with the passage of time, and the increasingly mysterious arrangement of objects in his photo-perfect still lifes (a bowl of ostrich eggs, for example, alongside a yellow tulip, or a shower cap beside a tube of oil paint). Many of these drawings and paintings combine the precision of hyperrealism with the lush texture of a centuries-old classic, leaving one to ponder how, say, a rendering of a goat -- each strand of hair taken into account -- can mirror reality so acutely and, at the same time, transcend it. A 1995 interview with Bravo and fascinating introductory essays by two of his friends, the novelists Paul Bowles and Mario Vargas Llosa, provide insights into the life of this ''illusionist,'' as Vargas Llosa calls him, who causes objects to ''lose the insignificance they have in real life and become delicate creatures.'' Suzanne MacNeille

title: The Amnesty Option
description: Crimes that tear the soul of a nation should not be left incompletely examined or obscured by mystery. South Africa has shown the healing power of truth as it looks back at the crimes of apartheid, granting amnesty to whites and blacks alike who come forward with evidence of their past misdeeds. As Americans watch the work of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, the moment may be right to consider whether a similar approach might be useful in the United States in certain narrowly defined situations. Unlike South Africa, whose new Government is still evolving, the United States has a fully developed and functioning criminal justice system. But it is also true that contemporary American society is still haunted by some unresolved questions that nag at the national conscience. Such questions, if left unresolved, promise to provide fodder for conspiracy theorists for decades to come. At a time when anti-Government propagandists are increasingly active, the prospect of increased alienation and mistrust among citizens is not an attractive one.

He joined Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens of NYC in 1941, became a Partner in 1945 and retired from the firm in 1986. He became affilated with The Maritime Law Association of the United States in 1946 and held various offices with that organization until his death. He became a Membre Titulaire of the Comite Maritime International in 1963, holding various offices including that of Delegate of The MLAUS at many international Plenary Conferences. He was a member also of the Swedish Maritime Law Association. For 25 years Mr. Moore was a Director of Benjamin Moore and Co., which was founded by his grandfather in 1883. He joined the Boy Scouts of America in 1927, achieved Eagle Scout rank and served as Scoutmaster and Commissioner for many years. Mr. Moore leaves his beloved wife Janet of Bloomfield, CT; his children from previous marriages Jean M. Holzman of Menlo Park, CA, John C. Moore Jr., of Reston, VA, Virginia M. Decker of Pleasantville, NY, Stephen R. Moore of Brownsville, VT, and Joy V. Moore of Newport News, VA; two step-children Marjorie W. Hutto of Old Saybrook, CT, and Roland Webster of Mystic, CT; also suriviving are a brother Roswell O. Moore of Bend, OR, and twelve grandchildren. Services will be held Thursday, July 10, at 11:30 AM, at St. John's Episcopal Church, 679 Farmington Ave., West Hartford, CT. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memeory may be made to the Benjamin Moore Scholarship Foundation, 51 Chestnut Ridge Rd., Montvale, NJ 07645, or the Comite Maritime America Foundation, c/o Chester D. Hooper, Esq., Haight, Gardne, Poor & Havens, 195 Bway, NYC 10007.
