In 1995, several research organizations reported that a hefty percentage -- in one study, 65 percent -- of teen-age mothers had babies by adult men. The image of lecherous men seducing troubled young girls barely past menarche prompted several states to step up enforcement of statutory rape laws, both to protect the girls and to reduce out-of-wedlock births.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTROSE, CHARLES
description: MONTROSE-Charles, on July 2, 1997 at age 99. Beloved husband of Mildred. Loving father of Elaine and Madeline. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Graveside service at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, at 1 P.M., Sunday.

title: Sanitizing the Internet? No Way!
description: ON June 26, 1997, the United States Supreme Court unanimously struck down a key provision of the wildly censorious Communications Decency Act, passed by Congress and signed into law by President Clinton in 1996. If upheld, this measure would have sanitized from the entire Internet any information any yahoo in any backwater of the country deemed unfit for minors.

description: Margaret Hamilton Meserve and Robert David Goulding, Ph.D. candidates, were married yesterday at St. Margaret's Church in Oxford, England. The Rev. Alan Green, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Public Housing Tenants Trade Rents for Mortgages
description: IRA P. JACKSON, a 54-year-old clerk and mother of five grown children, will be writing her last rent check to the Jersey City Public Housing Authority this month. In August, Ms. Jackson will be closing on the two-family home she purchased with her daughter and son-in-law from the authority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, EDWARD L. III
description: HICKS-Edward L. III, age 77, died of prostate cancer at his home in Greenwich, CT on July 3, 1997. He served as a Lieutenant in the US Navy in WWII and received a B.S. from Yale in 1942, where he was a member of St. Anthony Hall. He later received an M.A. at Teachers College, Columbia University. Mr. Hicks worked for New Jersey Zinc Company and was Vice-President of Guantanamo Sugar Company. He then moved into a new career of teaching at Greenwich Country Day School. A resident of Greenwich since 1946. Mr. Hicks was a member of The Representative Town Meeting serving on the education and finance committees. He was active in the Young GOP Organization and a member of the Republican Town Committee. He was Chairman of the American Red Cross Annual Campaign and was active in church and hospital fundraising. He served as a VicePresident and newsletter editor for the Greenwich Historical Society and as Director and President of the Greenwich Land Trust. At his death, he was a member of Christ Church, Round Hill Club, Belle Haven Club, Cruising Club of America, Yale Club of NYC and Amateur Ski Club of NY. Surviving him are his wife Elizabeth Kean Hicks, four children, Dr. Edward Livingston Hicks of Villa Nova, PA, Elizabeth Hicks Wheelwright of NYC, Cynthia Hicks Cutting of Tarrytown, NY and Stephen Winthrop Hicks of NYC and nine grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Elizabeth Wise of Vernon, AZ. A memorial service will be held on July 8 at 12 noon at Christ Church in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Yale University or Greenwich Country Day School.

description: Mike Figga, the Columbus Clippers' catcher, was asked to assess his pitcher's performance tonight.

description: THE window opened and Anthony Papa sniffed the sultry air and looked out at the city through his large, dark eyes. His thick, weight lifter's body was hunched into the fake leather back seat of a car service Lincoln. It was twilight on a muggy June evening, less than five months since his release from Sing Sing.

description: State legislators approved dozens of bills late last month in their rush to wrap-up business and impress voters before their fall re-election campaigns, but they did not touch a pile of bills aimed at limiting smoking.

description: When President Clinton and other NATO leaders meet in Madrid on Tuesday to open the alliance to formerly Communist countries in Central Europe, the big question is not really which ones will join.

title: Last Stand for Dorothy Day?
description: Seventeen years after her death, Dorothy Day, the pacifist who fought for the poor, is involved in another stand against the rich.

title: A New Life for a Polluted Old Bronx Rail Yard
description: THE 96-acre site at the southernmost tip of the Bronx, once a busy railroad yard, has sat unused for 25 years, its future clouded by the asbestos, hydrocarbons and lead left from its industrial past. Now, with an unusual alliance of developers working to revive the site, the asbestos and much of the heavily contaminated soil have been removed, and what remains will be paved over with clean material to seal up the remnants of pollution.

description: THE VIVID RETAIL adventure of my distant childhood was the shoe-department fluoroscope. Insert one's shoe, peer through an opening, and what had been a foot became a living skeleton bathed in green light. One wiggled the toes to make sure the connection was true.

title: A New Stage for South Africa
description: BRUSH UP YOUR ZULU. THE NEW South Africa is coming to Lincoln Center. Six plays, in fact, as part of Lincoln Center Festival '97, plus a ''Macbeth'' involving 66 drummers, singers, dancers and actors. It all begins on Tuesday, when the three-week arts festival opens. Still, if one doesn't kuluma isi Zulu or praat Afrikaans, one needn't worry. This time, South Africa is coming with supertitles.

description: Woodbridge Strong, a former law partner in the family practice of Strong & Strong in New Brunswick, N.J., died on June 21 at the Francis E. Parker Memorial Home in Piscataway, N.J. He was 87 and had previously lived in Highland Park, N.J., and Lenox, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAO, RITA CHRISTINE ROTHLIN
description: KAO-Rita Christine Rothlin, East Woods Road, Pound Ridge, New York, died at home, amongst family, on July 2, 1997, after a valiant struggle against ovarian cancer. Born Feb. 3, 1930, Kerns, Switzerland. She was an active member of St. Aloysius Parish, and was chiefly responsible for the floral arrangements there from 1986 to 1996. She is survived by her husband, C. Y. Kao, M.D.; two sons, Peter Kao, M.D., Ph.D. of Palo Alto, CA, and Hilary Kao, of Arlington, VA; 3 grandchildren; a stepmother and seven brothers and sisters in Switzerland. Visiting hours are 5 to 8 P.M., at the F. Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, CT, on July 6. Mass will be held at St. Aloysius on July 7 at 10 AM.

title: In an Ancient Mirror, an Image of Europe Rising
description: EMERGING FROM THE DARK shadow of the Ceausescu dictatorship in the early 1990's, the Romanian theater director Silviu Purcarete felt drawn by ''The Suppliants,'' the surviving fragment of Aeschylus' tetralogy about the myth of the birth of the Greek nation. In its story of exile, violence, national identity and survival, the director saw a powerful allegory for the confusion and uncertainty accompanying the ''rebirth'' of Europe after the collapse of communism.

title: For Leyland, Stability Is a New House Back in Pittsburgh
description: ONE OF the best managers in baseball is returning home, to where his heart is.

title: Cabbie Sought After Taxi Rams Village Store, Injuring 11
description: The police searched yesterday for a taxi driver whose cab careered into a busy Greenwich Village intersection late Friday night, injuring 11 people before crashing into a leather store.

title: Witherspoon Keeps the Liberty Clicking, and Winning
description: The ice packs were still taped to Rebecca Lobo's knees Friday night, but she had to make her way across the locker room one more time. One more high five. One more chance to tell the woman they call the other Spoon what an awesome pass she threw. And what a great game she had.

title: Rome's Green Havens
description: LOOK at a map of Rome and you will see an outer ring of enormous green parks. Some are private; others, such as the Villa Doria Pamphili and the Villa Borghese, are open to the public. Farther toward the center, inside the line of the partly preserved third-century Aurelian Wall, which still demarcates central Rome, are visible small and medium-sized patches of green. Though many of the most beautiful of these are the gardens of private villas (like the villas Medici and Aurelia, belonging to the French and American academies respectively), a number of them are public. During the day they are frequented by small children with mothers, grandmothers or nannies, joggers, couples, the elderly, solitary readers and, after school, the Italian World Cup soccer team of the year 2012. In other words, Romans.

The cashier always cried out ''C'est incroyable! (It's unbelievable!) ''Ce n'est pas vrai!'' (It's not true!) -- or words to that effect.

title: Hundley Elbow Surgery Is Just a Matter of When
description: Todd Hundley will try to delay the surgery that his throbbing right elbow needs. He will try to play as long as he can stand the pain, as long as the Mets remain in contention. But Hundley, an All-Star catcher, said yesterday that sometime between now and the end of October, doctors will perform the major operation, which will keep him out of action for a minimum of six months.

title: The King Of Trash Holds Court
description: JOHN WATERS peered out the window as the car pulled up to Tower Video on Lafayette Street and glimpsed the motley crowd that stretched all the way to the Bowery. ''Could you go around the block?'' he asked the driver wryly.

title: Yes, Electric Boat's Giving Stuff Away
description: THE newest additions to the Mystic Seaport Museum are not whaling ships or sidewheel steamers, but models of some of the most modern ships in the world: the nuclear submarines Hartford, Rhode Island, and Connecticut, which represent the latest classes of ship constructed by Electric Boat in Groton.

title: Juarez, Mexico: On the Border, Between Extremes
description: CIUDAD JUAREZ, a city of well over a million people just across the Rio Grande from El Paso, Texas, is a dynamic point along the membrane between the world of the desperately striving in Mexico and that of the relatively prosperous in the United States.

title: Assaults on Tourists Rise in Central Europe
description: WHEN President Vaclav Havel returned from a vacation in Belgium recently, he lamented that his country had gained the reputation abroad as the Wild East. A surge of pickpocketing, price gouging and general thievery against the swarms of tourists in Prague encouraged the impression, he suggested. But his beloved capital is not the only place in Central and Eastern Europe where tourists are targets. Two other popular cities, Budapest and Warsaw, also suffer from rising crime against foreigners, part of the overall growth of crime in these countries. Tourists are the most conspicuous and obviously the easiest and richest prey. And in many cases calls for help from tourists in trouble -- say a pickpocketing incident, a bag being grabbed on a crowded tram -- are ignored by indifferent residents.

title: Cambodian Fighting: Rumors of Civil War
description: Heavy attacks broke out yesterday in the Cambodian capital, indicating that the coalition the United Nations helped form four years ago had collapsed.

title: L.I. Vines
description: A Simple Sipper

title: Sometimes, Companies Grow by Baby Steps
description: HARDLY a week goes by without a major merger that shakes up an industry. Sometimes the deal is surrounded by startling numbers, as with the just-approved plan by the Boeing Company to buy McDonnell Douglas -- a $14 billion merger, the 10th-largest in American history, that would create the world's largest aerospace company.

title: Of White Lies and Yellow Pads
description: SO maybe a yellow legal pad found its way from the office supply cabinet into your briefcase and now does duty at home for grocery lists. Or you called in sick one day last week when, if truth be told, you were actually feeling quite well. Or perhaps your most recent expense report shows you to be a bigger tipper than you really are.

title: Whistler in Prints, in Context And as a Precursor of Styles
description: JAMES ABBOTT MCNEILL WHISTLER (1834-1903) was the prince of detachment. He referred to himself in the third person, for example, and he titled his best known painting, popularly called ''Whistler's Mother,'' as ''Arrangement in Gray and Black: Portrait of the Painter's Mother.'' As if to enshrine his lack of deep involvement, he signed his prints with a small image of a butterfly. But Whistler used that attitude to forge a new style of printmaking, which was to greatly influence the development of modern art.

title: Elizabeth Barnett, F. J. Campbell 4th
description: Elizabeth Anne Barnett, a registered nurse, and Frank Joseph Campbell 4th, a medical student, were married last evening at the Philadelphia Country Club in Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. James Dever, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Rabbi Paul B. Schwartz.

title: Eating the Catch
description: When I was a boy, I fished to catch fish. On trout streams in southwestern Montana, where I grew up, I was a natural-born pragmatist. I used what worked -- night crawlers, maggots, salmon eggs, anything that might ignite the match-head-size brain of a brookie or cutthroat and induce it to swallow the big barbed hook hidden inside. And I measured success in simple terms: how much of the kitchen sink the day's catch filled and how the trout tasted when cooked. In my family, to bend Norman MacLean's memorable line in my direction, there was no clear line between fishing and eating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, ALBERT
description: LEVINSON-Albert. Of Singer Island, FL, formerly of Perth Amboy, NJ, died July 2, 1997 after a long struggle with prostate cancer. title: Sparring Partners Turn Into Lovers
description: WHO is Beatrice? Who is Benedick? She is a brainy lady, the hard-to-get type, on the island of Sicily. He is a carefree soldier, the confirmed bachelor type, from Padua. ''Man is a giddy thing,'' Benedick believes. If Benedick scorns marriage, Beatrice scorns everything; he calls her ''dear Lady Disdain.'' Yet their characters have become standard-bearers for youthful love in all its teasing playfulness, the personification of Renaissance vitality.

title: Concerned More About People Than the Planes
description: EETTORE SOTTSASS JR., WHO will be 80 this September, grows more youthful with the years. The eye of this great Italian designer sees possibilities overlooked by architects half his age. Case in point: Sottsass's new design for the interiors of Malpensa, the international airport of Milan. While other airport designers are trying to recapture the giddy romance of flight, Sottsass has looked closely at the reality of modern commercial air travel and come to a sad conclusion. Nice try, but no duty-free cigar: the aerial romance ran out of fuel long ago.

title: A Sixth Child Is Dead After Camden Car Crash
description: A sixth child has died from injuries suffered in a traffic accident in Camden on Friday morning.

title: Glorious Gardens of the Vatican
description: LOFTY palms and other plants from as far away as Australia and Brazil thrive on the slope behind St. Peter's in Rome in the harmonious blend of styles, cultures and eclectic botany that has defined the Vatican Gardens since the Renaissance.

title: Finding Free Concerts for Summer
description: SUMMERTIME living is easy, the Gershwins assured listeners, and for families it can even be easier when concerts are free. Heading this week's list of free programs is a concert tonight at 7 by the Westchester Philharmonic at the Burke Estate in Hastings-on-Hudson. The first of two outdoor programs by the orchestra -- the second is on July 20 -- this is a Baroque concerto fest with Melody Chan, a 13-year-old Scarsdale violinist, playing the E major Bach Violin Concerto, the music director, Paul Lustig Dunkel, relinquishing the baton to be the soloist in a Vivaldi Piccolo Concerto and Telemann's Suite for Flute and Strings.

title: America's Aging, Violent Prisoners
description: STANLEY WILSON can no longer recall his age or why he was sent to prison. Alzheimer's has stolen his memory. His hazy mind wanders through space much more freely than his body these days, and he believes he will be released from his prison in the rolling hills of western Pennsylvania ''this weekend.''

title: LABOR DESERTING DEMOCRATIC PARTY IN MAYORAL RACE
description: With two months to go to the primary and four months to the general election, the Democratic candidates for mayor of New York City have failed to win the backing of the city's most powerful unions, a traditional bastion of support that Democrats often rely on to lift them to victory in citywide races.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, EDWARD G.
description: BAKER-Edward G. Died July 4, 1997, in Morehead City, NC, age 88. Beloved husband of Mary Louise, devoted father of five children. Also survived by one sister, Anne Delaney of Massapequa, LI; seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Dr. Baker was the former head of the department of mathematics at Newark College of Engineering. From 1942 to 1973 he was a professional engineer with the American Bureau of Shipping in New York. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, 11 A.M., at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Morehead City. Memorials may be made to St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 2005 Arendell Street, Morehead City, North Carolina 28557, or charity of one's choice.

title: Stromboli
description: To the Editor: The query about Stromboli (Q & A, June 8) reminded me of a visit to the Aeolian Islands in October. I spent an enchanting five days on Lipari, and traveled by ferry to other islands each day. My favorite was Panarea.

title: A New Buzz in Manhattan
description: David Graves (pictured) is wearing a pith helmet and veil as he delivers a jar of sugar water to a newly installed hive of honeybees. ''This helps them build their comb,'' he explains. A typically sylvan beekeepers' moment. The only difference: Graves is on top of a Manhattan office building, tending a secret beehive that has been in place since April. From his stand at the Union Square Greenmarket, the beekeeper and his daughter, Heather, sell maple syrup, honey, jams and jellies produced at their home base in Becket, Mass. By next fall, they hope to introduce ''New York City Honey.''

title: For the Die-Hards on a Colorado Ski Slope, Winter's a State of Mind
description: Outside the A-frame lodge, lawn sprinklers rotated and a summer breeze mingled the scents of suntan lotion and grilling hamburgers. Then the unmistakable clomp of ski boots was heard as a brace of skiers headed down the boardwalk to a busy chair lift.

description: THE waiters are French, seasoned professionals brought up gradually through the hierarchy of haute cuisine. title: A Diet of Full Evenings Leaves a Craving for Lean

One-act ballets were rarely seen in American Ballet Theater's season, which ends this weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House. But the more one lived vicariously through the repeated trials and tribulations of Odette, Aurora, Othello, Coppelia, Cinderella and others during the company's two-month run, which was virtually devoted to full-evening blockbusters, the more one yearned for the variety of the mixed bill.

I would like to emphasize one more that ought not be disregarded. title: How Can We Save The Next Victim?
description: I've been out of nursing for 13 years, but I would be horrified to think that the profession has come to the state Lisa Belkin alluded to. In my experience, no ''troubled nurse,'' unless totally incompetent, would have administered a flagrantly incorrect dose of a potentially lethal drug having taken only the few steps Belkin described to check the error. We were trained in calculating correct doses in nursing school, and it was drummed into our heads that no matter what the doctor ordered, responsibility for the correctness of the dose lay in our hands, since we did the administering. In such a case, a nurse does not say to a doctor, ''Are you sure you want me to give this?'' but instead, ''You do realize this is 10 times the indicated dose, don't you?'' But even if she made this communications mistake, the next step would be to go to the head nurse or charge nurse. The head nurse then calls the resident, and if the resident is not available calls the attending to double-check. There are occasions when nonstandard dosages of medications are called for, but I have often seen ''troubled nurses'' say to doctors, ''Well, if that's the dose you want, you give it!''

title: The Realer World

Throw seven dysfunctional postcollegiate strangers into rent-free housing for six months, let the sparks fly, tape it all and boil down the spiciest footage into weekly episodes for 2.5 million viewer-voyeurs. But this year, when the show moved into Beacon Hill, a downtown Boston enclave for wealthy families, the production's loud and rowdy ways produced conflict with the locals that inflamed the neighborhood -- a ''Real World'' first. Although the Boston cast packed up in June, many neighbors are still grumbling. Here's a blow-by-blow of what happens when ''reality'' meets life.

In addition, Superclubs guarantees sunshine for vacationers at all its resorts in Jamaica. If the sun does not shine any day during a stay at a Superclubs resort in Jamaica, the guest receives a voucher for a day's stay within the next year. Superclubs operates seven resorts in Jamaica and one in the Bahamas. Reservations: (800) 467-8737.

title: What Is Janet Reno Thinking?

The statute, which allows for the appointment of an independent prosecutor in cases of high-level executive-branch wrongdoing, had long been anathema to Republicans, who felt it was used as a nightstick against them during the Reagan and Bush years. The Democrats, of course, had grown quite fond of the statute, which was drawn up in the wake of Watergate, and hoped to revive it.

title: The Brothers Emanuel
description: As an adoptee currently writing a memoir that explores the concepts of nature and nurture, I was disappointed that the question posited by Elisabeth Bumiller in ''The Brothers Emanuel'' (June 15) -- ''What is the nature of what nurtured'' this impressive troika of siblings? -- is never answered. When the Emanuel family avoided talking about Shoshana in detail and she herself declined to be interviewed, Bumiller should have realized that there was no story. Without a full account of the troubled adopted daughter to contrast with that of the highly accomplished biological sons, the article lapses into a banal showcase for the talents and temperaments of three smugly successful 30-somethings. Their feats are attributed to nothing more remarkable than high parental expectations. The nature-nurture issue slips between the reader's fingers, with statements about genetics and environment tantalizingly dangled but never developed. From the scant information provided, it sounds as if Shoshana's difficulties may have stemmed less from being adopted and more from having had brain-hemorrhage complications and overachieving older brothers -- circumstances that could just as easily have afflicted a biological child.

title: Lawyers Are Victims, Too

title: Do You Come Here Often?
description: NIGHT OUT: Poems About Hotels, Motels, Restaurants, and Bars (Milkweed, paper, $14.95) is a clever homage to restless souls and creatures of the night. This anthology, edited by Kurt Brown and Laure-Anne Bosselaar, features the work of 125 contemporary poets in a surprising array of flavors and moods. You'll find everything here, from the dark (''We have all been in rooms / We cannot die in, and they are odd places, and sad,'' James Dickey writes in ''Adultery'') to the light (as in Bruce Berger's ''Dining Late'': ''There are no burnt croutons in the restaurants of Heaven. / No overindulgence of manna will put on weight. / Reservations are eternally held between seven / and half past eight''). Familiar names, like Raymond Carver, Derek Walcott and Lawrence Ferlinghetti, are well represented, but many lesser-known poets also shine, like Mark Cox in ''Inhospitable'': ''You, too, have walked the carpeted halls / with an empty ice bucket, pretending / to look for the machine, but really listening / for passion's channel / blaring from bolted-down, pre-set tvs.'' The poems are whimsically grouped by theme -- ''Rented Pleasures,'' ''Hamburger Heaven,'' ''Some Enchanted Evening'' and so on -- and while many readers may find themselves dipping in and out of this collection, it's hard to bypass titles like ''Vanna White's Bread Pudding,'' ''The Remarkable Objectivity of Your Old Friends'' and ''For the Barmaid Unhappy With the Size of Her Breasts.'' Many of the real gems are odes to transient hotels, seedy bars and all-night diners, dwelling on half-glimpsed trysts, clandestine gropings and the loneliness of late hours -- even as the poets are eager to see life, in the words of Chase Twichell, in the lovely ''Chanel No. 5,'' as ''a sort of gorgeous elegy / intimate with things about to be lost.'' Scott Veale

title: A German Who Beat the French at Their Own Game

In 1911, at the age of 16, he entered the Hanover Conservatory, where he received a rigorous and thoroughly Teutonic education. At 20, he gave a series of six recitals in Hanover, playing nearly all of Beethoven's 32 piano sonatas with a technical mastery and structural comprehension that awed his teachers and the critics. A brilliant man and a gifted linguist, he was drawn to German contemporary music, including the radical works of Hindemith and Schoenberg.

title: MINI-MOOS

Unfortu-nately his five-acre spread in Kent, Wash., sits amid sprawling housing developments, and county zoning laws restrict his herd to just two animals over 500 pounds. ''So I started breeding cattle smaller and smaller,'' says Gradwohl. Now his Happy Mountain Miniature Cattle Farm boasts a herd of 22 head, each animal smaller than 475 pounds and shorter than 42 inches at the shoulder. (A full-grown Angus bull might weigh more than a ton.) Gradwohl says mini-cattle make great pets, and his clients seem to agree. ''They all race around out there after a ball or something,'' says Sandy Schockow, a Californian whose minis, named Fer-dinand and Springtime, are fond of frolicking with Lady Rage, the family Rottweiler. ''Then they'll curl up for a nap beside us out on the patio.''

title: Benevolent Gore: A Test for the Squeamish
description: THE goriest, fleshiest, most explicit series currently on prime-time commercial television is not ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' or ''U.S.A. Up All Night.'' It's a program on the Learning Channel that over the course of four years has slowly amassed a loyal cult following. Titled ''The Operation'' (Saturdays, 8 P.M. and 11 P.M.), the series delivers just what the name promises: an actual operation every episode. There are no camera tricks or quick edits here, as on MTV, to cushion the viewer from reality. Each operation is shown for the most part in real time. If it sounds gory, that's because it is. But it's also fascinating -- philosophically as well as scientifically -- to find out the answer to the challenge constantly posed by bosses, bullies and coaches: ''What are you made of?''

Still, I was left unsatisfied with the way even young journalists tried to depict my age group. As a ''spokesman'' for Generation X, Alex Abrams exasperated me with his assertion that X-ers are only concerned with domestic issues. As a 23-year-old recent college graduate, I certainly do worry about the future of our nation's economy, skyrocketing costs of higher education, Social Security, et cetera, but the similarities between me and what my generation ''wants'' end right there.

The United States Justice Department sued Essex County in 1986 to bring its Youth House population to less than 100. The county agreed, but little had changed by 1993, prompting further action by United States attorneys that yielded a promise by the county to build a new youth house with a capacity of 240, said Bennet Zurofsky, the special master appointed to hold the county to its word.

description: LUNZER-Shoshana (Rose). We are heartbroken at the loss of our beloved sister, sister-in-law, and aunt, and mourn with Peter, her devoted husband, and adoring children, Ben, Jay, Francesca and David and their families. Shoshana strove throughout her life to fulfill the ideals of learning, piety, Tzedakah, and Chesed instilled by our late parents, Rabbi Benjamin and Helen Skidelsky. To Shoshana, Jewish living was truly an art. Her aesthetic sensibility, her love of literature and the arts, informed every aspect of her life. A superb mother, she was a hallowing influence, an enabler, who rejoiced in the many accomplishments of her cherished children and grandchildren. Her special reward was to see them perpetuate her values in their own homes and in the community. She was a woman of valor who demonstated extraordinary faith, courage, and dignity to the end of her life. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOETT, EDWARD J.
description: GOETT-Edward J. Age 78, died on Thursday, July 3, 1997. He was born in New York City, NY in 1918. He received his education at Fordham University, earning his B.S. in mathematics and physics & graduating Magna Cum Laude in 1939. He received his M.S. degree in chemical engineering at Columbia University in 1942. Mr. Goett began his career in 1942 with Charles Pfizer & Co. as Manager of Sales Development & a member of the Board of Directors. During this time, he developed a process to concentrate and produce drugs in a pure therapeutic form. In 1954 he joined Atlas Chemical Industries as Director of the Commercial Development Dept. Soon after, he was elected V.P. in charge of Chemical Research and Chemicals Division. He became a Director of the Company in 1954, member of the Company's Executive Committee in 1955, Senior VP in 1957 with the added responsibilities for industrial & public relations functions, Executive VP in 1958, President & Chief Administrative Officer in 1966, & Chief Executive Officer in 1968. Atlas Powder Co. became Atlas Chemical Industries in 1961, and in 1972 it was acquired by ICI Ltd. and merged with ICI America. Mr. Goett was President and Chief Executive Officer of ICI America until his retirement in 1980. Some of Mr. Goett's many awards & accomplishments in his career include the Achievement Award in the field of science from Fordham University Alumni Assoc. in 1956, the ''Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice'' medal (for Church and Pontiff) from Pope Paul, VI in 1965, the Annual Human Relations Award in 1969, the Engleston Medal for distinguished engineering achievement from the Columbia Engineering School Alumni Assoc. in 1978, and being named to the Delaware Business Leaders Hall of Fame in October of 1995. His professional memberships include the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, American Chemical Society, the American Institute of Chemists, past chairman of the American Branch of the Society of Chemical Industry. He also served as a member of the Board of Directors and Executive Committee of the Chemical Manufacturers Assoc., Director of the Bank of Delaware, Director of the United Community Fund of Northern Delaware, Inc., Director of the Greater Wilmington Development Council, Wilmington Metro Chairman of the National Alliance of Businessmen, and a member of the Conference Board. His other memberships include the Wilmington Club, Wilmington Country Club and Greenville Country Club in Delaware and Royal Poinciana Golf Club. He was a parishioner of St. William Catholic Church in Naples, Florida. He is survived by his wife of fifty-three years, Hazel S. Goett; his 3 daughters: Barbara Marie Goett of Pittsburgh, PA., Mary (Joseph) Greco of Chicago, IL., Linda (John) Collins of Naples, FL.; his sons: Edward (Barbara) Goett, Jr. of Naples, FL., James (Lucy) Goett of Fair Haven, New Jersey and Stephen (Carol) Goett of Bridgewater, New Jersey. Also surviving are 13 grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and his brother, Harry (Barbara) Goett of Los Altos Hills, California. Services will be held at St. William Catholic Church on Tuesday, July 8, 1997 at 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: After The Handover
description: For many Americans, the handover of Hong Kong is just the latest installment in the long-running China-U.S. morality play -- ''The Butchers of Beijing vs. the People.'' But Hong Kongers look at events here with much more mixed emotion. For them, it's not Communism versus democracy, but nationalism versus the rule of law. That is, there is real ethnic pride here in the return of Chinese sovereignty, after 156 years of British colonialism. But there is also real fear that what Hong Kongers appreciated most about Britain's colonialism -- the rule of law -- will vanish along with it. As one Hong Kong businessman remarked to me on handover day: ''I feel torn -- like I just watched my mother-in-law drive out of town in my new Mercedes. I'm glad she's gone, but what about my car?''

title: CHRYSLER SAYS IT WILL CLOSE OFFICE IN BEIJING
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to close its Beijing office, saying China's sluggish automobile market offers few opportunities for new projects. The move underscores global companies' disappointment at the slow development of China's auto industry. Production of cars, trucks and buses grew 2.6 percent last year, barely a quarter of the pace for the whole economy. Larry Burger, director of Chrysler projects in China, said the company no longer saw the need for a representative office. Some sales and marketing staff will be moved to a joint-venture plant making Jeeps in Beijing. Chrysler's bid to expand its China presence was foiled two years ago when Beijing picked Daimler-Benz A.G. to build a $1 billion mini-van and engine factory.

description: CHILDREN may chase after adult fireflies because they make great night lights in a jar, but the same glow of a baby firefly may keep chomping carnivores away.

title: Cocaine in a Transformer
description: An 18-foot-high electrical transformer that was shipped in lubricating oil from Mexico to a Ridgefield Park warehouse last week contained a secret compartment filled with more than a ton of cocaine wrapped in plastic, Federal officials said yesterday. United States Customs agents seized the cocaine, valued at as much as $80 million, after draining the transformer of nearly 400 gallons of oil on Saturday.

The company said second-quarter sales also rose at a rate comparable to the first quarter's 49 percent rise.

Still, the 19-year-old assembly line worker is not sure she really wants to keep up in one respect -- working the 8 P.M. to 5 A.M. shift every other week.

But despite his painful defeat in their match in New York, the world champion came back to capture an impressive first prize in his first post-computer event, the Novgorod International Tournament. So Kasparov upholds his marvelous resilience.

title: The Spin on the Democrats' Dollars
description: The approach of the Senate hearings on the 1996 fund-raising scandals has inspired some creative spin control. The White House and some Democrats have leaked embarrassing information about excesses in President Clinton's own campaign to take away the element of surprise as the committee starts its work today. Viewers should not be deceived by the spin or the predictions that Senator Fred Thompson's hearings may be undramatic. The hearings are likely to be critical to an understanding of what went wrong last year, and important information is already coming out.

title: 'Doll's House' Extended
description: ''A Doll's House,'' which had been scheduled to close on July 26, has extended its run at the Belasco Theater until Aug. 31. The cast remains unchanged. The play, which was brought over from London by the producer Bill Kenwright, won four Tony Awards, including best play revival. Janet McTeer, who plays Nora, won a Tony for best performance by a leading actress in a play, and Owen Teale, who plays Torvald, won as best featured actor in a play. The play also won a Tony for its director, Anthony Page.

title: Korean Bank Agency Concerned by Thai Move
description: South Korea's Bank Supervisory Board said yesterday that it was investigating whether Korean banks were taking heavy losses from last week's devaluation of the Thai currency. Newspapers reported that the devaluation, which caused the baht to fall as much as 13 percent against the dollar, would hurt Korean companies that have invested in Thailand.

title: Sport Through Kuralt's Eyes
description: ''Our visit could not have been nicer. You gave us everything any visitor could ask for. Just enough snowfall. Just enough sunshine. We have sunshine and snow back home, but your sun is brighter and your snow is whiter. Good as your snow-clad hills were for young folk to ski on, they were even better for just admiring silently from the edge of the wood.''

title: ZIONS BANCORP TO ACQUIRE GB BANCORP FOR $173 MILLION
description: Zions Bancorporation of Salt Lake City gained a foothold in the growing California market yesterday when it agreed to acquire GB Bancorp, a bank holding company based in San Diego, for $173 million in stock. Zions, with $7.2 billion in assets and branches in Utah, Arizona, Nevada and Colorado, will gain $720 million in assets and 14 branches in San Diego County. Zions, which had owned 4.5 percent of the company since 1995, will issue about 4.7 million shares to acquire the remainder of the closely held GB, worth $173 million based on its closing price yesterday. Zions will take a $2 million charge in the fourth quarter for related expenses. Also yesterday, Zions completed its acquisition of Kelling, Northcross & Nobriga, an investment bank in Oakland, Calif., that specializes in raising capital for public agencies.

title: Beetles May Stymie a Pretty but Prolific Marsh Weed
description: THE rampage of purple loosestrife, a pretty but pernicious weed that has choked wetland habitats from coast to coast, may soon be reversed. One million beetles that are natural enemies of the Eurasian plant will be released this summer in Federal and state wildlife areas across North America.

title: Strength in Diversity at Men's Shows
description: Fashion has proved time and again that even superficial goals have layers of meaning. So, it was a powerful shift when Gucci's designer, Tom Ford, changed the superficialities of men's fashion three years ago. Instead of gearing designer suits to make men look successful, powerful and established (the Armani goal), he made them younger, thinner and sexier. There was only one problem for the revitalized industry. Like the early Armani days, all suits started to look the same. It seemed that men who wanted to look older, robust and sexually repressed had nowhere to turn.

title: Hartz Mountain To Kirshenbaum

title: CALENERGY TO TAKE $136 MILLION CHARGE FOR TAX
description: The Calenergy Company said yesterday that it would take a one-time charge of $136 million, or $2.06 a share, in the third quarter to pay a tax levied against its British utility, Northern Electric P.L.C. The tax, which is expected to raise $:2.1 billion ($3.53 billion) from 19 electric companies, is meant to recoup what the Labor Government calls excess profit made by utilities that were sold to the public by the previous Conservative Government. Calenergy, based in Omaha, expected the tax to be enacted and created a reserve to cover the expense when it bought Northern Electric, for $1.5 billion, in December.

title: It's the Untouchables: Maddux vs. Johnson

title: Netanyahu Drops His Effort To Give Sharon New Post
description: After two weeks of furious infighting, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu bowed today to pressure from his Foreign Minister and abandoned efforts to name the veteran hawk Ariel Sharon to the Finance Ministry.

title: Investigation Is Broadened In Girl's Death
description: Voicing concern about the placement of a 4-year-old girl who died in foster care, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn asked a grand jury yesterday to investigate how the little girl ended up in the home of a woman who had been barred by another foster care agency from caring for children.

title: Crackdown Bleeds Kenya's Democracy Movement, Killing 7
description: Wielding ax handles, tear gas and rubber bullets, riot policemen crushed pro-democracy rallies across Kenya today, killing at least seven people and wounding dozens of others in the worst political violence in this relatively stable country since 1991.

title: Swiss Fund to Disburse Millions to Nazi Victims
description: The president of Switzerland's fund to compensate victims of Nazi atrocities said today that $11.7 million would be distributed to Holocaust survivors, most of them living in eastern Europe.

title: The Illegal Home Business: 'Speed' Manufacture
description: The police officers searching a modest home here on the outskirts of Kansas City late one recent afternoon encountered a perverse vision of Middle American domesticity.

title: Correction
description: A brief report on Wednesday in the Television Notes column about three HBO programs on drug abuse included an incorrect description, provided by HBO, of how a $3.3 million grant from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation was used. About $2.4 million paid for production costs and about $900,000 went toward an HBO educational project that is expected to cost $1.2 million or more. The grant did not go entirely toward production.

title: Paternity Issue Won't Go Away in Cosby Case
description: Lawyers for Autumn Jackson, the woman charged with trying to extort millions of dollars from Bill Cosby by claiming to be his out-of-wedlock daughter, clashed with prosecutors yesterday over a question that will not go away: Is he her father?

title: My John Travolta Dress
description: Fall 1985. A heavily embossed hand-written invitation arrived in the mail. Could the President and First Lady have the pleasure of my company at a White House dinner to honor the Prince and Princess of Wales? Black tie, cocktails, the works.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: OLD-FASHIONED ART -- Amid the neon of Times Square, artists toiled with brushes and stencils as work began on a mural outside the Roseland Ballroom. Metro Business, B6.

title: Volvo Expands Abbott Mead Role
description: The Volvo Car Corporation, a unit of Volvo A. B., has further expanded its relationship with Abbott Mead Vickers BBDOin London by naming that agency to create a campaign for the international introduction of a vehicle to be called the P23. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $96 million to $100 million.

title: Live Video Is Joining Sound on the Web
description: Steinway Hall is a small recital space in midtown Manhattan that accommodates 75 people. But when Jeffrey Biegel sits down to perform a piano recital there tonight, thousands of people around the world will be able to hear and see him on their home computers, thanks to a camcorder, digital technology and the Internet.

title: Red Lobster Said to Pick Euro RSCG Tatham
description: The Red Lobster restaurant chain, owned by Darden Restaurants Inc., has selected the Euro RSCG Tatham unit of Havas Advertising in Chicago to handle its account after 12 years at Grey Advertising in New York, advertising executives familiar with the decision said yesterday, speaking on condition of anonymity. Billings were estimated at $70 million to $90 million.

title: For Reproduction Doctors, the Science Is the Easy Part
description: In a brave new world where sperm is retrieved from dead men and a woman tends a baby she delivered at 63, a fertility specialist like Dr. Mark V. Sauer wrestles daily with ethical quandaries. And the one presented by the file on his desk at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center recently had him pinned.

title: What's in a Name? At Wyoming Butte, a Culture and a History
description: For millions of years, the gray volcanic plug has towered majestically over the surrounding plains, rising a quarter-mile into the sky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, DR. DEAN F. (PROFESSOR)
description: BERRY-Dr. Dean F. (Professor) of Charlestown, Boston on July 1. Son of Dorothy of Reno, Nevada and Glenn Berry (deceased). Father of Anne Kathryn Berry of Los Angeles. Margaret M. Pedani of Florence, Italy, Glenn C. Berry of San Francisco, and Alison E. Berry (deceased). Also survived by his former wife Kathryn KirklandHandley of London, England. Sister Kathleen Stumbo of Reno. Brother Bruce G. Berry of Groveland, Illinois and his fond partner Judy M. Livingston of Manchester, Vermont. Also survived by 11 nieces, nephews and cousins and countless former students, consulting colleagues and friends the world over. Funeral services at King's Chapel, 58 Tremont Street, Boston on Tuesday 8 July at 3PM. Family and friends are invited to celebrate Dean's life at an informal dinner 7 PM Tuesday evening at Florentina Restaurant, 145, Maine St., Cambridge. Memorial services will be conducted in London in September. Dean was a world renowned leader of management education and management thought. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College (BA), Indiana University (MA) and University of Michigan (Ph.D.). He was Dean of the INSEAD Graduate School of Business Administration in Fontainbleau, France, member of the faculties of The Harvard Business School, London Business School, Yale School of Organization and Management, and The Wharton School, and had been a Senior Partner in three international management consulting firms.

title: Scientists Meet Analytical Challenge of an Ephemeral Element
description: FOR 23 years scientists have known of a bizarre, man-made element that can be created only one atom at a time, each surviving for only a few seconds. Chemical analysis of this new element, recently named seaborgium, seemed out of the question.

title: Tunnel Bids to Be Opened
description: State officials are to open bids on a disputed $330 million traffic tunnel to Atlantic City casinos from three construction companies.

title: New Sailors and Cowpokes Join the Fun
description: New casts brought fresh merriment to two comedies when American Ballet Theater repeated its All-American Program on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: On the Fields of Mars
description: While the space shuttle Columbia circles the Earth on a routine mission and Russian cosmonauts try desperately to repair their stricken Mir space station, the real drama in space has been occurring some 120 million miles away, on the surface of Mars. There, a small robotic vehicle has been inching its way across the harsh, rocky landscape, and the Pathfinder spacecraft has been sending back the most spectacular images yet of the orange-and-gray surface of the planet.

title: Ferraro Weighs Race For D'Amato's Seat
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro said yesterday that she would probably seek the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato next year, attempting a political comeback that could recast what is already shaping up as one of the most competitive contests of 1998.

description: A teen-ager accused of killing her newborn asked a Delaware judge in Dover yesterday to reinstate a lawyer thrown off her murder case for violating the judge's order against discussing the case in public.

description: A former student accused of murdering Jonathan M. Levin told the police that two armed men forced him to tie up Mr. Levin while he was visiting the teacher in his Manhattan apartment and that he had fought with the men before managing to escape, according to court papers filed yesterday during the suspect's arraignment.

description: With each new color photograph from Mars Pathfinder, scientists are recognizing the awesome magnitude of a deluge that swept over much of the red planet billions of years ago, a catastrophe that perhaps only Noah could appreciate.

title: Giant German Retailer Seeks Warehouse Stores
description: Metro A.G., the German-based retailer that is Europe's largest, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the European warehouse stores of SHV Holdings N.V. for an estimated 5.2 billion marks ($3 billion). Metro Holding A.G., the Swiss company that owns 67 percent of Metro, already owns up to 40 percent of SHV's 86 membership-only Makro clubs. It is seeking to buy the rest from the family that owns SHV, which is based in Utrecht, the Netherlands.

title: Air Force Orders Lawyers to Review Procedures for Fairness
description: To insure fairness in its military justice system, the Air Force has ordered one of its bases to cease calling its legal newsletter Nooseletter and has ordered lawyers in a major command to eliminate any bias that may exist in their legal procedures.

title: Predictable Pedestrians
description: Physicists in Germany and the United States have invented a theoretical model, based on calculus, that they say can predict how pedestrians will create pathways across open grassy patches of city park.

title: Delays At First, And Then Delights
description: The first week of Wimbledon was, in the view of that expert commentator and four-time champion, Pete Sampras, ''weird.''

title: NORTHROP IN $1.9 BILLION PACT WITH MCDONNELL DOUGLAS
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a $1.9 billion agreement with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to produce parts for 80 Air Force military transport aircraft. The pact covers the years 1997 to 2002, with deliveries continuing into early 2004. It follows a 1996 agreement between the Air Force and McDonnell Douglas, which is based in St. Louis, to build an additional 80 C-17 military transport aircraft by 2004. Northrop is based in Los Angeles. Its commercial aircraft division produces components in Dallas and in Milledgeville, Ga., and Stuart, Fla. Last week, the Lockheed Martin Corporation announced plans to acquire Northrop Grumman for $8.3 billion.

title: Transfer Scheme Ends

title: Mets Manage to Keep Everyone Guessing
description: For a team that was part of baseball's first round of expansion in 1962, the Mets are steeped in tradition. The team's play in the first half of this season has reflected that history -- their early bizarre losses generating comparisons to Casey Stengel's Mets of '62 and their subsequent surge evoking memories of the '69 world champions.

title: A Taste of Democracy in Mexico
description: Mexico until Sunday was the world's most durable one-party state. The ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, dominated Mexico's government and politics for 68 years, using every autocratic weapon to maintain power, including rigged elections. When Mexican voters finally got the chance to express their views in fair elections on Sunday, the PRI monopoly collapsed. For the first time, Mexico has the makings of a multiparty democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAHILL, EUGENE P.
description: McCAHILL-Eugene P., of Fort Lauderdale passed away on July 6, 1997. Mr. McCahill was a Minneapolis businessman and philanthropist. Born 1898 in Duluth, Minnesota, he attended Loyola Academy in Chicago and graduated from Georgetown University Graduate School. He organized and was the first national chairman of the Georgetown Annual Giving Fund. He served for many years on the University's President's Council and the Board of Regents. Georgetown recognized his services by the awards of the President's Medal, the John Carroll Award, and an honorary degree of Doctor of Law. He was a naval aviator in World War I and served in World War II and the Korean War as a navy commander. He was engaged in a variety of business enterprises including iron mining, investment brokerage, and was president of the Home Gas Company, McCahill & Co., and the Duluth Utah Iron Mining Company. He was a co-founder, officer and director of the United Petroleum Company. He was active in many community organizations: he served on the St. Mary's Hospital Board of Advisors; was a trustee of the College of St. Catherine, from where he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters; he was an officer of the Navy League, the Serra International Foundation, and was a Knight Commander of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem. He is survived by his wife, Louise, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL; his sister, Mary Eleanor Denny of Sun City, AZ, and by many nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian burial will be offered at 11:00 A.M., Thursday, July 10, 1997 at St. Piux X Catholic Church, 2511 North Ocean Blvd, Fort Lauderdale, FL. An Interment service will be held at St. Mary's Cemetery, Lake City, MN. A memorial service will be offered at 10:00 A.M., Tuesday, July 15, 1997, at the Basilica of St. Mary, Minneapolis, MN. For information: Kraeer Funeral Home, 4061 North Federal Hwy, Fort Lauderdale, FL. Phone: 954-565-5591.

title: WEYERHAEUSER SELLS 30% STAKE IN PACIFIC PAPER
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it would sell 30 percent of a newsprint joint venture with Nippon Paper Industries to the Japanese company, giving the two 50 percent each. Weyerhaeuser now owns 80 percent of venture, the Pacific Paper Corporation, and Nippon Paper owns the other 20 percent. Pacific makes newsprint for sale in the United States and Japan. Terms were not disclosed. Pacific Paper generated $451 million in sales in 1996. Weyerhaeuser, of Tacoma, Wash., had total sales of $11.1 billion in 1996. Nippon Paper reported sales of 714 billion yen ($6.32 billion). Shares of Weyerhaeuser rose $3.5625, to $56.50.

title: Stand by Your Cat
description: When people discover that something in the house is making them sick, they get rid of it, right? Guess again. Not when that something is a dog or cat, a study of 341 adults in Vancouver, British Columbia, has reported. Many people would apparently rather suffer than part with the one member of the family who bestows unconditional love.

description: The Flagstar Companies said today that its creditors and shareholders had approved a restructuring plan, clearing the way for the company to file for bankruptcy protection.

title: Average Pay for College Professors Rises Less Than Inflation Rate
description: The average salary of college professors increased by 3 percent in the 1996-97 academic year, slightly less than the inflation rate, an annual survey by the American Association of University Professors showed.

title: SANTA FE ENERGY APPROVES MONTEREY RESOURCES SPINOFF
description: Santa Fe Energy Resources Inc. of Houston said yesterday that it had approved the spinoff of its stake in Monterey Resources Inc., an independent oil and gas company. Santa Fe Energy, also an independent oil and gas company, owns 45.3 million shares of Monterey common stock. In November, it sold about 17 percent of Monterey, which is based in Bakersfield, Calif., in an initial public offering. Santa Fe Energy said its shareholders would receive about 0.44 share of common stock in Monterey Resources and that the Internal Revenue Service had ruled the distribution to be tax free to the company and its shareholders. Its shares closed yesterday at $15.4375, up 18.75 cents. Monterey was unchanged at $14.8125.

title: Iberia Air Lines Hires Tiempo BBDO
description: Iberia Air Lines of Spain has named the Tiempo BBDO unit of BBDO Worldwide in Madrid and Barcelona to handle its consolidated domestic and international account, with billings estimated at $30 million. The account had been divided between Casadevall Pedreno & PRG in Barcelona, for domestic assignments, and Grey Advertising in Madrid for the international work.

title: Personal Health
description: AFTER cancer, the health problem that most frightens Americans is blindness. Yet surprisingly few people, including those who are otherwise health-conscious, get their eyes checked regularly. A thorough eye examination every two or three years is considered adequate for people under 50 with no known visual problems. But for people older than that, most experts recommend an annual checkup that, in addition to assessing visual acuity, tests for disorders like glaucoma, cataracts and macular degeneration, all of which become more common with age and can cause severe visual impairment.

title: Taiwan to Increase Insider Trading Penalty
description: A panel at the Taiwan Ministry of Finance has decided to increase penalties for insider trading to a maximum of seven years in prison from two years, local newspapers reported yesterday. Major shareholders of a company will be defined as those holding ownership of 5 percent or more in a company. The rule now applies to those holding 10 percent or above, the reports said.

title: Jury Is Sworn in the Cosby Case
description: A jury was sworn in yesterday in the trial of Autumn Jackson, the 22-year-old woman charged with trying to extort money from Bill Cosby by claiming to be his out-of-wedlock daughter, and opening statements are scheduled for today.

description: As an erstwhile actor in movie melodramas about Government infighting, Senator Fred Thompson should know by now what it means to be upstaged.

title: Historic Liberty Hall Donated
description: Built in 1772 as a 14-room Georgian manor house, Liberty Hall was the home of New Jersey's first post-Revolutionary Governor, William Livingston. The house, converted in the 19th century into a Greek revival-style mansion, remained in the family, but has been vacant since the death in 1995 of Mary Alice Barney Kean, a descendant of Governor Livingston. Mrs. Kean's husband was the uncle of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey.

title: Mars History: Heat and Cold Leave Marks
description: The first chemical analysis of a rock on Mars shows unmistakable traces of the planet's complex and tumultous geological history, marked by repeated cycles of internal melting, cooling and remelting that produced an abundance of telltale quartz, the Mars mission scientists announced today.

title: BELGIAN BANK TO ACQUIRE HARBOR CAPITAL MANAGEMENT
description: Generale de Banque S.A., Belgium's largest bank, will buy the Harbor Capital Management Company, a Boston asset management firm with about $4.7 billion in assets, for less than $100 million, said a person involved in the transaction. The acquisition will be Generale de Banque's first of a United States money management firm. A rough rule of thumb is that money management firms are sold for about 2 percent of their assets. If that applies here, Generale de Banque would acquire Harbor Capital for about $94 million. Harbor Capital Management is about 85 percent-owned by employees, with the rest held by Julius Baer Holding A.G. of Zurich.

title: The Years Under Deng: Both Booms And Regrets
description: ''China: Born Under the Red Flag'' concludes the ambitious three-part PBS history that began with ''China in Revolution'' and continued with ''The Mao Years.'' Tonight's two hours cover the Deng years, from the death of Mao Zedong in 1976 and the ascendancy of Deng Xiaoping to Deng's death in February. It is a story of economic resurgence and political repression, of astounding successes and intractable problems.

title: Hong Kong Chief Moves to Reduce Influence of Political Parties
description: Hong Kong's new government, which took office with the former British colony's handover to China a week ago, moved today to establish a new electoral system that is likely to reduce the number of pro-democracy members in future legislatures while insuring dominance of pro-business and pro-Beijing lawmakers.

title: Just Another Retail Bankruptcy? Maybe Not.
description: When Montgomery Ward filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this week, pundits were quick to draw an analogy with R. H. Macy & Company, which filed for Chapter 11 in 1992, only to be bought in 1994 by Federated Department Stores. Both Montgomery Ward and Macy are big companies whose names have well-known cultural associations among shoppers, both ooze retail history and mythology, and each lost its way as time caught up with it.

title: Low Bids on Atlantic City Road Please State
description: The developers of a road and tunnel project meant to open the way for new casinos in Atlantic City's marina district received bids on the construction costs today, and New Jersey officials said the bids were in line with their own estimate.

description: A single-engine plane crashed in the water between Jones Beach and Point Lookout on Long Island yesterday, killing all three people on board, the authorities said.

title: Saks Renews Lease At 49th St. Tower
description: Saks & Company has renewed its lease at Tower 49, the 45-story building at 12 East 49th Street, in a deal that could eventually allow the retailer to expand into about half the building's office space.

title: DRAVO SAYS COMPANY IS NO LONGER UP FOR SALE
description: The Dravo Corporation, a producer of lime products, said yesterday that a nine-month search for a buyer had been unsuccessful and that the company was no longer for sale. The Pittsburgh-based company said it would focus instead on internal growth and acquisitions. Dravo said in October that it was exploring options that included buying another company and forming joint ventures as well as selling itself. That effort ''failed to produce a transaction favorable to the best interests of shareholders,'' the company said. Dravo's shares fell 56.25 cents, to $10.0625.

title: AMERICAN RADIO WILL PAY $70.25 MILLION FOR MICRONET
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation of Boston said yesterday that its American Tower Systems unit had agreed to buy Micronet Inc. for $70.25 million. Micronet, based in Jamison, Pa., is an antenna site provider in the Middle Atlantic region, with 127 towers in service and others under development. The closely held Micronet also owns 20 towers in Los Angeles and San Francisco and 35 towers in Texas. American Tower Systems is also acquiring Micronet's video transport operations, which transport video, voice and data by satellite and terrestrial microwave networks. After the acquisition, American Tower Systems will own or manage more than 600 tower sites. American Radio's shares fell 50 cents, to $40.25.

title: Not So Fast on Immunity

title: Swiss Jobless Rate Falls Again, to 5.1%
description: Switzerland's unemployment rate fell in June to a lower-than-expected 5.1 percent, in the fourth successive decline. The report provided another sign that Europe's slowest economy was stirring after six years of no growth. There were 185,320 people out of work at the end of June, down from 192,091 in May, bringing the unemployment rate down two-tenths of a percentage point.

title: Bayer Aims to Break Barrier for U.S. in Foil
description: Whenever Cliff Bayer reaches a crest -- after a hard climb -- he finds another summit beyond, one ever higher. His grit, his determination to go on, remain with him.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, DANIEL J.
description: LYONS-Daniel J., 92, died July 3 at his home in Princeton, NJ. Born in Randolph, MA., he was the son of Elizabeth G. and Timothy F. Lyons. Beloved husband of Irene M. Lyons and devoted father of Jean L. Entwistle, Daniel J. Lyons, Jr., Paul O. Lyons and Irene L. Madden; nine grandchildren and a sister, Sr. Marion Lyons, SCH, of Wellesley MA. A graduate of Thayer Academy and Harvard University, Cum Laude, 1926. He was President and Chairman of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America in New York City and member of the Board until the present. Mass of the Christian Burial at St. Paul's Church on Tuesday morning, burial in Princeton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to St. Paul's Church Building Fund, 214 Nassau Street, Princeton, New Jersey 08540, or to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: South Africans Apologize to Family of American Victim
description: The four young men who were convicted of killing Amy Biehl, an American Fulbright scholar who was chased, stoned and then stabbed to death in a black township in 1993, apologized to her family today as they sought amnesty for her killing.

title: If They Can Make It There
description: New York City continues to be the hottest place to set a network show. About a dozen new fall series will have the city as their locale. And one that was planned to be set out of town is relocating to Manhattan.

title: Dow Surges 103.82 Points, to 7,962.31
description: The stock market soared to record levels again yesterday on growing optimism about corporate profits and a stable economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGINSKY, SELMA (NEE SLEPIAN)
description: MAGINSKY-Selma (nee Slepian). Beloved wife of Victor. Devoted mother of Jacqueline MaginskyTierney and Robin. Loving sister of Dr. Howard Slepian and the late Jean Sussman. Cherished aunt and cousin. Services Wednesday, 1:00PM Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Henry E. Howell Jr., 76, Leader Of Liberal Democrats in Virginia
description: Henry Evans Howell Jr., a populist-style liberal Virginia Democrat who irked party old-liners so much that they banded with conservative Republicans to end his political career in 1977, died on Monday at his home in Norfolk. He was 76.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Martha's Vineyard, all it takes to assemble a celebrity crowd for a worthy cause is a few phone calls to people like MIKE WALLACE.

title: Family Planning Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher Education's High Costs
description: State colleges and universities spend an estimated $30 million above the national average on building and maintenance costs, according to a six-month study that was released yesterday.

title: Kenya's Hard Line: President Gambles on Crackdown
description: By violently crushing pro-democracy demonstrations across Kenya on Monday, President Daniel arap Moi has gambled that opposition leaders seeking to rewrite the nation's Constitution do not have enough popular support to weather a brutal police campaign against them.

title: Irabu Plays Game Of Catch With Yankees' Girardi
description: The dress rehearsal for Hideki Irabu's much-anticipated debut at Yankee Stadium tomorrow night took place before 57,545 empty blue seats yesterday morning. It included more hand signals than actual pitches, as many interpreters as actual Yankees and a serene atmosphere that will change to actual bedlam when the Japanese pitcher unleashes his first official fastball.

title: The Ringmaster in Le Cirque 2000's Hectic Dream Kitchen
description: ''LET'S go here, let's go!'' Sottha Khunn was exhorting his troops to cook harder and faster, his voice raised ever so slightly. By 8 P.M. on a Tuesday in late spring, the waiters at Le Cirque 2000 were running, not walking. Sirio Maccioni, the owner, had already been to the kitchen twice, the first time to look for an order that had not arrived quickly enough and the second time to tell Mr. Khunn, in French, to set aside his job as expediter, take to the stove and make a special dish himself.

title: Food Notes
description: A Sarabeth's for Chelsea

title: Face-Off
description: Bill Clinton should not fret over his legacy. He has done a remarkable job of transforming his party.

title: Mexico's President Triumphs in Defeat
description: Although President Ernesto Zedillo's governing party suffered a sweeping defeat in the elections on Sunday, the President himself has emerged a winner, as opposition leaders credit him with taking a major step toward consolidating Mexican democracy.

title: VANSTAR BUYS SYSOREX INFORMATION FOR $52.9 MILLION
description: The Vanstar Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Sysorex Information Systems Inc. for as much as $52.9 million as Vanstar seeks to expand its computer network sales and consulting operations. The Houston-based Vanstar said it paid $46 million in cash and assumed debt and that it might also offer 500,000 shares to Sysorex, contingent on the future performance of the acquired business. The shares would be worth $6.9 million based on yesterday's closing stock price of $13.75, up 50 cents. Last year, Vanstar had sales of $2.2 billion while Sysorex, based in Fairfax, Va., had sales of $150 million.

title: Healy a Leaf, Leaving Rangers' Net a Little Bare
description: Glenn Healy, a goalie for the Rangers in the Stanley Cup season of 1994, signed as an unrestricted free agent with the Toronto Maple Leafs yesterday. His departure for a three-year contract that will pay him almost $4 million leaves the Rangers with an opening for the backup position behind Mike Richter.

title: At Commerce Dept., No More Flash a la Ron Brown
description: As Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown was a master at using powerful political symbols. Jetting around the world practicing what he called ''commercial diplomacy,'' he often traveled with an entourage of big-name chief executives and insisted that the Air Force play the role of chauffeur.

title: Clause in Rent Law Is Said to Allow Extra Rises for Some Apartments
description: State housing officials said yesterday that a provision of the rent-regulation law signed last month by Gov. George E. Pataki will temporarily allow landlords to raise rents on vacant apartments in New York City more steeply than first expected.

title: NATO Plus Three
description: The grand declarations, rippling flags and bright sunshine in Madrid yesterday could not obscure the serious differences within NATO over how far and fast it should grow. Those divisions may ultimately defeat the purpose of expansion, which President Clinton heralded as the creation of a Europe that for the first time is undivided, democratic and at peace.

title: British by Birthright
description: To the Editor:

title: Huang May Yet Testify to Senate Panel
description: The Senate committee investigating campaign finances began public hearings today with tantalizing suggestions of revelations to come and the first indication that John Huang, a central figure in the inquiry, might actually testify.

title: From Blackjack to Bat Crack
description: By next April, visitors to Atlantic City may be able to trade a seat at the blackjack table for one in the bleachers. Ground was broken yesterday for a minor league baseball stadium for the Atlantic City Surf, one of seven teams in the independent Atlantic League.

title: The Pop Life
description: Now that mainstream American audiences are beginning to embrace electronic dance music, perhaps next they will embrace the music's messengers, the disk jockeys.

title: A Law Office Like Any Other, Almost
description: Wood paneling. Muted colors. Hushed hallways. Open staircases among the floors. Neat rows of uniformly bound volumes filling the library shelves. Views of the Hudson River and Upper New York Bay.

title: Filling Stations' Owner Held in Fraud and Killings
description: An immigrant who rose from gas-station attendant to multimillionaire owner of a string of stations has been defrauding customers at the pump for years and ordered at least three murders, in part to cover up his schemes, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Metuchen Diocese Gets New Bishop
description: Msgr. Vincent D. Breen, the Vicar of Education for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, was named by the Vatican yesterday to be Bishop of the Diocese of Metuchen, in central New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, REV. FREDERIC M.
description: O'CONNOR-Rev. Frederic M., S.J. (of the Westside Jesuit Community). Survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Jesuit Residence, 53 East 83rd Street, Wednesday 3:00-5:00PM and 7:009:00PM and Thursday 3:00-5:00PM Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, 8:00PM at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church at Park Avenue and 84th Street. Interment Friday 12:30PM at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHRLICK, MILDRED VAN PRAAG
description: ROHRLICK-Mildred Van Praag, age 79, on July 6, 1997. Longtime resident of Palm Beach and formerly New York City and Montreal, Quebec. Beloved wife of the late Louis H. Rohrlick, Q.C. and a great friend to many people. Graveside service is on July 8th, at 12:30 P.M., at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, New York. Donations in Mildred's memory to your favorite charity or if you prefer Hospice of Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Questions Are More Plentiful for M.L.S.
description: With Major League Soccer's second All-Star Game to be played tonight at Giants Stadium, Commissioner Doug Logan speaks of the league in terms of giving birth.

title: German Unemployment Up by 11,000 in June
description: The number of unemployed in Germany rose by 11,000 in June, to 4.374 million, as an economic upturn failed to make a dent in jobless rolls, the Federal Labor Office said yesterday. The rise in the jobless rolls, which is adjusted for seasonal influences, was a bit larger than expected. Unemployment fell by 1,000 in western Germany. In eastern Germany, which makes up a tenth of the economy, jobless rolls swelled by 12,000.

title: Traditional Meatballs, Only Faster
description: It never seemed possible to me to make a spaghetti and meatball dish in 30 minutes, not because it needed to simmer for hours and hours, but because there supposedly wasn't enough time to shape the meatballs.

title: Fox Channel Concerts
description: For months, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has waged an unsuccessful battle to have its Fox News Channel carried by Time Warner on its New York City cable system. Now Fox is trying to draw an audience with weekly concerts outside the studios at company headquarters in midtown Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Dr. Jenny R. Bramley on June 2 incorrectly described the doctorate in physics she received at New York University in 1929. It was not the first awarded to a woman by an American university. (One compilation lists 26 women who earned doctorates in physics before 1929.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGE, DAVID L., JR.
description: GEORGE-David L., Jr., of Hawley, PA., and formerly from Pelham, New York, died suddenly Sunday, July 6, 1997. He graduated from Lawrenceville Schools in 1964 & Denver University. He was the son of David L. and Margaret Trimpi George of Hawley, PA. In addition to his parents, he is survived by a brother William T. George of White Mills, PA. Memorial contribution may be made to Hawley Public Library, Main Avenue, Hawley, PA. 18428.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, JACK
description: DAVID-Jack. Congregation Orach Chaim mourns the passing of its devoted member and extends heartfelt condolences to his sons Steven and Marvin. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Wolf Scheck, President

description: GOLDSMITH-Irvin J. On July 8, 1997, beloved husband of Theresa, adored father of James, and daughter-in-law of Kathleen, cherished grandfather of David, Jonathan, and Robert. We mourn the loss of a unique and precious human being. He leaves a legacy of devotion and love for his family and the world. Funeral services are on July 10, 1997 at the J. Smith Funeral Home, 862 Route 6, Mahopac, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Beth Shalom, 780 Route 6, Mahopac, New York 10541.
