description: FRANK-Theresa (nee) Steinberg. On July 8, 1997. Devoted mother of Eloise Malek. Beloved sister of Dr. Gertrude Stern. Loving aunt of Alice Stern, Kenneth Stern and Marjorie Slome. Adored great aunt of Daniel Slome Stern and Emily Slome Stern. President of Erasmus Hall Alumni Association. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, Riverside Funeral Chapel, 310 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: A Queens Man, 70, Is Dead After an Attack by a Pit Bull
description: A 70-year-old retired cement worker from Queens, described by family and friends as a dog lover, died of heart failure yesterday after he was attacked by a neighbor's pit bull, the police said.

title: Shopping for U.S. Insurer, Dutch Giant Buys in Iowa
description: ING Groep N.V., the Dutch financial giant, is carving out a chunk of the American life insurance market at a high price, $2.2 billion, but it is also ready to spend billions more to fulfill its ambitions in the American financial markets.

title: The Declaration, Too, Was Real and Imagined
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about 11 House Republicans known as deficit hawks misstated the position of one of them, Representative Mark W. Neumann of Wisconsin, on the re-election of Speaker Newt Gingrich last January. He voted simply ''present,'' not in favor of the Speaker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWERLING, IRVING
description: ZWERLING-Irving. Age 69. Died Monday July 7, 1997 among family members at his home in New York City. A devoted and loving husband and father as well as a brilliant lawyer. Irving will be missed by his wife of forty years Michele, his 3 daughters Caroline, Fabienne and Patricia, his son-inlaw Michael and his three grandchildren Justin, Gabby and Dylan. Mr. Zwerling will be cremated and services will be private.

title: A Tribute To an All-Star Grandmother
description: THE small black ribbon was pinned to the chest of Sandy Alomar Jr.'s white Cleveland Indians uniform. Another small black ribbon was on Roberto Alomar's white Baltimore Orioles uniform.

title: Jefferson's Annotations
description: To the Editor:

title: Lemon Verbena: From Sorbet to Soap
description: IT seems that lemon verbena's time has finally come. At last, a plant to grow, a fresh herb to use for flavoring and dried leaves to brew -- all in one.

title: Still Reeling From the Day Death Came to Birmingham
description: ''Four Little Girls'' is Spike Lee's immensely dignified and moving reassessment of a terrorist crime. This watershed moment in the history of the civil rights movement, the bombing on Sept. 15, 1963, of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., left four young Sunday school students dead (the oldest were 14) and a nation galvanized by outrage and shame. Thirty-four years later, Mr. Lee and the many witnesses he interviews are able to see both the tragedy and the turning point in this event.

title: On NATO Coup, Russia's Shadow
description: American officials were busy measuring themselves for cloaks of historical glory in Madrid this afternoon.

title: Tsingtao Brewery Plans Growth in Eastern China
description: The Tsingtao Brewery Company, China's largest beer exporter, will sell businesses, including taxi services and restaurants, to buy breweries in eastern China, a spokeswoman said yesterday. The move by the company, which owns one of China's most famous brand names, is part of a strategy of acquiring small plants.

title: Puerto Rico Produces Stars
description: Puerto Rico, which has a rich baseball tradition, wrote an impressive new chapter tonight as island-born players dominated the 68th annual All-Star Game.

title: Morgan Keegan Deal
description: Morgan Keegan Inc. said today that it would buy the assets of Knox, Wall & Company for an undisclosed amount. Knox, based in Atlanta, is a closely held municipal bond dealer. It will operate as a division of Morgan Keegan & Company, the brokerage subsidiary of Morgan Keegan Inc. Morgan Keegan is a securities broker operating in the Southeast.

title: Give Parents Help, Not Condemnation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Band That Lights the British Fire
description: The British passion for brass bands strikes American listeners as a quaint, perhaps mildly eccentric taste, mainly because it has been conveyed as such in dozens of oblique mentions in films and television programs, to say nothing of Monty Python sketches. But these ensembles have an interesting history, having started as a pastime for coal miners in the mid-19th century. Competitions for brass bands fostered a measure of professionalism and polish in the best ensembles, and as coal mines closed and miners were replaced by graduates from music colleges, the performance level has continued to rise.

title: Lilco Plan From Pataki Is Assailed In a Report
description: In a sharp critique of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, the Suffolk County Legislature issued a report from consultants today that denounced the proposal as ''a worst-case scenario.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about NASA's mission to Mars misidentified the particles emitted by a spectrometer on the roving vehicle Sojourner to determine the chemical elements in rocks. They are alpha particles, not protons.

title: Library Cuts a Service
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ratings Compromise
description: Thanks to written assurances from politicians who introduced ''V-chip'' into the television world's vocabulary, the drawn-out struggle over adding V, S and L to the television ratings system may finally stumble to a close this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCQUILLEN, HARRY III, ALOYSIUS
description: MCQUILLEN-Harry III, Aloysius. Family, friends and collegues announce a memorial in honor of Harry Aloysius McQuillen III. The service will be held on Thursday, July 10th at 3 PM in the auditorium of the Equitable Center, 787 7th Avenue between 51st and 52nd Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Mr. McQuillen's memory to the Cardinal Hayes High School Fitness Center, care of K-III Communications, 745 5th Avenue, New York, NY 10151.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENKEL, TOBIAS
description: FRENKEL-Tobias. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Tobias Frenkel. We extend profound condolences to his son and daughter-in-law, William and Gigi Frenkel, to his children, grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Thailand Says It Plans To Borrow $10 Billion
description: In a step that would increase Thailand's debt by a third, the Government plans to borrow $10 billion in the next six months to spur the economy and bail out the finance industry, a Government official said yesterday. The Government, which devalued its currency last week, is negotiating to borrow $5 billion from foreign banks, said Poosana Premanoch, deputy chief of staff to Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh. Another $5 billion is to be raised by selling international bonds.

title: Is Sampras the Best?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Room Where Cheese Takes Its Time
description: Ten years ago, Ihsan Gurdal visited his first cheese cave. It was a natural limestone cave on the outskirts of Paris, where cheeses ripened in cool, damp, still air until they were precisely ready to be eaten.

title: U.S. Groups Are Addressing the Plight of Israel's Ethiopian Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Counterpoint to a Sport's Brawling Image
description: EARLY yesterday morning, Lonnie Bradley, a middleweight boxing champion, looked out of a car window in Central Park and reflected on his career and his chosen profession.

description: JIRAK-Mary. We also wish to extend our heartfelt sympathy to the rest of the Gural/Jirak families. Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. William Cohen Ronald Goldberger Barry Gosin Aaron Gural Ira Fishman James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post and Arthur Rosenbloom.

description: LUBETKIN-Alice Green. Age 91 on July 7, 1997, following a long illness. Cherished grandmother of Jordan, Dylan, William and Alexander. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, July 9th 6-9 PM. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Wellesley College, in care of the Office of Resources, Wellesley, Massachusetts 02181.

title: The End of Yalta
description: How many Americans know the difference between Slovenia and Slovakia?

title: A Writer Finds Magic in a Film Genre
description: ''I always thought this was a noirish corner,'' said Nicholas Christopher, his white jacket faintly green in the atomic glow of a Greenwich Village vapor lamp. Overhead, in contrasting light and shadow, two street signs angled like a dagger blade marked the inexplicable intersection of a street with itself: Waverly Place meeting Waverly Place.

title: Mellow Old Rums, Worthy of a Snifter
description: IT was off-season in Barbados some years back, and the little beach hotel had only one guest, me. I became friendly with the young owner, and one night at the outdoor bar, he said: ''Rum is getting low. Want to go out with me tomorrow and see one of our distilleries?''

title: Devils to Turn to Youth After Losses
description: All the claims by the Devils about the enormous depth and diligent development of young players in their system will be put to a severe test this fall after last week's loss to free agency of Shawn Chambers and Dave Ellett, two of their regulars on defense last season.

title: Power and Reversal
description: When the State Legislature took away most of the authority of local school boards in New York City last year, its leaders loftily declared that they were cleansing the system of patronage, mismanagement and, most of all, politics. Yet as the recent dispute over the hiring of a district superintendent in Queens shows, the Legislature may have reordered the balance of power in the system, but it did not remove the politics.

title: Puccini Joins New Traditions at Glyndebourne
description: LEWES, England, July 4

title: Justice Dept. Closes Case on a Nominee
description: The Justice Department told several leading Senators today that it had concluded its inquiry into the personal finances of George J. Tenet, clearing the way for him to be confirmed by the Senate as the next Director of Central Intelligence.

title: David Anderson, 60, Ex-Envoy to Belgrade
description: David Anderson, a United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia in the 1980's, died on July 4 in Berlin. He was 60.

title: Wildlife at the Window
description: On an overcast evening about a year ago, I was sanding the walls in my upstairs bathroom when I heard a tremendous crashing in the alders just outside my opened window. I looked down at a cow moose with two copper calves. I recognized the cow, an old girl with a scar on her right shoulder. I'd seen her earlier in the year with a grown calf. Now she had new twins, perhaps 2 weeks old.

title: Cambodia Victors Kill Off Losers, Raising the Specter of a Civil War
description: Forces loyal to the Second Prime Minister, Hun Sen, began hunting down and killing some of his political opponents today and Cambodia faced the possibility of repressive strongman rule and even a descent into civil war.

title: Investigation of Kennedy Sex Case Is Halted
description: The authorities have halted an investigation into accusations that Michael Kennedy, a son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, had sex with his children's baby sitter when she was under age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ETHEL
description: WILSON-Ethel. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to Richard, Marc and Steven on the loss of their beloved mother. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mark Spund, Pres. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Travel on the Mind
description: IT has long been known that international business travel poses health risks like exposure to infectious diseases. However, business travelers are also three times as likely to suffer psychological problems as their stay-at-home colleagues, a recent study by the World Bank has found.

title: 2 Popular Diet Pills Linked to Problems With Heart Valves
description: Doctors at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., and at a medical clinic in Fargo, N.D., said yesterday that a very rare heart ailment had appeared in 24 women who took a popular diet pill combination. Their report has prompted the Food and Drug Administration to send warnings to thousands of doctors.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Metro Section last Wednesday described a book that profiles New York State Supreme Court Justices from the point of view of lawyers who argue cases before them. The article was accompanied by a chart that included some of the lawyers' quotations about three judges, Nicholas A. Clemente, Nicholas Colabella and Emily Jane Goodman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROLL, GILBERT HALLADAY
description: CROLL-Gilbert Halladay, 79, of Naples, FL. Captain USMC. Long time member Beaverkill Trout Club. Survived by Barbara Croll Burling, Rumson, NJ and Samuel W. Croll, Jr., E. Orleans, MA.

title: Indonesia Reins In Property Developers
description: Alarmed by Thailand's financial crisis, Indonesia has become the latest Asian country to rein in its real estate developers. Bank Indonesia, the central bank, said on Monday that it was prohibiting new loans to property companies for land purchases and that existing land holdings could not be used as collateral for new loans. It said that while banks' exposure to the property industry ''is still within a reasonable amount,'' the new measures are ''to anticipate undesirable conditions.''

title: Mourning for North Korea Leader Ends, but Son Is Not Anointed
description: North Korea reportedly declared an end today to the official three-year mourning period for its late leader, Kim Il Sung, clearing the way for his son, Kim Jong Il, to assume full power.

title: Nevada Hits Tyson With Fine and Loss Of Boxing License
description: Mike Tyson received the strictest penalty possible under Nevada rules today when the State Athletic Commission voted unanimously to revoke his boxing license and fine him $3 million for biting Evander Holyfield's ears in their June 28 heavyweight title fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABAZZ, DR. BETTY
description: SHABAZZ-Dr. Betty. The Women's Leadership Forum of the DNC acknowledges with deepest regret the passing of Dr. Betty Shabazz, an active and outstanding member since the Forum's inception. The knowledge, experience, depth, and humanity Dr. Shabazz brought to our discourse will be greatly missed. May those who survive her be comforted by fond memories of her warm smile and the kindness she shared with all who knew her. Cynthia Friedman, National Chair

description: CUNNION-Paul A., on July 7, 1997. Director of Philippine-American Chamber of Commerce. Husband of Kathleen (Muffin) McGrath Cunnion. In lieu of flowers contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated.

title: 3Com-Siemens Alliance Formed
description: The 3Com Corporation and Siemens A.G. announced a broad alliance today aimed at developing products to integrate data and voice networks. The alliance would include a significant expansion of the four-year-old reselling agreement the two companies already have in place, officials said.

title: Long Island's Prosperity
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Indecisive: The Temporary House Purchase
description: Like a delicious summer novel, a tale of intrigue, real estate and a dark-haired woman in a Mercedes-Benz is unfolding in southwestern Connecticut, where brokers and agents have been alerted to be on their guard for a possible serial home buyer.

title: Third Management Shake-Up At McDonald's in Two Years
description: With sales once again faltering in its domestic operations after an interlude of growth early this year, the McDonald's Corporation announced today that it would shift responsibility for a wide range of operating and marketing decisions from its corporate staff to five newly created regional divisions.

title: Celery Vase: An Antique Cooler Revived
description: SHOPPERS foraging through flea markets and antiques shops for affordable collectibles might consider celery vases. They look like oversize parfait glasses, but between 1820 and 1900, these 8- to 12-inch-tall vases were made to hold cold water and the salad of their day, celery or carrot sticks. Now, celery vases can hold flowers, spoons, bread sticks -- even celery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CICERO, MICHAEL J.
description: CICERO-Michael J. Founder and President of the Michael J. Cicero Civic Association and President of the Virginia Michael J. Cicero Foundation, Inc. He passed away on July 9 at Seaview Community Rehabilitation Center on Staten Island. He leaves behind thirty nieces and nephews who live in the New York area. He is laid out at the Virginia Funeral Chapel, 1707 Highland Blvd, Staten Island, July 10 and 11, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass at St. Sylvester's Church in Concord, Staten Island Saturday, July 12 at 10 AM.

title: SHARES OF TALBOTS FALL 20.5% ON NEWS OF EXPECTED LOSS
description: Shares of Talbots Inc. fell 20.5 percent yesterday after the retailer said it would lose money in the second quarter. Analysts had expected Talbots to post a profit, and its shares dropped $5.9375, to $23.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The retailer, based in Hingham, Mass., said after the close of markets on Tuesday that it expected to report a loss of $9 million to $12 million in the current quarter. The company also said that Clark J. Hinkley, 55, the chief operating officer who had also been in charge of merchandising, had stepped down. He will remain as executive vice president in charge of manufacturing.

title: Executive Changes
description: MILLER INDUSTRIES, Atlanta, a maker of towing and recovery equipment, named its chairman, William G. Miller, and its president, Jeffrey I. Badgley, co-chief executives.

title: Valderrama Stars Anew, But Fans Stay Home
description: Last year, when Major League Soccer combined its All-Star Game as part of a doubleheader with another match involving world stars, 78,416 fans turned out, making it a huge success. Tonight's match between the league's two conferences was the only game in town and, on a stormy night, drew less than a third of last year's crowd -- 24,816 -- to Giants Stadium. But what a game it was.

title: Imperial Prizes Given To Five in the Arts
description: The architect Richard Meier and the sculptor George Segal are among the winners of the 1997 Praemium Imperiale, or Imperial Prize, the Japan Art Association announced yesterday. The awards are given annually by the association for outstanding lifetime achievement in arts not recognized by the Nobel Prizes.

title: Messinger, in Campaign Kickoff, Says Giuliani Caters to the Rich
description: Ruth W. Messinger set out yesterday to define her campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, portraying him as a servant of the city's upper classes who had neglected the concerns of New Yorkers who rely on public schools, public hospitals and other basic municipal services.

title: Clinton Gives Few Details On Recommending Huang
description: President Clinton today played down his role in the Democratic National Committee's hiring of John Huang as a fund-raiser, saying he would have ''referred virtually anybody's name to the party'' if that person had volunteered to raise money for the campaign.

title: Deal on Making Ratings for TV Specify Content
description: Negotiators for the television industry and family advocacy groups reached an agreement last night on expanding the industry's six-month-old ratings system to include code letters for violence, sexual content and foul language, ending more than a year of contentiousness on the subject.

title: DANAHER MAKES HOSTILE OFFER FOR EXIDE ELECTRONICS
description: The Danaher Corporation announced a hostile takeover offer yesterday for Exide Electronics Group Inc. worth $20 a share, or $200 million. Exide's shares surged 60.2 percent in Nasdaq trading, gaining $7.75, to $20.625. Danaher's shares slipped 6.25 cents, to $49.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Danaher, based in Washington, makes tools and manufacturing equipment. Exide, based in Raleigh, N.C., makes products that protect computers and other electronic equipment from power disruptions. Danaher previously offered to acquire Exide for $22 a share, the company said, but Exide rejected that bid.

title: Mars Probe Finds Kittens
description: The newly arrived probe to Mars has returned irrefutable evidence that the red planet is populated with approximately 27 million 3-month-old kittens.

title: Tie Vote Blocks F.C.C. Inquiry On Liquor Ads
description: A deadlocked Federal Communications Commission handed President Clinton a temporary defeat today, blocking a proposed investigation into the advertising of hard liquor on television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSTAD, MARTIN HUGO
description: OLSTAD-Martin Hugo. Died July 5, 1997 in his 92nd year. Beloved father of Martin D., Carolyn Somer, and the late Dr. Walter B. Olstad. He is also survived by his brother J. Walter Olstad and two sisters Thyra Utz and Rachel Valentine, as well as 8 grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A native of Long Island, New York, Martin (Spike) Olstad was a son of sea captain Martin T. and Aagot D. Olstad of Greenport, New York. He received B.A., B.S., and M.S. Degrees from Columbia University. He was the President and Chief Executive Officer of the Niagara Blower Company, Buffalo, New York. Spike married Helen D. Oskison in 1929, residing in Port Washington, Long Island. Following Helen's passing in 1988, he moved to Collington, Mitchelville, Maryland, and married Alice Peterson, a close family friend, in September 1991. Alice passed away in June 1996. A memorial service will be held 2 PM, Monday, July 14th at the Collington Chapel. A service in the Southold, Long Island, New York Presbyterian Church will be held 11 AM, August 9, 1997. Memorials may be made to the Collington Fellowship Fund, 10450 Lottsford Road, Mitchelville, Maryland 20721.

title: A Carnival Of Beasts By the Light Of the Moon
description: One character is turned into a bag of potato chips. Another dies having sex with a grizzly bear. A third meets her end in a mink trap, wearing a $10,000 mink coat. Most of this happens, mercifully, offstage in ''Incident at Cobbler's Knob,'' written by David Sedaris and his sister Amy Sedaris, who like to call themselves the Talent Family. (To some fans, of course, Mr. Sedaris will always be Crumpet the Macy's elf from his essay and radio skit ''The Santaland Diaries.'')

title: For Puerto Rico, an All-Star Link

title: The split over punitive awards in getting the bad guys.
description: IN last month's proposed tobacco settlement, cigarette manufacturers apparently got what they coveted most: immunity from punitive damages. And while anti-tobacco groups are now at each other's throats over whether they exacted a sufficient price in return, everyone agrees that the potential for sky-high punitive damage awards in individual injury suits immensely strengthened their bargaining power. ''It's the lever that brought the tobacco industry to the table,'' said Michael Pertchuk, a former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission who now heads the Advocacy Institute in Washington, a nonprofit group closely linked to the anti-smoking coalition.

title: Ousted Head Of Fund Says He'll Return

title: Cry for Cambodia
description: The last thing Cambodia needed was the armed overthrow of its democratically elected Government. It had just begun to recover from a catastrophic quarter-century that included American bombing raids, the annihilation of one-seventh of its population during four years of Khmer Rouge rule, a Vietnamese invasion and a civil war. Now it faces new convulsions and executions and a likely withdrawal of most international aid.

title: The Truth About Ruth
description: New York City's elected Democratic officials and normally Democratic union leaders seem to be in a race to see who can put the most distance between themselves and Ruth Messinger's campaign for mayor. City Council members and state legislators whose politics leans toward the deeply, deeply pragmatic intend to endorse the Republican Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, running for re-election. Other politicians, like Queens Borough President Claire Shulman, are rather conspicuously on the sidelines. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan is broadcasting his perception that Ms. Messinger is a loser. The state party chairwoman, Judith Hope, apparently wants to concede the mayor's race so she can start talking about the 1998 elections. Though Ms. Messinger has always been pro-labor, some of the biggest city unions are hinting they might stay neutral in the fall, or even back Mr. Giuliani. One of her two underfunded primary opponents, the Council member Sal Albanese, has more union endorsements than she does. The other, the Rev. Al Sharpton, arguably has as many.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM TO BUY CONTROL DATA FOR $288 MILLION

Shares of Control Data, based in Arden Hills, Minn., rose $4.5625, or 29.1 percent, to $20.25, in Nasdaq trading. Control Data focuses on computer services, particularly those that help companies reduce paperwork. Control Data was formed in August 1992, when it was spun off from the original Control Data Corporation, now called the Ceridian Corporation. Welsh, Carson focuses on the health care and information services industries. Its companies have combined revenue of more than $9 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLEY, JOSEPH E.
description: FINLEY-Joseph E. Beloved and revered General Counsel Emeritus and historian for the Office and Professional Employees International Union died on July 8, 1997. Mr. Finley served the Union for Professional Technical and Clerical Employees for more than forty years. He advocated for OPEIU members in many court cases including several before the U.S. Supreme Court. He successfully argued the right of white collar employees of trade unions to organize and bargain collectively in OPEIU v. NLRB (353 US 313); and that the convention of the International Union could establish a minimum dues rate for local unions in Ranes v. OPEIU Local 28 (317 f.2d915). Besides chronicling the history of OPEIU in his book ''White Collar Union'' (1975), he was a prolific writer whose works include ''The Corrupt Kingdom'' (1973) on the United Mine Workers of America, the critically acclaimed novel, ''Missouri Blue'', which was part autobiographical, as well as several books on horse racing under a pseudonym. At the time of his death he was working on a book on the battle of Saratoga. Mr. Finley was born on August 7, 1919, to William V. and Nell (Whitten) Finely in Missouri. He was a graduate of the University of Missouri School of Journalism (1942) and Yale Law School (1951). He was a member of the bar of the United States Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, Maryland, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Besides having a private practice, he was a partner of Metzenbaum, Gaines, Finley and Stern, in Cleveland, Ohio, 1961 to 1970. He was also General Counsel for the International Brotherhood of Pottery and Allied Workers, East Liverpool, Ohio, 1970 to 1983. He heroically served in World War II from 1942 to 1946 as one of the early liberators of concentration camp survivors in Dachau. He is survived by his wife, Doctor Joanne Finely, MD, his daughter and fellow lawyer, Lucinda Finley and his sons, Scott, William and Ethan Finley. We offer them our most heartfelt condolences. We thank them for generously sharing him with us for so very long. His loss to our International Union is immense. There was no more dedicated, insightful defender of workers' rights. He rigorously pursued justice and fairness in the workplace and a better way of life for all working people. He was and is an inspiration to all. He was our historian, our advocate, our adjudicator, our brother and our very gentle friend. May he rest in peace. There will be no service, although a memorial will be held in New York City in a few weeks. For information, call OPEIU at 212-675-3210. The family has asked that any donations be made to the John Kelly Labor Studies Scholarship Fund or the Howard Coughlin Scholarship Fund. Please contact 202-393-4464 for details. Officers, staff, and members of the Office and Professional Employees International Union AFL-CIO, CLC Michael Goodwin, Intl President Gilles Beauregard, Intl Secy/Treas

Paced mostly at creeping tempos, but peppered with short blastoffs, their collaboration feels spontaneous and yet nearly dangerously lush; it is an emotional wringer.

title: Campaign Disarmament
description: The hearings before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee have an educational value that goes beyond the details of last year's campaign shenanigans. The hearings can show that American elections are so costly that it helps to think of fund-raising for them as a kind of arms race. The weapon perfected last year was, of course, ''soft money'' -- funds from wealthy individuals and corporations that were used to break through the ceilings on gifts to candidates enacted in the 1970's. These funds are supposed to go only for party-building activities and not to candidates themselves. But under both President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, the two parties used them for expensive campaign ads, and the limits on contributions enacted after Watergate went out the window.

title: Mystery Shows in Which Murder Is Secondary
description: There is a comfortable, creaky, old-fashioned appeal to ''Agatha Christie's 'The Pale Horse,' '' a new film that begins a month of British-made mystery movies on A&E. The five unrelated, made-for-television films are being promoted with the slogan ''A July to Die For,'' a claim that is wild even as metaphor. Though they range from Christie to the edgier ''Cracker,'' these are modest mysteries, focusing on the sleuths' personalities and on colorful settings rather than on murder. As they go through the paces of the genre, the films offer soothing entertainment for mystery buffs rather than spine-tingling suspense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, FRANKLIN M.
description: HELLER-Franklin M. Age 85, of North Branford, CT., formerly of Stamford, CT., husband of the late Elizabeth Phillips Heller, died July 8, 1997. Born in Dover, New Jersey on September 15, 1911, he was for seventeen years the director of the television show ''What's My Line''. In a television career which began in 1950, and spanned over twenty years, he was a pioneer in the industry directing many early dramatic shows including ''The Web'', ''Danger'', and ''The Front Page''. He was a national board member of the Directors Guild of America from 1965-1971, and remained an officer of the Guild for many years. In his later years, he worked as a literary agent. He is survived by a daughter, Jane Stewart of Norwalk, CT., three grandchildren, Heather Many of Brandon, VT., and Rebecca and Liam Filan of Middlebury, VT., and three great grandchildren. Interment private; there will be no service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of donor's choice.

title: VIDEO UPDATE TO BUY MOOVIES FOR $63.4 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Video Update Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Moovies Inc. for $63.4 million in stock. Video Update said Moovies shareholders would receive 1.1 of its shares for each Moovies share they own, or about 13.7 million shares total. After the transaction, shareholders of Moovies, based in Greenville, S.C., would own about 40 percent of Video Update's shares. Moovies sells and rents tapes through 317 video stores in 17 states in the United States. Video Update, based in St. Paul, sells and rents tapes through 389 stores across the United States and Canada. Moovies' stock fell 23 cents, to $4.50, while shares of Video Update slipped 12.5 cents, to $4.625.

title: Love, to Die For Or to Sing About
description: MOST times it seems that all the love songs are old ones. As far as popular music is concerned, we grow up with the songs we learn as adolescents, and few of us are moved to change. In the realm of art music, love songs appear more generally and inevitably to be part of history. The great operas of the 20th century are more about the frustration and corruption of love than about its fulfillment; music of full, frank amorous passion is hard to find in the modern period outside the works of Olivier Messiaen, who was in this, as in so many other respects, a stranger to his time.

title: Families Criticize Law On Crashes
description: When Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded last July 17 off the coast of Long Island, one of the 230 people on board was 17-year-old Kimberly Marie Rogers, the only child of William S. Rogers Jr. Ever since his daughter's two-and-half-mile fall from the sky, Mr. Rogers told a House Aviation subcommittee today, he has felt like a barbed wire is ''ripping and tearing inside of me,'' not only because of her death, but also because by law, her life is worthless.

title: Still Alien, Still Angry. Right, Mom?
description: Barry Sonnenfeld, wearing a ''Men in Black'' cap and a tie the color of a yield sign, stood at the curb on West 174th Street in Washington Heights staring up into the courtyard of a deeply ordinary brick apartment building half a block east of J. Hood Wright Park. ''See that corner window?'' he said. ''That was my sad and lonely hellhole.''

title: Donor-Checking Plan Failed, Ex-Democratic Official Says
description: The former financial director for the Democratic National Committee told a Senate hearing today that the party's system of investigating the propriety of big-money contributions had somehow eroded across the two years of President Clinton's re-election campaign.

title: Testimony in Senate Hearings on Campaign Fund-Raising by Democrats
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony today by Richard Sullivan, the former finance director of the Democratic National Committee, at hearings by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee in response to questions by by Senators Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, and Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee. The testimony was recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service.

description: CARPENTER-Jan. The employees of J.T. Falk & Company and Falk Technical Service express their deepest sympathies at the passing on July 10, 1997 of Jan Carpenter, beloved daughter of Louise and Gerry Falk, and to her husband Tom and son John.

title: EUROTUNNEL SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: Shareholders of Eurotunnel approved an $:8.5 billion ($14 billion) debt reorganization that concedes almost half the company's capital to creditor banks in a key step in averting bankruptcy. The company said about 97 percent of shareholder votes cast at a meeting in Paris were in favor of the plan. The approval came nine months after the company, which runs the tunnel beneath the English Channel, agreed on the outline of the debt plan with its top lenders. The approval means the British-French company will be largely controlled by its 170 creditors.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TABACALERA S.A., -- Madrid, a tobacco company, said its Tabacalera Cigars International S.A. subsidiary had agreed to buy Max Rohr Importer Inc., a cigar company, for $53 million.

title: Who Will Answer When Apple Calls?
description: Wanted: a chief executive to run a deeply troubled personal computer company with shrinking market share, mounting losses and some of the world's fiercest competitors.

title: NEANDERTHAL DNA SHEDS NEW LIGHT ON HUMAN ORIGINS
description: A hauntingly brief but significant message extracted from the bones of a Neanderthal who lived at least 30,000 years ago has cast new light both on the origin of humans and Neanderthals and on the long disputed relationship between the two.

Taylor Howell, Jr. and of the late Francis Adams Truslow. Mother of Francis Adams Truslow, Jr., Frederic J. Truslow, Elizabeth T. Russell, Sophia D.L. Truslow, and John T. Howell, III. Stepmother of Shirley H. Caracciolo. Sister of Laura J. Ingraham. Long time mainstay of the GoddardRiverside Community Center, The Huntington Township Art League, and the International House of Columbia University. Died at home of old age. Funeral service will be held on Saturday, July 12, 1997 at 11 A.M., at St. John's Episcopal Church, Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, N.Y. title: Sixers Sign Thomas to 3-Year Deal
description: The Philadelphia 76ers signed the rookie forward TIM THOMAS to a three-year contract, less than two weeks after obtaining his rights in a trade with the Nets. Thomas will make a total of $4.64 million over the three-year contract mandated by the National Basketball Association's rookie salary scale, with annual salaries of $1.35 million, $1.55 million and $1.75 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDSMAN, PAUL A.
description: LANDSMAN-Paul A. On July 9. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted brother of Sylvia and Beatrice. Cherished uncle, granduncle and brother in law. Interment private, Flemington, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture yesterday with an article about the Major League Soccer All-Star game carried an incorrect caption in some copies. The picture showed Marco Etcheverry of D.C. United stealing the ball from Carlos Parra of the MetroStars in a regular-season game; it was not a photograph from the All-Star Game on Wednesday night.

title: Alabama's New Chance for Justice
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's decision to reopen its investigation of the 16th Street Baptist Church bombing in Birmingham, Ala., is as gratifying as it is surprising. There are people still living who helped commit the most horrendous single crime of the civil rights era. There is considerable evidence against them in state and Federal files, and simple justice demands that every effort be expended to give these men the punishment they have evaded for 34 years.

description: To the Editor:

title: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES RISE TO ALL-TIME HIGH OF $145
description: Shares of the Warner-Lambert Company rose 7.2 percent yesterday on expectations that its cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor would keep gaining market share. Shares of the company, a drug and chewing-gum maker, based in Morris Plains, N.J., rose $9.75, to an all-time closing high of $145. Warner-Lambert is a co-marketer of Lipitor to doctors and hospitals with the New York-based drug maker Pfizer Inc. Davic Maris, an analyst at Aros Securities, said he had estimated that Lipitor would generate $450 million in sales this year, but he now believes that figure is far too low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, MURRAY H.
description: KIRSCH-Murray H. It is with heartfelt sadness that we mourn the passing of Murray H. Kirsch, longtime employee and friend. Our condolences are sent to Mr. Kirsch's family and friends. The Management & Employees of Standard Motor Products, Inc

title: A Weak Antitrust Nominee
description: The next head of the Justice Department's antitrust division will have a lot to say about whether the 1996 Telecommunications Act breaks the monopoly chokehold that Bell companies exert over local phone customers. He will rule on mergers among telecommunications companies and advise the Federal Communications Commission on applications by Bell companies to enter long-distance markets. Thus it is disheartening and disqualifying that President Clinton's nominee, Joel Klein, is scheduled to come up for confirmation today in the Senate with a record that suggests he might knuckle under to the powerful Bell companies and the politicians who do their bidding.

title: Inside Photography
description: To look at Seydou Keita's arresting, sometimes majestic studio portraits of perfectly ordinary people is to see vestiges of a long-past imperial grandeur, when the region that is now Mali boasted a fabulous trading and cultural center known as Timbuktu.

title: Joe Camel, a Giant in Tobacco Marketing, Is Dead at 23
description: Joe Camel, the cartoon character that became the focus of perhaps the most intense attacks ever leveled against an American advertising campaign, is being sent packing by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, which will replace it with stylized versions of Camel cigarettes' original camel trademark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRESS, WILLIAM L.
description: AGRESS-William L. Brother of Fay Corwin, beloved uncle of Carole Corwin of North Carolina and Stan Corwin of California. Also survived by several great nieces and nephews. He helped establish the Maternity Wing at Mt. Sinai Hospital, where he served as Administrator. Services today, July 11, 10 AM, Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Turning Daddy From Statue to Star
description: Fairy tales aren't what they used to be.

title: House Votes to Reduce Subsidy for Loggers
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to scale back a road-building subsidy for logging companies, but a coalition of environmentalists and budget-cutters fell just short in an effort to end the program altogether.

title: Town House Fence Trend Divides Upper East Side
description: Residents of the intimate side streets of the Upper East Side have long prided themselves on their friendly stoops and shade gardens behind small wrought-iron gates that say, in essence, ''Come on in.'' And so, people do -- to sleep on doorsteps, to bathe under outdoor faucets and to help themselves to the boxwood trees.

title: Claims of Abuse in Georgia Prison Are False
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Leading Suppliers of Oil Drilling Equipment Plan to Merge
description: Two of the world's largest suppliers of oil drilling equipment, the Reading & Bates Corporation and the Falcon Drilling Company, are merging, executives of both companies said late yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: Alun Leach-Jones

title: Yankee Outcasts Return With Mixed Feelings
description: Mariano Duncan was back in pinstripes yesterday, at least for the time being, but the disgruntled infielder-outfielder said that he was not mentally prepared to play for the Yankees, and it was clear that he was still furious at George Steinbrenner.

title: Children Without Childhood: Life in the Projects
description: OUR AMERICA

title: Defeated Cambodian Says Foe Feared Vote . . .
description: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who was ousted as Cambodia's joint leader last weekend, said in an interview today that his Co-Prime Minister, Hun Sen, had decided a month ago to seize power in a coup to avoid investigations into drug trafficking by his associates and a grenade attack on an opposition political rally.

title: An Unfettered Internet? Keep Dreaming
description: These have been heady days in Washington for that marvelous medium, the Internet. First, the Supreme Court, in Reno v. A.C.L.U., struck down restrictions on indecent content, overturning a law passed virtually unanimously by Congress.

title: Newborn Found in Bag In Apartment Building
description: A newborn girl was found inside a plastic bag yesterday afternoon in a fifth-floor hallway of a Bronx apartment building, the police said.

title: House, 217 to 216, Votes to Replace Arts Agency With Grants to States
description: By a one-vote margin, the House of Representatives voted today to dismantle the National Endowment for the Arts, a perennial target of conservatives, after Speaker Newt Gingrich proposed replacing the agency's nearly $100 million annual budget with block grants to the states.

title: Bonds Little Changed Before Price Report
description: Treasury securities were little changed yesterday, as investors awaited a report on producer prices for new clues on inflation.

title: Anticipation And Drama At Stadium
description: THE drama was building. If this were a novel, it might begin with it being a dark and stormy night; if a play, a roll of thunder as the curtain rises. But sometimes reality snuffs invention, and last evening was a night of surpassing loveliness, with a sweet scent of summer in the air at Yankee Stadium. But, also, with an unmistakable sense of electricity.

title: Web Company Lands Deal
description: Snickelways Interactive, a Web consulting company based in Manhattan, has signed an agreement with Alnet, an Internet company in Turkey, to develop on-line products for the Turkish market.

title: U.S. to Report To Congress Nafta Benefits Are Modest
description: Four years after a bitterly divisive debate over how a free-trade pact with Mexico and Canada would affect American workers, the Clinton Administration will report to Congress on Friday that the North American Free Trade Agreement has so far generated modest benefits for the United States.

title: The Race Trap
description: A Federal task force got it half right when it recently recommended that the Census Bureau abandon the idea of adding a multiracial category to census forms and other Government documents. The task force said that such a classification would ''add to racial tensions and further fragmentation of our population.''

title: Extradition in Bribery Case
description: After 20 months of fighting extradition from an Italian prison, a Wantage businessman was returned to Newark yesterday, prosecutors said.

title: INSIDE
description: Joe Camel, 1974-1997

title: Mob Turncoat Still Lures a Crowd
description: There is no doubt about it: Salvatore Gravano, the former mobster turned government witness, still has some drawing power. For his appearance yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, every seat was taken, and a line outside the door sometimes swelled to 30 people, exasperating the United States marshals trying to keep order.

title: Rituals Of Strife, With Eyes Averted
description: THERE are no bleeding bits of ear spit out by a crazed boxer. There is no sweat spraying from a head distorted by a slow-motion punch. The first thing you notice about Larry Fink's square-format, black-and-white boxing photographs is the blessed absence of glove-to-face contact. The second thing you notice is the bizarre absence of eye-to-eye contact.

title: Defeated by Life? No, Ready to Rumba!
description: ''Shall We Dance?'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 5. The film opens today in Manhattan.

description: The dramatic action yesterday of the NATO-led forces in Bosnia that resulted in the arrest of one indicted war criminal and the death of another is a positive step and shatters several myths.

title: Mexico and Drugs: Was U.S. Napping?
description: Early last year, a handful of senior American officials in Washington received an alarming secret intelligence report on Mexico. It was on its face, officials said, the sort of document that can force policy makers to change the way they think about a country or a region.

title: Was It Madness or Just Badness? Murder and More
description: Hardly a frame passes in ''This World, Then the Fireworks,'' a stylized 1950's-style film-noir mood piece, when you don't have a nagging sense that the actors aren't living up to the genre that the movie exalts with a smothering reverence.

title: Catching War Criminals in Bosnia
description: After months of hesitation, President Clinton and his fellow NATO leaders have initiated the most sensitive and potentially volatile action of the Bosnia peacekeeping mission, the pursuit and arrest of indicted war crimes suspects. It is a step that may help secure peace and justice in Bosnia, but one that must be taken with great care and precision. If mishandled, it could lead to needless NATO casualties, including American troops, and a resumption of violence throughout the Balkans.

description: NATO-led peacekeeping troops seized one Bosnian Serb war-crimes suspect and killed another today in a shootout in northwestern Bosnia in their first attempt to arrest any of the dozens of suspects at large.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DULCHIN, GERTRUDE
description: DULCHIN-Gertrude. On July 6. Beloved wife of the late Eli. Survived by daughters Marilyn, Elaine and Bonnie, three son-inlaws Armin, Jerry and Barry, and eight grandchildren. She will be in our hearts forever.

description: Franklin M. Heller, who directed the long-running television quiz show ''What's My Line?'' and many other dramatic and musical programs, died yesterday at Evergreen Woods, a retirement community in North Branford, Conn. He was 85.

description: Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts said yesterday that it planned to sell one of its three Atlantic City casinos to cut its $1.5 billion debt.

description: A Senate proposal to increase the age of eligibility for Medicare came under attack today as House and Senate negotiators met for the first time to work out their differences on a bill to eliminate the Federal budget deficit by 2002.

title: Messinger's Two Opponents Accuse Her of Superficiality
description: Even as Ruth W. Messinger sought to rally the Democratic Party and turn to the fall campaign, her primary opponents attacked her yesterday as a ''limousine liberal'' who stands no chance of defeating Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in November.

title: Diet Centers Reconsider Prescription Drug Use
description: Some commercial diet centers that had hoped that prescription diet pills would provide a quick fix for their sagging sales were reconsidering their positions on dispensing the medications after a popular combination of two such drugs was linked to a rare heart ailment.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES REPORTS 11% INCREASE IN EARNINGS
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter rose 11 percent, in line with estimates, reflecting higher sales of pharmaceutical and nutritional products and a recent acquisition. The company, a maker of drugs and medical devices based in Abbott Park, Ill., posted net income of $522 million, or 68 cents a share, up from $470 million, or 60 cents, a year earlier. The earnings matched the average estimate of 16 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. The company's shares fell 43.75 cents, to $66.

title: Hun Sen Says He's Enjoying Being Cambodia's Sole Ruler
description: He spoke of Richard Nixon and Mike Tyson, of crocodiles and kings. He lighted a cigarette and leaned back slightly as an aide fanned him with a pink file folder.

description: LIEBMANN-Fred, Dr. Passed away on July 9. Husband of the late Jenny Liebmann. Father of Herbert and Ronald. Father-in-law of Roslyn and Mona. Grandfather of Marjorie, Joseph and Jonathan. Great-grandfather of Emily.

title: Rover on Mars Hits Big Rock, But 'Driver' Keeps License
description: The roving vehicle Sojourner has had its first mishap on Mars. While trying to park snugly against a large rock, the rover pulled in a little too aggressively and wound up with the Martian equivalent of jumping the curb, leaving it tilted with one of its six metal wheels resting a few inches up the face of the rock.

title: Clinton Cheers Exultant Poles, And Vice Versa
description: Nearly eight years after the fall of Communism, President Clinton celebrated Poland's new ties to the NATO military alliance today, telling a jubilant, flag-waving crowd, ''Poland is coming home.''

description: Tony Thomas, a Hollywood chronicler and biographer, died on Tuesday at Providence St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank in Los Angeles. He was 69 and lived in Burbank.

description: Call it the Federal Court's School of Journalism. The visiting professor was Christopher Doherty, a reporter for The Globe, a supermarket weekly newspaper. description: The tortured state of Arab-Israeli relations is illustrated by the fact that of all the countries invited to attend a conference here in November aimed at improving economic ties between Arab nations and Israel, only Jordan has agreed so far to come.

title: Agreement Is Reached On M.T.A. Capital Plan
description: After more than a year of haggling, state lawmakers approved the Metropolitan Transportation Authority capital program today, and also agreed to provide money to restore the New York City subway and bus service that was cut in 1995.

description: When it comes to Finland's virtual reality Yellow Pages, forget your fingers. Your personal computer will do the walking, talking and listening.

description: The Chicago and Los Angeles offices of the Leap Partnership unit of the Leap Group were awarded two accounts yesterday with combined billings estimated at $19 million.

title: '77 Blackout: The Heart Of Darkness
description: MANY New Yorkers, possibly most by now, are too young or too new in town to remember the night when the light went out in the soul of the city. It was 20 years ago this weekend, a time when some were getting ready to say Kaddish for New York. What else do you do before burying someone except recite the Jewish prayer for the dead?

title: Home Video
description: Digital Progress

title: A Sexual Confrontation Of He Lies, She Lies
description: In ''Brilliant Lies,'' a biting Australian drama revolving around a lawsuit for sexual harassment, Anthony La Paglia plays the macho boss from hell, a misogynistic pit bull named Gary Fitzgerald, who when cornered foams at the mouth and spits out the vilest insults. His accuser, Susy Connor (Gia Carides), is no angel either. A sexually provocative woman with a history of exploiting her charms to get ahead, she is a deceitful, selfish hedonist whose version of what happened doesn't quite ring true. How selfish is she? The notion of turning over the $40,000 she stands to win from the lawsuit to her alcoholic father, Brian (Ray Barrett), who desperately needs a heart bypass operation, is initially repugnant to her.

title: Court Names Bias Task Force
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has appointed the first task force in the nation assigned to study discrimination against gay lawyers and litigants, a lawyers' group announced yesterday.

title: Expressiveness in Ceramics With Dazzling Glazes
description: At 75, Toshiko Takaezu is one of this country's most productive potters, known for her wizardry at glazes and for her development of closed-form ceramics: vessel-like in shape but with only vestigial openings. Like the California clay sculptor Peter Voulkos and other ceramists who came of age after World War II, Ms. Takaezu broke away from the traditional view of clay as a medium for functional objects to explore its potential for esthetic expression.

title: Gore and Gephardt, Potential Rivals in 2000, Join in Criticizing of G.O.P. on Taxes
description: Drawn together by a sense that the Republican Congress is politically vulnerable over taxes, Vice President Al Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, shared a stage here today to accuse Republicans of seeking to help the wealthy at the expense of working people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JIRAK, MARY
description: JIRAK-Mary. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation note with sorrow the passing of Mary Jirak, beloved mother-in-law of Jeff Gural, an esteemed member of our Real Estate Executive Committee. Jeff and his father, Aaron Gural, are long-standing volunteers. Aaron is past chairman of our Real Estate Division, and father and son were 1995 co-honorees of the Real Estate and Allied Trades Division. The leadership and staff of the Real Estate Division are indebted to the family's dedication and support, and express their condolences to Mary's daughter, Paula Jirak Gural, and to the entire Gural and Jirak families. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Charles R. Borok, Chair, 1998 Campaign Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Which Route Upward, On a Wing or a Prayer?
description: If heaven exists, what does it look like? Is it a gleaming tropical beach with snow-white sand and turquoise surf watched over by a fireworks of wheeling golden stars?

title: Harold Epstein Dies at 94; Renowned Gardening Expert
description: Harold Epstein, the elder statesman of the horticultural world, who invariably insisted that gardening was just a hobby but whose one-and-a-half-acre site in Larchmont, N.Y., contained a collection matched by few other American gardeners, died at his home on Tuesday. He was 94.

title: Revealing All and That's All
description: Ronnie Larsen's film ''Shooting Porn,'' a facetiously lighthearted tour of the gay pornography industry, is a hard-core skin flick posing as a documentary. Instead of focusing on the history of the genre or studying its effects on people's lives, the movie is a shallow, titillating look at two gay porn film directors, Gino Colbert and Chi Chi LaRue, working with assorted actors.

title: In a Protest, Poet Rejects Arts Medal
description: Angry that ''democracy in this country has been in decline,'' Adrienne Rich, the award-winning poet, has decided to turn down the 1997 National Medal for the Arts.

title: Woman Says Ex-Spouse Killed Her Son in 1971
description: The mother of a 4-month-old boy who died 26 years ago told a Georgia jury today that she no longer blamed her daughter, then only 2, for the baby's death and now considered her former husband responsible.

description: SINGAPORE  In a move to increase international pressure for a negotiated end to the political conflict in Cambodia, the Association of South East Asian Nations announced Thursday that it would indefinitely delay Cambodia's admission to ASEAN, which had been scheduled for this month.

title: F.B.I. Reopens Investigation Into Landmark Crime of the Civil Rights Era
description: Federal agents and the Birmingham police have reopened a long-cold investigation into the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church here, a crime that left four young black girls dead and raised the cruelties of the civil rights era to a new level.

title: J. P. Morgan Profit Falls 15%, But Its Stock Price Advances
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that earnings fell 15 percent in the second quarter, pulled down by lower revenue from bond trading. But a pickup in trading during June helped push the banking company's stock price higher.

title: NGC AGREES TO SELL LIGNITE RESERVES TO AN ENRON UNIT
description: The NGC Corporation of Houston agreed yesterday to sell lignite reserves and other unspecified assets to a unit of the Enron Corporation for $149 million as it sells off assets that do not fit with its main oil and natural gas businesses. NGC acquired the assets as part of its $1.3 billion acquisition of Destec Energy Inc. from the Dow Chemical Company last month. Lignite, a form of coal, is used as a source of fuel by some electric-generation plants in Texas and elsewhere.
