Kobin, her daughters Robin and Jennifer Chotzinoff of Denver, CO, her grandchildren Nicholas Selvy and Constance Hnatkowycz and her brothers James Harding of New York and Timothy Harding of Santa Barbara, California. A memorial will be held Tuesday, July 22, 4 PM at Mountaingate Country Club, Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hospice Foundation, Hospital Home Health Care Agency, 2601 Airport Drive, Torrance, CA. 90505 would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a selection of quotations about the decision to revoke Mike Tyson's boxing license in Nevada misattributed one of them in some copies. It was Oscar Goodman, Tyson's lead lawyer, not Luther Mack, one of the Nevada commissioners, who said of the license revocation: ''They had to do something in order to appease the world, the lynch mob atmosphere, the bloodthirstiness of the public. They did that.''

title: Stocks Close On High Side In Seesaw Day
description: Investors applied the adage of buying on the dips in price yesterday, helping stock prices rebound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOVIC, ABRAHAM
description: MARKOVIC-Abraham. Congregation Ohab Zedek, Belle Harbor mourns the passing of the beloved father of our esteemed member Mrs. Hedy Abel. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, DR. LEO R.
description: SCHWARTZ-Dr. Leo R. 7/10/95. Always in my thoughts; forever in my heart. Grace

title: Unbusinesslike Senators
description: To the Editor:

title: Stripping Dance Music So Only Ghosts Remain
description: Two techno pioneers, Kevin Saunderson and Derrick May, were the disk jockeys at the Roxy in Chelsea late on Thursday night for a show presented by Basic Entertainment. A decade ago, Juan Atkins, Mr. Saunderson and Mr. May, who had met at high school in Detroit, started experimenting with dance music. In basement and bedroom studios, using drum machines and samplers, they took the era's house music and stripped away the personal.

title: Nasdaq Index Upstages Dow In Its First Close Above 1,500
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, culminating a big week for the Nasdaq composite index, which soared to its seventh consecutive record close.

title: Tests of Gun in King Killing Are Inconclusive
description: After hearing that initial ballistics tests were inconclusive, a judge today held out the possibility that he might order more testing of the high-powered rifle that prosecutors believe was used by James Earl Ray to assassinate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Bias Ruling Against Factory
description: A judge ruled yesterday that Burlington Coat Factory violated a state anti-discrimination law by failing to act on an employee's complaint that she was harassed for being a lesbian. Sally Mims, now 39, complained to her supervisors at a store in Brick Township that her colleagues left her obscene messages and graphic photographs of women having sex, said her lawyer, Darren M. Gelber. Ms. Mims was dismissed as manager of the linens department in 1994, Mr. Gelber said.

title: WPS RESOURCES TO ACQUIRE UPPER PENINSULA ENERGY
description: The WPS Resources Corporation agreed late on Thursday to acquire the Upper Peninsula Energy Corporation in a stock swap valued at $71.5 million. Shareholders in Upper Peninsula Energy will receive nine-tenths of a share of WPS Resources for each share. WPS will also add one Upper Peninsula director to its board, increasing the size to 10. Upper Peninsula Energy is a Houghton, Mich., electric utility. Last year its revenue totaled $58.3 million. Last year, WPS Resources, of Green Bay, Wis., had $858.3 million in revenue. Upper Peninsula's shares gained $3.25 yesterday, to $21.50, in Nasdaq trading. WPS Resources' shares closed at $27.50, up 12.50 cents, on Big Board.

title: Girl Shoots Friend In a Gun Accident
description: A semiautomatic pistol accidentally fired yesterday as a 15-year-old girl held it in an apartment in Brooklyn, and the bullet struck a 12-year-old friend in the chest, the police said.

title: A Stark Landscape's Song
description: Ispent most of the last decade writing a novel set on Mars, and at some point early in the process I stared at a pair of stereoscopic photographs from the 1976 Viking 2 mission until the images merged into a shimmering false 3-D, and a shiver went down my spine: I saw what it would be like to stand on another planet. I think the widespread public enthusiasm for Pathfinder's great success is based on a similar shivery sensation -- the apprehension of our neighboring world's reality.

title: Pickett Regains Ownership Of Islanders
description: In the latest serpentine twist in the sale of the Islanders, John Spano formally relinquished ownership yesterday to John O. Pickett, the man who agreed in April to sell him the team.

title: Five on Patrol Are Wounded In Belfast
description: Two police officers and three British Army soldiers were shot by unidentified gunmen tonight as they patrolled a Roman Catholic section of West Belfast. They were not gravely wounded, the police said.

title: Union Plan Sees Buyouts Saving Jobs
description: New York City's largest union of hospital workers has proposed an innovative deal that would use at least $100 million from its pension plan to offer early retirement incentives for older workers as a means of guaranteeing job security for younger ones.

title: Shelving the Star Trek Myth
description: I went to Mars last week. We all did. We stared at that desolate landscape where torrents of water once flowed. Could that water have swarmed with life? Could there still be life beneath the barren surface? We long to know. We are driven to understand our place in the universe, humbling though that knowledge may be. Thanks to a bold, brilliantly executed triumph of human ingenuity, we are now much closer to that goal.

title: Beliefs
description: Dolly the cloned sheep has long since exhausted her 15 minutes of fame, and the question of cloning humans now ranks, as a matter of public urgency, somewhere below the dangers of air bags and the struggle over enactment of the tobacco settlement. Rightly so, some would say.

title: INSILCO TO REPURCHASE UP TO $220 MILLION OF STOCK
description: The Insilco Corporation said yesterday that it would repurchase up to $220 million of its stock for $38.50 a share and refinance its existing debt in an effort to improve its stock price. The company, a maker of industrial components and specialty publications, said that on Thursday it paid a total of $110 million for 2.8 million shares from its majority shareholder, Water Street Corporate Recovery Fund I L.P., and 51,948 shares from Robert Smialek, the chief executive. The money for the purchases came from the sale of the company's Rolodex unit in March. Insilco, based in Columbus, Ohio, will also pay about $110 million for up to 2.86 million shares on the open market, at $38.50 a share. Insilco rose $1.125, to $38.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the previous day's trading in the credit markets misstated the difference in yields between an eight-year global note issued by the Philip Morris Companies and the 10-year Treasury note. The yield on the Philip Morris notes was 79 basis points higher when the notes were issued on Thursday, not 81 basis points. (A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.)

title: New Carnegie Director
description: Bruce Coppock, executive director of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, has been appointed deputy director of Carnegie Hall, effective Dec. 1. Mr. Coppock, 46, previously served as manager of the St. Louis Symphony. He was a founder of the Boston Chamber Music Society, and was director of orchestra activities and chairman of the chamber music department at the New England Conservatory of Music. He also taught at the New England Conservatory, the Boston Conservatory, the University of New Hampshire and Brown University.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SERVICE EXPERTS INC., -- Nashville, will acquire 22 heating, ventilating and air-conditioning services companies with combined annual revenue of about $44 million.

title: The Right Machine for Mars
description: After Pathfinder, what next? More unmanned probes to Mars will follow, certainly. But the search for life or its fossilized remains on the red planet will require mobile systems capable of traveling long distances through unimproved terrain, climbing steep slopes, performing heavy work and delicate work, and adapting in a versatile way to unexpected conditions. In short, Mars needs humans.

title: Report of Loss Sends Shares Of MCI Lower
description: Underscoring the difficulty that long-distance telephone companies have faced trying to offer local service, the MCI Communications Corporation lost more than 17 percent of its market value yesterday after the company announced late Thursday that its local telephone operation could lose as much as $800 million this year -- twice the loss the company had previously forecast.

title: Lott Rejects Any Role for I.R.S. In Collecting Medicare Premiums
description: Senators of both parties insisted today that Congress must impose a Medicare premium increase on the affluent elderly, but the Senate Republican leader said his party would not go along with a White House proposal to have the Internal Revenue Service collect those extra premiums.

title: E-Z Pass Contract to Stand
description: In other action yesterday, the State Supreme Court effectively allowed the $488 million E-Z Pass contract to stand by declining to hear an appeal raising questions about how it was awarded, The Associated Press reported.

title: U.S. Consumption Tax Won't Increase Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich Has Vigor Of Yore on Tax Cuts
description: Sounding like his old self, Speaker Newt Gingrich proposed cutting taxes every year and instead of reducing capital gains and inheritance taxes, making them distant memories. Before college Republicans, he eagerly made what he called the ''moral case for cutting taxes.''

title: Karl G. Kessler, 77, Physicist
description: Dr. Karl Gunther Kessler, a physicist and former associate director for international and academic affairs at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, died on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 77 and lived in Bethesda.

title: Protective Life Will Buy Credit Life Insurer
description: The Protective Life Corporation agreed today to buy the John Alden Financial Corporation's Western Diversified Group for an undisclosed price to increase its credit life insurance business.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES IS PLANNING A REVAMPING
description: The Citizens Utilities Company said yesterday that it would cut jobs, close sales offices and make other cost-reducing moves to save at least $70 million a year in operating expenses. Citizens, a telecommunications and utility company, based in Stamford, Conn., said the expenses tied to the restructuring would reduce second-quarter earnings by $185 million, before taxes. The class A shares of Citizens Utilities fell 18.75 cents, to $8.75, a new 52-week low on the New York Stock Exchange. The company will also reduce its 1997 capital expenditure program by at least $175 million.

title: Lyme Disease Foundation Seeks Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: La Guardia's Unforgiving Runway May Be Too Much of a Challenge
description: It does not usually happen, but when the wind shifts, a plane bound for La Guardia Airport will sometimes have to land on Runway 13.

title: Endesa and Stet Win Bidding for Retevision
description: Endesa S.A. and Stet S.p.A. won their bid yesterday to buy 60 percent of Retevision S.A., a telecommunications company owned by the Spanish Government. The deal would provide competition for Telefonica de Espana and end its monopoly in basic telephone services. The decision was widely expected after Endesa, Spain's state-owned power company, and Stet, an Italian concern, offered 116 billion pesetas ($780 million) last month for the stake.

title: Lewis-Akinwande: a Fight for Heavyweight Redemption
description: Life or boxing or chaos must go on, so here's introducing Lennox Lewis and Henry Akinwande.

title: Lopez Hears Roar of Crowd Again at Open
description: During Thursday's first round of the United States Women's Open, Nancy Lopez watched from the practice putting green as fans by the thousands retreated from the grounds of the Pumpkin Ridge Golf Club, heading for home. They walked right past Lopez, who had yet to begin her play in the first round.

title: Rover on Mars Is Stuck in Idle After Error in Communication
description: In a mistake that cost the Mars Pathfinder mission a full day of exploration, flight controllers tried to radio instructions to the spacecraft while its receiver was turned off. Hearing nothing, the lander and its rover remained idle.

title: The Real Friends of the Arts
description: The House of Representatives voted to kill the National Endowment for the Arts by a one-vote margin this week. Several Republican moderates who normally support the N.E.A. voted with the majority, and each of them can be held responsible for a public repudiation of Federal funding for the arts. Fortunately there is a good chance that Republican senators with stronger backbones will restore the agency's minuscule $99.5 million budget.

title: Trump Says Time Is Right To Put Casino On the Block
description: Donald J. Trump said today that he has decided to sell one of his Atlantic City casinos for one uncomplicated reason: It is a good time to sell.

title: China Isn't Lawbreaker in Campaign Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Mail-Order Cards?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Promoter of Democracy Angers the Authoritarians
description: For the past decade, George Soros, the Hungarian-born financier and philanthropist, has spent more than a billion dollars promoting a free press and political pluralism abroad -- everything the world's authoritarian rulers despise.

title: University Hospital Plan Would Exclude Abortions
description: The University of Connecticut Medical Center plans to join with a Catholic hospital to build a center for out-patient surgery that will not perform abortions or sterilizations for women.

title: Childhood Memories, Without Illusion
description: Nora Laudani calls her new performance piece ''Jabbering Head,'' presumably in a wry allusion to the talking ones. But there was very little jabbering -- or pontificating -- in the work, which was presented on Thursday night at Surf Reality, 172 Allen Street. Instead, Ms. Laudani and Arthur Aviles, who performed the 75-minute piece together, represent two versions of a remembered life, recalled for the most part in murmuring asides and trenchant, scrappy mime.

title: High Court Suspends Lawyers
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court put the state's lawyers on notice yesterday that engaging in domestic violence would likely have adverse consequences for their careers. The court ordered two lawyers, one of whom is the Mayor of Lodi, suspended for three months because they had been convicted of assaulting their wives.

title: READER'S DIGEST EXPECTS EARNINGS TO FALL SHORT
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in the 1997 fiscal year would be lower than expectations and that it had halved its dividend because of continued problems attracting customers. The company, which publishes Reader's Digest magazine, cut its dividend to 22.5 cents a share, and forecast earnings for the year ended in June of about $1.65 before charges related to marketing, price cuts and excess inventory. Reader's Digest is struggling to woo younger readers to its magazines and books and stimulate growth in Europe, where sales have slowed. The company also said the head of its European operations, Martin Pearson, had resigned. Reader's Digest's shares, which have fallen 38 percent since the start of the last year, fell $1.875 to close at $25.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a Senate vote to delay military base closings transposed the locations of two bases in some copies. Kelly Air Force Base is in San Antonio; McClellan Air Force Base is in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Flight 800's Technical Puzzle
description: Almost a year ago, T.W.A. Flight 800 crashed off the coast of Long Island shortly after takeoff, killing all 230 passengers and crew members. Testimony by relatives of the victims this week before Congress offered vivid accounts of their searing pain. Government cannot heal their wounds. But it can work hard to prevent further tragedies. The first anniversary is a good time to take stock.

title: Clinton Makes Also-Ran Feel Like Winner
description: President Clinton came to Romania today to console a nation he had blocked from joining NATO in its first round of expansion. But it turned out that he did not have to work very hard.

title: Former Sheraton Food Buyer Is Sentenced for Kickbacks
description: A former executive of the ITT Sheraton Corporation was sentenced yesterday to 15 months in prison for taking ''hundreds of thousands of dollars'' in kickbacks from a produce wholesaler, according to Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: Top Massachusetts Court Overturns Term Limits
description: The drive for terms limits on lawmakers was dealt another blow today as the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts struck down a voter-approved law that would have kept politicians from serving more than eight consecutive years in an office.

title: Senate Is Cool to G.I. Mission in Bosnia but Doesn't Cut Off Funds
description: The Senate approved a military authorization bill today that sent a clear signal that it wants ground troops out of Bosnia by June 30, as President Clinton has promised. But unlike the House, the Senate did not cut off aid for the peacekeeping mission.

title: Not a Free Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: French Won't Sell Military Contractor
description: France dropped plans today to sell its controlling stake in Thomson-CSF, the biggest military electronics company in Europe, saying it was instead planning to make it the core of a large new military group.

title: INSIDE
description: Proposal on Hospital Jobs

title: Groundbreaking for Seaport
description: A groundbreaking ceremony will be held today for the first phase of Tuckerton Seaport, a $7.4 million effort to recreate the atmosphere of an 18th century shipbuilding and fishing center on Barnegat Bay. The seaport, to be built on Tuckerton Creek, will contain 28 replicas of actual buildings that existed along the bay, including the Tucker's Island Lighthouse, a decoy carving shop and a sawmill.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Don't Regulate Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: A London Concert Discards the Dross
description: The last time the British got their hands on the White House, they set it on fire, and it didn't fare much better over a century and a half later when Leonard Bernstein and Alan Jay Lerner seized on it for their ill-fated 1976 musical ''1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.''

title: James C. Hill, 56, Federal Health Official
description: James C. Hill, former deputy director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, died on June 26 in Richmond, where he had undergone surgery for a liver ailment. He was 56 and lived in Washington.

title: After the Vote, Brighter Mexican Prospects
description: Despite victories by many populist candidates who may put pressure on the Mexican Government to alter its orthodox economic policies, the balloting that ended seven decades of one-party rule here this week left many investors more encouraged about the nation's economic prospects than they were before the election.

title: GROUP SEEKING TO BUY XPEDITE INCREASES ITS OFFER
description: A group trying to purchase Xpedite Systems Inc. raised its offer price 50 cents a share, to $23, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Xpedite, based in Eatontown, N.J., provides computer and fax-based services. The group, which includes members of the company's senior management team, said the offer was conditional on a purchase price of $85 million or less for Xpedite Systems Ltd., a European affiliate of the company. Xpedite's shares were at $21.75, up 50 cents, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Cosby's Lawyer Details Phone Calls by Defendant
description: In the moments after Bill Cosby learned that his only son, Ennis, had been shot to death on Jan. 16, he called his lawyer in New York and said that he was stopping work on his television show and going home to his wife.

title: A Reward for Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares of Japan Retailer Fall on Debt Problems
description: The shares of the Yaohan Japan Corporation, a Japanese retailer, plummeted 33 percent yesterday after the company asked creditors for more time to pay debts. The stock fell 48 yen, to 95. The shares have fallen about 70 percent since the beginning of May.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column on Thursday about a textile designer, Jan Milne, omitted the name of the architect of Genki Sushi, a restaurant in Manhattan that uses a fabric by Ms. Milne. She is Alison Spear.

title: A Hitch: Metrocard Makes Fare Increase Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Edwin Diamond, a Writer, 72
description: Edwin Diamond, an author, teacher and journalist whose career spanned more than 45 years and ranged from covering the space age to critiquing the news media, died Thursday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Martinez Hits Another Homer To Cap Victory
description: Some semblance of normalcy returned to Yankee Stadium last night, a day after Hideki Irabu conquered the American pastime with the Yankees. Andy Pettitte pitched another marvelous game, Tino Martinez clubbed another titanic homer, the majority of the seats were empty, Mariano Rivera recorded a save and the Yankees squashed the Tigers again, 3-0.

title: Auto Insurance Reform Push
description: Democratic legislators are applying more pressure on the Republican majority to grapple with the thorny subject of auto insurance reform before the November elections. Assemblyman Sean F. Dalton of Elk Township said yesterday that he has urged Assembly Speaker Jack Collins to summon lawmakers back to the State House this summer for hearings.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Sentenced For Rape of 2 Women
description: Two teen-agers who raped a young woman and a teen-ager in Marcus Garvey Park last summer were sentenced yesterday to a minimum of six years in state prison.

title: Strictly Apolitical
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Earnings Dropped 53.4% in Second Quarter
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that net income had fallen 53.4 percent in the second quarter, reflecting increased spending on customer incentives and the effect of a strike that halted production of high-profit trucks.

title: ADVANTA SHARES SURGE ON REPORT OF BID REJECTION
description: Shares of the Advanta Corporation rose yesterday after it was reported by Bridge News that it had turned down a bid for $42 a share from National Australia Bank Ltd. A Wall Street professional said the company, a troubled credit card issuer based in Spring House, Pa., was looking for a price near $46 a share. The company's class B stock closed at $34.25, up $1.875, and the class A shares gained $1.125, to $34.625, after reaching $36.25 earlier in the day. A bid of $42 a share would value the company at about $1.85 billion.

title: Store Owner Shot to Death After a Chase In Chinatown
description: A shop owner chasing a teen-ager after a dispute in his store was shot and killed last night in the middle of a crowded street in Chinatown, the police said. Officers continued the chase, racing with guns drawn through crowds of tourists and evening diners, and arrested the teen-age suspect a few blocks away.

title: Lyme Disease Foundation Seeks Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: An Educator Gets an Education in Politics
description: Claire McIntee's school in Little Neck, Queens, was small enough that she was able to remember each student's name, safe enough that she was able to focus all her energies on teaching, not security.

title: A Comeback Is Thrown For a Loss
description: WASHINGTON REDSKINS officials breathed a deep sigh of relief: Terry Thomas Allen was O.K. ''Just some scratches on his elbow, that's all,'' one official chirped yesterday. Scratches on his elbow? Terry Allen nearly killed himself last Saturday and we hear about scratches and how happy everyone is that he'll report to camp today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the president of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. misstated the size of the denomination in some copies. It has eight million members.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Producer Prices Fall For Sixth Straight Month

title: When Young Sanctity Battles Old Sanctimony
description: Acting that warms the heart, humor that eases the day's cares, conflict that engages the emotions and lessons in love and idealism that stimulate the intellect constitute the considerable rewards of the Irish Repertory Theater's revival of ''Mass Appeal.''

title: In Defense of Tokens
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CAUGHT IN CROSSWIND -- Claire McIntee, superintendent of School District 26, says she was unprepared for the uproar that surrounded her appointment. Page 25.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the ''On Stage, and Off'' column yesterday about this fall's theater season misstated the schedule for ''Side Show'' and misstated the century in which it is set. The Broadway musical, about Siamese twins, is to begin performances on Sept. 19 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, not Oct. 16, and it takes place in the 20th century, not the 19th century.

title: Gravano Vows to Fight To Keep His Book Profits
description: Salvatore Gravano, the former mobster who is now a Government informer, said yesterday that he was prepared to go to court to fight lawsuits that relatives of some of his murder victims have filed in hopes of seizing his profits from a best-selling book about his life.

title: A Blind Rider Races Into the Nationals
description: When bicycles built for two race in a match sprint, they start at a crawl. Each pair of riders eyes the other pair, waiting for a move. With a lap and a fraction left, one team usually takes off, and the tandem bikes fly at well over 40 miles an hour.

title: Swiss Reinsurer Has Stake in Partner
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company, the world's second-largest reinsurer, confirmed yesterday that it held a stake of about 5 percent in the Winterthur Insurance Company, Switzerland's second-biggest insurer and one of its joint-venture partners. Swiss Re rebutted speculation that the investment was a strategic move, however, saying the Winterthur stake was one many stakes it held in insurers.

title: Video Is O.K., But Real Fun Is on the Street
description: SINGSONG snippets drifted through the air like the heat rising off the asphalt on East 109th Street. ''One my baby, two my baby, three my baby, go!'' chanted a group of girls who began jumping to the slap of a rope hitting concrete. Down the block, a boy in baggy shorts toted his boombox. ''Mo' money, mo' murder, mo' homicide,'' flowed from the speakers. ''Better have an alibi.''

title: Body Found in Raritan Bay
description: The body of a Brooklyn man who jumped off the Staten Island ferry last weekend was found yesterday floating in Raritan Bay, the police said.

title: Liquor Law Violation Charge
description: State regulators have accused seven bars and restaurants of violating liquor laws by concealing the fact that their investors included Daniel J. Carluccio, the Ocean County Prosecutor. Officials who enforce alcoholic beverage laws are barred from making such investments.

title: Bessemer Trust and LJH Plan New Hedge Venture
description: In an attempt to capitalize on the increasing popularity of hedge funds with rich investors, the Bessemer Trust Company said yesterday that it would set up Fifth Avenue Alternative Investments L.L.C., a joint venture with LJH Alternative Investment Advisers Inc.

title: Cambodia: Quandary for Diplomats
description: As foreign governments began to cut their aid programs to Cambodia as punishment for the coup carried out last weekend by Hun Sen, embassies here received a surprising letter today from Parliament.

title: Air Force Lieutenant Given Discharge for Fraternization
description: Air Force Secretary Sheila E. Widnall today granted a second lieutenant a general discharge from the Air Force as punishment for becoming romantically involved with an airman -- whom he later married -- and initially denying their relationship.

title: An Enthusiast Again, Gingrich Proposes a Tax Cut a Year
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich, sounding like his old optimistic self, today proposed cutting taxes every year and abolishing, not just reducing, capital gains and inheritance taxes.

title: William Welch, Cardiologist And Radio Host, Dies at 85
description: Dr. William J. Welch, who practiced internal medicine and cardiology for many years in New York City and who was the former host of a radio advice program, died on Thursday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Unpredictable Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Bold Mayor Forces Change (Even on the Willing)
description: This tiny port on Peconic Bay has been kind of quiet since the wild bootlegging days of Prohibition came to a close. That is, until David E. Kapell, a former professional bass guitarist with a taste for Panama hats, was elected Mayor in 1994.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-5

title: The Happy Dictator
description: Poor Ruth Messinger.

title: Cities, Once on Fiscal Ropes, Rebound Strongly
description: Six years ago, municipal officials in Huntsville, as in most other American cities, were spending cheerless days trying to suture a budget that was gushing red ink. The shiny new police cars authorized in the 1990-91 budget? Gone. The parks improvements and new garbage trucks? Same story. The new computers, street sweepers and expanded bus routes? Maybe next year.

title: Carrying On, Rain Checks Not Necessary
description: Forces of nature made a spectacular guest appearance when Dancing in the Streets opened its annual Dances for Wave Hill series of performances on Wednesday evening. Lightning provided special effects. There was percussion accompaniment by thunder. And raindrops danced wildly on the lawns of Wave Hill, a public garden in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: A Disintegrating House Inquiry
description: With promising hearings on the 1996 fund-raising scandals now under way in the Senate, the duplicative House campaign financing investigation being led by Dan Burton of Indiana is looking more useless and unprofessional than ever. The time is overdue for Speaker Newt Gingrich to shut down Mr. Burton's rogue operation and let Senator Fred Thompson's committee conduct a single, comprehensive inquiry.

title: Patent Fights Aplenty for M.R.I. Pioneer
description: Is Raymond V. Damadian's story just another David-and-Goliath tale? Not really. For the analogy to work, David's arsenal would have had to include far more than a single well-aimed stone.

title: Yes, They Will Come: In All Sizes and Colors
description: About 50 miles from the banks of the Mississippi, in a place where the cows and horses seemingly outnumber the people, two rustic farms share not only a field of corn, but also the Field of Dreams.

title: Gephardt Faults Effort To Balance the Budget
description: Pushing for an economic policy distinct from the Clinton Administration's and one he could banner as a Presidential candidate, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, says it is all right if the budget is only in ''rough balance'' because the nation's top priority should be investment and growth.

title: Producer Report Sends Treasury Prices Up
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond to its lowest level in more than seven months after the Government reported that prices at the producer level fell for a record sixth consecutive month.

title: Turnstile Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, organized by the Greater New York Bridge Association, is grinding toward its conclusion. There are now two undefeated teams, one of which is a group led by Mark Feldman of Manhattan. Two weeks ago at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, he and his teammates won their semifinal match against a group headed by Marcel Friedmann.

title: LITTON STOCK RISES ON REPORT OF A POSSIBLE TAKEOVER
description: The shares of Litton Industries rose yesterday after Business Week published a report that Litton could get a takeover offer for as much as $80 a share from the General Dynamics Corporation. Litton's stock rose $2.25, to $53, and General Dynamics was up 56.25 cents, at $77. Spokeswomen for Litton and General Dynamics declined to discuss the report. An unnamed investment manager told the magazine a buyout of Litton could cost $80 a share. General Dynamics produces destroyers, submarines, tanks, and communications systems for the United States military. Litton supplies computer system consulting services, ship radar systems, portable computer systems, computer display components and aircraft navigation systems.

title: 2 People Are Injured In Fall From a Ride On the Jersey Shore
description: Two people were injured last night when they fell from a beachfront amusement ride onto the sand in Seaside Heights, N.J., the police said.

title: Braves' Glavine Is Worn Down By Patient Bats
description: If their knack for coming back and beating Cy Young Award winners is not enough confirmation that the Mets are for real, then there is this: The Braves are hinting that the Mets are lucky.

title: Lawyers, Split Along Party Lines, Tangle Over Immunity for Huang
description: A sometimes testy three-hour meeting between lawyers for John Huang, the central figure in the Democratic fund-raising controversy, and lawyers for the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses ended today with Republican and Democratic lawyers clashing over whether Mr. Huang should be given a grant of immunity to testify.

title: Sanyo Securities Shares Fall on Article on Debt
description: Shares of Sanyo Securities Ltd., a second-tier Japanese brokerage firm, plunged yesterday on fears about its financial health after a local newspaper said the brokerage firm had asked life insurers to extend repayment of subordinated loans. A Sanyo Securities spokesman denied the report, saying the company had not made such a request this month. A restructuring plan begun in 1994 includes periodic extensions of loans from life insurers, he said.

title: Denny's Parent Makes Bankruptcy Filing
description: The Flagstar Companies, a restaurant operator, said today that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors in a Federal bankruptcy court in South Carolina.

title: Monitor of City Finances Is Leaving for London
description: Rosemary Scanlon, who has served for four years as the special monitor of New York City's finances in the office of the State Comptroller, announced yesterday that she was resigning to become a private financial consultant in London.

title: A.T.M.'s for Sears Stores
description: The Banc One Corporation agreed this week to place automated cash machines in all Sears, Roebuck & Company full-line United States stores. Terms were not disclosed. Sears, based in Hoffman Estates, is the nation's second-largest retailer. Banc One, based in Columbus, Ohio, said it expects to have about 800 machines in Sears stores by December. The bank and financial services company said it also has contracts to install about 4,700 of the machines in other retail chains in the next 12 months.

title: Two Lawyers Suspended After Assaulting Wives
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court put the state's lawyers on notice yesterday that engaging in domestic violence is likely to hurt their careers. The court ordered two lawyers, one of whom is the Mayor of Lodi, suspended for three months because they had been convicted of assaulting their wives.

title: Acolyte of a Master of Dance and Song
description: It being impossible to resurrect Fred Astaire in white tie and tails and have him alight in the Rainbow and Stars cabaret, the singer and pianist Steve Ross, a devoted Astaire acolyte and the suavest of all male cabaret performers, makes a delightful stand-in. His new act, ''I Won't Dance,'' which plays at the club through July 19, is a deft, fast-paced nonterpsichorean salute to the image, voice and spirit of Astaire. Although there's hardly any dancing on the room's expanded platform stage, by the end of the show, directed by Susan Claassen, the performance's graceful, gliding momentum should leave you feeling as though you have have just visited an Astaire-Rodgers movie set.

title: A Chateau Divided: Famed Yquem Riven by Family Feud
description: The clock on a 16th-century tower at Chateau d'Yquem has stopped and the view out over the vineyards descending to the Garonne River is of a tranquillity that suggests time may indeed stand still in this place where wine and myth overlap.

title: HOUSE VOTES END OF FEDERAL FUNDS FOR ARTS AGENCY
description: A day after voting to abolish the National Endowment for the Arts, the House today stripped the agency of its remaining $10 million to cover shutdown costs and rejected a compromise offered by Republican leaders to replace the arts agency with a system of block grants.

title: No Headline
description: ''It is time to call in Sherlock Holmes, for we now have the case of the missing inflation. If anyone can find it, it has to be Holmes -- for the Bureau of Labor Statistics has completely lost the scent.''

title: From a Jazz Trumpeter, Nat (King) Cole's Aplomb
description: It was neither a singer nor a pianist but an 81-year-old jazz trumpeter who came the closest to capturing the spirit of Nat (King) Cole in two commemorative concerts at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

title: Producer Prices Drop Again; Inflation, for Now, Has Died
description: Prices paid by producers fell for a record sixth consecutive month, the Government reported today, in the strongest sign yet that inflation has virtually disappeared from the American industrial landscape.

title: National Baptist Leader Denies Misconduct Accusations
description: Henry J. Lyons, the Baptist leader, and his wife, Deborah, presented a united front today as he denied the accusations of adultery and financial impropriety that have swirled around him since Mrs. Lyons was arrested in connection with the fire set to the lavish home her husband owned with another woman.

title: Dream Away Holds On To Win $1 Million Pace
description: Dream Away began his dream run a week ago and finished it tonight in the $1 million Meadowlands Pace, harness racing's richest event.

title: $1.5 Million Gift to Help Students at Juilliard
description: The Juilliard School at Lincoln Center has received a $1.5 million grant from the Alice Tully Foundation for a new scholarship fund for organ and voice and a debut vocal recital series at Alice Tully Hall. The first scholarships are to be awarded for the 1998-99 semester to students in at least their second year.

title: High-Tech Prison and the Face of Horror
description: ''You killed your parents and ate them, right?'' a prison official asks an inmate.

title: Now, NATO Troops Should Catch the Big Fish
description: The NATO-led force in Bosnia must now quickly arrest the most important people indicted for war crimes. After troops arrested one suspected war criminal and killed another in Prijedor on Thursday, NATO crossed its Rubicon, and there is now no way back to the previous policy of benign neglect.

title: Rwanda's War Role May Haunt Congolese
description: Diplomats and intelligence officers have long suspected that Rwanda's Government gave crucial support to the insurgency that toppled the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in neighboring Congo.

title: Fetal Tissue Injected Into Injured Spinal Cord
description: Researchers in Florida yesterday performed the nation's first transplant of fetal tissue into a person with a spinal cord injury, an effort that they hope will pioneer a new approach to arresting and possibly reversing disability.

title: Philippine Peso, Cut Loose by Central Bank, Falls
description: The central bank abandoned its defense of the Philippine peso today, causing it to drop more than 11 percent.

title: The 5 Minute Slush Pile
description: Convinced that the Internet is the next big thingfor finding talent, Linda Johnson and Murray Cohen, TV-movie producers in Hollywood, have set up the 5 Minute Film School, a Web site that solicits script ideas (mostly true life) for possible sale. Johnson once ran Aaron Spelling's movie-of-the-week division; Cohen was a production executive for Turner Network Television. Since its launch two months ago, the site has received nearly 1,000 submissions. And how many deals have been inked so far? Well, as they say in Hollywood, none. (Or as Cohen frankly puts it, Most of what we've seen is pretty bad.) Here's a look at dramas the world may never know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, RONALD S.
description: WILLIAMS-Ronald S. Wonderful husband, father, son, brother, friend. We will always love you. Contributions: Children's Aid Soc.

title: ALEXIS!
description: In honor of Bastille Day, a proclamation: Alexis de Tocqueville, France's most famous prognosticator about things American, often whiffed. In America there are numerous factions, he wrote, but no conspiracies. And: I am strangely mistaken, if the Federal Government of the United States be not . . .narrowing its circle of action more and more.Still, you have to hand it to him. A shy, frail 25-year-old who arrived in 1831, he traveled 7,000 miles in nine months, interviewed more than 200 people and made his way by canoe, pirogue, horseback, steamboat, stagecoach and foot. He saw exactly where slavery would lead: the most horrible of Civil Wars.He also impaled President Andrew Jackson (a very mediocre man). On balance, he seemed to like the place. He and his companion, Gustave de Beaumont, marched in two patriotic parades, including one in Albany.

title: The Subversive Proofreader
description: The History of the Siege of Lisbon

title: The Company Helped Pay for My Summer Vacation
description: SUMMER is here and you and the family want to get away for a few days. It's also a slow time at your company -- a good chance to catch up with faraway clients or to pitch some new business. Wouldn't it be nice to combine a business trip with a vacation, and have your company pick up some of the bill?

title: Romantic Repertory From Cliburn Winner
description: LONG before pianists descended on Fort Worth to play in the 10th International Van Cliburn Piano Competition, the South Shore Summer Music Festival arranged a concert introduction to the winner. And so, several Fridays ago, Jon Nakamatsu was scheduled to give one of his very first recitals as a Cliburn laureate. A call came in from the Cliburn Foundation, however: the gold medalist had an opportunity to make a major orchestral debut in Brazil. Would the South Shore Festival allow him to perform on July 18?

title: $1.50 to La Guardia? Take the M-60
description: SEVERAL recent trips between the Upper West Side of Manhattan and La Guardia Airport have convinced me that the M-60 bus, just five years old, is one of the best travel bargains in New York City. For the price of the regular bus fare of $1.50 in exact change, a token or a Metrocard, this little-heralded bus picks up passengers or drops them off at any of a number of stops in upper Manhattan and Queens and at La Guardia's major terminals, from Delta-Northwest to the Marine Air Terminal. Starting the Fourth of July, the bus became an even bigger bargain: Users of the new gold Metrocard can now transfer without charge (within a two-hour limit) from subways and all Transit Authority buses in Manhattan -- including the mainstay of the Upper West Side, the M-104, which runs on Broadway -- and from some Queens buses as well. The schedule of the M-60 is a classic of Cartesian regularity. As a rule, the buses operate every 20 minutes between 10 A.M. and 7 P.M. (every half hour from 4:30 to 10 A.M. and again from 7 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.), and travel time is about 50 minutes, depending on traffic. This compares favorably with just about any other form of public transportation to or from Manhattan. Recent bus trips in the direction of rush hour traffic between 106th Street and Broadway, the southern terminus, and La Guardia have shown that even with all the stops the bus makes along the way, the M-60 still covers the distance in about the same time as cars can manage.

title: LOUD ABOUT CAL
description: Calvin Coolidge, born 125 years ago this month, is among our most maligned Chief Executives. And that's not fair, says John Karol, a film maker who's now finishing Things of The Spirit, a $2 million, seven-year project that he hopes will buy Cal some slack. Besides defending Coolidge's oft-scorned tax cut, which helped him reduce the national debt by a third, Karol notes that Coolidge endorsed racial tolerance and liberalism and was more than the Oval Office Babbitt who said, The chief business of the American people is business. (Yes, he said it. But in the same speech he said, J.F.K.-like, The chief ideal of the American people is idealism.) Whether the film will flutter many hearts remains to be seen, but Karol is a believer. I'm a Democrat, he says, but I have found things in Coolidge's personal and political life that any small-d democrat can embrace.

title: The Spouse at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Mia Dell, Steven Bosak
description: Millie-Marie Dell, the daughter of Kate and Christopher Dell of Richmond, N.H., was married yesterday to Steven Edward Bosak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry F. Bosak of Briarcliff, N.Y. The Rev. Carol L. Karlson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of the Pines in Rindge, N.H.

title: Second Thoughts on Free Trade
description: THE Presidential Commission on United States-Pacific Trade and Investment Policy recently released its final report, the product of a year of deliberations. Charged with recommending policies to increase American access to Asian markets so that ''a maximum number of high-wage jobs are created and maintained in the United States,'' the commission endorsed our nation's current free-trade policy. The report hailed it for encouraging growth in exports and for generating jobs, and suggested ways to further increase those exports.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Indian Point 3 Cleared

title: 'Mad Cows' Run Up Brick Wall
description: Theories abound. People flail away at the ''dripping cows'' that have become a kind of a neighborhood Rubik's Cube to those who bother to look up when walking down Seventh Avenue between Second and Third Streets.

title: A Church Roof in Brooklyn Collapses During a Meeting
description: For years, the tiny wooden church at 1171 Greene Avenue, lately known as the Great Joy Baptist Church, had been an aid and comfort to the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. When the blackout that occurred 20 years ago tonight plunged Bushwick into chaos and looting, the 101-year-old church helped businesses and families recover. And when neglected apartment buildings in the neighborhood mysteriously caught fire, the church provided shelter for the families made suddenly homeless.

title: The Berkshires
description: Spring comes grudgingly to the Berkshires, if at all, but a cool, green summer is the compensation. Even in August, one can hike a north Berkshire ridge to the Snow Hole, a hollow where ice often lingers in summer.

title: Where Our Lawmakers Dare Not Boldly Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Suki John and Horacio Cocchi
description: ''I DESCRIBE myself as someone who does everything you can do to make a living through dance, except strip,'' said Suki John, 38, who teaches salsa and ballet at schools, senior-citizen centers and studios in New York City. She also writes about dance and has worked as a choreographer for companies in Spain, Cuba, England, Finland and France. ''I am the definition of freelance,'' she said.

title: Hostel Group Grows And Adds a Web Site
description: Hosteling International-American Youth Hostels, which has opened several new hostels recently in popular locations, now has a Web site. The site is http://www.hiayh.org and it has information on the organization's 150 hostels in the United States, including locations, prices, how to reserve and what's in the neighborhood.

title: Rounding Up the 16th Street Suspects
description: The F.B.I.'s decision to re-investigate the 1963 church bombing in Birmingham, Ala., sent me back to my old reporting files for the first time in several years. As a native of Birmingham and longtime acquaintance of two of the four families that lost children in the blast, I was pleased by the news. But I am also cautious, for I know that the evidentiary corridor of this case, which twists through the most violent urban Klan klavern in American history, is truly a hall of mirrors.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROGERS, MARIA LUISA
description: ROGERS-Maria Luisa. Died July 13, 1996 at the age of 74. In loving memory. Your Husband, Philip.

title: The Warrior Besieged
description: Still unanswered is how the women-in-combat question has affected what Katha Pollitt calls difference feminism -- the belief that women are morally superior to men because they are nurturers rather than killers. You can't have it both ways, sisters.

title: Playing the Woman Beside the Man Who Took San Juan Hill
description: AS EDITH ROOSEVELT, THE WIFE OF Teddy and a graceful counterpart to his gang of warring roustabouts in TNT's ''Rough Riders,'' Illeana Douglas stands out like a diamond in the dirt.

title: Running a Fever
description: Of this century's many pandemics, at least two have been traced to the perusal of fashion magazines. Platform shoes, which swept Europe and America in the 1940's, and bell-bottom pants, which first appeared in 1965, are believed to be caused by viruses that mutate and periodically come back. No generation, it seems, is exempt, although those who have contracted the diseases and survived (neither is known to be fatal) are evidently immune to subsequent outbreaks. ''Ugh, platform shoes,'' mothers could be heard telling their daughters in the 70's. ''I wore those in the 40's. I never have to wear them again.'' Now many of those who, as young women, succumbed to platforms in the 70's can be heard saying the same.

title: Written on the Wind: The Sky as Billboard
description: SOMETIMES, presents that last the least can also last the longest. For proof, consider the lingering memory of an exquisite meal, an exotic vacation or an extravagant wedding. Could any gift be more ephemeral, though, than an enormous skywritten message slowly vaporizing in the heavens, like a long kiss goodbye?

title: Growing Kiwis Without Strangling on the Vines
description: Growing fruit is a risky proposition in the garden. Trees need lots of pruning, spraying and thinning. Berries are subject to predation. Grapes are prone to fungal diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, MARIAN R.
description: ADLER-Marian R., age 65. On July 11, 1997. Of Boynton Beach, Florida. Formerly of Glen Rock, New Jersey. Predeceased by her husband, William in 1995. Mother of Cathy and John Feldman, Nancy and Steven Manket and Beth and Steven Berns. Sister of Stuart Ratner. Beloved grandmother of Amy, David, Cara, Michelle, Matthew and William. Services are 12:30 PM today, Sunday at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rte. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Caroline Bicks, Brendon Reay
description: Caroline Todd Bicks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Bicks of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' house in Castine, Me., to Brendon Thomas Reay, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald T. Reay of Seattle. Margaret J. Kravchuk, the chief justice of Maine Superior Court in Bangor, performed the ceremony.

title: George Street Begins Search For Director
description: The board of the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick is forming a search committee to find a successor to Gregory S. Hurst, who was the theater's producing artistic director for nine years until his resignation on July 1.

title: School Tries To Get Free Of a Partner
description: After watching dozens of small, specialized public academies open in the city in the last few years, including several in their district, Community School Board 2 members expected no difficulty after the board voted to charter an independent secondary school specializing in dance. But a recent change in Board of Education policy may stymie their plans.

title: A Family Postscript To the Pickle Factory
description: Here is still another pickle story:

title: Proof Man's Belly Has a Higher Purpose Than Beer
description: WHEN Tyrone Bailey starts stacking shimmies atop graceful undulations, it's easy to forget the popular misconception that all belly dancers are female.

title: They Also Serve Who Wait For the Phone to Ring
description: It's mid-July already, and Cardell Cooper's clothes are probably pretty wrinkled by now. Since late winter, Mr. Cooper, the Mayor of this Essex County city, has been waiting for a telephone call from Bill Clinton, summoning him to Washington to assume a high-level Administration post.

title: Near Grand Central, Demand for Space Increases
description: THE continuing recovery in demand for Manhattan office space is nowhere more evident than in the district around Grand Central Terminal.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Listening to Mozart's Talented Inner Child
description: AT the age when most children are still fixated on the tooth fairy, Mozart was already writing music -- even on walls, when the muse overtook him. He composed his first symphony, a single movement for oboes, horns and strings, when he was 8, and by 32, three years before his death, his symphonies numbered 41. The last six are staples, and the preceding five are heard sporadically. The rest are hardly played at all.

title: The Royal Treatment: These Dogs Had Their Day
description: WHOEVER said that the Duke and Duchess of Windsor had nothing but style should get a load of their pugs. The Windsors' Paris home was full of them, underfoot and in porcelain, silver, needlepoint, lacquer, gouaches and oils.

title: Ancient Evenings
description: The Last Party

title: Presto! A David Copperfield Magic Restaurant
description: Colossal Monuments Unlimited, a monument company run by Daniel Cooperage in the earlier part of the century (so the story goes), is to light up the corner of Broadway and 49th Street when it magically reappears in December. The project is to cost $28 million. But wait.

title: Tranquillity, and Truffles in Profusion
description: IN an earlier life, Tartufo, an Italian restaurant in Southbury, was called Bacci. The ownership and name have changed, but the chef, we were told, is the same. The tranquil, appealing decor is also much as it was. High-backed upholstered chairs in powder blue, well-napped and well-spaced tables, pale peach walls with cream trim, make the airy, nonsmoking main dining room an oasis of tranquillity. There is a separate bar and smokers' dining room and a small glassed-in porch off the main dining room.

title: Old Yanks Are Taken With New One
description: The accidental, yet monumental, meeting between the greatest living Yankee and the newest Yankee occurred outside the Yankee clubhouse yesterday as Hideki Irabu was walking toward the bullpen in left field and Joe DiMaggio was strolling up the dugout runway on his way to George Steinbrenner's private box. It was a priceless three minutes during Old-Timers' Day.

title: A Poet With A Camera In Tow
description: THE TRUTH IS, I DIDN'T KNOW CHARLES KURALT very well. Other than his kin, few did. I knew enough not to call him Charlie, but the Charles I knew best was the televised Mr. Kuralt. We, his viewers, knew him, liked him and listened to him. And we believed he'd listen to us. We began missing him the minute he signed off the air, leaving as host of ''Sunday Morning,'' three years ago.

title: Private Prisons: A Question of Savings
description: WITH tighter budgets, an increasing inmate population and a trend toward longer jail terms, governments are turning more and more to private companies to run prisons. But a report by the General Accounting Office, the vendors' own balance sheets and other factors all raise questions about the companies' ability to fulfill their central promise -- cutting costs.

title: Hopi Center
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Susan Spano's tribute to the American Southwest (''A Roundabout Tour of Southwest Glories,'' May 25). Having spent nine days in northern Arizona in March, I, too, wonder at the lack of acclaim that our own country's historical treasures receive.

title: The Warrior Besieged
description: The question of whether or not women ought to participate in combat roles is a nonstarter but for contemporary cultural prejudice. More than one thousand British servicewomen died in World War II, performing such duties as engaging in antiaircraft gun duels with Stuka dive bombers in the Battle of Britain. They also aimed, loaded and fired 20-millimeter and 40-millimeter guns situated on Royal Navy vessels to protect evacuating British troops from Dunkirk. I should likewise think that the example of Israel's war of independence puts paid to the notion that women are unfit for combat. A certain Dr. Ruth Westheimer, little taller than a Lee Enfield rifle is long, is noted for having conducted herself rather well under fire.

title: Swimming Like Hotel Guest, Without Room Charge
description: Helen O'Malley flipped her visor, applied more sun block, leaned back to adjust her lounge chair and took another sip of her gin and tonic. High above West 57th Street, with the smell of chlorine and bacon, lettuce and tomato sandwiches wafting by, Ms. O'Malley, a broker's assistant at an investment firm, was more than content. ''If you don't pay attention to the skyscrapers you could be anywhere,'' she said, ''the Hamptons, the Jersey Shore or the suburbs.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HARVEY E.
description: SMITH-Harvey E., on July 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Renee. Loving father of Miriam and Lisa and father-in-law of John. Adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Sarah and Michele. Service was held.

description: To the Editor:

title: Viva Mexican Democracy -- In Theory
description: DURING the Mexican Revolution, violence spilled across the United States' southern border so frequently that on the eve of World War I, the Army had half of its forces garrisoned there to contain Mexico's chaos. Ever since, Americans have wanted stability in Mexico and mostly they've had it: the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has been in charge for seven decades.

title: A Maintenance Guide to Gas Grills
description: YEARS ago, outdoor cooking involved lighting a pile of charcoal in a brick or stone hearth. For those who didn't have a masonry pit, or who wanted to take their barbecue to a favorite vacation spot, manufacturers offered a portable charcoal grill. Eventually, designers developed a gas grill that dispensed with the charcoal, yet still offered the full flavor of outdoor cooking.

title: Athletes Are the Victims In These Sneaker Wars
description: Sixteen-year-old Rafael Berumen launched his basketball career in earnest last week, flying from California to New Jersey on booster-club money to audition with 239 other high school players for several hundred college coaches at a recruiting fair sponsored by a shoe company.

title: It's Tough As Usual, But Cone Wins Again
description: David Cone limped across the clubhouse, struggled to pull off his dirty uniform, joked that he was too old to continue pitching in tough games like yesterday's 6-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers and looked as if he could have fallen asleep in the chair. But the most revealing feature was the expression on Cone's flushed face. It was a look of relief. Utter relief.

title: Bobbie Koepp And Sidney Green
description: Bobbie M. Koepp and Sidney Green are to be married today in Ithaca, N.Y. Judge Judith A. Rossiter of the Ithaca City Court is to officiate at the home of Hilary R. and John L. Ford, the daughter and son-in-law of the bridegroom.

title: Hoping for Tuscany on Hudson at a New Restaurant
description: A COUPLE of hundred feet from the Hudson River stands a dilapidated steel warehouse, a relic from this village's industrial past, that is now being transformed into a Tuscan-style restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JIRAK, MARY
description: JIRAK-Mary. On behalf of our entire organization it is with profound sorrow that we express our sincere condolences to our Vice Chairman, Jeff Gural and his wife Paula Jirak Gural on the untimely loss of Paula's dear mother Mary. We also wish to extend our heartfelt sympathy to the rest of the Gural/Jirak families. Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. William Cohen Ronald Goldberger Barry Gosin Aaron Gural Ira Fishman James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post and Arthur Rosenbloom.

title: Music Only An Artist Can Love?
description: YOU haven't heard slide guitar until you've heard it played with a bottle of ruby-red Revlon. On Wednesday night, 17 young women wielding nail-polish bottles sat on the floor of the Greene Naftali gallery in Chelsea, the city's latest art frontier, and struck up a half-hour-long wall of cacophony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUIREY, SYLVIA OBOLENSKY
description: GUIREY - Sylvia Obolensky. Funeral services Church of Messiah, Rhinebeck, New York, 11AM, July 26, 1997, followed by interment at Rhinebeck Cemetery.

title: Kelly Guariglia, Vincent Commisa
description: Kelly Ann Guariglia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Guariglia of Middletown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Vincent DePaul Commisa, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Diamond Nicholas Commisa. The Rev. William A. Hanson officiated at the King of Kings Lutheran Church.

title: Literary Rejections, Even for Children
description: For would-be poets and artists, no matter how young, being published is not easy. So when Community School District 3, which covers the Upper West Side and southern Harlem, published its third annual literary magazine, in June, the rejections far outnumbered the acceptances.

title: Gina Fuentes, Sheafe Walker
description: Gina Margaret Fuentes, the daughter of Margarita and Ernesto Fuentes of Fairfax, Va., was married yesterday to Sheafe Benjamin Walker, the son of Dina and Daniel Walker of New York. The Rev. John B. Luce, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The Rev. Julius C. Beretta, a friend of the bride who is a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: 3 Straight Against Braves? Not if Maddux Is Pitching
description: The Mets are infected with confidence, but not so much that they are delirious and out of touch with reality. Coming off two late-inning comeback victories, they scored three runs in the first two innings today against the Atlanta pitching machine otherwise known as Greg Maddux. The Mets had control of the game and the series.

title: A Strong Dollar Spurs Travel
description: IF you want to save money, stay home. If you venture out, the best travel values for the money are likely to be found in the world's most efficient consumer economy, the United States.

title: Two Years That Make a Big Difference
description: One of the biggest issues that the House and Senate will have to resolve in the current budget negotiations is whether to raise the age at which Americans are eligible for Medicare. The House chose to keep the age of eligibility at 65, and seems determined to stick to that position. The Senate's plan, on the other hand, calls for raising the age to 67. This proposal creates more problems than it solves.

description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRBY, RICHARD H.
description: KIRBY-Richard H. July 9, 1997. Loving husband of Dolores Lightfoot Kirby. Father of Faye Harden and June Storer. Brother of John A. Kirby, Jr. Viewing Monday, July 14, 1-7 PM, Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave, NYC. Funeral service at Mt. Olivet Baptist Church, 201 Lenox Ave (120th St.), July 15 at 11 AM. Interment July 17, Lincoln Memorial Cemetery, Suitland, MD.

title: Gina Duclayan, Daniel Radosh
description: Gina Martinez Duclayan, a daughter of Lucille J. Duclayan of Collinsville, Conn., and John F. Duclayan of Wichita, Kan., was married yesterday to Daniel Lord Radosh, the son of Alice Radosh of Brooklyn and Ronald Radosh of Brookville, Md. The Rev. James Potter, a minister of the United Church of Christ and an uncle of the bride, performed the nondenominational ceremony in Indian Lake, N.Y., at the summer home of the bridegroom's mother's family.

title: Corrections
description: Part of a chart about the New York apartment rental market on the front page of Real Estate today is colored incorrectly. In the chart and map for studio apartments, the Bronx should be colored yellow, indicating a decline in rents.

title: The Auto Insurance Albatross
description: Readers were asked what they would change to lower automobile insurance rates. Some offered reforms; others said they would not change a thing.

title: Sherri Hershkowitz, Jonathan Lerner
description: Sherri Lynn Hershkowitz and Jonathan Gordon Lerner are to be married today. Rabbi Yakov R. Hilsenrath is to perform the ceremony at the Highland Park (N.J.) Conservative Temple.

title: Aqui Se Habla Friendliness And Politics
description: THE work often takes place before daybreak; the hours taken up with conversations and conjugations. Ruth W. Messinger is learning Spanish.

title: Israel Games Draw Westchester Athletes
description: LORIN AMBINDER of Hartsdale will not have her twin sister's footsteps beside her this time. Nina Zeitlin of Scarsdale, will, however, be following in her mother's footsteps. Matthew Deutsch of West Harrison wants to trod in the footsteps of his forebears. Scott Grayson of Briarcliff Manor is hoping to follow the footsteps of his coach.

title: A Determined Martinez Makes a Name for Himself
description: The five-foot-high chain-link fence surrounds the backyard of the busy house on Kathleen Street in Tampa, Fla. It is designed to do what fences do. Divide one piece of property from the other. Keep the dog from escaping. Insure privacy. It is a fence, after all.

title: I Told You So
description: On Friday, the Clinton Administration released a report on the first three years of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The most the Administration could bring itself to say is that Nafta has had a ''modest positive effect'' on the American economy. That's a far cry from the extravagant promises made by the accord's proponents during the 1993 debate: ''Hundreds of thousands of new jobs! Higher wages! A cleaner environment! Just you wait and see!''

title: The Warrior Besieged
description: Richard Rayner does a credible job discussing the impact of women on the military. The goal of feminists and their political allies is to transform the American armed forces into a coed institution offering travel, equal job opportunities, education and self-fulfillment for everyone. Anyone who has fought in World War II, Korea or Vietnam knows that the only reason for the existence of an Army, Navy and Air Force is to win wars by killing as many of the enemy as possible.

title: Jamie Tarses' Fall, as Scheduled

title: Save Sigmund Freud
description: An odd thing happened in my classroom not long ago, something that made me pause and consider what it would be like to live in a culture that had fully banished Sigmund Freud. We were discussing a famous essay by the literary critic Leslie Fiedler called ''Come Back to the Raft Ag'in, Huck Honey.'' In it, Fiedler talks about repressed homosexual attraction between males. The students, bright kids at a good university, couldn't figure out what to make of it. None of them had ever encountered the idea of repressed desire, the idea that one could be passionately drawn to another person yet not be aware of it. Now, Freud's theory of repression is surely debatable, but never to have encountered the idea, not to have it as a possible explanatory resource -- that struck me as an impoverished condition.

title: Turkey, Jailer of Journalists
description: Turkey has the shameful distinction of imprisoning more journalists than any country in the world. The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists has compiled a list of 78 reporters, writers and editors now in jail, and the Turkish Press Council reckons the total may be twice as high. Now that a new Government has assumed power, it has a timely opportunity to open those prison doors. Doing so would lessen a stain on Turkey's reputation and enhance the democratic credentials of Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz's secularist center-right coalition.

It even decides how some tax money is allocated.

title: Stewart, Mitchum and a Nation's Character
description: WHAT THEY HAD IN common, beyond a charisma rare even by movie-star standards and a gift for making acting look easy, was that they spoke so clearly for our collective aspirations. James Stewart and Robert Mitchum, who by sad coincidence died only a day apart at the start of this month, seemed to spring from opposite yet equally fundamental sides of American nature: the stalwart and the subversive. Both were also part of a Hollywood, now long gone, that valued character over personality and let its greatest talents create full, deep self-portraits on the screen. To watch either Stewart or Mitchum was to believe you were seeing past the role into the essence of the man.

title: The Bel Canto Project Is to Begin at Caramoor
description: AN important development at Caramoor in Katonah is a multifaceted program to promote bel canto opera, with Will Crutchfield as the director. ''Beginning with Maria Callas, and continuing with Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne and their younger colleagues, the revival of bel canto has been the most successful and important restoration to the operatic repertory in the last 40 years,'' Mr. Crutchfield said. ''But it has not had as strong a foothold in New York as in other operatic centers, so there is a keen need for a consistent, high-quality forum for bel canto here.''

Indeed, some of the great moments in jazz were incongruous double-deckers created for no particularly good reason: Sonny Rollins made gold out of ersatz cowboy songs on his ''Way Out West'' album; Art Tatum found Xanadu in ''Danny Boy,'' and Abbey Lincoln more recently found it in ''Mr. Tambourine Man.'' And of course the durable melodies by America's popular-music composers writing for theater or film have become jazz's paving stones.

Rather, it is to prepare ''ensembles'' of works to travel around the world.

title: An Ode to Fitz

Without commenting directly on the quality of Halleck's verse, which Tierney describes, perhaps not inaccurately, as ''ranging from the incomprehensible to the awful,'' we would note that Halleck nonetheless played a role in the historic movement of the times that created a uniquely American voice in literature and poetry. Among those early voices was a contemporary of Halleck's, Washington Irving.

title: Leave-Takings, Codas and Fond Goodbyes
description: To complete an enterprise you have lived with for years induces a certain giddiness. I know: I've just done it. On Dec. 15, I sent my editor the fifth volume -- the last -- of ''The Bourgeois Experience: Victoria to Freud,'' the history of the inner life of the Victorian middle class that I began in 1971, literally a quarter-century before. My project looked quite different then: it has had a tortuous history of its own. Intent on telling my readers how radically I had reconceived my work under the pressure of my material, I added a coda, seizing the opportunity to conclude with some heartfelt exit lines: ''As I put down my pen, or, rather, as I transfer a text for 'The Bourgeois Experience' to a floppy disk for the last time, I . . . am moving on with a mixture of relief and regret: it is done at last! and, it is, sadly, done!''

description: One byproduct of New York City's plunging crime rate was a proposed economic-development ad campaign comparing New York's per capita crime rate to that of relatively tiny Boise, Idaho. New York's lower rate excited the Martin Agency, the Richmond, Va., company that won the account in 1996. A mock-up for its $12 million campaign showed a tough New York businessmen with a line announcing that his city's safety rates right up there . . . with Boise. Alas, focus groups didn't buy it, perhaps sensing that per head comparisons don't always mean much. New York had 984 homicides in 1996; Boise had 1. The idea, and the Martin Agency, were quietly rubbed out.

title: Maintaining Gas Grills: A Guide
description: YEARS ago, outdoor cooking involved lighting a pile of charcoal in a brick or stone hearth. For those who didn't have masonry pits or wanted to take their barbecues to favorite vacation spots, manufacturers offered a portable charcoal grill. Eventually, designers developed a gas grill that dispensed with the charcoal, yet still offered the full flavor of outdoor cooking.

title: A Landmark of Daily Life Is to Be Rebuilt in Brooklyn
description: There is an eerie square marked only by a green wooden roadblock where the Prospect Park newsstand at the Grand Army Plaza subway station once stood.

title: The ABC's of The TV Code
description: When you tune into your favorite television program in October, you may well find a label in the upper left-hand corner of the screen for the first 15 seconds of the show -- something like ''TV-14/ VSLD,'' translated to mean the show is unsuitable for children under 14 because it contains violence, sex, coarse language and suggestive dialogue.

title: Putting the Fun Back in British Politics
description: LIKE a soap opera freshened with new characters and a juicy new plot line, ''Prime Minister's Question Time'' has gotten to be fun again. With the election of Tony Blair as a Labor Prime Minister, C-Span's weekly half-hour of unedited parliamentary inquiry, broadcast Sundays at 9 P.M., viewers have a new leading man, a new supporting cast and a new script. Can Tony confound his enemies and carry through his bold yet prudent, daring yet cautious program for a new Britain? Can the Tories, humiliated at the polling booth, take petty revenge during question time?

title: A Sad Lack of Vision for a Venerable Club
description: THE Thomas J. Walsh Gallery at Fairfield University has missed the chance to enlighten its audience on an underexamined period of American art -- from just after the Civil War to the advent of Modernism. The Walsh Gallery (with the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, N.Y.) has organized an exhibition of art by early members of the Salmagundi Club, an important Manhattan haven for artists that began as a sketch club in Greenwich Village in 1871.

title: Zabel Wins Tour de France Stage and This Time Keeps the Victory
description: A day after he was stripped of a victory in the Tour de France for dangerous riding and head-butting in the final sprint, Erik Zabel mended his ways, held to a straight line, savaged nobody and cruised across the finish line an easy winner.

title: Correction
description: A chart on June 29 with an article about Ara Chekmayan, who owns a statue of a falcon that may have been used in the film ''The Maltese Falcon,'' misstated a plot detail in Dashiell Hammett's novel of the same name. In the novel, the falcon was found in a Paris shop in 1911, not 1931.

title: Drawn to a Wild, Remote River
description: The Rapid River in Maine is only one of many places in northern New England to fish for landlocked salmon, but its relative inaccessibility -- there are no public motor vehicle roads to it -- and wild aspect tug at me anew each spring.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page index in the Arts and Leisure section today carries three incorrect page numbers in some copies. Theater is on page 5, not 38. Dance is on page 6, not 39. Film is on page 10, not 38.

title: Even Space Has Its Bad Apples
description: Men in Black

title: A Photography Show Celebrates Stamina
description: WHAT would be a photography department at most seats of higher learning is, at Purchase College here, a photography ''area,'' and the students who enter it do so ''unaware of art history and elite cultural values.''

title: Legerdemain? Well, Sort Of
description: A FRIEND HAS PASSED ON AN article from The Times of London reporting on the development of a left-handed piano. This is not, I assure you, the left-handed monkey wrench of practical jokedom but serious business. Christopher Seed is the inventor and hopeful developer, although there is not really much inventing involved, only the employment of an idea.

title: Times Square Awaits MTV Live
description: Inspired by the success of the ''Today'' program's window-on-New-York set in Rockefeller Center, MTV will begin live broadcasts in September from an ambitious new studio that stretches across a full block and uses as its backdrop the crowds and billboards of Times Square.

title: The March of the Empty Suitcases
description: THE summer people have arrived. They are cluttering the streets, walking slowly, looking stupid. They are smoking in the subway and drinking red wine in the park. The young ones are nearly naked. Many are barefoot. The old ones are in clashing plaids. All are slung with sacks filled with water, hard currency, caps, jackets, inflatable back rests and maps they will pull out and unfold anywhere, halting traffic. I hate them. I wish they would go home.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 8 about a European's experience with American dating rituals omitted a translation credit. The article, by Arnon Grunberg, was translated from the Dutch by Ron de Klerk and Lisa Friedman.
