title: Emily Fisher, Rolf Grimsted
description: Emily Lewis Fisher, a daughter of Philip B. Fisher Jr. of New York and the late Emily Norcross Fisher, was married yesterday to Rolf Davidson Grimsted, a son of Dr. Patricia Kennedy Grimsted of Cambridge, Mass., and David A. Grimsted of Washington. The Rev. James A. Trimble, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's by-the-Sea in Winter Harbor, Me.

title: The Sun Is to Rise On Hemingway Events
description: After 16 years in Key West, Fla., it seemed as though the Hemingway Days Festival would be no more. Earlier this year, the festival's organizer, Michael Whalton, scrapped the festival because the writers' sons, John, Patrick and Gregory Hemingway, had demanded licensing fees and 10 percent of the gross. The Hemingway brothers have said that the festival's rowdiness and unlicensed merchandising were disparaging to the memory of their father. But now, it appears there will be two festivals.

title: Fodor's, or Your Portfolio?
description: Do you spend more time planning, say, your trip to Tahiti than researching your mutual fund investments? If so, you are not alone. A recent survey found that people tend to spend 28 days planning their annual vacation but take only nine days to decide which funds to buy. And 70 percent said they needed only one day to research their fund investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATENACCIO, JOSEPH
description: CATENACCIO-Joseph. On July 9, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Rosalia. Loving father of Robert and grandfather of Grace, Claire and Eva. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday and Saturday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, on Monday, at 10 A.M.

description: USED AND RARE

title: The Warrior Besieged
description: If women in the military can't defend themselves from sexual harassment, what are they doing in combat troops?

title: Take That, Couture
description: While couture designers were showing outlandish five- and six-figure costumes in the Paris shows last week, street fashion in New York was looking in an opposite direction: that of simple, sensuous femininity, in lace dresses and lace-trimmed slip dresses. Some of the half-slips and dresses are lingerie treasures from another era, found at thrift shops and antiques sales. The silhouette's loose easy fit recalls the liberated 1920's flapper -- a style that waged a reaction against the costume fashion inspired by the Ballet Russe. In a similar way, women in New York today are ignoring the bizarre costume style of Paris fashion with their own effortless fashion mix.

title: How a Proto-SoHo Thrived in Old New York
description: IT'S A RULE OF THUMB IN commercial real estate: location is everything. And that consideration has been very much on the mind of the New York art world in the last few years, as galleries move from SoHo to Chelsea, from Prince Street to Grand, wondering where the center of economic gravity will fall.

title: Jets to Hold Festival for Fans
description: Jets fans of all ages will join the team, at least spiritually, on Friday when training camp begins. The club is beginning a monthlong football carnival called Jets Fest '97. The football-related idea, modeled on the N.F.L. Experience festivals that are featured at Super Bowls, will include more than 15 games involving throwing, kicking and catching. Jets Fest will be staged adjacent to the team's practices on the north campus of Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y.

title: 'Beowulf' Is So Now, It Could Open in a Cineplex
description: IT MAY BE THE SUMMER'S IDEAL alternative to all those eardrum exploding movie blockbusters, or your continuing struggle to hold Thomas Pynchon's ''Mason & Dixon'' upright when your hands are freshly slathered in No. 30 sunblock.

title: Q. & A.
description: Increasing Sublet Fees In a Co-op

title: Where the Motive Is Old-Fashioned Fun
description: BEHIND the bookcase, a secret door. Just the spot for stashing away a dead body, don't you think?

title: It's the Economy, Congress
description: They once stretched, as politicians often intoned, as far as the eye could see. But Federal budget deficits, which only a few years ago were symbols of national decline, government run amok and political gridlock, are now evaporating.

title: Pick of the Season: Fresh Corn, Tossed in a Salad or Sauteed
description: A FRIEND of mine insists that the only way to get really great corn is to pick it after you have put the water on to boil. He would not have approved had he seen me in the market last month, sifting through the first shipments, which had been trucked from Florida. Fifty-nine cents an ear for corn at least a day old (if you were lucky)! But I could not resist, and I was lucky. The corn was as juicy and sweet as the best of the summer.

description: THE GREAT LOBSTER WAR

description: WEDNESDAY

title: Downhill From Scarsdale
description: Fans of J. P. Donleavy -- and newcomers to his antics -- can rejoice at his latest rich, ribald and touching creation, THE LADY WHO LIKED CLEAN REST ROOMS: The Chronicle of One of the Strangest Stories Ever to Be Rumoured About Around New York (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $18.95). Mrs. Jocelyn Guenevere Marchantiere Jones sweeps onto the scene as the doyenne of an estimable house and fortune in Scarsdale. Although her South Carolinian, socially registered grandmother disapproved of anything above the Mason-Dixon line, Jocelyn still honors her code of behavior: ''Your snobberies are the most preciously valuable asset you will ever have in life, cherish them well. Avoid unbrave men and when you're away from your own trusted lavatory, only go to the cleanest of places.'' But Jocelyn's certainties are tested when her husband leaves her for a bit of ''fresh flesh.'' Ever the lady, Jocelyn proposes modest terms for the divorce and holds her course through financial collapse. What follows is a freewheeling tour of our heroine's ''unexpurgated thoughts'' as fortune bounces her down the peculiar social ladder that separates Scarsdale from Yonkers, Yonkers from the Bronx -- and the New World nouveaux riches from the ''dignified homeless indigent.'' Donleavy proves himself as much the master of a certain New York social set and train corridor as he is of the psyche of a fresh-mouthed 43-year-old Daughter of the Confederacy. The reader cheers for Jocelyn as she fends off her friends' husbands, brandishes a .38-caliber Smith & Wesson and lives for her trips to Manhattan's museums. But her search for the city's cleanest restrooms becomes increasingly desperate, leading Jocelyn finally to a funeral parlor and a quite shocking reversal of fate. Eight elegant line drawings by Elliott Banfield complement Donleavy's slim text, depicting moments of scandal with a restraint that would do Jocelyn's grandmother proud. Nina Sonenberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICH, HARVEY
description: TEICH-Harvey. 93 years on July 11, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Helen; devoted father of Marlene and Gary Walter; loving grandfather of Lori and Jerry, Caroline and the late Ira; greatgrandfather of Ilana and Ashley. In memoriam contributions are being accepted to Franklin Hospital Medical Center, Development Office, 900 Franklin Ave., Valley Stream, NY 11580. Services were held July 11 and Shiva will be observed through Thursday AM.

title: An Attempt to Broaden Teaneck Pool Club Membership
description: The Teaneck Swim Club, with its basketball, volleyball and tennis courts, three pools and grassy picnic area on nine and a half acres of public land, has been operating in the township for two decades. Its membership has been limited to 800 households, and it has a long waiting list. Now the Township Council is to vote this month on an agreement with the club that would open it to more members and double the rent the club pays to the township. But the changes are not enough to satisfy a group of residents who say the club should be more open to town residents.

title: A Fast-Acting Testosterone Booster
description: HOW can you tell if a new car has scored a direct hit on its intended market? One reliable barometer, I have found, is the attention a car receives during a test drive. If a new model provokes plenty of unsolicited, favorable comments, it is likely to be a success.

title: A New Code Could Bring Courtesy to Court
description: It is a time-honored tradition that acceptable adversarial behavior for lawyers includes throwing tantrums that their mothers probably would have scolded them for: hurling a briefcase across the room, calling the other side's lawyer unprintable names, even telling off the judge.

title: Green Outpost, Where Famous Bought Seeds, Is Closing
description: As he prepares to close the Farm and Garden Nursery, started by his parents nearly 60 years ago where the World Trade Center stands, Bob Berg remembers the day in the early 50's when Marilyn Monroe came in. His father and uncle were wowed by her presence, but to Mr. Berg, it ''was no big deal.'' The actress was just another customer among many, and she was treated as such.

title: Danger as a Way of Life
description: For five years -- before I managed to make a living as a freelance journalist -- I made my money working as a high climber for tree-removal companies. The trees were leaning over people's houses and couldn't simply be felled; they had to be dismantled piece by piece. Two or three days a week I would climb 60- or 70-foot trees, cutting sections off with a chain saw and lowering them on ropes held by workers on the ground.

title: Chinese Cooking Without the Deep Frying
description: THERE is a story behind every restaurant. Even the tiniest takeout has a tale to tell. The modest Good Earth, which opened recently at 399 New York Avenue at Huntington Village (421-1414), is a case in point.

title: What Does the Leadership Mean to the Average Wong?
description: To the Editor:

title: Serious Romance
description: BOTH my mother-in-law, a chemist, and my mother, who shops, dislike Mother's Day. The crowds, the corsages and the fuss made by maitres d'hotel they don't know embarrass them. They would just as soon skip town and return the next day.

title: Personal Training at Ford's Gym
description: IT is a balancing act faced by many auto makers: how to create exciting cars that appeal to the small but influential group of hard-core enthusiasts without detracting from their main mission, selling large numbers of mainstream vehicles that generate the bulk of corporate earnings?

description: Cruising the Inside Passage

description: GALLAGHER-Francis J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Francis J. Gallagher, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1993.

title: A Southern Italian Hero, to the Rescue of the Hungry
description: Angelo's Cafe could easily be situated on a piazza in Verona (Italy, not New Jersey) instead of at a strip mall in Middletown.

title: The Warrior Besieged
description: Rayner seems to consider half the population -- all women -- potential sexual partners, and he seems to have difficulty considering them as much more. He twice confesses to feeling ''aroused'' by a female sergeant; he goes to a club that from its description appears to be a strip joint and ponders on the absence of a ''female warrior. . .strutting her stuff'' (his way of noting that no Army women are in attendance); he asks us to consider his version of events at Aberdeen: ''women being trained by men, wanting to secure the benevolence of the drill sergeants; women admiring the drill sergeants.''

title: Lauren Munro And Minot Dole
description: Lauren Blake Munro, a daughter of Margaret W. Munro of Dallas and Allan F. Munro of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Minot Truax Dole, the son of Istar H. Mudge of Millbrook, N.Y., and Charles Minot Dole Jr. of Essex, Conn. The Rev. Terence Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: A Music Festival Not as Timeless As Its Setting
description: THE SANTA FE CHAMBER Music Festival celebrates its 25th anniversary this summer, but the spirit of the observance speaks less of wistful reflection than of renaissance and redirection.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: PUN intended, the sound of music on film this week is noteworthy. Top attractions include a near-forgotten live action treat from Walt Disney, as well as a musical star who turns in an Oscar-winning performance in a drama. THE THREE LIVES OF THOMASINA (1964), directed by Don Chaffey, concerns a crusty Scottish veterinarian (Patrick McGoohan), his daughter (Susan Hampshire), her pet cat (Thomasina) and a beguiling village newcomer (Karen Dotrice). Based on a Paul Gallico story, this sweet Disney fable revolves around a cat with four paws on the ground that inadvertently alters the lives of those closest to her -- Friday/Early Saturday at 1:25 A.M. on the Disney Channel.

title: Still More Nonsense: Lewis Wins On Penalty
description: Mills Lane needs a vacation.

title: Land of the Cineplex, Home of the Cassette
description: AMERICANS ARE WATCHING MOVIES ANY way they can, in theaters or at home, by VCR, cable or satellite dish. Most people prefer to take in a movie without leaving the house, and they're getting only cozier and cozier with that notion. At the same time, if a film is strong enough, people are turning out in large numbers at the multiplex. And with the continuous flood of movies out there, they know they had better hurry before most are whisked off the big screen and reformatted to fit their television sets.

title: NET GAINS
description: Today's tennis players have a choice: To borrow from the gentlemanly styles of the past or to jump into the future.

title: Atlantic City Casino Workers Strain Neighbors' Resources
description: Jim Frugoli, a Brigantine city councilman, paused on a recent Saturday to take in the sunshine and the ocean breeze that caressed his island home town, just a throw of the dice from Atlantic City's dazzling casinos but worlds away from its crime and poverty. ''You can be just five minutes over that bridge from the life of the party of the whole East Coast, and yet come back to the solace and serenity of a beautiful island,'' Mr. Frugoli said. ''I'll tell you something,'' he added. ''If God made a better place to live, he sure kept it to himself.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, MURIEL
description: RUBIN-Muriel. Devoted wife of the late Jack, loving mother of Burton and Sue Rubin and Ivan and the late Mona Rubin. Adored grandmother of Jamie, Debra, Fred and Margot. Cherished great grandmother of Melanie and Jordan. Loving sister of Hortense Herman and Arnold Greenfield. Services were held Friday, July 11, 1997. Contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, ESTELLE NEE GLASSMAN
description: HAFT-Estelle nee Glassman, (59). Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Mindy and Richard Solomon, Michael Haft and Debra and Russell Monaco. Adored grandmother of Rebecca and Alexander. Dear sister, aunt and cherished friend. Services at Bayswater Jewish Center, Sunday, 11 AM.

title: North Fork Buyers Trade Commutes for Country Life
description: THE largely unspoiled farm country of the North Fork is increasingly attracting buyers willing to commute long distances in return for the advantages of country life.

title: Corrections
description: The Arts and Leisure Guide today contains an outdated music listing and picture caption about Mary Chapin Carpenter's benefit concert for Central Park Summerstage. Because of a scheduling conflict, the concert, originally planned for Friday, has been canceled.

title: Plays-in-Progress at Vassar College
description: SEVERAL months after ''Sex and Longing'' bombed on Broadway, the playwright Christopher Durang called Peter J. Manning, the producer of New York Stage and Film Company with second thoughts on his play of last season.

title: Dining High
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed Stuart Stevens's article ''Just Another Meal in Paradise'' (June 8). Eating in every three-star Michelin restaurant on successive days is a daunting feat, and I hope he has a good cardiologist.

title: A Roadway Built for the Elite to Trot Out Their Rigs
description: COMPLETED 99 years ago this month, the Harlem Speedway was a $5 million bread-and-circuses project built to serve both the rich -- who wanted a racing ground for their fast trotters -- and the not-so-rich, who were supposed to watch. A visitor can still follow the track of this controversial highway by going up the Harlem River Drive from 155th Street to Dyckman Street.

title: Crime
description: "This was the guide's last trip," Jane Whitefield vows in SHADOW WOMAN (Random House, $22), the new thrillerama in Thomas Perry's hide-and-seek adventure series about a Seneca Indian from upstate New York who plucks "the hunted, the wounded, and the defeated" from danger and spirits them away to brand-new lives. When a Las Vegas casino executive and ladies' man named Pete Hatcher runs afoul of his crooked associates, Jane engineers a sensational disappearance from a Vegas nightclub, right in the middle of the Miraculous Miranda's magic act. But the distraction of a new husband has made Jane sloppy, and in a few months she is racing west in a desperate attempt to rescue Pete from the clutches of Earl and Linda, a team of assassins who fuel themselves on a lethal hormonal cocktail of eroticism and rage.

description: To the Editor:

title: Old Boats to Get New Home
description: Built in 1907, the Yankee ferried immigrants to and from Ellis Island and, years later, tourists to and from the beaches of Block Island.

title: Town Mouse Seeks Moose
description: BROOKLYN born, Manhattan bred, I've always liked my ground solid, preferably paved. Of course, I enjoyed my annual spring trips to the city's botanical gardens and the occasional Central Park stroll, but too many days in real country left me restless. I missed the lullaby of horns and sirens and found the early morning bird calls more grating than any alarm clock. Yet suddenly there I was in my new Eddie Bauer Gore-Tex parka and Timberland guaranteed waterproof hiking boots heading for Alaska to experience Nature in the greatest wilderness of all. So I wasn't backpacking or camping. A wildlife adventure tour by bus, boat and float plane was a stretch for a city slicker like me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENEGAS, HELEN
description: SENEGAS-Helen, 85, died July 8, from cancer of the pancreas. She attended the Ethical Culture School, the Fieldston School, and Yale Art School. She was a commercial artist and life long resident of New York City. She leaves two daughters, Jean Senegas and Kay Gottesman, and two grandsons Evan and Brian Gottesman. A private funeral was held. Memorial contributions may be sent to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Ave. at 16th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: More of Italy To Shine at Night
description: A recent initiative by the Italian Culture Ministry will brighten even the darkest nights: until Sept. 14, 33 of Italy's principal art attractions will reopen from 8:30 to 11:30 P.M. on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMET, LILLIAN MARCUS
description: ARMET-Lillian Marcus. Beloved wife of the late David H. Armet. Devoted mother of Dr. Stuart and Helene Armet and Maxine and Irwin Mohr. Cherished grandmother of Ruthann and Scott Young, Dr. Allan and Debbie Mohr, Stacey and Stephen Wenczel and David and Jen Armet. Adored greatgrandmother of Justin and Ryan Mohr and Jerry Young. description: Responding to a ban on opposition party politics that was announced along with the creation of this country's new Government in May, one of Congo's most outspoken opposition politicians decided he should move his office.

title: The Englishwoman Who Is Fit to Play A Formidable Queen
description: ''I DON'T LIKE MAKING films, Judi Dench announced disarmingly, explaining in one simple phrase why so admired a British stage and television actress should be largely unknown outside her country. ''I never have liked making films. I like doing a play because you go on and on and it gets better. I don't like doing one take, or four takes, because I'm not sure of myself.''

title: Bus Ride to Connecticut Takes a Queens Girl to the Land of Summertime
description: Crouched on her black travel bag on the floor of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, munching animal crackers and vanilla cookies, Chanell Brown waited patiently on Monday for the hands of a watch to move from noon to 2 o'clock.

description: Giants linebacker Jessie Armstead knows that the Jets turned heads in the New York football community when they hired Coach Bill Parcells. But as training camps open for both teams later this week, Armstead, the Giants' defensive leader, has a prediction:

title: The Care And Harvest Of Mesclun
description: MESCLUN is a popular word among homemakers and gourmets -- and, most recently, gardeners. The French term describes the mixture of greens now used for salads to provide a blend of colors and textures as well as flavors.

title: Ids and Ads
description: I feel compelled to alert the public to two extraordinary events in the realm of advertising. A prominent scholar and searcher for truth now champions misrepresentation and fabrication in advertisements for himself. And a mendacious industry that peddles tobacco now offers censorship and regulation of advertisements for itself. American chutzpah really knows no bounds.

title: Girls Win First Prize for a First Musical
description: WHEN Jennie Cohen and Catherine Spencer greeted each other one recent morning they gave the impression that neither Rodgers and Hammerstein nor Lerner and Loewe had ever had so much fun.

title: Family Plot
description: It was my father calling, but not with the usual chitchat from home -- nothing about his golf game, Okinawa in 1945 or his crush on Rosie O'Donnell. Now that he has decided to give his body to science, providing a cadaver for medical students at the University of Texas (a loyal alumnus to the end, my father), he is thinking of selling off the remainder of our family grave site in an enormous cemetery in Houston.

title: Author Tells of Baseball Glory, Day by Day
description: THREE years ago a curve ball was thrown at Burt Solomon, a writer with more than four decades of experience. He was asked to write three chapters of a proposed baseball book on speculation.

title: Imagination on Two Wheels: A Vehicle Takes Flight
description: AN exhibition about the golden age of bicycles occupies the gallery at the Morris Museum just vacated by a show devoted to dinosaurs. Both subjects recall bygone eras, but they retain a universal, primitive appeal. Bikes and the beasts, once kings of their domains, have been overtaken by things more fleet.

title: Hunt for Royal Treasure Leads Okinawan to a House in Massachusetts
description: The ancient royal crown of Okinawa a silk helmet-shaped headdress studded with gold, jade, pearls and precious stones that is one of the most important still-missing national treasures stolen in World War II -- may be hidden in this well-scrubbed suburb of Boston.

title: Kathleen Howard, J. D. McCambridge
description: Dr. Kathleen Patricia Howard, a daughter of Patricia and John Howard of Manhasset, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. James Drury McCambridge, a son of Kathleen McCambridge of Arlington Heights, Ill., and the late Paul McCambridge. The Rev. Edward Kiernan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary.

title: Trippe's Clipper, Hailed in the Afterglow
description: THE lunch crowd at Manero's in Greenwich flies high six times each year. The occasions are the bimonthly meetings of Pan Am Airways retirees -- former pilots, captains, administrators and flight attendants, some of whom joined Pan Am shortly after it was a founded in 1927, and stayed there for most of their careers. Most of the more than 100 who attended the spring event are eager to sustain and rekindle friendships, and indulge in a little nostalgia.

title: Civil Rights, Elective Office, or What?
description: ROGER VANN, 31 years old, is in his second two-year term as president of the Greater New Haven chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. It is a volunteer position, covering towns from Madison to Milford to Cheshire and involving 1,500 members. For a living, Mr. Vann works as a radio talk show host on WELI (960 AM), based in Hamden. He is also a host on a morning show called ''Off Center'' with Tom Scott, a conservative former State Senator from Milford.

title: From Horse Farms to Public Recreation
description: ON a snowy day in the winter of 1996, Sally Lynch and Melanie Awe signed a contract with Suffolk County to restore and operate the Old Field Farm in Setauket. After the deal the women stopped at a liquor store in St. James, bought cold Champagne and asked for two paper cups.

title: AGENCY STRUGGLING TO IMPROVE WAY IT GRANTS CITIZENSHIP
description: Eight months after vowing to overhaul its troubled citizenship program, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is still struggling to put new procedures in place to prevent immigrants with criminal records from becoming citizens.

description: FREE CHOICES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBHOLD, FRANZ
description: LIEBHOLD-Franz, 91. Husband of the late Anne Thurnauer. Father of Kate (James Cole) and the late Peter. Grandfather of Daniel and Anne Cole. Arrangements private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHEIM, LESTER
description: ASHEIM-Lester, 83, died July 1 in Chapel Hill, NC. Retired William Rand Kenan, Jr., Professor at the School of Information and Library Science at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Dr. Asheim had also served on the faculty and as Dean of the Graduate Library School of the University of Chicago, as Director of the American Library Association International Relations Office, and as Director of the ALA Office for Library Education. Among his more influential books and papers were ''Not Censorship but Selection,'' ''The Humanities and the Public Library,'' and ''Librarianship in Developing Countries.'' Much awarded for his contributions to the field, Asheim was presented with a Festschrift, ''As Much to Learn as to Teach,'' in 1979. He's survived by cousins, Peter, Marty, Harriet, Lisa, and Steven Frank, all of Los Angeles; Daniel, Diane, and John Frank and Barney Greenberg, all of Seattle; Marc Greenberg of Snohomish, Washington; and Michael Frank of New York City. A memorial service will be held in the early fall at the UNC-CH campus; memorials may be sent to The Lester Asheim Scholarship Fund, C/O Gerry Compton, School of Information and Library Science, UNC-CH, CB#

title: On a Clear Day You Can See Florence
description: For almost 60 years, Bernard and Mary Berenson's villa at Settignano, outside Florence, was dedicated to the art of connoisseurship and the craft of entertaining. When he willed the place to Harvard University as a center for Renaissance studies, Berenson envisioned it as a ''lay monastery of leisurely culture''; Mary, never keen on the idea, grumbled that it would more likely be a ''wayside inn for loafing scholars.'' After reading William Weaver's text in A LEGACY OF EXCELLENCE: The Story of Villa I Tatti (Abrams, $49.50) and poring over David Finn's and David Morowitz's enticing photographs, you can't help thinking that in a perfect world I Tatti ought to be both. A highly refined attention to sybaritic detail does seem to have been an integral part of the house's history. Weaver tells us that while in hiding at an Italian nobleman's villa during World War II, Berenson insisted on sending his monogrammed shirts back to I Tatti by bicycle to be properly laundered, even when a German general had taken up residence. Mary once fired a coachman who pilfered violets and who threatened the cook ''because he was given polenta to eat.'' And rewards were certainly in order for the young architect who survived his hostess's tour of the local museums. ''He did not,'' Mary reported, ''make a single banal remark, or admire anything wrong.'' But maybe it's best to let her husband have the last word. ''My ideal,'' he wrote in his will concerning the future inhabitants of I Tatti, ''is that they should become ripe humanists.'' We should all be so lucky. Alida Becker

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWER, JOHN L.
description: TOWER-John L. 81, a long time Ridgefield resident and retired International Paper Company executive died Wednesday at Laurelwood Care Center in Ridgefield. Mr. Tower of 3 Peaceable Hill Road, Ridgefield was the husband of Shirley Leake Tower. Born in Auburndale, Massachusetts on April 2, 1916. He was the son of C. Lothrop and Esther Day Tower. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy and received a Bachelor of Arts Degree from Dartmouth College in 1938. Mr. Tower began as a newspaperman in Nashville, Tennessee and later joined International Paper Company in New York City. During his 25-year career at International Paper, he rose to become Corporate Vice President of Public Relations and later President of the International Paper Company Foundation. He retired in 1971. In 1950, Mr. Tower moved to Ridgefield where he served for 15 years on the Ridgefield Library Board of Trustees. Along with other board members, he was integral in bringing professional librarians and a larger structure to the library. Mr. Tower was the former President of Silver Spring Country Club and served on its Board of Trustees from 1980 on. He also sat on the Board of Trustees at Cardigan Mountain School in Canaan, New Hampshire for 28 years. He led Cardigan's first capital fund campaign. Besides his wife, he is survived by three daughters, Ellen Mulvaney of Argyle, New York, Sherry Purdy of Scituate, Massachusetts and Judith Symon of Shoreham, Vermont, a brother Frederic Tower of Wilton, seven grandchildren and a great-grandson. Contributions in Mr. Tower's name may be made to The American Parkinson's Disease Association, 116 John Street, NY, NY 10034. There are no calling hours. Services will be held Tuesday, July 15 at 2PM at St. Stephen's Church in Ridgfield.

Survived by his wife Virginia; his sons Robert of Denver, CO, Douglas of Chatham, NJ, and Christopher and his wife Mary of Franklin, MA. Beloved Papa to his grandsons Christopher, Timothy, and Gregory. Also survived by a brother, James, of Hudson, FL, and sister Ruth of Long Island, NY. Friends may call at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ, on Monday, July 14, 1997, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Committal Services are private for the family. He was born in Boston, MA, on September 10, 1918, graduated from Seewannaka High School and attended Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. Drafted into the United States Army in March 1941, he was commissioned an officer on December 31, 1942, and attended radar school at MIT and Harvard. He served in the European Theater of Operations with the First Army as RADAR officer of the 110th Anti-Aircraft Gun Battalion in Normandy, the Liberation of Paris and the Battle of the Bulge. After being discharged in 1946, he was a mechanical engineer with Jefferson Chemical Company and later with CE Lummus from 1955 to 1984.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, HELEN (COOLIDGE ADAMS)
description: ISAACS-Helen (Coolidge Adams) of Boston and South Dartmouth, MA, widow of the late Kenneth L. Isaacs, Chairman of Massachusetts Investors Trust, died Saturday, July 11, 1997. She passed away at her home on Beacon Street, Boston, overlooking the Boston Public Gardens and Boston Common. As a landscape artist they provided the subjects of her many paintings. Born Helen Coolidge Adams on January 17, 1917, in New York City, she was a descendent of two presidents. She was educated at Miss Porter's School, Farmington, CT. Her studies at the Fontainbleau School of Art in Paris led to a distinguished career as a painter of murals (Boston, Rochester, NY, and Daytona, FL) and a portrait artist of many prominent persons. Her last work was a selfportrait. She had a one-woman show at the Child's Gallery of Boston and New York City and at the Allied Artists' Group, New York City. Her neo-impressionist works are displayed at the Fogg Museum, Harvard University; National Museum for Women in the Arts, Washington, DC; and New Bedford Whaling Museum, as well as in many private collections. She is survived by her son Kenneth of Walpole, MA and her daughter, Ann (Merwin) of Baltimore, MD. She leaves six grandchildren: Catherine and Jennifer Isaacs, and Paul, Christopher, Stephen and Ruth Merwin. Her sister, Nancy Hessinger, and her brother Hugh Adams both reside in Florida. A Mass of the Resurrection and burial are private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to The Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Foundation, c/o Dr. Donald Koufman, Director, 32 Fruit Street, Boston, MA 02114

title: Targeted Advertising On Times Web Site
description: The New York Times Electronic Media Company will announce today that it is introducing a new marketing technology to its World Wide Web site aimed at helping on-line advertisers reach specific audiences. The New York Times on the Web (http://www.nytimes.com) will use an electronic data base system that will enable the Web site to display different ads to different on-line users, based on a user's demographic profile. The New York Times on the Web gathers this information when people register to use the Web site. The demographic information includes age, gender, income and zip code, which the data base will tie to identifiable E-mail addresses. Using these data, the company said, the Web site will be able to match advertisers with prospective customers. The company said it had 1.7 million registered users of its Web site. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

title: In Not-So-Serene Venice, Leaders Fear Rising Desire for Secession
description: Last September, Venice was made to play the unwilling host at the theatrical birth of Padania, the name of northern Italy's threatened breakaway state. Then, in May, in a dramatic late-night stunt, a group of radical secessionists scaled the bell tower in St. Mark's Square and unfurled the banner of La Serenissima Repubblica -- the Most Serene Republic -- as this watery city and its far-flung empire were known until two centuries ago.

title: Messinger Assails Giuliani On Pay Scales for Teachers
description: Posing with a small group of supporters in front of a public school on Staten Island yesterday, Ruth W. Messinger denounced key portions of the teachers' contract negotiated last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, saying it had contributed to a decline in the quality of public schools under his administration.

title: Giuliani Favors Internal Police Inquiries Over Review Board's
description: Responding to criticism that he has crippled the civilian board that investigates complaints of police misconduct, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that such outside investigations will never be as effective as the Police Department's own efforts to root out brutality and corruption from within.

title: Righteous Wrath
description: The last time I saw Simo Drljaca, he gave me a friendly pat on the back as I said goodbye. We had spent the better part of a day together, ending it with a beer and a toast to peace. Mr. Drljaca was a warlord in Prijedor, and he gave me a tour of his prison camps: Trnopolje. Keraterm. Omarska.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLAN, WILLIAM J.
description: DOLAN-William J. Of Greenlawn, New York, on July 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Irene and loving father of William, Jr., Gregory, Rev. Paul A. Dolan, Peter, Gerard, Mary Anne, Joseph, Patricia Anne and the late Margaret. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Brother of Margaret, Alice and the late Michael. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, New York. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10 AM at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, Greenlawn, New York. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: White House Standing Firm On Deadline for TV Switch
description: The Clinton Administration has committed itself to a firm deadline for completing the nation's switch to digital television, after lobbyists for the broadcast industry managed to work provisions into the Congressional budget bills that would allow it to evade or delay significant provisions of the Government's plan.

title: PIONEERING STATE FOR MANAGED CARE CONSIDERS CHANGE
description: Leading a national surge of second thoughts about managed health care, California, long a pacesetter in the field, has plunged into a wholesale review of its managed-care system, which now covers more than half the state's 32 million people.

title: End Sugar's Sweet Deal
description: The House will vote again soon on whether to eliminate loan subsidies that keep sugar prices high while fostering destruction of the Florida Everglades. A bipartisan proposal sponsored by Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Dan Miller, Republican of Florida, to phase out sugar subsidies barely lost last year. It may come up for another vote this week in the form of an amendment to an appropriations bill. That will give the House a second chance to put the interests of consumers and the environment over those of a small crowd of politically powerful sugar growers.

title: Protests Follow Death of Official Kidnapped by Basque Rebels
description: The death early today of a town councilman who had been kidnapped and fatally wounded by Basque separatists touched off new protests against terrorism throughout Spain, with tension rising particularly in the Basque city of Pamplona, where riot policemen struggled to control the angry crowds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Summer may be when many people take a vacation from work, but it is also when some move on to new jobs. RITA NAKASHIMA BROCK, a scholar in women's studies and feminist theology, has been named director of the Mary Ingraham Bunting Institute at Radcliffe College. The institute grants about 40 fellowships a year to female scholars, artists and scientists for projects ranging from novel writing to work in physics.

title: Top Athletes Own A Piece of the Rap
description: The recording artist, now a newly minted record industry executive, was on the phone talking acts. At work in Los Angeles, preparing for a quick visit to New York, he was talking enthusiastically about Peter Gunz, a rapper from the Bronx whose style leans to lighthearted braggadocio, and 1 Accord, a Bronx-based rhythm-and-blues quartet.

title: How NBC Could Gain From Stand On Ratings
description: To some, NBC appears to be a hero, using its position as the nation's most popular broadcast network to take a stand, resisting outsiders' efforts to dictate how its television shows should be labeled, scheduled or produced.

title: Series of Shifts At McCann Units
description: The McCann-Erickson Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York has made changes at units devoted to new media and public relations.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Tragic Human Toll Of the Early Stalin Years
description: You can watch the first two hours of ''Russia's War'' tonight without hearing much about World War II. Have patience; there are eight more hours to come. And meanwhile you will get a forceful account of the early decades of Soviet Russia through gritty photographs, painful memories, historical detail and, especially, an unsparing assessment of the career and character of Josef Stalin.

title: For Yeltsin, Vacation Fun Easy as Shooting Fish in a Barrel
description: Vacation season has descended on Russia, and like millions of other people, Boris N. Yeltsin lit out for the territory last week. A fisherman of great eagerness, if modest talent, the Russian President decided to head straight to the northern lakes of the Karelia region and try his luck with rod and reel.

title: Gambling Magazines: All That Glitters or Rolls
description: With more and more Americans flocking to the crap tables and the slot machines, whether on Indian land, Mississippi riverboats or the Atlantic City boardwalk, it was just a matter of time before a magazine like Chance came along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYTON, SHIRLEY
description: DAYTON-Shirley. Of Wayzata, MN. Born January 14, 1931 in Montclair, NJ. Died July 11, 1997 in Minneapolis, MN due to complications from a stroke. Shirley was a graduate of Pine Manor College and moved to Minneapolis in 1969 with first husband, H. Clifton Whiteman, who assumed the job as Senior Vice-President of Finance with IDS. Married Douglas Dayton, Minneapolis civic leader and former executive of DaytonHudson Company, in 1977. Chairman of the 1972 Symphony Ball held in the Crystal Court of the Minneapolis IDS Center. Past President of the Women's Association of the Minnesota Orchestra. Minnesota Orchestra Board member. First female director of Minnesota Outward Bound School in Ely, MN. On founding board of 1006 Society which raises funds for the Minnesota Governor's mansion. Breck School Board member. Board of the Friends of the Institute of Arts. Wrote two cookbooks. An avid collector of antiques. Owned a business, Meadowood Interiors. Member of The Colonial Dames and The Minneapolis Junior League. Leaves husband, Douglas J. Dayton of Minneapolis; three daughters: Susan Whiteman of Bayport, Pamela Ritz of Minneapolis, and Elizabeth Lyle of Southport, CT; three stepsons and their wives: David and Vanessa Dayton of Minneapolis, Stephen and Joyce Melander-Dayton of Santa Fe, NM and Bruce and Lynn Dayton of Newton, MA; four grandchildren: Margot Ritz, Charlotte Ritz, Nicholas Braun and Christopher Braun; four stepgrandchildren: Isaac Dayton, Caleb Dayton, Adele Melander-Dayton, and Dorothy Melander-Dayton; two sisters: Elizabeth Martin of Orleans, MA and Joyce Deyo of New York City, NY. Memorial Service 3:00 PM Tuesday at Wayzata Community Church (Wayzata Blvd at N. Ferndale Rd, 612473-8876). In lieu of flowers, memorials suggested to Breck School and Wayzata Community Church.

title: Girl Who Named Mars Rover Stays Down to Earth
description: While the rover that she named etches a short but historic path across the red planet, rolling across an ancient flood plain and testing the composition of Martian rocks, 15-year-old Valerie Ambroise sits at home here, waiting for her summer job to start and wondering why reporters keep hounding her.

title: A New Breed Of Scientists Studying Mars Takes Control
description: Brian Muirhead, deputy project manager for the Mars Pathfinder mission, sat in the control room at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory here, waiting for sunrise on Mars and the next communications with the spacecraft. He looked a little out of place. At 45, he is one of the project's senior citizens, a balding, bearded man among bright-eyed, bushy-maned youth getting their initiation in space flight.

title: Unsung Pirates Winning Games and Fans' Hearts
description: These can't be the Pirates, can they? Not the same Pittsburgh Pirates who were forecast to wind up last in victories and attendance in the National League. Not the team that seemed destined to end up in another city.

title: Arrests by NATO Worry Bosnian Serb Leaders
description: Two NATO operations to arrest war crimes suspects have caused panic among some of the top Bosnian Serb leaders, who fear they may be next, senior NATO officers and foreign diplomats say.

title: Nicholas Wins Duel and Open
description: For a moment, as the ball rolled toward the hole on the 18th green late this afternoon, Nancy Lopez -- and all those who had pulled for her through four tense hours -- watched her birdie putt attempt and believed it was going to fall into the cup. This would be the stroke that would finally even her daylong duel with Alison Nicholas. This stroke would provide the opening for a United States Women's Open championship that has eluded Lopez throughout a Hall of Fame career.

title: Cattle Barons of Texas Yore Accused of Epic Land Grab
description: As a courtroom drama, the legal battle shaping up between more than 800 descendants of Jose Manuel Balli Villarreal and the John G. and Marie Stella Kenedy Memorial Foundation has the makings of an epic, set against the backdrop of the vast and thorny brushland of South Texas. There are ancient family feuds, mysterious reports of yellowed documents found in an attic that could prove to be legal bombshells, claims and counterclaims of fraud and treachery.

title: Internet Analyst Joins Venture Capital Firm
description: J. William Gurley has joined Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, a venture capital firm, as its fourth partner. Mr. Gurley was previously an Internet financial analyst at DMG Technology Group, a division of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, the investment banking arm of Deutsche Bank. As an analyst, Mr. Gurley attracted a following based on a series of articles about the Internet market that appeared both on line and in Fortune magazine.

title: Hughes Plans To Introduce Satellite Dish
description: Hughes Network Systems -- which manufactures a ''pizza size'' home satellite dish, Digital Satellite System, that receives DirecTV and USSB digital television -- is expected to announce today that it will introduce a digital satellite system that will be able to receive both television broadcasts and high-speed Internet access through one dish.

title: A Series Not Unlike the Star's Career
description: The first half of Ornette Coleman's concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, accompanied only by Charlie Haden on bass and Billy Higgins on drums, sifted some meaning from the sprawling, rumpled career of one of American's most restless musicians. Almost surreally brilliant, with Mr. Coleman and his band mates of 40 years adding one improvised melody to the next for a bit more than an hour, the set showed that a distinction can be made between what Mr. Coleman does best and his admirable political attitude.

By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.98 percent and a six-month bill was 5.09 percent; the rate on a one-year bill was 5.21 percent.

title: Albany Takes Record Late Budget in Stride
description: The New York State government surpassed its own hard-earned record for futility shortly after 5:30 this afternoon, blithely slipping through the 104th day of its fiscal year without a new budget.

title: Account of Sonogram Dilemma Prompts Letters of Joy and Grief
description: Four years ago, when I was pregnant with my third child, I underwent not one but two ''routine'' sonograms at my obstetrician's office. The first was done at eight weeks, when my husband and I were informed that our baby was growing normally and everything looked ''fine.'' At the second test, done around the 20th or 24th week, the technician told me that everything was great and that I was carrying a normal, healthy baby boy. The technician printed out some still photos from the sonogram and I was sent on my merry way. In the parking lot, I vividly remember looking at one of the photos and thinking to myself that his hand, which was prominently displayed, did not look right: the fingers looked too close together. But I quickly dismissed the thought and never bothered mentioning it to anybody.

title: MCI's Loss Creates a Very Bad Trans-Atlantic Connection
description: MCI's stock recovered a bit yesterday from its jaw-dropping tumble on Friday, which came after the long-distance carrier disclosed that it would cost far more than expected to break into the local telephone market. But for the MCI Communications Corporation, the fallout from the announcement is likely to last longer than a couple of trading sessions.

title: Million Join March Against Basque Terrorism in Spain
description: Crowds estimated at more than a million marched in central Madrid and Barcelona tonight in a demonstration against terrorism after the funeral of a town councilman who was killed over the weekend by Basque separatists.

title: Corrections

title: Lower Estate Taxes Will Hurt Small Farms
description: At first glance, family farmers like Phil Menke of Cozad, Neb., seem likely beneficiaries of a proposed Congressional rollback of estate taxes. The family's wealth is in the fertile land it has farmed in the Platte Valley since 1905, and Mr. Menke is worried that his son might not be able to carry on this tradition. But Mr. Menke believes that a big cut in estate taxes will make things harder for his family, not easier.

title: Ecumenism's Big Moment
description: This week the 72d General Convention of the Episcopal Church meets in Philadelphia to vote on a Concordat, or cooperative agreement, with the Evangelical Lutheran Church that would bring the two into ''full communion,'' a compact that is short of a merger, but not by much. Lutherans will take action on the pact at their Churchwide Assembly on Aug. 17. Together these votes constitute a turning point for American Christianity and the future of the ecumenical movement.

description: Alexandra Danilova, an internationally popular ballet star known for her vivacity and theatrical flair, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Warburg Joint Venture With Firm in Russia
description: SBC Warburg and Brunswick Investments Ltd. of Russia said yesterday that they had created a joint venture, Brunswick Warburg, to specialize in the Russian banking and brokerage market. SBC Warburg, the investment banking division of the Swiss Bank Corporation, will have a 50 percent stake in the venture. Brunswick, Russia's leading brokerage house, and its management will own the rest. Other financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKER, EDWARD
description: LASKER-Edward. Philip Morris Companies Inc. notes with sorrow the death July 11, 1997, of retired Philip Morris Director Edward Lasker. Mr. Lasker served with distinction on the Philip Morris Companies Inc. Board of Directors from 1961 to 1983. During his years on the Board, Philip Morris became the largest tobacco company in the U.S., accelerated its international expansion, and acquired Miller Brewing Company and Mission Viejo Company. Mr. Lasker brought a unique perspective to Board deliberations, which enabled the company to meet the many complex challenges posed by a dynamic market. He made invaluable contributions as a member of the Audit, Finance and Nominating Committees. The Philip Morris Board and employees extend their deepest sympathy to his wife Cynthia; his three sons Albert, Lawrence and Steven; his stepson Courtland; and his sister Frances. Services will be private.

description: In the two-horse race to see which new television network will become the fifth major broadcast network, WB gained a major advantage yesterday when five stations owned or managed by the Sinclair Broadcast Group announced that they would defect to WB's affiliate roster from UPN's roster in January.

title: Parties Debate Joint Strategy For Hearings on China's Gifts
description: After a week of partisan sniping, Republicans and Democrats on the Senate committee investigating campaign-finance abuses changed their approach today and took a small step toward cooperating on a common inquiry into whether China influenced elections last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLIN, LOWELL E., M.D.
description: BELLIN-Lowell E., M.D. New York Community Hospital mourns the loss of Lowell E. Bellin, M.D., Physician, New York City Commissioner of Health, New York City Health Services Administrator, Chairman of the Division of Health Services Administration at Columbia University School of Public Health, and professor and teacher at many colleges and universities in the New York metropolitan area. He will be sorely missed by all. Dr. Bellin was a giant among men. He helped young people, colleagues, and all those who were fortunate to have become associated with him. A cardigan sweater tied around the neck or waist, or draped over the shoulders, can look fashionable and be ready to don should the temperature drop.

title: Near Vesuvius, the Hunt for A Library Faces Modern Politics
description: The Villa dei Papiri, the seaside mansion thought to have been built by Julius Caesar's father-in-law outside the town of Herculaneum, has long fired the imagination of archeologists, papyrologists and historians, but ''imagination'' has always been the key word. Buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius that smothered Pompeii in A.D. 79, it has stood for 1,900 years under more than 100 feet of lava and earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLIN, LOWELL, M.D.
description: BELLIN-Lowell, M.D. The President and the Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Lowell Bellin, beloved father of Eran Bellin, M.D., our esteemed colleague and Director of Medical Services at Rikers Island Health Services. A highly respected physician, educator and public health advocate, Dr. Lowell Bellin enjoyed a distinguished career as Commissioner of Health in Springfield, Massachusetts, and New York City; headed the New York City Medicaid program at its inception; was author of the City Ordinance requiring childproof gates to be installed on apartment windows, and was professor and Chairman of the division of Public Health at Columbia University. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Account of Sonogram Dilemma Prompts Letters of Joy and Grief
description: I am a radiologist who performs obstetrical ultrasound and a father who had a false-positive diagnosis on my son during his gestation seven years ago. My wife and I were offered amniocentesis by her obstetrician, even though my wife was only 33 at the time, with the statement, ''What can you live with easier? A 1 in 400 chance of precipitating a miscarriage in this pregnancy at 16 weeks, or a similar chance of having a Down's baby for the rest of your lives?'' From that perspective, it seemed reasonable, and my wife agreed.

And while both have been criticized by President Clinton for doing ''an inadequate job of opening the door to college,'' the White House's alternative is close enough to assure that a variation will be part of the eventual tax package.

The purchase price, $11 a share, represents a 21 percent premium over Katz's closing stock price yesterday of $9.0625. The deal has been approved by the boards of the companies. Katz, with revenue last year of $183 million, provides services to more than 2,000 radio stations, 340 television stations and about 1,400 cable systems.

title: ISRAEL SELLS MERRILL LYNCH 12% OF PHONE COMPANY
description: Israel said yesterday that it had sold 90.6 million shares of Bezeq Ltd., representing a 12.4 percent stake in the telephone company, to Merrill Lynch & Company for $250 million. The New York investment firm also acquired an option to sell about 10 percent back if it failed to find buyers for the shares by February 1998. Bezeq's shares rose 1.5 percent yesterday to close at 10.26 shekels, or $2.88. Merrill Lynch apparently paid about $2.76 a share. Stephen Marquardt, a Merrill Lynch managing director in London, said the company had bought the shares with the intention of reselling them, but would not say if the firm already had commitments from investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ROBERT J.
description: JOHNSON-Robert J. Of Chatham, New Jersey. Formerly of Locust Valley, NY, and Floral Park, NY, on July 12, 1997. Survived by his wife Virginia; his sons Robert of Denver, CO, Douglas of Chatham, New Jersey, and Christopher and his wife Mary of Franklin, Mass. Beloved Papa to his grandsons Christopher, Timothy, & Gregory. Also survived by a brother, James, of Hudson, FL, and sister Ruth of Long Island, NY. Friends may call at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ, Monday, July 14, 1997, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Committal Services are private for the family. He was born in Boston, MA., September 10, 1918, graduated from Seewannaka High School and attended Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. Drafted into the United States Army in March 1941, he was commissioned an officer on December 31, 1942, & attended radar school at MIT and Harvard. He served in the European Theater of Operations with the First Army as RADAR officer of the 110th Anti-Aircraft Gun Battalion in Normandy, the Liberation of Paris and the Battle of the Bulge. After being discharged in 1946, he was a mechanical engineer with Jefferson Chemical Company and later with CE Lummus from 1955 to 1984.

title: Account of Sonogram Dilemma Prompts Letters of Joy and Grief
description: When I was pregnant, a routine blood test showed exposure to toxoplasmosis $(infection with a parasite linked to birth defects$). No problem, said our doctor -- false positive IgG's are very common. But it's a cheap test, a negative result of which means avoiding the expense of the REAL test, an IgM, which is definitive. ''Don't worry,'' he said. ''In my 20 years of practice I have never seen a positive IgM test for toxoplasmosis.'' Result: positive. Prognosis: 20 percent chance of blindness, 15 percent chance of deafness, 30 percent chance of mental retardation, and no condition precludes the others. My reaction was one of total defeat. I could not face it. My first cousin is severely retarded and the toll on his brother and sister is painful to witness. My husband, to his everlasting credit, said, ''I will not abort a statistic'' -- words which I am reminded of daily as I behold our beautiful and perfectly healthy daughter.

title: Account of Sonogram Dilemma Prompts Letters of Joy and Grief
description: LAST November, I wrote an article about my experience with prenatal ultrasound, when the fetus I was carrying was diagnosed on three separate sonograms as having a limb deformity called a clubfoot. After months of anxiety, I gave birth in August 1996 to my daughter, Katherine, healthy from her black-haired head to her two normal, squirming feet. I used the article as an opportunity to discuss the medical, ethical and emotional complexities surrounding prenatal testing of any sort. Many readers responded with dramatic stories of their own: some that were false alarms and ended happily, as mine did, others with the opposite outcome, a severe deformity that had been missed on the prenatal ultrasound, and still others who benefited from the early detection of a disastrous fetal abnormality. As the letters excerpted below demonstrate, the field of medical divination is fraught with the undivinable, and no matter how advanced the technology, there will always be room for worry -- and hope.

title: HCIA SHARES PLUNGE ON SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT WARNING

It said analysts had been expecting a profit of 30 cents. In the quarter a year earlier, HCIA had operating income of 24 cents a share. HCIA blamed a revenue shortfall at its Provider Solutions unit and sales disappointments at other units for the poor outlook. HCIA's shares closed at $15.625, down $16.375, or 51 percent, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, HARRY
description: WEINER-Harry. On July 13, 1997. An innovator in the housewares industry and an advisor to New York City entrepreneurs. Immigrated to New York City in 1910 from Poland. In 1932, founded General Slicing Machine Company in Brooklyn, where he was responsible for award-winning and patented application of suctioncup technology to the bases of home and office equipment requiring a temporary anchor. After his retirement, in 1972, he dedicated himself to the New York office of the Service Corps of Retired Executives (SCORE). As a volunteer in and Presiden of the New York SCORE office for over a decade, he counseled prospective small business owners, providing them with the benefits of his business experience and expertise. Born February 22, 1905 in Brezno, Poland (now Ukraine) lived in Brooklyn, Spring Valley, and Newburgh, New York. Retired to Manhattan where he lived until moving to New Orleans in 1994. Survived by two sons, Walter, of Manhattan, and Roy, of New Orleans. He was Papa to ten grandchildren, and also leaves six great-grandchildren. His wife of 43 years, Sylvia Friefeld Weiner, died in 1972 at age 62; and his son Sidney, of Irvine, California, died in 1993 at age 61. Services Tuesday, 11:15 A.M. at The Riverside, West 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Burial will follow at the Jewish Community Center Cemetery in Spring Valley, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Tulane Cancer Center, 1430 Tulane Avenue, New Orleans, LA. 70112.

title: STONINGTON PARTNERS SEEKS A MAJORITY STAKE IN MERISEL
description: Merisel Inc., a struggling computer wholesaler in El Segundo, Calif., said yesterday that Stonington Partners Inc. had offered $152 million for a 70 percent stake in the company. Merisel said the proposal by Stonington, a New York-based investment firm, would allow shareholders to retain a greater equity interest than they would have under an earlier restructuring plan. In April, Merisel, seeking to avoid bankruptcy, announced a plan to exchange $125 million in debt securities for 80 percent of the company's stock. The Stonington transaction, if successful, would leave Merisel stockholders with 30 percent of the shares outstanding. Merisel's shares rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $2.96875.
