They decided to publish only books from other nations: literary pearls from Australia, Germany and Sri Lanka that conveyed something of their cultures while also prodding American youngsters into realizing they are not the center of the universe.

title: Young and Persistent, And Near a Showcase
description: When Mirjana Lucic was 4 years old, she badgered her father to let her tag along to the clay tennis courts in Maraska, her hometown on Croatia's Adriatic coast. Lucic wanted to play a game that she did not yet know the name of, and she was told to go play with her dolls. She didn't.

title: The Odd Couple That Did the Heavy Lifting on Pataki's Managed-Care Medicaid Deal
description: State officials from Gov. George E. Pataki on down took credit yesterday for winning the Clinton Administration's approval for a plan to enroll most of New York's 3.5 million Medicaid recipients in managed care. But two men who are not on the state payroll did much of the hard work that clinched the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BEN
description: BROWN-Ben, 75. Of NYC and Great Barrington MA., July 14. Great artist and wit, first graduating class of High School of Music and Art, NYC. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Father of Joshua Brown and Jenny Hurwitz. Grandfather of Gideon Joslyn Brown & Daniel Joslyn Brown. Services Thursday, July 17 at 11:30 at Hickey-Birches Funeral Home, 33 South Street, Great Barrington, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, DANIEL I.
description: UNGAR-Daniel I. Of Woodmere and Boca Raton on July 15, at eighty-one. Deeply beloved and devoted husband of Evelyn for fifty-six years; father of Steven (Aviva), Roberta (Allan Greene), Jerrold and Diane; grandfather of Nicole, Evan and Jonathan Greene. Originally from Philadelphia and Atlantic City. Chemist and consultant to food and drug industry. Love beyond words.

title: Glenn Wilburn, 46; Sought Wider Bomb Inquiry
description: Glenn Dale Wilburn, who lost his two grandsons in the Oklahoma City bombing and led a successful campaign to set up a local grand jury to investigate the crime, died yesterday morning at his home in Oklahoma City. He was 46.

title: Boy, 3, Is Killed in a Fall From a Taxi in Brooklyn
description: A 3-year-old boy died after he fell out of a taxi yesterday in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Easier Directory Assistance
description: For people who live in the New York City area, using directory assistance has just gotten a little easier.

title: Eating Well
description: FRUITS and vegetables know no season when they are purchased in supermarkets and specialty shops, and most of us have come to think of them in year-round terms: strawberries in February, tomatoes in November, asparagus in August.

title: Four Other Deaths Linked To Same Elusive Suspect, 27
description: The first victim, a 28-year-old former Navy lieutenant, was found wrapped in a rug in a loft apartment in the Warehouse District of Minneapolis, his head bashed with a claw hammer. The second victim, a 33-year-old architect, was found 60 miles north on the shores of East Rush Lake, shot once in the head.

title: HNC SOFTWARE IN $190 MILLION DEAL TO BUY COMPREVIEW
description: The shares of HNC Software Inc. rose 11 percent yesterday after the company said it would acquire the closely held Compreview Inc., an insurance information company, for about $190 million in stock. Shares of HNC, which is based in San Diego, rose $4.125 each, to $42. HNC, a maker of software for credit card fraud detection, said it would buy Compreview to expand its line of products and services for the insurance and medical markets. Compreview, based in Newport Beach, Calif., makes software to integrate payment systems and medical bill reviews.

title: Francois Furet, Historian, 70; Studied the French Revolution
description: Francois Furet, a prominent historian who challenged the popular Marxist interpretation of the French Revolution and reshaped French thinking about subsequent events, died on Saturday in a hospital in Toulouse. He was 70.

title: Cambodia Purge Said to Claim 40 Victims
description: At least 40 political opponents of Hun Sen, the former Communist who seized sole power in a coup earlier this month, have been executed and hundreds of others arrested, a United Nations official here said today.

title: Honors
description: * Aaron Grossman, senior vice president and partner at Newman-Stein, New York, was named 1997-98 president of the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Earnings Rise at Citicorp And at Chase Manhattan

title: Software Piracy Suspected in Advertising Industry
description: Some people in Silicon Valley are scrutinizing the advertising industry, contending that software piracy is rampant.

title: World Music by Way of Paris and a Triple Bill
description: There are doubtless more fitting ways to celebrate Bastille Day than to recall the heyday of French colonialism. But one of colonialism's byproducts, the emergence of Paris as a center for world music, was saluted by the concert on Sunday at Summerstage. It was a triple bill with Cheb Mami from Algeria, Lokua Kanza from Zaire and Alabina, a group of Spanish Gypsies (now based in Montpellier in southern France) that features an Israeli singer, Ishtar (whose parents are Egyptian and Moroccan).

title: Clients Don't Hire Lawyers to Be 'Independent'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Industry That Versace Helped Shape Fears for the Empire He Founded
description: As the creative force behind a worldwide fashion empire, Gianni Versace's death leaves questions about succession at his company and the viability of a business that had sales of more than $800 million last year.

title: Internet Will Become Its Own Watchdog
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-47th St. Photo Owner Is Indicted in Fraud
description: The former president and owner of 47th Street Photo, Irving Goldstein, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan on charges that he and a group of co-defendants falsified accounts to bolster the fortunes of a struggling company that was closely tied to 47th Street Photo, which filed for bankruptcy in 1992.

title: Lilco Deal Seems Set as Silver Backs Plan
description: The $7.3 billion partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company appears likely to win final state approval on Wednesday, after Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said today that he would vote for it if certain conditions were met.

title: Angel's Touch: Saving a Park From Neglect
description: THE way the story goes in the Bronx, Angel Hueca has his own park. Not a bench, a tree or a sprinkler, but the whole deal. The word on the street is that Mr. Hueca hooked up with some guy in the East Village who gave him the East River Park and asked him to do something with it.

title: China's Trade Surplus Soars to $17.77 Billion
description: China's trade surplus rose twentyfold in the first half of the year, to $17.77 billion, as manufacturing exports soared. Exports in the first six months of the year rose about 26 percent, to $80.87 billion, the newspaper China Securities reported, citing customs data. Data released earlier showed that imports reached $63.05 billion, down two-tenths of a percent.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHTER, RACHEL
description: FRUCHTER-Rachel. The Board and staff of Advocates for Children extend our sincerest condolences to our friend and colleague Norm Fruchter and his children Lev and Chenda on the untimely death of Rachel Fruchter. Galen Kirkland, Exec Director Joan A. Harrington, Assoc Dir

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on July 2 about the winners of the first International Cultural Competition for an original play, sponsored by the Alexander S. Onassis Public Benefit Foundation, misstated the total amount of prize money and the amount received by each of four runners-up. The total was $700,000, not $800,000; the runners-up received $25,000 each, not $50,000.

title: Industry Disputes Research In Secondhand Smoke Trial
description: Attacking the scientific evidence marshaled by flight attendants who are trying to prove that secondhand cigarette smoke made them ill, lawyers for the tobacco industry delivered opening statements today in the first class-action lawsuit to address the health consequences of cigarettes for nonsmokers.

title: The Flirting Game
description: Reading about Jamie Tarses gives me vertigo.

title: Gianni Versace, 50, the Designer Who Infused Fashion With Life and Art
description: Gianni Versace, the man who brought rock, art, sexuality and brilliant color into contemporary fashion, was shot to death yesterday outside his home in Miami Beach. He was 50.

title: JOHN NUVEEN COMPANY TO ACQUIRE RITTENHOUSE FINANCIAL
description: The John Nuveen Company, the investment banking firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Rittenhouse Financial Services Inc. for $145 million. Rittenhouse, based in Radnor, Pa., manages about $9 billion of assets, primarily in accounts offered through major broker-dealers. After the acquisition, which is expected to close in September, Rittenhouse would be a wholly owned subsidiary of the Chicago-based Nuveen, but would operate under its own name and keep its headquarters. Richard D. Hughes will continue as president of Rittenhouse and George W. Connell, its founder and chief investment officer, will continue to head the investment committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSEN, JOHN WARBURTON
description: JACOBSEN-John Warburton, entered into rest July 12 in Shelton, CT. Born on March 12, 1912, in Montreal, he was a graduate of the Royal Military College and McGill University in Canada. In his life, he was a world traveler, engineer and successful businessman. John was dearly loved by his family and friends and will be sorely missed. He is survived by a sister Marion O'Dea of Reston, VA and his daughter Carol Jacobsen Poland of Shelton, CT. Friends are invited to come to the home of his daughter from 4 to 6 P.M. this evening. John will be buried at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, New York at 2 PM on Friday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Humane Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, HARRY
description: WEINER-Harry. The leadership of UJA-Federation of New York notes with sorrow the passing of Harry Weiner, beloved father of Walter H. Weiner, a generous supporter of UJA-Federation through its Banking and Finance Division. The family's long-standing commitment to the fields of medicine and Jewish education are well known. To Mr. Weiner's son, Walter; Walter's wife, Nina; son Ray, his grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and to the entire family, we extend our sincere sympathies. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Donald Layton,Chairman, Banking & Finance Division Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Class Notes
description: Kwadwo Acheampong is coming of age in the middle of a battle over his brain.

title: Personal Health
description: KENNETH POWELL of Brooklyn is a compleat athlete. He plays tennis, works out in a gym, skis and surfs. But in addition to these vigorous activities, two or three times a day this 37-year-old father of two preschoolers does tai chi, a Chinese exercise that is at once calming and strengthening.

title: T/SF COMMUNICATIONS CONSIDERS A $124 MILLION BUYOUT
description: The T/SF Communications Corporation said yesterday that an undisclosed buyout firm had offered to buy the company, which is a casino industry publisher, for more than $37 a share, or more than $124 million. T/SF said it would put on hold plans to buy about two million of its shares for $37 apiece and become a private company. T/SF, based in Tulsa, Okla., publishes a magazine called International Gaming and Wagering Business and newsletters covering the casino industry. T/SF said it would give the buyout firm a few weeks to look at its books and make a final offer. The company's stock jumped $1.875 a share yesterday, to $37.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Allies Linked To Swapping Of Nazi Gold
description: Newly declassified American documents for the first time implicate the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Bank of Canada in Ottawa in attempts to launder tons of gold that the Nazis looted during World War II.

title: Acevedo Joins List of Battered Relievers in Mets' Bullpen
description: PITTSBURGH, July 15

title: Giants Sign Rookie Punter
description: BRAD MAYNARD, whose selection in the third round of the N.F.L. draft in April made him the first punter ever drafted that high by the Giants, signed a three-year contract with the team yesterday. The signing, which includes $400,000 for 1997, was announced by Integrated Sports Management, which represents Maynard, who averaged 44.4 yards a punt at Ball State.

title: DH TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO SALE TO AXIOHM OF FRANCE
description: DH Technology Inc., a maker of specialty printers and printer components, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the privately held Axiohm S.A. of France for $25 a share, or at least $162 million. Shares of DH Technology, which is based in San Diego, soared $7.125 each, to $23. DH said Axiohm would offer 6.5 million to 7 million DH shares directly to shareholders. That would make the deal worth $162 million to $175 million. After the acquisition closes, DH shareholders would own 15 percent to 21 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

title: Deal Has Cassell Sort of Happy
description: The voice on the phone was a bit matter of fact, coming from someone who had just signed a six-year, $21 million deal with the Nets.

title: U.S. Plans Civil Rights Inquiry Into Policy at U. of California
description: The United States Department of Education has told the University of California that it plans to investigate whether the university's dismantling of affirmative action has led to violations of Federal civil rights law.

title: Economic Reformer Likely to Be Premier of China
description: For nearly a decade, and certainly since the Tiananmen Square massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in 1989, millions of Chinese have awaited the day when the country's unpopular hard-line Prime Minister, Li Peng, would be forced to step down by the constitutional limit on his term.

title: When New Music Reaches a Certain Age
description: Essential Music, one of the more worthwhile new-music groups around, celebrated its 10th anniversary over the weekend with three programs at the Kitchen. A substantial collection of work ran from the new new to the kind of new to the old new.

title: Samuel B. Gould, 86, Unifier of SUNY, Dies
description: Samuel Brookner Gould, a visionary educator who fused 58 New York campuses into today's unified State University system, died Friday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 86 and had lived in Sarasota since his retirement in 1970.

title: Tausche Martin Gets A Daewoo Account
description: The Southeast region of Daewoo Motor America in Atlanta has named Tausche Martin Lonsdorf, also in Atlanta, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at more than $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNING, GERALD D.
description: GUNNING-Gerald D. Suddenly on July 14th, 1997 of Roslyn Heights. Husband of Marie. Father of Michael, Kerry Stauber, Gerald J., Marie and Patricia Zutaut. fatherin-law of Maryann, Stuart and Thomas. Grandfather of Zachary, Rachel, Claire, Kelly, and Colleen. Brother of John Gunning. Visiting Roslyn Heights Funeral Home, Inc., 75 Mineola Ave., Roslyn Heights, Wed. 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass Thursday, 10 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Roslyn. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. Past President Roslyn Highlands Fire Dept., member for 35 years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLEIFELD, DORA (5 YEARS) AND BEN
description: BLEIFELD-Dora (5 years) and Ben (25 years). Remembered forever. Love, Drs. Anita and Max Markowitz and Kevin

title: Inquiry Says Clinton Aide Took His Life
description: Nearing the fourth anniversary of the death of Vincent W. Foster Jr., the White House deputy counsel, the Whitewater independent counsel announced today that his exhaustive investigation had concluded that Mr. Foster committed suicide in a Virginia park.

title: Man Convicted of Killing His Wife, a Police Officer
description: An unemployed city bus driver charged with fatally shooting his estranged wife, a police officer, in January was convicted yesterday by a Brooklyn jury.

title: Wine Talk
description: NIEBAUM-COPPOLA, the director Francis Ford Coppola's winery in the Napa Valley, has just released two new wines, a red and a white called simply Rosso and Bianco. In the material accompanying two samples, Mr. Coppola himself harks back to the simpler times that inspired them.

title: Teaching Sexual Abstinence
description: After months of debate, the State Department of Health has decided to accept $4.2 million in Federal money earmarked to teach children to avoid sex until they are married, officials said yesterday.

title: Senate Panel Is Told Huang Kept Ties to Company Linked to China
description: John Huang, the offstage protagonist of the Senate hearings on campaign finance practices, was depicted today as the highly paid agent of an international conglomerate that has close ties to the Chinese Government and a record of generous contributions to the Democratic Party.

title: RUSSIANS SUGGEST AMERICAN TAKE ON MIR REPAIR TASK
description: The head of the Russian Space Agency proposed today that the American astronaut Michael Foale take the place of the Russian commander on the tricky space walk to repair the stricken Mir space station. But NASA officials said they needed to be persuaded of the urgency of the repair before they would allow Mr. Foale to take on the new mission.

title: Let's Face It, Irabu Is Not Nolan Ryan
description: IN the interests of accuracy, fair expectation and proper respect, it is not soon enough to wipe the term ''Japanese Nolan Ryan'' from the Hideki Irabu glossary. Drop it. Strike it. Nupe it, as Ryan would have said in his more active endorsement days.

title: Vice Presidentially, Jefferson Was No Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Versace, Fashion Innovator, Slain in Miami Beach
description: Gianni Versace, the fashion designer who rejuvenated the industry by tapping the energy of popular culture, was shot to death this morning as he opened the gate of his palatial South Beach home here. The police said the killing may have been the work of a man wanted for murders in three states.

title: Group Prepares Lawsuit Over H.I.V. Testing Law
description: An advocacy group for people infected with H.I.V. is preparing to sue the state and two New York City hospitals over the new state law that requires H.I.V. testing of newborns and disclosure of the results, saying the mandate violates the civil rights of mothers and infants and fails to insure proper care.

title: Food Notes
description: Breathing Room for Fairway

title: Jackson Rejects Offer by Bulls
description: PHIL JACKSON's agent said the coach turned down a ''woefully inadequate'' one-year contract offer made last Saturday by the Chicago Bulls.'' Negotiations then took an unusual turn yesterday when the Bulls' chairman, JERRY REINSDORF, said in a statement that the team wanted a direct meeting with Jackson and was ''prepared to directly offer him more money than any N.B.A. pure head coach on a single-season contract.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: KPMG Abused Its Relationship With Audit Client, Judge Rules
description: A New York judge ruled yesterday that KPMG Peat Marwick, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, had abused its relationship with one of its audit clients. The suit, brought by Stern Stewart & Company, a New York consulting firm, accused KPMG of using its position as the firm's long-term auditor and tax accountant to create a rival business.

title: N.F.L. Embarks on Stepped-Up Effort to Deal With Head Injuries
description: As National Football League training camps open this week, concussions will again be at the forefront of medical problems that bedevil players and confound team physicians. But under an enhanced program that will begin this season, 10 N.F.L. teams hope to gain more insight into head injuries by using neuro-psychological examinations on players who are at risk.

title: Ad spoofs go fittingly retro, only on Nick at Nite's TV Land.
description: WHOEVER declared that nostalgia isn't what it used to be may be further inspired by a series of madcap commercials that seek to stimulate fond memories of sales spiels that never ran, for a product that never existed.

title: Dow and Nasdaq Hit Highs as Stocks Surge
description: The stock market continued to march into the record books yesterday, bolstered by rising optimism about corporate earnings.

title: The Pop Life
description: Virtual Auditions

title: Ullrich Attacks Boldly and Pedals Into Lead
description: With 10 kilometers left in a vast journey over the Pyrenees mountains, Jan Ullrich made the move today that securely put him in the leader's yellow jersey, probably won him the Tour de France and possibly stamped him as the dominant bicycle racer in years to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKER, EDWARD
description: LASKER-Edward. Philip Morris Companies Inc. notes with sorrow the death July 11, 1997, of retired Philip Morris Director Edward Lasker. Mr. Lasker served with distinction on the Philip Morris Companies Inc. Board of Directors from 1961 to 1983. During his years on the Board, Philip Morris became the largest tobacco company in the U.S., accelerated its international expansion, and acquired Miller Brewing Company and Mission Viejo Company. Mr. Lasker brought a unique perspective to Board deliberations, which enabled the company to meet the many complex challenges posed by a dynamic market. He made invaluable contributions as a member of the Audit, Finance and Nominating Committees. The Philip Morris Board and employees extend their deepest sympathy to his wife Cynthia; his three sons Albert, Lawrence and Steven; his stepson Courtland; and his sister Frances. Services will be private.

title: Air-Conditioned Cabs: A Matter of Luck
description: A ride in a New York City taxicab on a hot summer day should be an exhilarating break from the city's merciless swelter, according to the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission. A number of new regulations have made ''air-conditioning on demand'' the right of all yellow cab customers in the city.

title: Weld, Seeking Mexico Post, Challenges White House to Stand Up to Helms
description: Responding to reports that President Clinton might bow to political pressure and back off from nominating him as Ambassador to Mexico, Gov. William F. Weld today challenged the White House to fight to win him the Mexico job and said he would accept no substitute.

title: Giuliani Leads His Opponents In Money Raised and Spent
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has already spent more than $4 million on his re-election effort -- almost half of the amount that is allowed under New York campaign laws -- and continues to display a huge fund-raising advantage over his Democratic rivals, according to reports filed yesterday.

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Leaders See Hope for Means Test for Medicare
description: President Clinton and Senate Republicans said today that they believed they could agree on legislation to charge higher Medicare premiums to affluent elderly people, even though House Democrats and some liberal Democratic senators dislike the idea.

title: Campaign Finance Labyrinth Is Obvious, If Not Clear
description: The moment was more graphic than revealing: On a day when the Republican Senate majority was determined to portray interlocking intrigues between the Riady family's holdings in the Lippo conglomerate and the business interests of China, a chart was brought forth, seven feet square, to dwarf all previous offerings in what has become a sub-battle of graphics at the campaign finance hearing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORNEY, HELEN (NEE CLOONEY)
description: TORNEY-Helen (nee Clooney). July 13, 1997, aged 82. Wife of the late Vincent J. Mother of Barbara, Deirdre, Martha, Patricia, James, Brenda and the late Deborah. Grandmother of Vincent & Gabriel Torney, Holland, Elizabeth and Benjamin Mills; and Ann and James Fortune. Mother-in-law of Bernard Mills & Rick Tulka. Sisterin-law of Alyce Burke, Ann Lukacs and Jane Sheridan. Cherished aunt of twenty-one and dear friend of many. She will be missed by all. Viewing on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Barrett Funeral Home, Tenafly, New Jersey. Funeral mass on Friday, 10 AM, at St. Joseph's, Oradell, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice at Bergen Community Health Care, 400 Old Hook Road, Westwood, N.J. 07675.

title: Jungle Boy and Pals, Furry and Not
description: If ''George of the Jungle'' had any pretensions, it would be an easy movie to mock. But this airheaded comedy released under the Disney banner is so filled with slapstick humor, so willing to kid itself and so much a benign Jolly Roger in pirating sure-fire elements from its predecessors that it adds up to the kind of silly summer fun that gives family entertainment a good name.

description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Dictaphone Corp., Stratford, Conn., to Colligan Group, New York, to handle advertising for its voice processing products, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Sugar Families Plan Merger Of Flo-Sun and Savannah
description: In a deal that allies two of the most influential families in the nation's sugar industry, Savannah Foods and Industries announced yesterday that it would merge with the domestic sugar operations of Flo-Sun Inc., the private holding company of the Fanjul family of Florida.

title: Newark Arts Gala
description: Kathleen Battle, Savion Glover, Chita Rivera and Wynton Marsalis are among those scheduled to appear at a benefit gala on Oct. 18 to open the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. Also appearing will be the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra and the Argentine dance revue ''Tango X2.'' Sponsored by the Women's Board of the center, the gala is expected to raise the last $1.5 million of the $180 million cost of the project. The event, at 6:30 P.M., will be taped for a later broadcast for PBS's ''Great Performances.'' Benefit tickets, which include a reception and dinner, cost $1,000 to $2,500 each; for information, call (973) 242-6000, extension 3. Tickets to the performance alone go on sale on Aug. 15; information, (888) 466-5722.

title: Cosby, an Unerring Father on TV, Speaks of Affair in Extortion Trial
description: For more than 20 years, Bill Cosby said, he kept a secret: that he had had a brief affair with a fan named Shawn Thompson, who told him she had given birth to their child, Autumn, and that she had made threats to reveal their relationship unless he gave her money.

title: Eat at Grandma's, Not at Mom's
description: If your own Jewish grandmother is too busy watching her cholesterol to fry up a batch of kreplach (meat-filled dumplings) or to let you dip your bread in her gribeness (rendered chicken fat with onions), despair no more.

title: New York Proposes High School Majors
description: Students in New York State would be required to declare a field of concentration, akin to a major in college, in order to receive high school diplomas under a proposal by the State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills.

title: Always al Dente, a Sardinian Bead Pasta
description: IT looks more like breakfast cereal than pasta, but fregola (pronounced FRAY-gola), toasted Sardinian pasta, is now sold in New York. Fregola, or freula sarda, is made by moistening durum wheat flour, the raw material of the best spaghetti, and then, in time-honored fashion, rolling it by hand into little beads. The pieces are sun dried and baked. It takes about 25 minutes to cook fregola grossa, the larger, lentil size, and 15 minutes for buckshot fregula media. But the nutty-flavor pasta retains a slight chewiness after long cooking, excellent for soups and casseroles. A 17-ounce bag in either size is $4.95 at Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), which also sells fregola baked with greens and anchovies, $9.50 a pound. ''Foods of Sicily and Sardinia and the Smaller Islands'' by Giuliano Bugialli (Rizzoli, 1996) has fregola recipes.

title: Busier Than A One-Man Band
description: In any production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' the scene where Prince Tamino undergoes a trial of hellish fire to gain acceptance into Sarastro's brotherhood is the most difficult to realize onstage. But the Swiss-born tenor Christoph Homberger, who presented the United States premiere of his one-man, unaccompanied version of the opera as part of Lincoln Center Festival '97 on Monday night, has come up with a solution so endearingly hilarious many people will never want to see it any other way.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: From Merengues to Meringues
description: TONIGHT on the plaza at Lincoln Center, there will be something to dance about: dessert. Berry cobblers and chocolate crepes will be among the irresistible sweets waiting for tarantella and tango aficionados and others ready to take the floor, as well as for the curious and hungry spectators who attend the Midsummer Night Swing program. The dance evenings continue through July 26, but for the dessert, it's a one-night stand.

title: Dark Horse for Joint Chiefs Job May Move Up
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen will recommend Gen. Henry H. Shelton of the Army, who commanded the American military operation in Haiti in 1994, to be the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Open the China File
description: As a result of disclosures in yesterday's campaign finance hearings, the Democratic National Committee said it would return $50,000. The money wound its way from the Lippo Group in Jakarta to President Clinton's friend and fund-raiser John Huang to the party coffers back in 1992. Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut said it ''certainly looks like the movement of foreign money into an American campaign in 1992.'' That makes two campaigns in a row, since we already know that the Democrats have returned $2.8 million in suspect foreign contributions in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRUCHTER, RACHEL G.
description: FRUCHTER-Rachel G. The memorial service will be held at the Picinc House, Prospect House, Brooklyn, NY on Sunday, July 20th 7 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: The Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Box 1232, Brooklyn, NY 11203-2098 or The Boston Women's Health Book Collective, P.O. Box 192, 240A Elm Street, Somerville, MA. 02144.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHTMAN, ESTHER
description: LEICHTMAN - Esther. Dearest mother of Francine Tancer (Michael). Devoted wife of the late Jacob Leichtman. Loving grandmother of Joan Tancer and Susan Tolchin. Cherished great grandmother of Jennifer and Eric. Died peacefully at home after a long and wonderful life. She was a lifelong supporter of Hadassah and she and her husband were involved in many worthy causes. Her marvelous sense of humor and story telling will be remembered by everyone who knew her. Her grace, charm, wit and beauty will be with us always. Her life was an inspiration to us all. Services today 2:00 PM, at Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stolen Gun Is Used to Kill
description: A 17-year-old boy was killed and two other teen-agers were wounded Monday night by bullets fired from a handgun that had been stolen from a Middlesex County narcotics officer, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Delta and US Airways will soon face competition in the New York-Washington air shuttle market.
description: DELTA AIR LINES and US Airways are about to get some new competition in the New York-Washington air shuttle market.

title: Laying Aside Dissension, N.A.A.C.P. Convention Focuses on Policy
description: Polly Williams was surprised and ecstatic to gain a new audience.

title: TV Notes
description: From Bochco: Adults Only

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column on Sunday about the wedding of Suki John and Horacio Cocchi referred incorrectly to the computer service that carries the Native's Guide to New York, an on-line forum managed by a friend of the bride. It is Compuserve, not America Online.

title: You've Heard of Soundscan, Now Read About Bookscan
description: Soundscan, a company whose computerized sales tracking system brought order to the nation's pop music charts, is preparing a version for books that some publishers hope could bring precision and efficiency to an industry struggling with declining sales and bloated print runs.

title: LAZARD FRERES' STAKE IN NURSING HOME OWNER

title: Newborn's Mother Is Held

These eyes peer from the bronze busts in the Hall of Fame Colonnade, a relic of a different era, and a reminder of the city's array of a hidden riches. Relatively few New Yorkers are aware that America's first widely imitated Hall of Fame is tucked deep in the 52-acre campus of the Bronx Community College. The colonnade itself is reached through a structure so sumptuous that it might take the annual budget of the entire City University system to build its duplicate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOWLTON, ABBIE INGALLS, MD.
description: KNOWLTON-Abbie Ingalls, MD. The Association of the Alumni of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University records with deep sorrow the death of its devoted alumna on July 15, 1997. A graduate of the Class of 1942, she trained at Presbyterian Hospital, then joined the faculty and rose to the rank of Clinical Professor of Medicine. She was an esteemed endocrinologist who was considered an authority on the management of patients with Addison's Disease of which her knowledge was encyclopedic. She devoted years to research, teaching and patient care at the Medical Center and was noted for her outstanding contributions, especially teaching of Physical Diagnosis, Internal Medicine and the monthly Clinical Pathology Conferences. She was adored by her patients, revered by her students and admired by her peers for the quality of her care and the depth of her caring. In 1986 she was awarded the Alumni Medal for Outstanding Service, and in 1990 Columbia's Alumni Federation Medal. In 1991 she was presented the Arnold Gold Foundation Award which is given to a physician who has demonstrated compassionate and devoted patient care and who has served as a humanistic role model for students and young physicians. She held almost every office in the Alumni Association, most notably Annual Fund Chairman from 1982-1997, 1942 Class Chairman from 1978-1997, & President from 1993-95. Her innovative leadership, wise counsel & dedicated service to her Alma Mater were a continuing source of pride to her colleagues in the Alumni Association. We join in expressing sincere condolences to her husband, Kenneth Calder, MD, P&S Class of 1944; her son, Thomas; her daughter, Mary; and two grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions in Dr. Knowlton's memory be sent to Columbia University, College of Physicians & Surgeons, 630 West 168 Street, BB2-250, New York, N,Y, 10032. Lester Blair, MD, President Anke Nolting, Associate Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOWLTON, ABBIE INGALLS, M.D.
description: KNOWLTON-Abbie Ingalls, M.D. The Department of Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University notes with deep sorrow the death of Dr. Abbie Ingalls Knowlton, Clinical Professor of Medicine, whose association with and contributions to our Department extend back nearly 60 years. An alumna of Bryn Mawr College in 1938, a graduate of the College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942 and a subsequent member of the Medical House Staff of The Presbyterian Hospital (including having been its first woman Chief Resident), Dr. Knowlton gave her entire professional life to unstinting, generous and gracious service to generations of patients, medical students and house staff. Quite apart from her distinguished contributions to a basic understanding of adrenal gland physiology and the early management of patients with Addison's disease which were formerly recognized in her election to membership in The American Society for Clinical Investigation, Dr. Knowlton served as an incomparable role model for all those fortunate to be associated with her. Wise, vigilant, faithful and tender in her care of patients, she taught by quiet but telling example what it is to be a physician and friend. To the end, despite a long and trying personal illness, she set a standard for others in her continuing care for patients, her kindness, her quick and perceptive interest in others and her unflagging courage and good spirits. She was a gallant, unfailingly gracious and universally beloved teacher and colleague whose passing leaves an aching void and who is greatly mourned. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Dr. Kenneth Calder, to her son, Thomas Calder and to her daughter, Mary Calder Johnstone. Myron L. Weisfeldt, M.D. Chairman, Department of Medicine College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University

title: A Rescue Assignment for NASA
description: The request from Russia that an American astronaut help repair the ailing Mir space station seems well worth honoring. The Russian commander aboard Mir is clearly in no shape, physically or mentally, to perform the repairs, so the head of the Russian space agency has asked that the American astronaut already aboard Mir step in to take his place. It is a risky undertaking, but NASA's own specialists believe the risks are manageable. There is no apparent need to wait until a specially trained Russian crew can ride to the rescue. A fellow space power has asked for American help at a critical time and should get it. Lending a hand would almost certainly improve collaboration on the Mir itself and could foster greater cooperation on more earthbound issues as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROBERT J. JR.
description: SCHWARTZ-Robert J. Jr. On July 15th, after a heroic struggle with lymphoma. Beloved and loving husband of Gail Ross and father of Matthew, Michael and Alexandra. Devoted son of Beatrice and Robert, stepmother Josephine Martin, and mother-in-law Matilda Ross. We have been blessed to know, love and be loved by such a kind, caring and intelligent person; we will miss him dearly. Born August 29, 1946 in Washington, D.C. Alumnus of Bucknell University, Lehigh University and Harvard Business School. Executive Vice President and Deputy Treasurer of Republic National Bank of New York, former Managing Director of the Mitsubishi Bank, Ltd., and former Managing Director of The Chase Manhattan Bank. Robert's professional dedication was to the field of financial engineering and derivative products, of which he was a pioneer. Co-editor of three books on the topic, founding Chairman of the International Association of Financial Engineering, a three-time board member of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, and a guest lecturer at Harvard, Columbia, Yale and St. John's Universities. Robert also committed himself to the work of the Windward School, a school for children with learning disabilities in White Plains, serving as a member of the board and President Emeritus of the Board of Trustees. Services on Sunday, 10 A.M., at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Windward School, Windward Avenue, White Plains, N.Y., 10605, or to Harvard Business School, Boston, MA. 02163.

title: Despite Ads, Teen-Age Smoking Is Unabated

Expansive skies, mesquite-covered hills and bronzed cowboys, pausing on their horses for a trail-side chat, paint a picture of Marlboro country. Only the single line of copy surprises the unsuspecting driver: ''Bob, I've got emphysema.''

title: A Wheelchair With a Racer's Edge
description: IT is no accident that this sporty new wheelchair appears to be a collage of parts from a high-performance mountain bike. Cycling enthusiasts may recognize the plump 6061-grade Alcoa aluminum tubing, the signature of Cannondale racing bicycles. The chair is due out in September. Cannondale's founder, Joseph S. Montgomery, 57, was inspired by his son Michael, 10, who loves to ski and play hockey, although cerebral palsy keeps him in a wheelchair. Mr. Armstrong also hopes for a share of what he says is a $400-million-a-year sports and lightweight wheelchair market. The Cannondale is lighter than most wheelchairs, and its wheels splay outward for better cornering. Both the sports model (left, up to $4,500) and the everyday model (right, $1,500 to $2,000) will be sold in bicycle shops. Their prices are competitive with those of conventional chairs. Information: (203) 544-9800, or in a few weeks at www.cannondale.com on the Internet.

title: Lorne Michaels Cable Deal
description: A few years ago, Lorne Michaels, the creator of ''Saturday Night Live,'' produced ''Wayne's World,'' a movie about two goofy hosts of their Generation X program on a local cable station. Now, in a real-life sequel, the production company owned by Mr. Michaels has acquired a company that develops Gen-X programs for college students on cable stations around the country.

title: Keeping an Eye Upon the Doughnut
description: SIXTY years ago, on July 13, 1937, the first Krispy Kreme doughnut was dispensed from a small stand in Salem, N.C., an old Moravian village that is part of Winston-Salem and that was famous for its yeast bread and coffee cakes. The doughnuts piqued the Southern sweet tooth. Franchised stands, crisply white as Streamline Moderne service stations, with green and red neon, became a fixture of the landscape. Signs proclaimed, ''Hot Doughnuts Now,'' when a batch left the oven.

title: Panel Seeks Care for Research Chimps
description: A central Federal agency should take over responsibility for owning and providing long-term care for most of the chimpanzees used in medical research, a National Research Council committee said today.

title: U.S., Bending a Bit, Will Offer Wider Role for 3d World at U.N.
description: After months of inaction over how to make the Security Council more reflective of today's world, the Clinton Administration is to recommend that three permanent seats be given to developing nations, a senior American official said today.

title: Stars of Old Movie Musicals Bask in Their Own Light
description: Boy meets girl. Boy sweeps girl into his arms for a delirious pas de deux in which they glide over a ballroom floor made only of starlight. Girl, smiling ecstatically, whirls faster than the speed of light in an enchanted deep blue midnight. And when it's over, perhaps they kiss. But what kiss could compare to the dance itself and the music by Jerome Kern or Arthur Schwartz or Richard Rodgers wafting the lovers through their dream?

description: Former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, who has been accused of condoning a ''dirty war'' against Basque separatists after he took office in 1982, has acknowledged for the first time that the state authorities may have gone too far in their struggle to curb the violence that was widespread.

description: Ever since New Jersey seized control of this city's school district in July 1995, state officials have struggled to curb what they consider exorbitant spending on food services. They have eliminated cafeteria jobs, reduced the number of kitchens where meals are cooked and cracked down on the theft of food from school pantries, a practice they say was common before the takeover.

title: AUDIT OF MEDICARE FINDS $23 BILLION IN OVERPAYMENTS
description: In the first comprehensive audit of Medicare, Federal investigators said today that the Government overpaid hospitals, doctors and other health care providers last year by $23 billion, or 14 percent of the money spent in the standard Medicare program.

title: Jury Examines Whether Saudi Contributed to Terrorist Groups
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan is investigating whether a renegade Saudi millionaire known for his virulent hatred of America has been funneling money to terrorist groups in the United States.

title: AVENOR TO SELL ITS STAKE IN LUMBER VENTURE TO PARTNER
description: Avenor Inc. of Montreal said yesterday that it would sell its 53 percent stake in Pacific Forest Products Ltd. for $573 million (Canadian), or $418 million (United States). Under the agreement, TimberWest Forest Holdings, a logging company in Vancouver, British Columbia, and Avenor's partner in the venture, will offer $29 (Canadian), or $21.18 (United States), a share for Pacific's stock. TimberWest will own all of Pacific's timberlands, consisting of 308,750 acres, which are mainly on Vancouver Island. As part of the same transaction, Doman Industries, based in Duncan, British Columbia, agreed to buy three sawmills and other assets from the venture for $144 million (Canadian), or $105.2 million (United States).

title: HIBERNIA IN $190 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR ARGENTBANK
description: The Hibernia Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Argentbank for stock valued at $190 million in a combination of two Louisiana banking companies. Hibernia, a bank holding company in New Orleans, said it would exchange 2.04 shares for each Argentbank share. Argentbank shares surged 21 percent, gaining $4.75, to $27.50, on the American Stock Exchange. Hibernia's shares slipped 25 cents, to $14.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Argentbank, based in Thibodaux, La., has 22 branches and $760 million in assets. Hibernia said that after the purchase of Argentbank and three other pending deals it would have 232 branches and $10.8 billion in assets.

title: Encore for 'Byzantium'
description: Ten artworks that were part of the ''Glory of Byzantium'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art this year will return to the museum for six weeks, starting tomorrow. The 10 works -- nine icons and an illuminated manuscript from the Holy Monastery of St. Catherine in Sinai, Egypt -- will be on view through Aug. 31. They will then be displayed at the Benaki Museum in Athens in a show arranged by Alpha Credit Bank, the principal sponsor of the Metropolitan's exhibition, before being returned to their permanent home in Egypt.

title: A Master Who Plays It His Way
description: The pianist Fred Hersch, a constant and highly esteemed presence in New York jazz for nearly 20 years, made his debut appearance at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night; it was a long time in coming, and he was prepared for it. Mr. Hersch's plans for re-adapting standards (the set included Cole Porter, Thelonious Monk and Ornette Coleman) are witty, scholarly and unfailingly well laid, and it helped to know the songs, their original rhythms, and, in some cases, how the words fit against the rhythms.

title: Middle East Miasma
description: What is known as the Middle East ''peace process'' has been in effect, with varying levels of intensity, since the Madrid conference brought Israel and its neighbors together in 1991. But never have the negotiations been stalled nearly as severely as they have been since March.

title: Clinton Chooses General for Head of Joint Chiefs, Aides Say
description: President Clinton today chose Gen. Henry H. Shelton of the Army as his nominee to be the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Administration officials said, ending a months-long search that had stumbled over the Pentagon's response to the sexual conduct of its officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHTER, RACHEL, PH.D.
description: FRUCHTER-Rachel, Ph.D. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecololgy at State University of New York-Health Science Center at Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center mourns the death of its beloved & dedicated faculty member, Dr. Rachel Fruchter. Dr. Fruchter was appointed to faculty in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at SUNY HSC at Brooklyn as an Instructor in 1974. In 1977, she was promoted to the level of an Assistant Professor and in 1987 she was appointed as an Associate Professor. Dr. Fruchter was a member of the faculty for twenty-five years. Dr. Fruchter was an excellent & respected epidemiologist and health researcher in the Department, institution and community. She was involved extensively in gynecologic oncology research. She worked closely with the Gynecologic Oncology Division and the Department to develop and implement gynecologic oncology research projects. She had a total of fiftynine publications, two book chapters and twenty-two abstracts. She was an excellent lecturer and she lectured extensively in the community and in the Department. Dr. Fruchter will be greatly missed in the Department and by her colleagues at SUNY HSC at Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center. -Dept. of Obs/Gyn -SUNY-HSC -Kings County Hospital Center

title: Thai Companies to Buy Chicken of the Sea
description: A group of Thai companies has agreed to acquire the Van Camp Seafood Company, the maker of Chicken of the Sea tuna. The group, led by Thai Union Frozen Products P.C.L., said it would buy the troubled Van Camp from the P. T. Management Trust Company of Indonesia for $97 million.

title: A new move to cut the costs of Federal regulations.
description: SENATOR FRED THOMPSON, chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, is making headlines with reports that China tried to influence the 1996 election. But when he's not searching for the Manchurian Candidate, the Tennessee Republican's first priority these days is adding a little common sense to the way regulations are analyzed. To this end, Senator Thompson and Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, have introduced the Regulatory Improvement Act of 1997, which would require Federal regulators to calculate price tags for all major rules.

title: Mourning, and Media Coverage
description: Versace stores throughout the world were closed today in mourning for Gianni Versace, the fashion designer who was killed on Tuesday outside his home in Miami Beach. And here in Italy, where Mr. Versace was born and began his fashion house, the signs of grief and interest in news accounts of the killing were acute.

title: At Catholic Summer School, Students Persist Despite Heat
description: The teacher's words seemed to slide across the room in slow motion, melting in the sultry air. Kevin Revell's classroom windows at Bishop Loughlin High School were open yesterday, but nothing passed in either direction. Unlike New York City public schools, many of the Roman Catholic schools in the city are not air-conditioned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POGROW, MORRIS
description: POGROW-Morris. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Rhoda Pogrow on the loss of her husband, Morris. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Hoop Dreams With a Twist
description: It all begins over an impromptu basketball lesson. While Dinah Groshardt (Connie Nelson), the sinewy girl's basketball coach and geometry teacher in a Midwestern high school, is showing Carly Lumpkin (Dee Hennigan), the algebra teacher's frumpy wife, how to play, the two 40-ish women exchange an impulsive kiss that changes both their lives.

title: Microsoft Profit Beats Forecasts, but Barely
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings rose 89 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter, reflecting strong sales of its Windows 95 operating system for personal computers and its successful drive into the corporate computing market with Windows NT, the software giant's network operating system software.

title: Adm. Albert G. Mumma, 91; Headed Navy Bureau of Ships
description: Rear Adm. Albert Girard Mumma, a naval engineer who commanded the Navy Department's Bureau of Ships in the 1950's as its nuclear power and missile program went full throttle, died on Tuesday at the Waverly Heights nursing home in Gladwyne, Pa. He was 91.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the new Georgia O'Keeffe museum in Santa Fe, N.M., misstated the year of the photograph. O'Keeffe was shown at work in New Mexico in the early 1960's, not in 1980.

title: N.F.L. Kickoff Is Approved
description: The communities of Wildwood, North Wildwood and Wildwood Crest have been striving to make their beaches better known as a playground for families than a haven for beer blasts. But on Wednesday, they agreed to let the National Football League begin its 1997 season on Aug. 30 with a two-day beach party. Two other beach communities, Avalon and Stone Harbor, turned down the N.F.L. earlier this month, citing concerns about traffic and alcohol. The event is co-sponsored by Miller Brewing Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWALD, EVERETT A.
description: DEWALD-Everett A. On July 16, 1997. Dearly beloved husband of Beatrice. Devoted uncle of Naomi Glass and Pauline Bodden. Sorely missed by his friends of W.H.I.R.P. Services private.

title: Mourners Gather in Memory Of Year-Ago Tragedy in the Air
description: They came by the busload, a cathedralful of mourners who lost their loved ones in the same instant a year ago yesterday when T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded over the Atlantic Ocean and went down, killing all 230 people on board.

title: Spain Turns on Rebels With Outrage
description: In nearly three decades of fighting for a separate Basque state, armed men and women have kidnapped and tormented, bombed and gunned down some 800 Spaniards, many of them judges, politicians, police officers and military personnel.

title: Senate Inquiry Offers More Inconclusive Hints on Huang
description: Winding up a three-day examination of the activities of John Huang, Senate investigators offered new circumstantial evidence today that he might have solicited money for the Democratic Party and conducted business with his former employer, the Lippo Group, while working at the Commerce Department.

title: Sweaty Saver or Cool Fool? Couples Battle Over B.T.U.'s
description: She is, well, steamed. He gave away her air-conditioner -- ''a monster'' that didn't fit the decor of their 80-year-old Victorian-style house. Now she wants central air-conditioning. He doesn't. And so, on a 90-something day, there he stood in the living room, sounding a bit too much like Jackie Gleason. All he said was, ''How comfortable it is!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, NED M. LOVING
description: ROSS-Ned M. Loving husband of Sandra. Father of two sons, provider of good health to many friends through Amway and Nutrilite. Services were conducted privately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVANT, LEON
description: AVANT-Leon, July 17, 1997. Brother of the late Samuel. Graveside service Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, N.J., Friday 11:30 AM.

title: 2 Acquisitions In Britain
description: Two agencies have made acquisitions in Britain for undisclosed terms.

title: Reading Program in Baltimore Reaches Out to Needy Children
description: They were at it again all over town the other day, singing, dancing, sailing, drawing and sifting through urban detritus for evidence of the past. It is all part of Supercamp, an eight-week program for 450 youngsters rarely given the chance to escape their inner-city neighborhoods for the world beyond.

title: Law School's Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur L. Liman, a Masterly Lawyer, Dies at 64
description: Arthur L. Liman, a masterly legal strategist who made his living representing both corporate tycoons and scalawags but made his public mark investigating pivotal events like the Iran-contra affair and the Attica prison uprising, died yesterday in his Manhattan apartment.

title: Demand Rises for Versace Merchandise
description: Stores across the country have reported increased sales of Versace merchandise since Tuesday, when Gianni Versace, the fashion designer, was shot to death on the steps of his house in Miami Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMLE, BOB ''CLARENCE,''
description: LEMLE-Bob ''Clarence,'' on July 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Peggy, devoted father of Stuart and Marian, Russell and Patricia, Craig and Amy. Loving grandfather of Jonathan, Clifford, Tracey, Casey, Elise, Julia, and Kyle. Brother of Leo, and the late Daniel, Blanche Dreifus, Jeanette Levine and Rose Levine. His decency and integrity will be deeply missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Dickstein Cancer Center, C/O White Plains Hospital Development Office, White Plains, New York 10601. Services will be at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York at 12 Noon, Friday, July 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEJEN, HEINZ (HENRY)
description: SCHLEJEN-Heinz (Henry). The Officers and Staff of Cromwell Advertising Agency announce with deep sorrow the untimely passing of our dear colleague. He will be greatly missed. Our condolences to his wife Joyce, daughter Nancy and the entire family.

title: Ignored Warning Leads to Chaos on the Internet
description: A human error combined with the fragile structure of the Internet dramatically demonstrated yesterday that the world's primary conduit for electronic commerce is still far from a flawlessly reliable network.

title: Exit, Stage Center: Curtis Crashes to Yanks' Rescue
description: The ninth inning turned perilous for the Yankees tonight. Mariano Rivera had a limp fastball, and two White Sox runners who could potentially tie the score danced off the bases. Rivera needed two more outs to end the game, make David Cone a winner and help the Yankees inch closer to the fading Orioles. Two measly outs.

title: Nikko Plans Venture With Smith Barney
description: The Nikko Securities Company expects to form a joint venture with the American brokerage Smith Barney Inc. to market wrap accounts in Japan.

title: New Video Releases
description: Sling Blade

title: Young Boy Breaks Leg On Ride in Atlantic City
description: A 4-year-old boy broke his leg yesterday when he fell 45 feet from a roller coaster on the Atlantic City boardwalk, the police said. It was unclear last night what caused the accident.

title: Redman, at 7 Under Par, Blisters Big Apple Course
description: Michele Redman has never won a tournament in six years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour. But today she shot a seven-under-par 64 to take the first-round lead in the JAL Big Apple Classic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILHEANY, JAMES C.
description: GILHEANY-James C., on July 17, 1997, of Garden City, New York. Beloved Husband of the late Ruth (Moore) Gilheany. Loving Father of Terence Sr. Dear Father-in-Law of Juliana. Devoted Grandfather of Terence Jr. and Anne. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Josephs R.C. Church, Garden City, on Monday at 10 A.M. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. Donations to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, New York, N.Y. 10002, appreciated.

title: Out of the Shadows and Into Rockefeller Center
description: Nestled in an unlikely place -- on a Rockefeller Center concourse, flanked by a Woolworth's and a subway entrance -- is a bank of nine video monitors that create one oversize image (the way the Times Square Jumbotron does). The Digital Video Wall, curated by the Museum of Modern Art, may not be the most restful place to watch videos, but it is a dramatic example of how video art is creeping into public places and public awareness.

title: GPU PLANS TO TAKE THIRD-QUARTER CHARGE OF $110 MILLION
description: GPU Inc. said yesterday that it would take a third-quarter charge of $110 million, or 91 cents a share, because of Britain's plan to charge owners of utilities a windfall tax. GPU, which with a partner, the Cinergy Corporation, owns 50 percent of Midlands Electricity in Britain, had 1996 third-quarter net income of $35.8 million, or 29 cents a share. The company, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., also said it had second-quarter net income of $70.3 million, or 58 cents a share, compared with $73.6 million, or 61 cents, a year earlier. GPU's stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday to $35.25.

title: Peripheral Fluff
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: READING SCORES RISE -- Results of state tests showed the greatest gain in eight years in the reading scores of third-grade students in New York City's troubled schools. B3.

description: SALKIND-Clare. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish National Fund by calling 212-751-4848 ask for Eva. Harry Steinberg, Chairman Steering Committee Ellyne Rose, Secretary

title: Liberty's 4th in Row a Balancing Act
description: The Liberty boasts several of the more prominent names in the Women's National Basketball Association. But last night's game at Madison Square Garden proved again that no one player -- or even two -- can be credited with the team's standing atop the league.

title: $25 and Under
description: When William Prunty was the executive chef of Jean-Claude Iacovelli's mini-empire of value-oriented bistros, he (like countless other chefs) looked forward to owning his own place.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: F.B.I. Agent Details Tapes Asking Money From Cosby
description: An F.B.I. agent who searched the California hotel where Autumn Jackson once stayed testified yesterday that she and other agents found tape recordings made by Ms. Jackson and her co-defendants of telephone calls demanding as much as $40 million from Bill Cosby.

title: Clinton, in 2 Speeches, Urges Racial Healing
description: In the hope of building support for his initiative on racial healing at home, President Clinton played sociology professor today, repeatedly strolling away from his prepared remarks to take two audiences on discursive tours of ethnic conflicts around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETMORE, EDWARD W.
description: WETMORE-Edward W., 66, of Old Saybrook, CT., died Wednesday (July 16). Husband of Eleanor Lihme Wetmore. Memorial Service will be held on August 1st at 2:00 PM, at the 1st Congregational Church, Prospect St., Essex, CT.

title: Departure Stirs Conflicting Reactions
description: Around New York City yesterday, reactions to the resignation of W. Ann Reynolds as Chancellor of the City University of New York reflected sharp divisions of opinions about her, both within the system and outside it. Some insisted that her departure was a healthy step; others called it an outrage.

title: Stocks Retreat As the Dow Drops 18.11
description: The stock market, its appetite for the record books temporarily quenched, slumped yesterday, dropping all the major indexes below their record highs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSANE, THOMAS P., PHD

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday and Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, on Saturday, July 19, at 10:45 AM.

description: New Chief for the Getty

Interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, N.Y.

title: The Bigger the Truck, The More Controversy
description: When Congress passed the last major Federal transportation spending plan, in 1991, it froze the rules controlling trucks that haul multiple trailers, so for six years their use has been limited by state regulations to the routes, weather conditions and travel hours that were in effect before the freeze.

title: How the Wind Blows at Troon: Furyk and Clarke Attack Early
description: The 126th British Open began today at Royal Troon in the sort of blustery and shifty conditions that every golf pro and fan instinctively link with Scottish links.

description: CALDER-Abbie Ingalls Knowlton. Memorial service, Monday, July 21st at 5PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street; reception to follow.

description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, MITCHELL S.
description: ROBERTS-Mitchell S., 9/7/13-7/17/ '97. A gentle man and a gentleman has succumbed after a long and brave battle. Pre-deceased by his loving wife, Irma. Varied career included instructor at CCNY and Director of AMREP Corp. Already missed by surviving children, Seth and Ronna and Ross; grandchildren Adam and Ethan mourn the loss of their beloved Poppy Mike. Often an inspiration, always supportive, his kind words and deeds smoothed our paths. He was loved and respected by all who had the pleasure of knowing him. In accordance with Mike's wishes, there will be no service. The family will observe a brief period of mourning at Seth and Ronna's home.

title: On Long Island, Wit, Words and Modest Works
description: SCHOOL is out for the summer, but art's still in session on Long Island. This year, contemporary installations are experiencing concentration problems. Modest drawings and paintings on paper make their mark. And a handful of historical shows, which have done their homework and look great to boot, give the overall class average a significant boost.

title: If Troon Isn't Martian, It's Certainly Metsian
description: Viewed occasionally on ESPN yesterday, Royal Troon resembled less a Scottish golf course than the forbidding terrain being probed on Mars by Pathfinder's Sojourner rover: a mostly uninhabited landscape, featuring a mound called Yogi, a tubby rock named Boo Boo, a bunker dubbed Spacely.

description: To the Editor:

title: DEADLY EPIDEMIC EMERGES IN SUDAN
description: Dr. Michaleen Richer and her crew set up their laboratory outside a dilapidated clinic in a village of mud huts bathed in the forest's dappled light.

title: Watson Mulls Dealing For Canseco or McGwire
description: Facing life without Cecil Fielder for at least the next eight weeks, the Yankees have talked with the Oakland Athletics about the availability of designated hitter Jose Canseco. They are also interested in another Oakland slugger -- the major league home run leader Mark McGwire -- but it is uncertain whether McGwire, who can turn down a trade, would want to play in New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Debt-Collection Scandal at Sears Curbs Profit
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported a decline yesterday in net income for the second quarter -- reflecting a charge stemming from a debt-collection scandal -- but its earnings before extraordinary items rose 16 percent, exceeding analysts' forecasts.

description: CONNELLY - Eleanor Milburn. Died July 16, 1997 at 91. Contributions may be made to the American Lung Association.

description: VALENSI-Quentin, M.D., 71. Retired Associate Professor of Pathology at NYU Medical Center. Beloved husband of Anneros, loving father of Jean-Paul and Vanessa. Owner of Timbertone Wall Coverings. Services on Friday, 9:30 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Thomas Evans, 86, a Takeover Expert, Dies
description: Thomas Mellon Evans Sr., a financier who was one of Wall Street's most feared corporate raiders in the 1950's and 1960's and later the breeder of champion thoroughbred horses, including a Kentucky Derby winner, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Newborn's Mother Is Held
description: A 16-year-old girl, who is accused of abandoning her newborn son in the city bus station, was ordered yesterday to remain in a juvenile detention center.

title: Coke's Net Up by 24.8% In 2d Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that earnings rose 24.8 percent in the second quarter, lifted by after-tax gains from the restructuring of its bottling network and by international volume growth.

description: Peru's Government fell deeper into turmoil today with the resignation of two more cabinet members over a brewing scandal involving wiretapping and repression of press freedoms.

description: Congress cannot spend all of its time worrying about Medicare, tax cuts, the balanced budget and Chinese interference in the 1996 elections.
