description: In percent

title: In New Jersey, Evolution in Retrospectives
description: A FEW retrospectives and several new galleries of Tibetan art at the Newark Museum, whose Tibetan collection is among the best in the world, shape the summer season in New Jersey.

title: Man Is Charged in '91 Killings Once Blamed on Drug Dealers
description: A convicted robber on probation for life since his release from prison in June was arrested yesterday by the Police Department's Cold Case Squad and charged with murdering his girlfriend and her father in Queens six years ago, the police said.

title: Some Fond Farewells for the Mainstay of Main Street
description: Florence Hillig, after retiring six years ago from her office job in Manhattan, took to coming to the Woolworth's store in Flushing, Queens. Tuesdays, she seldom missed a chance to shop because of the 10 percent discount for seniors.

title: Solarz to Tackle Cambodia Issues
description: In an effort to explore a resolution to the political crisis in Cambodia, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today asked the former New York Congressman Stephen J. Solarz to travel to the region as a special envoy, the State Department announced.

title: ASPECT STOCK DROPS 24% ON PROFIT EXPECTATIONS
description: Shares of the Aspect Telecommunications Corporation fell 24 percent yesterday after analysts cut their earnings estimates because of worries about lagging growth. Shares of the company, a manufacturer of call center systems, fell $6.4375, to $19.6875, in trading of 7.1 million shares. Aspect, based in San Jose, Calif., reported on Wednesday that its profit from operations rose 16 percent, to $10.6 million, or 22 cents a share, from $9.1 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 28 percent, to $93.5 million from $72.9 million.

title: Israelis Turn Self-Critical As Mishap Kills Two
description: The collapse of a makeshift bridge at the Maccabiah Games and the death of two Australian participants has set off an unusual round of painful soul-searching among Israelis about their attitudes toward order and toward death.

title: 3d Graders Improve Test Scores In Reading
description: The reading scores of third-grade students in New York City's most troubled schools showed their greatest gain in eight years, according to the results of state reading tests released yesterday.

title: It's Not Only Straight and Narrow
description: The camera peeks out of the pizza oven, admiring the stereotypical specimens that ''Kiss Me, Guido'' so affectionately lampoons. These are big guys from the Bronx, speaking with an accent in which ''pawn'' and ''porn'' are indistinguishable. They say ''go down to da city'' when they mean visiting Manhattan. And they are macho men of a very different stripe from the film's West Village characters, who see the tight tank top as a means of showing off attractive musculature. Among the film's Bronx characters, the same garment may merely be an undershirt to cover the gut.

title: Sprint's Profit Falls On Higher Spending
description: The Sprint Corporation said today that its profit fell in the second quarter, reflecting increased spending on new businesses like wireless communications.

title: Revolving Door Spins Faster at Top Corporations -- For AT&T, Troubling Questions
description: Every crisis spawns a catch phrase, and for AT&T executives in recent weeks, the phrase was, ''I'm playing Switzerland.''

title: A Bounty of Works You'd Hardly Find At Your Video Store
description: IN the beautiful, meditative ''Oriental Elegy,'' the master Russian filmmaker Aleksandr Sokurov approaches a misty Japanese island and turns the journey into a poetic quest for the afterlife.

title: Accounts
description: * Border Books and Music, Ann Arbor, Mich., owned by Borders Group, to Butler, Shine & Stern, Sausalito, Calif., to handle the creative portion of its account, which had been handled by Perich & Partners, Ann Arbor. Carat North America, New York, part of Aegis Group P.L.C., was awarded the media duties last month, which had also been handled by Perich. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: GARTNER GROUP TO PURCHASE 2 UNITS FROM MCGRAW-HILL
description: Gartner Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Datapro and Northern Business Information, two computer market research units of the McGraw-Hill Company. Terms were not disclosed. Gartner Group, based in Stamford, Conn., is a technology consulting firm that provides market research, analysis and other services to 8,300 clients worldwide. McGraw-Hill, based in New York, publishes books, software and magazines. It said the sales would allow it to concentrate on financial services and educational and professional publishing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the indictment of the former president and owner of 47th Street Photo, on charges of falsifying accounts, referred incompletely to a yeshiva in Brooklyn also named in the indictment. According to the office of United States Attorney in Manhattan, the institution involved, the United Talmudical Academy, is based at 5301 14th Avenue in Borough Park, and has four other Brooklyn locations -- at 1010 45th Street, at 1346 45th Street, at 5411 Fort Hamilton Parkway, and on 49th Street (for which a specific address was not available). The indictment did not involve other institutions in Brooklyn with similar names.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, HYMAN
description: RULNICK-Hyman, July 18, 1993. Still so hard to believe you are gone. I miss you still. Your loving daughter, Joyce

title: Friends, No, but Teammates Still
description: In his autobiography ''Just Give Me the Damn Ball!'' Jets wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson seemed to accuse his teammate Neil O'Donnell of everything from faking injuries to starting the Vietnam War. Johnson might want to consider wearing a helmet in the locker room as well as on the field. Many of the Jets' players apparently are not happy with him -- still.

title: Fireman Pleads Guilty To Causing False Alarms
description: A New York City firefighter with 14 years on the job pleaded guilty yesterday to calling in two false alarms from a pay phone in the kitchen of his Queens firehouse last year.

title: Where the Sacred Serpent Rests, a Mine Intrudes
description: When not washing sheets at the laundry of the four-star Crocodile Hotel here, Yvonne Margarula heads the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation, which seeks to protect local Aborigines and their lands.

title: California Put on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association cracked down on the California men's basketball program yesterday, placing the team on probation for three years because its former head coach paid a player's family $15,000 a year for two years.

title: Encountering Death With Defiance and a Dance
description: Is there art in an execution? The very idea sounds distressing, but in ''Bergville Stories,'' a high-spirited portrait of itinerant Zulu laborers barricaded in a camp in a black South African township that does not want them, the writer Duma Ndlovu shows how something so forbidding can be engaging, poignant and even heart-rending.

title: Lucent Is Set To Buy Leader In Voice Mail
description: In its first major acquisition since becoming an independent company, Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $1.8 billion in cash to acquire the Octel Communications Corporation, the largest maker of telephone voice mail systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROBERT J.
description: SCHWARTZ-Robert J. The Board of the Directors of the International Association of Financial Engineers (IAFE) mourns the passing of our founder, chairman and dear friend-Bob Schwartz. Bob was a guiding light in the field of Financial Engineering. He will be sorely missed, both for his contributions to the field, and for for his warmth, integrity, friendship & compassion. The Board extends their heartfelt condolences to his family. Services will be held at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Avenue, Scarsdale New York, 914-723-7727, on Sunday, July 20, 1997, 10 A.M. The IAFE has established The Robert J. Schwartz Memorial Fund to perpetuate his contributions to the field of Financing Engineering. Please make donations payable to IAFE, Robert J. Schwartz Memorial Fund, 646 Main St. Port Jefferson, LI 11777.

title: The Kindness of the Hunt
description: About 350 years ago, the last native English wolf was shot with a musket outside Nottingham. Bad luck for the wolf, but Christmas Day for the fox.

title: Kinetic Energy From a Senator's Words
description: It was an episode that illustrated just how supercharged the political environment is that surrounds the Senate's hearings into campaign finance abuses.

title: Troubled Co-op Building Coming Back as Condos
description: A rare conversion from a co-op to condominium is the next step in the planned revival of a 197-unit cooperative on Manhattan's Upper East Side that recently emerged from bankruptcy.

title: A Grief-Stricken Queen And a Manly Commoner
description: The braids and bonnets that intricately adorn the head of Queen Victoria, played with splendid regal grace by Judi Dench in the stately ''Mrs. Brown,'' are heavier than any crown. With them comes the burden of propriety that restricts every aspect of her royal life. Watched and fussed and fawned over during every waking hour, this film's central character is also in the midst of private mourning when the story begins in 1864.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STESSIN, NANCY
description: STESSIN-Nancy. The entire Juilliard Community mourns the death of Nancy Stessin, who worked very closely with her husband Herbert Stessin in the teaching of piano at all levels at the Juilliard School. We extend our deepest condolences to Herbert and the Stessin family. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday on the United Nations erroneously referred to Mary Robinson as the former President of Ireland. She will remain President until at least September, when she assumes her new post as the United Nations High Commissioner on Human Rights.

title: Father and Son
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Slip After More Data Show a Strong Economy
description: Treasury prices fell slightly yesterday following a recent run-up, after several reports showed signs of economic strength.

title: DIGITAL LOWERS THE PRICES OF ITS PERSONAL COMPUTERS
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it had lowered the prices of its personal computers by up to 21 percent in an effort to keep pace with competitors' price cutting. The move comes a week after the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company announced price cuts of more than 20 percent to try to generate more demand and to stall gains in market share by the Dell Computer Corporation and Gateway 2000 Inc. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., said reduced manufacturing costs would allow it to pass along the savings. Its stock fell 93.75 cents yesterday, to $38.8125.

title: Golden Girl of Vice K.O.'s Oleo Heir
description: So many cigarettes are theatrically flourished in Raymond De Felitta's nifty sleeper of a film ''Cafe Society'' that when it's over you may be tempted to inspect your clothing for the stale, clinging odor of secondhand smoke. Many of those cigarettes jut from the enameled tips of tapering holders fingered by bejeweled, white-gloved ''socialites'' posing for the flashbulbs in El Casbah, a swank early-50's Manhattan saloon reminiscent of El Morocco.

title: Not All Giants Are in Camp
description: Like several National Football League teams on the verge of their first preseason practice, the Giants will hardly be surprised when their first-round draft pick is absent as training camp opens Friday at SUNY-Albany. But that doesn't forecast a lengthy holdout for Ike Hilliard, a wide receiver from the University of Florida, who was the draft's seventh pick over all.

title: A Lieutenant to Gingrich Is Out After Taking Part in a Coup Bid
description: Representative Bill Paxon resigned his post as one of Speaker Newt Gingrich's top lieutenants today, after junior House members sought to enlist his help and that of other House leaders in a coup attempt.

title: New Sign in Times Square
description: The 1998 Goodwill Games will not descend on New York City for a year. But already, the games are being heralded with a huge sign in Times Square, the mecca of urban signage.

title: Ms. Messinger's Budget Blunder
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York is a formidable candidate for re-election. But there seemed reason to believe that Ruth Messinger, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, would make him fight hard for a second term. Unfortunately, so far the opposite has happened.

title: In Connecticut: Recent Nauman, Sentimental Memories and Black Culture
description: AMONG its other esthetic virtues, Connecticut has a lively network of art museums. Fine permanent collections, vibrant programs and a round of varied shows, from the big-time Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford to the jewel-like Bruce Museum in Greenwich, could keep an art lover happy all year round (between, of course, regular visits to New York City).

title: Search for Fugitive Intensifies as Doctor Is Found Slain in Maimi Suburb
description: The manhunt for Andrew P. Cunanan, the fugitive sought in the killing of the fashion designer Gianni Versace and four other men, took investigators today to a Miami suburb where a 44-year-old doctor was slain in his bedroom, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSACE, GIANNI
description: VERSACE-Gianni. To the King, thank you for always making me feel like a prince and for the profound impact you made on my life. You will be with me forever and proud. Love you always, Mark Reynolds

title: Clinton Warns Europeans of Trade Complaint on Boeing Deal
description: President Clinton threatened today to go to the World Trade Organization if the European Union moved against the acquisition of McDonnell Douglas by Boeing. He also hinted at possible American sanctions against the Europeans.

title: New Video Releases
description: Private Parts

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARBER, ROBERT
description: FARBER-Robert. My beloved brother. You opened a world for me and through its door I am able to celebrate you every day of my life. You are with me in my heart and in my thoughts at all times. You truly live on through so many of us who continue to love and miss you terribly. For all of us July 18th, your birthday, will always be a day of gratitude for the time we got to share with you. I Love you. Lindy

title: Merck Shares Soar on Earnings
description: Merck & Company reported a second-quarter earnings gain today that was bigger than expected, and its stock rose 8.4 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRUCHTER, RACHEL G.
description: FRUCHTER-Rachel G. The memorial service will be held at the Picinc House, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, NY on Sunday, July 20th 7 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: The Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Box 1232, Brooklyn, NY 11203-2098 or The Boston Women's Health Book Collective, P.O. Box 192, 240A Elm Street, Somerville, MA. 02144.

title: Seles Matures Beyond the Hype
description: SHE was a carefree teen-ager and burgeoning celebrity here once, preening for the cameras, hammering winners for her special friends, Marla Maples and Donald Trump. Monica Seles was an archetypical cover for Seventeen, which six years ago was exactly her age.

title: Board Sets Phone Rates
description: Long-distance telephone companies seeking to enter the local phone market have two choices: build their own local networks or buy time on existing systems. Yesterday, state regulators set a standard rate of $16.21 per customer per month for companies that want to buy time on the state's largest local network owned by Bell Atlantic-New Jersey.

title: Medicare Cuts That Harm Cities
description: Congressional conferees may decide today whether the Medicare cuts they are determined to impose will be apportioned fairly or will victimize urban areas and transfer the funds to rural areas.

title: Boy Breaks Leg on Ride
description: A 4-year-old boy broke his leg yesterday afternoon when he fell 45 feet from a roller coaster on the Steel Pier off the Atlantic City boardwalk, the police said. It was unclear last night what caused the accident.

title: Bankers Trust Posts Earnings Rise of 20%
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 20 percent, driven by greater profits from trading and investment management.

title: Middleman of Waste Material, Mistakes and Leftovers
description: John Okun stood in a dark basement in Long Island City, Queens, waiting for someone to find the light switch. But he already knew what would be revealed: something odd or forgotten, wasted or unwanted. That's why he'd been called in on the case.

title: Power Broker Looks for Deals to Keep New York Cool
description: At 2:30 yesterday afternoon, New York City's power broker of the moment took his seat at his desk and picked up the phone to do a deal. Before him stretched a panoramic view of the metropolitan area, from Dutchess County all the way to Fresh Kills on Staten Island.

title: A Pitiful Giant
description: This year's convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was supposed to have been all about children, which was not a bad idea because huge numbers of black children are hurting in ways that would break a normal person's heart. But the interests of children were betrayed right at the start when the thuggish boxing promoter Don King was honored, embraced and gushed over by Kweisi Mfume, the man who was hired to clean up the act of the once-illustrious civil rights organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMAN, ARTHUR L.
description: LIMAN-Arthur L. Survived by his loving family. Services at 12 noon today, Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York. Contributions to Yale Law School Arthur L. Liman Fund for Public Interest, Box 208-215, New Haven, CT. 06520, Harvard University Recording Secretary's Office, 124 Mount Auburn Street, 4th Floor, Cambridge, MA. 02138 or Legal Action Center, 153 Waverly Place, New York City 10014.

title: Satire on the Hudson
description: In the still of a violet night, on a majestic bluff that overlooks West Point and the Hudson River, a summer theater is poking fun at piety, classical French comedy and even itself.

title: McDonnell Posts Rise in Profits
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that its earnings rose 3.7 percent in the second quarter, as higher profit from its aircraft financing unit and lower interest and tax expenses offset earnings declines at its aerospace and military businesses.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The three-martini lunch, as everybody knows, died years ago. Now there are signs that the three-course lunch may also be on its way out. We seem to be entering the age of the speedy bar lunch.

title: Revolving Door Spins Faster at Top Corporations -- Leashes Get  Shorter for Executives
description: After barely more than eight months as president of the AT&T Corporation, John R. Walter is gone. And he is the second revolving-door corporate casualty in a week, following Gilbert Amelio, who was ousted last Wednesday from Apple Computer Inc. after 17 months as chairman.

title: Despite Assurances, U.N. Workers Fear Downsizing
description: This morning it was the United Nations staff's turn to hear about reform from Secretary General Kofi Annan.

title: British Troops Detain Four Men in Blasts at Base in Bosnia
description: British soldiers fired warning shots and detained four men they suspect of having set off three small explosive charges at a British base on Wednesday night.

title: Costly Gap On 57th St. Is the Center Of a Dispute
description: It should have been built by now, the slender tower slated for East 57th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues that will serve as the American headquarters and flagship store of Louis Vuitton. The idea was to have an opalescent facade designed to look like a seashell whose hues would change as neon lights washed over it.

title: Temper Cited as Cause of 28,000 Road Deaths a Year
description: Aggressive behavior like tailgating, weaving through busy lanes, honking or screaming at other drivers, exchanges of insults and even gunfire is a factor in nearly 28,000 highway deaths a year, and the problem is getting worse, the chief Federal highway safety official said today at a Congressional hearing.

title: It's a Jungle Out There, Wherever 'There' Is
description: No matter where the jungle, there are still lessons to be learned by man from the animals.

title: ASTRONAUT ERROR DEEPENS ANXIETIES ON SPACE STATION
description: An astronaut aboard the Mir space station mistakenly disconnected a critical cable today, disabling the guidance system that enables Mir to gather solar energy and causing yet another crisis for the trouble-plagued craft.

title: TRIQUINT STOCK DROPS 20% ON EARNINGS OUTLOOK
description: The shares of Triquint Semiconductor Inc. tumbled 20 percent yesterday amid concern that its earnings would not increase as quickly as expected for the rest of the year. Shares in the company fell $9.125, to $35, in Nasdaq trading of 2.4 million shares. Analysts said Triquint, which makes integrated circuits used in many wireless communications devices, lowered its earnings expectations for the third and fourth quarters in a conference call on Wednesday. Triquint, based in Hillsboro, Ore., reported second-quarter earnings on Wednesday that were slightly better than analyst estimates.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, agreed to buy the corporate and municipal bond administration business of One Valley Bank of Charleston, W. Va., for undisclosed terms.

title: Sihanouk Enhances His Reputation for Unpredictability
description: As Cambodia's democracy collapsed in a coup earlier this month, its aging and mercurial figurehead, King Norodom Sihanouk, remained in Beijing, where he has often retreated for long periods.

title: Injuries Keep O'Brien Out of the World Meet
description: Dan O'Brien, the Olympic decathlon champion, has declined a wild-card invitation to compete at the world track and field championships next month in Athens because of injuries.

title: Killers, Creeps, Elvis's Mom
description: Lowlifes, stalkers, inept criminals, borderline psychotics, serial killers and Elvis Presley's mother populate the songs of Space, a band from Liverpool that played at Irving Plaza on Wednesday. It was the first night of the Intel Music Festival, which continues through tomorrow at 20 clubs around Manhattan. Space is the residue of the British music-hall tradition after four decades of rock: jokey voices carried by high-tech brawn, hinting at real trouble behind the bounce.

title: The Job's Not Done Yet
description: With revenue coming in higher and spending lower than expected, some members of Congress and economic analysts are advocating a do-nothing approach to the Federal budget deficit. The deficit will disappear by itself, they claim. But that's just the kind of rosy thinking that got us into trouble in the 1980's. We have made enormous progress in reducing the deficit, and our economy is stronger as a result. It would be a mistake to abandon that fiscal discipline now.

title: The Art of Storytelling, Transformed by Hackers
description: HAMLET ON THE HOLODECK

title: Shevardnadze Agonistes
description: When President Clinton welcomes Eduard Shevardnadze to the White House this evening, it will be a homecoming of sorts for the Georgian leader. Many times in the final years of the cold war, he met as Soviet Foreign Minister in the Oval Office with American Presidents and Secretaries of State, demolishing the barriers that divided East and West. For that historic statesmanship he should be honored here. But Mr. Shevardnadze is a good deal more complex than the common hagiography about him would suggest. He belongs on the short list of the world's toughest, most hardened politicians.

title: Greatest Show Fails to Get Details From Greatest Bar
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Greatest Show on Earth had no right to an accounting of the profits of the Greatest Bar on Earth.

title: Kmart's Builders Square Unit To Be Combined With Hechinger
description: The Kmart Corporation has found a buyer for the ailing home improvement business it has been trying to sell for months.

title: Klockner-Werke Shares Soar on Forecast
description: The shares of Klockner-Werke A.G. soared yesterday after the company, an auto-parts and machinery maker, said its pretax profit would quadruple this year and that Viag A.G. had sold its 13 percent stake. The shares jumped 11 marks, to 141 marks, after the company repeated forecasts that it expected a pretax profit of 200 million marks ($112 million) for the fiscal year.

title: Tax-Break Deal Tied To Creation of Jobs
description: As part of an agreement to keep Furman Selz, an investment banking and financial services firm, in Manhattan, the city and state have agreed to give the firm up to $2.4 million in tax breaks over the next 16 years, city officials said yesterday. But the deal has some important fine print: The firm has to grow and create jobs in order to collect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, HARRY
description: WEINER-Harry. Our heartfelt condolences to the Weiner family on the loss of their beloved patriarch. Rabbi Joseph Kalatsky Dean, Yad Avrohom Institute

title: For French Joie de Vivre, Leave Laptops at Home
description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHTER, RACHEL
description: FRUCHTER-Rachel. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society (CSS) extend our sincere sympathy and condolences to our esteemed former Trustee Norman Fruchter and his family on the untimely death of his wife. Rachel Fruchter was a force for good in her community and her contributions to the well being of others will remain as a living tribute. David R. Jones, President Stephen R. Aiello, Chairperson

title: The Spoken Word
description: DIFFERENT LIGHT BOOKSTORE, 151 West 19th Street, Chelsea. A discussion of the book ''Mothers'' by Jax Peters Lowell, by the Social Activities for Lesbians Book Group. Sunday at 1 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 989-4850.

title: Independent Findings
description: To the Editor:

title: Ameritech and Sears Canada change agencies as a series of switches at big accounts continues.
description: TWO big advertisers are changing agencies as the multibillion-dollar account switches of the last 18 months continue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPPER, ELIAS
description: PEPPER-Elias, on July 16th, 1997. Beloved son of Minerva (deceased), brother to Beatrice, and kin to all who loved him. Family will receive friends Friday 2-6 and Saturday 7-9 P.M., with funeral service on Sunday, 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment will follow at Sharon Garden Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Indeed, It's a Long Journey That Begins With the Hand
description: ''The lesson of the machine,'' the singer Joan La Barbara says somewhere in the middle of Morton Subotnick's new ''Intimate Immensity,'' ''is objectivity and neutrality.'' If so -- and I think the point is either utterly trite or totally untrue -- it is a lesson Mr. Subotnick has spent 40 years not needing to learn. Other composers of his generation, often not using electronic sound or computers (I am thinking of Steve Reich or Gyorgy Ligeti), have come up with models of how, in human thought, the mechanical folds into the intuitive, of how the unexpected can spring out from reiterative process. Their music suggests that the lesson of the machine is a new subjectivity and a sense that we are all, whether we have Intel inside or gray matter, akin.

title: High Marks for Giuliani From Budget Watchdogs
description: With only a few whispers of gloom, the state board that oversees New York City's finances gave an unusually positive grade to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's most recent budget yesterday, saying the fiscal outlook is the brightest in years.

title: Echoes of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Net Rises 89% But Barely Beats Forecasts

title: Sweatshop Raids Cast Doubt on an Effort By Garment Makers to Police the Factories
description: For several years, Federal officials have pointed proudly to an anti-sweatshop program that relies on apparel companies to police factories as a model of government-industry cooperation and as a way to reassure consumers that the clothes they buy are not made by exploited workers.

title: New York Times Company Posts 81.5% Rise in Quarterly Profit
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that earnings rose 81.5 percent in the second quarter, to $84.9 million, or 85 cents a share, from $46.8 million, or 48 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. The company said strong advertising revenue and the purchase of two broadcasting stations accounted for much of the gain.

title: Politicians as Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Under Parcells, a Sense of Renewal
description: Marvin Jones accepting discipline. Neil O'Donnell ''feeling 10 times better.'' It was the promise of such things with the arrival of Bill Parcells as coach that led a record number of Jets fans to renew their season tickets after the team produced its worst mark in history at 1-15.

title: Restaurants
description: The huitlacoche craze swept across Southern California 15 years ago. It was a time when people liked to brag about eating things others had never heard of, and this corn fungus, which is an honored Mexican ingredient, was considered a coup. It was spoken of in reverent tones, as if a great new American truffle had just been discovered. Never mind that it wasn't very tasty.

title: For Children
description: Frankenbean and the Monster Carrots'

title: Jackie Chan And Babes Fight Nazis
description: At one point in Jackie Chan's ''Operation Condor,'' the characters seem to be in a British bedroom farce, but with guns. In the atrium of a Morocco hotel, doors are opening and closing, villains and heroes are entering and exiting, and near-encounters abound. A hotel employee wearing a fez suddenly appears with a huge automatic weapon but refuses to use it until the beautiful blonde tips him. Then the blonde sets to firing the weapon with the same aplomb Jamie Lee Curtis showed when faced with a similar challenge in ''True Lies.''

title: Woolworth Gives Up on the Five-and-Dime
description: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it would shutter all 400 of its remaining five-and-dime stores, closing the book on a 117-year history of a store that offered lipstick, diapers and a milk shake at a discount all under one roof.

title: Mets Find Some More Magic in the Heat of the Moment
description: While the backup and then the regular shortstop were performing late-game acrobatics on defense, the Mets' offense was scrounging for a run to avert a four-game losing streak, something Butch Huskey later said ''could have been disastrous for us.''

title: States of Art: Exhibitions Throughout The Region
description: THIS is a busier summer art season than usual in the region around New York City. In Connecticut, at the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield, a Bruce Nauman retrospective brings together well-chosen drawings, prints and related works from the last decade. The Stamford branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art has a perfect summer special: works by eight artists whose subjects include melancholy, nostalgia and romance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALEY, BENJAMIN H.
description: PALEY-Benjamin H., on July 16, at age 93. Beloved husband of the late Faye. Loving father and father-in-law of Stuart and Naomi Paley, and Harriet and Harold SebagMontefiore. Cherished grandfather of Jenny, Adam, and Jane. Dear great-grandfather of Hannah Faye. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN, MICHAEL
description: ROSEN-Michael. July 18, 1980. Forever remembered and cherished. Your family

title: Former Mobster Directly Links Gigante to a Murder
description: Testifying by closed-circuit television, a cancer-stricken former mobster yesterday provided the first direct account linking Vincent Gigante to any of the Mafia murders he is charged with ordering.

title: The World Continues Its Summer Visit to Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center Festival '97 runs through July 27 at locations at or near Lincoln Center. Tickets, which range from $20 to $120, can be purchased at the festival box office at Avery Fisher Hall or through Centercharge, (212) 721-6500. Here is a schedule of performances this weekend.

title: Dime Bancorp Income Up
description: Dime Bancorp reported yesterday that its net interest income rose 4.4 percent to $119.1 million in the second quarter, up from $114.1 million in the same quarter last year. Non-interest income totaled $29.2 million, a 24.3 percent increase from the $23.5 million earned a year ago.

title: British Official Makes It Clear: Time Isn't Right for the Euro
description: The tenuous nature of Europe's proposed monetary union was demonstrated again today when British Government and business officials reiterated their reluctance to immediately embrace the planned single currency, the euro.

title: COGECO AND SHAW TO SWAP CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEMS
description: The Canadian cable operator Cogeco Cable Inc. agreed yesterday to swap cable television systems with Shaw Communications Inc. Cogeco would acquire Shaw's cable systems, which serve about 91,000 subscribers in the Ontario cities of Windsor, Chatham, Learnington and Smiths Falls. In turn, Shaw would buy Cogeco's cable systems, which serve about 72,000 subscribers in Lethbridge, Alberta, and parts of British Columbia. Because the systems have different values, Cogeco, based in Montreal, is to pay Shaw about $50 million (Canadian), or $36.4 million (United States), at closing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEINSTEIN, HARRY
description: FEINSTEIN-Harry. 7/11/80. Our happy life together, close to our hearts always. Francine, Nina, Beth and David

title: Police Kill a Gun-Wielding Suspect Who Threatened Suicide
description: A distraught man shot and killed his former girlfriend in an apartment building in a Brooklyn housing project last night, then, outside the building, threatened suicide and pointed a shotgun at police officers, who shot and killed him in response, the police said.

title: Tandy Is Selling Stake in a Unit
description: The Tandy Corporation said today that it would evaluate the possibility of making its Computer City retail unit a stand-alone company.

title: Income Is No Measure Of a Life's Value
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: Hamlet

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about declining ratings for the CNN cable network misstated the number of households represented by one ratings point. As the article noted, it currently equals 712,000 households for CNN, not 970,000. (In cable television, a ratings point represents 1 percent of the households in which the network is available; CNN is distributed to 71.2 million homes.)

title: Why Let Government Set Our Artistic Priorities?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands in China Demonstrate Against the Closing of Factories
description: Thousands of Chinese workers took to the streets earlier this month in the southwestern city of Mianyang to demand jobs and welfare payments after several large state-owned factories declared bankruptcy, officials here said tonight.

title: Criticized by Board, CUNY's Chief Quits For Job at Alabama
description: After months of harsh criticism from her board of trustees, W. Ann Reynolds, the Chancellor of the City University of New York, announced yesterday that she would leave in mid-September to become the president of the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

title: Unlikely Partners in Crime
description: Tim Robbins is tall enough to slouch with his elbow draped across Martin Lawrence's head, thus providing an advertising gimmick for their buddy movie ''Nothing to Lose.'' Their odd-couple teamwork is also shown off to funny advantage by the film's two-minute trailers. As anyone who has seen these previews knows by now, Mr. Robbins plays a yuppie executive who is shocked to learn that his wife (Kelly Preston) is cheating on him. This makes him think that he has nothing to lose, hence the title.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the moment, CAMILLA PARKER BOWLES has managed to push Diana, the Princess of Wales, her former rival for the affections of PRINCE CHARLES, out of the London headlines. The reason for all the fuss: Mrs. Parker Bowles turned 50 yesterday.

title: In Gorse And Wind At 'Railway'
description: AT Royal Troon, the 11th hole is known as ''the Railway'' for the trains that rumble by on the other side of the stone wall to the right. And as Tiger Woods was about to address his tee shot there yesterday in the 126th British Open, he heard the ''toot-toot'' of the whistle on the orange-and-black commuter train from Glasgow.

title: Senate Conferees Modify Stand on Airline Tax
description: The Senate moved today toward a compromise with the House over a tax provision of keen interest to airlines, agreeing to drop its own plan in favor of the House's proposal to increase international departure and arrival fees.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Water Use Is Restricted
description: Despite the recent dry weather, New Jersey has ample reserves of water, but some suppliers are finding it hard to pump enough to meet the demand and have imposed mandatory restrictions or asked for voluntary conservation.

title: TEL-SAVE AGREES TO BUY SHARED TECHNOLOGIES
description: Tel-Save Holdings Inc., a long-distance company in New Hope, Pa., agreed yesterday to buy Shared Technologies Fairchild Inc. for $11.25 a share, or about $511 million. Tel-Save's shares fell $1.90625 each, to $19.09375, while Shared Technologies rose $1.75, or 19.7 percent, to $10.625, in Nasdaq trading. Shared Technologies shares will be converted to Tel-Save shares based on an average closing price of Tel-Save's stock over a 15-day period before the transaction closes. The combined company will have 475 buildings, 110,000 local lines, 1,200 employees and about 500,000 customers. Shared Technologies Fairchild, based in Wethersfield, Conn., provides telecommunications services and shared systems to tenants of multitenant office buildings.

title: New York Pork
description: To the Editor:

title: To Ask Is Not Always To Extort
description: The prosecution of Autumn Jackson on charges that she tried to extort money from Bill Cosby raises one of the most unsettled and troubling issues in the law. The heart of the problem is this: Ms. Jackson was entitled, consistent with her constitutional rights, to sell her story to the press. Moreover, she, along with anyone else, was legally entitled to request money from Mr. Cosby or any other person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, MARK
description: REINER-Mark. You touched all of our lives in so many positive ways. Mark, you are and will always be loved by all of us. We love you and will miss you. The Konsker Family

title: Hudson Valley Conversations
description: SUMMER exhibitions in suburban museums tend to go against the grain of the season's quiet pace. While everyone is heading for the hills to unwind, the museums gear up, knowing that the roads to those hills often lead past their doorsteps. The summer exhibition fare in the Hudson Valley runs the gamut from homey to sophisticated, and so-so to pretty good, but nearly every museum has pulled out most of its stops, so A's for effort are in order all around. By coincidence, the shows hew to a relatively narrow range of subject matter -- two are involved with crafts, two with landscape -- which means that they align themselves into a pair of two-way conversations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two years ago, EUGENIA ZUKERMAN, the flutist, was battling a life-threatening lung disease. But she has recovered, and with a vengeance.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: INSIDE
description: Another Killing in Miami

title: Columbia/HCA Inquiry Is Said To Produce Evidence of Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors in the investigation of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation have obtained evidence that certain hospital executives responsible for obtaining reimbursement from Medicare submitted false information to the Government, people with knowledge of the effort said yesterday.

title: Phillips Begins Working Quickly
description: On his first full day as general manager of the Mets, Steve Phillips was in his Shea Stadium office at 7:45 yesterday morning. By the time the day was half-finished, Phillips had met with reporters twice, spoken on the phone with at least half the major leagues' general managers and met with Manager Bobby Valentine before and after yesterday's game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRETTER, VICTOR
description: TRETTER-Victor. The Board of Trustees and Administration of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine and the foot clinics of New York are saddened to learn of the passing of Mr. Victor Tretter, one of our distinguished board members. Mr. Tretter served the college and clinics for many years with distinction. Our thoughts and prayers are extended to his wife Agnes and his family. Alfred Gerosa, Chairman Louis Levine, President

title: The Designs of a Genius Redesigning Himself
description: WHEN America's westward expansion finally reached the Pacific coast, the artist's imagination became the country's new frontier. Or so one might conclude from a show of uncommon beauty on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art, ''Frank Lloyd Wright: Designs for an American Landscape, 1922-32.'' The show, first presented at the Canadian Center for Architecture, offers five projects, all unbuilt, in which Wright developed a range of innovative forms for buildings far removed from the urban center. Not coincidentally, the show also depicts an artist in the painful process of recreating himself.

title: Kenya Leaders Hint at Letup On Harsh Laws
description: Under pressure from opposition leaders and Western diplomats, Kenya's ruling party announced today that it would consider amending or repealing several repressive laws that have been the focus of violent demonstrations in recent weeks.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL TO SPIN OFF ADDITIVES BUSINESS
description: The Great Lakes Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off its fuel additives business, creating an independent company called Octel. Great Lakes Chemical, based in West Lafayette, Ind., is a specialty chemicals concern. The company created by the spinoff will include Octel Associates, a maker of compounds that prevent engine knocking, and Octel America, a developer of other fuel additives. In preparation for the spinoff, Great Lakes will buy back a 10.65 percent interest in the company held by the Chevron Chemical Company. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, DR. LEE EDWARD
description: FARR-Dr. Lee Edward, one of the nation's preeminent physicians in nuclear and environmental medicine, died in Walnut Creek, CA on July 16, 1997 of cancer. A native of Albuquerque, New Mexico, Dr. Farr was born on October 13, 1907, the only child of Edward and Mabel Farr. He was a graduate of Albuquerque High School and went on to Yale University, and Yale University School of Medicine where he earned his M.D. in 1933 and remained to serve as an Assistant in Pediatrics. In 1934 Dr. Farr was appointed an Associate in Medicine at the Hospital of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in New York City, and from 1940-1949 served as Director of Research and Physician-inChief at the Alfred I. Du Pont Institute of the Nemours Foundation, Wilmington, DE., where he researched and developed a treatment for nephrosis in children. Dr. Farr was named Medical Director, Chairman of the Medical Department and Physician-in-Chief of the Medical Research Center at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, NY in 1949. While at Brookhaven, he pioneered the design and construction of the world's first nuclear reactor built and used primarily for medical purposes. In 1962 the University of Texas in Houston appointed Dr. Farr Chief of the Section of Nuclear Medicine at M.D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute as well as Professor of Nuclear and Environmental Medicine, Professor of Environmental Health, and Chairman of the Department of Environmental Health at the University of Texas School of Public Health. In 1968 the California State Department of Public Health appointed Dr. Farr Chief of Emergency Health Services and Head of Disaster Health Services. He worked to establish the State of California Bureau of Emergency Medical Services of which he was named the first Chief in 1970, a post he held until his retirement in 1973. During World War II, Lieutenant Commander Farr served with the U.S. Navy as a Medical Officer aboard the U.S.S. Tryon, an armed hospital transport ship in the Pacific assigned to remove casualties from Guadalcanal. On active duty from 1942-1946, he retired from the Reserve in 1968 as a Captain in the Medical Corps. Beginning in 1970, Dr. Farr served as a member of the Advisory Committee on Naval Medical Research of the National Academy of Sciences and was a consultant to the U.S. Naval Medical Research Missions to Formosa and Taiwan. In addition to his Navy positions, Dr. Farr was a Consultant for many programs for the Atomic Energy Commission and was a member of the U.S. Delegation to the International Conference on Atomic Energy in Geneva in 1955. He was also selected in 1955 as a member of the Advisory Committee to the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission analyzing medical effects on atomic bomb victims and served as Chairman from 1955-1968. Dr. Farr received the Mead Johnson Award for research in Pediatrics in 1940, and was made an honorary member of the Medical Society of Athens and awarded the Gold Cross Order of Phoenix by Queen Frederlika of Greece in 1960 for his consulting work in nuclear medicine. The West German Republic in Bonn bestowed upon him the Order of Merit in 1963 for similar consulting work in Julich, Germany. Dr. Farr was the author of over 200 papers and articles on nuclear medicine, nuclear reactors, protein metabolism, emergency medical services, and radioactive and chemical environmental contaminants. Dr. Farr was widowed in 1984 upon the death of his wife of 48 years, Anne. He is survived by his wife of twelve years, Miriam Kirk Farr, by his children, Charles Edward Farr of Long Beach, CA, Susan Farr Armstrong of Walnut Creek, CA, and Frances Farr Torrey of Alamo, CA, by seven grandchildren, and one greatgrandchild. A memorial service will be held on Monday, July 21, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Walnut Creek, CA., at 11:00 A.M. The family prefers contributions to the Lee E. Farr M.D. Lectureship at Yale University School of Medicine, 333 Cedar Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06520.

Imagyn, based in Laguna Niguel, Calif., a maker of surgical products for gynecological disorders, said it had reviewed both offers and decided in favor of Urohealth's revised bid. His friends remembered ''Chris'''' as a person of unimpeachable character, one fiercely loyal to both family and friends. He was the proud son of the late George and Mary Meade and is survived by loving brothers and sisters, James Meade of New York City, Thomas Meade of Great Neck, Jerome Meade of Port Washington, Anne Meade of New York City, and Maria Meade of Port Washington. title: An Amber Light on Wartime Loot

The Russian Parliament overrode his veto in June, but Mr. Yeltsin has vowed to challenge the law in the Constitutional Court. Nationalists and Communists contend that the art is merely compensation for the enormous losses of Russian cultural treasures, such as the renowned Amber Room, taken from a Czarist palace by German looters, its postwar whereabouts unknown.

title: BISYS SHARES SLIDE AS BANKAMERICA ENDS BUSINESS DEAL
description: The stock of Bisys Group Inc. fell 16.6 percent yesterday after the BankAmerica Corporation's mutual fund group ended their business agreement. The loss of the contract could cut Bisys's earnings in the fiscal year that ends next June by about 15 cents a share. Analysts had estimated the company, which provides financial processing services, would earn $1.88 a share in the fiscal year. Bisys's shares dropped $6.50, to $32.625, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. The board of Pacific Horizons, the BankAmerica unit, provided no ''specific reasons'' for its decision to end the distribution and administration agreement in September, Bisys said. The contract generated about $15 million in revenue.

Mr. Clinton was in a good mood, playing hearts and reminiscing about his Arkansas days.

description: An appeals court struck down key elements of the Federal Communications Commission's rules for opening local telephone markets to competition yesterday, adding yet another obstacle to the already rocky landscape of telecommunications regulation.

description: The Army today charged its most senior enlisted soldier with sexual misconduct involving a female officer, the fifth woman to come forward since the investigation against him began in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMAN, ARTHUR L.
description: LIMAN-Arthur L. The Board of Directors and staff of the Legal Action Center mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Arthur L. Liman, mensch, mentor, warrior for justice and our founding and only Chairman. Under his dedicated leadership for 25 years, the Center has fought discrimination at every level of society on behalf of people with histories of alcohol and drug problems, AIDS and criminal records. We have benefited from his extraordinary vision and unstinting commitment to public service, and we will sorely miss his counsel, wisdom and love. All who care about civil rights and social justice have lost a great champion. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife Ellen, his children, Emily, Douglas and Lewis, his sister Gladys, and his many friends and colleagues. Peter Barton Hutt, Vice Chairman Paul Nathan Samuels, Director/ President

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Arthur L. Liman, the New York trial lawyer best known as chief counsel to the Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair, referred incompletely to accusations about a former New York City Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross. While the New York State Health Department brought charges of negligence and incompetence against Dr. Gross in 1985, the charges were dismissed five years later by the State Board of Regents, which oversees the Health Department. (The obituary also misspelled Dr. Gross's given name; it has one ''t,'' not two.)

title: First Killing May Offer Clues to Four Others
description: Just before the killings began, Andrew P. Cunanan told friends in San Diego that he was flying to Minnesota to ''settle some business'' with an old friend, Jeff Trail.

title: Authorities Sniff Out a Dump
description: Responding to complaints of an overpowering stench, authorities raided a trash-hauling company in Jersey City yesterday and found about 20 tons of restaurant scraps and other commercial garbage baking in 10 shipping containers, officials said. ''The smell was overpowering,'' said Jeffrey Jotz, a spokesman for Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive.

title: Welfare Cuts Don't Dash the Optimism of Store Owners
description: William Rodriguez and his financial backers understood the risks when they decided to reopen a supermarket on Havemeyer Street in the Southside section of Williamsburg. Welfare, which for years had accounted for the bulk of the supermarket's revenues, was being overhauled. The number of people on public assistance was shrinking, and benefits, including food stamps, were being denied to tens of thousands of legal immigrants, hundreds of whom live in the Brooklyn neighborhood. A supermarket association was reporting that business was off by 10 percent in the city as a result of the changes.

title: Gore Defends Budget Plans As a Priority
description: Criticizing ''out-of-date dogmas,'' Vice President Gore today defended the Clinton Administration's drive for a balanced budget against liberals in his party who say that strict balance is less important than investment and economic growth.

title: Drug Ring in Pizza Parlor
description: Like many fathers, prosecutors said, Giovanni Saponara wanted to train his 14-year-old son in the family business. But yesterday in Federal court, Mr. Saponara admitted that the business was a drug ring based at a Mount Laurel pizzeria.

title: Dr. Eugene Shoemaker, 69; Set Record for Finding Comets
description: Dr. Eugene Merle Shoemaker, who, with his wife, Carolyn, held a world record for the number of comets discovered, was killed yesterday in a car accident near Alice Springs, Australia. Mrs. Shoemaker suffered broken bones and was hospitalized. Dr. Shoemaker was 69 and lived in Flagstaff, Ariz.

title: In Music of the Absurd, The Comedy Has Heart
description: Dean and Gene Ween -- not brothers, and not their real names -- are on their sixth album (their fourth for a major label, Elektra) and the cult following for their escapist-absurdist songs continues to grow. But as the brains and soul of the five-man band Ween, they don't put on airs. They play who they are, or who they were when they froze in late adolescence about 10 years ago: smart high school hippies from New Hope, Pa., with no social conscience and a note-perfect ability to mimic every superhit of the 70's and 80's album ever advertised on television.

description: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said today that he had urged the guerrilla group to resume the cease-fire it abandoned last year and that he expected a positive and prompt reply.

description: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce is expected to acquire Oppenheimer & Company, the New York brokerage firm, for about $500 million within the next few days, people familiar with the proposed transaction said yesterday.

title: A Jailed Mobster Refuses To Testify in Mafia Case
description: An imprisoned mobster described by the Government as Vincent Gigante's former top lieutenant in the Mafia defiantly refused yesterday to testify as a prosecution witness against him, calling the trial a ''charade'' and referring to Mr. Gigante as ''a mental case.''

title: Unlike Other Fashion Houses, Versace Should Survive Its Founder
description: In the fashion industry, perhaps more than in any other business, the survival of a company often rests heavily on the shoulders of a single individual. Yet for most prominent fashion designers, their ambition is to create something so distinctive, so much the trademark of a single mind, that it is almost blasphemy to talk about designating a successor.

title: Move to Rhode Island Slated
description: The owners of a chemical plant in Lodi where five workers were killed in a 1995 chemical explosion plan to move its manufacturing operations to Rhode Island, officials said yesterday.

title: Robert Bosch to Buy Stake in Zexel of Japan
description: Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Germany said yesterday that it would buy a 16.26 percent stake in the Zexel Corporation, a Japanese auto parts maker, from Isuzu Motors Ltd. for 28.8 billion yen, or $248 million. The acquisition of 40 million shares will make Bosch the largest shareholder in Zexel, with a 30.1 percent stake. Isuzu will retain a 4.2 percent interest.

title: For Episcopalians, Debate on Women
description: When the Episcopal Church began a 10-day meeting of the General Convention, its top legislative body, in Philadelphia on Wednesday, its leaders gathered as a church where women are ever more visible. Seven women now sit among the church's 200 bishops; there were none a decade ago. About 12 percent of 11,000 Episcopal priests are female.

description: The house at 1114 Monroe Avenue in Asbury Park has boarded-up windows and a cracked, crooked chimney. It sold last year for $13,500, considerably less than its assessed value of $52,100.

title: WHX AGREES TO SUPPORT MERGER OF CTS AND DYNAMICS
description: The WHX Corporation has agreed to support the merger of the CTS Corporation and the Dynamics Corporation of America after CTS amended its offer. CTS's amended offer would give Dynamics' shareholders the option of receiving either 0.88 CTS share or $58 cash for each Dynamics share held. WHX owns a 13.5 percent interest in Dynamics. Last month, CTS, an electronics-components maker, offered $56.25 a share for as much as 49.99 percent of Dynamics, also an electronics-components maker, and 0.88 CTS share for each remaining Dynamics share. The CTS bid topped a rival, hostile $56-a-share bid by WHX, based in New York. WHX, the holding company for the steelmaker the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation, began its hostile pursuit of Dynamics in March.

title: Sinbad Cancellations
description: Two presentations of Sinbad's Soul Music Festival, at the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Aug. 2 and at the Jones Beach Theater on Aug. 3, have been canceled because of scheduling conflicts. The concerts, featuring Earth, Wind and Fire, will not be rescheduled. Refunds are available at the point of purchase. Information: (212) 307-7171.

In a separate statement, HFS said it had terminated discussions about the acquisition of Signature.

title: Yankees' Dismal Showing Is No Gift
description: The fifth inning kept getting uglier and uglier for the Yankees. Luis Sojo made an errant throw; Charlie Hayes did not fully pursue a grounder, and Derek Jeter then kicked it; the umpires napped, and a befuddled Dwight Gooden tried to navigate through the minefield. It was difficult for Joe Torre to watch the display on his 57th birthday.

description: MJichele Redman has been in this position before: leading a Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour event after the early rounds.

title: ARCH COAL PLANS CHARGES AGAINST EARNINGS
description: Arch Coal Inc. said yesterday that it would take unspecified charges against third-quarter earnings for severance expenses and the cost of writing down duplicate assets from its recently completed merger. Arch Coal was formed from the July 1 stock swap combination of Ashland Coal Inc. and the closely held Arch Mineral Corporation. The combined entity has $1.7 billion in assets and more than 2 billion tons of coal reserves.

title: Summer Storms Sweep Region; 3 People Dead
description: Severe thunderstorms flashed across the metropolitan region yesterday, knocking down power lines and uprooting trees in bursts of high winds, rain and lightning that left three people dead and provided a violent and disruptive finale to the first heat wave of the summer.

title: Missing Test Bullets Snag Move For New Trial in Dr. King Case
description: After a week of searching, prosecutors said today that they had still not found the bullets fired 29 years ago in Federal Bureau of Investigation tests of the rifle they believe was used by James Earl Ray to assassinate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Giuliani's campaign has a helpful suggestion for supporters who have given the maximum contribution to his campaign and are seeking ways to impress him further with their generosity. Caso, and his brothers, Louis J. Milone and John E. Milone. His brothers, Dominick R. Milone and Joseph R. Milone, predeceased him. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 11 AM, at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Entombment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Salvatore A. Milone Scholarship Fund at Molloy College.

title: Contracts Winding Up As the Giants Hit Camp
description: The Giants welcomed veterans and rookies to training camp today, the players gathering in parking lots to compare new cars, new hairstyles, or, in some cases, new waistlines. Team officials then held meetings and counted heads. There were no surprises.

title: Et Tu, Bill?

Less than three years ago, Speaker Newt Gingrich's promise to change Washington forever made him the hero of the Republican majority and particularly the fire-breathing ideologues who made up the G.O.P. class of '94. But between 1994 and 1997, Mr. Gingrich managed to make himself as unpopular with fellow Republicans as he has become with the American people.

title: What The Mir Can Still Teach Us

Critics of American involvement in the Russian space station see this latest series of troubles -- starting with the serious damage caused by a collision with a cargo ship on June 25 -- as reason for getting the American astronaut on the Mir home safely and then bringing the project to an honorable end.

This year, someone shot an arrow right between his smiling eyes. For weeks it stuck there, like an emblem of the backlash over lawyer advertising that has divided the legal community here and across the country.

title: Blips of Pain and Hope, Humorously Monitored
description: With her girlish voice and spiffy melodies, Jill Sobule leads listeners to expect cheerful, unassuming pop. But her light touch is a subterfuge. A blithe waltz asks, ''Would you hide me in your attic?,'' while the title song of her new album, ''Happy Town'' (Lava/Atlantic), is a buoyant piece of lounge-pop that ponders whether Prozac-drugged contentment is better than despair and joy. Ms. Sobule, who performed at the Bottom Line on Wednesday night on an Intel Music Festival quadruple bill, knows that simplicity and innocence are not the same.

title: With Prado's Mild Face Lift, The Rain in Spain Stays Out

title: Corrections

The company is selling its engineered composite business, which makes products like exterior body panels for cars and trucks; it is keeping its business of making conveyor and power transmission belts, air springs, hose, molded rubber and transportation replacement products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTTON, MARIDEAN WATT
description: HUTTON-Maridean Watt, of New York City, died in Edina, MN, on July 13, 1997. Survived by mother Christine Watt and sister Carolyn Reynolds. Meridean taught art in Yonkers, NY. In recent years she created a program for children at the Museum of American Folk Art in NYC. Memorial service to be held at the Cremation Society of MN, Edina Chapel at 2 PM, July 26th. Memorials preferred to the Museum of American Folk Art in New York City.

title: Carl Maxey, 73, Spokane Civil Rights Lawyer
description: Carl Maxey, a scrappy civil rights lawyer credited with virtually singlehandedly desegregating much of the inland Northwest, took his life on Thursday, the police said in Spokane, Wash., where he had long been known as the city's leading criminal defense attorney and a pre-eminent civic leader. He was 73.

title: Jennifer Scott, Timothy Lukens
description: Jennifer Walker Scott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Scott of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Timothy Eric Lukens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Lukens of Chevy Chase. The Rev. William D. Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Church in Truro, Mass. The Venerable Gerard C. Sharp, an Anglican archdeacon in Johannesburg, participated in the ceremony.

title: As Messinger Turns Cool on Dr. Crew, the Mayor Tries Warm
description: Ruth W. Messinger went to a public school on Staten Island last Sunday to assail Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's education record. In the process, she offered a lukewarm assessment of the Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew: She could work with him, Ms. Messinger said, but was not prepared to say she wanted him to stick around if she wins.

title: Swimmers Brave the Hudson in 16th Marathon
description: Shortly after daybreak in yesterday's brisk morning wind, 22 swimmers, their bodies slicked with lanolin and Vaseline, slipped into the 68-degree water of the Hudson River. And as their heads bobbed up and down, the bullhorn sounded and the clock began to tick.

title: Corrections

title: Mir's Crew Waits in Space For Reinforcements
description: First a collision damages a module. Then an astronaut unplugs the wrong cable, casting the space station adrift. So last week the crew of Russia's Mir was told to stand down. With so much awry and so much at stake, with nerves frayed and reserves depleted, the Russian Space Agency's chief physician prescribed rest. The decision will delay for at least the third time a repair mission to reconnect three vital solar panels.

title: Preaching Moderation On Her Own Side of the Aisle
description: Representative Marge Roukema abruptly stopped complaining about the ''disgraceful'' way her party recently held up disaster relief for flood victims and jumped to her feet, hollering at the television screen in her office.

title: Plenty Of Room For One
description: LOTS of people travel alone. The Travel Industry Association of America said that 26 percent of the 224.6 million trips Americans took last summer were made by adults on their own, and this number has been pretty steady for the last few years. But when asked ahead of time about their plans for the longest trip of the 1996 summer, travelers indicated that they thought only 4 percent of these trips would be taken solo. This big gap between plans and reality, according to Dexter C. Koehl, spokesman for the Travel Industry Association, could partly be explained by a reluctance to acknowledge the fact of traveling alone.

title: She Cannot Walk, Yet She Can Dance
description: KITTY LUNN SWAYS, EXECUTING A wheelchair pirouette. She turns the wheels with gestures that are part of the dance. When on the floor, she bends an outstretched leg with a swift movement of her hands, seeming to dance with her whole body.

title: A Neighborhood Was Jarred By Cries of 'the Mute Ones'
description: In the neighborhood they were known as los muditos, the mute ones: industrious young people who left the house at dawn and did not return until after midnight.

title: New Equipment Will Measure Just How Much the Surf Is Up
description: By next summer, equipment will be placed on New Jersey beaches that will enable scientists to study beach erosion patterns, allow emergency management personnel to plan for evacuations during coastal storms and let people use the Internet to see what the waves look like.

title: Michelin Turns to Asia With Guide to Thailand
description: Michelin has published a Green Guide to Thailand, its first venture into Asian travel. The 295-page book uses the Michelin system of rating sights as ''interesting'' (one star), ''highly recommended'' (two stars) and ''very highly recommended'' (three stars), and covers the present capital, Bangkok, and the ancient capitals of Sukhothai and Ayutthaya, along with the country's mountains, beaches and islands. The price is $20.

description: In my youthful ignorance, I assumed Rosenblum would present a story of shared vanilla ice cream and discussions about regularity, culminating in a peck on the lips.

title: In the Cauldron of Competition, Moments of Growth and Grace
description: Sooner or later, I knew I would have to compete in a golf tournament, graduating from my regular friendly Saturday rounds to edgier situations. Being able to handle competition was supposed to be a sign of making progress, and the bulletin board at our club flowered each season with tempting flyers announcing scores of interclub and other local matches I had always ignored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOORHEES, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: VOORHEES-Edward Joseph. Of Seaford on July 18, 1997. Captain, U.S. Air Force, World War II, 72nd Bomber Squadron. title: A Holiday in Bali
description: It is a spring evening in Bali. My husband and I are seated on cushions at a low table, sipping cold mango drinks. The sound of gamelan music is drifting toward us from one of the small lighted homes that seem almost suspended in the reflection of the still water of the rice paddies that stretch out in front of us. Our 5-year-old has long since passed out on the cushions, and the waiters come and go almost silently, avoiding her sprawl, with no expression of irritation.

title: Stir-Frying Sugar Snap Peas, the Ultimate in Convenience
description: SUGAR SNAP PEAS, in season at farms throughout the region, may be the ultimate convenience vegetable. They are good raw, as a snack or with a dip. Cooking them takes a simple stir-fry and a few seasonings tossed in a skillet.

title: Treating Child Obesity: From Healthy Eating to Working Out

From the time he arrived at the bus stop, the comments would start: ''Hey, dough boy!'' ''You're so fat, your sneakers are bulging out.'' ''Look what fat Mike is wearing today.''

title: A Walt Whitman Sampler, From Churchly to Sensuous
description: A MYSTIC, A MODERNIST, A radical liberationist, a joyous narcissist, an Aquarian prophet, the Bard of Democracy: Walt Whitman could perhaps be accused of overreaching. Yet for Whitman enthusiasts, the great poet pulled it all off, and then some. Just ask the esteemed American baritone Thomas Hampson, a perceptive reader of Whitman.

description: WHEN the composer and lyricist Jerry Herman wrote ''I'll Be Here Tomorrow'' for the 1979 musical ''The Grand Tour,'' he could not have imagined that an upbeat show tune would turn into a personal anthem.

description: During the second quarter of this year, Microsoft's stock leaped from just over $90 a share to $126, and by last week the price had moved past $150 a share. Investors could not get enough of the stock.

title: Military College Awaits Its First Female Cadets
description: For years, the grand statues of the school's most acclaimed sons, Stonewall Jackson and George C. Marshall, have stood vigil over campus grounds, silent witnesses to the annual reruns of tradition born 158 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMAN, ARTHUR L.
description: LIMAN-Arthur L. The officers, leadership, and staff of UJAFederation of New York mourn the passing of Arthur Liman, a giant in the New York legal world. He and his wife, Ellen, have long been devoted friends & generous supporters of UJA-Federation, and leaders in the New York community. A partner in the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison, he ensured that the firm would provide philanthropic leadership. Mr. Liman, a recipient of the Proskauer Award of the Lawyers Division, improved countless lives through his generosity, relentless pursuit of justice, and steadfast support for public service. His late brother-in-law, James H. Fogelson, was also an exceptional leader of UJA-Federation's Lawyer's Division, which established the James H. Fogelson Young Leadership Award in his memory in 1992 and awarded him the Proskauer Award posthumously. We extend our deep sympathies to his wife, Ellen; his children:, Emily, Douglas, and Lewis; his sister, Gladys Phillips; and the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Laurence Greenwald, Chair, Lawyers Division Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Despite Consolidations, There's Room for Many Funds
description: BIG institutions with big money are doing a lot of talking about getting into the mutual fund business. Among the recent spate of splashy, headline-grabbing deals was last month's agreement by the Zurich Group, Switzerland's biggest insurance company, to purchase Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the old-line fund management company. Other deals are also in the works, as big banks like J. P. Morgan negotiate to buy stakes in fund companies like American Century Investments of Kansas City, Mo.

title: In 'Contact,' Science and Fiction Nudge Close Together
description: WHAT IS ELMER FUDD doing in a serious movie about astronomers and the search for extraterrestrial life? The answer is revealing of the attention to small details that gives the new movie ''Contact'' the texture of authenticity when it comes to science. Perhaps only a handful of astronomers caught the in-joke, but it reassured them that the filmmakers had done their homework.

description: I think it is time we did something positive with our collective war stories, rather than use them only for catharsis. We need to push for prevention, not just cure. No one can tell us positively why we contracted the disease and what we should do to prevent its recurrence. I accept that preventive measures may not be available in the remainder of my life, but I hope that they will be there for my granddaughters.

description: A day after storms thrashed the metropolitan region, killing three men, causing power failures and delaying dozens of trains, service had been restored to all railroad lines yesterday, but thousands of homes in New Jersey and on Long Island were still without electricity.

title: White House Is Cool to Republican Compromise on Tax-Cut Bill
description: Republican leaders made their first substantive proposal to the Clinton Administration for a compromise tax-cutting bill late on Friday, but officials involved in the talks said today that it drew a chilly response from the White House and that the negotiations were in danger of deadlocking.

title: The Riady Breach
description: Much still remains unknown about the Riady family of Indonesia, its links to China and its involvement in Bill Clinton's 1996 Presidential campaign. But more than enough information has now been assembled by Senate investigators to see that the Riady role in the campaign is a case study in the uncontrolled uses of tainted money in American politics. Anyone who doubts the urgent need to tighten campaign finance laws, especially those governing ''soft money'' donations to party organizations, need only look closely at the Riady example.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, ROBERT

His knowledge and understanding of public policy at all levels of government inspired our faculty and students. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, Dean

title: Two Tales of Once-Great Expectations
description: THE LAST TIME PUBLIC TELEVISION broadcast a documentary addressing black-Jewish relations, it offered a story of rescue and redemption that proved, quite literally, too good to be true. That 1992 film, ''The Liberators: Fighting on Two Fronts in World War II,'' purported to show how an all-black tank battalion freed Jews from the Nazi death camps at Dachau and Buchenwald. Several months after a celebrated premiere, the film was unmasked as fallacious, and in an ironic way became a monument to the desperation in some quarters for a myth of common cause between blacks and Jews to displace the reality of bitter division.

description: Zane Klein, general counsel of Guardsmark Inc., a Memphis-based national security and investigative service, died on June 27 after collapsing in his office in Memphis. He was 60 and had lived in Memphis since moving from Manhattan in 1993.

title: For Some Hispanic Immigrants, a Sense of Kinship With the Silent Laborers
description: THEY come from dust-blown villages and jam-packed cities, young men barely old enough to work up a decent lather on their wispy mustaches, all drawn by the lure of the American dollar. They blend into neighborhoods like Jackson Heights, where waves of Latin immigration have made the commercial strips look like an entrepreneurial outpost of the Organization of American States.

title: Black and White Together At Warmbaths Primary
description: It's a searing, humid february morning on the playing fields of Warmbaths Primary School, in the conservative Afrikaner heartland. A wire fence separates the neatly mown fields from the encroaching acacia-bush veld beyond. The fields are festooned with bunting, and temporary bleachers have been erected down one side. Scratchy sakkie-sakkie (Afrikaner folk music) warbles from the P.A. system. Schoolchildren sit on the bleachers and shout out war cries as their teams compete in various track and field events, supervised by teachers dressed in white. Behind the stands, P.T.A. moms sell doughnuts and hot dogs. The town's leading businessmen are on hand to present trophies. Events like this have been mainstays of country life in South Africa for decades.

title: Graham and Others Having Difficult Time Following Changes
description: Kent Graham has had a busy past few months preparing to take over the Arizona Cardinals' starting quarterback job, but he could not help but notice all of the changes that have taken place in the National Football League.

title: A Gathering of Youthful Achievers: The Best and the Brightest
description: ANYONE intimidated by the best and the brightest might have felt at least vaguely uncomfortable at the Rye Town Hilton last weekend. The hotel was the site of the Northeast Region Senior Conference of Inroads, an organization for high-achieving black, Hispanic, American Indian and Asian high school and college students who also have jobs at major corporations. Ambitious, articulate and full of youthful enthusiasm, they were living examples of how to make a good impression.

title: Laid Low by the Dog Days
description: One hundred summers ago, The Hartford Courant summed up what was no doubt a sweaty, sweltering summer with a line for all seasons: ''Everybody talks about the weather, but nobody does anything about it.'' As thermometers in the Northeast climbed into 90-degree territory every day last week, it became clear that part of that much-quoted sentence is now wrong: people no longer talk about the weather, they argue about it. Or, more precisely, about how to beat it. To run the air conditioner, or not?

title: The World Resurrects Che
description: Thirty years after his assassination in the Bolivian mountains, Ernesto (Che) Guevara has captured the public fancy in ways he never intended. At least three biographies and several movies about Che will come out this year. The silk-screen Che icon with beard and beret now hawks compact discs, beer, Swatch watches, skis, designer dresses and a host of other products not traditionally associated with international Communism. Scientists have now found his body, one of seven skeletons in a pit in Bolivia, and brought it to Cuba.
