description: ABOUT a year ago, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Matluck went house hunting. ''We saw a six-bedroom Colonial that we liked tremendously,'' Mr. Matluck said. ''It was 20 years old, set on an acre on a nice street in Chappaqua. However, it was too expensive.''

title: Personal Perspective On the Sound
description: FROM the observation tower at the Connecticut Audubon Society's coastal center at Milford Point, Mary Parker Buckles, author of nature books, pointed out a small, weathered wooden platform barely visible about a half mile west down the barrier beach. ''That's where I wrote the shorebirds section of my book,'' she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, DR. NORMAN L., DDS.
description: ROSNER-Dr. Norman L., DDS. 80, of Tamarac, Florida, passed away on July 10, 1997. Dr. Rosner was born in New York City in 1917. He was a 1938 graduate of NYU and of the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery in 1942. Dr. Rosner served four and a half years during World War II as a Captain in the army. He practiced in New York City for over 35 years. He was a husband to Roz; a father of Ken, and predeased by his daughter Barbra; a grandfather of Paul, Jed, Season, Jaden, Scott and Kyle; and a great-grandfather of Zoe and Noah.

title: No-Nonsense Judge And Tough Guy, Fight Ref Mills Lane Takes No Guff
description: He sold the shirt. A collector from Canada, with a wad of bills, actually asked to buy his shoes first, but the shoes fit like slippers and, no, they weren't for sale, no way, no how. The shirt, though, the shirt was negotiable. ''I'll give you $200 for it,'' the Canadian said, and the most recognizable referee on Earth, Mills Lane, looked at his watch -- T-minus one hour to Tyson-Holyfield -- and said, ''O.K., deal.''

title: In Clinton, Monday Night Is the Jazziest Night of the Week
description: CAN low-down bluesy beer-basted live jazz flourish around the new family-oriented Times Square? It's not quite 52d Street yet, but on Mondays the ghost of Cannonball Adderley smiles down on the neighborhood as many local musicians make the rounds of a new generation of clubs.

title: Fostering Pride in Public Housing
description: MOST of the preoccupied commuters or shoppers who drive into downtown here scarcely notice the public housing complexes and their residents, which flank the gateway to the city.

title: Dressed in Memoriam
description: New Yorkers wore their favorite Versace designs this past week as a tribute to the designer, who was slain last Tuesday in Miami Beach. Some dressed in his personal favorite of all black. Others remembered his life and talent by wearing what many consider to be his most successful work, his exotic prints. Alice Ann Nash, silhouetted at right, is a passionate Versace collector, with clothes that date back 27 years to when he worked for Complice. Ms. Nash, an interior decorator, owns racks of archival Versace clothes, scarfs, belts, bags, jewelry and shoes, as well as several dozen signature pillows and china. Her three cats dine off Versace plates. A young man, below, in a silver Versace shirt, was one of many who stopped to sign a condolence book at the Fifth Avenue Versace store. Mauro Maccioni, top left, a partner in the restaurant Circo, wore a Versace tie, his favorite, printed with commedia dell'arte acrobats.

title: Paying the V.A.T.
description: To the Editor: It was too bad that I did not read Betsy Wade's column ''Getting V.A.T. Back, at a Price'' (June 22) before a recent trip to Europe. But I have a warning to add.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A FINAL SHOW

title: A New Actor in the Treasure House
description: JOHN McDONOUGH still lives in the same sturdy Colonial-style farmhouse in Bloomfield where he grew up, watching one of his television idols, Captain Kangaroo, every morning.

title: A Separate Peace
description: EGYPT'S ROAD

title: Sir James Goldsmith, Financier, Dies at 64
description: Sir James Goldsmith, a flamboyant British-French financier who maintained three families, homes in four countries and used his billions to fight the European Union, died Friday in Spain, a spokesman said. He was 64.

title: Hot Rocks
description: Volcanoes

title: Robin Howe, Andrew Grossman
description: Robin Eve Howe and Andrew Grossman, executives at women's clothing companies in New York, were married yesterday at their home in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: A Serious Chef, an Elaborate Bill of Fare
description: THE Restaurant at National Hall in Westport has essentially the same decor and staff, as well as a similar menu, as when it was Restaurant Zanghi. The inspired Nicola Zanghi is gone, however, and his sous chef, William Lopata, is now at the helm.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Cattle Car

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIBRUNN, EDYTH WOLFF
description: MAIBRUNN-Edyth Wolff. July 18, 1997. Wife of the late Edwin Maibrunn and Arthur Wolff. Mother of Harry Wolff and Patricia Gross. Grandmother of six and greatgrandmother of two. Contributions may be made to: Eric S. Gross Library, Yale University, Psychiatry Department, 25 Park Street, New Haven, CT, 06519.

title: Come Back, Five-and-Dime
description: For every generation since its inception, Woolworth stores had a place. At the end of the last century, they offered discount boot blacking, school straps and tin pepper boxes. In the teens, its New York City skyscraper symbolized a nation's growth. During the 60's, its lunch counters meant more than an ice-cream soda to blacks who fought to sit at them.

title: A Cathedral for a Queens Congregation
description: Parishioners who have been attending Sunday services in three shifts in their 800-seat church school auditorium will gather next Sunday to inaugurate the $23-million, 2,500-seat Cathedral of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens. The 93,000-square-foot church complex at 110-31 Merrick Boulevard will not only provide needed seating capacity for the 8,600-member, 163-year-old congregation, but will offer community facilities including an 8,500-square-foot fellowship hall where 800 people can dine, and church offices. In addition to the 19,000-square-foot sanctuary, there will be a chapel seating 150.

title: I Guess He's Still on Break
description: He is the phantom employee: Someone in the office who routinely comes in, turns on the computer, drapes a jacket over the back of the chair and then vanishes, leaving everyone else to do the work (or not). Is this your boss, or a co-worker? Did he get his royal comeuppance? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Janice Horowitz, R. M. Bookstaber
description: Janice M. Horowitz, a reporter at Time magazine in New York, is to be married today to Richard M. Bookstaber, a managing director and the global risk manager at Salomon Brothers, the New York investment bank. Rabbi Simkha Y. Weintraub is to perform the ceremony at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: For Sex Shops, the Side of the Street Makes a Difference
description: Days may be numbered for the ''purple palace,'' as some neighbors call Warehouse on the Block, the fuschia-colored, X-rated video shop on Third Avenue.

title: Housing Drives Service Members to Poverty
description: On a recent morning, Casey Williams fell in with the tide as tens of thousands of Mexicans crossed the border here on their way to jobs in San Diego. He carried a green duffel bag, standard United States military issue, which advertised clear as the desert sky who he was: an American sailor on his daily commute to work from his home in Mexico.

title: Man's Face Burned During Bronx Robbery
description: A 34-year old Bronx man suffered second-degree burns across his face yesterday morning after four robbers pushed their way into his home, demanded money and pressed a hot knife against his skin as his wife and 18-month-old child looked on, the police said.

title: Free Concerts Focus On the Pipe Organ
description: RECENTLY the Hartt School of Music in West Hartford sponsored a weeklong series of ''Explorations in Choral Artistry,'' and now Wesleyan University has embarked on a ''Pipe Organ Encounter,'' with high school students spending a week on campus in intensive coaching and workshop sessions. Also included are six concerts, all of them open to the public without charge.

title: A Wall St. Wallflower Is Starting to Dance
description: MARY GORDON remembers sitting on a panel at a recent investment conference about a multibillion-dollar industry -- and the speakers almost outnumbered the audience.

title: East Meets Beethoven, Cheerily
description: SONY CLASSICAL WAS obviously thinking ahead: although Tan Dun's 72-minute ''Symphony 1997'' was composed to commemorate the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule and had its first concert performance there on July 1, Sony recorded the work a few months early and rushed out an ornately packaged CD (SK 63368), with notes in English and Chinese, within days of the reunification. Yo-Yo Ma is the cello soloist, and Mr. Tan conducts the Hong Kong Philharmonic and other performers.

title: After 25 Years, a Once-Promising Golfer Resurrects His Game
description: SOON after he began swinging a golf club at age 10, Harry Hurt 3d won more than 20 competitions in and around his hometown of Houston. By the time he was 18, he was the No. 1 man on the Harvard University freshman golf team and on the fast track toward a lucrative golfing career. Then he jumped off the train.

title: Paying the V.A.T.
description: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler on V.A.T. left out one of the hidden costs of foreign value-added taxes: United States Customs duty.

title: Daniel Sargent, 72, a Director at Salomon Bros.
description: Daniel I. Sargent, the founder of the corporate finance department of Salomon Brothers and later a managing director of the firm as well as the head of its credit and business practice committee, died on Thursday at his home in North Salem, N.Y.

title: Warning: These Numbers May Depress You
description: FORBES published its annual list of global billionaires last Monday, and in a single year Bill Gates, the world's richest businessman, more than doubled his wealth, to $36.4 billion. But even with a July 28 cover date, the magazine was already out of date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAUNITZ, WILLIAM J.
description: CAUNITZ-William J. July 20, 1996 My darling husband Bill, remembered with love, always. Pat

title: New Hampshire Victory In 1747 to Be Marked
description: Three days of festivities and historical re-enactments next weekend will mark the 250th anniversary of the siege of the Fort at No. 4 in Charlestown, N.H. During the Siege of 1747, the British repulsed an attack by the French and Indians, an event to be commemorated from July 25 to 27.

title: Correction
description: A report on the Playing in the Neighborhood page last Sunday about tours of Central Park misidentified the location pictured. It was Bethesda Terrace, not the Bow Bridge.

title: Stephanie Schaaf and David Balsley
description: Stephanie Winslow Schaaf, a daughter of Mary V. Kearns of Ridgewood, N.J., and Bradford Schaaf of Chatham, Mass., was married Friday to David Robert Balsley, the son of the Rev. Dennie Carcelli of Seattle and Robert E. Balsley of Issaquah, Wash. The Rev. Janice Garrett, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony in the main chapel at the Presidio, the former Army base, in San Francisco.

title: Found at Sea
description: BLACK JACKS African American Seamen in the Age of Sail. By W. Jeffrey Bolster. Illustrated. 310 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $27.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Partners

title: Korean Funeral Farce At Asian Film Festival
description: NOW in its 20th year, the Asian American International Film Festival opened on Friday in Manhattan, and there is still time to catch most of the films because the festival continues through Aug. 10 in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Madcap Bad Boy of Contemporary German Art
description: WHEN THE GERMAN ARTIST Martin Kippenberger died in March, at the age of 43, he seemed to have left no esthetic stone unturned. Nor had he run out of things to do. These slightly contradictory impressions converge in Kippenberger's sprawling retrospective at the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, a lively new museum in Geneva that seems destined to give the city a more prominent position on the contemporary art map.

title: Red-Hot Sorenstam In Range Of Redman
description: Annika Sorenstam's golf game is back on track after she failed to make the cut last week in her attempt to capture a third consecutive United States Women's Open title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILES, PETER JOHN DE LA FOSSE
description: WILES-Peter John de la Fosse. Died July 11, 1997, peacefully at home. Beloved husband of Carolyn. Emeritus Professor of Sovietological Studies, London School of Economics 1965-1985. Professor, Brandeis University, Massachusetts 1960-1963. Visiting Professor, Columbia University, New York 1958. Fellow, New College Oxford 1948-1960.

title: The Stephens 'Drop'
description: A ''drop,'' in spookspeak, is a clandestine place to deposit and receive documents. A ''dead drop'' can be a hole in a tree; an ordinary drop can be an office or friend's house where an operative can leave or pick up data without the knowledge of employer or family.

title: High Note in Prague for the Children's Aid Society Chorus
description: The Sullivan Street home of the Children's Aid Society Chorus has a new bauble: a shiny silver trophy representing the chorus's recent second-place finish in the Prague International Choir Festival and Competition.

title: Clothing to Shield Against Tick Bites
description: DR. ANNEMARIE MANGIAMELI and her husband, Dr. Richard Lipari, were thrilled to discover a nature sanctuary behind the house they bought here in 1995. Their yard allowed ample room for a jungle gym and gardens, and a horse trail separated their property from their neighbors, rounding out their dream of a country environment for their family.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a bookbinding shop in Jefferson Township referred incorrectly to the work done on some book spines and the function of the shop's Linotype machine. Workers cut smooth edges on the spines of textbooks, not those of rare volumes. The machine molds the lettering used for gold embossing; the embossing itself is done on a separate machine.

title: Plants to Gladden the Eye of a Sphinx in the Desert
description: Add humus to hold moisture, manure for richness. Double-dig the bed, discarding the ''bottom spit,'' that near-subsoil stratum lurking below whatever the topsoil is. Yada yada yada -- do everything the good garden book says. Every time you start a new garden where there hasn't been one before, it's the same all over again.

title: Are Grateful Dead Festivals Really For the Family?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bosnia's Peace Dividend: Hatred for Everyone
description: NATIONALISM, far from being on the wane as one might expect following the end of the war in Bosnia, is far more entrenched and insidious than it was when the conflict started.

title: For a Choreographer, a Chance to Leap Out of Debt
description: FOR more than 20 years, Elizabeth Streb sweated out a living as a dancer and a choreographer. Then, in a twinkling, things changed: she learned in June that she had won a MacArthur Foundation award, or ''genius grant,'' and would receive a total of $290,000 over the next five years.

title: Stained Glass at the Speed Of, Er, Light
description: As a teen-ager, Patrick Clark, an American growing up in Vienna, chanced upon a piece of old stained glass in the ruined ballroom of an abandoned Austrian villa. Ever since, Mr. Clark said, he has been fascinated by stained glass, even hanging stained-glass panels in his college dormitory room.

title: No Headline
description: ''Atlanta was full of itself even before the Games. Atlanta is like an egotistical guy. His pants may be a little shorter than they should be, and he may be balding a little on top, but he has not lost one bit of his swagger.''

title: Tuscan Class
description: To the Editor: I would like to thank the Travel section for alerting me to a vacation that turned out to be personally enriching. On July 21, 1996, the Travel Advisory column told about a weeklong series of workshops of landscape painting in Tuscany (''Learning to Paint the Tuscan Landscape''). I decided to revive an interest in art that I had not pursued since high school, many years ago.

title: UNFRIENDLY FIRE
description: On Friday the 13th last month, Alma Arthurs of Lincoln, New Brunswick, was at home with her husband when hundreds of gallons of a sticky reddish-brown substance fell from the heavens, covering their modest house from roof to ground. The odor of the stuff - bad - convinced the Arthurs that a passing jet had dumped its waste ballasts, but they've been unable to get anyone to admit it. ''We tested it for fecal coliform, and there was none,'' says Ray Mather, an investigator with Environment New Brunswick, a Canadian provincial agency. The Arthurs have continued to point angry fingers at nearby Frederiction Airport, but Alvin Munn, the manager there, refuses to take the rap. ''Every time something falls from the sky, people blame the airplanes,'' he says. ''Things do become airborne, you know. It could be something launched or whatever.'' Like what? ''It's mysterious. But these things happen.''

title: Man Arrested In One Killing; Serial Suspect Is Still at Large
description: Police officials said today that they had made an arrest in the killing of a local doctor and that the slaying had nothing to do with the killing two days earlier of the fashion designer Gianni Versace.

title: When You Are What You Ride
description: RIDERS of Harley-Davidsons include blacks, whites, Orientals and most other categorizations on the census form. They may be high school dropouts or Ph.D.'s, con artists or matinee idols, ex-convicts or investment bankers. But whatever their backgrounds or bank accounts, they tend to dress, ride and act much alike.

title: When a Benchmark Gets a New Bench
description: MANY people compare their investment returns with those of the Dow Jones industrial average or other benchmark index. What is sometimes difficult for these investors to remember is that the indexes themselves are occasionally rejiggered -- and when they are, their returns can be sharply affected.

title: Terra Cotta Magic With a Polychromed Interior
description: THE 1922 American Encaustic Tile Company building at 16 East 41st Street was a virtuoso rendition of the tilemaker's art -- until it was drastically altered in 1993, despite protests, for a pizza restaurant.

title: A Year of Performances In One Night at NJPAC
description: Call it an overture for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center's first season.

title: Mala Yee and Sham Mosher
description: WHEN they met as students at Brown University, Sham Mosher and Mala Yee instantly disliked each other. ''I thought he was a flaky artist and he thought I was no fun,'' she recalled.

title: Order His Rare and Well Marbled
description: Swimmers take note. The mythic terror of the deep, famous for its razor-sharp teeth, its starring role in ''Jaws'' and its power to scare beachgoers, is actually a fussy eater that may find humans unappetizing.

title: 35 and Mortal: A Breast Cancer Diary
description: No matter what stage of disease or type of surgery, the bottom line is the diagnosis is cancer. Cancer is still a very scary word. Fear of recurrence is always an issue, but it does lessen with time. Orenstein's article offers useful tools to those living with cancer: keep a journal; talk to others with the disease; attend group support sessions; assess the stress in your life; express your fears; be resourceful and become informed, active partners with your health-care team; move on with your life.

title: Cambodia's Bureaucracy of Death: Reams of Evidence in Search of a Trial
description: THERE were still bloodstains on the floors of the Tuol Sleng torture chamber when a handful of scholars discovered in its back rooms a huge, meticulously kept archive of what has come to be known as Cambodia's ''bureaucracy of death.''

title: New Magazine Has Feel of Warhol
description: Longtime friends Peter Halley, a painter, and Bob Nickas, who organized shows for galleries and museums, have always loved magazines and were fans of Andy Warhol's original Interview magazine. So it is not too surprising that they decided to team up to publish their own magazine, deciding somewhat randomly on the name Index. They published their first issue a year and a half ago.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on page 32 of The Times Magazine today, about an integrated primary school in South Africa named Warmbaths, contains quotations from Tom Beukes, a retired headmaster of the school. On July 9, after the article had gone to press, Mr. Beukes was killed in the convenience store he purchased after his retirement. South African authorities are investigating the murder, which they are calling an assassination.

title: Cooking Up a Quagmire
description: DERELICTION OF DUTY

title: Since 1971, a Poll Just for New Jersey
description: IN 1971, John Blydenburgh, a professor of government at Rutgers University, got a $20,000 grant from the Fund for New Jersey and started a statewide poll called the New Jersey Poll, which eventually became known as the Eagleton Poll.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER WEST SIDE

title: Residents Want Cars Out of Prospect Park
description: For Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the famed 19th-century park designers, the key to creating tranquil refuges from urban crowds and congestion was to separate man, horse and carriage. In Central and Prospect Parks, they meticulously planned and built gently winding pedestrian walkways, bridle paths and carriage drives that were completely separate from one another.

title: Troubled Archive
description: It is widely considered to be the most valuable collection of civil rights documents in existence, a treasure trove for students of Southern history in the 1950's and 60's. But the King Center in Atlanta, the financially strapped institute run by the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., seems to have decided it can no longer afford to maintain the archive, which is accessible to outsiders only on rare occasions.

title: Hotel Offers Course For Off-Road Drivers
description: For thrill-seeking vacationers, the Equinox in Manchester, Vt., is offering a chance to put a Land Rover through its paces across rugged Green Mountain terrain. Modeled after a similar program in Great Britain, the hotel's Land Rover Driving School, which opened April 19, offers group and private lessons from one hour to a full day in school-owned Land Rovers, with a maximum of three guests in a vehicle, plus instructor. All drivers must show a valid license and proof of insurance.

title: Islanders Bid Is Possible
description: Bob Gutkowski, the president of the Marquee Group, is trying to assemble a group composed primarily of Long Island investors to buy the Islanders.

title: Veto Aids a 'Dollar Van' Line
description: Brooklyn Van Lines has won the latest political skirmish over its right to operate, but the war over commuter vans is likely to continue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMANN, ANN (NEE KENNELLY)
description: HUMANN-Ann (nee Kennelly). On July 19, 1997. Loving wife of the late Edward Humann. Dear sister of Berenice Maguire, Joseph and Thomas Kennelly. Beloved aunt and great-aunt to many. Reposing Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Damsel in distress: only one need apply
description: When you travel solo, even the mildest misadventures tend to make better stories. A few years ago, driving through the high, wild country of northern New Mexico, I ran out of steam just as evening and rain began to fall. Too depleted to drive, alone, over the 10,000-foot Cumbres Pass in the stormy night, I decided to get a motel room in Chama.

title: I Meant Not to Mow My Lawn
description: Is maintaining a beautiful lawn worth the cost -- financially, physically and environmentally?

title: Car Renters Pass or Fail
description: CAR-RENTAL companies have been changing the way they examine customers' driving records. Ever more prospective renters are subject to scrutiny -- Avis, for example, now checks applicants in 10 states and the District of Columbia; in 1995 it was only four states and the District of Columbia.

title: One Disk's Worth
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Chen And Jay Fiske
description: Margaret Cie Chen, a daughter of Ching H. Chen and Dr. Tio C. Chen of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to John Frederick Fiske, a son of Vandy Humphrey of Rochester and Dr. John M. Fiske of Medford, Mass. Judge Paul L. Klein, a retired judge of New York City Civil Court, performed the ceremony at the Yale Club in New York.

title: A Haunting Opera Made of Cranky Obsessions
description: ART IS DEAD, A CERTAIN ARTIST thinks: swallowed up by a vast, idiotic popular culture. Different ''schools'' fight like rats over the scraps that are left. Although the practical value of the arts is nil, those in power still interfere, and they range from vicious self-promoters to doddering old bigots. There is little chance of glory, but prison and even torture are possible rewards for ''creating.''

title: Two Steps Backward on Open Markets
description: THE United States, long the world's leading model and advocate for open telecommunications markets, is suddenly in danger of setting an unbecoming example for how to close them. And the landmark agreement of the World Trade Organization to open global telecommunications markets is in danger of being undermined.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBELL, MARY
description: LUBELL-Mary. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the passing of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of our devoted friend & coworker, Arthur Lubell. Mrs. Lubell received the Valiant Woman award at last year's Spring Luncheon of the YU Women's Organization. Mr. Lubell is a leading member of the University's Planned Giving Committee. A trustee of the Sidney Weisner Estate, he helped established a research program at our Albert Einstein Colleg of Medicine, a chair in political science at YU, scholarships at Yeshiva College and Stern College for Women, and Rabbinic Kollel Fellwoships at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary-all in memory of Sidney Weisner. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Arthur Lubell; children, Ruth, Diane, and Lewis; grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower Chairman, National Board, YUWO

title: Hogan! Germans Need You.
description: BURDENED by decades of guilt, Germans are understandably reluctant to mine their past for laughs. So it's surprising to say the least that each evening at 6:30 the ratings jump by 50 percent on the Munich-based Cable One network, as up to 840,000 Germans tune in to ''Hogan's Heroes,'' the American prisoner-of-war sitcom that even some Americans criticized as insensitive to World War II's horrors when it first aired in the 1960's.

title: A Music Mecca Loved but Reluctantly
description: IF ARCHITECTS HAVE VISIONS AND MUSICIANS have needs, why did so much go wrong in the building of Lincoln Center? Momentous decisions of design and financing attend the birth of any arts center, but they are eventually reducible to one: the needs of the arts versus the art of the possible. I suggest that the first has been sacrificed in the name of the second.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Lincoln, Mercury, Jaguar And Lots of Repair Service

title: Pfizer Adding 100 Labs to Its Groton Complex
description: JUST a few hundred feet from Pfizer's laboratories here, where scientists are carrying out delicate experiments, construction workers are blasting a three-acre hole into solid granite, removing 2,000 cubic yards of rock a day to make way for 550,000 square feet of new research space.

title: Centerfolds Emeritus
description: The ''Ambitions'' section on Kalin Olson's Playmate Data Sheet is typical. Miss August 1997 is 21, she hails from Hot Springs, Ark., and she hopes to make it as ''a model and actress'' -- like many of the 424 Playboy centerfold subjects before her.

title: Man Relates Tangled Tale Implicating Deaf Ex-Wife
description: So far, few explanations have been offered for what led to the situation of 62 Mexican immigrants found in two Queens homes today. But a vehicle linked to the trinket trade many of the immigrants were forced to engage in led to a deaf Long Island man who says he can explain it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAND, THEODORE I., PH.D.
description: FAND-Theodore I., Ph.D., chemist, age 81 on July 8, 1997 in Morristown, N.J. Beloved husband of Helen Hirsh for fifty-five years, loving and devoted father of Rita, Marlene, and the late Steven, dear brother of Anne Gold and the late Dr. Max Fand. Born in Brooklyn. Dr. Fand received his B.S. from Brooklyn College, his M.S. from the University of Michigan and his Ph.D. from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. After several years as an Analytical Chemist for the government, he began a life long career in the pharmaceutical industry. In 1942, Dr. Fand joined Nepera Chemical Company which later merged with Warner-Lambert in Morris Plains, NJ. Starting out as a Quality Control Chemist he went on to become a Director of New Product Development, and eventually Vice-President in charge of Research and Development. He retired in 1983 after forty-one years. During World War II he worked on penicillin and sulfa drugs and later helped develop a wide range of prescription and consumer products. He had many patents and publications to his credit and was highly esteemed for his creativity, integrity and standards of excellence. In 1974 Dr. Fand directed the distribution of a special storage media for eye banks which preserved corneas for shipment throughout the world. He was an authority in all areas of pharmaceutical research and was respected in both industry and government. He originated inter-company collaboration to optimize drug development. Dr. Fand loved his work. He was gentle, compassionate and unassuming, and was an inspirational mentor, both professionally and personally to many. He was a member of the Phi Lambda Upsilon, the Society of Sigma Xi and belonged to the American Chemical Society for more than 50 years. Contributions may be made to The Lighthouse or to the American Heart Association.

title: Paired-Up Packaging On the Upper East Side
description: The new owners of a block of 35 apartments in a condominium on East 93d Street plan to combine 24 of them into larger units in response to market demand, leaving 11 unchanged.

title: A Latin Lilt At a Lake In New York
description: BY eight o'clock Saturday morning, the Lake Welch shuffle is well under way. Cars dash from the George Washington Bridge to the Palisades Interstate Parkway, only to end up in a crawl 10 minutes down the road. By Pomona, three exits before the beach, the parkway has turned into a giant lake of humanity, moving in barely perceptible ripples.

title: Elizabeth Myers and Clark Byse
description: Elizabeth Anne Myers and Dr. Clark Byse were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. William D. Walsh performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Jill L. Baboff and Bruce Heller
description: Jill Lauren Baboff, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leon I. Baboff of Bethany, Conn., is to be married today to Bruce Todd Heller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Heller of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jacob in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARNOW, CARYL TAISHOFF
description: CARNOW-Caryl Taishoff. Of Manhattan, world traveler, suddenly on June 8, 1997 in Capetown, South Africa of a motor vehicle accident in her 69th year. Beloved friend and companion of James Graham. Beloved mother of David Carnow (Rosanna) of Warren, NJ; Donald Carnow (Heidi) of Wilmette, IL; and Tammi Jo Bechard (Russell) of Bolton, MA; beloved grandmother of Robin, Diana Lee and Adrian (NJ); Donna and Mackenzie (IL.); Jesse and Ryan (MA). Also survived by sisters Miriam Gerry (CT.) and Sally Cleveland (MS.) and cousin Hilda Taishoff (NY). She was laid to rest June 23 in a private service at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Queens, New York. She was full of vigor and life. She guided many to excel. She gave so much to so many and will be greatly missed by all. Memorial donations to your local public library or public TV or radio station.

description: BLACK LEGACY A History of New York's African Americans. By William Loren Katz. Illustrated. 250 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Dressed for Excess
description: Like bees to honey, they flocked to Loehmann's, not just to drown themselves in bargains but also to win lunch and a $250 shopping spree with that Empress of Excess, Renee Taylor. Taylor earned her divinity as Sylvia Fine, the pork-munching, overdressed Jewish mother on ''The Nanny.'' A wonder of engineering, with her bosom up to here, her waist in to there and her neckline down to there, this woman generally resembles nothing so much as a shapely sausage on stiletto heels, one encased in leopard skin and lame. Moreover, she doesn't merely shop at Loehmann's; she worships there.

title: Phil Schaap and Ellen LaFurn
description: Ellen Acheson Smith LaFurn, a kindergarten teacher at Public School 14 in Jersey City, was married yesterday to Philip Van Noorden Schaap, a jazz historian in New York. The Rev. David F. John Garcia Gensel, a former pastor of the jazz ministry at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York, took part.

title: Closed Beaches Running Out of Lifeguards and Sand
description: Few people visited the Rockaway beaches last week as haze and the occasional thuderstorm plagued the peninsula. But the weather was not entirely to blame for the sparse crowds.

title: Woe to Shows That Put On Operatic Airs
description: THE GREAT SONGWRITERS from the glory days of the American musical used to love poking fun at operatic music in their shows. There is an impish example in the 1956 Jule Styne musical ''Bells Are Ringing.'' A bunch of New York bookies, who front their operation as a classical record mail-order business, describe the ''Simple Little System'' they use to place their bets through a telephone-answering service.

Now plans are advancing to turn the commercial complexes, or their sites, to new uses, ranging from housing to retail and office space.

description: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Florence, my pocket was picked twice in 48 hours, in a manner I had not seen described. I was fortunate enough to recover my wallet without any loss each time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSE, VIRGINIA R.
description: PEARSE-Virginia R., of Vero Beach, FL., died July 10, 1997 at home in Chatham, Mass., at the age of 83. Mrs. Pearse was born in Evanston, Illinois, and had lived in Rumson, New Jersey; St. Croix, Virgin Islands; and Delray Beach, FL. She is survived by her husband, Robert G. Pearse, Delray Beach, Fla.; 3 daughters, Penelope Houghton, Rumson, NJ, Stephanie Hurtt, Navesink, N.J., and Roberta Pearse-Drance, Pennington, N.J.; 5 grandchildren; and two sisters. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 2, 1997 at St. George's-by-the-River, Rumson, New Jersey, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to The Riverview Foundation, designated for Riverview Hospital, 1 Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, NJ 07701.

description: Deborah Brittain Shaw, the daughter of Deborah Rossiter Cox of Oxford, Md., and John Arthur Shaw of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Daniel Ferrel McInnis, a son of Joan Gaertner McInnis of Tinton Falls, N.J., and Robert Dean McInnis of Del Mar, Calif. The Rev. Caroline Smith Pyle performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: The Peripatetic Heart
description: MANY people travel to heal a broken heart. They want to find proof that others don't view their faults quite so seriously as do ex-loved ones. Perhaps they wish to reaffirm their sexiness through blind encounters, to heal themselves, to forget. Some even fall in love and return with acceptable partners. Men make this journey differently than women do. At least, I think they do.

title: Hurricane Soaks Alabama as It Skirts Coast
description: Hurricane Danny weakened slightly but continued to produce drenching rain as it came ashore yesterday evening at the north end of Mobile Bay in Alabama, washing out roads and stranding residents who had chosen to ride out the storm.

description: Elissa Alan Raether, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Raether of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Edward Addison Kovas, a son of Kathleen Kovas of Nantucket, Mass., and the late John B. Kovas. The Rev. Ronald Allison, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church.

title: Hospital and College Form Agreement on Acupuncture
description: WHEN a 5-year-old boy underwent minor surgery recently at the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester here, his parents asked that an acupuncturist be present during the procedure. As it turned out, the acupuncturist merely observed the surgery by the hospital's pediatric surgeon. But the fact that an accredited teaching hospital accommodated the family's request is a sign of things to come at the medical center that was formerly known as New Rochelle Hospital.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SEPARATIONS

title: Couples Needs About Three More Eagles
description: Seagulls and swallows swoop above Royal Troon, but Fred Couples discovered an eagle in today's third round of the 126th British Open. His 6-iron from 168 yards disappeared into the cup for an eagle 2 on the dreaded ''Railway'' par-4, the 463-yard 11th alongside the Strathclyde Transport tracks.

title: Tent Living, Singing Around the Fire
description: MANY of the cabins and common buildings at Camp Woodstock on the shores of Black Pond in northeast Connecticut are built from the huge white pine trees that graced the property before the 1938 hurricane leveled the area. The wide-board construction and smell of wood adds to the rustic experience at the camp in the northeastern Connecticut town of Woodstock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSCOWITZ, EDWIN
description: MOSCOWITZ-Edwin, 70, of West Orange, N.J., and Tamarac, FL., died July 11. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he also lived n North Woodmere, NY. Mr. Moscowitz was president of Peerless Umbrella Company in Harrison, NJ. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He was a long-time member of Temple Hillel in Valley Stream, N.Y.; and was a grand master of the Masons. Surviving are his wife of 47 years, Marilyn; 4 children: Linda Moscowitz, Joan Patasnik, Ellen Grossman, and Gene Moscowitz; his mother, Cecil Schwartz; sister, Renee Resnick; and six grandchildren. Services were held on July 13th by Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

description: ROVENSKY-Josephine P. July 17, 1997 in NYC. Beloved wife of the late William Rovensky and Hollis Gale. Dear grandmother of Hollis Lenderking of Palo Alto, CA. Service will be Tuesday, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Jets' Johnson Taking Subtler Approach Now
description: It is a diplomatic Keyshawn Johnson who is finishing the first weekend of training camp with the Jets.

title: Cleaner Buses Could Be Added To New Jersey Transit's Fleet
description: Driving behind a New Jersey Transit bus may be less hazardous to the lungs if a grant approved by the United States Senate Transportation Appropriations Committee stays in the final federal budget. The Senate committee voted to provide $12 million for New Jersey Transit to buy alternative-fuel buses. The $12 million would buy approximately 40 alternative fuel buses at $300,000 each. Much of the current 2,000-bus fleet runs on diesel gas, which next to coal is one of the dirtiest-burning fuels, said Curtis D. Fisher, executive director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group Citizen Lobby. Jeff Whelan, a spokesman for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a senior member of the committee, said he was cautiously optimistic the bus grant would stay in the final federal budget.

title: A Final Journey Into the Heart Of Cuba
description: TOMAS GUTIERREZ ALEA was already ill with the cancer that would soon kill him when he made ''Strawberry and Chocolate,'' the bittersweet comedy that in 1995 became the first Cuban film to go into general release in the United States and be nominated for an Oscar. So when the success of that movie led to other offers, he understood from the start that he had received a rare gift: a final opportunity to sum up a lifetime of work and ideas.

title: Shakespeare Meets the Long Gray Line
description: MY orders arrived from the Department of the Army: I was to ''proceed from Los Angeles, Calif., on 6 March 1997 to give a poetry reading and participate in a discussion with cadets and faculty.'' My assignment had been ''determined to be in the public interest.'' I'd been expecting this. I had been advised some weeks earlier by Col. Rick Kerin, director of operations -- and by my personal military escort, Capt. Ed Ledford -- about the imminent official summons. What did I do? What would any red-blooded American poet do? My family and I synchronized our watches for ''0700 hours.'' I picked up my duffel bag (fake Vuitton). I answered my country's call. I flew due east to West Point.

title: Safer by the Dozen
description: With so many mutual funds on the market, investors may be tempted to keep adding to their portfolios. But how many funds do they really need?

description: FINBERG-Edna Miller. Died July 18. Graduate of Tufts Dental School, 1941; Yale School of Public Health, 1947. title: Playing the Immunity Card
description: AFTER being granted immunity by Congress a generation ago and providing the extraordinary testimony that helped topple President Richard M. Nixon, John W. Dean 3d, his former White House counsel, spent four months in Federal custody for conspiracy to obstruct justice.

title: 10 Most-Wanted List: Mirror to a Nation's Psyche
description: THOUGH the 27-year-old man being hunted for the murder of Gianni Versace last week seems to be running circles around the authorities, the odds actually swung heavily against him last month when the Federal Bureau of Investigation elevated him to its list of ''Ten Most Wanted Fugitives.'' In the 47 years since the F.B.I. began the list as a publicity device, 421 of the 449 people in the top 10 have been tracked down.

title: For the Body, a Curvy Home That Calls to the Soul
description: THIS VERY PLEASANT, SMALL, modern city on the northwest coast of Spain is the site of a recent building designed by Arata Isozaki. La Coruna has a working waterfront, with rows of cranes and gantries. Above the harbor, scores of modern apartment blocks should mar the horizon but somehow don't, perhaps because they are scaled to the low, hilly terrain. Marine light drenches the town.

title: The British Detective as 'a Kind of Dinosaur'
description: DETECTIVE Superintendent Andy Dalziel is more caveman than new man -- a cigarette-puffing, beer-swigging detective with a large gut, a foul mouth and a scowl that seems carved into his face. With his thick Yorkshire accent and his abrasive demeanor, he serves as a fine foil to Peter Pascoe, the boyishly handsome and semi-yuppified Detective Inspector who works for him in ''Dalziel and Pascoe,'' a British import coming back to New York this week. It will be shown on Tuesday at 9 P.M. on A&E.

title: Colonial-Era Legacies Often Control Land Use
description: IN colonial times, the Dutch or British crowns or their representatives gave the founders of Long Island's towns title to certain underwater lands through patents and grants. Valid to this day, those legal instruments are recognized in the state's Constitution and by the Legislature.

title: Airlines Give Discounts To Get Kids Buckled Up
description: The major United States airlines have instituted fare discounts of 50 percent for children age 2 or younger who travel with adults and occupy their own seat, using their safety seat. American Airlines began the move July 2, and other carriers followed rapidly.

But the message from motoring organizations and diplomats to travelers is: Don't hold your breath for sudden changes on the ground.

title: The Better Half Got the Worse End
description: THE headlines last week trumpeted the good news: Deaths from AIDS had dropped 19 percent in the United States, continuing a decline first reported in May. The disease, it appears, has turned a corner in this country, changing from a death sentence into a chronic, treatable illness. As the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention declared, ''We have entered a new era in the H.I.V. epidemic.''

title: Wake Up, America: Apathy Can Be Dangerous
description: Unless the heat has warped our memory, it was only a couple of years ago that Americans were so mad at Washington there could have been a new Congressional election every month. Today, the cry of ''throw the bums out'' is seldom heard, and the people storming the ramparts of the Capitol are mostly the usual suspects looking to cut the usual deals.

title: Susan Hovdesven, Matthew Miller

The student who walks in a novice will come back a composer, librettist, director, stage manager, production manager, set designer, costume designer, makeup artist, carpenter and electrician. A press agent, too. All after nine days.

title: Leo Gruliow Is Dead at 84; A Self-Taught Soviet Scholar
description: Leo Gruliow, who turned a chance Depression-era job as a Moscow journalist into a cold war career translating Soviet periodicals into English, died on July 13 in a hospice near his home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 84.

title: Some Like It Fast
description: Robert levine has been experimenting again on the sidewalks of New York. Several years ago, you may remember, this Californian attracted national attention by scientifically demonstrating that our pedestrians are the least likely in America to help a stranger in need. This was a little embarrassing but hardly surprising. It merely confirmed our image of ourselves. But now Levine has come up with something truly disturbing.

description: IN the Hamptons it's not the early bird catching a worm. It's a television newscaster grabbing the chicken.

title: Let's Get Physical
description: The notion that pre-schoolers should not be couch potatoes lies behind the PBS program BLOOPIE'S BUDDIES, where the educational component is physical -- WEEKDAYS on CHANNEL 21 at 10:30 A.M., CH. 50 at 5 P.M. and CH. 25 at 3 P.M. Bloopie, a globe shape (with an actor inside) and stick-figure-like arms, urges children to jump, hop, spin, dance and otherwise get their energy out.

title: Living With Medical Marijuana
description: One morning in May, Sgt. Scott Savage of the San Jose Police Department's narcotics unit paid a visit to the newest tenant in the modest one-story professional building at the corner of Meridian and San Carlos: the Santa Clara County Medical Cannabis Center. Sergeant Savage, who has the upbeat demeanor of a young suburban cop (think ''Adam-12'') and wears polo shirts to work, has one of the more unusual jobs in American law enforcement. He is responsible for developing a set of regulations and procedures to govern the distribution of medical marijuana in San Jose, work he likes to describe as ''very creative'' and ''a thinking man's game.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEIDNER, MARY
description: WEIDNER-Mary. Mommy, today would have been your 65th birthday. You were our Rock of Gibraltar and our very best friend. Our hearts still ache for you. With all our love, Your Children.

Johnson performed the ceremony at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J.

title: Hit the Spa
description: The miraval life in balance resort is only two years old, but it's already changing the landscape of well being. In Catalina, Ariz., about 20 miles north of Tucson and the famed Canyon Ranch, this pretty retreat of man-made brooks and strategically placed flower beds is an oasis of green under a parched desert sun.

title: The Old in One Another's Arms
description: Davida Rosenblum's story cheered me as few things have recently. In the early 1980's, I met a man of 86 at my church in Manhattan. I was 36. His wife had died two months earlier, and he was bereft. I figured that I would offer my friendship to carry him over this period of adjustment.

title: Smoke at 35,000 Feet
description: The opening statements in a $5 billion secondhand smoke trial in Miami last week were the opening of hostilities.

title: Warm, Spirited and Without Pretense
description: EVERY neighborhood should have an Italian restaurant like La Terrazza in Cedarhurst. It is a warm, spirited, white-tablecloth spot that is devoid of pretense. First-timers are greeted enthusiastically; second-timers find themselves in a familiar circle of regulars.

title: Opening A Window On Hasidism
description: ONE OF SEVERAL EXTRAORDINARY snippets of archival film in the documentary ''A Life Apart: Hasidism in America'' shows the Lubavitcher Rebbe's 1929 visit to New York, during which his American followers implored him to leave behind the perils of Stalin's Soviet Union and bring his flock to the United States. America was not yet ready for Hasidism, the Rebbe replied; America was a trefina medina, an impure and unholy place where even rabbis shaved their beards.

title: When It Comes to Water Supply, Not Everybody Is Equal

title: Blasts From the Past, All Revolutionary
description: COOL is not a word one might expect to hear in a conversation with a museum director. But it does, two or three times in as many minutes, when you're talking to Janet Rassweiler. So do some unexpected attitudes about museums.

title: Dow Goes Whoopee, Again
description: Onward and upward went the stock market last week, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing past 8,000 a few months after hitting 7,000. It has doubled in less than two and one-half years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSACE, GIANNI
description: VERSACE-Gianni. To the King, thank you for always making me feel like a prince and for the profound impact you made on my life. You will be with me forever and proud. Love you always, Mark Reynolds

title: Watson Has Trade Doubts
description: Yankee General Manager Bob Watson expressed some doubt today about a deal for a power hitter being made before the July 31 trading deadline.

title: 35 and Mortal: A Breast Cancer Diary
description: It is always a pleasure to find Peggy Orenstein's articles in the Magazine. This time, however, when I saw the title accompanying her byline -- ''35 and Mortal: A Breast Cancer Diary'' (June 29) -- my heart sank on her behalf. I send best wishes for a sustained recovery and my appreciation for her story. Through her perspective, the debate on mammograms for women under 40 gains a voice that seemed oddly missing just six months ago -- that is, the voice of those deemed statistically insignificant.

title: Democrats Lead the Way on Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Altruistic Moves at Arts Center
description: THE Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill has embarked on several outreach programs. One with long-range implications is the center's invitation to nonprofit organizations to use the stage and services of the staff without charge so long as presentations are free and of benefit to the community.

title: Finding an Initial Public Offering in the Temperate Zone
description: WHEN the At Home Corporation made its public debut on July 11 and zoomed 62 percent above its offering price, many small investors were left to watch in frustration. New offerings often soar on their first day of trading, and the only people who get to buy them before their ascent are professional money managers and the very rich.

title: Wanted, Dead or Alive: Family Members Found Through Genealogy
description: Sandra Lanman didn't have any little cousins to play with when she was growing up. Now, at 47, she does -- in Helmetta, just five miles away from her home in East Brunswick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEISLER, FLORENCE A.
description: HEISLER-Florence A. Westbury Friends School Board mourns the passing of Florence Heisler, Ph.D, dedicated and long term supporter of the school. She died in her Bentley Village retirement home in Florida on June 3, 1997. She was born on April 3, 1909 and was a member of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers). She received her Ph.D. in Psychology from New York University. Her deep interest and support of the Westbury Friends School was a great source of strength to us. We are grateful for her wisdom and generosity of her spirit. A memorial service will be held at Westbury Friends Meeting House in Westbury, NY on Sunday, September 28, 1997, at 4 P.M. Contributions may be made in Florence Heisler's name to the Westbury Friends School, 550 Post Avenue, Westbury, New York 11590.

To hear Yates tell it, he was being called by drivers eager to step into the No. 28 Ford Thunderbird even when Irvan's departure was still just a rumor.

title: Age Is No Barrier for the Liberty
description: They were too old, the scouting reports said. Too old for this league, anyway. That, however, was said before the Liberty ever stepped onto a basketball court.

title: Still Italian but Renovated in Larchmont
description: ALTHOUGH the name of this 18-year-old restaurant remains, La Villetta has metamorphosed into an entirely fresh creation, renovated by new owners who have added lots of light and sparkle. Around the mural of a sun-drenched Italian hillside terrace, sponged yellow walls echo the brightness, as do glittering chandeliers, candles and flowers. But although the stage is set and the audience in place, this new production, on the boards since January, still seems to be struggling; the cast and crew could use more rehearsals.

title: Dana Jacobson and Jason Alliger

Goodnight -- who was crushed by his semi in 1995 while changing a tire -- now lies beneath a large, intricate, hand-carved model of the vehicle that ended his life, which rests on a base that looks like a highway. Cost: $11,000.

title: Brain Surgery Made Easy
description: Mick Jackson's first novel, THE UNDERGROUND MAN (Morrow, $22), tracks the gloriously odd, fabulously wealthy fifth Duke of Portland -- a real figure turned here into a fictionalized character -- through his last days near the end of the 19th century. Haunted by a terrible childhood accident, the specifics of which are revealed only in the final pages, the Duke occupies his days meandering about his estate, philosophizing on matters great and small, delving into his own psyche and startling his staff and neighbors. The Duke's most remarked-upon eccentricity is his obsession with tunnels: he has carefully built a wide-ranging network of them beneath his lands, allowing him free and hidden access to all parts of his realm. But Jackson's tightly written narrative, in the form of the Duke's journals, with the occasional testimony of various bystanders, focuses more on the man's often hilarious hypochondria, his bright if useless observations (like the ''precise impracticabilities of one year sticking all the fallen leaves back into the trees'') and his inevitable descent into madness. It is difficult not to sympathize with the Duke, but equally easy to feel the discomfort and trepidation that fill those who move through his tiny universe -- including his faithful aide, Clement, and his neighbor, Mellor, a clergyman and amateur archeologist. A kind of climax comes in a grotesque yet gripping scene when the Duke performs brain surgery on himself, drilling a coin-sized hole in his skull and reaching in to feel his brain, his ''little box of tricks,'' in a failed effort at final relief. A skilled writer blending fact -- the tunnels, at least, exist -- and highly imaginative fiction, Jackson has produced a marvelous study of human foibles and done justice to the memory of a very strange man. Erik Burns

I spent too many years watching my town's millionaires attending weddings in their sneakers not to grow up believing that the classiest consumption is the least conspicuous. When I travel my conviction does not hold true for meals -- I like to eat well -- but almost without exception my hotels have been, if not quite hell, suburbs of purgatory. title: Don't Blame the Printer
description: In 1992, Ray Gun, an alternative rock-and-roll magazine, earned a reputation for radical graphic presentation that so challenged the conventions of legibility that its texts were reduced to textures. Its raucous graphic design set the standard for a kind of hip style of typographic tomfoolery that soon became the rave with countless other alternative-culture publications and on posters, packages and music videos. The traditional type hierarchies -- headlines, subheads, body text and page numbers -- were rejected in favor of unrelenting randomness. Text was allowed to bleed off the page in the middle of a paragraph, and in one issue an entire article was printed backward in an illegible typeface. Ray Gun's first art director, David Carson, and his small army of designers made pages that were more like Abstract Expressionist canvases than magazine layouts. Rather than communicate ideas, they created auras that gave an impression of expression. The magazine was the harbinger of visual codes for the post-baby-boom generation, and it remains the granddaddy of edgy graphic magazines as well as a document of its time. But RAY GUN: Out of Control (Simon & Schuster, $45), a celebratory compendium of covers and pages from the magazine and its sister publications, Bikini, Blah Blah Blah, huH and Stick, is not the best way to document this trend. This book, edited by Dean Kuipers and Chris Ashworth, looks more like a collection of printers' errors than a book. And although the graphics are punctuated by interesting essays on the magazine's brief history, they are lost amid the confusing morass of type and image. Now that the Ray Gun style has been adapted for mainstream television and print advertisements, this assemblage is more confusing than outrageous. Steven Heller

title: HIGHWAY BOUNTY
description: As Congress prepares a giant new highway bill, lawmakers are complaining that Federal highway dollars are often used for more than just roads - like restoring a Shaker barn outside Albany for $159,500. Or preserving the ancient mounds of oyster shells along the Maine coast for $364,000. Such projects occur because the law requires states to spend some of the Federal highway money they receive on historic preservation, with a stipulation being that the site must be visible from the road. Applying that concept liberally, one affected roadside site is the West Virginia state Capitol, recipient of a $620,000 spiff-up. ''There's legitimate justification for some of it,'' says Senator Robert C. Smith, a reform-minded New Hampshire Republican, ''but when we get into buying seashells, it's preposterous.''

Following the model of that venerated ancestor, the six-year-old Lollapalooza Festival, they're all different and they're all, in some ways, the same. Who better to accommodate him than Jim and Tom Trunzo, the Leechburg, Pa.-based designers of A.P.B.A. Pro Boxing for Windows software. The Trunzos rate each fighters in 34 categories, including speed, power and ability to take a punch. The machine crunches it all and spits out a blow-by-blow account of a battle between any two competitors, compelte with crowd reaction, color and fouls. To determine Gooden's place in the pantheon, the Trunzos ran each of the following matchups 100 times. Here's how Gooden fared.

title: Footloose and Family-Free
description: JUDGING by anecdotal evidence, the best that can be said about traveling alone is that it offers great opportunities to meet people and, thus, no longer be alone. As for the literature on the subject, the vast majority of it consists of coping strategies, tips on destinations that are singles-friendly and clever conversational gambits in different languages. One can't help coming away with an impression that anyone who hits the road solo starts off with a serious handicap, and that those who aren't joined in bedlock or bound to an affinity group are in danger of that dread modern social disease solitude. But with all due respect for the sensitivities of the unmarried, divorced or widowed, it seems to me that setting out on one's own has inherent advantages that deserve to be considered even by people who have a choice in the matter.

title: Tea Museum
description: To the Editor: My daughter Anne and I visited the Bramah Tea and Coffee Museum four years ago, when it first opened. We, too, were looking for something different from the usual London tour sites (''Curiosities in Every Corner,'' May 18). Anne spotted a teapot with an unmistakable B. Kliban cat design. We noticed the attribution was to ''Kuban.'' I asked for the person in charge, to inform someone of the error. This is how we met Edward Bramah, who graciously accepted the correction. The name was engraved on the pot in capital letters; KLIBAN was misread as KUBAN and was thus listed in the lavishly illustrated catalogue. Mr. Bramah chatted with us, treated us to tea, and left us with a memorable experience.

title: Vocation: C.E.O. Avocation: Lifeguard
description: MIKE SHAPIRO, having called on a dozen clients between Mystic and Old Saybrook, including two at Ocean Beach in New London, would appear to have put in a full day's work. But it was only noon on a recent Monday, and there, perched on a lifeguard stand at Ocean Beach, not far from the boardwalk concession where he had made his last client call of the day, was Mr. Shapiro. Appropriately enough, it was chair No. 1, befitting the senior lifeguard at the sprawling beach and the highest ranking official at the Mansfield Paper Company in West Springfield, Mass., a distributor of paper products. Somehow, Mr. Shapiro manages to combine the disparate jobs of lifeguard at Ocean Beach and president and chief operating officer of a paper distribution company based 80 miles away. For three and a half days each summer Mr. Shapiro spends approximately 30 hours lifeguarding at Ocean Beach and the other three and a half days at Mansfield Paper.

title: Two's a Crowd

Feeling stubborn -- not to mention hungry -- I waited around the foyer for 45 minutes, watching waiters push through the kitchen door carrying oversized bottles of beer, tureens of steaming soup and platters of dumplings so beautifully decorated that they looked like bonbons. Finally a large round table opened up, which I insisted on taking. There I sat, sampling each delicious course as it came, surrounded by seven empty chairs. I was charged $12 for the meal, which would have fed three easily, at $4 each.

They are more economical and environmentally friendly because they use shade to block the rays of the sun and ventilation to pull the hot air from the house. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAAD, JOHN THOMAS
description: SCHAAD-John Thomas. Of Old Tappan, N.J. on July 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Perry). Loving father of Nancy Marie, Gloria May and Lorraine Marian. Devoted and cherished grandfather of Christopher Daniel. Before retiring in 1992, Mr. Schaad was employed by The New York Times. A U.S. Army vet 1951-1953. A private service was held. His love and laughter will be greatly missed. God saw you getting tired and the cure was not to be; so He put his arm around you and whispered, ''Come with Me''. With tearful eyes I watched you and saw you pass away although I loved you dearly I could not make you stay. A golden heart stopped beating, hardworking hands at rest, God broke my heart to prove to me He only takes the best. Memorial gifts to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Hard-Charging Company Is Seeking New Power

title: A Moderate's Moment
description: It is the moderate Republicans who hold the balance of power in Washington now, the moderate Republicans who are considered up for grabs on every big vote. So, in January, when a new one arrived fresh from Maine -- Senator Susan M. Collins -- people of every political stripe rushed to win her over. A Nike lobbyist, seeking to protect the company's low-wage sneaker factories in Asia, wanted a meeting with Collins before she formulated a Most Favored Nation policy. Her Roman Catholic bishop in Maine called right before her first vote on ''partial birth'' abortions.

title: Yang takes trip, yearns for yin

I can say that weekends and little holidays don't count, nor does travel in my own country, but clearly I'm kidding myself; I have caved in.

Contributions to memorialize her to: Jewish National Fund (Trees), 212-751-4848.

title: Stuart Jewell, Who Filmed Nature's Wonders, Dies at 84

Neary fought him. Most adored brother and friend of Liz and Andee. Treasured grandson of Margaret and Bernie, Mildred and Irving. We miss your beautiful smile, your sweetness. Our hopes and dreams were in your very promising future, a top student, athlete, musician, and all around great kid. Loved by all who got to know you. We miss you so dearly. We are heartbroken. Aunt Jane, Uncle Ishaia, Yoni and Pasha

title: Keep Cameras in the Courtroom
description: New York's 10-year-old experiment with allowing television cameras in the courtroom has successfully enhanced the public accountability of the justice system without sacrificing the rights of trial participants. Indeed, the three special review commissions the State Legislature set up over the years to study the program's effects have all recommended that the law authorizing cameras be made permanent. But instead of finally acting on that sound advice, Albany let the law expire on June 30. The chances of getting cameras back in the state's courts even for another trial period are now in serious jeopardy.

title: Treasury and Other Financings Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

With the most dominant player in women's golf chasing her hole by hole at Wykagyl Country Club, Redman refused to wilt and was rewarded with her first victory in six years on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

We extend our deep condolences to his family. Matthew Goldstein President of Baruch College

With someone translating in sign language, he warned them about people who seduce deaf Mexicans into traveling to the United States to labor as street vendors.

Born in Brooklyn to Philip and Mildred Loeb Amster, Judy graduated from Vassar College in 1956. Judy is also survived by her dear cousins Jane, Beth and Ruth. Services were held Sunday. Contributions may be made to the Gilda Radner Ovarian Cancer Detection Program at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, or to Vassar.

title: Indonesian Balancing Act
description: When all is said and done the Clinton foreign policy is going to be judged very heavily by how well it manages the two great historical transitions now under way: the decline of Russia and the rise of China. For now, Russia's decline is going relatively well (thanks to Boris), but the rise of China is another matter. It's critical that China's rise at the close of this century be handled better than Japan's rise at the start of this century, since Japan's emergence as a powerhouse led to three wars in Asia.

description: JUSTIN LEONARD'S smile shone brighter than the silver claret jug he had just earned as the British Open champion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESCHAMPS, SIDNEY

title: Digerati are unlikely celebrants of a primitivist conflagration in the Nevada desert.

A man squats in ersatz tribal gear complete with a stick through his nose. Celebrants like these have come to a five-day festival in Nevada's Black Rock Desert that takes place annually on Labor Day weekend with 115-degree temperatures, parched earth and ritualistic spectacle (last year about 10,000 people arrived).

title: The I.R.A. Cease-Fire
description: The Irish Republican Army's decision to resume its cease-fire yesterday brings Northern Ireland closer than it has ever been to meaningful peace talks that will include all major Catholic and Protestant parties. But that result is not yet assured. The I.R.A. must scrupulously maintain its cease-fire through the start of those talks, scheduled for mid-September, and then continue it throughout what are sure to be difficult and frustrating negotiations. As important, the province's main Protestant parties must not abandon the bargaining table the moment Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, arrives.

title: Forty Acres and a Mule
description: Bill Clinton has earned a boat-load of scorn since suggesting that he might apologize for slavery, as some in Congress have suggested. Critics from both left and right argue that such an apology would be trivializing, empty, arrogant and racially divisive. The dominant view, typified by the columnist Charles Krauthammer, is that there is essentially nothing to discuss, since the Civil War closed the issue and the slavers and the enslaved are long since dead. But all the noise suggests the issue is very much alive. The terms of Emancipation are nearly as explosive today as during the 1860's, when they dominated public consciousness and nearly tore the Government apart.

Pentair, based in St. Paul, is a diversified manufacturer. General Signal, based in Stamford, Conn., makes products for the process-control and electrical industries; it had 1996 revenues of more than $2 billion. The sale includes all divisions of the pump business, including Aurora Pump and Hydromatic. Shares of General Signal fell $1 yesterday, to $51, while shares of Pentair rose 25 cents, to $37.3125.

title: Tracking American Anti-Drug Aid
description: This week House Republicans will try to strike from next year's foreign aid bill a useful law intended to keep American weapons from falling into the wrong hands. Last year Senator Patrick Leahy sponsored a one-year law that prohibited the State Department's counter-narcotics funds from buying weapons for foreign military and police units whose personnel are credibly accused of serious human rights violations, unless those men are being prosecuted. At the direction of Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, the Clinton Administration has wisely decided to apply these provisions to all American counter-narcotics aid.

title: DIGITAL GENERATION ACQUIRES MEDIATECH/STARCOM

Mediatech delivers television commercials and syndicated programs to broadcasters. Indenet, of Encino, Calif., supplies technology and software to the broadcast and cable industries. It said the deal had improved its cash position by about $13.2 million and reduced its debt by $2.2 million. Shares of Digital Generation, based in San Francisco, closed at $6.75 yesterday, up 87.5 cents, and Indenet's shares rose 43.75 cents, to $2.

Raelene, already a mother, says of her new boyfriend, ''He cares about me, I know he does or he wouldn't say he wants to marry me.'' De'Yona, being raised by her strong, straightforward grandmother, insists she will never have children; she wants to be a singer and is surrounded by too many brothers, sisters and cousins already.
