description: MCKESSON CORP., San Francisco, the wholesale distributor of drugs and other health care products, signed a five-year agreement valued around $1.25 billion to be the primary pharmaceutical supplier to Phar-Mor Inc., Youngstown, Ohio.

title: Speculators Press Attack On South Asian Countries
description: Currency speculation continued to take a toll on South and Southeast Asian economies yesterday, as the Indonesian rupiah tumbled as much as 7 percent and interest rates were driven up in Hong Kong and Singapore.

title: 'Incidental' Racism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Friend of Gnats, Nits and Mites Has One Message: '6 Legs Good'
description: ENROLLING in a college class on insects, May R. Berenbaum was carrying out what seemed like a simple plan: Know the enemy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEFFENS, MADELINE U.
description: STEFFENS-Madeline U. Age 82 of Virginia Beach died on Saturday, July 19, 1997. Mrs. Steffens was born December 20, 1914, in the Bronx, N.Y. She is the daughter of the late Thomas and Marion Driscoll Ward. She is a graduate of Mt. Saint Ursula High School and Panzer College. She was a North Arlington High School Physical Education teacher from 1932-1970, having received the Princeton Prize for New Jersey Teacher of the Year in 1969. She received the National Association for Girls and Women in Sports Project Acclaim Award. Mrs. Steffens is survived by a loving family; wonderful friends; and thousands of students whom she loved dearly. A memorial service will be held at Queen of Peace Church in North Arlington, NJ, 11 AM, August 5th. For further information call Altmeyer Funeral Home, 1-800-934-4648.

title: William Reynolds Dies at 87; Oscar Winner for Film Editing
description: William Reynolds, a deft and meticulous Hollywood film editor who won Academy Awards for ''The Sound of Music'' and ''The Sting,'' died on July 16 in South Pasadena, Calif. He was 87.

title: H. Upmann is moving to emerge a winner as the premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period.
description: AS the white-hot premium cigar industry enters a shakeout period, H. Upmann, the Consolidated Cigar Corporation's flagship premium cigar, is beginning a multimillion-dollar ad campaign intended to make sure it emerges a winner.

title: Restoring Tuition Spending
description: With the state awash in unanticipated tax revenue, Gov. George E. Pataki said tonight that he was willing to restore $175 million in proposed cuts to the tuition assistance program that provides aid to thousands of college students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOFFER, PATRICIA
description: ZOFFER-Patricia. On July 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Berthold Zoffer. Loving mother of Evan Zoffer. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, 11:30AM. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Save the Redwoods League, 114 Sansome Street, Room 605, San Francisco, California 94102.

title: German Merger Would Create Europe's No. 2 Bank in Assets
description: Two big German banks announced plans today for a $10 billion merger that would create one of the biggest banks in Europe and an institution with more assets than any bank in the United States.

title: Silent Tales of Pain, Hardship and Hope
description: In one of the many silent testimonies from a Queens motel where 57 deaf Mexican immigrants were being held, a young man recounted how his baby boy was taken from him five years ago by the same people who forced him to work from morning until night selling $1 trinkets on the subway. He has been looking for the child ever since.

title: COMPUTERVISION SELLS ITS HARDWARE UNIT TO CVSI
description: The Computervision Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its product design hardware unit to CVSI Inc. for $42.6 million in cash and debt and would take a $45 million charge to shift its focus to selling only software. Part of the charge will pay for unspecified job cuts, although most of the charge is for ''facility reduction,'' a company spokeswoman said. Computervision, based in Bedford, Mass., will now concentrate on making software that gives workers access to information about products no matter where in the company they are. Computervision received $32.6 million in cash for the unit, Open Service Solutions, with $7.6 million coming from M. D. Sass Investors Services Inc.

title: A Budget Deal Not Worth Saving
description: The current budget negotiations between the President and Congress are often portrayed as an epic struggle over how to cut taxes, trim spending, invest in education and balance the budget for the first time in a quarter-century. But a less flattering version would note that the roaring economy is already driving the deficit close to zero, making a final deal superfluous if not harmful. Indeed, the deficit could be eliminated quicker if the budget deal collapsed.

title: The Abuse of Illegal Immigrants
description: The deaf Mexicans discovered last weekend living in virtual slavery in two cramped houses in Jackson Heights, Queens, were victims of the evils that can be inflicted on illegal immigrants who live in constant fear of discovery and deportation. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York has responded to the Mexicans' plight with sensitivity and compassion, arranging for them to be sheltered by the Red Cross in hotel rooms instead of being bused off to a Pennsylvania jail. But there is little question that most of the illegal immigrants will eventually have to be deported back to Mexico.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir PETER BLAKE, 50, the manager of Team New Zealand, which won the America's Cup in 1995, had often wondered what he would do after defending the trophy in the year 2000. An answer came via fax from France, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Hurricane People
description: For two days at our home on Mobile Bay we have watched Hurricane Danny's winds thrashing the oak trees, pounding the wharves, turning walls into instruments that whistle and moan. Power gone, we eat sandwiches by candlelight, play board games and listen to our transistor radio, that lowliest of technological devices.

title: PLY-GEM TO END HICKS, MUSE PACT AND GO WITH NEW BIDDER
description: Ply-Gem Industries said yesterday that it planned to end an agreement to be purchased by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. and would instead accept a higher offer of $19.50 a share, or $271 million, from an unidentified bidder. The unnamed suitor made its bid last week for Ply-Gem, a New York-based building materials company, topping the June offer of $18.75 a share, or $261 million, from Hicks, Muse, the Dallas-based buyout firm. Transaction values are based on Ply-Gem's 13.9 million shares outstanding as of yesterday. Hicks Muse had also agreed to assume $182 million of debt; Ply-Gem declined to comment on how much debt the unidentified bidder would assume. Shares of Ply-Gem rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $19.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, WINNIFRED
description: JAFFE-Winnifred. After a long illness, Winnifred Jaffe passed away on July 21, 1997. She was born October 16, 1898 and spent almost half a century in education. Her educational degrees were from Teacher's College, Columbia University. Her teaching was almost entirely in Ridgefield, N.J. She is survived by her brother Dr. William J. Jaffe. Her late parents were Elias & Ida Rosensohn Jaffe. Her late brother and sister were Dr. John Jaffe and Sophie G. Jaffe. Services at Gutterman's, Wednesday 9:30 AM, 331 Amsterdam Avenue near W. 76th St, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, BETTE MANDEL
description: BLOOM-Bette Mandel, on July 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted sister of Jules Mandel. Loving aunt of David, Jodie, Erica, Justin, Herbert and Steven. Services on Tuesday, 1:30 P.M., at Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, New York. Donations to Bnai Brith Gotham and Society of Illustrators Museum.

description: AT&T Earnings Fall But Top Expectations

description: Boys and Girls

title: New Truce, New Questions
description: Has the Irish Republican Army renounced its historic commitment to armed struggle and opened the way to a power-sharing future for Northern Ireland? Or has its declaration of a new cease-fire just tactically substituted ballot for bullet in a continuing fight that will end only if Ireland is fully united?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABCOCK, MARTHA PEASE
description: BABCOCK-Martha Pease. On July 20, 1997 beloved wife of the late Richard F. Babcock, loving mother of Martha Gibb Bayne and Lewis M. Gibb, Jr. Devoted grandmother of Cynthia B. Simpson, William Bayne, Jr., Lewis M. Gibb, III, Ann G. Peck, Thomas Gibb and one great granddaughter. Funeral arrangements to be published.

title: Congress to Consider Transportation Spending
description: Within 60 days, Congress will begin considering the renewal of the Federal bill authorizing $26 billion in annual transportation spending, lawmakers from the region said yesterday.

description: Delta Air Lines said today that it was offering a $99 companion fare to customers who booked tickets through the Internet, effective immediately.

title: The Giants' Fragile Offensive Line Gets a Scare
description: Less than an hour into this morning's practice, during which offensive and defensive linemen had been executing a run-blocking drill, several Giants players suddenly rose from their stances and began to yell: ''Trainer! Trainer!''

title: Guiding the Giants With a Caring Hand
description: It was after the 1993 season, and the Giants were announcing the release of their longtime quarterback Phil Simms. In the back of a crowded room at a news conference sat Wellington Mara, the owner, with tears in his eyes. That says a lot. Mara is a man who rarely shows his emotions publicly; indeed, it has been his steady hands that have helped to craft one of the best franchises in professional sports.

title: By some measures, First Union may be acquiring Signet Banking for a reasonable price.
description: HOW does a big, sophisticated institution like the First Union Corporation, America's sixth-largest bank, determine how much it will pay for an acquisition?

title: AT&T Says Results Hit 'Low Water Mark'
description: Describing its second-quarter results as its ''low water mark,'' the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that its income from continuing operations plunged 38 percent, to $959 million.

title: Agencies Had Inspected Captives' Apartment
description: One of two apartments in Queens crammed with dozens of deaf Mexicans had become such a neighborhood fixture -- and source of complaints -- that employees of several city agencies visited there over the last several months to investigate overcrowding or to respond to a medical emergency, city officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOY, FLORENCE
description: McCOY-Florence. On July 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harvey McCoy. Loving sister of Mildred, Lordi and Louise Digges. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, 4-7 PM. Funeral service at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: Russia's Ominous Void
description: For two years, opponents of NATO expansion have warned that inviting former Warsaw Pact countries into the alliance would bolster Russia's nationalist and Communist opposition forces. In Moscow, however, the extension of invitations to the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland to join NATO came and went this month without producing any visible reaction from Russia's opposition.

title: Leonard's Next Big Hurdle In Europe Is the Ryder Cup
description: Justin Leonard had just finished kissing the old claret jug in public, and he was describing how it felt to hit the long, downhill birdie putt on the 17th hole on Sunday that gave him the British Open lead for good.

title: Prison Term for Officer Who Killed Unarmed Man
description: A transit police officer who fatally shot an unarmed man in the back as he fled down a deserted Bronx subway platform was sentenced yesterday to one and a half to four and a half years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBELL, MARY
description: LUBELL-Mary. The Touro College family is deeply saddened by the passing of Mrs. Mary Lubell, beloved wife of our friend and benefactor, Arthur Lubell. We join with the family at this time of deep sorrow and convey our condolences. Dr. Bernard Lander, President

title: Pantani Makes It 2 of 3 in Alps
description: They liked Sunday's epic Tour de France battle between Richard Virenque and Jan Ullrich so much, they ran it again today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLIMENKO, JESSE
description: CLIMENKO-Jesse. On July 20, in New Milford, in his 94th year. Services private. Contributions in his memory to New Milford Hospital, 21 Elm Street, New Milford, Conn. 06776, or City Harvest, Inc., 159 W. 25th St., 10th Floor, NY, NY 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEFFERMAN, BARBARA OHRBACH
description: FEFFERMAN-Barbara Ohrbach. Of Cathedral City, California. Died July 17, 1997 at Desert Hospital Hospice in Palm Springs. She is survived by her mother Ree Ohrbach, her husband Frank, five children and six grandchildren. Services will be held noon Monday at Ramon Chapel, in Cathedral City, Calif. She will be sorely missed. The family suggests donations to Neuro Fibromatosis Foundation in New York City.

title: No. 1 Pick Farrior Has First Practice
description: He looked like an outsider, standing alone while his teammates milled around, waiting for practice to begin this morning at 8:50. When James Farrior, the Jets' No. 1 pick, spent a few minutes on the field, working with the second team, Coach Bill Parcells finally noticed him.

title: Movies for Children, and Their Parents, Are Far From 'Pollyanna'
description: The traditional family film, once a lucrative staple of Hollywood's studio system, is quietly dying as the industry feeds an increasingly restless audience with bigger stars, more provocative themes and stories with an edge unheard of even a decade ago.

title: No Headline
description: ''There's a bias among some of our political elites that if you are willing to die for the Bible, you're a fanatic, but if you die in front of a tank, you're a hero.''

title: Arafat Orders The Arrest Of Policemen
description: Under pressure from Israel and the United States, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has ordered the arrest and investigation of several of his police officers after Israeli accusations that they were involved in planning an attack on Jewish settlers in the West Bank.

title: Hevesi Backs Challenger for Public Advocate
description: In a move that could complicate Mark J. Green's path to re-election as Public Advocate -- as well as his bid for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate in 1998 -- City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi will endorse Mr. Green's little-known opponent in this year's Public Advocate primary, aides to both men said last night.

description: ''Lay aloft!'' barked Joe Wilson, the captain of the deck, resplendent in a long black coat with gold brocade and a tall fore-and-aft hat.

title: F.T.C. Asks Data On British Utility
description: Pacificorp and the Energy Group P.L.C. said today that they had been ordered to provide the Federal Trade Commission with more information before it rules on Pacificorp's $5.8 billion bid for Energy Group, a British-based power company.

title: Keeping Cool and Chic in Black
description: In many parts of the country, summer calls for a switch to pastel and white clothing, but in New York City black spells seasonless chic, whether worn head to toe or with a flash of white.

title: Pataki Found Lagging in Minority Appointees
description: Fewer than 8 percent of the top officials in the Pataki administration are members of minority groups, well below the average for all states, according to a recent study by researchers at the State University of New York in Albany.

title: TMP to Buy Ad Agency
description: TMP Worldwide said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Austin Knight Ltd. of London, a recruitment advertising agency with 24 offices worldwide.

title: Disney Sets Deal For Record Label
description: As expected, the Walt Disney Company announced today that it had agreed to buy Mammoth Records, an independent record label, in a move to bolster its struggling presence in the music industry.

title: Upstate Glass Plant Agrees To Give Up Pollution Credits
description: State and Federal environmental officials have reached a tentative agreement with a major glass manufacturer that will require the company to significantly reduce pollution at a new plant in central New York and return to the state hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of so-called pollution credits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEMENY, GEORGE
description: NEMENY-George. On July 20th, 1997. Father of Patricia Berman and Laurie Estep. Father-in-law of Meyer Berman. Grandfather of Andrew, Abby and Lynn and Anna, Rachel and Elizabeth. Service is today at 1 P.M., at the ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: Nominee to Pay Water Bills
description: Willie Brown, the Essex County Assemblyman who was poised to become a commissioner of the state agency that regulates utilities even though he owed more than $18,000 in water bills, agreed yesterday to repay the money immediately, Newark officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Vows column on Sunday about the wedding of Mala Yee and Sham Mosher misstated the date of the event. It was July 12, not June 12.

description: SCHNEEWEISS-Pauline (nee Goldfine). 6/2/13-7/22/96. Rivie, I love you forever. Sam.

title: Once Upon a Time, in a Poetic Land, Lived a Ballerina Who Walked on Air
description: Like the story it retells through Frederick Ashton's ineffable magic, the Royal Ballet's ''Cinderella'' has a restorative power. The company that battled the incoherence of an ersatz fairy tale on opening night was transformed back to a stylistic whole.

title: Far Apart, 2 Particles Respond Faster Than Light
description: IT was as if some ghostly bridge across the city of Geneva, Switzerland, had permitted two photons of light nearly seven miles apart to respond simultaneously to a stimulus applied to just one of them.

description: HAMBURG - Frances. Beloved wife of the late Samson, devoted mother of Steven and Marilyn, cherished mother-in-law of Debbie and Zev, adored grandmother of Joshua, Ilan, Michal, Max and Rebecca, dear sister of Seymour.

title: Chairman of LVMH Quits Guinness Board
description: Bernard Arnault, chairman of the French luxury goods company LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, resigned yesterday from the board of the British beverage company Guinness P.L.C. The move came just five days after Guinness and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. criticized Mr. Arnault's proposal for a three-way joint venture involving the drinks activities of the companies.

title: NATIONAL TECHTEAM'S STOCK SKIDS ON EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Shares of National Techteam Inc. fell 37 percent yesterday after the company said its second-quarter earnings would fail to match Wall Street's expectations. The company, a provider of computer-related support services, said yesterday that it expected to break even in the quarter that ended on June 30. Analysts surveyed by First Call had predicted earnings of 14 cents a share. In its second quarter last year, National Techteam, based in Dearborn, Mich., earned $1 million, or 9 cents a share, on revenues of $15.8 million. The company attributed the disappointing outlook to project delays and start-up costs related to several new contracts. Its shares fell $5.875, to $10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, IRVING
description: EISENBERG-Irving, on July 20, 1997. A caring and loving man to his family and friends and benevolent to all humanity. He will be deeply missed and always remembered. Beloved husband of Ina and the late Esther. Devoted father of David and daughter-inlaw Sonia and stepfather of Ellen Lane and Dr. Stuart Brown. Cherished grandfather of Sandra and Stephen Feder and Paul and Patti Eisenberg, and step-grandfather of Darren, Melanie, Ginger, Justin and Dahviya. Loving great-grandfather of Danielle Feder and Jamie Eisenberg. Dear brother-inlaw of Evelyn Paull and Rose Eisenberg. Services Wednesday, July 23, 11 AM, at Astoria Center of Israel, 27-35 Crescent St., Astoria

title: Alf Engen, 88, Skiing Champion And Designer of Ski Resorts
description: Alf Engen, who won 16 United States skiing titles, half in ski jumping, and who helped design more than 30 American ski areas, died Sunday in Cottonwood Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 88.

title: And Rube Was Our Prophet
description: I am sitting in a car trying to make a telephone call. Shame to say, the car is not maneuvering in heavy traffic. It is sitting on a parking lot with the motor off.

description: TREIMAN-Oscar Bard. You were talented-a National Clarinet Contest Winner, hardworking and good-thoughtful and compassionate, wise, deep, witty and a loving and dependable friend. Happy 78th! You're deeply loved.

description: COOPER-Carter V. 27th January 1965-22nd July 1988. Golden and True. Mom and Anderson

title: A Pulse That Lingers
description: Inflation is dead, right? After all, despite more than six years of uninterrupted economic growth and with unemployment now near the levels last enjoyed in the 1960's and early 1970's, consumer prices have risen at a mere 1.4 percent rate so far this year. And the cost of manufactured goods is actually falling.

title: I.B.M. Reports Mixed Results For Quarter
description: Moving forward in its quest to show Wall Street that it can deliver consistent quarterly growth, I.B.M. reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were better than expected, as a result of strong sales of mainframe computers and computer components and the growth of its computer services business. But overall revenue was weaker than many analysts had forecast.

title: Kia Motors Sets Record For Daily Car Sales
description: The financially troubled Kia Motors Corporation of South Korea said yesterday that it had sold an estimated 14,000 cars in South Korea, in its largest daily performance ever. The sales figure came after the company offered a discount of up to 30 percent on purchases paid in full with cash. On an average day, the auto maker sells about 1,000 vehicles, it said.

title: Computerized Translations: OK, but Not Parfait
description: SPEAK English to your computer, press the button, and have your voice come out speaking French. In science fiction, not a problem; in the real world, not a chance.

title: Ancient Plant Rediscovered
description: THE plant Takhtajania perrieri looks a bit like a small magnolia, with flowers the color of red wine. It dates from 30 million years ago, and the last time a specimen was found was 90 years ago. Now researchers from the Missouri Botanical Garden have reported finding several other specimens in Madagascar. The tree was rediscovered in 1994, though it was not identified until a couple of months ago. When a team went back in June, it found a thriving population.

title: The Edsel, With All Its Quirks, Is Hailed as It Turns 40
description: Ted Girvan would not let anyone else drive his: the muffler is loose. Richard Jump worried about how much gas was left in his: the fuel gauge is broken. Bruce Paterson finally got the passenger-side door on his to stay shut: it did not close on the first try. Or the second, the third or the fourth.

title: British Airways Seeks a Meeting
description: British Airways called on its largest flight attendants' union today to present its proposals to settle a pay dispute that led to a three-day strike this month.

title: Gingrich Reminds Rebels He's 'Head Coach'
description: Seeking to reassert control over mutinous House Republicans, Speaker Newt Gingrich pointedly reminded his members today that he is the party's ''head coach'' in the House and said he assumed he would remain Speaker for five more years.

title: Accounts
description: * Di Noto Lee, New York, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $5 million: Domaine Chandon, Napa, Calif., a unit of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, to handle advertising for the maker of sparkling wine, previously handled in-house, and Boise Technology, Itasca, Ill., a division of Boise Cascade, as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of high-tech office products.

title: Columbia Inquiries Said to Look at Olsten Dealings
description: A series of 1994 transactions between the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation and the manager of home health agencies in Florida has grown into an important part of the unfolding criminal investigations of the giant hospital company, people with knowledge of the situation said yesterday.

title: Bonds Quiet As Greenspan Is Awaited
description: Treasury prices were little changed yesterday as investors braced for Congressional testimony from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as well as for the Treasury's sale of $27 billion in new debt this week.

title: 'Appreciation For a Very Good Team'
description: AS it turns out, Bobby Valentine may have been right when he said much earlier this season that Hideki Irabu would have been better suited for Queens as opposed to the Bronx. For at this point of the Mets' stunning yet tempered development, Irabu would have been just one more student in Valentine's overachieving class.

title: Jury Sees Tape Of Defendant With Cosby
description: Lawyers for Autumn Jackson, the woman accused of trying to extort money from Bill Cosby, rested their case yesterday after a short but spirited defense that included only one witness and a dramatic appearance by Mr. Cosby -- on videotape, standing beside Ms. Jackson on a visit she made to his Queens studio in 1991.

title: Raymond Herzog, 81, Executive
description: Raymond H. Herzog, former chairman of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, died July 12 at his home in Pine Tree Hills, Minn. He was 81. The cause of death was cancer, according to a statement from the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIKLE, THOMAS HARRY, JR. M.D.
description: MEIKLE-Thomas Harry, Jr. M.D. Of Roxbury, CT. Former dean of Cornell University Medical College. On July 19, 1997. Public memorial gathering at 3 PM Sunday, July 27 at the Roxbury Congregational Church Fellowship Hall, 24 Church St, Roxbury, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions to Roxbury Congregational Church, 24 Church Street, Roxbury, CT 06783 or the Parkinsons Disease Foundation, William Black Medical Research Building, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 650 West 168 Street, New York City 10032-9982.

title: Taiwan Company Considers a Stock Swap
description: An official at Chunghwa Telecom Co., which is owned by Taiwan's Ministry of Transportation and Communication, said yesterday that it had begun talks to swap shares with Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd., the territory's largest telephone company.

title: King-Merchant: Eternal Fight
description: The HBO boxing analyst Larry Merchant ''is a hater,'' said the promoter Don King.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The legacy of a musical career: When Christopher Keene, the general director of the New York City Opera, died in 1995 at 48, he left a nine-foot Steinway grand he had used to prepare for operas he conducted. Now, thanks to an anonymous benefactor, that piano is going to the tiny town of Hopkinsville in southwestern Kentucky.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest on Saturday referred erroneously in some editions to an article about criticism of the Connecticut State Treasurer's hiring of a Wall Street firm. The article did not appear in later editions. Readers wishing copies of the article may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1474.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATZEN, MORRIS
description: LATZEN-Morris. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amielwohl, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, BELLA
description: GOLDEN-Bella. The West End Synogogue community mourns the loss of its oldest member. However, Bella Golden, at 101, matriarch of four generations of Reconstructionist Jews, has already passed on to and through her remarkable family her generosity of spirit, her creative talents expressed in her excellent silversmithing, ceramic work and needle arts, her innovative pathfinding, her broad-sweeping educational energy and talents and, not least, the importance of wearing a hat at just the right jaunty angle. Surely her memory will continue to be a blessing; she has already enriched us all. Rabbi Avi Winokur Cantor Kathy J. Barr Donald Shapiro, Chairperson

title: Controversy on Player's Salute to Drug Lords
description: The MetroStars are losing in Major League Soccer, but they are creating news around the world. Yesterday, one day after signing Branco, the famous Brazilian defender, the MetroStars were trying to untangle themselves from an awkward situation involving Antony De Avila, the Colombian striker who plays for them.

title: Police May Have Had Cunanan Address Before Killing
description: As they struggle to find the man suspected of killing five people in four states, the Miami Beach police are now fending off criticism that they may have possessed evidence that could have led them directly to the hotel room of the suspect, Andrew P. Cunanan, days before the killing of Gianni Versace last Tuesday.

title: Just Like His Fastball, Irabu's Temper Simmers
description: Some of the mystery and curiosity that encase Hideki Irabu are evaporating slightly because the Japanese pitcher reveals more about his pitches and about his personality every fascinating day. Not every revelation has been pleasing to George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, who is waiting to see Irabu's commanding fastball and instead was inundated today with questions about Irabu's controversial spitting incident Sunday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALL, MURRY
description: TALL-Murry, 89, of West Palm Beach, Florida. Former President of Aviation Instrument and Gear Corp. Survived by Eunice Tall Baros of North Palm Beach, FL., Bruce Tall of Stuart, FL., and Clifford Tall of Myrtle Beach, S.C., and seven grandchildren.

description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Park Uses Contraception, Not Killing, to Keep Elephants in Check
description: AS the helicopter hovers overhead, the elephant herd scatters through the dry winter brush. But within minutes the cow with a dusty orange radio collar is spotted and a 10-inch-long dart is fired into her left flank. She keeps running for a while but soon slows and then continues her munching, seemingly oblivious.

title: Scientists Explore the Remotest Frontier, Just Off New Jersey
description: THE helicopter flew north past the garish gambling hotels that line the Atlantic City shore, then made a sharp right turn out to sea in search of a different kind of gambling operation. An hour later, some 108 nautical miles east of Atlantic City, a tall derrick suddenly pierced the enveloping cocoon of summer haze, and the helicopter set down a group of reporters on the deck of the Joides Resolution.

title: Foreign Business Pushes Siemens Profits Up 10%
description: Siemens A.G. said yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose a greater-than-expected 10 percent, helped by surging international business. Siemens, Germany's largest electronics and engineering company, said profit for the three months that ended on June 30 rose to 625 million marks ($349 million) from 568 million marks a year earlier.

title: Moderate Bishop Elected To Lead Episcopal Church
description: Leaders of the Episcopal Church, which has struggled with financial difficulties and is deeply divided over issues of homosexuality and traditional church teaching, today elected a scholarly moderate to the denomination's top post.

title: A Nod to the Pope and Polyphony
description: There are a handful of writers, artists and composers who come to each succeeding era like half-empty containers, waiting for the spirit of the times to fill them up and newly reinvent their art. One is Shakespeare, another his contemporary Palestrina, a musician whose presence spreads broadly across this summer's Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Fiat Is Investing $1 Billion in India
description: Fiat, the Italian auto maker, will invest $1 billion in India in the next five years, partly to set up three new factories, the auto maker said yesterday.

title: New Generation of Women Defines Mood of the 90's
description: When the last 50 years in fashion are recorded, the boldface names will largely be written in testosterone-laden ink. Though women are well represented in design, it is primarily men -- from Christian Dior to Karl Lagerfeld, from Norman Norrell to Ralph Lauren -- who have until now shaped fashion and laid claim to its top positions.

title: Telling Tales of Hunger, Abuse and Forced Labor
description: The burly young man from Mexico City told his tale in a Creole tongue that blended Mexican and American sign language with animated gestures and mime. Five years ago, he said, his baby boy was taken from him by the same people who forced him to work from morning until night selling $1 trinkets on the subway. He has scoured the subways in New York, he said, looking for his boy, the one who would now be 6 years old with a red birthmark on his forehead and a mole on his left cheek.

description: From Disciple to Designer

description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan. July 22, 1945-February 21, 1993 The brilliance of your life radiates through every fiber of our being. Time does not diminish its intensity nor dull its focus. On your birthday and every day you continue to be and always will be at the core of our lives.

title: 16 People Are Injured As Bus and Car Collide
description: A city bus collided with a car that ran a red light in Harlem yesterday, injuring 16 people, most of whom suffered minor cuts and bruises, the authorities said.

description: Clarence Richardson, the public defender appointed to represent a 12-year-old boy charged with driving a stolen car, met his client for the first time only a few minutes before the trial began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLEY, MADELON DEVOE
description: TALLEY-Madelon DeVoe, 65; married to Truman M. Talley in 1953, she is also survived by her brother, Raymond F. DeVoe, Jr., and leaves three children, Mrs. Melanie T. Whatley, Macdonald W. Talley and Marina H. Talley. Born in New York City, Mrs. Talley attended Columbia and graduated from Sarah Lawrence. After raising a family, Mrs. Talley began a highly successful career in the business and financial world, published two books, and has had major board positions in a variety of NY financial institutions. In 1995, Mrs. Talley was appointed by Governor Pataki as the Commissioner of the NY/NJ Port Authority. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, July 23rd, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street from 4-7 P.M. A funeral mass will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 84th and Park, on Thursday at 11 A.M. Burial will be private.

title: New C.I.A. Chief Picks Veteran Staff
description: George J. Tenet, after 10 days as Director of Central Intelligence, named his staff today, turning to veterans of cold war spying and former staff members from the White House and from Congress, where Mr. Tenet spent most of his career.

title: Majors Tap Beeston for Post
description: With Paul Beeston's arrival imminent, will Bud Selig be far behind?

title: Underachiever No More, Everett Hits Two Homers
description: Underachiever. Fair or not, that label was hung last year on the Mets' stoic right fielder, Carl Everett.

title: Prosecutors Offer a Chilling Story of Exploitation
description: Federal prosecutors offered a grimly detailed account yesterday of how a band of illegal Mexican immigrants had smuggled deaf Mexicans into New York City for nearly a decade, charging that the smugglers ran an efficient, organized criminal enterprise complete with assigned roles as recruiters, money collectors and enforcers.

title: Crusading TV Station Is the City's Daytime Drama
description: When leftist guerrillas bombed Frecuencia Latina TV here five years ago, killing three employees, the television station's owner, Baruch Ivcher, enclosed the station with a concrete wall 20 feet high and persuaded the Government to post soldiers and tanks outside.

title: Immigrants: In Plain Sight, But Not Seen
description: IF the No. 1 and No. 7 lines were any indication, the subways were free yesterday of deaf Mexicans involved in the silent trade of dropping pens or key chains into passengers' laps in search of a dollar.

description: COLODNEY-Anna (nee Amsterdam). Devoted wife of the late Victor. Loving mother of Naomi Fiekowsky and Seth. Grandmother of David, Richard and Elisabeth. Great-grandmother of Aaron, Rachel, Dylan, Adam and Ariel. Died July 16, 1997. Graveside funeral service held July 18.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Justices Allow Lawsuits Based on a Justifiable Fear of Getting AIDS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court drafted a new standard yesterday for determining when a person is entitled to recover damages for emotional distress caused by a fear of contracting H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The court said it hoped to encourage the public to become better informed about how the disease is transmitted.

title: Boeing Has Its Feet on the Ground
description: In the aerospace business, Boeing seems invincible. By placing big bets on new aircraft and paying close attention to research and engineering, it has grown to dominate its industry by a wide margin. When it has tried to diversify outside the notoriously volatile aircraft industry, though, it has a remarkable history of missing the mark.

title: Navigating in a World of Gentiles
description: THE BACON FANCIER

title: Canadians End Blockade In Salmon-Fishing Dispute
description: Three days after they first blockaded an Alaskan ferry to keep it from leaving port in British Columbia, angry Canadian fishermen locked in an international dispute over rights to fish for salmon in the Pacific northwest pulled their boats away and allowed the ferry to depart late Monday night.

title: OMNIQUIP TO BUY FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL'S SNORKEL UNIT
description: Omniquip International Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Figgie International Inc.'s Snorkel unit for $150 million and assumed debt. The unit, which makes aerial fire equipment and work platforms, had sales of $158 million last year. It employs 900 people in Missouri, Kansas, Australia and New Zealand. The acquisition would give Omniquip, based in Port Washington, Wis., a distribution network and products that are compatible with its telescopic material handling equipment. Figgie, based in Willoughby, Ohio, makes products for the military, firefighting and aviation industries.

title: Chess
description: The model for an untried genius bursting forth is the 23-year-old Jose Raul Capablanca at the San Sebastian International Tournament in Spain in 1911. Some of the luminaries objected to his inclusion, claiming he was not qualified, but Capablanca did not much care. He won the tournament and also took the prize for most brilliant game.

title: Cigarette Caused Forest Fire
description: A forest fire that burned 800 acres in Berkeley and Manchester Townships on Saturday was caused by a carelessly tossed cigarette, the New Jersey Forest Fire Service said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPPERELL, GERALD V.S.
description: PEPPERELL-Gerald V.S., on March 15, 1915 to July 15, 1997, Marine Insurance Executive. Born and educated in Britain, Gerald Pepperell graduated from the University of London. He served in the British Army from 1939 to 1946, rising to the rank of Major and was awarded the Territorial Decoration. He came to the United States with his family in 1953 and became a United States citizen. Active in the marine insurance field, he held many executive positions, including Chairman of the American Marine Underwriters' Association and Vice-Chairman of the International Union of Marine Insurance. He was Chairman and President of Talbot Bird, a subsidiary of Armco, and he held several directorships including Eagle Star Assurance (North America) and Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance. He leaves his wife Margaret, (nee Thomas), his son John (wife Penny) in Toronto, Canada, his daughter, Elisabeth Dietrich (husband Bill) in Gibson Island, MD., and five grandchildren.

title: Sensationalizing Space
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Feud in House Stalls Budget Talks
description: Talks over budget and tax legislation sputtered today as members of both parties said that struggles among House Republican leaders had severely impaired the outlook for agreements between President Clinton and Congress.

title: Zilog Agrees to Be Acquired for $527 Million
description: Zilog Inc., a semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Texas Pacific Group in a deal the companies valued at $527 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGLER, ROBERT
description: NAGLER-Robert. Of Quogue, NY and Santa Barbara, CA. On July 15, 1997. Survived by his wife Ellen; daughter Hilary, son Adam; aunts; cousins; and a world of friends. A memorial service will be held at the Nagler family home in Quogue at 11 AM, Friday, July 25. In lieu of flowers the family would be grateful for contributions to the Nagler Family Scholarship Fund, College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850 or to the Quogue Volunteer Fire Dept, Quogue, N.Y. 11959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, EDYTHE
description: BROWN-Edythe. Beloved wife of the late Nat Brown. Beloved mother of Cedric and Jacqueline Brown and Kenneth and Freya Brown. Beloved sister of Mae Applebaum, Claire Gossett and Jonathan Schneider. Beloved grandmother of five grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Funeral at Parkside Funeral Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park on Wednesday, June 23, at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARD, MARGUERITE COCHRAN
description: SARD-Marguerite Cochran, former wife of the late mathematician Arthur Sard, died in her home June 18, 1997 in Chula Vista, Ca. Marguerite was born in 1910 in Narberth, Pennsylvania, and brought up in Philadelphia where she graduated from Friends Select School. She attended Connecticut College for Women, The University of Wisconsin, The Sorbonne in Paris, and graduated from Barnard College in 1932 with a degree in English Literature. She and Professor Sard lived for nearly forty years in Flushing, New York, where Professor Emeritus Sard taught math at Queens College, until retirement to La Jolla, CA, and association with the UCSD math department. Marguerite lived in La Jolla for seventeen years, Wesley Palms Retirement Home in Pacific Beach for two years, then the past eight years at Fredericka Manor Retirement Home in Chula Vista. Marguerite was a world traveler and was always active in civic and social organizations, being a member of the Queens College Women's Club, the UCSD Oceanids, President of the Cultural Center of La Jolla, President of the San Diego Society of the Archaeological Institute of America, and had associations with various civic organizations and charities. A memorial service will be held Sunday, July 27, 1997, 2:00 PM, at Fredericka Manor's Fellowship Hall in Chula Vista, CA. Phone (619) 422-9271.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELASTRO, LEONARDO (COUNT LEONARDO LAMORIE)
description: ANGELASTRO-Leonardo (Count Leonardo Lamorie), 90, in Salt Lake City. Born Bari, Italy. Dancer, actor in vaudeville, movies, opera. Services today 11 A.M., Lindquist Bountiful Mortuary, Bountiful, UT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMAN, ARTHUR
description: LIMAN-Arthur. The board of trustees and staff of The Museum of Television and Radio mourn the loss of our esteemed board member. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman Robert M. Batscha, President The Museum of Television and Radio

title: Democrats Get to Scrutinize G.O.P. Asian Connection
description: In the first round of the Senate campaign finance hearings, Republicans presented evidence of what they said were Chinese Government links to Democratic fund-raising practices. This week, the Democrats get their chance to claim Republicans also took money from foreign sources, in their case, a Hong Kong businessman.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOLBERG, BEATRICE S.
description: KOLBERG-Beatrice S. Happy Birthday, Aunt Beatrice. Much Love Always.

description: * Bruce G. Silverman was named president of Western International Advocacy Group, Los Angeles, a new division of the Western International Media Corp., owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos. The new unit will provide media services for agencies handling political advertising and cause-related marketing campaigns. Mr. Silverman had most recently been president at Asher/Gould Advertising, Los Angeles.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SILENT TESTIMONY -- Defense lawyers in the murder and racketeering trial of Vincent Gigante rested their case without calling a single witness. B3.

description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Shrew' As Good As Gold
description: And you thought it was a boy beats girl story. It's money -- not love, not the clashing of the sexes -- that makes the world go round in the Stratford Festival production of ''The Taming of the Shrew.'' This is the not entirely unwarranted view set forth by the young director Richard Rose in his lively if overburdened interpretation of the comedy.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier and politician, misspelled the name of his surviving companion. She is Laure Boulay de la Meurthe, not Laura Bouley de la Meurthe.

title: Plaintiff Takes Stand, to Claim a Share of 'Rent'
description: A year and a half after a fledgling musical called ''Rent'' opened off Broadway, a woman who was paid more than $10,000 for collaborating on it took the stand in Federal court yesterday to claim a share of the millions of dollars in profits of what is now a runaway Broadway hit.

title: The Kind of Sweep That Is Hard to Come By
description: Winning four consecutive games isn't so difficult. Teams have had winning streaks of at least four games 85 times this season. All right, the Phillies and the Athletics haven't done it, but we're not talking about teams in the English football system (soccer to Americans) that would be bumped into a lower division because they're so bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURGIS, WARREN
description: STURGIS-Warren. Of Boston, New York City and Southbury, CT. Beloved brother to 3 siblings now deceased and uncle and godfather to many nieces and nephews. Funeral services at 3 P.M., July 26, at Christ Church, Roxbury, CT. Producer of documentary films, worked with ''March of Time'', founded Sturgis-Grant Productions, known for award-winning medical education documentaries. Devoted to family. Gifts may be made to Washington National Cathedral.

title: The Connecting Line
description: In just one day last week three stories were reported that told of the stunning successes the Chinese Politburo has achieved in manipulating America and diminishing it as a credible political player in the Far East.

title: Pharmacia Unit And Gray Part Ways
description: The United States consumer health care unit of Pharmacia & Upjohn in Kalamazoo, Mich., and Grey Advertising in New York said yesterday that they had mutually parted ways on consumer brand advertising for products, including the Rogaine hair loss treatment, ''due to the long-term strategic direction of both companies.'' As a result, those products, with combined billings estimated at $37 million, have been reassigned, without reviews, to two Pharmacia & Upjohn roster agencies.

title: Liberia Gets a Fair Vote, Courtesy of Unfree Neighbors
description: One of the lessons of the Liberian presidential election this weekend seems to be: if you want a free and fair election in Africa, make sure it's run by a police state -- somebody else's.

title: Court Curbs Tax on Business
description: In a unanimous decision, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that business equipment and machinery cannot be taxed by cities and towns.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Shuttle Service to Begin in West 30's
description: Shuttle bus service is to begin today for commuters who work west of Pennsylvania Station, offering free rides during rush hour in a loop along Seventh Avenue, 31st Street, 10th Avenue and 34th Street.

title: Stocks Mostly Fall, Though Dow Is Up
description: Stocks ended mostly lower yesterday, as nervous investors awaited the semiannual appearance of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before Congress. In his two days of testimony, he will detail the central bank's outlook on the economy.

title: Time Warner's New York Blackout
description: Having sanctimoniously assured New Yorkers that its cable system would serve all their viewing needs, Time Warner is now betraying local viewers by denying them live coverage of the Senate hearings on campaign finance abuses. Whatever the business explanations for this lapse, Time Warner's conduct is an abdication of its journalistic and civic responsibilities.

title: Railroad Says Conrail Is Trying to Drive It Out of Business
description: A tiny railroad that floats freight cars on barges across New York Harbor, providing the most direct route for railroad traffic between Brooklyn and New Jersey, has accused Conrail, the region's dominant shipper, of trying to force it out of business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, CHARLES
description: GOLDBERG - Charles. Retired dentist, of Hewlett, L.I., formerly Bronx, NY, July 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Claire, devoted son of the late Tillie & Sam, loving father of Samuel and Ann, Fred and Jan, Irene and Bruce Drantch. Beloved brother of Isidore and Rose, late Ethel and Jules Levy, Sylvia and late Moe. Adoring grandfather of Sara, Todd, Adam, Harris, Aaron and David. Funeral on July 22 at the Parkside Funeral Home, 9860 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, New York at 10 A.M. Mourners will be sitting at the late residence until Friday. Family requests that donations in lieu of flowers be sent to the American Diabetes Association, 1660 Duke Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22314.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES PLANS TO ADD DOBBS AUTOMOTIVE
description: Republic Industries, which owns a large chain of new-vehicle dealerships and is building a nationwide chain of used-car dealerships, agreed yesterday to buy the Dobbs Automotive Group for $200 million in stock. Dobbs, based in Memphis, is the nation's seventh-largest dealer group, according to the 1996 Automotive News Top 100. It includes Buick, Ford, General Motors, Honda, Lexus, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Pontiac and Toyota dealerships in Alabama, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., had revenues of $2.37 billion in 1996.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Decline 1.4% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that open positions on short sales declined 1.4 percent, to 3.39 billion shares, for trades in the month ended July 10 and settled on July 15. The drop was down from last month's record high of 3.44 billion.

title: Norsk Hydro Says Pretax Profit Fell 5%
description: Norsk Hydro A.S., Norway's biggest-listed company by market value, said yesterday that its second-quarter pretax profit fell 5 percent, as higher financial costs and lower fertilizer prices outweighed increased earnings from oil, gas and light metals. Norsk Hydro said pretax profit for the quarter fell to 2.664 billion kroner ($342.5 million), from 2.814 billion in the corresponding quarter last year. The number was below analysts' predictions.

title: Sweeping Aside 1,200 Years to Collaborate
description: European noblemen of a thousand years ago had much more exciting and intelligent entertainment than anything to be found now. Anyone who doubts that need only look in on Benjamin Bagby's astonishing performance of the first quarter of the epic poem ''Beowulf'' -- in Anglo-Saxon, no less -- tonight at the Kaplan Penthouse in Lincoln Center. It will be the last of his three appearances in the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, MRS. ANNE I. (MRS. GUY NORMAN ROBINSON)
description: ROBINSON-Mrs. Anne I. (Mrs. Guy Norman Robinson) of New Canaan, CT. Scott Nicholls, Jr., Treasurer

title: 9.5% Growth In China Stuns Experts Again
description: The Chinese economy is growing at an amazingly fast clip, yet it confounds economists by spurring remarkably little inflation.

description: To the Editor:

description: In New York yesterday, it was announced that Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' longtime cook is writing a cookbook for publication next year.

description: HAMBURG-Frances. The Board of Governors and membership of Tam O'Shanter Club regret the passing of their member Frances Hamburg. Our sincere condolences to her family. Robert Katz, President Donald Freedman, Secretary

title: Fed Chief's Remarks Spur Surge in Bonds
description: Treasury prices surged yesterday and drove yields to their lowest levels in almost eight months after investors took comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to suggest that the Fed would not soon raise interest rates.

title: DREW INDUSTRIES PLANS TO BUY LIPPERT FOR $55 MILLION
description: Drew Industries said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held Lippert Components Inc. for $55 million in cash and stock to expand its manufactured housing and recreational vehicle supply business. Drew, based in White Plains, would pay $27 million in cash and almost 2.2 million shares for Lippert, a maker of chassis, axles, roofing and other parts for manufactured housing and recreational vehicles. The acquisition would give Drew 16 additional plants in 12 states east of the Rocky Mountains. Lippert, based in Alma, Mich., had $107 million in 1996 sales, and the combined companies would have sales of $300 million. Drew's shares rose $1 yesterday, to $14.

title: Immigration Angst
description: Long before gays in the military became a political issue, Americans had adopted a ''don't ask, don't tell'' approach to illegal immigration. Immigrants did not tell because they did not want to be noticed. And the rest of us didn't ask because we knew the details of their passage would turn our stomachs. Some illegal immigrants would eventually realize the American dream, and then their story could be celebrated. But the American dream was not supposed to include forced labor.

title: Wilting? Chill Out In Cold Soup
description: IN the middle of the scorching heat last week, Darcy Wymans stood in line for the only thing that could cool her down. It wasn't ice cream, lemonade or frozen yogurt. It was soup.

title: South Korean Banks Aid Ailing Kia Group
description: The Kia Group will get 160 billion won ($180 million) in emergency loans from creditor banks trying to keep South Korea's eighth-biggest conglomerate afloat. The loans come as Kia announced record car sales thanks to a 30 percent price cut. The group sold 23,584 vehicles on Monday, compared with 27,000 in the whole of June, and 14,000 more vehicles by noon yesterday. Kia was put under bankruptcy protection last week.

title: Yanks Face Moral Issue With Whiten
description: IF the various sports halls of fame banned drunks, drug addicts, wife beaters, check bouncers, philanderers, racists, bullies, foulmouths, sneak punchers and general misanthropes, you would have yawning gaps in Cooperstown, Canton, Springfield and Toronto.

title: Memory Falters in Lawsuit for 'Rent' Royalties
description: Although she is suing for a share of the royalties from ''Rent,'' which could reach as high as $250 million, a woman seeking recognition as the co-author of the smash Broadway rock musical had difficulty in Federal court yesterday recalling the words to songs she said she had contributed.

title: Trapped in the Old World's Arias and Plots
description: One of the tragedies of American music in the last 50 years has been the failure of the great flowering of opera companies to contribute to a great flowering of opera composition. Under such circumstances, an adventurous company -- a company that wants to revive something of roughly our time and place -- has very little repertory from which to choose. Enter ''Vanessa.''

title: Would Che Have Turned Capitalist? Never!
description: To the Editor:

description: BIAGGI-Marie (nee Wassil), July 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Mario. Loving mother of Jacqueline, Barbara, Richard (Toni) and Mario (Carol). Cherished grandmother of eleven. Dear sister of Neil and Jerry Wassil. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc, 201st Street and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Wed. and Thurs., 2-5 and 79 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 10AM, Fordham University Chapel. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Philip Neri Restoration Fund, 3025 Grand Concourse, Bx. 10468, would be appreciated.

title: 'Candide' to Close
description: ''Candide,'' a new production of Leonard Bernstein's musical with book by Hugh Wheeler and lyrics by Richard Wilbur, Stephen Sondheim and John LaTouche, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street, Manhattan. It will be the 103d regular performance of the play, directed by Harold Prince and starring Jim Dale; it had 11 previews.

description: To the Editor:

title: Tyco Toys Goes To Mattel Roster
description: Mattel Inc., the toy maker in El Segundo, Calif., said yesterday that as expected it had divided responsibilities for its newly acquired domestic Tyco Toys business among its three roster shops: Foote, Cone & Belding in Los Angeles, Ogilvy & Mather Los Angeles and the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALM, ANNE
description: PALM-Anne. Passed away on Saturday, July 19, 1997. Pre-deceased by her husband Charles Palm and brother Joseph Klempka. Survived by one son and daughter-inlaw Greg and Marie Palm of London, England and Summit, N.J. Two granddaughters: Jennifer Palm of New York and Katherine Palm of Summit, N.J. Funeral services will be held Friday, July 25, 9:15 A.M., at Bednarsky Funeral Home, Inc., 96 Glenwood Ave, Binghamton, N.Y. and at 9:30AM at St. Joseph's Church. Burial will be in Vestal Hills Memorial Park. Family will receive friends Thursday from 7 to 9PM at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIRSTEIN, KENNETH SCOTT, MD.
description: KIRSTEIN-Kenneth Scott, MD. May 24, 1950 to July 23, 1993. Four long years, the most desolate of my life. Light of my life, bless you as often as the hours have been endless to me since you've been gone. Love forever, Tom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, WINNIFRED
description: JAFFE-Winnifred. After a long illness, Winnifred Jaffe passed away on July 21, 1997. She was born October 16, 1898 and spent almost half a century in education. Her educational degrees were from Teacher's College, Columbia University. Her teaching was almost entirely in Ridgefield, N.J. She is survived by her brother Dr. William J. Jaffe. Her late parents were Elias & Ida Rosensohn Jaffe. Her late brother and sister were Dr. John Jaffe and Sophie G. Jaffe. Services at Gutterman's, Wednesday 9:30 AM, 331 Amsterdam Avenue near W. 76th St, NYC.

title: A Pay Raise Plan Is Protested
description: The Bergen County Board of Freeholders is poised to give itself a pay raise today amid protests from a labor union representing county workers, which was offered a less substantial pay raise earlier this year.

title: Start-up and low-fare airlines continue to remain out of favor for corporate fliers, despite savings.
description: AFTER the Valujet crash in the Florida Everglades in May 1996, many travelers started booking away from not only Valujet, but also many other start-up, low-fare airlines. A new survey suggests that they remain out of favor with corporate travel managers.

title: Volvo Profits Rise 48%, Aided by Asset Sales
description: Volvo A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 48 percent as strong car sales and asset sales outweighed losses in its United States truck division. Profit rose to 1.96 billion kronor ($252 million), from 1.325 billion a year earlier.

title: EXIDE ELECTRONICS' BOARD REJECTS DANAHER BUYOUT OFFER
description: The board of Exide Electronics Group Inc. had decided to reject an offer of $20 a share, or about $200 million, from the Danaher Corporation and is considering an alternative transaction with an undisclosed third party. In a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Exide, based in Raleigh, N.C., said the board met on Monday and officially recommended that shareholders reject the offer. In addition, the board said it had entered into confidentiality agreements with certain third parties about a potential sale or merger.

title: Madelon Talley, 65, a Pioneer On Male-Dominated Wall Street
description: Madelon DeVoe Talley, an investment manager who was one of Wall Street's first female executives, died Friday in a car accident near Wyndam, N.Y., her husband, Truman M. Talley, said. She was 65.

title: Old West and Reality: A Showdown
description: Among his other shady accomplishments, Jesse James was a master at spinning his own image. ''Outlaws,'' an episode of ''American Justice'' about the real lives behind Western legends, recalls that James once wrote his own press release about a train robbery, in advance. Before riding away from the train, he handed the conductor the release and told him to fill in the amount of money the James gang had made off with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOLAFIA, BONNIE
description: ABOLAFIA-Bonnie. After a hardfought, 2 year battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Morris, loving mother of Corinne and Jane, cherished daughter of Estelle and Joseph Goldsmith, dear sister of Jeff Goldsmith. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10 A.M. Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINSKY, GERTRUDE
description: MINSKY-Gertrude. Gertrude Minsky passed away peacefully July 21, 1997. She was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Arthur Minsky; the most wonderful mother to Joan Minsky and Ann and Mark Levitt; a kind, wise and nurturing grandmother to Emily Jacobs, Stefanie Jacobs, Jennifer Levitt and Jason Levitt. Gertrude was a friend to everyone she knew radiating love and graciousness. She gave new meaning to the term generous, in every sense of the word. title: Can Polyphony Be Pious as Well as Beautiful? An Opera Argues for Aye
description: What does a Christian God expect of music? Emulation, thought the 16th-century liturgical composer Palestrina. Nature has its biological and physical symmetries; I shall create my own Garden of Eden in sound. Submission, thought Palestrina's papal contemporaries as they plotted the Counter-Reformation at the Council of Trent. Music is only a street, smooth and unadorned, along which the Word of God is meant to pass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISLEY, WILLIAM H.
description: RISLEY-William H., 80, of Prospect St. in Litchfield, died early Monday morning. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 18, 1917, son of the late Dr. Harry and Emma (Smith) Risley. He graduated from the Taft School in 1935 and Dartmouth College in 1939. Following military service during World War II, Mr. Risley worked as an executive for Pan American Airways for 22 years. He was the founder of Sailfish Sportscraft of Canada and Italy, and later Travel Consultants of Litchfield. He served as an officer of the First National Bank of Litchfield. Mr. Risley was devoted to his community. He served as president and chairman of the White Memorial Foundation, as a director and treasurer of the Grafton Pond Land Trust, as trustee, planning committee member, chairman of the old boy challenge and 1996 recipient of the Citation of Merit at the Taft School, and as a trustee of Old Sturbridge Village. Mr. Risley was active in a number of clubs. He was a past president of the Litchfield Country Club and the Osler Bluff Ski Club of Canada. He held memberships in the following organizations: the Moorings Club and the Vero Beach Country Club of Florida, the Dartmouth Club of New York, the Sanctum of Litchfield, the Washington Rod and Gun Club, the Connecticut Historical Society, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Pops, the Raleigh Tavern Society, the Audubon Society of New Hampshire, the Antiquarian & Landmarks Society, the Heritage Foundation, the Republican National Committee and the Republican Presidential Task Force. He leaves his daughter, Mary Snyder Risley of San Francisco; two sons, William Snyder Risley of Washington, CT, and John Taylor Risley of East Longmeadow, MA; two step-sons, Dr. Charles Joseph de Sieyes of Falmouth, Maine and David Conroy de Sieyes of Hamilton, MA; and eight grandchildren, Rebecca, Emma, Matthew, Mary, Nicholas, Evan, Malcolm, Charlotte. A memorial service will be held on Thursday at 3:30 P.M. at the First Congregational Church, Litchfield. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the White Memorial Conservation Center, 71 Whitehall Road, Post Office Box 368, Litchfield, CT. 06759.

title: The Biggest Acting Job of All: Self-Deception

Like Joe Buck of ''Midnight Cowboy,'' which Mr. Arteta consciously evokes with his hero's first bus ride, Carlos thinks charm and a can-do attitude are enough to get him anywhere. Dazzled by daydreams of Hollywood, Carlos feels boyishly invincible. He doesn't even mind the fact that a like-minded fool can be found on every corner.

title: Diplomacy and Religious Tyranny
description: The Clinton Administration and Congress have become quite skillful at identifying human rights abuses around the world while not doing enough to end them. The latest manifestation of this troubling habit is a new State Department report on the persecution of Christian groups abroad. The study's emphasis on religious intolerance is heartening. But the purpose of the project has less to do with changing American policy toward repressive countries than scoring political points at home.

title: STANDARD MOTOR AND COOPER TO SWAP SOME BUSINESSES
description: Standard Motor Products Inc. agreed yesterday to swap its brake business for Cooper Industries' temperature control business. The deal would include an exchange of assets, assumption of liabilities and possibly a cash payment. Cooper's temperature control business includes heating and cooling system parts and electric motors. Standard's brake business includes hydraulic and friction products and drums and rotors. Standard Motor, a replacement auto-parts maker in Long Island City, Queens, had 1996 sales of $721.8 million. The Houston-based Cooper, an electrical products and tool company, had 1996 revenues of $5.31 billion.

title: WYNDHAM HOTEL AGREES TO ACQUIRE CLUBHOUSE HOTELS
description: The Wyndham Hotel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Clubhouse Hotels Inc., a chain of 17 hotels, for $49.1 million in Wyndham stock, $54.1 million in cash and $26.8 million in assumed Clubhouse debt. Under the agreement, Clubhouse, based in Kansas City, Mo., would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Wyndham, which is based in Dallas. Wyndham plans to convert at least seven of the 17 Clubhouse properties into Wyndham Garden Hotels in six months, after $10 million in renovations.

The handguns used to kill the deliverymen, Jeremy Giordano and Georgio Gallara, had been stolen after a brick was hurled through a gun shop window, the authorities said.

The Board of Directors, Board of Education, Faculty and Students of The Hebrew Academy of Nassau County (HANC) mourn the loss Monday, July 21, of long time friend, Samuel Golding-Shmuel Ben Yosef. An attorney at law, intellect, philanthropist, honorary member of The HANC Board of Directors, Samuel Golding's energies were directed toward the furtherance of education. His generous support helped bring to fruition the dream of a HANC elementary and nursery school in the West Hempstead community-The Samuel and Elizabeth Bass Golding Elementary School and The Samuel and Elizabeth Bass Golding Early Childhood Center. Samuel Golding's philanthropy was not limited to HANC. Samuel Golding was grandfather to HANC's thousands of graduates. His sage advice and caring will be missed by his HANC family. He is survived by his dear wife, the Honorable Elizabeth Bass Golding. May the memory of Samuel Golding be blessed, and may we merit to carry on his memory through the children of The Hebrew Academy of Nassau County. title: The Lost Vesuvian Library
description: Everyone knows about Pompeii, but in some ways the more interesting ancient site is Herculaneum, the smaller town nearby that was also entombed when Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 A.D. Writing 30 years ago, Frank Brown, director of the American Academy in Rome, called Herculaneum ''archeology's most flagrant unfinished business.'' The city has never been properly exhumed, partly because it was buried under 60 feet of hot mud lava, while Pompeii was engulfed by volcanic ash.

title: Senator Heading Inquiry Attacks Justice Dept.
description: The chairman of the Senate committee investigating campaign finances accused the Justice Department today of engaging in ''a hopeless conflict of interest'' by opposing a Republican plan to grant immunity from prosecution to five prospective witnesses, including four Buddhist nuns, who may have given money that was not their own to the Democratic Party.

description: New York City's unemployment rate rose to 10 percent last month, up from 9.6 percent in May, the State Department of Labor said yesterday. title: APPLE HIRES HEIDRICK & STRUGGLES FOR EXECUTIVE SEARCH
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Heidrick & Struggles Inc., an executive search firm based in Chicago, to help the struggling computer maker find a new chief executive. The company said it could not commit to a specific time frame, but such a search ''is typically expected to take about 90 days.'' Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., said Heidrick & Struggles would work closely with a search committee established by the company's board. Earlier this month, Apple removed Gilbert F. Amelio as chairman and chief executive.

description: A television is attached to a wall in the visitors' clubhouse here, just above the door to the manager's office. Assuming one of the Mets overheard a score or saw a highlight, the team took the field against the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight knowing it could pass Florida in the National League standing -- the Marlins had lost in the Eastern time zone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIND, SAMUEL M.
description: KIND-Samuel M., 68, died Sunday, July 13, 1997 at Bowman Gray Hospital in Winston-Salem, NC. He was born and raised in Trenton, NJ, and retired to Hendersonville, NC in 1994. He was the son of the late Leo Kind & Claire Sugarman Kind, of Trenton, New Jersey. Sam was preceded in death by his brother, Ira Kind. He is survived by his wife, Dana Kind, his son, Richard Kind, his daughter, Joanne Kind Hinton; two stepdaughters, Holly Bosshard and Natasha Rana; five grandchildren, 3 nieces and their 5 children. Sam was a graduate of Valley Forge Military Academy and Rutgers University. After serving in Korea in 1956, he acquired LaVake Jewelers in Princeton, New Jersey, where he ran a flourishing business for 38 years. He was extremely active in his community. In Princeton, he was on the Board of the Trinity Counseling Service for 9 years and was its President in 1993. He also served on the Boards of Directors of the Medical Center at Princeton, United Jersey Banks, Greenacres Country Club, and the Princeton Borough Merchants Association. He served in Rotary, the Chamber of Commerce, and was a member of the American Gemological Society. In North Carolina, Sam was one of the first two resident Board members of the Champion Hills Club, and was a volunteer for the Henderson County Literacy Council. Sam was an avid golfer and bridge player. Sam's parents were founding members of the Har Sinai Temple in Trenton, and Sam was a member until he moved to North Carolina, at which time he joined the Agudas Israel Synagogue. Memorials may be made to the Trinity Counseling Service, 22 Stockton Street, Princeton, New Jersey, 08542; or to the Har Sinai Temple Social Action Fund, 491 Bellevue Avenue, Trenton, N.J. 08618.

title: Nurses' Strike Is Delayed in Hope of New Talks
description: The 600 nurses at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn have postponed a strike that was to begin at 7 A.M. today. The union delayed the strike because it had expected to resume negotiations at a meeting on Monday with a Federal mediator. But hospital officials did not show up for the meeting.

title: Rattling Rhythms of Africa
description: Toward the end of Sunday afternoon, Omar Pene and Super Diamono of Senegal hit the stage in Prospect Park. Suddenly, the day changed. The music became choppy, and the band magically shifted rhythms, switching from one to another. And the group's percussionist, Thio Mibaye, improvising on seven drums with his hand and a green stick, somewhere between a twig and a branch, propelled the music with rattling, challenging rhythms.

title: Court Says Priest May Be Sued
description: An Episcopal priest who is accused of engaging in intimate sexual behavior with a parishioner while he was counseling her can be sued for breach of trust, the New Jersey Supreme Court held yesterday.

title: Print and outdoor ads in Nike's new campaign point consumers to a jog on the Internet.
description: THE athletic footwear giant Nike Inc. is trying to bolster its ''street'' credentials by going one on one with consumers on line. An extensive print and outdoor-media campaign begun in June eschews Nike's evocation of the emotional drama of sports to focus instead on interactivity. Rather than portraying athletes wearing Nike's ubiquitous logo, the advertisements, by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., feature photographs of Nike sneakers accompanied by E-mail addresses that refer slyly to the marquee athletes who endorse the shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLEY, MADELON DEVOE
description: TALLEY-Madelon DeVoe, 65; married to Truman M. Talley in 1953, she is also survived by her brother, Raymond F. DeVoe, Jr., and leaves three children, Mrs. Melanie T. Whatley, Macdonald W. Talley and Marina H. Talley. Born in New York City, Mrs. Talley attended Columbia and graduated from Sarah Lawrence. After raising a family, Mrs. Talley began a highly successful career in the business and financial world, published two books, and has had major board positions in a variety of NY financial institutions. In 1995, Mrs. Talley was appointed by Governor Pataki as a Commissioner of the NY/NJ Port Authority. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, July 23rd, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street from 4-7 P.M. A funeral mass will be held at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, 84th and Park, on Thursday at 11 A.M. Burial will be private.

title: Stocks Rally On Comments By Greenspan
description: Stocks soared to record levels again yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told investors just what they wanted to hear: There is no imminent threat of a rise in interest rates.

title: A Blur of Beards, Breasts, Balloons and a Baton
description: Operagoers must have done a lot of head-scratching in 1947. While the Baltimore Opera was presenting a 50th-anniversary production of Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein's enigmatic ''Mother of Us All'' over the weekend, as reported here earlier, the Tanglewood Music Center offered a 50th-anniversary production of Francis Poulenc's absurdist ''Mamelles de Tiresias.''

title: North Korea May Let Japanese Go Back Home
description: Keiko Nakasuji is still haunted by what happened when she saw her mother for the first time in 26 years. Her mother had moved to North Korea in 1966 with her second husband, who was Korean. After years of pleading, Mrs. Nakasuji was allowed to visit her in the rigidly controlled Communist nation.

title: Egypt's Big Deal With U.S. Reverses a Slump in Wheat
description: Wheat prices rose yesterday after Egypt bought grain from the United States, bolstering expectations that exports could pick up after a slow start this year.

title: Corn Adds Crunch to a Sesame Noodle Dish
description: Sesame noodles are ubiquitous. They can be found at practically every carryout and salad counter, in addition to almost every Chinese restaurant. What started out as a simple variation with shrimp became more elaborate when the local corn looked so appealing. It added the right crunch and a summery sweetness. Tomatoes, barely dressed, are a perfect accompaniment.

description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that Marc Shapiro, chairman and chief executive of its Texas Commerce Bank N.A. subsidiary, had been named vice chairman for finance and risk management of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: 16 Arrests in Drug Case
description: Federal agents staged a series of predawn raids yesterday and arrested 16 members of a heavily armed gang accused of selling heroin, cocaine and weapons, including semi-automatic rifles, from a public housing project in Newark's Central Ward. Since at least January 1996, the loosely knit gang, which apparently worked without a leader, sold thousands of dollars' worth of guns and drugs in and around the Baxter Terrace Houses, said Garey Chin, an assistant special agent in charge of the F.B.I.'s Newark office. Four more suspects were being sought, said Agent Chin.

title: LVMH Juggles Stakes In 2 British Companies
description: LVMH has sold some of its stake in Guinness P.L.C. to buy more shares of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. in a bid to exert more influence over the British companies' planned merger, people familiar with the plans of LVMH, the French luxury-goods company, said yesterday. LVMH's chief executive, Bernard Arnault, whose company owned 14.2 percent of Guinness and 6.4 percent of Grand Met on Monday, is said to want 10 percent of each company. That would let him call special shareholder meetings to push his plan to merge their liquor businesses with LVMH's Moet Hennessy Champagne and Cognac unit.

title: Italy Convicts Ex-SS Officers In '44 Killings
description: An Italian military court handed out jail sentences to two German former SS officers yesterday for their part in a massacre of civilians outside Rome in 1944, in another chapter in the longest running, most emotionally charged and legally contentious of Italy's war crimes trials.

There are not only sweet cherries, but also, for the next couple of weeks, sour cherries; both are about $3 a pound, or $4 to $5 a quart. The freshest ones have green stems.
