description: WHAT is chablis? It depends. According to one definition, it is a French white wine named after the town southwest of Paris where it is made. But in the United States, it can be anything a winemaker wants it to be, and an obscure provision in the tax bill the Senate is considering makes sure things stay that way.

title: 2d-Quarter Net at Pepsico Matches Street Expectations
description: Buoyed by gains in its soon-to-be-spun-off restaurant business, Pepsico Inc. matched analysts' earnings expectations in the second quarter, despite slowed growth in the company's Frito-Lay snack-food business and sluggish beverage profits.

title: A Hearing for Whiten Is Delayed by Inquiry

description: For nearly three years, ever since 22,000 American soldiers landed here to restore then-President Jean Bertrand Aristide to power, foreign troops have been an accustomed part of the Haitian landscape.

The picnic is for 70 members of the New York Grand Opera Guild, the organization of supporters and benefactors of the opera, not for members of the company itself.

title: Whitman Called Bond Rater's Parent for Meeting on Debt Plan
description: Faced with criticism from the Standard & Poor's Corporation last May over her plan to borrow billions of dollars for the state pension system, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman called the president of the company that owns the bond rating agency to express her concern and to ask that the state get another chance to make its case.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIDDLE, GRACE
description: RIDDLE-Grace. July 23, 1996, of Princeton, NJ. Mother of George & Adele. Grandmother of Margaret, Adele, George. Sister of Harriet Brown. Dear friend of Jennie Marinella. Second only to the love of family, her vibrant and enthusiastic approach to life and love of NYC are sadly missed. Mrs. Riddle was known professionally in the theater as Rita Newton.

title: Abuse Charge Clouds Utah Organizer's Future
description: Serious questions have arisen about whether Thomas K. Welch, chief organizer of the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City, will keep his job after being charged on Monday with battery against his wife, according to Olympic officials.

title: President Offers to Back Congress in Effort to Reduce Costs of Medicare Program
description: In a push to achieve long-range savings in the Medicare program, President Clinton today vowed to ''defend the vote of any member of Congress, Democrat or Republican,'' who supported raising premiums for the affluent elderly.

title: Report Outlines Unsafe Conditions In Welfare Offices
description: New York City is spending nearly $8 million a year to lease welfare offices with faulty elevators, leaky roofs, exposed wires and rats, a report released yesterday by the Office of the Public Advocate said.

title: B.A.T. to Pay $1 Billion In Mexico Cigarette Deal
description: B.A.T. Industries agreed yesterday to buy a controlling stake in Empresas La Moderna S.A.'s cigarette unit for $1 billion in cash and the assumption of $212 million in debt of the unit, Cigarrera La Moderna. An additional $500 million would be paid three years after the closing. The move would give B.A.T. control of a company that makes 50 percent of the 47 billion cigarettes sold annually in Mexico, the world's 15th-largest cigarette market.

title: Johnson's Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Words, Or Policies, Protect Immigrants?
description: In the days since 57 deaf Mexicans were discovered in virtual bondage in Jackson Heights, Queens, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has positioned himself as their staunchest protector, denouncing the ignoble conditions that they endured and all but acting as their lawyer before Federal immigration authorities.

title: Messier Talks Take a Turn for the Better
description: The contract negotiations between the Rangers and Mark Messier, which produced a series of unpleasant charges and countercharges last week, have warmed up this week, clearing the way for the hockey team to re-sign its 36-year-old captain and center soon.

title: Unicef Tells How Half the World Lacks Even Basic Sanitation
description: Nearly three billion people, more than half the world's population, do not have access to even a minimally sanitary toilet, Unicef said in a report today, adding that this lack of basic hygiene contributes significantly to the spread of new plagues, the resurgence of old diseases, and the deaths from diarrhea or related illnesses of 2.2 million children a year.

title: Yeltsin Vetoes Curb on Religions But Could Face an Override Vote
description: Defying Parliament and the powerful Russian Orthodox Church, President Boris N. Yeltsin today rejected a bill that would sharply curtail religious freedom in Russia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MILLS CORP., Arlington, Va., and Simon DeBartolo Group Inc., of Indianapolis, said they had bought 165 acres of land near Charlotte, N.C., on which they plan to develop a $180 million, 1.4-million-square-foot factory-outlet- style shopping mall.

title: Rationality in Crack Sentencing
description: President Clinton took a step toward fairer drug sentencing yesterday when he proposed narrowing the disparity that treats crimes involving crack cocaine, popular in poor black neighborhoods, 100 times as harshly as crimes involving powdered cocaine, popular among whites. The change had been recommended by Attorney General Janet Reno and the White House drug policy director. The challenge now is to persuade Congress, which established the extreme 100-to-1 sentencing ratio 11 years ago, to rectify its mistake.

title: Bruno Zehnder, Photographer, 52, Is Dead
description: Bruno Zehnder, an adventurous Swiss photographer best known for his striking images of penguins and other wildlife, died earlier this month when he lost his way in a blizzard while trying to return to the Russian base at Mirnyy, Antarctica. He was 52 and lived in Manhattan.

Dear grandmother of Jennifer and Lauren Silbert, Eli & Adam Cook, and Joshua Streit. Private service at Mount Ararat Cemetery. Shiva on Thursday and Friday 6-9 PM, at 10 UpperCross Way, Shoreham. A memorial service celebrating Shirley's life will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the ''Shirley Silbert Memorial Scholarship Fund for Teachers'', Lesley College, 29 Everett St., Cambridge, Mass. 02138-2790. For information Rocky Point Funeral Home, Inc., Rocky Point, NY.

title: The Cosby Case Nears a Close With a Dispute Over Which One Is the Real Victim
description: In closing arguments at the trial of Autumn Jackson, the 22-year-old woman charged with trying to extort money from Bill Cosby, prosecutors and defense lawyers clashed over whether Ms. Jackson's actions constituted extortion -- and who was the real victim in the case.

title: Telecommunications Concerns Top Estimates
description: The telecommunications industry's twin pistons of growth -- wireless telephones and the Internet -- fired robust quarterly financial reports yesterday from the Northeast's two largest local telephone companies and from Northern Telecom of Canada, a major maker of telecommunications equipment.

title: When Morphine Fails to Kill
description: PROPONENTS of assisted suicide often argue that when a doctor helps a patient who wants to die, it is no more ethically troubling than when a doctor kills a patient slowly with morphine, often without the patient's knowledge or consent, a medical practice these proponents say is increasingly common. So why forbid doctors to prescribe lethal pills that could allow patients to control how and when they die?

title: MAIDENFORM AND NCC INDUSTRIES FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Maidenform Worldwide Inc. and NCC Industries said yesterday that they were filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as the companies restructure their operations. The news comes three months after the VF Corporation, the largest United States jeans maker, based in Wyomissing, Pa., said it had ended talks to buy the closely held Maidenform. The New York-based Maidenform bought 92 percent of NCC Industries, a publicly traded maker of intimate clothing based in Cortland, N.Y., two years ago. Maidenform, with about $400 million in annual revenue, said it expected to receive $50 million in financing from its primary lending group as it cuts costs and streamlined its seven divisions into two.

title: Isles' Ex-owner Faces Charges Over Purchase
description: John Spano returned from a business trip to the Cayman Islands yesterday and is expected to appear at an arraignment today in Federal court on Long Island on criminal charges stemming from his abortive purchase of the Islanders.

title: Indonesian Currency Surges on Support Vow
description: The Indonesian rupiah surged as much as 2.4 percent against the United States dollar yesterday as a Government minister pledged to maintain the trading system for the currency. After a meeting with President Suharto, the Minister of Finance, Marie Muhammad, said Indonesia would not change its policy of a managed floating rate for the rupiah.

title: Swiss Find More Bank Accounts From the War, and Publish List
description: Under mounting international pressure, Switzerland's major banks are publishing a list today of roughly 2,000 dormant World War II-era accounts that may include the assets of Holocaust victims. The list names more than twice the number of such accounts that the banks said they had identified as recently as 1996.

title: Italy Is Selling Yellow-Pages Publisher
description: The Italian Treasury said today that it would sell the yellow-pages publisher Seat S.p.A. to a group headed by Banca Commerciale Italiana S.p.A., rejecting a bid from the ITT Corporation of the United States.

title: Golota Should Fight Lewis in October
description: ANDREW GOLOTA, whose Aug. 16 fight against RAY MERCER was postponed, is expected to face LENNOX LEWIS, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, on Oct. 4 at the Atlantic City Convention Hall, said DINO DUVA, Golota's promoter.

title: Help for Minor Parties

But under a decision handed down on Monday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, nontraditional parties will have more time to circulate their petitions in the hope of getting on the ballot.

Continued practicing until his death at East Harlem and Riverside Clinics in Manhattan. Graduate NYU Medical School, 1936. Former Major, U.S. Army World War II, Fellow American College of Surgeons, American Urological Association, American Board of Urology. Affiliated with LI Hospital. Active member City Athletic Club. Viewing Wednesday, 7-9PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel. Funeral services Thursday, Noon, at Riverside Chapel.

title: President to Defend G.O.P. on Medicare
description: In a push to achieve long-range savings in the Medicare program, President Clinton vowed to ''defend the vote of any member of Congress, Democrat or Republican,'' who supported a Senate plan to raise premiums for the affluent elderly. Mr. Clinton sought to reassure House Republicans who feared that adopting the proposed savings would make them vulnerable to Democratic attacks in the 1998 Congressional campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, THOMAS MELLON, SR.
description: EVANS-Thomas Mellon, Sr. St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center-trustees, administration, physicians and staff-extends deepest sympathy to the family of its esteemed former trustee whose distinguished service contributed significantly to the success of the merger that created the Hospital Center in 1979. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman Ronald C. Ablow, MD, President

title: Restrained In All but The Feeling
description: Gal Costa, the Brazilian singer who opened the Expresiones Latinas series at Avery Fisher Hall as part of Lincoln Center Festival '97 on Monday night, is an oddly perfect interpreter. She's always in tune, and even the most difficult phrases never trip over their own feet; she's unfailingly swinging. Her arrangements and the small acoustic band that plays them let silence gush between the instruments, giving the music a profound clarity. And though she's obviously a virtuoso, she never relies on her athletic abilities, instead using restraint, the colors of her voice and a song's melody to let the emotional currents of a song surge.

title: Summer Recipes for Shrimp: Looking Beyond the Cocktail
description: SHRIMP is one of the country's favorite foods, particularly in summer. Just think of cocktail parties to get an idea of how much is consumed. Shrimp can be barbecued, boiled, steamed, grilled, broiled, roasted, sauteed or braised. They are compatible with dishes from almost every ethnic group and are delicious hot or cold, turning up in soups, stews or salads. And as a boon to the hot and frazzled cook, they can be bought already cooked and cleaned.

title: Fassel Blunt in Defense Of Brown as No. 1 Man
description: Jim Fassel was a few minutes into his tenure as Giants coach when he announced that Dave Brown would be his starting quarterback. He believed in Brown, and he took this step with the fervid hope it would avoid a preseason quarterback controversy.

title: Whiten Rejoins Team But Does Not Play
description: Mark Whiten was at Yankee Stadium yesterday and in uniform for the first time since he was arrested Monday in Milwaukee in an investigation into an alleged sexual assault on a 31-year-old woman at the Pfister Hotel there.

title: Citicorp to Add Web Site
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it had hired a New York company to build ''virtual communities'' on the Internet as a new way to communicate with customers worldwide.

title: Giuliani Says Messinger's Budget Plan Would Require Cutting Police Force by 7,000 Officers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani described Ruth W. Messinger's plan for a $1.1 billion reduction in city spending yesterday as a ''really jerky set of proposals,'' and said that the savings she outlined for the Police Department would force a cut of 7,000 officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESLOW, ERNEST
description: CHESLOW-Ernest, of Edison, NJ, on 7/23/97. Husband of the late Mildred (d. 1996). Father of Joseph, Jeffrey, and Dr. Edward Cheslow. Brother of Morris, Bernard, and Anne Luffman. Grandfather of 3 and great grandfather of one. Graveside services will be today, at 11:00 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York. Contributions may be made to Broome-Tioga Arc., 901 Front Street, Binghamton, New York 13905. For information Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, New Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: A Wall of Reassurance
description: WHEN adults want privacy from a child, how can they separate their domain without entirely disappearing from view? That was the question facing David Gauld, a Manhattan architect, whose client was about to marry a woman with a young child and combine his apartment with one next door. ''He wanted the old apartment to be the master bedroom-home office suite and the new one to be the living room, kitchen and child's room,'' Mr. Gauld said. So he divided the two wings with a wall filled with sand-blasted glass windows. When the couple disappear behind it, the young girl can see the lights and know they are there, as if the wall were a very large night light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANNER, RAY L.
description: KANNER-Ray L. Loving wife of the late Irving. Beloved mother of Elissa (Morton) Baum and Cynthia Silverman of Toronto. Devoted sister of Harriet (Sophie) Kurzon. Cherished grandmother of Simeon and Duffie, Deborah, Seth and Laura, Daniel, Dara, David and Derek. Adored greatgrandmother of Jason, Sabrina, Jared, Gabrielle, Isadora and Kyra. Services Friday, July 25, 1997, 9:30 A.M., at Gutterman's Inc., (Riverside Building) 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

title: NATO and Russia Move Toward Arms Cutback
description: The United States, Russia and 28 other nations agreed today on the framework for a treaty to reduce the number of tanks and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe, especially in Central European countries of the former Warsaw Pact.

title: Deal With Time Warner Would Bring Fox News to the City by October
description: Time Warner Inc. and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said yesterday that they had signed a widely anticipated agreement that will give Mr. Murdoch's Fox News channel access to Time Warner's cable system in the city.

title: People
description: * Ric Militi, senior vice president for integrated marketing at Lois/EJL, Los Angeles, a unit of Lois/USA, was named to head a new Lois integrated marketing company, Year 2K Communications, as president.

title: Greenspan Silence on Stocks Speaks Volumes to Investors
description: He was concerned about the lofty level of stock prices when the Dow was at 6,400 late last year. But when Alan Greenspan assessed the economy for Congress this week, he hardly mentioned Wall Street -- never mind that stocks were bursting through 8,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINSKY, GERTRUDE
description: MINSKY-Gertrude. In Loving Memory of Your Beloved Mother & Grandmother, Gertrude MinskyAnn, Mark, Jennifer and Jason. With our heartfelt sympathy, Mona and Artie.

title: Strike Closes Parts Factory In Job Dispute
description: This has been the year of strikes at the General Motors Corporation, a series of contests pitting a union determined to keep the company from downsizing against a bloated auto maker struggling to get in shape as more and more customers buy from G.M.'s more efficient competitors.

title: Fire Damages 2 Museums at Trocadero in Paris
description: France's Museum of Monuments and Museum of Cinema were damaged by water and burning debris after a fire started on Tuesday night and swept across the roof of the east wing of the Palais de Chaillot in the Place du Trocadero, across the Seine from the Eiffel Tower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERT, SHIRLEY JANE (NEE HALPER)
description: SILBERT-Shirley Jane (nee Halper), of Pembroke Pines, Fla. and Ridge, NY, suddenly July 20, 1997 in her 76th year. Beloved wife of Mitchell. Loving mother of Alan, Joan, & Carol. Dear grandmother of Jennifer and Lauren Silbert, Eli & Adam Cook, and Joshua Streit. Private service at Mount Ararat Cemetery. Shiva on Thursday and Friday 6-9 PM, at 10 UpperCross Way, Shoreham. A memorial service celebrating Shirley's life will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the ''Shirley Silbert Memorial Scholarship Fund for Teachers'', Lesley College, 29 Everett St., Cambridge, Mass. 02138-2790. For information Rocky Point Funeral Home, Inc., Rocky Point, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday, and in late editions on Sunday, about Dr. Thomas H. Meikle Jr., a medical educator, misstated the surname of a surviving daughter. She is Margaret Winterkorn-Meikle, not Meikle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABCOCK, MARTHA PEASE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, PETER J.
description: MCCABE-Peter J. On July 23rd. 45 years old. Beloved husband of Kathleen Comfrey. Loving father of Peter and Michael. Dear Son of Millie and the Late Peter J. McCabe. At Feeney Funeral Home Inc., 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ (201-444-7650). A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday 10:00 AM at St. Luke's Church with interment to follow at St. Luke's Cemetery. In lieu of Flowers donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIKLE, THOMAS H., JR., MD
description: MEIKLE-Thomas H., Jr., MD. The Faculty and Staff of Columbia School of Public Health and the Center for Applied Public Health mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Thomas H. Meikle, MD. Dr. Meikle's contribution to training for minority health professionals made a lasting impression on the health of the nation. Dr. Meikle, who both at Cornell and more recently at the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, has been a strong advocate for improved health of all people. He will be greatly missed and we send our sincere condolences to his wife, Jacqueline Winterkorn, MD, and children, David and Sarah Meikle, and Elizabeth and Margaret Winterkorn. Allan Rosenfield, MD, Dean Cheryl Healton, DrPH, Div. Head, Sociomedical Sciences Columbia School of Public Health

title: Rural and City Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: Casinos on Piers Backed
description: The Atlantic City Council gave preliminary approval last night to a measure that would allow casinos to be built on four of the resort's famous piers, starting with the Million Dollar Pier, which would become an extension of Caesars Atlantic City. The measure would also authorize casinos on the Steel Pier, the Central Pier and on the former site of the Steeplechase Pier. A similar proposal stalled earlier this month, but the bill was revised to accommodate members' objections. One change would require developers to replace any youth-oriented entertainment attractions that are displaced by casinos. A second vote is scheduled Aug. 6.

title: Let Witnesses Veto Televised Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuban Bands Transcend Limits of Time and Place
description: The new world collided squarely with the old at NG La Banda's concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, causing a train wreck of sound and leaving pleasure to be gleaned in spite of the context. NG La Banda, one of the great bands to come out of the recent flowering of Cuban popular music, plays loud, amplified and dense drum music that responds to a dancing audience. Avery Fisher Hall is designed for acoustic European classical music, with a seated audience. Even with sound modifications, the texture of the band's music, usually sharp and precise, became murky and indistinct in this show, part of Lincoln Center Festival '97.

title: Bard Music Festival Celebrating Haydn
description: The music of Joseph Haydn is to be the focus of the eighth annual Bard Music Festival Rediscoveries at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. The festival, featuring 12 all-Haydn programs, will be held on the weekends of Aug. 8 and 15 and will include lectures, symposiums and orchestral, choral and chamber concerts.

title: Jury in Gigante Trial Begins Deliberation
description: After a month of testimony and arguments, a jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn began deliberating yesterday in the murder and racketeering trial of Vincent Gigante, who is accused of being the boss of the Genovese Mafia family.

title: George Nemeny, 86, Architect Known for Airy Family Homes
description: George Nemeny, whose designs for family homes on Long Island earned him dozens of architecture awards in the 1950's and 60's, died on Sunday at the Village Nursing Home in Greenwich Village. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Countess Diana Prevails at Saratoga
description: For the 129th year, Saratoga Race Course opened for business today as New York's midsummer home for thoroughbreds, and once more fans were reminded that this is the legendary home of upsets, the place where Secretariat was outrun in 1973, Man o' War in 1919 and Gallant Fox in 1930 by the 100-1 moon shot Jim Dandy.

title: Immunization Of Children Rises Slightly
description: After climbing sharply in the previous three years, immunization levels edged upward last year, to 78 percent of children from 75 percent in 1995.

title: Young, Illegal, Needing Work: Easy Targets
description: BY noon, the men who stand on the street corners waiting for work know that the day is wasted; the pickup trucks with the job offers are not coming. Still, the laborers will wait on the far corners of Broad Avenue all day. Yesterday afternoon, four young men who said they had been waiting for jobs since before 7 were still waiting at 3:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLAS, ROSANNA LUCILLE
description: DALLAS-Rosanna Lucille, of Southampton, N.Y., on July 19, 1997. Predeceased by her husband Dr. John Ruskin Dallas and her son John R. Dallas. Survived by her son Robert Dallas and her sister Mary Levesque of Albuquerque, NM. There will be a Funeral Mass on Saturday, July 26, at 11:00 A.M., at St. Joseph's Church, Lewiston Maine. Burial will follow at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Lewiston, Maine. Donations in Mrs. Dallas' name to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 200 Parkway Drive South, Suite 101, Hauppauge, New York 11788, would be appreciated.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Poppy Propagation

title: Eli Lilly Reports Net Loss, But It Had Operating Profit
description: Eli Lilly & Company said today that it swung to a net loss in the second quarter, reflecting a previously announced charge of $2.4 billion, but that its profit from operations rose 21 percent, in line with estimates.

title: With Beeston Hired, Owners Look to Selig
description: In luring Paul Beeston away from the Toronto Blue Jays, Major League Baseball stayed within its own house in filling its new No. 2 role of president and chief operating officer. Now it remains to be seen if the owners will do the same in selecting the No. 1 person.

title: ITT in Deal for Property Cuba Seized in '61
description: Facing retaliation from the United States, an Italian telecommunications company has reached an unusual agreement to pay compensation for using property that Cuba's Communist Government seized from ITT more than three decades ago, officials said today.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO BUY SOUTH FLORIDA BANKING
description: Colonial Bancgroup Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the South Florida Banking Corporation for about $51 million in stock to expand its operations in Florida. The deal will give Colonial 12 more offices and $250 million in additional assets in southwestern Florida. It is the company's seventh acquisition in the state this year. Colonial, based in Montgomery, Ala., said it would exchange 1.6089 shares for each South Florida Banking share. Colonial shares, which have risen more than 50 percent in the last year, dropped 25 cents, to $26.125. Shares of South Florida Banking, which is based in Bonita Springs, Fla., climbed $1.50, to $23.50.

title: Signs Hint of Tax-Bill Trouble
description: Congressional leaders briefed White House officials today on the tax-cutting package worked out between House and Senate Republicans, amid signs that Republicans could be in for a long standoff with the Clinton Administration over how to divide the first Federal tax cut since 1981.

title: Referendum on Auto Rates
description: A consumer group urged the State Legislature yesterday to offer voters a chance to demand that car insurance rates be reduced by 20 percent. A spokesman for Consumers for Civil Justice, Barry A. Brendel, said the nonbinding referendum, which is likely to pass overwhelmingly, would force lawmakers to act on the proposal. To be included on the Nov. 4 ballot, a bill authorizing a referendum would have to be approved by both houses of the Legislature and signed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman before Aug. 29.

title: YOUTH SERVICES INTERNATIONAL TO SELL BEHAVIORAL UNIT
description: Youth Services International Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its behavioral services business to Youth and Family Centered Services Inc. for $21.7 million. Youth Services International, based in Owings Mills, Md., operates 24 residential and community-based juvenile justice and behavioral health programs for 3,000 youths in 12 states. Youth and Family Centered Services, based in Austin, Tex., specializes in services for children and adolescents. It is owned primarily by Cravey, Green & Whalen, an Atlanta-based private equity firm. In April, Youth Services International said it planned to sell the business and concentrate on its core juvenile justice business.

title: ALLIANCE IMAGING TO BE SOLD FOR $258 MILLION
description: Alliance Imaging Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by Apollo Management L.P., an investment firm headed by Leon Black, for about $258 million in cash, options and assumed debt, extending Apollo's move into the health care industry. An Apollo unit will pay $11 for each Alliance share and assume $67 million in debt. Apollo's purchase of Alliance, which operates mobile units for magnetic resonance imaging, is its third health care transaction in three months and its second purchase of a mobile M.R.I. company. Alliance, based in Anaheim, Calif., operates 87 M.R.I. systems and eight computed axial tomography, or C.A.T., devices. Its shares rose 12.5 cents, to $10.375.

title: ELCOM RETAINS ADVISER TO HELP LIFT SHARE VALUE
description: Elcom International Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Smith Barney Inc. to help it explore its options, including the possible sale of the company, to increase value of its shares. Elcom, a software developer in Norwood, Mass., said it had retained the investment bank after rapid revenue growth failed to yield the market value it deserved. The company's stock has declined 57 percent since Dec. 29, 1995. In Nasdaq trading, Elcom's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $6.375, giving the company a market capitalization of more than $170 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEHNDER, BRUNO
description: ZEHNDER-Bruno. We will always remember your spirit, curiousity and passion for life, photography and your penguins. We will miss you. Mary, Andy, and Morris Engel Estate of Ruth Orkin

title: Israeli Vote Raises Obstacles to Golan Deal
description: A bill that would make it harder for any Israeli Government to cede the Golan Heights passed a preliminary vote in the Parliament today.

title: SUMMIT TO SELL REFRACTIVE CENTERS UNIT TO LCA-VISION
description: LCA-Vision Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Summit Technology Inc.'s Refractive Centers International Inc. unit in exchange for 17 million LCA-Vision common shares. A spokesman said LCA-Vision, which is based in Cincinnati, currently has 19.6 million common shares outstanding. LCA-Vision said that when the deal was completed, it would have a total of 43 laser vision correction outlets in the United States, Canada, and Europe. Summit, based in Waltham, Mass., said it would distribute about 9 million of the LCA-Vision shares it receives to its shareholders as ''soon as practical'' and retain the remaining 11 million LCA-Vision shares. LCA-Vision's stock rose 25 cents, to $3. Summit shares fell 43.75 cents, to $6.8125.

title: Assisted Suicide? Not in My State
description: Despite ruling that there is no constitutional right to assisted suicide, the Florida Supreme Court acknowledged last week that the Legislature could allow doctors to help patients die. Last month, the United States Supreme Court took a similar position, saying that while it found no constitutional right to die, states were free to legalize assisted suicide.

title: Funds Needed for Edison Site
description: The Edison National Historic Site in West Orange is one of the 17 most-underfinanced national parks in the country, two advocacy groups said in a report released yesterday. About $29.6 million is needed to rehabilitate the laboratory complex where Thomas Alva Edison invented more than 400 items, including the light bulb and the phonograph, according to the report by the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, and the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: War-Era Swiss Bank List Produces Mostly Rancor
description: Squinting at column after column of small print in newspapers, scrolling through screen after screen on the Internet, people studied the list of nearly 2,000 long-dormant Swiss bank accounts yesterday. They checked and rechecked the names. And they said they were surprised and confused by what they saw, and angry that the banks had not done more to track down the depositors.

title: Agents Seek Associates in Smuggling Ring
description: Law enforcement officials began searching here today for associates of the Mexican family accused of holding scores of deaf immigrants in virtual slavery in New York, but they appeared to find something less than the satellite smuggling ring that some officials had feared might exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEKTALOV, SAMMY
description: NEKTALOV-Sammy. Sammy's deep love for our Yeshiva, our people, his family and friends will forever be an inspiration to us all. Rachel Goldman, President Rabbi Gary Menchel, Menahel

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: W.N.B.A.

title: A Place to Pretend to Eat
description: WHEN Marco Pennette and Fred Barron created ''Union Square,'' an NBC comedy series set in a Manhattan coffee shop, which will start on Sept. 25, they turned to David Rockwell, the architect of Nobu, the Monkey Bar and other New York restaurants.

title: F.A.S.B. Panel Rejects Tax-Deferral Method
description: An arm of the Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday rejected favorable accounting treatment for the latest technique to let executives profit from stock options while deferring taxes until retirement and, at the same time, diversifying their investment portfolios.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPHILLIPS, BRIAN
description: MCPHILLIPS-Brian. The Ocean Bay Park Association sadly notes the passing of its member and offers condolences to his sisters Elaine Crimmins and Gail Looney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOONE, MARIA TERESA
description: BOONE-Maria Teresa. On Tuesday, July 22, 1997, Maria Teresa Boone of La Plata, MD., beloved wife of the late Baldwin Neale Boone. Mrs. Boone was a retired linguist for several international organizations. Friends may call at The Arehart-Echols Funeral Home, 211 Saint Mary's Avenue, La Plata, MD, on Friday July 25, from 2-4 and 6-9 P.M. with prayers at 7 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Saturday, July 26 at 9 A.M. at the Sacred Heart Catholic Church, La Plata, MD. Interment to follow at the Church cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to Bread For The City, 1525 Seventh Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20001.

title: Don't Ignore Moderates
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, MIRTHA
description: FRANK-Mirtha. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins the Department of Medicine and its endoscopy unit in acknowledging with great sadness the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Mirtha Frank, a valued employee in the unit for more than 25 years. To her children and grandchildren, her entire family and to all who loved her, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Stephen G. Baum, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Alvin M. Gelb, M.D. Ethel and Milton Bornstein, Chief, Division of Gastroenterology and Liver Disease

title: Yankees Squander Chances But Win on a Lucky Break
description: Gaffe followed gaffe, inning after inning, as the afternoon wore on at Yankee Stadium. There were poor decisions on the base paths. There were breakdowns at the plate. So it was only fitting that yesterday's game was decided on one final breakdown.

title: Irish Bands That Fit Right In
description: Cultural festivals like the recent Guinness Fleadh make Ireland seem like a completely alien and exotic culture to those who don't spend much time there. But in Ireland -- as most everywhere else -- there are those who don't need to mine their national identity to create. On Friday night, five rock bands from the Irish club circuit (Nine Wassies, Revelino, the Idiots, Junkster and Blink) appeared at Arlene's Grocery as part of the Intel New York Music Festival. And the only musical thing identifying them as Irish was Nine Wassies' sporadic Gaelic lyrics. The occasional U2-style guitar-playing of Junkster may have also been a clue, but it is a style that is internationally imitated.

title: Worry Over Bank Loans Drags Down Thai Baht
description: Thailand's troubled currency, the baht, fell again yesterday against the dollar amid concern about bad Thai bank loans and foot-dragging on economic change. The baht fell as low as 32.025 to the dollar.

title: A Chair With Spartan Beauty
description: TWO years ago, at age 47, Robert Levin, a Manhattan photographer, decided he needed another focus. Having studied industrial design at Pratt Institute in his youth and having spent much of his professional life photographing interiors, he decided to go into furniture design.

title: The Globalutionaries
description: There is a fascinating revolution going on in Indonesia. It's not always visible, but if it succeeds it could save this country from the dead hand of the Suharto regime, which after 30 years in power is a spent force, without energy or ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILDNER, PATRICIA ELMAN
description: BILDNER-Patricia Elman. Beloved mother and sister. Remembered on your 75th birthday for your generosity of spirit. Love, Mossa and Nina

title: Bond Prices Dip on Sale Of New Notes
description: Treasury prices fell slightly yesterday after what traders called an expensive auction of new five-year notes.

title: Messier Corners A Market
description: WE should all have Mark Messier's nightmares. The kind in which your employer essentially challenges you to go out and seek a better offer and you return with one that's about three times as good.

title: 'Strong Disciplinary Action' Is Recommended for Principal
description: The school system's special investigator recommended yesterday that the principal of a Brooklyn intermediate school be disciplined and possibly dismissed for failing to reassign a music teacher suspected of sexually abusing a student.

title: Mallinckrodt To Buy Maker Of Medical Gear For $1.8 Billion
description: Mallinckrodt Inc., a leading producer of diagnostic imaging agents, medical devices and chemicals, said today that it had agreed to acquire Nellcor Puritan Bennett Inc., another big supplier of medical products, for $1.81 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Boeing Gives In and Wins European Approval of Deal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAHRER, ALICE, ''LITZY''
description: FAHRER-Alice, ''Litzy'' of South Palm Beach, FL. Born in Vienna, Austria. Formerly of Riverdale, NY. On July 23, 1997 in Calvary Hospital, NYC. Survived by two daughters, Fran Narr and Ivy Fahrer and two grandchildren, Kim and Kevin Oppenheimer. Funeral service Friday, July 25, 9:45AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Calvary Hospital.

title: Speeding Car Inspections
description: To ease the long waiting time for car inspections, state transportation officials said yesterday that they had hired 135 more inspectors at offices of the Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: A Prize-Winning Book, If Defense Can Grasp It
description: In past years, when one of the Giants walked around training camp with a thick, heavy playbook under his arm, you knew he played on offense. All those schemes to memorize, all those reads to learn, all those formations and adjustments.

title: Inquiry, in Rebuff, Immunizes 5
description: Acting with unusual bipartisanship, the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses rebuffed the Justice Department today and voted to grant immunity from prosecution to five potential witnesses, including four nuns involved in a Democratic fund-raiser attended by Vice President Al Gore at a Buddhist temple last year.

title: Balancing Viewpoints As Racial Barriers Crumble
description: How are you supposed to move when the world is shifting beneath your feet? The characters portrayed in Paul Slabolepszy's ''Once a Pirate'' and Greig Coetzee's ''White Men With Weapons,'' a double bill of one-act, one-man plays from South Africa at La Guardia Theater through Sunday, make it clear that social uncertainty dictates its own laws of kinetics.

title: Trump Backs Tunnel Fight
description: Donald J. Trump's company has given more than $165,000 toward the legal expenses of a group of Atlantic City residents seeking to prevent a tunnel from being built in their neighborhood, state officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ABRAHAM
description: KATZ-Abraham. A leading member of our Board. His devotion for five decades to our Yeshiva Etz Chaim of Boro Park and his love and activities for the Jewish people is his ever lasting legacy. Our sincere condolences to his family. Hon. Jerome Hornblass, Pres. Yeshiva Etz Chaim Foundation

title: British Students Facing a New Test: Tuition
description: The Government announced today that for the first time, Britain plans to impose tuition fees on all college students, effectively abandoning the country's long-held commitment to free higher education for everyone.

title: For Police, Obstacles in Pursuing Elusive Suspect and Figuring Out a Pattern
description: On June 21, ''America's Most Wanted'' flashed Andrew Phillip Cunanan's picture on television for the fourth time in less than two months, but this time the show immediately brought calls that placed the suspected killer for the first time in South Florida. The first tip came from West Palm Beach, where a man said he had just spotted Mr. Cunanan at a gay bar there, Federal law-enforcement officials said.

title: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP AGREES ON A PLAN TO COVER CHILDREN
description: Republican leaders of the House and the Senate agreed today on a $16 billion plan to provide health care for uninsured children, the biggest investment in children's health since Medicaid was created in 1965. But President Clinton said the proposal was unacceptable because it did not guarantee adequate health benefits for children.

title: Man Slain in Queens After Breaking Up Fight, Police Say
description: An act of valor on a subway platform led to the death of a Queens teen-ager Tuesday night when he was tracked down by more than a dozen youths and shot in the chest, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, ELISABETH
description: HIRSCH-Elisabeth. Age 92. Died peacefully on July 22, 1997. Widow of Fred S., beloved sister of Lottie Lesser, sister-in-law of Dorothy Korngold and Stephanie Hirsch. Dear aunt and great aunt. Memorial services Friday 11AM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: Where Stalinist Youth Roared, Limousines Purr
description: There is a kingdom of children set above the rocky coast here, a Crimean wonderland surrounded by spruce and bathed in the sweet breezes of the Black Sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, ANNE I. (MCCAREN)
description: ROBINSON-Anne I. (McCaren), on July 18, 1997 at age of 94 in New Canaan, CT. Wife of late Guy N. Robinson, prominent N.Y. architect; mother of Lois R. Russell (Mrs. A. David) of Redding, CT., and Guy (George) N. Robinson of NYC. An early advocate of historic preservation, she led a campaign, in the 1940's, to raise funds for restoration of the 1675 Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum in the Bronx. An active volunteer on behalf of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, she co-chaired its annual Spring Gala benefit. She had an indefatigable interest in gardening and was President of the Garden Club of Darien in the early 1960's. With the Garden Club of America, she was Conservation Committee Chair and then a Director; and in 1975 she received the GCA's Medal of Merit for her exceptional contributions to conservation. Her clubs were: Colony Club, Needle and Bobbin Society and Wee Burn Country Club. A longtime, tireless volunteer with the Youth Foundation, Mrs. Robinson was a Director and then President from 1976 to 1990. Bequests in her honor may be made to The Youth Foundation Inc., 36 West 44th Street, New York, NY 10036-8102. Memorial service details at a later date.

title: Milosevic Trades Top Serbian Post for Yugoslav Presidency
description: Slobodan Milosevic switched jobs today, dropping his title of President of Serbia and emerging as President of the Yugoslav federation after a swearing-in ceremony in the federal Parliament.

title: New York's Prison Building Fever
description: The battle over prison construction is one of the remaining disputes holding up New York State's budget. Gov. George Pataki, trying to prove he can be tough on crime, had proposed to build 7,000 new prison beds over three years at a cost of about $635 million. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver says only 800 new beds are necessary. For several reasons, the Speaker is more right than the Governor.

title: Ulster Protestants Reject Disarmament Bid
description: The main Protestant political parties voted today to reject a proposal by the British and Irish Governments on the methods and timing for disarming the Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary groups.

title: Cramer-Krasselt Selected by Valujet
description: Valujet Airlines in Atlanta, whose public image has suffered since a May 1996 crash in the Florida Everglades, said yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt to handle its integrated marketing account, with billings estimated at $15 million. The account has been handled for the last year by Hughes Advertising in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOANE, CHARLES B.
description: SLOANE-Charles B. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Associates, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, deeply mourn the loss of Charles B. Sloane, a generous benefactor and friend of Ben Gurion University. Charles Sloane established a graduate fellowship award at Ben Gurion University in memory of his late brother, Stanley Laurie Sloane, a generous supporter along with his wife Harriet Sloane and was a former member of the University's Board of Governors and the National Board of Directors of the American Associates. We extend heartfelt condolences to his nephew, Robert Laurie Sloane of New York City, his niece, Ann Goodman Sloane of Rockville, MD., and sister-in-law Harriet Sloane of New York City. Kenneth L. Tucker, President Kenneth M. Farber, Exec V.P. Lis Gaines N.Y. Regional Chairperson

title: Rights of the Acquitted
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''There isn't anybody in New York, there isn't anybody in the world, who's in the hotel business and wouldn't want to make a hotel out of the Chrysler Building.''

title: Help the Undereducated
description: To the Editor:

title: When Home Page Isn't a Home Page
description: Don't say Internet ''site.'' Say ''venue.'' Don't say ''home page.'' Try ''gateway'' instead. And please, don't say Internet ''user.'' The preferred term is ''participant.''

title: Jackson Given One More Year, And $6 Million, To Coach Bulls
description: Phil Jackson has been known to fire up an incense candle to rid himself of past malevolent spirits. This time, all he needed was Michael Jordan to chase off the bad vibes between Jackson and the powerful Chicago Bulls duo of Jerry Reinsdorf and Jerry Krause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MARCUS
description: ROSS-Marcus. July 19, 1997. Loving husband of Helen (Suskey) Ross. Beloved father of Martha Nilsson Edelheit of Stockholm, Sweden, and Robert A. Ross of New York City. Cherished grandfather of Ensign Joe J.E. Ross of Coronado, California. Founder and owner of Cambridge Chemists on Madison Avenue for 51 years. Memorial Service Friday, 12 Noon, July 25, 1997 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street.

title: Panel Calls for Removal Of Supreme Court Justice
description: State judicial officials have recommended that an acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan be removed from the bench for making lewd comments about a female intern and for lying to a judicial selection panel.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: REMOVAL SOUGHT -- State officials have recommended that an acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan be removed from the bench. B3.

title: Boeing Concession Averts Trade War With Europe
description: The Boeing Company may rule the skies as the world's dominant commercial aircraft manufacturer, but it humbly gave in to the demands of European antitrust regulators and won approval today of its $14 billion merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: Stocks Keep Advancing; Dow Up 26.71
description: It's the kind of summer that investors have long dreamed about.

title: Weiss, Whitten Wins Domecq Account
description: Domecq Importers, a unit of Allied Domecq P.L.C. in Old Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano in New York by naming that agency to handle responsibilities for its Courvoisier Cognac brand. The account, with billings estimated at more than $3 million, had been handled for six years by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York.

title: Icy, Fruity Malt Liquor Lures Minors, Critics Say
description: At El Ciro Food Market and Deli at 125th Street and Broadway, teen-agers running in and sliding open the freezer bin for a Sno-Cone or an ice cream sandwich to beat the heat have been laying their hands on a new treat: St. Ides Special Brew Freeze and Squeeze, an ice cold fruit-flavored malt liquor.

title: Swiss Bank Reports Finding $11 Million More in Unclaimed Accounts From Wartime
description: As Swiss banks sought to restore credibility lost in their handling of dormant accounts thought to belong to Holocaust victims, one of the country's top banks acknowledged today that it had earlier failed to report the existence of accounts worth more than $11 million that may include Jewish assets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIPPS, LILLIAN BUCHBINDER
description: RIPPS-Lillian Buchbinder. Today marks the 100th anniversary of her birth on July 24, 1897. She was a second generation member of a now six generations old, warm and close American Buchbinder family. Lillian and all of the descendants of her parents who are no longer with us are remembered always with affection. Norman and Lewis

title: CHRONICLE
description: PATRICK EWING made an appearance on the Knicks home court at Madison Square Garden yesterday morning, but he shot no baskets nor did he utter a single word about basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMSON, DWIGHT J.
description: THOMSON-Dwight J. Former chairman of the board of Champion Papers, Inc. forerunner of Champion International Corporation, died on July 20, at the Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara. He was 81 years old. A graduate of the Ashville School in North Carolina and of Yale, Mr. Thomson attended an early advanced management program at Harvard Business School. In World War II, he served four years as a Naval Reserve Officer. His entire business career was spent with Champion International as an executive and board member. He was a Director Emeritus of Cinncinnati Bell, Inc. Mr. Thomson's two avocational interests were the Boy Scouts of America and American Humanics Inc., in Kansas City. The former awarded him the Silver Beaver, Silver Antelope and Silver Buffalo. Through Missouri Valley College in Marshall, the latter recognized his service with an honorary doctoral degree. His first wife Gloria Watkins of Tulsa preceded him in death. He is survived by his second wife, Ann Cornell, whom he married in 1980, four daughters from his first marriage, Blair T. Blum, San Diego, CA, Carolyn T. Brookbank, Fort Mitchell, KY, Gloria T. Redmond, Durango, CO, Laura G. Thomson, Cincinnati, OH, and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be directed to the Boy Scouts of America, American Humanics, Inc., or the Donor's Preferred Charity.

title: Alan Mixon, 64, Longtime Actor In the Theater and on Television
description: Alan Mixon, who discovered a passion for performing while traveling with his grandfather's circus and transformed it into a three-decade acting career, died on Saturday in New York. He was 64.

title: Bridge
description: Thousands of players are converging on Albuquerque, N.M., where the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals will be played during the next 10 days. Some are already hard at work, in the playoffs for the Grand National Team Championship, which began at the local level nine months ago.

title: President of Nomura Says Firm Paid $3 Million to a Gangster
description: The president of the Nomura Securities Company, Junichi Ujiie, acknowledged yesterday for the first time that the company had made illegal payoffs to a racketeer.

title: He Hits Her, and She Lies About It
description: They look like a happy young couple, both glad to be back in their apartment, home from work at the end of the day, celebrating a big check from the husband's job as an insurance salesman. The next day he goes off to a ball game with her father, promising to pick up groceries while he's out. The two men return, laughing and tipsy, and the woman smiles tolerantly. But a little later, when she complains that the husband forgot to buy cooking oil, he flies into a fury and begins hitting and kicking her. The next day, when her father sees her bruised face, she lies and says there was a burglary.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Robert Lamont Green, 79, Arbiter of Men's Fashions
description: Robert Lamont Green, a men's fashion editor, consultant and lecturer who was the fashion director of Playboy magazine for more than 20 years, died last Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: Penn Plaza Solves Wind Problem With a Special-Effects Fountain
description: The owners of One Penn Plaza had half an acre of prime midtown concrete that they wanted to turn into a nice little park. Something with a fountain and benches, maybe even trees and flowers. They imagined lunchtime crowds chatting, flirting, reading and escaping the cacophony of midtown Manhattan in a soothing midday motet of splashing water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASSER, HY
description: GLASSER-Hy. Age 73, died 20 July 1997, of Boynton Beach and New York. Loving husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Larry and Amy. We love you and will miss you forever.

title: Maidenform's Problems Reflect Industry Pitfalls
description: In the world of apparel, few things are as complicated as a bra. It may have 20 pieces and come in more than a dozen sizes and colors. Fit is extremely important -- no woman is going to buy a bra and take it to her tailor to have it altered. All of this makes production a real headache.

title: Release of Tobacco Documents Is Upheld
description: A Florida state appeals court yesterday rejected efforts by the tobacco industry to block the release of potentially explosive documents of the Liggett Group, finding that the papers contained evidence that cigarette companies had used their lawyers to misrepresent the dangers of smoking and to conceal research.

title: IXC AND PSINET AGREE ON 20-YEAR NETWORK DEAL
description: IXC Communications Inc. yesterday agreed to let Psinet Inc. use part of its telecommunications network in exchange for a 20 percent stake in Psinet worth an estimated $240 million. IXC, which leases long-distance and digital transmission lines, will allow Psinet access to its network without charge for 20 years. IXC, based in Austin, Tex., said the agreement would let it offer its own Internet access services. Shares in Psinet, which has headquarters in Herndon, Va., rose $1.25, to $9.375, while IXC's shares rose $3.125, to $26.375. Under the agreement, if the value of the Psinet common stock is less than $240 million a year after IXC delivers all the extra network lines, Psinet will give IXC cash or more stock to bring the value to $240 million.

title: Study Sharply Raises Estimate of Troops Exposed to Nerve Gas
description: A new study by the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that nearly 100,000 American troops may have been exposed to low levels of nerve gas as the result of the demolition of an Iraqi ammunition depot shortly after the 1991 Persian Gulf war, and that they should be warned of possible health risks, Government officials said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WEXFORD MANAGEMENT L.L.C., Greenwich, Conn., a unit of Wexford Capital, acquired a drilling rig for $110 million from Smedvig A.S.A., Stavanger, Norway, an integrated offshore drilling and oil services company.

title: Showdown Is Set as Clinton Nominates Weld
description: President Clinton today went ahead with the nomination of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts to be Ambassador to Mexico, setting up a confirmation showdown in the Senate and putting himself in the middle of an ideological fight within the Republican Party.

title: Liberia's Ambiguous Election
description: Liberia's American-influenced past and its Nigerian-influenced present were both evident in Sunday's presidential elections. The overwhelming winner, Charles Taylor, studied in Massachusetts and was later jailed there for embezzlement at the request of a former Liberian Government. His closest rival, Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, graduated from Harvard and later worked as a Citibank executive.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture on Monday with an article about the effects of the killing of Gianni Versace on the South Beach section of Miami Beach was reproduced in mirror image in some editions. The palm trees at the sidewalk cafe on Ocean Drive should have appeared at the right.

title: Two Incomes a Must
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Companies Place Accounts in Review
description: Two marketers have placed their accounts in review.

title: Union Pacific Resources has strong reasons to seek Pennzoil.
description: BEHIND the Pennzoil Company's fierce resistance to a $4.2 billion hostile bid by the Union Pacific Resources Group is a change of heart by James L. Pate, Pennzoil's chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Jury in Cosby Trial Begins Deliberations With 7 Requests to Review Exhibits
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan began deliberating yesterday in the case of Autumn Jackson, who claims she is Bill Cosby's out-of-wedlock daughter and who is charged with trying to extort money from him in exchange for her silence.

title: Parent Urges State Registry For Providers Of Home Care
description: Peggy Dunne, whose infant son, Kieran, was killed by his nanny four years ago, urged state lawmakers today to establish a state registry for people who provide in-home care to children, the elderly and the infirm.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERBLATT, JOHN, M.D.
description: SILBERBLATT-John, M.D. On July 22, 1997, physician for New York City clinics, beloved husband of Barrie Berns-Silberblatt, father, stepfather, grandfather. Services on Thursday, at 12 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours on Wednesday, 7-9 P.M.

title: Report of Decline in Inventory Pushes Gasoline Prices Higher
description: Prices for gasoline contracts surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after an industry report showed that inventories declined more than expected last week, as vacationing motorists had their busiest week of the year.

title: Swim Club Opens Doors
description: The Teaneck Swim Club, a private swimming and sports center on tax-free public land, will have to accept 45 new families as members as a result of an ordinance passed by the Municipal Council Tuesday. But a community group that has accused the 20-year-old club of discouraging minority residents and poor people from joining said the town's efforts did not go far enough. Under the ordinance, 95 percent of Teaneck's residents will still be excluded, said Bill Crain, a member of the community group.

title: Water Restrictions Lifted
description: Thanks to the recent rain and cool weather, New Jersey-American Water Company yesterday lifted the water restrictions imposed last week on 200,000 customers in Essex, Morris, Somerset and Union Counties, company officials said.

title: Grand Met-Guinness Role to LVMH Head
description: The chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Bernard Arnault, has bought the right to call special stockholder meetings in both Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Guinness P.L.C. and allow investors in the companies, which have agreed to merge, to vote on his alternative proposals. After stock purchases on Tuesday, LVMH, the French luxury-goods company, now holds more than 10 percent of both British liquor companies, the level needed to call meetings.

title: Warily, Serbs and Croats Meet on Sports Field
description: In an effort to heal the wounds of war, the highway was opened, then the phones were re-connected. Tonight there was a soccer match, the first between Croatia and Serbia since the war in the Balkans pulled them apart six years ago.

title: Fraud in Spano's Isles Deal, Prosecutors Say
description: A Federal prosecutor depicted John Spano today as a financial charlatan who lied, forged and deceived his way into buying the Islanders from John Pickett for $165 million in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTZER, LILLIAN
description: MALTZER-Lillian. Women of Reform Judaism, The Federation of Temple Sisterhoods is deeply saddened by the untimely passing in an automobile accident of our beloved and esteemed past President, Lillian Maltzer. Her devotion to Judaism, the advancement of women and development of leadership have left a rich heritage. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Dr. Joseph Maltzer, her children, grandchildren and great grandchild. May her memory be for a blessing Judith O. Rosenkranz, President Ellen Y. Rosenberg, Executive Director

title: A Turcotingo by Any Other Name . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Sleepless In Santa Monica
description: Usually his looks make it into the first sentence. Then comes a punning play on the lyrics of one of the dozens of hit songs he's composed: ''What the world needs now is Burt Bacha rach,'' for instance. But sometimes magazines show unusual restraint, as The Atlantic Monthly did in June, when it waited six pages to qualify him as handsome ''in a tousle-haired, sleepy-eyed, long-jawed, blissed-out-genius sort of way.'' It says a lot about American culture that his genius is usually mentioned second.

title: Soldiers Shouldn't Want for Affordable Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: OLYMPIA DUKAKIS says she likes to ''hang out'' with her family, and she is doing that in a variety of ways this summer.

title: Officials Plan Cuts or Additions in Bus Service on Nearly 100 Routes
description: Anticipating that Metrocards will change the way commuters use buses and subways, transit officials said yesterday that they would cut bus service on several major north-south routes in Manhattan, while adding service to crosstown lines and to routes running to the distant reaches of the other boroughs.

title: Call Me Cod. Here's My Tale.
description: COD

title: Gingrich Calls for Healing at Revival-Style Meeting of House G.O.P.
description: Quoting Scripture, offering prayers and pleading for unity, Newt Gingrich tonight quelled the most serious uprising in his fractious majority since he became Speaker of the House two and one-half years ago.

title: BERLITZ TO BUY ELS EDUCATIONAL FOR $95 MILLION
description: Berlitz International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy ELS Educational Inc., a closely held provider of English-language instruction, for $95 million. ELS operates 25 centers in the United States and two in England. ELS also operates a language center franchise program in 16 countries. Its revenue in 1996 was $62.6 million. Financing for the transaction, which is expected to close in September, will be provided by Nationsbank. Berlitz, which is based in Princeton, N.J., has language-instruction centers in 38 countries.

title: Maxwell House promotes a partnership with Habitat for Humanity in a national campaign.
description: THE Maxwell House Coffee Company is beginning a national television campaign this week that does not include a single shot of percolating coffee or freshly ground beans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, BETTE
description: MANDEL-Bette. B'nai B'rith Gotham Unit #

title: Silver to Use Budget Talks To Try to Clarify Rent Law
description: The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, said today that he would use budget negotiations with Republican state leaders to push for changes in a fine-print provision of the state's new rent-regulation law that allows rents of vacant apartments to rise significantly higher than had been expected. But Republican officials said they thought it unlikely that the law would be amended this year.

title: Richard Jewell Files Suit Against The Post
description: Richard Jewell, the onetime suspect in last year's Atlanta Olympics bombing, filed a defamation suit yesterday against The New York Post, seeking $15 million in damages.

title: President Offered to Call Party Donors, Memo Says
description: President Clinton personally requested a list of potential contributors whom he offered to call to try to raise $1 million for the Democratic National Committee early last year, according to a White House memorandum recently turned over to Congressional investigators.

title: For a new generation of Asian tigers, a harsh currency lesson.
description: THE first to fall was Thailand, which was forced to devalue its currency earlier this month to prevent a horde of speculators from draining its Government reserves dry. Then, in quick succession, the currencies of Malaysia, the Philippines and Indonesia were battered by secondary shocks.

title: Big-Bang Theory: To Deal or Not to Deal for Power
description: The Yankees, 17 games over .500 for the first time this season, are in a conundrum, but not the sort that will make their rivals in the race for the American League East crown or the wild-card berth smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLEY, MADELON DE VOE
description: TALLEY-Madelon De Voe. The Executive Board and Publication Committee of CRISIS Magazine mourns the untimely death of our close friend and colleague. Her leadership, faith, and generosity will be sorely missed. Requiescat in Pace. George J. Marlin, Chair, Executive Board Deal W. Hudson, Publisher and Editor

title: Body on Boat Could Be Cunanan's, Officials Say
description: A police search of a houseboat here on Wednesday revealed the body of a man that local and Federal officials say might be that of Andrew P. Cunanan, the 27-year-old California man suspected in the murders of five men in four states, including Gianni Versace, the fashion designer.

title: Roundhead Redux
description: To ban or not to ban? Hardly a question at all in today's new Cromwellian Britain, not when it comes to fox hunting. Or smoking. Or ''selection'' in schools. Or single stay-at-home mothers. Banned they will be. The people want it so; it shall be so.

title: Leaders Near Budget Accord On Food Aid
description: New York State is likely to insure that as many as 100,000 immigrants continue to receive food stamps, even after the Federal Government stops paying for them next month, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROM, HELEN
description: STROM-Helen. On July 22, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Beloved mother of Sally and the late Neil. Loving sister of Florence and the late Bernard.

title: Eric Ashworth, 39, A Literary Agent
description: Eric Ashworth, a literary agent who specialized in guiding young authors first into print and then into careers, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39.

title: Mysterious And Spooky
description: IF the Addams family's decorator went out looking for a G & G Building (as in Gothic and gargoyles), he or she might end up at the new location of Suzanne Lipschutz's 33-year-old store, Secondhand Rose, which opened last month in TriBeCa. The focus is on the outlandish, the fantastical, the slightly spooky. The Addamses could nestle in blue-gray Venetian carved wood chairs embellished with scaly sea monsters (above with matching table, $4,500). Morticia could light (dimly, of course) a long corridor with an English wrought- iron bat lamp (shown with Ms. Lipschutz, inset, $4,800).

title: Senate Scolds Canada Over the Salmon Fracas
description: The Senate rebuked Canada today over a fishermen's blockade of an American ferry boat in a dispute over salmon fishing rights, accusing the Canadian Government of failing to accept responsibility for the action and urging President Clinton to respond with ''appropriate action.''

title: Don't Weaken the F.D.A.
description: Congress entertained several proposals last year to reform the Food and Drug Administration in order to force the agency to approve new drugs and medical devices more quickly. But critics argued that the proposals went too far in loosening regulatory safeguards, and no bill emerged. This year, in a new Congress, reform is back on the agenda -- as are many of the same criticisms.

title: In the Mood for Romance, Ravel and the Royal Dance the Night Away
description: The Royal Ballet's third and final bill at the Metropolitan Opera House, presented on Tuesday night, is called aptly and accurately ''Ravel Mixed Program.'' The range is wide.

title: Test for British: Tuition
description: Britain plans to impose tuition fees on college students, abandoning a long commitment to free higher education. The move is a further sign that Prime Minister Tony Blair is intent on dismantling many of the vestiges of Britain's welfare state.

title: 4 Energy Companies Post Strong Earnings
description: Four large United States energy companies, Mobil, Chevron, Shell and Conoco, reported strong earnings for the second quarter yesterday despite lower crude oil and natural gas prices.

title: Look Into Management
description: To the Editor:

title: In Prague, a List Brings Some Hope
description: PRAGUE  Stephan had heard that the names would be in the morning newspapers, so he walked down to his local supermarket on Wednesday with a vague sense of hope and anticipation.

title: Nonprofit and Religious Groups Vow to Fight Workfare Program
description: Denouncing workfare as morally unjust, a coalition of 68 churches, synagogues and nonprofit groups is refusing to hire welfare recipients under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's program requiring people to work for their benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOLAFIA, BONNIE
description: ABOLAFIA-Bonnie. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Bonnie Abolafia, and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband Morris and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Harry Laufer, President

title: Bohanon Rides To the Rescue One More Time
description: Brian Bohanon lives a bohemian baseball life, moving from town to town, never staying long enough to grow roots. The Mets promoted the 28-year-old left-hander to pitch against the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight, and they may well return him to Class AAA Norfolk in a week or two. He has been good enough to pitch in the major leagues, but not quite good enough to remain here.

title: A Scalloped Dream, A Hotelier's Fantasy
description: STEPPING from the elevator cab -- an Art Deco triumph of polished Cuban plum-pudding wood veneer -- one sees the deserted reception desk, and behind it, a tiny switchboard encased in 67-year-old oak.

title: BB Pellets Strike Agent Writing Parking Tickets
description: A Department of Transportation worker was struck by two BB pellets while writing out several tickets for an illegally parked car late yesterday afternoon in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about cooperation between the United States and Mexico in the prosecution of drug traffickers misidentified the place where a Mexican prosecutor was assassinated in September. It was Mexico City, not Tijuana.

title: N.F.L. Rejects Sanders's Deal
description: The five-year, $34.5 million contract that would have made Detroit running back Barry Sanders the highest-paid player in the National Football League was rejected by the league office yesterday, three days after he agreed to the deal. The situation will probably work itself out in the next few days. But if it does not, the Lions will either have to sit Sanders until a new deal is done or cut several players, since they are technically over the league's salary cap.

title: GSD&M Is Named By Bank of America
description: Bank of America in San Francisco has named GSD&M in Austin, Tex., to handle the broadcast media buying portion of its account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million. The account was previously handled on an interim basis by the New York and Santa Monica, Calif., offices of Deutsch Inc. The decision came after a six-month review that had been narrowed to GSD&M, which is owned by GGT Group, and one other finalist, Carat North America in New York, part of the Aegis Group P.L.C. Deutsch continues to handle the creative and planning portions of the account.

title: When Money Counts
description: EVERYONE loves a sun-filled room, until it becomes a home office. The best view in town can literally create an eyesore when it leads to computer-screen glare. So the search begins for a good window shade.

title: CUNY Chancellor Followed Policy on Writing Test Requirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Irving Strobing, Radio Operator on Corregidor, Dies at 77
description: Irving Strobing, the Brooklyn-born Army radio operator who stirred the pulse of a country by tapping out the last brave messages of horror, humor and hope before the surrender of the Philippines in World War II, died on July 8 at a veterans hospital in Durham, N.C. He was 77 and had sent the last radio transmissions before the fall of Corregidor on May 6, 1942.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOGARTY, GERARD W.
description: HOGARTY-Gerard W. (1991). We continue to celebrate the joy of your life. Love, Mother, Tim, Family and Friends

title: The U.N.'s Mission Impossible
description: The reforms recommended last week by United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan represent a much needed first step toward streamlining the organization's unwieldy and badly dated bureaucracy. But they are unlikely to win back the popular -- meaning American -- support upon which the United Nations depends.

title: 3M Earnings Increase 9.7% But Fall Short of Expectations
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that earnings rose 9.7 percent in the second quarter, slightly less than analysts expected, as the strong dollar and new-product costs cut into higher sales.

title: More Than a Pretty Face, But Pretty Doesn't Hurt
description: After languishing for more than a year in a distant second place, ABC's ''Good Morning America'' is getting a face lift, with a new co-anchor selected, a search under way for a new executive producer and network officials trying to make the program, as they put it, ''less structured and more fun.''

title: Reggae's Youth Movement
description: Most reggae festivals inevitably end up as battles between old and new currents in Jamaica's prolific and protean music culture, with bawdy, fast-tongued rappers competing for the crowd's attention with slower, rootsier, more socially conscious singers. At Reggae Culturama '97 on Sunday, one of many all-day music festivals to take place on a blazing afternoon at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island this month, the younger performers beat out the old, as is the norm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INSELBUCH, SAMSON
description: INSELBUCH-Samson, 93, on July 23, 1997, the beloved husband of Frada, his ''Sunny'', father of Elihu and Harriet, and grandfather of Adam, Frank and Lenora, and Jessica and Jan. Patrick Gerald Collins, who as a retired Marine officer advised the service and other organizations about the tactics, training needs and battlefield doctrine of tomorrow, died last Thursday in Fairfax, Va., at the home of one of his daughters. He was 64 and lived in Hampton, N.H., near Portsmouth.

title: Moscow Viewers Are Fascinated With Gory Police Shows
description: During a recent Friday rush hour, two Georgian men were shot in the head in a courtyard off central Moscow's main highway, a short walk from the American Embassy. After a sudden burst of rain, the rivulets of blood that had been creeping toward the neighbors gathered on the sidewalk turned into blood-red puddles at their feet.

title: Judge Rejects Royalties Claim From 'Rent' Author's Colleague
description: ''Rent'' -- the lawsuit -- closed in Federal court yesterday with a judge's ruling that the hit musical was the sole legal creation of Jonathan Larson and had not been authored with a collaborator, no matter how much she contributed to the show's success.

title: Concession With Little Immediate Effect
description: The Boeing Company's concession to European Union officials -- giving up exclusive 20-year contracts to supply aircraft to American, Delta and Continental airlines in return for approval of the acquisition of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation -- will have little practical effect for years to come, industry experts said yesterday.

title: Tarses Says She's Staying at ABC
description: After weeks of relentless speculation in Hollywood about her future at ABC, Jamie Tarses, the president of ABC Entertainment, said today at a news conference that she was staying at the network, was ''deeply committed'' to her job and was happy working under Stuart Bloomberg, the division's newly appointed chairman.

title: Colombia's Death-Strewn Democracy
description: A state official in this remote pueblo in a rebel-dominated region in southern Colombia has a photo. It shows him with eight leaders of the Patriotic Union, a left-wing opposition party born during peace negotiations between the leftist rebels and the Colombian Government 12 years ago. One by one, the people in the photo have all been murdered. He is the only one still alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ROYCE
description: ROTH-Royce. In her 79th year. She received degrees from New College and Teacher's College, Columbia Univerity; studied at Cambridge University and did doctoral work in history at Columbia. During World War II was News Editor and Chief, Swiss-Scandinavian Desk of the Office of War Information; immediately post-War was Press Officer for N.Y.C. for The State Dept. From 1946-53 she worked with USIS/USIA as Editor and Chief, Field Publications Unit; designed and managed new magazine Free World, distributed in South and Southeast Asia; and was asked to be the first woman to head a Voice of America desk (Southeast Asia). Volunteer and Trustee in numerous organizations including Public Education Association, Dalton School, Yorkville Civic Council, Women's City Club, and The Citizen's Committee for Children. Active member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She leaves her husband of 53 years Dr. Francis B. Roth, loving children Dr. James Andrew and Nancy Roth Remington and their spouses Barbara and Tom, and grandchildren Sarah Anne and Jessica Leigh Roth and Alexander Frederick Remington. She devoted herself to her children and to education; therefore, should friends desire, contributions can be made to Smith College, Haverford College or the Public Education Association. Funeral private. We will always remember her vibrant life.

title: Black Lawmakers Criticize Clinton Over Cocaine Sentencing
description: Sharply rebuking the White House, the Congressional Black Caucus said today that President Clinton had not gone far enough in recommending to Congress that the Federal sentencing disparity between crack and powder cocaine be only reduced rather than eliminated.

title: Campaign Money, at Any Cost
description: Just as the Senate hearings into 1996 campaign finance abuses turned to Republican misdeeds yesterday, the White House was embarrassed by new disclosures about its own frantic campaign to raise money. The more that is learned about fund-raising efforts, the worse both parties look.
