It is a barrier island where history is still marked in storms and shipwrecks, and where each spring locals tally the number of houses that ''went in'' -- to the ocean, that is -- the previous winter.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the arrest of seven people accused of planning to attack American military bases referred incompletely to measures taken by the authorities to care for a 10-year-old girl after the F.B.I. arrested her parents at a remote Colorado resort. The bureau, a local sheriff and state officials arranged for the child to be placed in foster care, an F.B.I. spokesman in Denver said, but the sheriff who was to pick her up was delayed by an hour. Until he arrived, the girl stayed with a family and child her own age whom she knew. She was not left with unknown hotel guests.

description: Brooklyn has chosen the Bush Terminal industrial area on the Sunset Park waterfront to be the site of a new business incubator for garment manufacturers, the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, announced yesterday.

description: A Dallas jury awarded $120 million in damages yesterday after finding that the local Roman Catholic diocese had ignored evidence that a priest was sexually abusing boys and that it had then tried to cover up the abuses.

title: Irving Strobing, 77, a Hero on Corregidor, Dies
description: Irving Strobing, the Brooklyn-born Army radio operator who stirred the pulse of a country by tapping out the last brave messages of horror, humor and hope before the surrender of the Philippines in World War II, died on July 8 at a veterans hospital in Durham, N.C. He was 77 and had sent the last radio transmissions before the fall of Corregidor on May 6, 1942.

description: The scientists in Scotland who produced Dolly, the sheep that was cloned from an adult sheep, announced today that they had taken a major step in the genetic engineering of animals. Using a method much like that used to produce Dolly, they created a lamb that has a human gene in every cell of its body.

The record at that time, 936.59, was set on July 16. It was not surpassed on Tuesday or Wednesday. Yesterday the index did set a record, reported today on page D6.

title: LAFARGE SAYS TALKS TO BUY LAIDLAW SUBSIDIARY FAILED
description: The Lafarge Corporation said yesterday that discussions to buy JTM Industries, a subsidiary of Laidlaw Inc., had ended because the two could not reach an agreement. The companies had signed a letter of intent three months ago. Lafarge was interested in acquiring JTM to expand its fly-ash recycling business. Fly-ash is the byproduct of coal-burning utilities and is used as an additive in concrete, soil and asphalt. JTM, based in Kennesaw, Ga., has annual sales of about $60 million and 80 outlets in 28 states. Shares of Lafarge, which operates 14 cement and two gypsum wallboard plants in Canada and the United States, rose $1.0625, to $27.875.

title: Army Corps Of Engineers Strikes Accord In Bias Case
description: The Army Corps of Engineers agreed yesterday to give job promotions and $1 million in compensatory damages to a group of black deckhands on a Mississippi River dredge who were found to have endured racial slurs and discriminatory personnel practices.

title: Tina Turner, 58 and Still Kicking

Her opening act is Cyndi Lauper, another woman who sold millions of albums in the 80's. With video blowups and frisky dancers, searing strobe lights and a band eager to pose, the production might dwarf any performer less commanding than Ms. Turner. But at 58, Ms. Turner is still a force of nature.

title: Sewage Ban Proposed
description: State officials asked the Federal Government yesterday for the authority to prevent boat owners from dumping chlorine-treated sewage in the Shark River Inlet. About 300 boats travel through the inlet on a typical weekend day in the summer.

title: Father Kills Two Children, Then Himself
description: An Iranian immigrant who was apparently distraught over the failure of his marriage killed his two young children yesterday and then hanged himself in a closet in their Brooklyn home, the police said.

This year's opening of Jean Georges, a bit to the south, was cause for rejoicing; a great chef had finally ventured west. Recently the area even got its own Greenmarket.

title: New Evidence On Nerve Gas In Gulf War Spurs Inquiry

Dick, who received his Master's in architecture from Yale Univ. in 1963, worked most of his professional career for the firm now known as Smith Barney, Inc. of New York. Dick was highly respected in his profession and was known as a man of great integrity. He was also a consummate family man with a keen sense of humor. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Friends are asked to make donations to the Maine Chapter of the ''Make a Wish Foundation'' in lieu of flowers (87 Elm St., Suite 206, Camden, ME 04843, (207-263-3171).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONDERLING, EGMONT
description: SONDERLING-Egmont. We have lost a loving husband, a father and a grandfather-our beloved Egmont Sonderling. To those of us who loved him, his kindness and concern for others will forever be in our hearts. Egmont's life is the story of faith, hard work, dedication and commitment. We will all cherish the memories of how he expressed his feelings to each of us in his quiet, unassuming way. Egmont's journey to America, almost 75 years ago, began on an oil tanker which crossed the Atlantic Ocean. He came to Chester, Pennsylvania. As millions of European immigrants had done, Egmont came to the United States because he heard and believed that here the streets were paved with gold. He very much wanted to participate in the American Dream. He would often remark that when he first saw New York City he was simply overwhelmed. Over the years, his faith centered him in the belief that G-d must have been on his side. Egmont never forgot that just ten years after his arrival in America, the horror of Nazi Germany would be unleashed against his beloved people and all of mankind. Egmont Sonderling's destiny took him to Chicago where he became a visionary in the emerging fields of broadcasting, entertainment and advertising. In the ensuing 65 years, he built a company that would become one of the world's pioneer group broadcasting corporations, covering 11 major markets. His success touched a large chain of movie theaters in New England and New York. In 1980, the majority of his then publicly owned Sonderling Broadcast Corporation was merged in to Viacom International. Throughout these years of active, creative leadership, this wonderful man always remembered his humble origins, always remembered his family, was always concerned for the quality of life for all people. Egmont was truly forever grateful for the opportunities he found in America. His enthusiasm for life was unbounded. His life's experience instilled within him a deep, principled commitment to give something back to the people in the communities where he lived. He decided early on that his success was to be shared with others and he derived a tremendous sense of joy in being able to support many causes across the nation and around the world. Egmont Sonderling had a special feeling for the residents, tenants and clients of the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged at Douglas Gardens. He was always conscious of his heritage and grateful that he had been given the opportunity to escape the years of horror in Germany. In this way, as both a philanthropist and as a Board Member, he was deeply involved with an organization which aids Jewish elderly and which provides care to thousands of Floridians of all races, religions and creeds. Our beloved Egmont earned a reputation as a most generous host in his support of a long list of other worthy causes as well: medical research, the handicapped, and the arts, especially the Opera and Ballet. He became a Crown Jewel during the Golden Anniversary Season of the Opera and also served as Co-Chair of the Grand Opera Ball. Those of us who mourn this loving, decent and honorable man will cherish the bright dreams he dreamed and the love which we will share always. Survived by his devoted wife Marjorie Serralles Sonderling, loving children Roy and Bonnie Sonderling, Annik Serralles Wolf and Michael, Juan E. Serralles, IV and Rita, Marjorie E. Serralles Russell and Terrence, Mary Ann F. Serralles Alonso and Mark, cherished grandchildren Morgan Wolf and Juan E. Serralles, V.

title: In Ulster Drama, a U.S. Player Is Hopeful About Peace

Mitchell, the chairman of the Northern Ireland peace talks, sat in the unpretentious ground-floor restaurant of the Europa Hotel and assessed his three years of work toward ending sectarian warfare in this British province.

title: No Dice, Haley

On the subject of the $2.1 million loan from a Hong Kong businessman to a Republican Party think tank in 1994, Mr. Barbour tried to have it both ways. The former Republican Party chairman asserted that he never knew the money was foreign in origin, but that it would have been fine if it had been.

title: Lawmakers Near Agreement on Property Tax Cuts and Early Education Programs

The programs, which would cost billions of dollars, are coveted by both Republicans and Democrats and would kick in as the state's elected officials run for re-election next year.

title: Worker's Error and Mechanical Failure Are Blamed in 2 Derailments

title: At End of Cunanan Manhunt, Suicide and Mystery
description: In the desperate days before he shot himself in the master bedroom of a luxury houseboat moored in a canal here, Andrew P. Cunanan telephoned an acquaintance frantically trying to get a fake passport so he could escape, Federal investigators said today.

description: In the days leading up to the Cambodian coup earlier this month, Khmer Rouge guerrillas seemed to be provoking Hun Sen, the militarily powerful Second Prime Minister, by dallying with his political rival and by taunting him in radio broadcasts from their jungle stronghold.

title: Fast Enough for Food If Otherwise Not Swift
description: Ed loves his job at Good Burger so much that he sleeps in his blue-and-white-striped uniform. He also showers in it. Ed (Kel Mitchell) is so dumb that he thinks chickens moo. When asked to repair the milkshake machine, he gets inside it and happily emerges covered with pink glop. When an angry customer (who received a hamburger ''with nothing on it,'' not even a meat patty) storms out of the restaurant with ''See you in hell!,'' Ed smiles good-naturedly and calls out: ''O.K.! See you there!'' When Mr. Mitchell says it, it's hysterically funny. And he's immensely likable.

title: A Crafty Politician Performs For a Challenging Audience
description: ''I understand politics a little bit,'' confessed Haley Barbour, his throaty Mississippi drawl instantly suffusing the Senate hearing room with the air of a master player of big-money campaigning, an ardent pro who knows when he is being challenged to watch his back and hold his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABCOCK, MARTHA PEASE
description: BABCOCK-Martha Pease. Of Locust Valley, NY, on July 20, 1997 at North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove. Beloved wife of the late Richard F. Babcock. Loving mother of Martha Gibb Bayne and Lewis M. Gibb, Jr. Devoted grandmother of Cynthia B. Simpson, William Bayne Jr., Lewis M. Gibb, III, Ann G. Peck, Thomas M. Gibb, and one great-granddaughter. Direct descendant of Commodore Matthew Perry. Member of Colonial Dames of America. Longtime supporter of Family Service Association of Nassau County and Old Westbury Gardens. Service Sat., July 26, at 11 A.M. at St. John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor. Interment private at Woodlawn following the service. In lieu of flowers a gift to Family Service Assn., 129 Jackson St., Hempstead NY 11550 or the charity of your choice is suggested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASTMAN, ARTHUR M.
description: EASTMAN-Arthur M. Literary scholar, teacher and editor, died peacefully on July 21, 1997, surrounded by his children at the age of 78 in Green Valley, Arizona. Arthur Eastman will be remembered for his achievements, his gift to inspire, his love of words, his courage to stand by principles, his charity, his ever present wit, and for his kindness and graciousness which never seemed to fail. A graduate of Oberlin College, Professor Eastman earned his Ph.D. at Yale in 1947. His distinguished career included teaching at the University of Michigan and chairing the English Departments of Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, PA., and Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, VA. He won the Hopwood Teaching Award at Michigan. He was the inventor And principal editor for 8 editions of the Norton Reader, a widely used college textbook. He co-edited the Norton Anthology of Poetry and the Masterpeices of the Drama. He also published other works on Shakespeare, teaching and administration. After his retirement, Professor Eastman moved to Green Valley, Arizona with his second wife Ann Heidbreder Eastman who died in August 1993. He is survived by four children (Barbara, Richard, John and Martha); his first wife, Becky Eastman; one grandson, Paul; and his brother, Richard Eastman and his family.

title: Swiss Bankers' List Throws Light On Pain and Intrigue of Wartime
description: At first glance, a reading of the list seemed like a walk through an old cemetery, name after name, victim after victim, a roster to recite before the ritual uttering of the mourner's prayer.

description: In a setback for the Giuliani administration, a judge in Manhattan yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Federal welfare law that cuts off benefits for legal immigrants who are not citizens.

title: 92d Street Y Loses a Director
description: Michael Barrett, the pianist and conductor who has directed the Tisch Center for the Arts at the 92d Street Y since January 1995, is leaving his post on Aug. 31.

title: NORTEK AGREES TO BUY PLY GEM FOR $310 MILLION
description: Nortek Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Ply Gem Industries, a maker of building products, for $19.50 a share, or $310 million. Nortek will also assume about $172 million of Ply Gem's debt. Nortek said Ply Gem's board had approved the deal. Ply Gem recently canceled its $18.75-a-share agreement to be acquired by the Atrium Corporation, an affiliate of the Dallas-based investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst. As a result, Atrium will be paid $12 million in breakup fees and expenses. Nortek is based in Providence, R.I., and Ply Gem has its headquarters in New York. Ply Gem's shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $19.25. Nortek slipped 50 cents, to $26.50.

title: Poor and Deaf From Mexico Betrayed in Their Dreams
description: With unerring regularity, the deaf immigrants sent glossy postcards home to their relatives in Mexico, suggesting a whirlwind new life in New York City, highlighted by regular sightseeing excursions to Rockefeller Center, the Statue of Liberty, even Bowling Green.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, WILLIAM J.
description: BRENNAN-William J. 1906-1997. Justice Brennan's eloquent opinion, upholding New York's designation of Grand Central Terminal as a landmark, saved not only one of our City's greatest buildings, but our Landmarks Law, itself. He laid to rest the notion that private property rights and the public good cannot be faithfully and fairly balanced. We attempted to honor Justice Brennan by awarding him our President's Medal in 1991. By accepting it, he honored us. The Municipal Art Society of New York

title: Prodigy Names TBWA Chiat/Day
description: Prodigy Inc., the on-line service in White Plains, said yesterday that it had named TBWA Chiat/Day in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million. The account had been at Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano, also in New York, since last August.

Sunday at 1 P.M. Free with garden admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 622-4433.

description: Political opponents of President Alberto K. Fujimori produced documents today that suggest the President was not born in Peru and thus is ineligible for the office he holds.

title: Myths and Criminal Masterminds

In the case of Andrew P. Cunanan, the murder suspect who ''led'' local and Federal law-enforcement officials around the country for nearly three months before his suicide in Miami Beach on Wednesday night, the distinction was awarded early.

title: Colombian Turncoat Tells Miami Court Samper Took Drug Money
description: Testifying in a drug trial here, the chief accountant of Colombia's Cali cocaine trafficking ring said he personally arranged for nearly $6 million in covert campaign donations to the Colombian President, Ernesto Samper, and that before taking office Mr. Samper met secretly with traffickers to discuss ways they could avoid long jail terms.

description: In a first, a cable network won the most nominations for the prime-time Emmy Awards announced here today, with HBO receiving 90 for comedy shows like ''The Larry Sanders Show'' and movies like ''Miss Evers' Boys.''

title: BECHTEL MAY SELL HALF OF INTERNATIONAL GENERATING
description: Bechtel Enterprises Inc. is in talks to sell half of its International Generating Company subsidiary to Shell International Gas Ltd., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. The companies did not release details. Last year, the P. G. & E. Corporation recorded a gain of about $70 million after selling its half of International Generating, which builds electric power plants, to Bechtel. Oil companies are moving into the fast-growing market for building and operating power plants in developing countries. International Generating is constructing plants in four countries, and seven other projects are in the works.

title: Whodunit And Why Did He?
description: In ''Those Left Behind'' Ben Bettenbender uses devices culled from detective stories to fashion a mystery tale that keeps exfoliating, almost line by line to reveal at last a mystery no one can comprehend: the man who created it is dead.

title: The Nine Lives of Mr. Milosevic
description: When Serbia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, capitulated to the demands of demonstrating citizens earlier this year, the world and many of the protesters thought the swelling opposition would gradually carry him from power. They were wrong. Today Mr. Milosevic retains his hold on what is left of Yugoslavia, and this week began a four-year term in a new post.

title: Japanese Economy Continues Recovery

title: ASTROTECH SHARES RISE 32.5% ON NEWS OF DEAL WITH ITEQ
description: The stock of the Astrotech International Corporation jumped 32.5 percent yesterday after the company said late on Wednesday that it would be acquired for about $108 million by Iteq Inc., a Houston manufacturer of gas processing equipment. Shareholders of Astrotech, a supplier of above-ground storage tanks, are to receive 0.93 of an Iteq share for each Astrotech share held. Iteq said it expected the combined company to have annual revenues of about $350 million. Iteq, formerly known as Air-Cure Technologies Inc., had 1996 revenues of $110.8 million. Astrotech, based in Pittsburgh, had 1996 sales of about $122 million. Shares of Astrotech were up $2.4375, to $9.9375. Shares of Iteq slipped 50 cents, to $11.25.

description: Do not spit toward the fans. Do not think about spiking your glove on the grass. Do not kick or throw the resin bag. Do not march around the mound in disgust. Do not throw behind batters out of frustration. Do not let emotions impair your pitching.

description: The Xerox Corporation said today that earnings rose 15 percent in the second quarter, lifted by higher sales of digital copiers.

title: Seoul to Prop Up Its Crumbling Banks
description: The South Korean Government said yesterday that it would pump 1.5 trillion won ($1.68 billion) into its crumbling banking system, including the first cash injection into investment banks in 15 years. The money, which will be deposited by the Ministry of Finance and Economy for 15 days at low interest rates, is intended to keep open credit lines to cash-starved companies. More money may be made available. The deposits will carry annual interest rates of 10 percent, below the 15-day interbank rate of 12 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMANN, HELEN JOBIN

Born in London, November 4, 1910, the third child of Artur and Helen Humbert Jobin. She is survived by her children Nicholas J. and Pamela Humbert, her sister Berta, her nephew Dennis Jobin two nieces Judith Jobin Leary and Kathleen Jobin Sorenson and five great nieces and nephews. She is pre-deceased by her brother, Rudolf. Serivces will be at home at 90 Rockledge Road, Bronxville, NY at 8PM, on July 25. The family will receive visitors on the same day from 11am-7:30pm. Burial will take place at Raymond Hill Cemetery, Carmel, NY on Sat., July 26, 11am.

title: Digital Equipment's Operating Earnings Rise in Quarter
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation ended a difficult year on a positive note yesterday, reporting quarterly operating earnings that more than doubled from a year earlier. description: Electronic toll collection will begin on the George Washington Bridge at 12:01 A.M. Monday, the Port Authority said yesterday. It will be a major step toward installing a single system on more than 700 tollbooths in New Jersey and Delaware over the next three years.

title: Good Forecast for Economy
description: New Jersey's economy is booming, forecasters said yesterday. By the end of the year, employment in nonagricultural industries is expected to rise by 1.8 percent, creating 65,000 new jobs, according to a report released yesterday by Rutgers University.

title: Art in Review
description: Choong-Sup Lim

title: SERVICEMASTER UNIT BUYS ROLLINS LANDSCAPING DIVISIONS
description: Rollins Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its Orkin landscaping and lawn care divisions to Servicemaster L.P.'s Trugreen-Chemlawn unit. Terms were not disclosed. Trugreen-Chemlawn provides lawn and landscaping services. Servicemaster, of Downers Grove, Ill., offers maintenance, pest control, lawn care and other services. Rollins, an Atlanta-based consumer services company, said it had sold the unit to focus on its core businesses. It also owns Orkin Exterminating, which offers termite and pest control services, and Rollins Protective Services, which provides electronic security systems.

title: France Snips at the Old Ties That Bind It to Africa
description: After decades of propping up or toppling governments in French-speaking Africa as if it were still the colonial master there, France is going to cut back on the number of its troops there and is taking a fresh look at how it doles out money to old cronies who rule in France's interests, according to officials of the new Socialist-led Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEL, GRETA
description: STIEL-Greta. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our member, Greta Stiel. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENESEE & WYOMING INC., Greenwich, Conn., a railroad operator, said it planned to make an offer to buy the Australian Government-owned railroad company, Australian National, and Tasrail properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, LIONEL M.
description: KAUFMAN-Lionel M., 87, of Sarasota, FL., formerly of NYC and Scarsdale, NY. On July 23, 1997. Columbia graduate, Class of 1930, Retired Asst. Publisher Marketing and Media Decisions and Publisher, Promotion Brainstorming, a media newsletter. Devoted husband of Doris (Nee Buhler), beloved father of Susan Cook, Lionel M. Jr. (''Chip''), Ellen Haggerty and Lucy Frantz, dear grandfather of Scott, Todd, Julie, Carolina, David, Robin, Hannah, and Molly, brother of the late Helen Schweitzer. Memorial service July 27 at 2:30 at 7850 Beneva Road South, Sarasota, Fl. NY memorial service to be announced. Information, call 1-914-635-3402.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INSELBUCH, SAMSON
description: INSELBUCH-Samson, 93, on July 23, 1997, the beloved husband of Frada, his ''Sunny'', father of Elihu and Harriet, and grandfather of Adam, Frank and Lenora, and Jessica and Jan. He was in every way a man of honor and a gentleman. Services on Friday, 12 noon, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISLEY, INGEBORG
description: NISLEY-Ingeborg. Widow of Paul Nisley, passed away peacefully on July 22, 1997 at her home in Manhattan. She was an accomplished pianist and served as organist at the French Evangelical Church of New York for twenty-five years. Friends will be contacted about a private gathering. We mourn the loss of Ingeborg. Her Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELLET, RODMAN
description: PELLET-Rodman. The Birch Wathen Lenox School is deeply saddened by the loss of Rodman Pellet, headmaster of the school between 1966 and 1983. Mr. Pellet's life served as an example of the values we hope to instill in our students. As a school community, we are fortunate to be the beneficiaries of his unwavering commitment to children and their accomplishments. Frank J. Carnabuci Headmaster The Birch Wathen Lenox School New York City

title: Uncovered Short Sale Positions Fall 2.8% on the Nasdaq Market
description: While short interest may increase because of bearish sentiment among investors who hope to profit by buying back the borrowed shares after price declines, it may also rise because of trading strategies that use futures, options and other stock-related derivatives.

title: Digital Equipment Moves Account
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York said yesterday that after four years they had mutually agreed to ''terminate their relationship'' on the company's domestic personal computer business. As a result, the account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, was moved without a review to DDB Needham New York, a unit of Omnicom Group that already handles the bulk of Digital's business, including the brand and corporate advertising.

title: For Children
description: 'Earth 2 U, Exploring Geography'

title: Microsoft, Ever Hungry, Looks for New Conquests
description: The Microsoft Corporation has a blunt message for the rest of the computer industry: The world's largest software publisher plans to continue expanding its empire to embrace ever-larger parts of the corporate computing and consumer electronics markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIS, IRVING
description: GEIS-Irving, molecular artist, writer and poet, passed away July 22, 1997 at the age of 88. The recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, he was world renowned as a pioneer in the field of biomolecular art. His innovative interpretations of molecular structures were a source of inspiration to scientists as well as elucidating through his art, the complexities of molecules to an entire generation of researchers and students of science. He is survived by his loving wife of sixty-one years, Miriam, his devoted and loving daughter, Sandy, as well as his brother, Ralph Geisberg, sister-in-law, Anne, and adoring nieces and nephews. He will be deeply and forever missed. Services Friday, July 25, at 1 PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. Tel. 769-4400

title: Novartis Sales Meet Analysts' Expectations
description: Novartis A.G., the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter sales rose 16.3 percent from a year earlier, bringing the first-half rise to 19.2 percent, which was at the lower end of analysts' expectations. Reporting first-half sales for the first time since the union of Sandoz A.G. and Ciba-Geigy A.G., Novartis said second-quarter sales rose to 8.386 billion Swiss francs ($5.6 billion), bringing the first-half total to 16.562 from a pro forma 13.891 billion francs.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Substance of Fire

title: GORAN TO BUY REMAINDER OF AUTO INSURANCE BUSINESS
description: Goran Capital Inc. said yesterday that its insurance unit had agreed to buy the 48 percent of its automobile insurance business it does not already own from Goldman, Sachs & Company for $61 million. Goran, through its Symons International Group unit, a Toronto-based reinsurer, will buy the stake from GS Capital Partners II L.P. and other funds affiliated with the New York-based investment banking firm. Goran offers nonstandard auto and crop insurance and reinsurance in the United States, Canada and Barbados.

title: The Wrong Man
description: It was not a big deal. On a rainy Thursday evening in April David Wayne Spence, 38 years old, heavily tattooed and 60 pounds overweight, was walked into the death chamber of the state prison at Huntsville, Tex. He made a few final comments, was strapped to a gurney and given a lethal series of injections -- sodium thiopental, which rendered him unconscious, pancuronium bromide, which collapsed his lungs, and potassium chloride, which stopped his heart. He was pronounced dead at 6:32 P.M. last April 3.

title: Catholic Teachers Win Suit
description: Lay teachers at religious schools have a right under the state's Constitution to form a union and engage in collective bargaining, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Laws Force Life Support on a Man Who Never Could Consent
description: Jimmy Wigmore lies comatose in an intensive care unit here at Horton Medical Center. His brain barely functions -- not enough for his eyes to blink, for his lungs to inflate and deflate on their own or for his throat to swallow food, but enough to make scattered waves on a scan.

title: Jury Is Still Deliberating In Cosby Extortion Trial
description: The jury in the trial of Autumn Jackson, the woman charged with extorting Bill Cosby by threatening to sell a story that she was his out-of-wedlock daughter, went home yesterday without reaching a verdict after a second day of deliberations in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JOEL
description: FRIEDMAN-Joel. Passed away July 22 at Mt. Sinai Hospital at age 84. He attended Duke University and graduated New York University School of Law. Father to Steven and Richard. Grandfather to Denise Rosenberg, Lauren, David and Kate Friedman. Brother to Charlotte Kottler, Jesse, the late Bernard and Daniel. He will be sorely missed for his humor, elegance and grace.

title: ACQUISITION ANNOUNCEMENT SENDS NELLCOR STOCK UP 34%
description: The stock of Nellcor Puritan Bennett Inc. rose 34 percent yesterday after the announcement Wednesday night that the company, a supplier of medical products, had agreed to be acquired by Mallinckrodt Inc. for $28.50 a share, or $1.81 billion. By acquiring Nellcor, a leader in the respiratory care market, the St. Louis-based Mallinckrodt would be able to compete better in supplying essential hospital needs. Mallinckrodt's hospital product lines include X-ray contrast media, radiopharmaceuticals and devices for diagnostic imaging. The stock of Nellcor Puritan, based in Pleasanton, Calif., soared $7.15625 a share yesterday, to $28.09375, while Mallinckrodt's shares fell $1.50, to $38.25.

title: Producer, Under Siege, Drops Icy Malt Drink
description: Responding quickly to reports that minors had been buying a fruit-flavored frozen malt liquor that was being test-marketed in New York City, its producer said yesterday it would immediately stop making and distributing the drink nationwide.

title: MADGE NETWORKS TO DISMISS A THIRD OF ITS WORKERS
description: Madge Networks N.V., a networking company, will dismiss about 500 people, or a third of its work force, and narrow its focus in an effort to halt two years of mounting losses. The moves come after Madge reported late on Wednesday that it had a second-quarter loss of $6.7 million, bringing its total losses to $22.5 million in the last two years. Madge shares fell $1.1875 yesterday, to $6.3125. Madge's chairman, Robert Madge, said the company was moving its corporate headquarters from San Jose, Calif., to his native England. Madge employs about 1,600 full-time workers in about 20 countries.

title: Lawyer Sues for Payment From Wife of O'Rourke
description: The estranged wife of Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, is being sued by her former lawyer for $8,360 he says she owes him from the couple's divorce case, which has gone on for almost a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMAN, ARTHUR
description: LIMAN-Arthur. American Friends of Bar-Ilan University in Israel extend their sincerest condolences to the family of one of the University's most distinguished honorary alumni Arthur Liman. We share many beautiful memories. Jane Stern Lebell, President Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor General Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President

title: Overhauling Kenya's Charter Sends Factions Near the Brink
description: Kenya's political crisis deepened this week as the Government, civil rights leaders and opposition politicians failed to reach an agreement on how to go about reforming the Constitution or repealing repressive laws from the colonial era.

title: Albany Sets Bad Example For California
description: THE LOS ANGELES TIMES reports that concern is spreading in California over how the Governor and Legislature cannot get their act together. An article the other day said that as a result of political gridlock in Sacramento, the state budget was horribly late: 15 days and counting.

title: Battery Park City Plans Apartments and a School
description: Hoping to persuade more families to stay or move to lower Manhattan, the Battery Park City Authority is building a 25-story rental apartment building with large-sized units and a new elementary school on a site off the West Side Highway.

title: Gifted but Obtuse: Pfitzner's Odd Lot
description: AS a friend said to me the other day, what is it with this Pfitzner guy? Here we are, nearly half a century after his death, in the middle of a sudden and full-scale -- if probably also brief -- revival, courtesy of Lincoln Center Festival '97. His long face, with rough-cropped hair and a shovel beard, has been glaring at us from the festival's publicity material for weeks. Then came the grand arrival, with his opera ''Palestrina'' this week at the Metropolitan (tomorrow's performance will be the last one), and with a compendious program of his chamber music presented at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: People
description: * Dean Lubnick was named head of a new-media unit at Hampel/Stefanides, New York, as new-media services director. He had been client services director at Style Works Interactive/Live Online, New York.

title: Union Endorses Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's support for a controversial tunnel project in Atlantic City won a union endorsement for her re-election campaign yesterday.

title: Ban on Horseshoe Crabs
description: State officials met yesterday in Monmouth County to consider whether a ban on horseshoe crabbing should be extended after it expires Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, ANNE R.
description: ELLIS-Anne R. Beloved wife of Robert Ellis on July 23, 1997. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

title: Made for Each Other, Truly and Obviously
description: Tom DiCillo's ''Box of Moonlight,'' a seductive fable from the very clever director of ''Living in Oblivion,'' offers a whimsical new way of celebrating Independence Day. It is early July when Al Fountain, a strait-laced engineer played with deadpan skill by John Turturro, decides to leave his workaday life behind. Turning his back on a dead-end job, a closet full of white shirts, an impatient wife and a son hooked on video games, Al sets out in search of a lost childhood paradise. He gets lucky and finds something better.

title: Suspect's Suicide Brings Relief and Normality
description: With official confirmation today that Andrew P. Cunanan, the man sought in the killing of Gianni Versace and four other men, had killed himself residents and tourists here expressed relief as life began to return to normal.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: GIULIANI REBUFFED -- A judge upheld the constitutionality of a Federal welfare law that cuts off benefits for legal immigrants. B3.

title: Ericsson Says Net Income Rose 45% in Quarter
description: Ericsson A.B., the world's third-largest telecommunications equipment maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose a greater-than-expected 45 percent as mobile phone sales doubled and market share rose. Profit rose to 2.788 billion kronor ($355 million), from 1.926 billion kronor in the second quarter last year.

title: Cochran the Agent? It Could Work
description: Johnnie Cochran was having breakfast with Spike Lee recently, and you can bet the conversation was not about how tasty the blueberry muffins were. The topic was sports, race and the law. Ideas come at strange times. And maybe the idea was not born at this breakfast, only solidified. But this idea, if enacted successfully, could transform the sports agent business.

title: Life and Death in Cuba
description: Cuba may be suffocating in the grip of a strait-laced and bumbling Communist bureaucracy, but the warm-blooded spirit of its people can't be chilled by economic hardship and silly rules and regulations. That's the cheerful message of ''Guantanamera,'' a good-naturedly shambling romantic comedy with an acidic political undertow.

title: Spain to Sell Part Of Utility Stake
description: The Spanish Government said yesterday that it would sell up to an additional 35 percent of Empresa Nacional de Electricidad S.A., the state-controlled electricity producer known as Endesa. SEPI, the state holding company that owns 67 percent of Endesa, said the offer, scheduled for October, would be the largest privatization ever carried out in Spain. SEPI said it expected the sale to generate between 750 billion pesetas ($4.9 billion) and 1.1 trillion pesetas ($7.1 billion) for the Government. SEPI said 32.5 percent of the shares to be sold would be allocated to international investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERETZ, EMMA
description: BERETZ-Emma. Beloved wife of the late Julius died on July 23, 1997 in her 89th year. Survived by loving sister Greta Beretz, sister inlaw Lena Bendorf, nieces, nephews, grand and great grand nieces and nephews.

title: A Saint With a Midas Touch
description: Maybe it's time for a moratorium on movies set in Las Vegas. As a metaphor for the doomed pursuit of material salvation, the place is a terminal cliche. Any movie set in Las Vegas ought, if nothing else, to celebrate the city's transcendent gaudiness. But Alex Cox's film ''The Winner'' is such a dispirited, murky affair that Las Vegas feels about as perky as a suburban shopping mall. Even a farcical seduction scene set in the Liberace Museum can't lift the movie's pall of glumness.

title: Walking On the Edge In Pinstripes
description: LET'S muffle all the talk about a Mets mirage and vanishing act. This is late July, not April, and the narrow distance between the Mets and the Yankees is significant. The Mets are in this for the long haul; they just took two of three games from the Dodgers in Los Angeles in their signature gritty style.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the selection of a new co-anchor for the ABC program ''Good Morning America'' included an outdated reference to its executive producer. The program is not still searching; it appointed Mark Lukasiewicz to the position on July 9.

title: U.S. Has No Reason to Block Anti-Drug Aid to Colombia Police
description: To the Editor:
