description: TENNIS

title: White House Addition Lets President Enjoy Being in Hot Water
description: President Clinton has had a donated seven-seat hot tub installed near the South Lawn of the White House, beside the swimming pool, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANCHIK, BARBARA
description: BANCHIK-Barbara. July 24, 1997. Beloved wife, mother and sister. Services Sunday, July 27, Bennett Funeral Home, Scarsdale, New York at 10:30 AM. Her memory will live in our hearts forever. The Family

title: A Gentler Hand at Columbia's Helm
description: In Thomas F. Frist Jr., Columbia/HCA Healthcare has the friendlier face it needs to reassure investors and perhaps strike a deal with Federal investigators.

title: International Dance Bill Has a Twist: American's Premiere
description: A room of one's own is what Virginia Woolf had in mind, and that is exactly what every choreographer puts on a wish list too. The room, however, is called a studio, and the American Dance Festival here provides not only space for six weeks but also the raw material of dance: eager and willing bodies prepared to do a choreographer's bidding and to contribute to the process as well.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about documents indicating that President Alberto Fujimori of Peru is ineligible for office misidentified the document shown. It was a baptismal certificate, not a birth certificate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEED, C.E. ''BUD''
description: WEED-C.E. ''Bud'' formerly of N.Y.C. died July 23, 1997. Loving brother of Anne Frate of Darien, CT. Former husband of Lois Weed N.Y.C. Companion of Rita Patterson of Delray Beach, FL. Services and burial were held in Darien, CT.

title: EARTHGRAINS AGREES TO THE PURCHASE OF COOPERSMITH
description: The Earthgrains Company agreed yesterday to buy the wholesale baker Coopersmith Inc., as it seeks to increase earnings by adding more brands and cutting distribution costs. The price to be paid by Earthgrains for Coopersmith in the cash transaction was not disclosed. Atlanta-based Coopersmith, which operates wholesale bakeries mostly in the Southeast, had $250 million in sales last year. Earthgrains' shares rose $1.375, to $73.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The St. Louis-based company, formerly known as Campbell Taggart, was spun off from Anheuser-Busch in March 1996.

title: Through a Gate to the Far Side of the Universe: A TV Series
description: Three years ago, ''Stargate,'' a not-so-standard science-fiction action movie featuring Kurt Russell and James Spader, surprised everyone by earning more than $70 million. On the horizon, surely, was ''Stargate 2,'' if not 3 and 4. Instead, the movie's creators, Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin, turned to a little project called ''Independence Day,'' and the ''Stargate'' enterprise was directed toward television.

title: Fujimori Is Called '100 Percent Peruvian'
description: A lawyer for President Alberto K. Fujimori today disputed allegations by opposition politicians that the President was not born in Peru and thus is not qualified under the Constitution to serve in office.

title: Executive Who Oversaw Big Growth at Perot Systems Quits
description: The Perot Systems Corporation announced yesterday that James A. Cannavino, the longtime I.B.M. executive who became its president and chief executive, had resigned.

title: Irish Priest Gets 12-Year Term For Sexual Abuse of Children
description: In a case that scandalized this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country, the Rev. Brendan Smyth was sentenced today to 12 years in prison after his conviction in 74 instances of sexual abuse of 20 young people over 36 years.

title: SAFETY COMPONENTS SETS ACQUISITION OF AIR BAG UNIT
description: Safety Components International Inc. said yesterday that it had purchased a maker of air bag fabric from the Collins & Aikman Corporation for $56.3 million in cash. The unit being acquired is the Air Restraint and Technical Products division of JPS Automotive L.P. Safety Components will also pay off the division's $650,000 debt, and it will buy a 350,000-square-foot building adjacent to the property of the division, which is based in Greenville, S.C., for $1.25 million. The division is the largest supplier of air bag fabric in North America, with 40 percent of the market. Safety Components, a manufacturer of air bag components, expects to add $80 million in revenue through the acquisition to give it total revenue of about $200 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HAYES WHEELS INTERNATIONAL INC., Romulus, Mich., a maker of steel and aluminum wheels, agreed to buy two truck-parts businesses from Robert Bosch Corp., a unit of Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Stuttgart, Germany. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Brilliant Bach, Bland Bach
description: It may take a measure of perverse wizardry to make the music of Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach sound more vigorous, involving and immediately appealing than that of his father, Johann Sebastian, but Florilegium, an expert period instrument group from London, proved on Tuesday afternoon that it can be done. Granted, the ensemble stacked the deck slightly in its concert at the Frick Collection: it surrounded two of Carl Philipp Emanuel's particularly colorful trio sonatas with comparatively staid works by Johann Sebastian.

title: Reds Change Approach: Knight Out, McKeon In
description: Ray Knight, whose fiery style of managing always threatened to lead to self-destruction, lost his job yesterday, less than two years after he was the personal choice of the Cincinnati Reds' self-destructive owner.

title: Asian Central Banks Seek Ways to Block Speculators
description: Asian central bankers, reeling from speculative attacks in the foreign-exchange market, agreed today to study ways to increase the value of their countries' currencies but stopped short of promising to intervene in the market to support the currencies.

title: Bond Prices Slide as Investors Await Data
description: Treasury prices slipped yesterday as investors waited for several economic reports next week for confirmation that inflation continues to be dormant.

title: ALABAMA NATIONAL IS PLANNING TO BUY FIRST AMERICAN
description: Alabama National Bancorp said yesterday that it would buy the First American Bancorporation for about $50 million in stock to expand its Alabama operations. With the acquisition, Alabama National gains seven offices and about $230 million in assets in northern Alabama. The company will have a total of 39 offices and assets of about $1.1 billion. First American's 900 stockholders will receive 2.2 million shares of Alabama National, based in Birmingham, Ala., worth about $49.5 million based on Thursday's closing price. Alabama National's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $23. Shares of First American, based in Decatur, Ala., are ''nominally traded'' at about $16, said Dan David, First American's president and chief executive.

title: Let's Give Up on the N.E.A.
description: Once again, the National Endowment for the Arts is under attack. By a one-vote margin, the House decided this month to abolish the arts organization by stripping it of its $99.5 million appropriation. (The Senate has voted to continue the appropriation.)

title: Robust Profits Continue, and Smaller Companies Join In
description: Three-fourths of the way through the second-quarter reporting season, corporate America is once again showing robust earnings.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary yesterday about a development proposal that is considered the leading contender for the New York Coliseum site misstated the height of the proposed tower. The developer, Millennium Partners, says the planned tower would have 64 stories, not 68.

title: Warriors Sign Top Pick
description: The Golden State Warriors signed ADONAL FOYLE, their first-round selection and the eighth pick over all in this year's draft.

title: Ride Re-opens After Changes
description: The Jet Star roller coaster on Morey's Pier reopened last night after being shut down since Sunday, when a 9-year-old boy fell off and broke his jaw. Patrick McKeown of Gloucester Township tumbled 20 feet after the emergency brake accidentally engaged, state officials said. Before allowing the roller coaster to start up again, Labor Department officials required several changes, including seat belts and wider spaces between cars, said Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the department.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Two Executives Are Out In Columbia/HCA Shake-Up

title: In Mexico, Deaf Find The Future Lies North
description: It is one of the first things they learn: the right hand, palm up, resting atop the left hand, palm down. In Mexican sign language this is the United States, and to deaf Mexicans the United States is a glint of hope in a dark and silent world.

title: Orders in June For Durables Rose by 2.3%
description: Orders for durable goods rose 2.3 percent in June, more than expected, with half the increase coming from a flood of orders for commercial aircraft, the Commerce Department said today.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: AFTER THE STORM -- Heavy rains left residents in parts of New Jersey coping with flooded streets, fallen trees and basements that had to be bailed out. Page 26.

title: Old Kent Shares Rise 7%
description: Shares of the Old Kent Financial Corporation, a bank holding company in Grand Rapids, Mich., climbed more than 7 percent yesterday ahead of the stock's move to the S.& P. Mid Cap 400 index after the close of trading. Much of the stock's price jump was attributed to index-fund managers buying the stock early. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Old Kent, rose $4.4375, to $63.3125, a new 52-week high.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANSMAN, RUTH
description: TANSMAN-Ruth. On July 12, 1997 in Miami Beach, FL. A resident of Teaneck New Jersey and Miami Beach, she graduated from Hunter College earlier this year. South Shore Hospital honored her with the Volunteer of the Year Award. Widow of Martin Tanzman, she is survived by her daughters Roberta Tansman and Susan Elin (Joel) and grandchildren, Deborah, Alison and Daniel Jacobs and David and Rebecca Elin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, JOAN (HEMING)
description: FRANK-Joan (Heming). On July 24. Beloved wife of the late John V. Frank. Loving mother of Daniel H. Frank and Katherine L. Frank. Devoted grandmother of Samuel, Jasper, Lucas, Ian and Cole. Dear sister of Harriet Simpson, Charles Heming and Delia Cantor. Family will receive visitors on Monday July 28, 5-8pm at her home. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: Carolina Raid Finds Exploited Deaf Mexicans
description: Federal agents raided two houses in this small, blue-collar city today and found more than a dozen illegal Mexican immigrants, most of them deaf, who the agents believe were ''held in bondage'' by bosses who exploited their deafness for profit.

title: Bridge
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals began here today as the Grand National Team Championship approached its finale. In one semifinal match today, Florida opposed California while Michigan faced a group from Louisiana and Alabama.

title: Wells Fargo Risks Becoming a Victim of Its Own Power
description: It did not take long for customers here to notice the difference in service after Wells Fargo & Company took over the First Interstate Bancorp last year. It got bad, really bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMINQUEZ, DIANA M. CENDAGORTA
description: DOMINQUEZ-Diana M. Cendagorta. Teacher, J.S. Burke Catholic High School. Died Sloan-Kettering Hospital, New York, July 23, 1997. She was 45 years old. Graduated from Brooklyn college and attended Seville Univ., Seville, Spain and received her Master's Degree from Queens College. Survived by her husband Manuel Dominquez III; son Manuel Dominquez IV; daughter Diana Maria (Piti-Piti) mother Violet Cendagorta; 1 cousin Gloria Koller; 1 uncle Ignacio Cendagorta. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Toohey Bros. Funeral Home, 154 Route 17K Newburgh, NY, 914567-3994. Memorial Mass will be celebrated at Our Lady of Fatima R.C. Church, Plattekill, New York on Sunday, July 27th at 12 noon.

title: SunAmerica to Buy Licenser of Brokers
description: SunAmerica Inc. said today that it would buy the closely held Financial Services Corporation, which licenses investment brokers, for an undisclosed amount to increase the size of its sales force by more than 20 percent.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CHESAPEAKE UTILITIES CORP., Dover, Del., said its chairman, John W. Jardine Jr., would step down. Ralph J. Adkins, its chief executive, was named to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Mr. Jardine, who will continue as a company director. Also, John R. Schimkaitis, the company's president, was named to the additional post of chief operating officer.

title: Rifts Develop Among Those Pursuing the Assets of Holocaust Victims
description: One day after Swiss banks released a list of dormant accounts from the Nazi era, an array of divisions developed today among potential claimants and investigators over how to keep pressing the search for assets belonging to Holocaust victims.

title: The Remnants Of a Hurricane Bring Flooding To the Region
description: After a weeks-long dry spell that turned untended lawns brown and drained reservoirs a bit below their midsummer norms, yesterday brought a different batch of weather headaches to some parts of the metropolitan region: flooded streets, fallen trees and basements that had to be bailed out.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday profiling Tenet Healthcare misstated the background of the company's chief executive, Jeffrey C. Barbakow. He is not a lawyer.

title: You Get In, Then Yada, Yada, Yada
description: The taxis in this town just got a little chattier.

title: A Man Cleared, but Not His Name
description: He feels the stares of strangers in restaurants, knowing they still wonder if he is the one. He has come to distrust almost everyone, save his mother and his lawyers. That will happen, he says, when the only woman you have dated in a year sells her story to a magazine. He has grown accustomed to the confrontations, as on the night at a Braves game when a man screamed at him in the parking lot, ''What are you going to do, blow up the new stadium?''

title: Theater Organ Returning
description: In 1974, just as multiplexes were overtaking the baroque movie palaces of another era, the organ that once filled the Loew's Jersey Theater with music and a multitude of sound effects was removed and shipped out West. The organ, one of five made by the Robert Wonder Organ Company in the 1920's, had 1,678 pipes and ''a console bigger than some compact cars,'' said Colin Egan, the managing director of the Loew's Jersey Theater, which is undergoing restoration.

title: New York Apathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKS ON BUDGET YIELD AN ACCORD ON DISABILITY AID
description: Congressional Republicans bowed to President Clinton's demands today and tentatively agreed to restore disability benefits to more than half a million legal immigrants, as budget negotiators broke a weeklong impasse and began making progress on several bitterly contested issues.

title: U.S. Seeks Asian Help to Push For Compromise in Cambodia
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright arrived here tonight for meetings with Southeast Asian nations that will help decide if Hun Sen's coup in Cambodia will succeed.

title: Beating Allegation Inquiry
description: The Police Department's Internal Affairs Division is investigating complaints that officers brutally beat a drug suspect while he was in handcuffs, officials said yesterday.

title: Editor's Note
description: An Op-Ed article last Monday by former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called for the United States to build strong ties to the country of Georgia partly because of its potential importance as a shipping outlet for oil and gas. Mr. Baker's law firm represents an oil consortium and other companies in the region. The Times should have made those interests known to the reader.

title: National Math Test Will Challenge Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Formerly Known as . . . Well, You Know
description: For years I have resisted calling the musician who doesn't want to be called Prince by his new name, which is either an unpronounceable glyph or ''the artist formerly known as Prince.'' But over time his name has eroded to ''the Artist,'' which is what was printed on tickets for his concert on Wednesday night at Jones Beach. Calling him the Artist makes sense, since it is just another pseudonym for a musician, like the Orb or Dr. Dre, who isn't even a doctor -- at least the Artist is an artist. Furthermore, the last few days have shown that the Artist is entering a new phase in his career, perhaps even one that deserves a new name.

title: BellSouth Move In Long Distance
description: The BellSouth Corporation said this week that South Carolina regulators had approved its bid to begin long-distance service there.

title: Ben Hogan, Golf's Iron-Willed Legend, Dies at 84
description: Ben Hogan, the flinty-eyed Texan who was perhaps the most creative shotmaker in the history of golf and one of its most accomplished players, died yesterday morning in Fort Worth. He was 84.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Results Exceed Expectations
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 20 percent, more than most analysts had expected, as higher chemical earnings offset drug-division losses on a United States blood plasma venture. Rhone, France's biggest drug and chemical company, earned 934 million French francs, or $153 million, in the quarter, up from 777 million francs a year ago.

title: Liquor Maker Given Respite in South Korea
description: Jinro Group, South Korea's biggest liquor maker, has been given a reprieve by creditors, who have agreed to extend a bailout that has kept the company afloat. Jinro's creditors first froze its debts in April as part of a plan to keep it out of bankruptcy. They met yesterday to make final a plan that includes emergency loans and a postponement of debts, the company and its bankers said.

title: Masters of Spontaneity
description: There are times in every good soloist's career when all the raw materials for improvisation stored up over years of learning and work offer endless permutations and possibilities, and Gilberto Santa Rosa, the Puerto Rican singer, had one of those times at Lincoln Center on Wednesday night. Mr. Santa Rosa is one of the great living vocal improvisers; there were moments when he lost himself in a trance, where the words, improvised in rhymes and floated on a harvest of new melodies and rhythms, seemed as if they'd never end.

title: 2 LEADERS ARE OUT AT HEALTH GIANT AS INQUIRY GOES ON
description: The executive who became the most visible symbol of profit-driven medical care stepped down yesterday as the top officer of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, amid a criminal investigation of whether the company's pursuit of profits has stretched beyond the legal limits.

title: A Night of TV And Then Sobs
description: Mary Ann Cunanan watched on television on Wednesday as the Miami Beach police besieged the houseboat where her son, Andrew, was later found dead. At times she prayed for his safety; at times she prayed for the families of the men he was suspected of killing.

title: Beliefs
description: The nation's most widely shared religious ritual is undoubtedly the Sunday collection. It may also be one of the most mysterious.

title: Bambi the Pest
description: When Walt Disney released the animated fable ''Bambi'' in 1942, there were approximately 500,000 white-tailed deer in the United States. Now, with no natural predators, severe restrictions on hunting and an abundance of new habitat on the edges of forest clearings, there are more deer in the U.S. than when the Pilgrims landed in 1620.

title: Judge Upholds Plan For New Courthouse
description: A United States District Court judge in Manhattan has refused to block construction of a new Federal Court complex in downtown Brooklyn, denying a request by opponents of the project who argued that the proposed 17-story court building would harm the environment.

title: Harassment Charges Detailed in Hearing
description: Brenda L. Hoster, the woman whose accusations of sexual misconduct sparked a criminal investigation of the Army's top enlisted soldier, came face to face with him today at an Army hearing and portrayed his treatment of her as a living hell that pushed her to end her 22-year career in the Army.

title: Players Big and Small Recall the China Opening of '71
description: On the salmon-colored carpet of the delegates' lounge of the United Nations, beneath the enormous tapestry of the Great Wall that the Chinese Government sent as a gift in 1974, the Ping-Pong table seemed a little incongruous. So did the pairs of middle-aged men and women in shorts or sweatsuits doing paddle-to-paddle combat, engaging in forehand slams and backhand chops to the applause of well-dressed onlookers. So, against that backdrop, did Henry Kissinger.

title: Griffey's Target Isn't Maris
description: After three weeks of close calls and misses, Ken Griffey Jr. finally homered again last night, assuring at least two things for the Seattle Mariners' gifted center fielder: the end of his longest dry spell of the season in homers (14 games) and the resumption of the talk about Roger Maris.

title: Barney's Delays Picking a Bidder
description: Barney's Inc., the fashion retailer, said yesterday that it was postponing its selection of a buyer until next Friday so it can negotiate a higher bid.

title: Dora Maar, a Muse of Picasso, Is Dead at 89
description: Dora Maar, the photographer and painter who was Picasso's lover and the principal model for many of his so-called weeping women portraits in the late 1930's and early 40's, died this month in her Left Bank apartment. She was 89.

title: Joan of Ark.
description: Teddy Roosevelt added the West Wing. William Howard Taft added the Oval Office. Harry Truman added the Truman Balcony. And Bill Clinton added the Hot Tub.

title: Guarding Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: An F.D.A. Panel Approves a New Biotechnology Drug
description: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration today unanimously recommended approval of a biotechnology drug produced by Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation and Genentech Inc. for the treatment of a form of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that is a slow-growing but fatal and incurable cancer of the immune system.

title: Graphic Designer Named To Seat on CUNY Board
description: Gov. George E. Pataki nominated John Morning, a graphic designer with a long history of philanthropic and community activity, to the board of the City University of New York this week. Mr. Morning would fill the seat left vacant by the resignation of Robert Price, a businessman, earlier this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERON, EVA DUARTE
description: PERON-Eva Duarte. July 26, 1952. We will love and adore you forever and you will never be forgotten. We will take up your name and wave it aloft like a victory flag, Mother Eva. Your Descamisados Children

title: The Sandman Made Me Do It
description: One of the most interesting pieces of information to come out of the House Republican leadership crisis was that the G.O.P. whip, Tom DeLay, had joined a conspiracy against Speaker Newt Gingrich because he was too tired to resist. It was, his spokesmen told reporters, a tragic case of ''mental fatigue'' after 18 hours of work. One minute, it seems, the former exterminator from Texas was keeping an eye on the cabal of conservative rebels so he could protect the Speaker's interests. The next thing he knew, he was pledging his vote to kick Mr. Gingrich out. The public may look at Mr. Gingrich's humiliated underlings and see nothing but thwarted ambition. But Mr. DeLay's friends understand that overtiredness is the leading cause of political casualties in the workplace.

title: New Twist on Swiss Accounts: Envoy Sees Her Mother's Name
description: Soon after she arrived in Switzerland last summer to become the American Ambassador to the country where she was born 63 years ago, Madeleine M. Kunin cajoled embattled Swiss bankers, urging them to help the heirs of World War II victims and refugees, and particularly to publish a list of long-dormant bank accounts.

title: Next: Beer on a Stick
description: Should Congress ever hold hearings on beer marketing practices, the big brewers won't have to look far to find what finally tipped the scales of public opinion against them: a frozen malt liquor found in freezer bins, next to the Popsicles.

title: AIDS and Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: In Snapshots, Bronx Songs In Key of Life
description: THE snapshot from 1946 shows the young man and his wife smiling, hugging each other in the hills of Puerto Rico. They had returned after a decade in New York, so thrilled by a distant relative's promise to set the young man up in a clothing store in Cayey that the couple sold their furniture, gave up their Bronx apartment and said goodbye to snow, concrete and factories.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ERDHEIM, BARBARA
description: ERDHEIM-Barbara. 7/3/43-7/26/96 Courageous fighter. Love forever, Lynn Merrill Unger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFERT, DANIEL A.
description: WOLFERT-Daniel A. Beloved husband of Pearl, devoted father of David and Laurie Wolfert, Jonathan and Susan Wolfert. Dear brother of Judith Chodos and Ruth Harrison. Adored grandfather of Samantha, Benjamin, Eric and Adam. Services Sunday, 10AM, at ''The Riverside Nassau North Chapels'', 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York opposite LIRR.

title: 25% of Phone Concern Is Sold in Russia
description: A group led by Uneximbank and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell won an auction yesterday to acquire a quarter of the telecommunications holding company RAO Svyazinvest. The group, known as Mustcom Ltd., bid $1.88 billion in Russia's biggest asset sale to date. The group also includes Uneximbank's sister company, the International Company for Finance and Investment, and Renaissance Capital, a brokerage firm in Moscow.

title: No Headline
description: ''That the nation has found a consensus for its highest office in someone who has sprung from the grass-roots of our society and grown up in the dust and heat of this sacred land is symbolic of the fact that the concerns of the common man have now moved to the center stage of our social and political life.''

title: Sound Familiar? Everett Stars as Mets Rally
description: The Mets violated their own credo. They have bragged about their ride-sharing program on their race for a post-season bid, a different hero every day. But tonight, Carl Everett was the hero for the second consecutive night and third time in five days, as the Mets, blistering hot, came back to beat the San Diego Padres, 4-2.

title: New! The Itty-Bitty Body Politic
description: So you wanna know about Tamagotchi(TM), the Virtual Reality Pet, eh? Well, who doesn't! . . . Tamagotchi has been incredibly popular, and manufacturing is working at full capacity to try to catch up with demand. . . . With proper care and feeding (accomplished by pushing buttons on the egg), Tamagotchi quickly grow into adorable virtual reality pets in a wide variety of shapes and personalities.

title: Soviet Line Emerges on Top In 3-Way Photo at Saratoga
description: In a driving finish reminiscent of races that Fourstardave was involved in at the peak of his long career, three horses crossed the line about a neck apart today in a photo finish in the second Fourstardave Stakes. And the photo showed that Soviet Line had his nose in front of Val's Prince, who held second place by a neck over Outta My Way Man.

title: 3d Murder Trial Is Rejected
description: A man whose two murder trials in the 1979 slaying of a Moorestown police officer ended in deadlocked juries cannot be tried a third time, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Looking for a Prince: Fairy Tales Come True
description: All that Darcey Bussell has to do to captivate an audience, it seems, is point a nicely stretched foot or wave to the cheering throngs at curtain calls. Ms. Bussell did both -- and a great deal more -- in Frederick Ashton's ''Cinderella,'' presented by the Royal Ballet on Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Where the 60's Never Ended
description: If 1960's rock were to vanish, most of it could be reconstituted from Karl Wallinger's songs for World Party, which performed to a full house at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night. Mr. Wallinger, 39, is an unabashed fan and student of 1960's rock, steeped in the Beatles and well aware of folk-rock, soul and psychedelia. ''Been a long long long time since I heard something that I really love,'' he sang in ''Call Me Up,'' while a three-man saxophone section pumped out a riff akin to the Beatles' ''Lady Madonna.'' Mr. Wallinger sounded like a disgruntled baby boomer, but one who was trying to do something about the situation.

title: U.S. Needs to Broaden Law Against Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Insurer to Help Trace Policies Lost in War
description: A leading Italian insurance company that is seeking to expand its business in Israel today offered to set up a $12 million fund and investigate the fate of policies that were issued by its Central European subsidiaries and confiscated by Nazi occupiers during World War II.

title: He Led Police to Killer; Now He Seeks Reward
description: Heroism or happenstance? To Fernando Carreira, the 71-year-old caretaker whose inspection of a houseboat here led the authorities to the body of Andrew P. Cunanan on Wednesday, it is not a question.

title: A Jets Power Move: Parcells Chooses Weis, for Now, to Call Plays
description: It had been a minor mystery in the Bill Parcells regime: why hadn't he named an offensive coordinator, and what would be the role of Ron Erhardt, who had the title for the Giants' two Super Bowl victories under Parcells?

title: Stage to Traversoni After Wild Finish
description: Punitive damages reigned today in the 19th of 21 stages in the 84th Tour de France, 172 flat kilometers (106 flat miles) from Montbeliard to Dijon in cool and sprinkly weather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWI, GEORGE H.
description: NEWI-George H., 62. Of Bonita Springs, Florida. Formerly of Chappaqua, New York. Died suddenly while vacationing in Stavanger, Norway July 22. A former President of the ABC Television Network, was a graduate of Syracuse University and served as an officer in the U.S. Army. He is survived by his wife Sally Garnett Newi, two sons George Jr. of Atlanta, Alec of Chicago and his daughter Lisa Newi Long of Pleasantville, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco on Saturday, July 26 at 2 PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, a donation be sent to the Make a Wish Foundation, 280 North Bedford Road, #

title: Environmental Plea for Private Beach Falls Flat
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Warns Bosnian Serbs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELLET, RODMAN
description: PELLET-Rodman. The Birch Wathen Lenox School is deeply saddened by the loss of Rodman Pellet, headmaster of the school between 1966 and 1983. Mr. Pellet's life served as an example of the values we hope to instill in our students. As a school community, we are fortunate to be the beneficiaries of his unwavering commitment to children and their accomplishments. Frank J. Carnabuci Headmaster The Birch Wathen Lenox School New York City

title: Religious Freedom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Resuscitating the Mideast Peace Talks
description: The last thing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wants as Israel and the Palestinians edge toward reviving their long-stalemated peace talks is a new confrontation over Jewish housing in Arab East Jerusalem. So Mr. Netanyahu moved swiftly and wisely to declare that he would block a new project that was unexpectedly approved Thursday night by Jerusalem authorities.

title: In Fight Over Privatization, Netanyahu Wins a Round
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appears to have won the first round of his struggle with the powerful public-workers unions over efforts to privatize the Government-owned telephone monopoly after several days of disrupted telephone services and a one-day general strike.

title: National Math Test Will Challenge Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Griffey Wakes Up and Powers Rout of Yankees
description: When the intriguing topic of Ken Griffey Jr.'s summer swoon was broached with Joe Torre before last night's game, he playfully pleaded for a switch in the discussion and mouthed ''shhh'' like a librarian. He did not want to jinx the Yankees by focusing on Griffey's slump. He wanted to stay silent and hoped Seattle's superstar would stumble into New York and snooze for the weekend.

title: Experts Say Gigante Had Reduced Role, So Conviction Won't Hurt Crime Family
description: Law enforcement officials said yesterday that Vincent Gigante's racketeering conviction was unlikely to immediately weaken the Genovese crime family's powerful underworld position, since his active role as boss of the gang was reduced in recent years by intense law enforcement pressure and a heart ailment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CLARE S. (NEE MCLAUGHLIN)
description: WILLIAMS-Clare S. (nee McLaughlin), July 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Archie J. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Auricchio. Proud grandmother of Laura Auricchio. Also survived by her twin sister, Ruth Maher. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street) NYC, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at 9 A.M., Tuesday, at Saint Emeric's R.C. Church. Interment at Our Lady of the Isle Cemetery, Shelter Island, New York.

title: 3 Are Found Guilty Of Trying to Extort Money From Cosby
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted Autumn Jackson yesterday of trying to extort $40 million from Bill Cosby, the man she claimed was her father.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Outcry Prompted Harsh Penalty, Alex Kelly's Lawyer Suggests
description: A day after Alex Kelly was sentenced to 16 years in prison for raping a 16-year-old girl 11 years ago, Mr. Kelly's lawyer, Thomas P. Puccio, suggested that the public outcry against Mr. Kelly had led the judge to impose an unusually harsh sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESS, MORRIS
description: LESS-Morris. On July 24, 1997. Beloved brother of Evelyn Newman, Jack Less, the late Kitty Watkins and Joseph Less. Loving uncle, great uncle and great-great uncle. Graveside service on Sunday at 11:45 A.M. at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: George Newi, 62, a Former ABC Executive
description: George H. Newi, a former president of the ABC Television Network, died on Tuesday while on vacation in Norway. Mr. Newi, a resident of Bonita Springs, Fla., was 62.

title: REIT May Pay $1.4 Billion For Westin
description: A real estate investment trust in Phoenix has agreed to pay $1.4 billion for Westin Hotels and Resorts, a person familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: AETNA NAMES PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Aetna Inc., the health care and insurance provider, promoted Richard L. Huber to president and chief executive yesterday, ending weeks of uncertainty after the resignation of Joseph T. Sebastianelli. In choosing Mr. Huber, 60, who had been vice chairman of strategy and finance, Aetna opted for a manager with knowledge of finance, not one with a career in health care. Aetna stock fell $2.4375, to $112.625, on the New York Stock Exchange amid concern the company would be better off if its top executive had a background in health care, said Cathy Seifert, an analyst at Standard & Poor's Corporation. The Hartford-based company sold its property and casualty insurance business last year and paid $8.9 billion for U.S. Healthcare.

title: Tough Laws Get Credit for Drop In New Jersey Violent Crime Rate
description: Overall violent crime continued to fall across New Jersey last year, although it rose significantly in two rural counties where farm fields are quickly becoming housing developments, state officials reported today.

title: GM and Union Reach Accord To Settle a Strike at Parts Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative contract agreement tonight to end a strike at a transmission factory that had forced the company to idle six other plants in three days.

title: Dick Taylor, 72, Veteran Golf Journalist
description: Dick Taylor, a longtime golf journalist, died Thursday at his home in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, PATRIE W.
description: SAMUELS-Patrie W. Died July 23 in her 83rd year. Mother of Lynn S. Richardson and James P. Samuels. Memorial service to be held Sunday, July 27 at 12:30PM 353 Rowayton Ave, Rowayton, CT.

title: Prohibition: Doing Good, Finding Evil
description: ''Prohibition: 13 Years That Changed America'' is not intoxicating history, but as a cocktail of newsreels, silent movies, anecdotes and jazz accompaniments, it goes down smoothly, with a kick or two along the way.

title: Not CUNY's Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Players Recall Hogan As a Man of Mystique
description: Dave Marr recalls that he was a ''scared kid,'' a 20-year-old meeting the world's best golfer for the first time. It was 1954 at the Seminole Golf Club in Florida, and Marr conceded that Ben Hogan could be intimidating if you did not know him.

title: Asian-American Films Speak a New Language Of Multicultural Variety
description: In 1978, the Asian-American International Film Festival was little more than a weekend affair at the Henry Street Settlement House in lower Manhattan.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES RAISES ITS BID FOR CHAPARRAL STEEL
description: The Chaparral Steel Company said yesterday that Texas Industries had raised its offer by $1.25 a share in its bid to acquire the 15 percent of Chaparral stock it does not already own. Texas Industries is now offering to pay $15.50 in cash, or $69.8 million, for each of the 4.5 million shares held by minority shareholders. The company, a maker of steel rods and beams based in Midlothian, Tex., has about 28.5 million shares outstanding. The company said a board-appointed special committee would review the offer.

title: Lowest-Caste Hindu Takes Office as India's President
description: Half a century after Mohandas K. Gandhi led India to independence with a vision of a society that would rid itself of its ancient system of caste discrimination, a member of Hinduism's lowest caste took the oath today as the country's President and declared his elevation as proof that ''the concerns of the common man'' have finally taken precedence in the nation's affairs.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a July 24 letter incorrectly stated whom the Edsel was named after. The automobile was named after the son of Henry Ford and the father of Henry Ford 2d.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRAN, BEE
description: AGRAN-Bee, of Miami Beach on July 24. Beloved wife of the late Alex, loving mother to Dr. Marvin and Alice Agran of Scotch Plains, NJ, Barr Agran of Ft. Lauderdale, Arnold Zachary and Cindy Agran of Vero Beach, Carole and Bill Ostroff of NYC. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Scott Agran, Cara Agran, Steven Agran, Michael Agran, Jason Agran and Gregg Ostroff, Alex Agran and Alexa Sellers. Services 1:00PM Sunday at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. For information call Bloomfield-Cooper 800-247-5235.

title: Learning to Sign
description: To the Editor:

title: Fined Surfers Lose Appeal
description: Three surfers who were fined for ignoring a local swimming ban during Tropical Storm Bertha last summer lost their appeal in Monmouth County Superior Court yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Yankees Take Out Insurance in Incaviglia
description: Saying that the asking prices for power hitters have been too expensive, the Yankees went the economical route last night by signing Pete Incaviglia to a minor league contract. Incaviglia, a 33-year-old right-handed outfielder, will report to the Class AAA Columbus Clippers today in Rochester, and Manager Joe Torre said he could be promoted to the Yankees by next week.

title: Islanders Loan Restructured
description: John O. Pickett reached an agreement last night with Fleet Bank to restructure the payments on an $80 million loan originally made with John Spano for his abortive purchase of the Islanders in April, according to a statement from Gary Bettman, the National Hockey League commissioner.

title: Jurors Find Gigante Guilty Of Racketeering, Not Murder
description: Vincent Gigante, the enigmatic figure known for wearing a bathrobe and pajamas in public, was convicted yesterday of conspiring in plots to kill other gangland figures and of running lucrative rackets as the head of one of the nation's most powerful Mafia families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINE, GERTRUDE
description: PINE-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Pine, M.D. Devoted mother of Martin Pine, M.D. and Carol Pine. Dear sister of Leha Meltzer and sister-in-law of Herb Meltzer. Service 12:00 Noon, Sunday at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Lawmakers Still Chewing On 2 Issues in Budget Talks
description: State budget talks neared conclusion today, with the areas of serious dispute narrowed to prison construction and workfare rules. Lawmakers said they thought a long-overdue agreement could be announced on Sunday.

title: World's 'Relief Valve'
description: To the Editor:

title: After Getting Complaints on Child Seat, Chrysler Issues Video
description: The Chrysler Corporation sent instructional videos to about 135,000 customers last week after receiving complaints that child seats built into its minivans malfunctioned.

title: It's Our River -- Let Us Get to It
description: New Yorkers are eager to reap the benefits of the Hudson River's comeback after decades of cleanup efforts that have cost billions of dollars. But while state and local officials are struggling to meet demand for more access to the river, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad is quietly waging a campaign to keep the public away.

title: Australis Media to Buy Rival Pay-TV Concern
description: Australis Media Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire a rival Australian pay-television operator, Foxtel, for $307 million (Australian), or $226 million (United States), in stock. Foxtel is owned by the News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, and the Australian phone giant Telstra. Those two companies would have a 66.5 percent stake in Australis if the deal is completed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5

title: U.S. Links Top Bosnia Serbs to Attacks
description: The United States has concluded that senior Bosnian Serb leaders are orchestrating attacks on NATO troops and senior Administration officials said today that NATO would retaliate if the incidents continued.

title: From Joggers to Jitters
description: ODC/San Francisco glitters. That was evident this week when this high-powered modern-dance troupe opened a two-week season at the Joyce Theater. But the performance also raised the question of how much choreographic substance lies behind the surface sheen.

title: State Seeks End to Fuel Rule
description: State officials have once again asked the Federal Government to stop requiring gas stations in northern New Jersey to sell oxygenated fuel. New Jersey has met the national standard for carbon monoxide levels for the last two years, which means that fuel with higher oxygen content is no longer necessary, John Elston, chief of air quality management for the state Department of Environmental Protection, said yesterday.

title: A Rift in the Chase
description: The Swiss banks' listing of dormant accounts from the Nazi era has opened up wide divisions about where the pursuit should lead. Paul A. Volcker, who is heading an investigation of the accounts, objects to a class action suit in New York, saying it could chill Swiss cooperation. But others on his committee disagree.

title: Coliseum Deal Is Governed By Financing
description: State officials acknowledged yesterday that they had tentatively recommended a winner in the yearlong competition to develop one of the most coveted pieces of Manhattan real estate -- Columbus Circle -- based less on architectural and aesthetic considerations than on financial grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, ALEXANDER RUST
description: JOHNSTON-Alexander Rust. Died on July 23 in Greenwich, CT. Husband of Frances Winans Johnston, father of Alexandra Manley, Jane Cowdin and Paul Johnston. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 A.M., Monday, July 28 in Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

title: Plan for Apartment House in East Jerusalem Angers Arabs
description: The Jerusalem municipal government's late-night decision on Thursday to give an American Jewish financier permission to build Jewish housing in an Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem abruptly added a new source of antagonism to the already tense standoff between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: 3 Killed and One Injured When Their Car Hits Tree
description: Three men were killed and a fourth was critically injured early yesterday morning when the car they were riding in spun out of control and hit a tree in Upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, RAE (JOSEPHSON)
description: THALER-Rae (Josephson). On July 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Wonderful and loving mother of Susan Abramson. Devoted mother-in-law of Lewis Abramson. Adoring grandmother of Robin and Julie. Cherished sister of Hilda April. She is also survived by many nieces, nephews, family and friends. Services Sunday, 10:30AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Contributions may be made to Women's American ORT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, REGINA V.
description: LEVIN-Regina V. On July 25, 1997. Beloved sister of Muriel Glass and the late Blanche Henry; loving sister-in-law of Dan and Walter Glass and the late Jonas and Milton Glass. She will be remembered by all who knew her for her many good deeds and generosity.

title: Bronx Man Is Accused Of Slashing His Mother
description: A 24-year-old Bronx man who became enraged when his mother refused to give him a cigarette pulled out a sword and sliced off the tip of her finger and then attacked her boyfriend early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Thai Finance Concerns Ordered to Open Books
description: Sixteen Thai finance companies that were shut last month because of insolvency have two months to convince potential buyers of their worth, a Finance Ministry official said yesterday. In the meantime, each will be allowed to reopen on Monday. Customers, though, will not be able to withdraw money for an unspecified period of time.

title: Former Leaders Of G.O.P. Vary On Donations

title: Head High
description: In central Iowa the corn is head high. It runs in perfect regimen right up to the ditches, where cattails and horsetail grass grow. No need for fences here, for there are few dissenters in a field of corn. On some farms the upright corn-leaves are as dull as old paint. On others they seem to glisten, and a driver passing by at high speed in the seat of a pickup truck catches a scattered reflection skimming over the acres of seed corn like a school of fish rushing across a saltwater flat. The geometry of farming seems, if anything, a little purer in the soybean fields, where the black earth flickers between the rows. The bean fields are very clean, not a weed in sight. They are, in fact, miracles of suppression as much as miracles of yield.

title: E-Z END
description: Imagine having fine furniture for your living room -- and when the time comes for you to face the final frontier of death, pulling out the shelves and in you go, says Richard Johnstone, a Southern Baptist minister in Pioneer, Calif. Johnstone sells Carpenter Caskets, a $19.95 instruction kit for a simple make-it-yourself coffin that can double as a bookshelf, armoire, hope chest or coffee table. The total cost, after buying your favorite funereal lumber, averages $300. Why spend $10,000 for a velvet-lined coffin-only casket? Johnstone asks. Especially if you'll only use it once? As Johnstone explains, the kits are also about process -- by crafting your own box, you become spiritually and physically attuned to your ultimate fate. Fine idea. But why not buy, say, a laminated IKEA wardrobe for $159 and console yourself with the savings? When you build your own, Johnstone says, you're forced to face the facts.

Weiss of Lutherville, Md., was married yesterday to William Judson Sokol, the son of Janet and William Sokol of Fredericksburg, Md. The Rev. William P. Baxter Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Garrison Forest School in Owings Mills, Md.

description: Lenin and a Crazy Clock

title: On Bombings At Resorts, Cuba Betrays Its Jitters
description: Unnerved by bomb explosions at a pair of tourist hotels in Havana earlier this month, the Cuban Government has responded by lashing out at political dissidents and jailing a German tourist for possession of what were mistakenly thought to be dangerous ''explosive artifacts.''

title: Please Don't Char The Guests
description: A RUDE wind was worrying the genteel guests on the waterfront property of Anthony Drexel Duke and Luly Duke.

title: When Temptation Edged Out Temperance: Raising a Wry Toast to Prohibition's Failure
description: IT seemed like an excellent idea at the time. Shut down every brewer, distiller and saloonkeeper in the United States, declare the beer stein obsolete, and put the olive back where it belonged, in fresh salads. Take the drink out of America's shaky hand and put the nation on the rail-straight path to righteousness, productivity and well-being.

title: How to Install a Whole House Fan
description: INSTALLING a whole house fan can help cool a house because it will evacuate the hot attic air and draw in cooler, replacement air from the outside. These fans are most effective when the outside air is cooler than the inside.

title: Corrections
description: A review on May 25 of Arundhati Roy's novel ''The God of Small Things'' misstated the family name of the twins around whom the novel revolves. It is Ipe, not Kochamma; Kochamma is an honorific that applies to their great-aunt, known as Baby Kochamma. This correction was delayed by research into cultural practices in Kerala, the Indian state in which the novel takes place.

title: Torrington Twisters Get Warm Embrace
description: THE man who collects the tickets at the ballpark in Torrington is older than it is, which speaks volumes about the durability of Joseph (Lefty) Silano.

title: Pol Pot Is Reported Jailed for Life; Doubts Persist
description: The clandestine radio station of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas announced today that their leader, Pol Pot, had been tried for ''rebellious deeds'' on Friday and sentenced to life in prison.

title: They're Used Up, Worn Out, But Valued by Some
description: JOHN AND NANCY WILSON KNOW the value of a dollar, especially if it's out of print. It's not what it can buy but the story it has to tell that matters to the Wilsons.

title: Sargent, Soul Mate To Henry James
description: JOHN SINGER SARGENT'S paintings read like novels. Three girls, slight as sparrows, leave a Venetian church, their heads lowered: from piety or grief? An elegant Parisian physician toys with the cord of his dressing gown, his handsome face lighted with anticipation: of what? Suspense, a sense of event, lies at the heart of Sargent's work. And the exhibition ''Uncanny Spectacle: The Public Career of John Singer Sargent,'' at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute through Sept. 7, is itself a narrative, telling the story of how the young painter displayed his talent and character to the world.

title: The Wall Street Soothsayer Who Never Blinked
description: AROUND 6:30 most weekday mornings, a motherly looking woman in a suit and spectacles catches a commuter bus with her teen-age daughter in Flushing, Queens. As the pair trundle along their 40-minute journey to their destinations in lower Manhattan, an office and a high school, they share the newspaper, do the crossword puzzle and chat about their plans for the day.

title: God Is an .800 Hitter
description: When it comes to sales gimmicks, goofier has always been better in pro sports: Disco Demolition Night. Mary Tyler Moore Appreciation Night. Interleague play. But on this spring Sunday afternoon in Arlington, Tex., the Texas Rangers are filling their pristine baseball stadium with the help of a strikingly pious promotion: Lutheran Day. The team offered discounted tickets to Lutheran churches throughout the Dallas-Fort Worth area, and now parishioners are streaming through the turnstiles to an elegant red-brick-and-steel structure officially named the Ballpark at Arlington, but known by some locals as ''the Temple.''

title: U.S. Envoy Sees Role in Cambodia for Asian Foreign Ministers
description: The American special envoy for Cambodia, Stephen J. Solarz, found enough flexibility in his conversations with the Cambodian leader, Hun Sen, to allow Asian foreign ministers to continue looking for a solution to the political crisis there, an American official here said today.

title: Would You Like To Buy A Prison?
description: As Wall Street marches on with great exuberance, there is no better reflection of the state of investor attitudes than the market for initial public offerings.

title: U.S. Ends Its Opposition to Iran Gas Pipeline
description: The Clinton Administration has decided to drop its opposition to a natural gas pipeline across Iran, the first easing of the United States' efforts to isolate Iran economically, White House officials said tonight.

title: In Chicago's Loop, Offices Are Converted to Condos
description: AS the market for office space in older downtown buildings continues to sag, developers are buying them in increasing numbers for conversion into alternative uses.

title: Once Again, History Envelops Bartlett
description: WHEN he was growing up in a segregated township in South Africa, Shaun Bartlett never dreamed that one day the President of his country would come to his wedding -- or that the President would be Nelson Mandela.

title: U.S. Is Wary, but Hopeful, Going Into Admiral's Cup
description: It comes along only once every two years, and no more than three sailboats from a single nation get to compete. And the Admiral's Cup series always carries clout, usually because the regatta is such a worry.

title: Robert Barnett, 85, State Dept. Expert on Asia
description: Robert Warrn Barnett, a retired United States diplomat and author, died Friday in Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington, where he lived. He was 85.

title: Crabs, Birds and, Yes, Money
description: Since 1990, birdwatchers and fishermen have argued over the fate of the horseshoe crab, frequently coming to blows in May and June, when hundreds of thousands of the ungainly dark brown animals crawl out of the surf to mate, nest and lay eggs.

title: Questions of Race Run Deep for Foe of Preferences
description: By society's measure, he emerged black from the gene pool, a peculiar arithmetic that Ward Connerly insists he has never understood.

title: REITs Now a Presence in State's Industrial Market
description: FIRST they entered the New Jersey office market. Now real estate investment trusts -- usually publicly owned entities that pay out nearly all of their real-estate derived income to investors and essentially pay no taxes -- are becoming an increasing presence in the state's industrial arena. In the process, they are starting a spate of new projects.

title: Will the Dominoes Fall?
description: The market tumbles. Frightened investors bail out of their mutual funds, forcing managers to come up with cash by selling their holdings into a declining market. This selling pressure pushes stock or bond prices down even further, prompting more fund investors to sell shares, and on and on.

title: Equine Medicine Taking Cues From Humans
description: FOR months Hal, a 13-year-old quarter horse gelding from Fort Salonga, was taking painkillers daily for a swelling in a joint. After his veterinarian had tried conventional techniques but could not find the source of the problem, he referred the owner, Joe Modica, to the Long Island Equine Medical Center in Huntington Station.

title: Elsewhere in the World, the Right To Worship Freely Hasn't a Prayer
description: FEW freedoms are as fundamental to Americans as that of religion, but as a matter of United States foreign policy, the fight for religious liberties around the world has been a relatively low priority.

title: Why They Don't Dance Much in American Films
description: A ROW OF TROUSERED LEGS stretches across the screen. Waiting patiently, they move very little except to shuffle a step or two forward on the unemployment line. Suddenly the droning Muzak shifts to a disco beat. One leg kicks out a little and then another, almost unconsciously. The camera pans across the men to catch one, paunchy and no longer young, slipping into a modest but confidently executed turn. Dance, it seems, can spill into the dimmest corners of everyday life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGT, SUSAN E.
description: VOGT-Susan E. 54. July 20th of ovarian cancer. Memorial service Sunday, August 24, 4:00 PM, 157 Signal Hill, Wilton, CT.

title: Grace M. Ward, Thomas Slosberg
description: Grace Maria Ward, a daughter of Maria C. and E. Graham Ward of Quissett, Mass., was married last evening to Thomas Dean Slosberg, a son of Joyce and Myles J. Slosberg of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Beverly Lerner officiated at Willowbend, a country club in Mashpee, Mass. The Rev. Timothy B. Cogan, an Episcopal minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Cristina Himes And Tod Heisler
description: Cristina Elizabeth Himes and Tod Shelton Heisler were married yesterday in Grafton, Vt. The Rev. Jean B. Pinto, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Johnson House.

title: Cheap Las Vegas Rooms Are Harder to Find
description: PILOTS preparing for takeoff at McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas have been known to use this joke in their greeting to passengers: ''Ladies and gentlemen, we will be circling back over the Strip on our way out of town today, so feel free to look down and wave goodbye to your money.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, MARY KATHERINE (NEE BITOMLEY)
description: FITZPATRICK-Mary Katherine (nee Bitomley), on Wednesday, July 23, 1997 of Summit, NJ. Wife of Joseph E. Fitzpatrick. Mother of Deborah Duerr, Julie Butler, Joseph E. Jr., and Jennifer Dane. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Relatives and friends may attend the Memorial Mass at St. Teresa of Avila Church, Summit, New Jersey on Saturday, August 9th at 10:30AM. Donations may be made to The Summit Historical Society, POB 464, Summit, N.J. 07901.

title: George Street Postpones Project With Arts Center
description: Given recent upheavals at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, which peaked with the resignation of the producing artistic director, Gregory S. Hurst, on July 1, it is no surprise that a major change in next season's schedule has already been made.

title: Gentrifying a Borough's Stables
description: Once upon a time Staten Island equestrians galloped freely. But in 1964 the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge provided easy access to the city's most rural borough, and with it came development that chewed up farms, parkland and riding trails.

title: The Fight for the World War II Memorial
description: WHEN Bill Lacy was asked to conduct a design competition for the World War II memorial in Washington, he viewed the invitation as a thrilling opportunity. ''This would be something squarely in the center of the Mall,'' between the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial, he said. ''That was something no architect could pass up.''

title: After 50 Stormy Years, Rays of Light Now Fall on Study of the Dead Sea Scrolls
description: In about 30 B.C., the Maskil, the leader of a strict and ascetic Jewish sect known as the Essenes, emerged from his desert compound to address the Sons of Dawn, disciples who were serving a two-year novitiate before they would be accepted as full-fledged Sons of Light and allowed to enter the community.

title: Top Picks' Great and Late Starts
description: The top draft picks for the Giants and the Jets, wide receiver Ike Hilliard and linebacker James Farrior, respectively, have had quite different rides coming into the National Football League: one on a soft cloud, the other on a white-water rapid.

title: Life in the Fast Lane
description: A few weeks ago, several million motorists in the New York metropolitan area had a bizarre experience that will soon be shared by every American highway traveler. Heading home from their Fourth of July weekends, they came upon their crowded bridges and constipated tunnels and found them ever so slightly transformed. There were the usual Amazonian traffic jams, of course. But on the far sides of the rivers of steel, several lanes of cars moved quickly, their drivers spared the usual ordeal of re-entering Manhattan after a holiday weekend. The cars were equipped with the new E-Z Pass -- essentially a small box read by an electronic scanner as the car rolls through the tollbooth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIT, MONROE
description: MAIT-Monroe. Of Aventura, FL, formerly of West Hempstead, LI, NY, passed away July 25, 1997. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Funeral services in Florida.

description: INSTALLING a whole-house fan can help cool a house because it will evacuate the hot attic air and draw in cooler, replacement air from outside. These fans are most effective when the outside air is cooler than the inside.

title: Under the Clock
description: To the Editor: For all folks who were courting young ladies in the 30's and 40's, it was ''Meet me under the clock at the Biltmore.''

title: Old Tennis Rivalries Resume
description: THREE of the greatest players in the history of tennis -- Jimmy Conners, John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg -- will renew their rivalries when the Citibank Champions Tournament comes to Westchester Aug. 6 to 9 as part of the international Nuveen Tour.

title: Mary K. Hunter, James Savarese
description: Mary Katherine Hunter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Hunter of Ithaca, N.Y., was married there last evening to James Edward Savarese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Savarese of Washington. The Rev. E. Geoffrey Howson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in Sage Chapel at Cornell University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONG, ANDREW
description: HONG-Andrew. Of Harrington Park, NJ, on July 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Susan; devoted father of Robert, Tom and Albert; fatherin-law of Maria; grandfather of Daniel; dear brother of Sung Yoon Hong, Sung Dae Hong, Sung Oh Hong and Sung Moon Hong; dear son of Ki Soon Hong. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 10 AM, St. Joseph Church, Demarest, NJ. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: With Carhops and Victorian Dining Rooms, a Bay Head for All Tastes
description: IT'S only 10 in the morning, and the temperature has already topped 90. If it's cooler when you visit Bay Head and other towns in northern Ocean County, then ride your bicycle or skate to the Normandy Beach Cafe for breakfast. The staff prepares pancakes with blueberries and raspberries that turn into a hot, gooey, tangy liquid by the time they leave the griddle. They remind me of a raspberry muffin I once bought at a farmer's market in Massachusetts, so heavy with fruit that every time I bit into it juice ran down my chin.

title: How the Chains Work Us
description: SCHLOTZSKY'S DELI thought it had conquered the American sandwich market. After blanketing the nation with 600 outlets and winning over Wall Street, the Texas-based chain assumed it would gallop into New York with its sandwich-making wizardry and watch the competition crumble. But Schlotzsky's, it seems, miscalculated badly -- by about two minutes.

title: Liberty's Comeback Falls Short
description: The Charlotte Sting was in the pressure cooker, wilted by an intense defense that produced steal after steal by the Liberty and turnover after turnover by the Sting. In the span of three minutes yesterday afternoon, the Liberty cut an 11-point deficit to 2 points.

title: Midsize, Yes, but They're Growing All the Time
description: The medium-sized cars aimed at Middle America keep getting bigger. Consider, for example, the 1998 Honda Accord that goes on sale in September. Although Honda has not released specifications, the redesigned car is expected to be longer and wider, with a longer wheelbase. A bigger cabin will push the sixth-generation Accord from the compact to the midsize class, as determined by the Environmental Protection Agency, with as much interior space as a Ford Taurus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, GRACE KOPIT (NEE ESTHER G. KOPIT)
description: PERLMAN-Grace Kopit (nee Esther G. Kopit). Of Palm Beach, FL, died July 25, 1997. Born September 7, 1915, she was the devoted daughter of Jacob and Dora Kopit, cherished wife for 46 years of the late Joseph, loving mother of Sandy, Kenneth and Dr. Felice, doting grandmother of Lindsay, Jacob and Elizabeth. A graduate of New York University, she was a founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and for many years an active member of its Women's Division. She was a woman of uncommon charm, humor and elegance, unsurpassed in her love and devotion to her family and adored by them in return. A delightful friend and companion, she was herself blessed with many wonderful and enduring friendships. She was a remarkable woman and will be missed every day. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Graveside service Monday, 11 AM, at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY.

title: After Army, Rookie Finding Giants Uniform an Easy Fit
description: In a pro football training camp, rookies are supposed to be rarely seen and never heard. But in the Giants' camp this month, there is one rookie who has been invited to speak up. He has no chance of making the 1997 team. Yet the veteran players have made him a most popular luncheon guest.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZER, WILLIAM LAND
description: MINTZER-William Land. On July 23, 1997, at age 52. Broadway lighting designer, founder and director of the Professional Conservatory Program in Theater Design/Technology at Purchase College, SUNY. Co-owner of The Mountain Road Resort in Stowe, VT. Survived by Jeffrey H. Knox, his partner. Memorial service to be announced, Purchase College, early September. In lieu of flowers contributions to William Mintzer Scholarship Fund would be gratefully received.

title: Got a Refrigerator? Mr. Magnet Wants to Decorate It
description: EXCEPT for a plastic crab or two stuck in its metal gate, the door to Shorelines, Perry Shore's Upper West Side showroom, is a nondescript affair. But on the back of the door hangs a second door, from a 1950's refrigerator, which is covered by magnets depicting a variety of people and things, from Botticelli's Venus to Marilyn Monroe.

title: Rangers Race Only Against the Trading Deadline
description: The fast approaching deadline for trading players without waivers was the topic of conversation. Doug Melvin, the Texas Rangers' general manager, was asked which side of the trading line he was on.

title: Essay on 'Sidewalk Dance' Is Encouraging Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Country Gothic
description: Bigger isn't always better, but in vacation architecture it is sometimes a necessity. When Mark Simon and James C. Childress of Centerbrook Architects undertook the design of this Northeast weekend retreat, their clients asked for a house that would accommodate gatherings of a very large extended family while retaining the cozy feeling of a summer cottage. So the architects turned what could have been a 15,000-square-foot behemoth into a more down to earth compound of smaller buildings, including two guest houses, a pool, a tennis pavilion and garages, in addition to the five-bedroom main house. To satisfy local height restrictions, these buildings had to lie rather low on the landscape (elegantly designed by the late Lester Collins), which is dominated by small-scale scrub oak, low-bush blueberry and other native plants.

title: Resisting Hospices Costs Clifton Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Daughter or Not, Extortion Is a Crime
description: Autumn Jackson grew up believing Bill Cosby was her father, and when the 22-year-old found herself in trouble, she went to him for help -- demanding $40 million to keep her secret. Last week a Federal jury in Manhattan convicted her of extortion. The verdict came after a three-week trial in which the reputation of the man who wrote the book on fatherhood was severely tested, as he admitted he had had a brief affair with Ms. Jackson's mother. But he denied that he was the young woman's father.

title: In the End, Cunanan Proved Neither Cunning Nor Brazen
description: A broken lock lay on the floor of the houseboat, a sign the intruder had forced his way inside. Pillows and blankets were scattered about, and a makeshift bed sat in the living room. The intruder had moved from boat to boat along the dock, rarely venturing elsewhere, not even for food. His corpse, when the authorities found it, looked a bit scrawny, they said, not much like the robust man from the wanted posters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNS, JOSEF
description: ORNS-Josef. On July 20, 1997, husband of Rickey, father of Cindy, and (Arthur) Miller and Stuart Orns. Grandfather of Sam and Sara, and brother of Carol and (Fred) Kimmel. Brother-in-law, uncle, nephew, cousin, and friend to many. Memorial services on Sunday, July 27, 4 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, RAE (JOSEPHSON)
description: THALER-Rae (Josephson). On July 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Wonderful and loving mother of Susan Abramson. Devoted mother-in-law of Lewis Abramson. Adoring grandmother of Robin and Julie. Cherished sister of Hilda April. She is also survived by many nieces, nephews, family and friends. Services Sunday, 10:30AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Contributions may be made to Women's American ORT.

title: Consider the Useful Weed, Flower and All
description: SOMETIMES the most common plants, even weeds, prove to be quite useful, deserving respect.

title: At Closed-End Funds, A Big Push to Open Up
description: LAST week, investors in T. Rowe Price Associates' New Age Media voted themselves a healthy profit just by changing the legal format of the fund.

title: Rare in Nassau: A Large Tract With Right Zoning
description: IT is unusual to find new subdivisions in established areas of Nassau County. And even more rarely does zoning permit houses to be built on small lots so that they can compete in price with existing houses in the area. But occasionally large tracts of land with favorable zoning do become available.

title: Of the Essence
description: TUMBLE HOME

title: Yes, There Does Exist a Place for the Sheerest of Sentiment
description: SENTIMENTALITY is usually derided, but in today's topsy-turvy art world it's not surprising that it's enshrined somewhere. ''As Time Goes By: History, Memory and Sentimentality'' -- an exhibition at the Stamford branch of the Whitney Museum through Aug. 20 -- shows that treating sentiment in a variety of ways is absorbing, even if doubts remain about its viability as a subject for art.

title: All Play, No Work
description: He is the phantom employee: Someone in the office who routinely comes in, turns on the computer, drapes a jacket over the back of the chair and then vanishes, leaving everyone else to do the work (or not). Is this your boss, or a co-worker? Did he get his royal comeuppance? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: New Floors Add Stress, Too
description: In the fifth month of construction at the Chelsea, a seven-story apartment building that is having 11 stories built on top of it, Hannah Slan had finally had enough.

description: To the Editor:

title: Proposing New Goals for Workfare
description: TEAMS of Westchester County welfare reformers and their New York City counterparts met here recentlyto consider new goals for workfare programs, which have saved both areas more than $100 million, Mary E. Glass, the county's Commissioner of Social Services, said.

title: Caribbean Politics, American-Style
description: FOR more than 30 years, John Compton and his United Workers Party dominated the politics of this Caribbean island, guiding the British colony to independence and dispensing patronage like a stern yet benevolent father. But a few weeks ago, when voters went to the polls, the opposition St. Lucia Labor Party won 16 of 17 seats in Parliament. Mr. Compton's choice to succeed him as Prime Minister, Vaughan Lewis, lost his seat to a 28-year-old opponent.

title: Long Hours. Low Pay. Must Like Travel.
description: DOWN near the tip of the Jersey shore, a young woman more accustomed to the dappled greens and pastel blues of summer at home in rural Ireland blinked into the blistering lights of the Wildwood boardwalk and tried to describe her initial impressions of America.

title: Fatal Stabbing in Queens
description: A Massachusetts man stabbed his estranged wife to death at her home in Queens yesterday afternoon and then tried to commit suicide by stabbing himself twice in the chest, the police said.

title: Owning a Fraction of a Jet
description: TIRED of airport lounges and inconvenient flight schedules? Wish you could get away from the guy with the bad breath in the next seat who wants to talk?

title: A Labor of Love Harkening Back to Greece
description: SANTORINI My Love in Great Neck is so named because it is a labor of love. That is what one owner said when I called to make a reservation (none needed). He said, ''We tried to make this place as much like the little tavernas of Greece as we possibly could.'' They succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, WILLIAM (BILL)
description: GREENBERG-William (Bill). 77 years, of Margate, FL, formerly of Merrick, NY died Friday, July 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth; father of Steve Greenberg and Caryn Chechanover; father-in-law of Paul Chechanover; brother of Ada Michel. Bill was an educator and a veteran of both World War II and Korea. Golf was his passion. He will be missed by his many relatives and friends.

title: Art and Artisanry (Big Party, Too)
description: BANDS will play, street entertainers strut and artists offer works in the 21st annual SoNo Arts Celebration Saturday and next Sunday. The outdoor festival, which last year lured more than 85,000 visitors, will again be staged in the South Norwalk waterfront historic district.

title: Holly Stevenson, Ernest Hunt 4th
description: Elizabeth Holly Stevenson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Stevenson of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to Ernest Edward Hunt 4th, the son of the Very Rev. Dr. Hunt 3d and Mrs. Hunt of Paris. The Rev. H. Miller Hunter Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Paul's Church in Ivy, Va.

title: Making the Web a Friendly Place to Visit
description: ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE monitor is a man with an animated watchworks embedded in his back. As I move the cursor across his skin, words materialize, and when I click on one, the screen is suddenly infested with a cluster of darting, multicolored Chiclets. I discover that when I move the cursor, I can change their movement and make them fly together or apart. It's like choreographing a swarm of gnats.

title: Adventurous Dishes in a Fine Setting
description: LAKE WARAMAUG at New Preston has added another jewel to its culinary crown. The Birches Inn is an old-timer handsomely revitalized and restored in 1995. It not only looks lovely now, but its restaurant, under new management, is also far better than we had any reason to expect. Indeed, remembering the Birches of yore, we had few expectations.

title: Going to Work On Vacation
description: FOR two weeks last fall, Keith Thomson, a financial planner in Toronto, spent his vacation as a volunteer for the VIEW Foundation, hauling cement blocks and bags of sand in the pouring rain to build trails in a remote, ecologically sensitive rain forest in Costa Rica.

title: Belinda Walker, Luther Terry Jr.
description: Belinda Lisabeth Walker, the daughter of Jean H. and William C. Walker Jr. of Ossining, N.Y., was married yesterday to Luther Leonidas Terry Jr., a son of Janet R. Terry of Cathedral Village, Pa., and the late Dr. Terry. Joseph A. Suozzi, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated in the chapel of the Hackley School in Tarrytown, N.Y., from which the bride graduated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROW, STEPHEN GARY
description: BOROW - Stephen Gary, 59, award-winning architect, in La Jolla, Calif., July 22. A much loved brother, uncle and friend, he inspired all who knew him with his integrity, creativity and courage. In his eagerness to embrace life's lessons, he taught us all.

title: Lauren Martinez, Richard duPont Jr.
description: Lauren Rusch Martinez, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. William Hague performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Chapel in Northeast Harbor, Me.

description: WHILE some chains readily admit they tamper with their national formulas to navigate the New York market, others try to project the image of a uniform chain and recite the party line: nothing is different.

description: PELLETT-Rodman G., of Stewart Manor, New York on July 18, 1997. Our deepest sympathy to loving wife Claire and children Mary, Anne and Tim. description: FRANK-Joan (Heming). On July 24, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John V. Frank. Loving mother of Daniel H. Frank and Katherine L. Frank. Mother-in-law of Patricia Lowy Frank and Jerome F. Page. Devoted grandmother of Samuel, Jasper, Lucas, Ian and Cole. Dear sister of Harriet Simpson, Charles Heming and Delia Cantor.
