A memorial service will be announced later.

title: A Slice of Long Island Art Makes It to Venice
description: ONE much-admired aspect of Long Island's 19th-century heritage has traveled to the current Venice Biennale in the form of architectural inspiration, making the journey over a route that touches on sociology, politics, cultural committees and public art philosophy.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Operation Condor

title: Ernesto Zedillo's Place in History
description: Now that Mexicans have made clear their enthusiasm for democracy, President Ernesto Zedillo must determine how he will govern in the three remaining years of his presidency. He can defend the privileges and remaining powers of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which absorbed punishing electoral losses earlier this month. Or he can make a clean break with the party's old guard and align himself squarely with the new, more democratic order he helped create.

title: Lovers, Loners and the Lost Find a Peaceful Place at Night

title: Why Not Try Leeches for Family Fun?

A leading expert on leeches and their modern medical uses (yes, there are some), Sawyer is opening the Medical Leech Museum next month in Charleston, S.C. The public never tires of leeches, the 54-year-old biologist says confidently. People may hate them, they may find them disgusting, but they never get bored. Question: Will people get a chance to be bitten by one? No, that would be stupid, Sawyer says. the wound would bleed for 10 hours. Fear not, though -- other thrills abound. Here's a look.

But when Joseph Coplan, a health insurance consultant who lives on West Fourth Street, found that his silver Jetta had been towed from a spot that he thought was legal, he decided not to accept his fate. He proved that his car was towed in error, and he was eventually reimbursed for his costs and the time that he spent figuring out who was responsible for the mistake.

The counterintuitive manner in which subatomic particles behave couldn't be clearer to those who can sight-read the mathematics, nature's symphonic score. But try translating these truths into language and the trouble begins.

And while investors should realize that the music-retailing industry faces several long-range problems, they may find some worthwhile plays among the survivors of the shakeout.

''Acoustic baffling'' are her first words in response to the hushed sounds from surrounding tables. ''That's what it's called in soundproofing studios,'' she says. ''It's like a sponge that soaks up sound so you can hear yourself talk.''

title: Nonaction Hero
description: For 25 years I've made my living as an actor in the theater and in movies. I have appeared in plays like ''Death Defying Acts'' and ''The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel,'' as well as in movies like ''Hoffa'' and ''Wall Street.'' In films, I tend to work in the back end of the vineyard while my agent sits in the Hamptons sipping chardonnay. But whatever the role, I look for ways to present the fears, desires and other complications of modern life. My roles to date haven't called for much fistfighting on top of runaway trains, so I was thrilled when I got called to play a supporting role in ''Air Force One'' with Harrison Ford, which opened Friday.

The sun is just appearing on the horizon as he gets out of his pickup truck and crouches next to a section of barbed-wire fence that has been flattened. He strokes his mustache, reading the traces of footprints and bicycle tracks in the sandy soil, then glances at the bluff on the other side of the Rio Grande, toward Mexico. Little by little, however, the proceedings led by Senator Fred Thompson are fulfilling their mandate to uncover the abuses of last year and lay the foundation for reform. The asphalt court in the city's Central Ward is sunk three or four feet below the burned-grass mounds of Jesse Allen Park, giving ''the run'' a Coliseum-like excitement as hundreds of local fans, many of them from the Felix Fuld public housing project down the block, sip beer and soda and stand above the action, cheering the players on. The court had been a gathering spot for years before a league was formed in 1989. Most of its original 10 teams survive despite a brief spell in the early 90's when flagging interest threatened to close it down. For the last two years, the league's supervisor, schedule-maker and final authority for court disputes has been Jay Waller.

title: Of Kayaks and Cormorants

The southwest wind kicked up whitecaps in Trincomali Channel, slapping our kayaks broadside, and clouds began to obscure the distant mountains of Vancouver Island. Overhead a fish-scale haze spread across what had been clear blue sky an hour earlier. Conditions weren't severe enough to worry experienced sea kayakers familiar with these waters, but we were neither. My husband, Stanley, and I were just out for an afternoon's paddle on a four-day island getaway with family and friends. This was only our second trip to the Gulf Islands in British Columbia. Besides, the kayaking classes I had taken a few years earlier had made me permanently leery of any force of nature remotely capable of flipping the boat upside down and forcing me to perform the dreaded ''self-rescue'' maneuver with a pint of frigid saltwater up my nose.

title: Images of Private Dreams
description: A collection of crisp portraits and soft-focus landscapes taken from 1977 to 1996, THE SILVER CORD (Scalo/DAP, $45) is a kind of austere, arid diary of the photographer David Armstrong's life. He has frozen the beauty of his friends -- mostly gay men, along with a few women and people of indeterminate sex -- in cool, classical poses, calm and patient and private. His subjects sit quietly in somberly lighted rooms with wistful expressions on their faces. In one series, Armstrong's lover placidly embodies various images of gay sexuality: posed as a sailor, in a dog collar, on a bed with velvet-soft window light caressing his face, his shoulders, the marbly veins in his hands. The blurry landscapes look like abandoned portraits -- the people have all gone away, leaving behind empty streets and gardens. In these photographs, instead of creating sharp, legible images, Armstrong makes misty, moody, painterly pictures that drag the viewer in, back into private memories and dreams. Some of these uninhabited spaces seem more alive than the pictures with people: we never learn much more about personalities than that they are lovely. Armstrong's portraits seal a perfect past in amber, while his diaphanous landscapes beckon with the promise of possibility. Jake Miller

title: What Modern Slavery Is, and Isn't
description: SLAVERY has been in the news a lot lately. Last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said a Mexico-based ring had been holding deaf Mexican illegal immigrants in ''virtual slavery'' in New York. A few days later, the Mayor himself was accused of condoning slavery by requiring at least some of the city's million-plus welfare recipients to work at community jobs. ''Rudy, we will not be your slave drivers,'' said posters held by representatives of religious organizations and voluntary agencies who refused to participate in the city's workfare plan. Slavery is a label applied to low-wage workers in the garment and sportswear industries abroad and sweatshops in American cities. It is invoked to condemn the sex industry and prison labor.

title: Advice to the Glovelorn
description: By the end of Philip Roth's new novel, ''American Pastoral,'' the decline of the domestic glove industry has come to stand for nothing less than the demise of American civilization. ''When they assassinated Kennedy and Jacqueline Kennedy left the White House, that and the miniskirt was the end of the ladies' fashion glove,'' laments Lou Levov, a glove manufacturer from Newark and one of Roth's main characters. Conversations with Lou inevitably turn to the lost arts of the trade he loves, in long soliloquies that incorporate technical vocabulary (tranks, fourchettes) and a seemingly unlimited inventory of glove trivia. Readers who knew that Shakespeare's father was a glover, raise your hands.

title: Help for Rape Victims, A Doctorate for Pharmacists
description: Because their injuries are usually not life-threatening, victims of rape often must endure long waits at hospital emergency departments. To avoid destroying evidence, they cannot change clothes, shower, eat, drink or use the bathroom. To speed examinations, improve collection of evidence and provide compassionate treatment, a program called the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) program has been established in Monmouth County. Twelve nurses, trained in the medical, legal and psychological needs of rape victims, are on call at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank and Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, each with a special treatment area. Collaborating with the hospitals are the Women's Center of Monmouth County crisis center, the Monmouth County Prosecutor's Office and 48 police departments.

She was anxious before setting out; she'd been having a hard time in social situations -- parties, especially. At 5 feet 10 inches with long blond hair, green eyes and an underbite that often makes her look as if she's half-smiling, Jill cuts an imposing figure for 16; she is the sort of girl boys notice instantly and are sometimes afraid of. And the fear is mutual, despite her air of confidence.

title: Books From The Times

Brody and reporters of The New York Times, edited by Nicholas Wade (Times Books/Random House, $27.50). The articles are arranged by subject (stages of life, cancer risks, eating right), and the main body of the text is preceded by the forthright confession in a headline that ''Health Advice Is Easier to Give Than to Follow.''

title: The House Sir Walter Scott Built
description: THE energetic young agent at the Scottish Tourist Board in Edinburgh was regretful. There were no longer organized tours to Abbotsford House. She tried valiantly to divert us with alternatives -- Sterling Castle, perhaps, or a day trip to Arran. But we were insistent. We had come to Scotland, in early spring, to visit Abbotsford, Sir Walter Scott's estate in the Border Country. It was a pilgrimage of a kind, to celebrate my husband's completion, after years of delighted absorption, of ''The Surgeon's Daughter,'' the final volume in the collected works of the dean of Scottish literature. We wanted to see the desk at which Sir Walter had written ''Ivanhoe'' and to stroll along the banks of the Tweed, his ''shining river.''

description: THE biennial battle for control of the Board of Legislators is under way, but with an added twist this year. The question is no longer just whether the Republicans will retain a majority of the seats on the Board but whether they can elect what the party's leader called a working majority.

title: On the Affinity Between Poetry and Art
description: In tracing the affinity between poets and painters $(Art review: ''Tracing the Affinity Between Poetry and Art,'' July 6$), the theme of the current exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn, Helen Harrison, your reviewer, overlooked feferring to ''Twenty-One Etchings and Poems.'' Unlike other collaborative projects between contemporary artists and poets, this unique portfolio, limited to an edition of 50, has been recognized as an important influence having aroused the interest of many contemporary artists and poets to undertakea similiar endeavor after 1960 when the portfolio had been exhibited at the Morris Gallery in Greenwich Village. The portfolio received impressive reviews in the major art publications and in the New York Times.

title: Men Behaving Very Badly as a 90's Metaphor
description: IMAGINE ''CARNAL KNOWLEDGE'' with Jack Nicholson going unpunished for his male chauvinist behavior. Picture Billy Wilder's ''Ace in the Hole'' with the cynical reporter played by Kirk Douglas not dying at the end. Or superimpose onto the last scene of ''Vertigo'' a shot of James Stewart turning to Kim Novak as he pulls her up to the bell tower: ''So,'' he asks, forcing her to look over the ledge, ''how does it feel?''

Churchville of Manhattan. The Rev. Donal Kehew performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church on Block Island, R.I.

Formerly a singer, she was a member of MWA and The National Arts Club. Her book Switchback, written with coauthor Tom Bade, is a time travel fantasy love story. All those who survive her are sustained by the power of her love.

description: ''Ordinarily, consenting adults must bear the consequences of their conduct, including sexual conduct. In the sanctuary of the church, however, troubled parishioners should be able to seek pastoral counseling free from the fear that the counselors will sexually abuse them.''

title: Why Israel Shrugs At the Swiss List
description: ON the day when the first list of dormant Swiss bank accounts was published last week, the evening news program in Israel carried nothing about it. And the main headlines in Israeli papers dealt not with the list but with a one-day strike and the collapse of a stadium bridge. In fact, the entire storm over assets of Holocaust victims held in Switzerland never really made many waves in the country where, it would seem, the reaction should be most intense.

title: Avant-Garde To a T
description: Last Monday, the Austrian designer Helmut Lang, left, showed his collection in New York for the first time, rather than in Paris. And Lang-clad fans could be seen along Fifth Avenue, as well as at the widely anticipated show, held in a garage on West 27th Street as part of men's fashion week. Mr. Lang's avant-garde clothes, widely imitated by other designers, are based on a credo of simplicity, and designs in black, with a contrasting white or color sash, were this season's success. Two women, top left, wore satin trousers with a matching sash. Others wore his perforated slip dress, left, or T-shirts with a vinyl band or slashed sleeves.

title: Commuter Rail for the Home
description: If this particular New Jersey Transit train is late, you have no one to blame but yourself. It's made by Lionel; its route is in your rec room or basement, and punctuality is a personal matter. Last year, when Lionel introduced its first limited-edition set -- an engine and three passenger cars -- dealers couldn't keep up with the demand. Two thousand orders went unfilled.

title: Susan L. Rosner, Robert L. Rovner
description: Susan Lynn Rosner, a daughter of Roslyn Rosner of East Hills, N.Y., and Philip Rosner of Fort Salonga, N.Y., was married last evening to Robert Leo Rovner, the son of Gwendolyn and Sidney Rovner of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi Batsheva Meiri performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Victory 13 Remains Elusive For Jones
description: Bobby Jones had a league-high 12 victories in mid-June and a legitimate claim on a few Cy Young award votes. A month later, he would probably settle for his 13th victory.

title: If This Keeps Up, They'll Be Charging for Health Care
description: Effectively ending its policy of providing free higher education for everyone, the British Government said last week that its universities would begin imposing tuition fees on all college students. By American standards, the proposed fees -- about $1,600 a year --seem small, but British students said they were shocked at losing what they had long regarded as a basic right.

title: Colonel Discharged Over Homosexuality
description: The Army has discharged a decorated lieutenant colonel just one week shy of the 20-year career mark that would have entitled him to full retirement benefits after his home was burned down and a firefighter found a videotape of the colonel engaging in sex acts with other men.

title: Teaching Abstinence: The Price of Federal Money for Sex Education
description: If the Federal Government says yes, New Jersey will be getting $4 million for new sex education programs. There's just one catch: the money must be used only to teach children to say no, to completely avoid sex until marriage.

title: Kathleen Lynch, Jonathan Hale
description: Kathleen Marie Lynch, a teacher, and Jonathan Michael Hale, a chef, were married yesterday at the Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N.Y. The Rev. Jeffrey McArn, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The High Cost Of Sexual Harassment
description: At first, the State Attorney General, Peter Verniero, said he felt no need to publicly discuss his decision that New Jersey pay $344,873.82 in lawyers' fees and settlement costs in the sexual harassment case brought against the state Republican chairman, Chuck Haytaian.

title: Eclectic Mix Of Ontario Inns
description: NOT so many years ago, accommodations in Ontario's small towns and countryside left a lot to be desired. No longer. Ontarians are learning that a little luxury goes well with their forests and lakes, and dour villages where people toiled six days a week and prayed on the seventh have been rededicated to relaxation and pleasure. Last fall I stayed at three very different places, loosely describable as country inns: a summer house converted to a bed-and-breakfast, a limestone gristmill reincarnated as an inn, and a remote hunting and fishing lodge that has become a very French, very Ontarian retreat.

title: Thriller, the Unusual and Children's Book
description: IN the 15 years that Laura Van Wormer made the Hamptons her retreat, she kept an extensive journal, jotting down where she went and whom she saw.

title: Pataki Vetoes Bill On Condo Loans
description: In a move that surprised condominium lawyers, Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have allowed condo boards to borrow money for their buildings.

title: For Deaf Peddlers, Both Opportunity And Exploitation
description: You can buy practically anything at the wholesale stores on Los Angeles Street: smiling ceramic Buddhas, crates of heart-shaped sunglasses, countless Spanish-language videos of action movies. The deaf peddlers come mostly for key chains.

title: August Nights, Chamber Recitals
description: For 28 years, the stated mission of the Chestnut Hill Concerts has been to bring world class chamber music to the Connecticut shoreline, and that's what one can expect on the first four Fridays in August. The First Congregational Church of Madison has a lawn for picnicking before the performances, which begin at 8 P.M. this season.

title: A Refugee From the 70's
description: After you've read Hortense Calisher's latest novel, IN THE SLAMMER WITH CAROL SMITH (Marion Boyars, $25.95), the landscape of Manhattan looks different. Carol Smith, the narrator as well as the heroine of the story, was an accessory to an undergraduate bomb plot in the early 1970's; for this she was sent to prison, where she suffered a mental collapse. And after 20 years of confinement, she winds up in a shabby room in Spanish Harlem, under the intermittent care of an unstable social worker. Confronted with the New York of the 1990's, Carol soon finds herself wandering the streets. Although the novel provides a frank, unbiased exploration of homelessness, its strength is at times undercut by the flimsiness of its plot. Yet Calisher's vibrant, erratic rhythms make Carol's observations continually surprising. ''In the Slammer with Carol Smith'' is as jazzy as its title. If you're willing to look past the vagaries of its plotting to its remarkable prose, Calisher's book will yield ample rewards. Emily Barton

Even so, he emerged as golf's Dalai Lama, visited in his Fort Worth office by touring pros hoping to learn the secret of his swing. Or any secret.

description: To the Editor: Anyone traveling to Beaver Creek, Colo., this summer should be warned about massive construction in the area. In the village center, hundreds of hard hats begin at 6 A.M., and continue until 7 P.M. Dust, noise, trucks, trailers, cranes and roped-off areas make a visit here quite unpleasant.

description: To the Editor: ''From Mazes to Millipedes: Museums for Young Minds'' (June 29) was terrific! Each museum is a wonderful place for young people -- and adults -- to stretch their minds, and to have fun.

title: Archipelago With French Flair
description: IT was the boat that first intrigued us: a high-riding white ferry plowing crisply through the midnight-blue waters of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, on its voyage from Souris, on the eastern shore of Prince Edward Island, Canada, to Cap-aux-Meules on the Iles-de-la-Madeleine. The boat, glimpsed from the P.E.I. campground where we've vacationed for several years, had the same effect on us as watching Canada geese in flight: We felt landlocked, rooted. We wanted to go. So last August we took a five-day break from P.E.I. and found ourselves on the deck of the Lucy Maud Montgomery (since replaced by the larger Madeleine), on a five-hour, 70-mile trip northwest to the Magdalen Islands (as they are called in English) of Quebec.

title: For the Fishlady, a Business That Gives Life an Aquatic Slant
description: HER license plate reads, ''Fishlady,'' and Jeanne Pedro lives up to the name. As owner and operator of her own business here, Tanks Alot, she is on call day and night, setting up and tending to aquariums in people's homes, offices and other spots where pretty swimming creatures soothe frazzled nerves.

description: There we were, on a plane to cyprus, feeling assaulted by the slings and arrows of modern life, and convinced, perhaps perversely, that the farther we traveled and the more obscure our destination, the more rested we would feel.

title: Crime
description: I am pretty much fed up with series mysteries that grind round and round on the same rusty wheels. Equally annoying is that phony maintenance work known as ''character development,'' which too often means that the hero has got a new gun or the resident cat has had kittens. So it pleases me to report on some authors who are smart enough to know when to fiddle around with the formula for a successful series -- and when to leave well enough alone.

title: Nirvana in the Can
description: New York City prison officials recently met with Farrokh Anklesaria, who is the director of the Enlightened Sentencing Project in St. Louis. Topic: the possible use of Transcendental Meditation techniques in city jails. At a cost of $1,500 per inmate, Anklesaria says, T.M. training could reduce the recidivism rate in a big way, saving the government millions. It gives you a different sense of living, said one participant in a court-ordered T.M.-for-probationers program in St. Louis. I've seen my inner self.

title: When a Man Cannot, A Song Soars
description: EAMONN McGIRR sang his heart out the other night. He sounded just as he used to, his tenor like a clarinet. Afterward, the people squished together below the bandstand at Tricentennial Plaza kept chanting his name, which sounded like ''Amen, Amen, Amen.'' Then they went on about how he had restored their faith in God and the world.

It's only a silly play in a community theater, but it's theirs. And even a silly play is living theater; that beats a television sitcom, which is only a living.

title: A Vaporous Medium for a Steamy Season
description: ''SUMMER Pleasures,'' in the lobby of the headquarters of the Schering-Plough Corporation here, is an exhibition of watercolors that offers few surprises but provides a special kind of satisfaction. The usual haunts associated with the season are here in force, including boats, beaches and front porches. Many of the works are cliched or trite, but since the medium is the difficult and transparent one of watercolor, which allows no covering up or repairs, a feeling of admiration that it can be done at all enters into the experience.

''Lay aloft,'' called out the captain of the deck, and 216 sailors, marines and civilian crew members scurried up the rigging of the U.S.S. Constitution and unfurled its sails.

title: Stargazing
description: We are children of a star, nurtured by rays from the sun. The six-part mini-series SOLAR EMPIRE tries to unravel the mystery of our particular star and the solar system that surrounds it. Photographs taken by Voyager I and II and the Hubble Space Telescope and computer graphics take us to Mercury, the sun's nearest neighbor, where temperatures range from -300 to 800 degrees Fahrenheit; to Venus, hidden behind clouds of sulfuric acid, and to Saturn's tangerine surface and marmalade sky surrounded by icy pearls. Michael Dorn's narrative helps paint a picture of Earth and the solar system, which in five and a half million years may have its final sunset -- SUNDAY AT 10 P.M. ON TLC. Yolanda A. Andrews

title: Art That Survived In a Land Of Tumult
description: ''ANXIETY IS IN THE AIR AT ANGKOR,'' wrote the American artist Ad Reinhardt in 1961, after visiting the ruined temples of the Khmer kings of Cambodia, built between the 9th and the 13th centuries. To him, the spectacle of a fabled architecture and sculpture being slowly suffocated by the jungle was both moving and deeply unnerving.

The account was previously handled on a project basis by Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif.

It was not just an idle remark. He meant that he respected his colleagues' faith in their differing understandings of what the Constitution requires.

title: As Cathedral Opens, Preacher-Politician Looks Ahead
description: A few hours after attending services early yesterday morning, Charlene Simpson was so overwhelmed by the opening of New York City's newest cathedral that she returned to worship at the day's third and final service. For Mrs. Simpson, the new $23 million Cathedral of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens, was the crowning achievement in the church's efforts to rebuild what is still one of the borough's poorest corners.

description: In her first speech as the new president of the American Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman urged teachers yesterday to take the lead in helping to close poorly performing schools rather than fighting to keep them open.

description: MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom Inc., and Yahoo Inc. announced the introduction of their much anticipated World Wide Web music guide, Unfurled, this month. The music cable network and the Web directory service teamed up to create the new site, which will offer music fans a comprehensive directory linking users to music-related Web sites. Unfurled will also have daily music news, event listings and industry gossip.

Hamilton responded that he is not a crybaby, that Mets catcher Todd Hundley is really the crybaby, and Hundley answered with a lot of nasty words, most of which were adjectives unsuitable for a Padre, particularly on a Sunday.

title: Finding which bacteria have infected a patient and which antibiotic will be most effective.
description: AS some bacteria become increasingly resistant to antibiotics, doctors must combine more and stronger forms of the germ-killers to find an effective drug. Sometimes, that process requires experimentation with different antibiotics to see if they eliminate bacteria. If time is of the essence, that can be dangerous for severely sick or injured patients.

title: Zanardi Takes U.S. 500
description: Last year, when the U.S. 500 took place the same day as the Indianapolis 500, a pace-lap crash by the front row ruined Championship Auto Racing Teams' effort to upstage Indy. title: Reveling in Punk's History And a Few Subtle Variations
description: There's punk, any simple chord progression played faster than mid-tempo with aggression and hoarse vocals. There's hardcore punk, quicker and darker, which once had regional differences but boiled down to a crude state that has pretty much stayed the same for 15 years. And then there's sunny, frenetic ska-punk, which has been around for about as long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMISKEY, FRANK J.
description: CUMMISKEY-Frank J. Age 70, retired Vice President of International Business Machines, died Friday, July 25, 1997, of a heart attack. A resident of Greenwich, CT, he served as Vice Chariman of DSC Communications of Plano, TX, until April of this year. Before his retirement, Mr. Cummiskey served in a variety of domestic and international positions including President and Director of IBM Europe S.A., President and Director of IBM World Trade Europe, Middle East, and Africa Corporation, and Presidient of IBM's General Business Group/International. A member of Indian Harbor Yacht Club since 1967, he served as Commodore and Director. He also was a member of the New York Yacht Club and the Council on Foreign Relations. He was bon in New York City to Julia Carroll and Frank J. Cummiskey. He is survived by his wife Geraldine Shea Cummiskey and nine children: Frank J. III; John J.; Mary Jean C. Young; Paul J.; Catherine M.; Elizabeth C. Evans; Peter J.; James J.; Sarah C. Taylor; eleven grandchildren and two sisters: Margaret M. Cummiskey of Bronxville, NY, and Mary C. Trapasso of Warren, NJ. A memorial service will be held at Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Steamboat Road, Greenwich, CT, on Wednesday, July 30, at 4 PM. The family request that in lieu of flowers a donation be made to Save The Children, PO Box 940, Westport, CT 06881 (203-221-4000), or a charity of your choice.

title: New Yardsticks for Global Banks
description: Throughout the developing world, the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in recent years were symbols of the untempered free market. Nations seeking loans have often had to cut their budgets, which usually meant slashing social spending. They had to privatize and deregulate. But as World Bank officials lent money to build Eastern Europe after Communism's fall, they began to realize that these countries needed more than free markets. They needed healthy state institutions. The bank, and more slowly the fund, are now beginning to direct their loans to the welcome goal of building effective states.

title: Editors' Note

title: State Campaign Records Hide the Facts
description: It would cost just a few hundred thousand dollars for New York State to replace its jumbled record-keeping on campaign contributions with an easy-to-understand system of computerized campaign filings. The computerized system would let citizens monitor the flow of money and help deter the widespread corporate cheating that now takes place under cover of poor record-keeping. But legislation to make it happen is going nowhere for want of leadership from Gov. George Pataki.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, GRACE KOPIT (NEE ESTHER G. KOPIT)
description: PERLMAN-Grace Kopit (nee Esther G. Kopit). Of Palm Beach, FL, died July 25, 1997. Born September 7, 1915, she was the devoted daughter of Jacob and Dora Kopit, cherished wife for 46 years of the late Joseph, loving mother of Sandy, Kenneth and Dr. Felice, doting grandmother of Lindsay, Jacob and Elizabeth. A graduate of New York University, she was a founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and for many years an active member of its Women's Division. She was a woman of uncommon charm, humor and elegance, unsurpassed in her love and devotion to her family and adored by them in return. A delightful friend and companion, she was herself blessed with many wonderful and enduring friendships. She was a remarkable woman and will be missed every day. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Graveside service Monday, 11 AM, at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY.

description: For a girl who uses a wheelchair because of cerebral palsy and an elderly man who stopped driving long ago, the Edison bookmobile provides an invaluable service, library officials said last week.
