description: The descendants of the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Sr. have perpetuated his name from one generation to the next -- sometimes more than once in a generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLER, AARON DAVID
description: BRESLER-Aaron David. Age 73. Retired Director of Antenna Systems Divsion for AIL Systems, Inc. Dr. Bresler was a Life Fellow of the IEEE. He was a graduate of CCNY cum laude in 1944 and received his MEE and DEE from Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. Beloved husband of Marjorie (Denker Wiener); loving father of Emily and Tom Kuhny, Susan Bresler, Edie and Kevin Bresler O'Malley and Stewart and Sagit Bresler; caring step-father of Susan and Carol Wiener; cherished grandfather of Tamir, Aviv and Natalie; brother of Helen and Jesse Drogin and Martin and Shirley Bresler. Funeral service Monday, 10 AM, at Gutterman's, Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: A Running Club Is 100 Miles Outside of the Mainstream
description: As the sun climbed over a distant ridge of the Rockies one recent Sunday morning and the temperature climbed through the 40's, Steve Peterson stood meditating at the edge of a meadow. His hands moving as if to conduct an inner orchestra, he performed a series of exercises meant to align his body and mind for a 55-mile training run, during which he hoped to achieve a state described by the name of his running club: Divine Madness.

title: A Vanquished Star of the PC Universe Now Hopes to Render the PC Superfluous
description: Philippe Kahn is in stealth mode, plotting his revenge on the PC industry.

title: Mexicans in New York Search for a Toehold on a Crowded Ladder
description: The Irish who moved to Mott Haven in the 1860's searching for jobs are long gone, but the memory lingers at St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church. The altar and sanctuary walls -- in marble of green, white and orange-yellow -- are a sly echo of the Irish colors. Above, huge stained-glass windows depict Bible scenes, like Jesus feeding the multitudes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, JOAN (HEMING)
description: FRANK-Joan (Heming). On July 24, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John V. Frank. Loving mother of Daniel H. Frank and Katherine L. Frank. Mother-in-law of Patricia Lowy Frank and Jerome F. Page. Devoted grandmother of Samuel, Jasper, Lucas, Ian and Cole. Dear sister of Harriet Simpson, Charles Heming and Delia Cantor. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in memory of Joan Frank to the Central Park Conservancy. Family will receive visitors on Monday, July 28, 5-8 PM at her home. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: A New Dynasty Begins at the Tour de France
description: The next dominator has arrived. By general agreement, the Jan Ullrich era has begun in the Tour de France.

title: Pharmacy System Restored
description: A computer system that reimburses New Jersey pharmacists for prescription sales was back on line late Saturday after it was shut down for the third time this month, The Associated Press reported.

title: Irving Geis, 88, Prolific Artist Who Helped Demystify Science
description: Irving Geis, an artist who illuminated the wonders of science, from the vastness of space to the intricacies of molecular structures, died on Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 88 and lived in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

title: At Palestinian Papers, Money Is as Elusive As Freedom
description: Just as Palestinians are struggling to establish a state of their own, an independent Palestinian press is fighting to be born. So far, neither effort has been easy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNFELD, BERNARD
description: KORNFELD-Bernard. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted and treasured father of Adam and Neil. Proud grandfather of Zachary and Stephanie. Loving fatherin-law to Margo and future fatherin-law to Jillian. Dear brother of Ann. He loved and was loved and admired back. He will be greatly missed and is in our hearts forever. Memorial service to be held today at 5 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel on W. 76th St. Friends who wish may contribute to the Mayo Clinic's Amyloid Research Program, c/o the Hematology Dept.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNEY, DOROTHY
description: DOWNEY-Dorothy. A woman of great wit and warmth who loved people and politics, words and music, grammar and syntax, but above all, family and friends, died peacefully Friday at her home in North Salem, NY. She was eightynine. Born Dorothy Evelyn Paddock on May 17, 1908, she was the daughter of Ellen Meehan Paddock and Lewis Nathan Paddock of Providence, RI. There she graduated from famed Classical High School and later from The Katherine Gibbs School. Subsequently, she worked for the Providencebased Paddock Paper Company and continued her musical studies. She was an accomplished pianist and vocalist when she met and in 1933 married James Edward Downey of Hartford, CT. The couple lived in Providence until 1940. Dorothy and James Downey were blessed with four sons and then two daughters. As she would with her grandchildren a generation later, Dorothy imbued her children with an individual sense of uniqueness, values and fair play. She made each person she touched feel like the most important being in the world. The Downeys lived in the New Haven area throughout the 1940s and afterwards in Concord, MA. In 1954 they moved to Darien, CT. Some years later, following her husband's death in 1969, Dorothy relocated to her home in North Salem. Mrs. Downey is survived by her children: Dr. James L. Downey, a pediatrician of Winnetka, IL; Robert N. Downey, partner Goldman Sachs of NY; Steven M. Downey, Chairman DWT, Inc., of NY; Paul A. Downey, President of Downey Capital, of San Francisco; Eleanor Downey Martinez, former Senior Editor at NetRadio of NY; and Caroline Downey Abrams, Chief of Legislation and Legal Opinions, NYS Division of Human Rights, also of NY; a sister, Eleanor Paddock LaBonne, of Somers, NY; 19 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. For information, contact Clark Associates Funeral Home of Katonah, NY. Visiting hours will be on Monday evening from 6-8 PM at 4 Woods Bridge Road in Katonah. A funeral mass will be offered for Dorothy at St. Joseph's Church in Croton Falls, NY at 10 AM on Tuesday, July 29, 1997, with interment that afternoon at Old North Burial Ground in Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers, and in recognition of Dorothy's lifelong love of politics, women's rights and public service, donations are asked to be made in her name to ''Emily's List'' or to the American Cancer Society.

title: Restaurant Chain Picks Austin Kelley
description: Rio Bravo International in Atlanta, a unit of Applebee's International Inc., named Austin Kelley Advertising in Atlanta to handle advertising for its Rio Bravo Cantina restaurants, which had been at McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago for two years. Billings were estimated at $5 million. The decision came after a three-month review that also included Barkley & Evergreen in Kansas City, Mo., Henderson Advertising in Greenville, S.C., and Wyse Advertising in Cleveland.

title: People
description: * Mark Buckman, senior vice president and worldwide media director on the Coca-Cola account at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group, was named to the added new responsibilities of worldwide media operations director. Muirne Laffan, vice president and international group media director, was named to the new post of senior vice president and media director. And Mark Stewart, executive vice president and media director at McCann New York, was named to the added responsibilities for McCann North America.

title: Official in India Sets Up A Dynasty of His Own
description: India's most unpredictable and contentious politician has stirred new waves of indignation by responding to a warrant for his arrest in a $280-million corruption scandal by resigning his top post in the country's poorest state, naming his wife as his successor and vowing to continue ruling from a jail cell.

title: The Impossible Crime
description: Any intelligent person who takes a close and honest look at the David Wayne Spence case will see that it was a travesty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENSON, ROBIN BROUDE
description: STEVENSON - Robin Broude, passed into the light, July 24, 1997 at 4:48 PM. Beloved wife of Bruce, sister of Susan, daughter of Bernard and Martha. Formerly a singer, she was a member of MWA and The National Arts Club. Her book Switchback, written with coauthor Tom Bade, is a time travel fantasy love story. All those who survive her are sustained by the power of her love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, PETER J.
description: RYAN-Peter J. The partners and employees of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson mourn the passing of former partner Peter J. Ryan who imparted to us and our clients wise counsel and much wisdom. We feel privileged to have benefited from his humanity, which embodied much of what was, and is, good about our law firm. We will always remember Peter for his exceptional qualities as a lawyer and friend, and for the humor and grace that made each of us proud to be his colleague. We extend heartfelt sympathies to his entire family.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, JEROME
description: WALLACH-Jerome. Husband of the late Goldie Wallach. Beloved father of Susan and Len Weiss, Betty Melnick and Jane Kessler. Dear brother of Frances Schwartz. Loving grandfather and G.G. Pop. Services private.

title: The Many Faces Of a Single Master
description: Ornette Coleman's four-night run in Avery Fisher Hall, titled ''? Civilization,'' was oddly exposing, and not necessarily in the way Mr. Coleman wanted. At 67, he is widely regarded as one of this country's living musical geniuses, and his rhetoric as an outsider notwithstanding, he has been feted with some regularity. Lincoln Center did the right thing, and without any apparent reservations, put on the greatest hits of Ornette Coleman.

title: Patterns
description: Comeback for Musclemen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, ANN
description: WEISSBERG-Ann. The East Hampton Tennis Club mourns the loss of our longtime active member. An avid tennis player, she was a great friend and will be missed. Our deepest sympathies go to Joe, Norbie, Judith and their families. Gil Bach, Pres., EHTC

title: Face the Facts About Alcohol and Crime
description: As a former director of national drug policy, I have been an outspoken advocate of tougher drug policies, and I believe that one of the most troubling social trends of this decade is the explosive increase in marijuana use by young people. But there is another area that the public needs to pay attention to as well: the link between alcohol and crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIX, CHARLES W.
description: NIX-Charles W. On July 27, 1997. Devoted companion of Evelyn Rothstein, loving brother of Dorris. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Blast at Putnam County Steakhouse Kills 2
description: A thunderous explosion demolished a popular steakhouse and bar in Brewster, N.Y., yesterday afternoon as workers began preparing for the dinnertime rush. Two people inside were killed and five others were injured, the Putnam County Sheriff's office said.

title: A Hire Lets Donna Karan Do What She Does Best
description: Donna Karan excels at many things. Now, she is going to focus on them.

title: Of Blacks and Jews, and Calls for Talk
description: Dialogue is the main prescription offered tonight for the headaches that Jews and blacks keep causing each other. Bring youngsters together and ''let them dialogue,'' somebody says. But most of the people seen talking together in ''Blacks and Jews'' are evidently not infected with racism or anti-Semitism. Mostly they are worried about other Jews, other blacks, who probably require stronger medicine than talk.

title: Stocks End Mixed; Dow Rises 7.67 Points
description: Investor uneasiness about air-thinning market levels and weakness among technology issues dragged the broader market down yesterday, but analysts were largely unconcerned that economic reports scheduled for release this week would fuel further selloffs.

title: U.S.-Made Land Mines Killed Many Americans, Report Says
description: Studies long stored in the Pentagon's archives show that tens of thousands of American soldiers were killed or maimed in the Vietnam and Korean Wars by American-made land mines, according to a report by groups seeking American support for an international moratorium on the weapons.

title: Reject William Weld
description: William F. Weld's decision to resign as Governor of Massachusetts and campaign for the job of ambassador to Mexico is a strong step based on his self-interest as he sees it. Now the U.S. Senate should take a strong step based on the country's self-interest, by rejecting him for the job.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: IMC Global to Acquire Freeport-McMoran Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HACQUEBARD, ELISA
description: HACQUEBARD - Elisa. Dearest Elisa, thinking of you. Much love, Gerry

title: Not Nolan Ryan, at Least for Now
description: A funny thing happened to Hideki Irabu on his way to the New York Yankees' bullpen. He ended up in Columbus, Ohio. After an impressive debut against Detroit on July 10, Irabu staggered to a shaky victory against Cleveland on July 15 and was then hammered by Milwaukee and Seattle, neither of which showed much respect for his $12.8 million contract or his advance billing as the ''Japanese Nolan Ryan.''

title: Amendment Will Only Protect Some Religions
description: To the Editor:

title: Marriott Planning a Hotel On a Garment District Site
description: The Marriott Corporation will build a sliver-thin 244-room hotel on 40th Street, just west of Avenue of the Americas, the first new building in 27 years in the congested, cavernous streets of Manhattan's garment district, according to plans to be announced today by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Stony Brook, With a Partner, Seeks to Run Brookhaven Lab
description: In a move that would join the largest educational and research institutions on Long Island, the State University of New York at Stony Brook announced plans today to seek a Government contract to manage the troubled Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: Tuition Is Coming to Oxford
description: Last week Prime Minister Tony Blair upset British college students, and especially their parents, by announcing that all undergraduates may soon be billed for tuition. Thus Mr. Blair's Laborites propose ending a long-held British commitment to free higher education, a step his Conservative predecessors never dared venture. Moreover, the plan means that Britain's million-odd university students will no longer be automatically eligible for generous local educational authority grants to cover room and board.

title: River Rises. So Does German Mettle.
description: The dike that protects Burghard Maierwald's house from the silken, silvery menace of the bloated Oder River is just a few hundred yards of flatland away from his door. And so, after days of flooding that has devastated swaths of Central Europe, he decided that it wouldn't happen here as it has in Poland and the Czech Republic.

title: Bosnians Back Home, With Quiet U.S. Help
description: As her husband and neighbors pounded away to frame a roof for the house that the family had fled when it was shelled five years ago, Ferida Osmic, 60, began to thank those who had made it possible for them to come home.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: Kirin Brewery To Close Some Plants
description: The Kirin Brewery Company, Japan's largest beer maker, said yesterday that it would close some plants and increase productivity at existing operations to cut costs. The move comes as Kirin struggles to regain market share won by its fast-growing rival Asahi Breweries Ltd., maker of Japan's best-selling beer, Super Dry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIPP, SAMUEL, S.
description: TRIPP-Samuel, S. On July 27, 1997 in his 94th year. Beloved husband of the late Mary Tripp. Devoted father of Grace and Norma. Grandfather of eight. Great-grandfather of ten. A passionate and committed lawyer and servant of the law for 68 years. Service 1pm, Wed, Schwartz Bros, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Westinghouse, in a Surprise, Says It Earned a Slight Profit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported an unexpected profit for the second quarter today, with higher advertising and cash flow at its radio stations overcoming a loss from its struggling CBS television network.

title: Unfitted Jackets for Summer
description: Structured and relaxed are the yin and yang of this fall's fashion, and in fashion there are always contradictory extremes. While it's still summer, the structured power suit may hold few charms, but the unfitted jacket has vast appeal. And there are many lightweight versions in stores now.

title: Turning the Immigrant Experience Into Song
description: The Nuyorican Soul show at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Friday night had the feel of a rock opera, but with a narrative that was less built in as a story than external. The show, a reproduction of a record released this year called ''Nuyorican Soul'' (GRP) and produced by (Little) Louie Vega and Kenny (Dope) Gonzalez, made an argument for the Puerto Rican experience in New York in the 1970's. It's an experience that, like all immigrant experiences, mixes the old country with the new.

title: No Headline
description: ''The church is not a museum for saints. It's a hospital for sinners!''

title: Three Firms Moving to City
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation has recruited three small high-technology companies to move to Manhattan.

title: Papers Crucial In Florida Deal Over Tobacco
description: As a trial nears in a major smoking-related lawsuit against the tobacco industry, a legal confrontation is looming between Florida officials and cigarette company lawyers over the disclosure of documents.

title: Yankees Take Move in Stride
description: Hideki Irabu's demotion yesterday did not send shock waves through the Yankees' clubhouse. After all, that's baseball, and these are the Yankees.

title: Cambodian Chief Puts on Show of Government as Usual
description: Armed force gave way to parliamentary theater today as Cambodia's de facto leader, Hun Sen, sought to legitimize his seizure of power with an elaborate demonstration of government as usual.

title: Astronomers Recalculate 'Whack' That Made the Moon
description: BEFORE the Apollo lunar explorations, scientists had three competing theories for the origin of the Moon. In the fission theory, the early Moon had spun off from Earth, leaving the Pacific basin as a scar. Another theory conceived of the Moon as a small wandering planet that had passed too close and was captured by Earth's gravity. Or the Moon and Earth might be siblings, both accumulating and evolving as separate planetary objects in the same neighborhood.

title: Workfare Issue Now Blocking Budget Accord
description: Yet another issue is further delaying the already long-delayed state budget: workfare. One side of the debate, led by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, wants to keep workfare costs down. The other side, led by Assembly Democrats, wants workfare participants to be eligible for union membership and to have the hours they work more accurately reflect the jobs they do.

title: To Test a Powerful Computer, Play an Ancient Game
description: DEEP BLUE's recent trouncing of Garry Kasparov sent shock waves through the Western world. In much of the Orient, however, the news that a computer had beaten a chess champion was likely to have been met with a yawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITWORTH, PAUL C.
description: WHITWORTH-Paul C., Psychotherapist and WW II Veteran, on July 27, 1997, of Phila., formerly of West 86th St., New York. Dear brother of Ruth Foltz and Warren Whitworth. Survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Services and interment private. Contributions in Paul's memory can be made to Save the Children Foundation, 54 Wilton Rd., P.O. Box 940, Westport, CT 06881. For information L.A. DiGiacomo, Inc., 215-677-9300.

title: The Audacity of William Weld
description: Not every governor would give up his job to campaign for Senate confirmation as ambassador to Mexico, but then not every governor has the independent means, political ambitions and quirky instincts of William Weld. Mr. Weld's decision to vacate the Statehouse in Boston sets up one of the oddest and potentially most interesting personal confrontations Washington has seen in years. He may not overcome the recondite objections of Senator Jesse Helms, but in challenging the North Carolina Republican's imperious, parochial management of the Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Weld does a service to his party and the nation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BAUSCH & LOMB INC., Rochester, named David Whalen president of its North American eyewear division.

title: Spano Raises Funds for Bail
description: John A. Spano has raised the $1.5 million he needs to secure the $3 million bail imposed last week at his arraignment for Federal bank and wire fraud charges in connection with his failed acquisition of the Islanders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENOK, ABBY D.
description: LENOK-Abby D. on July 28, 1997. Beloved wife of Eugene. Devoted mother of Paul and Arlene, Amy and Evan. Dear sister of Dr. Stanley and Gloria Datlow. Cherished grandmother of David, Amanda, Hillary and Joshua. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, ESTHER
description: NOVAK-Esther. Wife, mother, friend, on July 27, 1997, at age 82. She died peacefully after a full and productive life. Her counsel, compassion and love will be sorely missed. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Abraham, two children, Joel and Isabel, four grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. For information regarding the burial service, please call I.J. Morris Memorial Home, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: MASCO ACQUIRES CABINET MAKER, TEXWOOD INDUSTRIES
description: The Masco Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Texwood Industries, a closely held United States manufacturer of kitchen and bath cabinets. Financial terms were not disclosed. Masco, a building products maker, said it expects Texwood, based in Duncanville, Tex., to have 1997 sales of about $150 million. Masco, based in Taylor, Mich., had 1995 sales of $2.93 billion. Texwood will operate as a subsidiary of Masco's Cabinet Group. Masco said the acquisition would broaden its range of kitchen and bath cabinetry.

title: A Bad Feeling Chases Messier Out of New York
description: It was just one year ago that Mark Messier sat beaming on a makeshift podium in Madison Square Garden as the Rangers announced the signing of Wayne Gretzky.

title: Lincoln National Set to Acquire Bulk of a Cigna Business
description: Seven weeks after selling its big home and automobile insurance unit, the Lincoln National Corporation said yesterday that it was buying most of the Cigna Corporation's individual life insurance business for $1.4 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JACK
description: GREENBERG-Jack. The Board of Directors, Administration and Staff of Peninsula Hospital Center are saddened by the loss of Jack Greenberg, a beloved volunteer and member of the East End Auxiliary. Deepest sympathies are extended to the family. Robert V. Levine, President and Chief Executive Officer Joel A. Miele, Sr., P.E. Chairman, Board of Directors

title: Q&A
description: Sleep Deficits

title: No Matter the Language, Obsession Is Obsession
description: On stages around the world, an international form of pop music exists. The language can be changed without stylistic problems, and international pop music takes as its model English-speaking pop and rock, occasionally using local sources to remind audiences where they're from. Ednita Nazario, who performed on Sunday afternoon as part of the Expresiones Latinas series for Lincoln Center Festival '97, is Puerto Rican, and sings in Spanish.

title: A Novelist Beginning With a Bang
description: The last chapter is, without question, erotic and subversive: a divorced Syrian Christian woman from the southern Indian state of Kerala makes love on a moonlit riverbank to the graceful household carpenter, an outcaste Hindu. There are references to an untouchable tongue, to terror and pleasure, to the price that will be paid. ''Night's elbows rested on the water and watched them,'' Arundhati Roy writes with the kind of sensuous personification that marks ''The God of Small Things,'' her strikingly well-received first novel.

title: Restaurateur Bows on Name
description: Donald Eckhard knew about Chiclets chewing gum before he opened his restaurant two years ago and called it Chicletts Cafe. But Mr. Eckhard was surprised when the gum's manufacturer, Warner-Lambert, filed a Federal lawsuit against him on July 2, claiming that he had infringed on the Chiclets trademark. Yesterday, Mr. Eckhard reached a settlement under which he will accept $1,000 from Warner-Lambert and rename his restaurant.

title: Whiten Gets Chance to Hear Cheers
description: When Mark Whiten was announced as the batter in the ninth inning last night, the fans at Yankee Stadium did not know how to react. They have been consistently booing Whiten, who is under investigation in a sexual-assault case in Milwaukee. But he was in a position to win the game for the Yankees, so they remained silent.

title: Powell Is Silent On CUNY Position
description: Urged yesterday to follow the lead of Dwight D. Eisenhower, who became president of Columbia University before running for President, Gen. Colin L. Powell would not say whether he would consider becoming chancellor of his alma mater, the City University of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBER, EILEEN
description: LIEBER-Eileen. On July 28, 1997. Artist, and also an art teacher for the Valley Stream school system for many years and studied at the Art Student's League. Beloved wife of Lawrence, devoted sister of Barbara Rappaport, loving aunt of Michael and William Rappaport. Services Wednesday, 11 am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Gregorio Weber, 81, Biochemist And Innovator in Spectroscopy
description: Gregorio Weber, a biochemist at the University of Illinois who broke ground in an area of chemical analysis called fluorescent spectroscopy, died on July 18 at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 81.

title: RODALE PRESS AGREES TO ACQUIRE NEW WOMAN MAGAZINE
description: Rodale Press said yesterday that it would acquire New Woman magazine from the K-III Communications Corporation and that it would end cigarette and hard-liquor advertisements when it took control.Terms were not disclosed. Rodale, the closely held publisher of Men's Health, Prevention and other health magazines, said it would start publishing New Woman with the November issue. New Woman has a paid circulation of about 1.3 million, down from 1.35 million in 1991. Rodale said the ban on tobacco and hard-liquor advertising was consistent with its longstanding company policy. Last year, less than 10 percent of New Woman's advertising was for cigarettes or hard liquor, the companies said.

title: Top Driver Seriously Injured
description: DAVE VILLWOCK, 42, the leading driver in hydroplane racing, was injured when his boat, Miss Budweiser, crashed on Sunday during the Tri-Cities (Wash.) Water Follies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The long goodbye: COLETTE AVITAL, who was the Israeli consul general in New York until last week, has been the guest of honor at farewell parties for almost a year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about recent quarterly earnings reports included the second-quarter results of the Kellogg Company erroneously. Kellogg plans to report its results on Friday; the reference to a 62.2 percent gain applied to an estimate from analysts surveyed by First Call.

title: Man Held as Enforcer in Chicago Ring Exploiting Deaf Peddlers
description: A 21-year-old illegal immigrant from Mexico was charged yesterday as the enforcer -- the man who took in the money and gave out the beatings -- of a Chicago ring that law enforcement officials said was associated with a New York operation accused of exploiting deaf Mexican immigrants.

title: Blood Test Planned Over Cosby Paternity
description: A lawyer for Bill Cosby said last night that the entertainer was having his blood taken for a paternity test in hopes of proving that he is not the father of Autumn Jackson, the woman who claimed to be his out-of-wedlock daughter and who was convicted last week of extortion.

title: Adult Prisons Won't Reform Young Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: The Garden's Cerebral Move
description: I shall not miss Mark Messier's penchant for taking over a game through his force of personality or his ability to score a game-winning goal. The guy is 36, isn't improving, got hurt a lot and can't be regularly spectacular. But what grew more spectacular with each of his six years in New York was his amazing cranium. So let Ranger fans excoriate Madison Square Garden executives as modern-day sons of Harry Frazee, who sold Babe Ruth to the Yankees.

title: College Cheaters
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES ENERGY AGREES TO SELL PROPERTIES
description: The Equitable Resources Energy Company, a unit of Equitable Resources Inc., agreed yesterday to sell its oil and natural gas properties in the Western United States and Canada to five purchasers, for a total of $174 million in cash. The Cabot Oil and Gas Corporation will buy property in the Greater Green River Basin in Wyoming; Inland Resources Inc. will buy property in Uinta Basin, in Utah; Big West Oil and Gas Inc., a unit of Flying J Oil and Gas Inc., will buy property in Powder River Basin, Wyo.; Summit Resources will buy the Williston Basin property in Montana and North Dakota, and EBOC Energy Ltd. will buy properties in western Alberta, in Canada.

title: Town Sets Fly Traps on Beach
description: Town officials have set traps on the beach to curb an infestation of salt marsh greenhead flies, which attack like mosquitoes and swarm like locusts. The marsh greenhead flies have laid siege to this island resort north of Atlantic City, the A.P. reported yesterday.

title: Malaysia's Conspiracy Theory Draws Criticism From Albright
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and her deputies waded publicly into a culture clash with Malaysian leaders today, rejecting repeated charges that Southeast Asian currencies were being sabotaged by Westerners and dismissing calls for a rewriting of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which Malaysia's Prime Minister called oppressive.

title: City University Students Earn Their A's and B's
description: To the Editor:

title: Payless Cashways Stock
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would delist Payless Cashways after suspending trading in the company's stock and debt securities. The exchange said the level of the company's net tangible assets had fallen below acceptable standards. Last week, Payless Cashways, a building materials retailer based in Kansas City, Mo., filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law.

title: Batting Seventh Today for the Mets: Just About Anyone
description: Manny Alexander, the Mets' young infielder, once played in Baltimore, where the lineup rarely changed. Brady Anderson always led off, unless he was suddenly hit with an appendix flare-up or if cracked ribs prevented him from playing. Cal Ripken always played shortstop, and if he was hitting well, he would bat fourth or fifth, depending on whether a left-hander or right-hander was throwing.

title: IMC to Buy Freeport-McMoran Inc. for $750 Million
description: IMC Global Inc., fortifying its position as the world's dominant producer of phosphate fertilizers, announced an agreement yesterday to buy Freeport-McMoran Inc. for about $750 million.

title: DISNEY TO SELL 8 NEWSPAPERS FOR $185 MILLION
description: The Walt Disney Company agreed yesterday to sell eight newspapers in Oregon to Lee Enterprises Inc. for about $185 million and to sell a group of shoppers, free-circulation newspapers, to Harte-Hanks Communications for $104 million. The moves further the strategy of Disney of divesting itself of publishing assets to focus on its movie, entertainment and theme park businesses. The deal with Lee, based in Davenport, Iowa, also includes a shopper and specialty publication group that covers eight markets in Washington, Oregon, Nevada and Utah. The shoppers that are being sold to Harte-Hanks reach 2.4 million homes in California and the Midwest. Harte-Hanks, based in San Antonio, is already the largest publisher of shoppers in North America.

title: For Yankees and Irabu, Hype and Big Plans Backfire
description: New York is a funny town. Yesterday, it was downright hysterical, screeching over the Rangers' failure to break the bank for Mark Messier while at the same time smirking over the Yankees' insistence on breaking the bank for a couple of ineffective pitchers named Hideki Irabu and Kenny Rogers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 17 about the trauma involved in testifying before South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission about abuses during the apartheid era misstated the title of Thomas J. Winslow at the Trauma Center for Victims of Violence and Torture, a nonprofit group in the Cape Town area. He is the logistics manager, not the assistant manager.

title: Growing Fetal Tissue for Surgery at Birth
description: EXPERIMENTS on lamb fetuses may have put scientists closer to developing tissues for repairing birth defects in newborns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANNING, ANDREWS
description: WANNING-Andrews of Saugerties, New York, and Blue Hill, Maine, age 84. Professor Emeritus of Bard College, 17th century scholar and lover of literature, music and sailing. Graduate of Choate, Yale and Cambridge University, Professor Wanning also taught at Yale and Harvard. Stricken while traveling in England, he died in Kingston, New York, on July 25. He leaves his former wife, Patricia Emerson Watson, his brother Thomas Edwards Wanning, his sons Rufus and Thomas Wanning and daughter Esther Wanning, and two grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the Bard College Chapel at noon Friday, Aug 1. Donations may be made to Bard or Magdalene College, Cambridge, England.

title: Motor Vehicle Branch Pushed
description: Following last week's announcement that the state would spend $1.4 million to ease lines at motor vehicle inspection stations, two State Assembly members asked Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday to reopen a branch office of the state Division of Motor Vehicles in Paterson.

title: Shooting and Scoring, Sometimes
description: TO THE HOOPBy Ira Berkow296 pages. Basic Books. $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, COL. HARRY H.
description: HAAS-Col. Harry H., died peacefully at home in Victoria July 24, Born March 19, 1900 in Union City, NJ. Graduated from United States Military Academy at West Point in 1922. Married Hazel Newkirk in 1923. After retiring from the Military in 1955 he joined Houdaille Industries and was appointed vice pres. in 1957 retiring in 1963. Survived by his daughter, Jacquelyn (Kenneth) Gibbs; two grandchildren, Karen and Donald; great grandchild, Benjamin, of Victoria, B.C. Funeral services will be held at U.S. Military Academy West Point Thurs, July 31st 1:30PM.

title: Teasing Brains, Not Trigger Fingers
description: THE MICROSOFT CORPORATION has long contributed to the electronic drain on America's productivity with games like Flight Simulator, Solitaire, Minesweeper, Powerpoint and Windows Reboot. Its newest entry is Microsoft Entertainment Pack: The Puzzle Collection, a project developed largely in Russia and overseen by Alexey Pajitnov, the Moscow-born designer of the infuriatingly addictive Tetris. He now works for Microsoft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASH, MONROE
description: NASH-Monroe, of Tenafly, NJ, age 84, on July 26th, 1997. Beloved husband of Florence J. Devoted father of Dr. Irwin, Dr. Carl R., Laura H., and Theodore R. Loving grandfather of twelve. Services were held Monday. For info, call ''Wien & Wien,'' 800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. Jan 17, 1911-July 26, 1994. FELIX...his name meant ''happy,'' and that was what he always made me and all those whose lives he touched so lovingly. Janice

title: Current-Account Deficit Falls in South Korea
description: South Korea's current-account deficit fell 73 percent in June, to $360 million, in a promising sign for companies that are counting on a stronger won to inflate their profits. The won has dropped 14 percent against the dollar since early 1996 as Korea's record current-account gap limited the supply of dollars. The won stabilized in mid-March as exports started to recover.

title: In Gianni Versace's Creative Shadow
description: From the sober sans serif dedication in the program of Calvin Klein's show to Tommy Hilfiger's giddily opportunistic alignment with a man who believed in rock-meets-fashion, Gianni Versace was never far from the thoughts of those at the New York men's wear shows, which ended yesterday. Two weeks ago, the nomadic audience was in Florence at Mr. Versace's last men's wear collection. So it was not without a chill that they found this sentiment from Mr. Klein at the first show of the season: ''I would like to dedicate this collection to the memory of Gianni Versace.''

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Role Grows in Bosnia

title: Treat Drug Offenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarkson Fisher, Federal Judge, Is Dead at 76
description: Clarkson S. Fisher, who rose from Monmouth County judge to serve as the chief judge of the United States District Courts in New Jersey from 1979 to 1987, died on Sunday at the Medical Center of Princeton. He was 76 and a lifelong resident of Long Branch, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, RAE
description: THALER-RAE. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our longtime member. We extend condolences to the family. Services were held at Gutterman's Rockville Centre, July 27th. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMR CORP., Fort Worth, sold its offshore data management business to National Processing Co., Louisville, Ky., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: GOLDSTEIN-William died July 24, 1997, son of the late Samuel and Ethel. Survived by daughter Linda Cohen, son Arnold, granddaughter Holly Cohen, a brother Judge Aaron F. Goldstein of NY State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, IDA
description: SCHWARTZ-Ida. The Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY, sadly records the death of its longtime member and friend. Sincerest condolences to her husband Louis and the family. May God comfort and console them. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Stanley A. Shanies President

title: Lincoln Center Is 'Interested' In a Theater at Coliseum Site
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had been discussing a new theater with Lincoln Center officials for quite some time, but it remained unclear whether anyone outside his administration knew until a few days ago that he wanted to propose the Coliseum site in Columbus Circle instead of a location closer to the center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTON, FANNY
description: FELTON-Fanny. Widow of Gregory; beloved aunt of Jim Leyton and Harry Harel. Died peacefully July 26, 1997. Burial at Enfield Cemetery, London, July 29, 3:30pm.

title: Police Say a Serial Rapist Has Attacked 31 Women Over 3 Years
description: A serial rapist has been attacking women in the Bronx and Northern Manhattan over the last four years, often in city housing projects, the police said last night.

title: Cunanan Reward Paid, And Mayor Is Chided
description: The caretaker whose inspection of a houseboat led the Miami Beach police to the body of Andrew P. Cunanan visited Manhattan yesterday to receive a $10,000 reward from a gay advocacy group. And he seized the opportunity to needle Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for not following through on his own promise of an identical reward.

title: Criticism Over Blast Leads Top Air Force General to Retire
description: The top general of the Air Force said today that he would retire early, in part because he believed one or more Air Force officers would unfairly be held responsible for the terrorist attack in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 airmen last year, lawmakers and Pentagon officials said.

title: Joan H. Frank, 77, a Producer Known for a Hallmark TV Series
description: Joan Heming Frank, a television producer who worked on the original ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' drama series in the 1950's and 60's when the performances were broadcast live from a studio in Brooklyn, died on Thursday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 77.

title: Fans Spread the Blame for Their Loss of a Star
description: Leonor Mamanna was home when an aunt called with the news. Mark Messier was leaving the Rangers and signing with the Vancouver Canucks.

title: A Long Love Affair With a Crown Jewel
description: The Royal Ballet has come here for years without the Lincoln Center Festival and will undoubtedly do so in the future. The company's brief run may have been made possible by joint financing from both the festival and the Metropolitan Opera, but the overwhelming sense was that the festival needed the ballet more than the other way around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JAMES JOSEPH
description: O'CONNOR-James Joseph, 81 years, on July 28th, 1997, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Jane. Devoted father of Patricia Brown, Susan Boyd, Catherine O'Connor, James J. O'Connor, Jr. and stepfather of Marylove, Jeffrey and Richard Thralls, Barbara Peck and Joan O'Brien. Adored ''Papa Jim'' to nineteen grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A broadcast engineer with WOR Radio, Mutual Broadcasting and the BBC. He handled radio communications during the Gemini VI, Apollo and Skylab programs. He served for 30 years with the Navy MARS system and was known on ham radio as ''W2KGO.'' Member of St. Mary's R.C. Church for 55 years, the American Legion Post #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, RHODA B.
description: MOKOTOFF-Rhoda B. At age 85 on July 27, 1997 after a long illness. Survived by her husband of 62 years, Harold; children Steffi and Robert Berne, John (Moke) and Hue Mokotoff; grandchildren Elizabeth Berne, Alexander Berne and Sophia Mokotoff; brother Mickey Becher. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY 11968, will be gratefully received.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, CHARLOTTE
description: GOLDBERG-Charlotte of Margate, FL died July 27, 1997. Wise and strong, loving wife of the late Max A. for 67 years. Mother of Rita and Charles Goldberg, Robert and Arlene Goldberg. Grandmother of Steven and Sara Goldberg, Bruce and Leslie Goldberg, Jayne and Richard Woolf, David and Janet Goldberg, Robin Goldberg. Great grandmother of Danielle, Jesse, Joshua, Jennifer, Andrew, and Evan. Memorial services at 12:45 PM, July 30th, Guttermans, Rockville Centre.

title: A Point of View Is a Festival's Point
description: Festivals are meant to take us out of ourselves, to break our cultural routine. They do so by having a point of view, and it usually belongs to a single person. One can argue with John Rockwell's tastes -- for Lincoln Center Festival '97 was certainly a reflection of its director -- but these few weeks have told us a lot about his. That is as it should be.

title: Chess
description: Tal Shaked, the United States junior champion, made a very nice showing in the June edition of the First Saturday tournament series in Budapest, but came up short of what he wanted. He did indeed win the competition, with a 9 1/2-3 1/2 score, and in doing do so surpassed three grandmasters. By a half-point, however, the 19-year-old Shaked missed achieving the norm that would have made him a grandmaster.

title: U.S. Atomic Tests in 50's Exposed Millions to Risk
description: Atmospheric nuclear bomb tests in Nevada from 1951 to 1962 exposed millions of American children to large amounts of radioactive iodine, a component of fallout that can affect the thyroid gland, the National Cancer Institute said today.

title: Struggling Family Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, PAUL L.
description: MILLER-Paul L. Seventy-seven, died peacefully after a full and productive life on Saturday, July 26th. He is survived by his wife of forty-seven years Adele, and his three daughters Hilary, Beverly and Leslie, one granddaughter and four grandsons. His son, Paul L. Miller, Jr. died in 1993. There will be a private burial and service in Northeast Harbor, ME. Those wishing to may send contributions in his memory to The Peregrine Fund, World Center for Birds of Prey, 5666 West Flying Hawk Lane, Boise, ID 83709.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call for a new theater on the site of the New York Coliseum paraphrased the reaction of a Lincoln Center official incorrectly. The official, who spoke on the condition that he would not be named, said that Lincoln Center, which has been seeking to build a theater of its own at Broadway and 64th Street, did not need two new theaters for itself. He did not say that the area could not accommodate two new theaters.

title: Japanese Auto Exports Rise 20.6% in 6 Months
description: Japanese auto makers exported vehicles at the fastest pace in a decade in the first six months of the year, as a combination of popular models, a weak yen, surging demand overseas and slow sales at home all helped overseas sales. With exports up 20.6 percent from January through June, Japan's 11 auto makers are ahead of their projected 6.9 percent growth for 1997.

title: Optimism on Report Today Lifts Bonds
description: Treasury prices surged yesterday, bolstered by optimism that today's Employment Cost Index report would show that labor costs remained subdued.

title: As Currency Crisis Roils Asia, Thais Ask I.M.F.'s Help
description: The fast-growing countries of South and Southeast Asia, regarded for years as the most economically promising of the world's developing nations, have been shaken by a plunge in their currencies.

title: Hundt Endorses MCI-British Telecom Merger
description: Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said yesterday that he would support British Telecommunications' $21 billion takeover of the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: Guccione Eyes The Voice
description: Robert Guccione Jr., the founder of Spin magazine and the son of Robert Guccione Sr., the publisher of Penthouse magazine, wants to buy The Village Voice and said he has retained an intermediary to approach The Voice's owner, Leonard N. Stern.

title: Conglomerates Learn to Pick Their Spots
description: Last month, Textron Inc. said it was selling Speidel, the old-line watch maker. There was nothing wrong with Speidel -- indeed, its earnings had been growing at a steady 5 percent annual clip. It was simply the only consumer-product company left in the Textron stable. ''We want to focus on our core manufacturing and finance businesses,'' James F. Hardymon, Textron's chairman, said.

title: Serbia Is Cracking Down on Radio and TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Senator in Campaign Finance Hearings Stays Above the Fray
description: First, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut was the Democrat who was toughest on his fellow party members during hearings of the Senate committee investigating possible campaign finance abuses. Then last week, he was the toughest on four nuns.

title: It's Mexico or Bust as Restless Massachusetts Governor Resigns
description: Gov. William F. Weld announced his resignation today, midway through his second term, saying he wanted to devote his full attention to fighting for the Mexico ambassadorship, a job few in Washington think he will get.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND THE G.O.P. ANNOUNCE DEAL TO BALANCE BUDGET AND TO TRIM TAXES
description: Congressional Republicans and the Clinton Administration agreed tonight on how to balance the budget for the first time in nearly three decades and on the first major tax cuts since 1981.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIPNIS, SIDNEY
description: KIPNIS-Sidney. A resident of Santa Monica and Palm Springs, CA. and formerly of Williambsburg, Brooklyn, died on July 23, at age 70. Survived by his beloved wife, Geri, his dear children, Neal Kipnis of Riverside, CA. and Robin Kipnis Kaufman, of Agoura, CA., their equally cherished mates, Dana Kipnis and Gregg Kaufman, his sweet grandchildren, Lindsay Kipnis and Jared and Brooke Kaufman and his dear brother, Sol, and his mate, Lily. A resident of California since his discharge from the US Navy at the end of World War II, he never forgot Brooklyn and the friends of his youth.

title: Prison-Building Pretext
description: To the Editor:

title: The Elderly Need Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, ISABEL
description: ROBERTS-Isabel of Riverdale, New York. Formerly of Great Neck. On July 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Chester. Loving mother of Terry Greenberg and Maxine Brennan. Mother-in-law of Arthur. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and his wife Jeanette, Barry, Gail and Kevin. Great-grandmother of Danny. Cherished sister of Ethel Jones. Services will be conducted at Riverdale Funeral Home. 5044 Broadway at 214th St., New York City, on Wednesday, July 30, at 1 p.m.

title: Where the Girls Are, and Why They're Not So Different From the Boys
description: Watching the all-female festival the Lilith Fair at Jones Beach last weekend, and reading the many stereotypes about female musicians that the tour has generated in the news media, one can't help wondering whether there really is a difference between male and female pop singers and songwriters. The people who choose the Grammy Awards seem to think so, since they have separate categories for male and female vocalists. But outside of vocal range, do men and women really sing about different things in different ways?

title: We'll Have The Theater De Jure
description: HERE we are, almost in August, with New Yorkers wondering where to go now for lively theater. Broadway is marking time, the Lincoln Center summer festival is over and most of the season's blockbuster movies are out.

title: Closest to Their Hearts
description: President Clinton got his way on many of the big disputes over Federal spending, while Congressional Republicans prevailed on the tax issues about which they care most deeply.

title: A Dynamic Farewell From a Longtime Rights Leader
description: He preached and beseeched. He bounced and denounced.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: CHRONICLE
description: TONY BLAIR, the new British Prime Minister, has been undergoing one of the rites of passage into power. He has been having his picture taken by well-known photographers.

title: Some Changes Via E-Z Pass at George Washington Bridge
description: The new electronic toll system was inaugurated yesterday on the George Washington Bridge, doing little to shrink the wait for most commuters but allowing drivers with the new E-Z Pass tags who managed to use special lanes to zip right through.

title: After two decades and counting, Procter & Gamble is still trying to exorcise Satanism tales.
description: IT will apparently take an act of God for the Procter & Gamble Company to kill persistent tales that its trademark and its executives are linked to Satanism.

title: A Money Trap Leaves 'Irish Houdini' No Escape
description: To the millions of Irish men and women who made him Prime Minister three times, Charles J. Haughey was The Boss, an intelligent and benevolent ruler with a tight smile for his friends, a steely blue-eyed glance for his enemies.

title: Some Scientists Ask: How Do We Know Dolly Is a Clone?
description: In the five months since the clone named Dolly was announced, some scientists have begun to grumble. How do we know the whole thing wasn't a hoax? Why didn't the scientists who created Dolly go to greater lengths to prove that she really is what they say she is, a lamb produced by cloning the udder cells of an adult sheep? Why, some ask, is the rest of the world so willing to accept the world-shattering claim that an adult animal was cloned?

title: A General Retires Over Blast Criticism
description: The top general of the Air Force, Gen. Ronald R. Fogleman, said yesterday that he would retire early, in part because he believed that one or more Air Force officers would unfairly be held responsible for the terrorist attack in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 airmen last year.

title: Run Silent, Run Deep, Run Into . . . Oops!
description: Oct. 3, 1986, was a Friday. Rosh ha-Shanah began at sundown, ''Children of a Lesser God'' opened in movie theaters and the Mets-Pirates game was postponed because of rain. That day, if HBO's intelligent, ultimately gripping film ''Hostile Waters'' is accurate, New Yorkers were seconds away from death by nuclear disaster. So were Bostonians, Washingtonians and everyone in between. As Rutger Hauer, playing a Russian submarine captain, tells his crew, ''Not only will we be vaporized, but the entire Eastern Seaboard of the United States will feel the heat.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RETTINGER, ABE
description: RETTINGER-Abe. 93. Leaves his wife, Tema, after 70 years together; his daughter, Frances Guze; his son, Dr. Seymour Rettinger; sonin-law, Dr. Solomon Guze and daughter-in-law, Charlotte Rettinger; his sisters, Lilian Bernheim and Sarah Brill; his grandchildren, Dr. Peter Wenig, Robert Wenig, Jodi Koch, David Rettinger, James Rettinger; great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Funeral at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck on Wednesday, July 30th at 12:00 noon.

title: Conjuring Rabbits and Bikes
description: Contented purring seemed to fill the John Jay College Theater on Friday night. But although rabbits, doves and geese appeared in ''Le Cercle Invisible,'' there were no cats. The purring came from a delighted audience.

title: Gulf Canada to Buy Stampeder Exploration
description: Gulf Canada Resources has agreed to buy Stampeder Exploration Ltd., a Canadian crude oil exploration and production company, for stock worth $739 million (Canadian), or $532 million (United States), the companies said yesterday.

title: Forget the Youngsters, Holmes Wants Foreman
description: Larry Holmes does not hold any illusions about getting a shot at a heavyweight title. He just wants to work his way toward a big payday against George Foreman in a sort of oldies reunion before this year is over.

title: Spiritual Hodgepodge
description: To the Editor:

title: In Its Second Year, the Numbers Get Bigger if Also Vaguer
description: The Royals have decamped. Ditto ''Les Danaides'' (suitcases and all), ''The Zulu Macbeth,'' NG La Banda and Beowulf, bringing to an end the second annual performing arts marathon that made up Lincoln Center Festival '97.

title: Honors
description: * Joanne Davis, senior vice president of the Advertising Club of New York, was elected president, succeeding R. Jeffrey Petersen. Ms. Davis is a managing partner at Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Mr. Petersen is associate publisher of Architectural Digest, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications. Steven Farella, senior vice president and director for North American media operations at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which is owned by MacManus Group, was elected senior vice president, succeeding Ms. Davis.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: A Guitar the Size of a Cell
description: SCIENTISTS at Cornell University have built a guitar about the size of a human blood cell, a microscopic instrument with six real strings that a germ could pluck, if it had fingers and a taste for high-pitched music.

title: Heat Wave Lifts Corn and Soybean Prices
description: Corn and soybean futures prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as weekend rain missed the driest Midwestern growing areas and forecasts called for more hot weather, raising concern that crops could be damaged during critical development stages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, BARBARA SCHWAB
description: ROSENBERG-Barbara Schwab. Entered into rest July 24, 1997. Cherished wife of fifty years to Fred Rosenberg of Mamaroneck, NY. Beloved mother of Robert and his wife Diane of Princeton, NJ; Ann and her husband Eric Walsh of Portland, Oregon; Charles and his wife Jan of Port Chester, NY; Jean and her husband Peter Southwick of Arlington, MA. Lovingly remembered by her grandchildren Rebecca, Jessica, Robin, Dylan, Natalie and Lindsay. Funeral arrangements private. Memorial donations to Harvard Medical School, Office of Resource Development, 25 Shattuck Street, Boston, MA 02115, attn: Renal Research Fund.

title: A Tired Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Away Secrets
description: Internet hype can turn age-old problems into new grave threats. The biggest tempest may be the concern over the use of encryption, or secret codes, to scramble information sent over the Internet and other computer networks. The use of codes may thrill people who want to protect the business plans on their office computers and the love letters they send by E-mail. But it worries the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh, and other law-enforcement officials.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: 2 Chip Mergers Show Growing Consolidation
description: Consolidation in the chip industry accelerated today, with the announcement of two multimillion-dollar acquisitions.

title: American Express Profit Rises Beyond Analysts' Expectations
description: The American Express Company's second-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, as the company increased its revenue from its charge card, credit card and investment advice businesses.

title: Jewish Voyagers to the New World Emerging From History's Mists
description: AN enduring image of the earliest Europeans to arrive in the New World, with help from Hollywood, is an overdressed Conquistador, crucifix or sword held high, spreading salvation among the indigenous population.

title: Start of Free Transfers Spurs Use of Metrocard
description: Nearly a month after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority introduced free transfers between subways and buses for Metrocard users, the card accounts for about 4 in 10 rides each day in the system, officials said, a marked turnaround from the card's slow beginnings.

title: Cultures Collide Down in the Aisles
description: Expresiones Latinas was a grand invitation, an inclusive gesture in thinking about the Americas. The presentation of seven days of pop music from the Hispanic world at an institution concerned predominantly with European art suggested a serious evaluation and a cultural openness that seemed fresh.

title: In a Borough of Immigrants, A Strong Market for Hovels
description: A prospective tenant is led into yet another of the human beehives found behind the pleasant facades of residential homes in Queens. The first floor has been carved into five cubicles, the second into six. Some renovations are so recent that chunks of plaster litter the parquet floor, and wooden door frames have yet to be painted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARONEY, DR. JAMES HILTON ''PAT.''
description: MARONEY-Dr. James Hilton ''Pat.'' Of Summit and Basking Ridge, NJ. On July 23, 1997. Peacefully, in the presence of his sons, at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Born Cranford, NJ, on April 2, 1908. Educated at Cranford H.S. '24, Pingry '25, Lawrenceville '26, Princeton '30, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons '34. Interned at St. Luke's Hospital, NYC, in internal medicine and pediatrics. Married Mary Fowler (1910-96), of NYC '36. Practiced pediatrics at Summit Medical Group, which he was the 10th physician to join, and Overlook Hospital 1938-76 and at Matheny School & Hospital 1956-96. Emeritus Fellow Medical Society of New Jersey and American Academy of Pediatrics. Commissioned Lt. jg US Navy '42; served at Philadelphia and Annapolis in American Theatre and as Chief Medical Officer aboard USS Wright in Asiatic Pacific Theatre, WWII; Honorably Discharged Lt. Comdr. '46. Cofounder and First President 1955-59 of Beacon Hill Club, Summit. A man of honor, dignity, integrity, generosity, frugality and wit. Loved gardening, woodworking, gaming, sailing and maple sugaring with family and friends in Vermont. Admired greatly all who work with their hands. Survived by his three children-Mary M. Walston, of Albuquerque NM, James H. Maroney, Jr., of Leicester VT, and Denman F. Maroney, of Monsey NY-and eight grandchildren. A memorial will be held at Christ Church, 561 Springfield Ave, Summit NJ, Sat Aug 16 at 10 AM. Donations in his memory may be made to Matheny School & Hospital, Main St., Peapack, NJ 07977.

title: Wayfarers Hauling the Best of Intentions
description: Big cast (120 people)! Big topic (humanity's inhumanity)! Big scholarly ambitions (the re-creation of an Aeschylean tetralogy that survives only in fragments)! Plus the international and intellectual cachet of a Romanian cast speaking a French translation of classical Greek poetry, all wrapped in a visual elegance that could go straight to the windows of Bergdorf Goodman!

title: Taking His 'Phantom' Power Into the Ballad World
description: Only a singer of extraordinary stamina could endure the rigors of playing the title role in ''The Phantom of the Opera'' for 1,937 performances without signs of strain. But Davis Gaines, who has racked up that record number for any performer around the world in productions of the show, may be the closest thing on Broadway nowadays to a vocal Superman. With an instrument that soars through the normal baritone and tenor ranges with pitch-perfect control and an acute, mechanized vibrato, he appears to have a voice of steel.

title: Caretaker in Brooklyn Is Shot and Killed
description: A caretaker who spent 18 years cleaning and maintaining a city housing project in Brooklyn was shot and killed yesterday afternoon as he gathered the trash outside one of the apartment buildings, the police said.

title: An Important Small Bill
description: Gov. George Pataki must decide soon whether to sign a bill that benefits a small number of utterly helpless New Yorkers. There will be no political benefit to supporting the legislation, and it will probably make some of Mr. Pataki's administrators angry. But issues like these are among the reasons the Governor, and indeed most elected officials, say they went into politics in the first place.

title: CRITICAL VIEWS
description: CLASSICAL

title: Deep Roots And High Energy
description: Folklore and show business entwine for Daniela Mercury and Albita Rodriguez, who shared a bill at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night, part of the Expresiones Latinas week at Lincoln Center Festival '97. Ms. Mercury, from Brazil, and Ms. Rodriguez, from Cuba, are both determined to reach a broad audience without abandoning their roots. Their solution: keep local rhythms, write or find catchy tunes, sing about love and homeland, dress for rock videos and pour on the energy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTHELEUR, DIDIER
description: MARTHELEUR-Didier. In memory of our beloved Didier, who passed away on Sunday, July 27. We will cherish the love and joy that he brought into our lives. He leaves behind his son Sam, his wife Shannon, his parents Nicole and Andre, his sisters and brother, Astrid, Jean and Yaan, his grandmother Paulette, his uncles Sylvain and Jacques, and many other family and friends who will miss him dearly. Friends who wish to join the family in remembering Didier are invited to the Plaza Memorial at 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 11am on Tuesday, July 29th.

title: Hard-Core Smokers, Last-Ditch Remedies
description: THEY stay in a small unit at the end of the hall on the 10th floor of Methodist Hospital here -- the incorrigible cigarette smokers. Five men and three women, all at the end of their rope, each having paid $3,000 to spend eight days living in a bland hospital room of the Mayo Clinic, and each fervently hoping that an intense residential program will make it possible to quit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNEY, DOROTHY
description: DOWNEY-Dorothy. A woman of great wit and warmth who loved people and politics, words and music, grammar and syntax, but above all, family and friends, died peacefully Friday at her home in North Salem, NY. She was eightynine. Born Dorothy Evelyn Paddock on May 17, 1908, she was the daughter of Ellen Meehan Paddock and Lewis Nathan Paddock of Providence, RI. There she graduated from famed Classical High School and later from The Katherine Gibbs School. Subsequently, she worked for the Providencebased Paddock Paper Company and continued her musical studies. She was an accomplished pianist and vocalist when she met and in 1933 married James Edward Downey of Hartford, CT. The couple lived in Providence until 1940. Dorothy and James Downey were blessed with four sons and then two daughters. As she would with her grandchildren a generation later, Dorothy imbued her children with an individual sense of uniqueness, values and fair play. She made each person she touched feel like the most important being in the world. The Downeys lived in the New Haven area throughout the 1940s and afterwards in Concord, MA. In 1954 they moved to Darien, CT. Some years later, following her husband's death in 1969, Dorothy relocated to her home in North Salem. Mrs. Downey is survived by her children: Dr. James L. Downey, a pediatrician of Winnetka, IL; Robert N. Downey, partner Goldman Sachs of NY; Steven M. Downey, Chairman DWT, Inc., of NY; Paul A. Downey, President of Downey Capital, of San Francisco; Eleanor Downey Martinez, former Senior Editor at NetRadio of NY; and Caroline Downey Abrams, Chief of Legislation and Legal Opinions, NYS Division of Human Rights, also of NY; a sister, Eleanor Paddock LaBonne, of Somers, NY; 19 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. For information, contact Clark Associates Funeral Home of Katonah, NY. Visiting hours will be on Monday evening from 6-8 PM at 4 Woods Bridge Road in Katonah. A funeral mass will be offered for Dorothy at St. Joseph's Church in Croton Falls, NY at 10 AM on Tuesday, July 29, 1997, with interment that afternoon at Old North Burial Ground in Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers, and in recognition of Dorothy's lifelong love of politics, women's rights and public service, donations are asked to be made in her name to ''Emily's List'' or to the American Cancer Society.

title: ZYGO TO ACQUIRE DIGITAL INSTRUMENTS FOR $220.5 MILLION
description: The Zygo Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Digital Instruments Inc. for $220.5 million in stock to expand its product line of precision measuring instruments. Zygo, a maker of precision instruments that are used to increase high-technology production yields, said it would buy Digital for seven million shares, worth $220.5 million based on yesterday's closing price. Digital Instruments is based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Shares of Zygo, which is based in Middlefield, Conn., rose 25 cents, to $31.50. The company made the announcement after the market close.

title: GATEWAY 2000 PRESIDENT RESIGNS TO HEAD VENTURE FUND
description: Gateway 2000 Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Richard Snyder, had resigned to head a venture capital fund in his home state of Michigan. Mr. Snyder, who joined the direct marketer of personal computers in 1991, will continue to serve on Gateway's board. He was previously a partner at the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand in Chicago. Gateway, based in North Sioux City, S.D., was founded in 1985. Its shares fell 68.75 cents, to $39.8125, yesterday before Mr. Snyder's departure was announced. Last week Gateway reported that its net income rose to $56.5 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with $51.4 million, or 33 cents a year earlier. The latest results were below analysts' expectations.

title: Peru Leader Tries to Defuse Crisis, Denying Military Control
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori rose before Congress today in an effort to end the deepest political crisis of his career, but his state of the nation speech left unanswered several crucial questions about how firmly he is in charge of the country.

title: A Baptist Church Scrutinizes Its Leader's Lavish Life Style
description: When Henry J. Lyons was only 12, his family minister told him that he would one day become president of the nation's largest black religious denomination, making him a powerful and nationally respected figure among millions of Baptists across the country. So it was with the air of a man certain of his command that he ascended the familiar pulpit of Bethel Metropolitan Baptist Church on a recent Sunday, his baritone voice resonating.

title: Truly Blue: Fans Ignored Once Again
description: A LETTER came to the office recently from a man named John Covello, who introduced himself as the executive vice president of a new organization, America's Sports Voice. ''It's your game,'' is Covello's message for fans. ''Get it back.''

title: Nets Sign Van Horn To Three-Year Pact
description: The Nets signed Keith Van Horn, the second player selected in the National Basketball Association draft last month, to a three-year deal yesterday, a month after acquiring him from the Philadelphia 76ers in an eight-player trade.

title: Giants Not Panicking Over Dearth of Centers
description: The Giants' starting center, Brian Williams, still cannot see without double and triple vision. Day by day, he improves little, and he will learn Wednesday if surgery will be necessary to repair a fracture near his right eye. The Giants' backup center last season, Adam Schreiber, is a free agent who rejected the Giants' last offer nearly three weeks ago. The Giants have not called back.

title: Why Penguins Are Cool
description: At first glance, staying cool would not seem to be a goal of penguins. But a new study suggests that low body temperature may help king penguins stay down longer when they dive. The reason is that a lower body temperature means a slower metabolism and decreased need for oxygen, which would mean a longer time underwater, up to 7.5 minutes for king penguins, on one breath.

title: The Observer and the Observed in the Urban Scene
description: The fascination creative artists have with making the detritus and details of daily life into artworks may seem to be a peculiarly 20th-century phenomenon, given the influence of the found-object schools of sculpture and composition. Actually, the tradition of elevating the mundane goes way back. You can hear it in Jannequin chansons and the descriptive works of Baroque composers; you can see it in the tavern paintings of Jan Steen. Even the chaotic textures of urban chaos have joined the repertory in works as diverse as Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' Varese's ''Ameriques'' and several of Steve Reich's scores, from ''Come Out'' to ''Different Trains'' and ''City Life.''

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ANOTHER OPENING -- E-Z Pass made its debut on the George Washington Bridge, with a minimum of snarls. B3.

title: Borg-McEnroe Stirs Memories
description: It will be like old times on Saturday when BJORN BORG and JOHN McENROE, great rivals of the 1970's and early 1980's, meet in Colorado Springs in the semifinals of the Challenge, presented by Quality Inns. The first semifinal will match JIMMY CONNORS and YANNICK NOAH on Friday, with the winners meeting Sunday.

title: Mexico's Next Task Is to Negotiate Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, EILEEN RENEE
description: REISS-Eileen Renee. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Lynn ReissSeegert; cherished daughter of Martha Davis; devoted grandmother of Randall James Seegert; dear sister of Kenneth Davis; loving (bloody) aunt of Meredith Paige Davis. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, Tuesday, 11:30 AM.

title: For a Bar Not Used to Dancing Around Issues, Dancing Is Now the Issue
description: Back in the 1960's, the doormen at the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village had to keep an eye out for raids by the police vice squad, which regularly targeted the few gay bars in Manhattan. Lately, the bar's manager has been watching on weekend nights for the police and inspectors from the city's Social Club Task Force, investigating complaints of noise and illegal dancing.

title: Judge Rules Fire Box Plan Denies Access To the Deaf
description: A year after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council reached a hard-won compromise to shrink the city's fire alarm box system, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the plan violated the civil rights of the city's 65,000 deaf and hearing-impaired residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYLE, JOSEPH D.
description: RYLE-Joseph D. On July 25, 1997. A friend of all and a wonderful Raconteur. A memorial mass will be held. Time and place to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ROYCE MOCH
description: ROTH-Royce Moch. July 23, 1997. She leaves husband of 53 years, Dr. Francis B. Roth; brothers, Irving and Gerald, and their immediate families; children, Nancy and Jim, and their spouces Tom and Barbara; and grandchildren Alex, Sarah, and Jessie.

title: Clinton Urges Minimum Wage for Workfare
description: President Clinton today put himself at odds with Republican governors and insisted that welfare recipients who are placed in state workfare programs be paid the equivalent of the minimum wage.

title: 2 Finalists Chosen In Midas Review
description: The Midas International Corporation said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its account to two agencies, from four. The account, with billings estimated at $25 million, had been handled by the Chicago office of the J. Walter Thomspon unit of WPP Group until that agency resigned it because of a conflict with its important Ford Motor Company account.

title: Latest Swiss Bank Surprise: Secrets From the Shredder
description: After refusing for months to publicly discuss the content of files rescued from shredding by a security guard last winter, Switzerland's biggest bank said today that it had duplicates of some of the documents and that it had unearthed evidence ''possibly'' related to the sale of Jewish property in Berlin during the Nazi years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPERT, ESTHER
description: LIPPERT-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Meyer and cherished mother of Alan and dear sister-inlaw of Bernie and Caroline. Loving and loved grandmother of Michael, Robin, Gillian, Jocelyn and Dawn; and loved aunt to Edith, Alvin, Joan and Barbara and Irving, Marla, Michael, Sandra, Sari, and Hildy. Graveside service today at 11:15 at Wellwood Cemetery in L.I. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to the American Heart Association.

title: The Captain's Leaving Affects Both Roster and Image
description: After Babe Ruth left the Yankees, he finished his career with the Boston Braves. Walt Frazier, the great Knick, ended up wearing the uniform of the Cleveland Cavaliers. And Joe Namath -- Broadway Joe of the New York Jets -- was last seen on a football field dressed as a Los Angeles Ram.

title: Another Main Street Sinkhole
description: A main sewer line gave way beneath Main Street yesterday, opening yet another of several sinkholes that have jammed traffic along the busy thoroughfare in recent years.

title: Credit Report Bill to Be Signed
description: State Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, who is Acting Governor while Christine Todd Whitman attends the National Governors' Association meeting in Las Vegas, Nev., is to sign legislation today that allows residents to request one free copy of their credit report annually.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOIZEAUX, DANIEL CLARKE
description: LOIZEAUX-Daniel Clarke. Age 83 of Greenwich, CT. retired Art Director and Trustee of Loizeaux Publishers, on July 27 in Lancaster, PA. His wife, Marion Davies of England, predeceased him in 1995. He is survived by his sister, Marie Loizeaux and brother, Elie, both of Lancaster; three daughters, Katharine Loizeaux of Kent, CT, Esther den Breems of West Redding, CT and Marion Loizeaux of Greenwich, CT; and five grandchildren. Funeral on Saturday, August 2 at 10:00am, White Plains Gospel Chapel, North Broadway and McBride Avenue, White Plains, NY

title: Deputy Chief Is Top Finalist To Lead Los Angeles Police
description: The civilian board that oversees the Los Angeles Police Department today chose a deputy chief as its preferred finalist to be the next police chief of the nation's second-largest city, virtually assuring his selection by Mayor Richard J. Riordan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMOND, MATTHEW T.
description: LAMOND-Matthew T., suddenly on July 27, 1997. Beloved son of James F. and Mary Beth (nee McNerney). Loving brother of James L., Claire and Elizabeth. Adored grandson of Florence McNerney and Marie Lamond. Mass of Christian burial, Thursday, 9:30am at Saint Patrick's RC Church. Visitation, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 97th Street at Third Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Xavier High School, 30 West 16th St., NY, NY 10011, or M.A.D.D., 4617 Bedford Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBERG, ILSE
description: NEUBERG-Ilse. Born on November 25, 1900 in Krefeld, Germany. Beloved wife of the late William Neuberg; sister of the late Kurt Levin. She is survived by her nephew Dr. Hans W. Neuberg and his wife Birgit; cousins: Donald, Peggy and Joan Miller. Services Thursday 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: An Ethical Role for Recruiters
description: When John R. Walter resigned under pressure on July 16 after just seven months as president of the AT&T Corporation, his exit raised a lot of questions. First and foremost: How could the company's directors, who lavished such high praise on Mr. Walter when they hired him last fall, change their minds so quickly?
