description: To the Editor:

title: Videotape Shows Pol Pot Facing Khmer Rouge Justice
description: Pictures from an extraordinary show trial in a jungle clearing in Western Cambodia appear to provide the first concrete evidence that Pol Pot, the 69-year-old Khmer Rouge leader who has not been seen in public for nearly two decades, is alive and in the custody of his former comrades.

title: LSI LOGIC PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 5 MILLION SHARES
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, a computer chip maker, said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to five million shares, or 3.4 percent of its common stock. LSI Logic, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it decided to buy back the shares after a recent drop in the stock price. Shares of LSI rose 6.25 cents, to $32. The stock was as high as $46.875 on May 28. The company had 144.9 million shares as of June 30.

description: In percent

title: After a Major Setback, He's a Minor Leaguer
description: Only 18 days after his first start, Hideki Irabu, the highest paid and most hyped rookie in Yankee history, was demoted yesterday, turning him into a $12.8 million minor league pitcher for two tune-up appearances.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a jury award of $120 million after a finding that the Roman Catholic Diocese of Dallas had tried to cover up evidence that a priest was sexually abusing boys misidentified a member of the diocese's marriage tribunal who denied at the trial that the priest's ex-wife had told him that her former husband was attracted to boys. He was the Rev. Leon Duesman, not the Rev. Gerald Hughes.

title: Once Again, Roberts Joins Team Parcells
description: Welcome back to Bill Parcells's world, William Roberts.

title: Lazard Is Reported to Be Hired As National Westminster Adviser
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. has hired Lazard Brothers & Company as its adviser on a possible merger or unit sale after two failed merger attempts this year, people familiar with the situation said today.

title: News Corp.'s Heritage Bid Faces Problem
description: The News Corporation's plan to buy the Heritage Media Corporation for $1.35 billion has run into possible antitrust problems with Federal regulators.

title: Mars Meteorite Fuels Debate on Life on Earth
description: THE Martian meteorite bearing sausage-shaped specks suggestive of ancient microbial life on Mars is helping to drive a debate on Earth: whether similar forms of life exist here.

title: A Devious Plan to Eliminate Lyme Disease
description: For unsuspecting deer it will look like a free lunch. But when they stick their heads into the specially designed feeding station and nibble the tasty, ground-up corn, they will brush up against paint rollers coated with pesticide.

title: Another Loophole Bonanza
description: They call it a tax cut. Don't believe it. What's really happening is the construction of 10,000 new loopholes in a tax law already packed with special breaks for favored groups.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Set Records, With the Dow Up 53

title: Clarkson S. Fisher, 76, Is Dead; Was Federal Judge in New Jersey
description: Clarkson S. Fisher, who rose from Monmouth County judge to serve as the chief judge of the United States District Courts in New Jersey from 1979 to 1987, died on Sunday at the Medical Center of Princeton. He was 76 and a lifelong resident of Long Branch, N.J.

title: Rating the New Sodas
description: A TASTING of 17 microbrewed sodas and 6 of their mass-market counterparts made it clear that the fizz over fancy soda pop owes a lot to packaging. Who would prefer a bulbous plastic half-gallon container to a designer glass bottle with a arty label?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARUSO, JOSEPH
description: CARUSO-Joseph. The members of the Greenwich Green Cooperative deeply regret the loss of their President, long time friend and neighbor. We will miss his music, his talent, and his sense of humor. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Judy, and the entire Caruso family.

title: Crowding at Columbia
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Prices Rally Again After Report on Wage Costs
description: Treasury prices extended their rally yesterday, after reports showed a muted increase in labor costs.

title: KLM May Sell 19% Stake Back to Northwest Airlines
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines are close to ending their two-year-old legal battle by agreeing to have the Dutch carrier sell its 19 percent stake in Northwest back to the United States company, people familiar with the negotiations said last night.

title: Powell Declines to Seek Job as CUNY Chancellor
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell declined invitations yesterday from Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to become a candidate for the job of Chancellor of the City University of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, AMELIA H.
description: COHEN-Amelia H., on July 28 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Willi. Devoted sister of David M. Hausdorff. Loving aunt of many nieces and nephews. Contributions in her memory may be made to Amit Women.

title: McMichael Can't Pull Off Mets' Last Trick
description: Greg McMichael is like an umpire or a referee: the only time the middle reliever gets noticed is when he does something wrong. Unfortunately for the Mets, McMichael became a headline act tonight, as in Giants Win.

title: Marketing New Year's Eve
description: The new owner of One Times Square intends to turn the New Year's Eve ball into a traveling advertisement for the square itself, the owner's agents said yesterday.

title: Irabu's Next Move Should Be Down to Earth
description: The rain was pouring like cold darts and the whipping wind was vicious when the Yankees arrived from Milwaukee at Newark International Airport in the early-morning hours eight days ago. Because of the inclement conditions, the players were given an option to stay dry by simply getting on a bus back to Yankee Stadium and gathering their luggage later that day.

title: Little Effect Seen on Giuliani's Workfare
description: New York City's workfare program, the largest in the nation, is being buffeted by several aspects of the new budget agreements in Washington and Albany, but its essential nature seems unlikely to change for several years.

title: Ford to Rejuvenate Dying Mercury Cougar
description: The Ford Motor Company announced plans today to rejuvenate its tired Mercury division by reviving Mercury's oldest nameplate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the last line of the Chess column was omitted from Science Times yesterday. The column should have ended, ''Shaked got his sacrificed material back while retaining his mating attack plus three extra pawns. Bunzmann gave up.''

title: Eating Well
description: AMERICAN consumers, bombarded with advertising, medical studies and word-of-mouth wisdom, are buying vitamin and mineral supplements at an unprecedented rate. But they often do not have proper guidance on what to take or how much.

title: Illinois Governor Testifies In Federal Bribery Trial
description: In an unusual courtroom appearance today, Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois testified that he knew nothing about the awarding of $7 million in contracts to a computer-consulting firm whose officials were among his biggest campaign contributors.

title: $159 Million for Tower
description: The 37-story Newport Tower office building in Jersey City has been sold to a Toronto real estate company.

title: MICROSOFT WILL NOT FACE NEW ANTITRUST INQUIRY BY F.T.C.
description: The Microsoft Corporation will not face a Federal Trade Commission antitrust inquiry, as the agency yesterday rebuffed a request from a group of senators who said the Justice Department had gone soft in its long investigation of the computer giant. The agency's chairman, Robert Pitofsky, said an antitrust investigation by the F.T.C. ''could involve a substantial duplication of effort as well as raise serious concerns about fairness to the targets and potential witnesses.'' The decision, though expected by antitrust lawyers, was a setback for the Netscape Communications Corporation, which had challenged the Justice Department either to reinvigorate its investigation of Microsoft or to turn matters over to the F.T.C. Separately, Microsoft bought a stake in Navitel Communications Inc., a closely held maker of Internet telephone software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, PAUL L.
description: MILLER-Paul L. Seventy-seven, died peacefully after a full and productive life on Saturday, July 26th. He is survived by his wife of forty-seven years Adele, and his three daughters Hilary, Beverly and Leslie, one granddaughter and four grandsons. His son, Paul L. Miller, Jr. died in 1993. There will be a private burial and service in Northeast Harbor, ME. Those wishing to may send contributions in his memory to The Peregrine Fund, World Center for Birds of Prey, 5666 West Flying Hawk Lane, Boise, ID 83709.

title: Experts Testify Shabazz Boy Is Psychotic
description: Malcolm Shabazz, the 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X, was characterized today in Family Court as a profoundly disturbed youngster with a history of setting fires and psychotic episodes dating to early childhood, but no conscious intention of harming his grandmother when he set the fire that killed her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANGEL, EVELYN
description: MANGEL-Evelyn. On July 28, 1997, beloved mother of Carole Feldman and Rob, devoted grandmother of Jarrett Aaronson. Services Wednesday 10 A.M. at The Boulevard - Riverside Chapels Brooklyn, 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park).

description: Two Chicago experts, reviving a partnership, won the Life Master Pairs at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Sunday.

description: LATORA-Richard P. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. On July 28, 1997. Beloved brother of Michael and the late Theresa and June. Fond uncle of Richard. Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Friday 10 A.M.

description: The state of Massachusetts got a little less interesting today as William F. Weld, the unpredictable, wild boar-hunting, Grateful Dead-quoting Republican governor, stepped down, handing his job over to Lieut. Gov. Paul Cellucci, a loyal career politician.

description: THE CHIN KISS KING

title: From Victim to Suspect for a Mexican Peddler
description: For more than a week, prosecutors say, Ivan Gomez-Sanchez lived in the safety of the Westway Motor Inn in Queens along with 56 other deaf Mexican peddlers. The suspected ringleaders were arrested early in the investigation, and the rest appeared to be the victims of ruthless bosses who beat them when they did not sell enough cheap trinkets in the streets and subways.

title: 2002 Olympic Organizer Steps Down
description: Thomas K. Welch, who has been charged with domestic violence against his wife, resigned yesterday as the president of the committee organizing the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.

title: HSN, WITH 50.1%, HAS CONTROLLING STAKE IN TICKETMASTER
description: HSN Inc., parent company of the Home Shopping Network, has increased its share to 50.1 percent and gained a controlling stake in Ticketmaster Group Inc., the computerized ticket company. Terms were not disclosed. In July, when HSN acquired a 47.5 percent interest for $209 million in stock, Barry Diller, the chairman of HSN, said he intended to buy enough stock in the open market to gain control of Ticketmaster. HSN, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said it had no definite plans for the company but was considering a merger. Ticketmaster, based in Los Angeles, had revenues of $162.5 million in the first nine months of 1996. Its shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $17.50.

title: Group Homes Win Approval
description: Legislation awarding $22 million to create group homes for 500 developmentally disabled people was signed into law yesterday. In 1994, New Jersey voters approved a bond issue that included $80 million to provide housing for the developmentally disabled, but since then, only 182 people have been moved into group homes, said Velvet G. Miller, an assistant commissioner with the State Department of Human Services. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, ANDREW R.
description: BAER-Andrew R., of Armonk, New York, on July 28. Devoted son of Dr. Rudolf L. Baer; loving father of David and Jessica; cherished brother of John R. Baer; uncle of Alexandra and Abigail; and nephew of Eva Baer. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Friday, August 1, at 9:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: Rudolf L. Baer Foundation, C/O Dept. of Dermatology, New York University Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016-6402.

title: Flash Flood at Colorado Trailer Parks Kills 5 and Injures 40
description: A freak flash flood roared through two trailer parks here early today, derailed a freight train and tossed houses like beer cans, injuring 40 residents and killing at least five people.

title: No Headline
description: ''I can call a restaurant and make a reservation as Ed McBain, and when I get there the chef will be coming out of the kitchen with books for me to sign. If I call as Evan Hunter, I get a table near the phone booths.''

title: Victims Are Identified In Fatal Steakhouse Blast
description: As bulldozers pushed aside rubble, the authorities continued yesterday to seek the cause of an explosion that demolished a popular restaurant and bar before it was to open Monday, killing two employees and seriously injuring a third. The victims were identified as the manager, Robert A. Sterman, 41, of Putnam Lake, and Veronika Ferrusi, 25, of Carmel. She recently started working as a waitress.

title: Ideals Running Scared in High School
description: As Trevor Garfield (Samuel L. Jackson) bicycles energetically to his teaching job at a tough Brooklyn high school, it's easy to imagine where he's going: to students who swagger at first, then melt at the sound of Shakespeare. To administrators who resist change, then admit the errors of their ways. To parents who are eternally grateful for the way a dedicated teacher can turn lives around.

title: MCCAWS BUY 15 MILLION NEXTEL SHARES FOR $232.5 MILLION
description: Nextel Communications Inc. said yesterday that the McCaw family had bought 15 million shares for $232.5 million as part of a long-term investment plan. The family, relatives of Craig McCaw, the founder of McCaw Cellular Communications, exercised options to buy the shares for $15.50 each. Nextel, based in McLean, Va., is looking for cash to build a nationwide digital wireless phone network to provide voice, data and paging services over small phones. The McCaws have options to buy 25 million more shares for $16.70 each in July 1998, 15 million shares for $18.50 each in July 1999 and 5 million shares for $21.50 each in July 2001. Craig McCaw sold McCaw Cellular to the AT&T Corporation for $11.5 billion in 1994. Nextel's shares rose $1.9375, to $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, RABBI LAWRENCE
description: CHARNEY-Rabbi Lawrence. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1942, he served congregations in New York, Massachusetts and Chicago. He assumed the pulpit of Northwest Suburban Congregation (Chicago) in 1960 and became rabbi emeritus in 1985. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lillian, children Brenda Rosen, Dr. Davida, David and our colleague, Rabbi Michael Charney and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Kenneth Forbes, 76, Actor Turned Executive
description: Kenneth P. Forbes, a stage and film actor who later became a newspaper executive in Suffolk County, died on Sunday in Muncy, Pa. He was 76 and lived in Hughesville, Pa.

title: The Phoenix of Belgrade: Milosevic Rises From Yugoslavia's Ashes
description: The whistling, jeering protesters who jammed the streets of this city for three months have evaporated, their bristling energy transformed into sullen apathy. The trio of leaders who stood before them no longer talk to each other.

description: TENNIS

title: Dow Up 53.42, to 8,174.53, a High Again
description: Stocks reached new highs yesterday, buoyed by economic reports that pointed toward low inflation and moderate growth.
