description: On weekends in this warm, wet summer, the byways of the Eifel hills fill with the trophies of a leisured society rich enough for big-time toys: exotic cars heading for a meeting of the Ferrari club, herds of Harleys rumbling by the streams.

title: Rangers to Ignore Modano, Agent Says
description: The business representative for Mike Modano, the accomplished Dallas center who is a restricted free agent, said he talked yesterday with Neil Smith, the president and general manager of the Rangers. Part of the discussion, according to Howard Gourwitz, concerned the possibility of Modano coming to New York to replace Mark Messier, who left Monday for Vancouver.

title: Kessler and Koop Urge Congress to Do Away With the Tobacco Settlement
description: Two of the nation's most respected public health experts urged Congress today to forgo the $368.5 billion legal settlement with the tobacco industry and instead draft legislation that would focus solely on cutting smoking rates, without giving cigarette manufacturers any concessions.

title: Family Firms May Get Help
description: In expanding exemptions from estate taxes, one of the highest Federal levies, the budget agreement would provide more shelter for upper-income taxpayers, family farms and family-held businesses.

title: Pop Life
description: Oldies by Jane's Addiction

title: Mayor's Co-op Burglarized
description: As Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani has touted the city's double-digit drops in crime as his proudest accomplishment, dramatic evidence that the city is a far safer place. As a landlord, he discovered yesterday that there is still crime on the home front: burglars broke into an Upper East Side apartment that he owns.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Corruption Panel Urges Arafat to Dismiss His Cabinet
description: A panel of Palestinian legislators who investigated corruption in the Palestinian government recommended today that legal action be taken against several of its most powerful ministers and that Yasir Arafat dismiss his entire Cabinet.

title: A Dying Village Is Fertile Soil for Bookworms
description: In its first life, this mountain village in southern France lived off vineyards and olive groves and, blessed with fast torrents, it built water mills to drive the wheels of textile and paper plants. That era ended half a century ago when far-off countries started making these products far more cheaply.

title: Center at Library to Foster Scholarship in Humanities
description: The New York Public Library has appointed the historian Peter J. Gay as founding director of the $15 million humanities center it is establishing to foster innovative thinking about society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISSNER, LOUISE A., (NEE AUF DER HEIDE)
description: LISSNER-Louise A., (nee Auf der Heide), lifelong of West New York, New Jersey, on Monday, July 28, 1997, devoted mother of Carolyn L. Heveran, loving grandmother of Elizabeth McSwain, Henry George Ottley, and James Henry Ottley, cherished great-grandmother of 4. Daughter of the late Henry George Auf der Heide, and niece of the late New Jersey Congressman, Oscar L. Auf der Heide. Louise was a beloved and active member of the West New York community for 97 years. She ran for election as councilperson of West New York, in 1962. In 1964, Louise served as President of the West New York Library Board. A religious prayer service will be held at McCorry Brothers Funeral Home, 780 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, on Wednesday, July 30, at 8:00 P.M. Funeral is private. Visiting hours on Wed. from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Memorial donations to: UNITY, 1901 NW Blue Parkway, Unity Village, MO. 64065-0001, would be appreciated.

title: A 'Socko' Albright Steals the Show
description: SUBANG JAYA, Malaysia  The Burmese foreign minister, Ohn Gyaw, best known to the outside world as the impassive face of the Burmese military regime, went on stage and performed a traditional Burmese dance with his wife and daughter, amid great hilarity from the audience as he giggled at his own clumsiness.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITENKO, BARBARA
description: WITENKO - Barbara. Girlfriend, happy birthday. I miss you like crazy. Love, Diana

title: Secret Life of Watermelons: Fresh, Sweet and Serious
description: WATERMELON is a very democratic fruit: large enough to feed a crowd, sweet enough to please children and low enough in calories to appeal to weight-conscious adults.

title: Dr. Lee Edward Farr, 90, an Early Proponent of Nuclear Medicine
description: Dr. Lee Edward Farr, an early proponent of the medical uses of nuclear energy and the first medical director of Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, died on July 16 in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 90.

title: Biblical Starvation
description: To the Editor:

title: Gooden Gets The Victory But Is Far From Sharp
description: The more closely the Yankees analyzed Dwight Gooden's performance last night against the Athletics, the more concerned they should have become. Gooden was not sharp after inheriting a five-run lead in the second inning, and his poor pitching left Joe Torre wondering how reliable he will be as the pennant chase begins.

title: Pepsico Offers New Soft Drink
description: The Pepsi-Cola Company has begun a national campaign to introduce Josta, a caffeinated soft drink with guarana, a berry from the Brazilian rain forest. Spending on the campaign to introduce Josta -- part of efforts by soft-drink marketers to expand beyond colas -- is not being disclosed.

title: A Generous but Expensive Break
description: Of all the items in the budget agreement, the proposal to allow families to cut their Federal income taxes for each child under 17 years old is by far the most expensive to the Treasury and perhaps the most generous to taxpayers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMOCO CORP., Chicago, the international petroleum and chemical company, agreed to sell its Polish retail network, which includes 12 service stations and convenience stores and 33 land sites for development, to Texaco Inc. of White Plains. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKINSON, GEOFFREY
description: ATKINSON-Geoffrey. A retired telecommunications engineer died on July 28, at Indian River Estates, Vero Beach, FL where he lived. He was 82. A native of Bradford, Yorkshire in England. Atkinson earned an electrical engineering degree at Leeds University in 1937 and joined Standard Telephone and Cables, Ltd., a British subsidiary of ITT. He served in the British Army Royal Signal Corps in WW II. Atkinson rejoined ITT in 1946, came to the United States with his family in 1960, and became a U.S. citizen in 1965. He ended his career with ITT's headquarters in NY, and ITT's Telecommunications Technology Center in Stamford, CT in 1977. Mr. Atkinson is survived by his second wife of 23 years, Betz Cech Atkinson. His first wife, Margaret Crowther Atkinson, whom he married in 1939 died in 1974. He is also survived by his daughter Jennifer Mary Rodriguez, his son Robert Crowther Atkinson, his step-daughter Diane Proctor, his step-sons, Richard and Michael Cech and eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family requests that you make a donation to a charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: McDonald's selects DDB Needham Worldwide as its domestic agency over Leo Burnett.
description: AFTER an intense creative shootout between its two national advertising agencies, the McDonald's Corporation selected the Chicago office of DDB Needham Worldwide yesterday as its lead domestic agency, relegating the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, which has held that role since 1981, to secondary status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALT, SASHA BIRNKRANT
description: ALT-Sasha Birnkrant. Beloved sister of Arthur, Jerry, and Milton, loving aunt. She celebrated life to the end. Services Friday 11:30 A.M. at I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, L.I. For information call: 516-499-6060.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIPZIG, HELEN
description: LEIPZIG-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Robert, cherished aunt and great-aunt. Graveside services today, 2 PM, at the Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Molson Seeking Partners' Shares in Brewery
description: The Molson Companies said today that it wanted to acquire the 60 percent of Molson Breweries it does not own from its partners, Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. and the Miller Brewing Company, which could cost it as much as $1.1 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, MURIEL
description: MORGAN-Muriel. A woman of great warmth, dignity and a keen intelligence, who possessed a passion for politics, golf, bridge, literature, the opera, good manners and great grandchildren. Born in 1910, she lived her very full life in Manhattan, Palm Beach and Westhampton, where she died peacefully at her home on Monday, July 28th. Married to Alfred Y. Morgan for 54 years, who predeceased her in 1988, she imbued her loving daughters, Mimsi (Mrs. Laurence Bodkin), and Martha (Mrs. J. Kevin Kenny), and her devoted son, Alfred III, with her unique sense of values, of justice and compassion, and a remarkable sense of humour. One of five children of Mr. and Mrs. William Stafford of Brooklyn, Huntington, and Palm Beach, only her loving sister Greta Brady survives her. Among her greatest joys are counted her twelve grandchildren, five great grandchildren, and devoted nieces and nephews, all of whom were in her company close to the time of her passing. A funeral mass will be offered at the Immaculate Conception Church, her country church for over 50 years, on Main St. in Quiogue, LI, at 9:30 am, July 31. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Religious of the Sacred Heart, 406 E. 80th St., New York, New York 10021.

title: GE CAPITAL PLANS TO BUY BRITISH TRAILER RENTAL COMPANY
description: In another move yesterday, GE Capital agreed to buy Central Transport Rental Group P.L.C., a British trailer rental company formerly known as Tiphook P.L.C., for $:118 million ($192 million) in cash and the assumption of $:223 million of debt. GE Capital said it would combine the company, which operates a fleet of 22,500 trailers at 132 depots in nine European countries, with its own TIP Europe trailer rental and leasing company.

title: No Kick From Champagne? Try These Chocolates
description: LIKE gas pumps with octane ratings, some candy bars are emblazoned with numbers telling how much of a chocolate jolt they supply.

title: A Man Unafraid to Change, And Then to Sing About It
description: Too often, when a major opera company presents a world premiere, there is a dismaying sense of obligation on the part of the presenters, and a resultant wariness on the part of audiences. This was not the case at the Santa Fe Opera, where expectant operagoers nearly filled the 1,889-seat open-air theater for Saturday night's world premiere of ''Ashoka's Dream,'' an opera by the composer Peter Lieberson and the librettist Douglas Penick.

title: Deep in Their Bones
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum Director Resigns
description: Only 11 days after the opening of the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., an event that refocused national attention on the artist and her adopted region, the museum's director has resigned.

title: Concert-Hall Sound? Not in My House
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Admits Polluting
description: The hunter thought that something was wrong when he saw steam rising from the brook and the frogs swimming in December. His tip led prosecutors to the discovery that a company upstream, the Fluid Packaging Company in Lakewood, was discharging toxic material into the frogs' habitat. Yesterday, Fluid Packaging admitted to dumping unspecified toxic chemicals into the groundwater supply and to storing explosive crystalized ether improperly in its cosmetics and personal-hygiene packaging plant, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, DORA
description: CLARKE-Dora, died on July 29 at her home in East Northport. Death came after a long illness. Born in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, her love for the violin developed early and she worked to buy her first instrument by the time she was eight. From 1982 to 1992, Ms. Clarke was Director of Music for the Northport/East Northport School District. Ms. Clarke is survived by two brothers and their wives, E. Edward and Elaine Clarke of West Hartford, CT and Richard and Barbara Clarke of Columbia, SC and six nieces and nephews. Instead of flowers, friends are asked to send contributions to a Dora Clarke Northport Music Scholarship Fund, C/O Richard Manning, 25 Hillside Place, Northport, NY 11768. Visiting hours Wed. 2-5, and 7-9 PM at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, L.I. Funeral service Thursday at First Presbyterian Church, Main Street, Northport. For time of service, please contact the funeral home.

title: Agent Questioned in Bomb Case
description: A lawyer for Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, accused of being the mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, questioned an F.B.I. chemist yesterday about the Government's evidence, but later conceded that he had failed to raise significant doubts about its reliability.

title: OWENS CORNING TO BUY AMERIMARK BUILDING PRODUCTS
description: Owens Corning has agreed to acquire Amerimark Building Products Inc. for $310 million. Owens Corning, based in Toledo, Ohio, makes Fiberglas and building materials. It had 1996 sales of $3.8 billion. Amerimark, based in Raleigh, N.C., is 90 percent owned by GE Capital, the finance arm of the General Electric Company. It makes aluminum and vinyl building materials for residential construction. Its 1997 sales are expected to reach $450 million. Owens Corning's acquisitions in the last three years accounted for $450 million of its 1996 sales. Its stock slipped 37.50 cents, to $41.125.

title: Guilty Plea in Homes Swindle
description: A Hoboken car salesman pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court in Camden to conspiring with bank officers and businessmen from 1988 to 1993 to steal $2.3 million from several banks by inflating the value of homes in Union County. The scheme bears similarities to a case against 14 New Jersey real estate companies that was outlined in a Federal lawsuit filed on July 17, but prosecutors said the two matters were not related.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, WALLACE A.
description: RUSSELL-Wallace A. A memorial service will be held at a later date for Wallace A. Russell, 75, of Tampa, Florida, who died on July 26, 1997, while traveling in Ashland, Oregon. Mr. Russell was a Professor of Psychology at the University of Minnesota, Iowa State University, and The University of South Florida. Information contact Simonsen Funeral Home, Ashland, Oregon.

title: Court Upholds 2 Professors' Right to Strike a Pose
description: Does a university president have the right to censor a display of photographic portraits of faculty members posing with deadly weapons?

title: Hotels in New York and Los Angeles offer regional alternatives in their business suites.
description: REOPENING Monday after extensive renovation, the Sheraton Manhattan Hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street, is offering a special rate of $189 a night through Sept. 7.

title: A Budget With Many Faces
description: Compared with the last major Federal tax cut in 1981 the one envisioned for the coming fiscal year is much smaller, but intentionally so. Page A16.

title: Higher Overseas Travel Fees, Little Change in U.S.
description: Under the new budget agreement, Americans traveling outside the United States would pay four times more in airline ticket taxes than they do now; frequent fliers may have to redeem more miles for free tickets, and domestic travelers would not only continue paying the ticket tax that had been scheduled to expire at the end of the year, but would also pay a fee for each flight segment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. Jan 17, 1911July 26, 1994. FELIX...his name meant ''happy,'' and that was what he always made me and all those whose lives he touched so lovingly. Janice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, KATHERINE
description: MAYER-Katherine. Suddenly on July 29, age 85 in Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Great Neck. Full partner in Evins Exterminating Co. Loving mother of Alice Stein and her husband Robert and Jackie Ferguson and her husband David. Grandmother of John and Tomoko, Jim, Jeffrey and David. Graveside services will be held at Beth El Cemetery Friday, August 1. Meet in main office at 10:45 A.M. For info: Gutterman-Musicant 800522-0588. Please send donations to National MS Soc, 200 Parkway Drive S., Hauppauge, N.Y. 11789.

title: Swiss Bank List Recalls the Turmoil of War
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bread Salad Tossed With the Unusual
description: Aficionados of the ''authentic'' Italian bread salad, panzanella, will have quibbles with this quick and easy version. The bread is not day-old, there is much less oil, and adding cucumbers is not traditional. But the taste is there, as long as you use the best ingredients.

title: Moralizing Over Workfare Won't Create Any Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Internet With Your Sushi?
description: Ken Lowe may have discovered the perfect marriage for discriminating palates with a taste for technological gadgetry: the Sushicam.

title: No to Holocaust Chair
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Sending Holbrooke to Balkans to Push Leaders on Peace
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, who brokered the Dayton agreements to end the war in Bosnia, will lead a special mission to the region next week to press the leaders of Serbia and Croatia to carry out the peace agreement, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Yahoo Plans $21 Million Charge To Exit Joint Venture With Visa
description: Yahoo Inc., the leading Internet search company, said today that it would take a pretax charge of $21.2 million against its second-quarter earnings, reflecting its decision to buy its way out of a joint venture with Visa International.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was one of those quintessential New York evenings. The New York Philharmonic, led by Keith Lockhart, conductor of the Boston Pops, performed on Monday. Through the threat of a thunderstorm that gave way to a pink sunset, thousands sat on the grass listening to works like ''An American in Paris'' and ''Appalachian Spring.'' Fireworks streaked across the sky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RETTINGER, ABE
description: RETTINGER-Abe. 93. Leaves his wife, Tema, after 70 years together; his daughter, Frances Guze; his son, Dr. Seymour Rettinger; sonin-law, Dr. Solomon Guze and daughter-in-law, Charlotte Rettinger; his sisters, Lilian Bernheim and Sarah Brill; his grandchildren, Dr. Peter Wenig, Robert Wenig, Jodi Koch, David Rettinger, James Rettinger; great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Funeral at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck on Wednesday, July 30th at 12:00 noon.

title: Budget Deal to Cost T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F. Its Tax Exemption
description: T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., the $200 billion retirement system that serves many of the nation's college and university professors and administrators, has lost its battle to retain its tax-exempt status. Under the tax legislation approved by Congress and the White House, earnings from the group's pension operations will be subject to tax for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLARSFELD, LEAH (NEE DOSTIS)
description: KLARSFELD-Leah (Nee Dostis) on July 29, 1997 at age eighty-nine. A woman of great spirit, boundless energy and a deep love of life and people. Married for 59 years to the late Nathan Klarsfeld. Born May 29, 1908 in New York City to Greek Sephardic parents Isaak and Esther Dostis of Ioannina, Greece. Adoring mother of Judge S. Herman Klarsfeld, Dr. Elayne Klarsfeld Mustalish and Kenneth Klarsfeld. Dear mother-in-law of Wendy, Dr. Anthony Mustalish and Adele. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Jonathan, Annette, Rachel, David, Peter, Andrew, and Jeffrey, his wife Elka and great grandchild, Lauren. Also survived by her sister, Mary Kestenbaum, wife of the late Jack and her brother, Milton Dostis and his wife, Helen. She will be greatly missed by all, including her many nieces and nephews. For many years, a Democratic Captain and committee member, a talented artist and active in ORT and Hadassah. Service on Thursday, July 31 at 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARETSKY, PROFESSOR BARRY LEWIS
description: ZARETSKY-Professor Barry Lewis. The Brooklyn Law School Community mourns the loss of a beloved colleague, distinguished scholar, esteemed teacher and great friend. His legacy as an educator exceeds the sum of the books and articles he wrote, the classes he taught and the law reforms he urged. Over the past two decades he has touched the lives of thousands of students, lawyers and friends. Although his presence will be missed, it will be long felt. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Joan Glatman, his children, Arielle, Joseph and Tamar, his parents, Harold and Edythe Zaretsky; his sister and brother-in-law, Sandy and Robert Kanin and his entire family. Paul Windels, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

title: Wine Talk
description: NEVER play cards with a guy named Doc, never eat in a place called Mom's, and never buy a petite sirah from someone who tells you it's just a small syrah.

title: In Cambodia, Timber Keeps Civil War Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Insurer Sale
description: The Confederation Life Insurance Company, a failed Canadian insurer, has put its investment real estate portfolio up for sale, according to its liquidator, Canada's Superintendent of Financial Institutions. KPMG Inc., the agent for the deal, said the portfolio consisted of 12 Canadian properties: 7 office properties and 5 retail properties. Five of the properties are co-owned with other investors. KPMG said the liquidator hoped to sell the whole portfolio in one deal but would consider offers for smaller groups of properties.

title: Dunham Loses in Arbitration
description: The Devils defeated goalie Mike Dunham and the National Hockey League Players Association in an arbitration decision that was announced yesterday. Had Dunham and the union won, the goalie would have become an unrestricted free agent. Because the Devils won, Dunham is a restricted free agent. Even if another team offers Dunham a contract, the Devils can keep him by matching it.

title: Difficult Time Ends: Duncan Dealt to Jays
description: Mariano Duncan drifted from locker to locker in the Yankee clubhouse yesterday, spreading the news everyone had expected for some time. The second baseman had been traded to Toronto for a minor leaguer and cash. He was contented, and his teammates were relieved.

title: Woman in Cosby Case Urged to Take Blood Test
description: Lawyers for Bill Cosby and Autumn Jackson, the woman who claimed to be his out-of-wedlock daughter and who was convicted last week of extortion, said yesterday that they had discussed having her blood taken for a paternity test.

title: City Commissioner in Miami Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: A City Commissioner here has been indicted on Federal charges of mortgage fraud and money laundering barely nine months after he was elected to replace a commissioner who resigned in disgrace and is now in prison for a bribery conviction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, SHIRLEY
description: PECK-Shirley. The Board of Directors and staff of Berkshire Hills-Emanuel Camps extend their sincere condolences to Andrew J. Peck, past-president of The Board. Our deepest sympathies to Andy, Karen and David.

title: INSIDE
description: Two Forceful Voices Against the Tobacco Pact

title: New Options Include Shift Into Preventive Benefits, and Slightly Higher Costs
description: The budget agreement would make vast changes in Medicare, offering new health insurance options to the elderly, broadening coverage of preventive services and creating strong new financial incentives for managed care companies to serve people in rural areas.

title: City's Budget Requests Fall on Receptive Ears
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council won a substantial portion of their requests from Albany in the state budget agreement reached last night, most prominently an election-year gift to the Mayor that will eliminate the sales tax on small clothing purchases beginning in 1999.

title: Brennan's Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: Gift Baskets Over the River

title: U.S. Reports Slight Increase In Wage Costs
description: Employee compensation costs rose slightly this spring because of an increase in benefits, but the gain posed no inflationary threat, Government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKETZ, REBECCA LEE
description: LOCKETZ-Rebecca Lee, age 41. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the ACLU mourn the sudden death of a friend and colleague, Rebecca L. Locketz. She was a trailblazer in the field of workplace rights and genetic testing, and a dedicated community leader who was often described as ''a feminist, lesbian activist committed to social change.'' Her warmth, love of life and generosity -not to mention an unswerving commitment to civil liberties -will be sorely missed by her many friends. The ACLU sends our deepest condolences to her partner, Pearl Balla, and her family. Funeral service will be held at 7:30 P.M., today at the Flemington Jewish Community Center, Flemington, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELSON, ELIZABETH MUNCH
description: MICHELSON-Elizabeth Munch, 64, of Southbury, CT died July 28, 1997. She was born in Hartford, CT and was a well known decorative arts author & curator. She leaves her children, Leslie Michelson of Cambridge, MA; John and Colleen Michelson of Enfield, CT and Keith Michelson of North Tunbridge, VT; 2 grandchildren, Robert and Katie Michelson; a sister, Judith Pinney of Avon, CT., and many devoted friends who remained caring, loving and supportive throughout her long illness. Funeral services will be held in the chapel, Temple Beth Israel, 701 Farmington Avenue, West Hartford, CT., Thursday, July 31 at 1:00 P.M. Donations may be made to the Gilda Radner FOCR, Rosewell Park Cancer Institute, Buffalo, New York 14263.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOLA, JOHN BOBBY.
description: SCOLA-John Bobby. We mourn the passing of John Bobby Scola, a devoted member and officer of the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers (BAC) for 76 years and former business agent for BAC Local 9 New York. Scola, 94, was active in International Union affairs since he attended his first convention in 1936. BAC is the oldest international union in North America, founded in 1865. It has 100,000 members. Until his passing, Scola served since 1980 as the Mid-Atlantic Regional Training Director for the International Masonry Institute (IMI), a joint labor-management trust of the BAC and its contractors. He was based at the Woodside Training Center in Queens. From 1940 until 1979, he served as business agent of former Local 9 New York (now part of Local 1), instructors who create innovative teaching aids for apprentices. We will miss his wise counsel, his friendship, his invaluable knowledge of our industry and his robust sense of humor. Funeral services are Friday, August 1 at Immaculate Conception Church, Jamaica, NY. Viewing is July 31 at the Bernard Dowd Funeral Home, Jamaica 718-739-8117 John T. Joyce, President John J. Flynn, Secretary-Treasurer International Union of Bricklayers & Allied Craftworkers

title: Disk Maker's Shares Climb On Microsoft Connection
description: Shares in the disk maker Nimbus CD International Inc. rose 14 percent yesterday on heavy volume after the company announced that it had signed a contract to become an authorized manufacturer of digital disks for the Microsoft Corporation.

title: BLUE SHIELD OF CALIFORNIA TO BUY TWO COMPANIES
description: Blue Shield of California, seeking to add about 200,000 members to its managed-care plans, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Care America Health Plans and the CareAmerica Life Insurance Company for $175 million. The CareAmerica companies, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., are for-profit units of Unihealth, a not-for-profit holding company. With the added members, Blue Shield of California, a not-for-profit insurer based in San Francisco, will have a total of about 1.8 million in its plans and about $2 billion in revenue.

title: On Free Book Day, Self-Help Is Out, Helping Yourself Is In
description: For those tempted to despair for the future of civilization, a small beacon of hope could be seen today in this postcard town on Long Island Sound. It was free book day at the Pequot Library's annual book sale, and almost everyone behaved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPIELBERG, JANET JOAN CAPPA
description: SPIELBERG-Janet Joan Cappa. Died July 30, 1987. She is forever in our hearts. David, Alex, Tony, Betty Jean, Natalie, Miranda

title: Albright to Name Special Aide On U.S. Policy Toward Tibet
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told Congressional leaders today that she would appoint a new ''special coordinator'' to oversee American policy toward Tibet.

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Cheer Plan to Balance Budget
description: President Clinton and the Republican leaders of Congress jubilantly -- but separately -- celebrated today their long-sought agreement on a plan to balance the Federal budget after decades of deficit spending and to provide the first Federal tax cut in 16 years.

title: Keeping the Past at Bay, Peter Thinks First String
description: Christian Peter was in a game-like situation for the first time in more than 18 months last Saturday, playing with the Giants' second defensive unit during the team's annual intrasquad scrimmage. The last time Peter was on a football field -- with 21 other players, officials and a crowd watching -- was during the Fiesta Bowl after the 1995 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERS, MICHAEL
description: SILVERS-Michael, on July 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Leslie Fader-Silvers, loving father of Diane, Robert and Leslie (Paul) Baglie, loved grandfather of Devin, Andrew and Alexandra. Services Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, today at 1 PM. Contributions may be made to Crystal Run Village, 601 Stoney Ford Road, Middletown, NY 10941.

title: Taxes Cut, Credit Taken
description: Today's budgetary bonhomie went beyond tributes to the virtues of bipartisanship, though there was plenty of that from politicians who had been sniping at each other only the day before.

title: Summer's Bounty Makes Improvising With Pasta Easy
description: SUMMER cooking is about spontaneity, about leaving recipes at home and going to green markets with an open mind. Fortunately, pasta is an improvisational sort of dish that can accommodate whatever is most fresh, most aromatic or particularly colorful.

title: Subway Signs: Less Than Indicative
description: If you are looking for the M train on a sign at the Canal Street subway station entrances, you will not see it listed with the other trains.

title: The Ratings: Too Much for Parents or Not Enough?
description: Whatever you make of the latest batch of ratings concocted by the television industry (excluding NBC), the child-advocacy legions and stray politicians, they have already been a boon for humorists. Roger Rosenblatt's takeoff in Time magazine was titled ''NTVRSMESHAF.'' Subtitle: ''New TV-ratings system made even safer for helpless American families.'' People haven't had so much fun with letters since their last visit to ''Sesame Street.''

title: Provisions to Aid College Students
description: President Clinton has made education a centerpiece of his second term, and education was the first issue he cited in hailing the budget agreement announced yesterday.

title: Lower Rate and New Definition
description: The budget proposal would cut the capital gains tax rate, but an investor would have to hold new assets longer than before to get the break. And some investors who could have sold on Monday at a low tax rate would face a much higher rate if they decided to sell now.

title: 8-Year-Old Boy Drowns in Pool At a Water Park in New Jersey
description: An 8-year-old Staten Island boy, who had received a scholarship to attend summer camp, drowned on Monday, his first day at the camp, during an outing at a water park in Keansburg, N.J.

title: $24 Billion Would Be Set Aside For Medical Care for Children
description: The budget agreement would set aside $24 billion in the next five years for a new program to finance medical care for children without health insurance.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What did Union and Confederate troops do to occupy themselves between battles in the Civil War? As die-hard baseball aficionados know, they played baseball.

title: Tears for a Union's Founder, Cheers for His Successor
description: There were more than a few moist eyes at the annual conference of the American Federation of Teachers when the widow of the union's longtime president, Albert Shanker, rose to address the 2,000 participants.

title: The Newest Bubbly on the Shelf: Micro-Sodas Seek Their Niche
description: AT the Gourmet Garage in SoHo, the soda cooler is stocked not with the usual cans of Pepsi and Diet Coke, but with a rainbow of unfamiliar labels and flavors, like Blue Bubble Gum Soda from the Jones Soda Company, whose label has a picture of a windup toy television.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Friday about an exhibition at the Grolier Club in Manhattan relating to the 19th-century English bibliophile Sir Thomas Phillipps misstated the given name of the man who collected the material on view. He was Harrison D. Horblit, not Howard.

title: Foley Tries to Hold On As O'Donnell's Backup
description: Bill Parcells could be playing a dangerous game. The Jets do not have an experienced backup quarterback.

title: Hong Kong Court Upholds China's Rule
description: A constitutional challenge to China's rule in Hong Kong was rebuffed today when a three-judge panel ruled unanimously that the territory was powerless to question Beijing's decisions, particularly the scuttling of Hong Kong's elected legislature and its replacement by a handpicked assembly.

title: Dresdner Raising Money For Foreign Investment
description: The Dresdner Bank, Germany's second-largest bank, after Deutsche Bank, said yesterday that it was planning to raise about 2 billion marks ($1.02 billion) to expand investment banking abroad. It also reported that first-half operating profit rose 20 percent, to 1.7 billion marks, in line with expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIGER, BETH
description: DANZIGER-Beth. Beloved wife of Howard, devoted mother of Alan and Amy, Tracy, Mark, dear sister of Carl Meisel and Mona Swanson, loving aunt. Service 11 A.M., Thursday at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Rd, Closter, NJ.

title: Spain Chooses Arbed As Steelmaker Partner
description: Spain chose Arbed of Luxembourg over Usinor Sacilor of France to become the major shareholder and partner of Corporacion Siderurgica S.A., known as CSI. The Spanish agency that handles state asset sales said it favored Arbed's bid of 129.2 billion pesetas ($834 million) for 35 percent of CSI. The bid from Usinor, Europe's No. 2 steelmaker, was worth roughly 109 billion pesetas.

title: The Bull's Last Bite
description: July 30, 2067 In a long-anticipated development, the Treasury Department announced today that the very last scrap of United States currency -- a worn and tattered $50 bill belonging to an unemployed steelworker in Germaine, Idaho -- has been invested in the stock market.

title: Banker in Spano Deal Quits
description: The Fleet Bank executive who approved an $80 million loan to JOHN SPANO that is at the center of fraud charges against the former Islanders owner has resigned from the Boston-based bank. DAVID SPLAINE, who was a member of Fleet's sports-lending group, quit about 10 days ago, said JIM MAHONEY, a Fleet spokesman. He confirmed that Splaine had approved the controversial loan, which has been restructured and will be repaid by JOHN PICKETT, who reclaimed the team from Spano.

title: Order to Pay Student's Tuition
description: Three new magnet high schools are opening in Bergen County next month, but as many as 40 local communities have balked at paying the tuition of students who elect to enroll in these so-called academies. In part, the school districts acknowledge, they are worried that the magnet schools, which will focus on business, engineering and medical science, will siphon off their best students.

title: Switzer's New Game Face Stuns Cowboys
description: Football fans have probably heard all about how relaxed Dallas Coach Barry Switzer is supposed to be, how he is nothing but a puppet for the team's owner, Jerry Jones. A baby sitter who shares a laugh and a drink with his players, instead of disciplining them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALISBERG, NORMAN, MD.
description: ALISBERG-Norman, MD. July 29, in Hartford, Connecticut. He was the former Chief of Medicine at Bristol Hospital. He is survived by his wife Helene, his daughter Nancy of Brooklyn, New York, his son Andrew of Greenwich, CT., and four grandchildren. The funeral will be Wednesday July 30, 1 PM, at Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Avenue, Hartford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXINN, EVA
description: AXINN-Eva. Beloved wife of Calvin. Cherished mother of Dede, Lennard and Barbara. Dear sister of Anneliese Lindner. Devoted grandmother of Jessica, Rachel and Amanda. Services Thursday, 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', Inc., 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: PEPSICO GAINS $830 MILLION IN SALE OF FOOD SYSTEMS UNIT
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had received about $830 million from the sale of its Pepsico Food Systems restaurant-supply unit, which is based in Dallas, to Ameriserve Food Distribution Inc. The purchase price, which was previously undisclosed, was included in Pepsi's quarterly securities filing. The sale of the unit to Ameriserve, a subsidiary of Holberg Industries in Greenwich, Conn., was completed on July 11. Pepsico Food, with $3.4 billion in sales, distributes food to Pepsi's Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC restaurant chains. Its sale resulted in a gain of $307 million, or 17 cents a share. Ameriserve, based in Brookfield, Wis., distributes food to more than 10,000 restaurants, including Wendy's, Burger King, Arby's, Dairy Queen and Subway.

title: Lowe & Partners/SMS Named by Eddie Bauer
description: Eddie Bauer, the retailer owned by Spiegel Inc., said yesterday that it had named the San Francisco office of Lowe & Partners/SMS to handle its national brand advertising account, which had been handled for the last year by Black Rocket in San Francisco, until the company and that agency agreed to part ways last month.

title: Insulting the Crocodile
description: Olympia Snowe never realized that one committee chairman had the power to stop a confirmation hearing. She does now.

title: Negative Responses Come From the Political Left and Right
description: As President Clinton and members of Congress of all political stripes lined up today to praise the agreements to cut taxes and balance the Federal budget, the few who publicly opposed the deal found themselves lonely voices in the political wilderness.

title: Ammonia Linked to a Type of Nicotine
description: An independent scientific study has found that the use of ammonia by tobacco companies can dramatically increase the level of nicotine available to smokers.

title: Ore-Ida Narrows Its Review to 4
description: The Ore-Ida Foods specialty products division of the H. J. Heinz Company has narrowed a review on its account for frozen pasta, snack and wrap-sandwich brands to four finalists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTER, ESTHER J.
description: COTTER-Esther J., of Westland, Michigan. Longtime resident of Tarrytown, N.Y. died in Waterville, Maine, July 27, one day after her 90th birthday. Predeceased by husband Fred J. Cotter. Survived by sons Fred C. Cotter and William R. Cotter, daughters-in-law Gai and Linda, 8 grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren. Funeral services Thursday, July 31, for info. Coffey Funeral Home, Tarrytown.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: TIME and temperature sign spotted by Jack Joyce, a Long Island Rail Road commuter, on Monday evening, July 14, atop a building in Long Island City, Queens:

title: Beating Cited in Death Of Foster Child, 4
description: An autopsy on a 4-year-old foster child showed that she died of dehydration, malnutrition and injuries inflicted by a blunt object, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: International Cachet In Portable Meals
description: Mark Furstenberg, who brought good bread to the nation's capital when he started the Marvelous Market bakery in 1990, has opened a new operation called the Bread Line, which specializes in pita, rolls and bagels with fillings from around the world.

title: A Retailer May Have Strayed Too Far From Its Roots
description: Claudia Teller knows all about the legend of Loehmann's: that if only you look hard enough, you should come up with at least one great Donna Karan sweater or Isaac Mizrahi dress for a fraction of the normal retail price.

title: Lying in the Weeds
description: Psychiatrists and pundits the professional alienists and the professionally alienated -- take most of August for their vacations. Somehow the nation survives.

title: Woman Held in Fatal Stabbing in the Subway
description: A subway rider, returning home from work in Queens, was fatally stabbed Monday evening by a homeless woman who had been arrested a week earlier on charges of weapons possession and menacing but was released on her own recognizance, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBER, EILEEN
description: LIEBER-Eileen. On July 28, 1997. Artist, and also an art teacher for the Valley Stream school system for many years and studied at the Art Student's League. Beloved wife of Lawrence, devoted sister of Barbara Rappaport, loving aunt of Michael and William Rappaport. Services Wednesday, 11 am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: U.N. Reveals New Evidence Of Gas From 2d Iraqi Depot
description: The United Nations announced today that clouds of chemical weapons might have been released from a second large Iraqi ammunition depot in the vicinity of American troops during the Persian Gulf war in 1991, raising the possibility that the number of troops exposed to chemical weapons could be far larger than the Pentagon's latest estimate of as many as 100,000.

title: Tower in Times Square Means Timely Planning
description: Rising from the basement floor of the construction site -- below the level of the carefully braced tube for the subway shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central Terminal that runs through one corner of it -- two cranes, which will rise with the building, are swinging into place the first of the 18,000 massive steel beams that will support the 48-story headquarters for the Conde Nast publishing company.

title: Unlicensed Brokers Face Fraud Charges
description: Investigators from the New York State Attorney General's office arrested two unlicensed brokers yesterday, charging they had a role in a securities boiler room operation that investigators said kept most of the $500,000 collected from unsuspecting investors, many of them elderly.

title: The Politics of Zero Deficits
description: This week's budget deal between the White House and Congress is being portrayed as a historic agreement to balance the Federal budget for the first time in nearly three decades. But in economic terms, this is a small-bore achievement. The booming economy has already reduced the deficit to modest proportions, and this deal will ramp it down another needless notch. The real significance of the agreement lies in what it tells us of the nation's shifting political tides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, HELEN CLAIRE STOPFORD
description: WARD-Helen Claire Stopford, M.D., on July 27, 1997. Wife of the late Dr. Robert L. Ward. Mother of Maryellen, Frank, Robert, Helen, Maureen, John, Kathleen and Matthew. Visiting in the Doyle Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd., Little Neck, New York, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass will be offered in Saint Anastasia RC Church on Friday at 9:30 A.M.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: NEW MAP -- Legislative leaders have begun to redraw four New York City Congressional districts. B3.

title: Tax Benefit Now Unlikely For Airtouch
description: Airtouch Communications Inc.'s $5 billion purchase of U S West Media Group's United States wireless business will have to be restructured because Congressional tax writers would not change an effective date by one day.

title: Japanese Raid Yamaichi In Widening Payoff Scandal
description: The scandal roiling Japan's financial markets widened this morning as prosecutors raided the headquarters of the Yamaichi Securities Company, the nation's fourth-largest brokerage firm, on suspicion that it had made illegal payoffs to a racketeer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, BRO. ANDREW F.S.C.
description: O'CONNOR-Bro. Andrew F.S.C. July 28, 1997. Age 84. Professor of Romance Languages, Manhattan College. The Brothers will receive friends at the Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Road (West of Broadway at 242 Street, Bronx) on Wednesday, July 30, 1997 from 25pm and 7-9pm and on Thursday, July 31, 1997 from 2-5pm and 78pm. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Thursday evening July 31, 1997 at 8pm in the Christian Brothers Center. Interment will take place on Friday, August 1, 1997 at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENOK, ABBY
description: LENOK-Abby. We are sharing the sadness with our friend and former Chief Financial Officer, Eugene, over his loss. America-Israel Cultural Foundation Vera Stern, President Harvey Rothenberg, Treasurer Kathleen Mellon, Exec. Director

title: New Rules on I.R.A.'s Are Likely To Raise Number of Participants
description: New rules for Individual Retirement Accounts would make millions more Americans eligible to use the tax advantages of these plans to save for retirement or education expenses.

title: Transmuting Wine by a Tangy Alchemy
description: ON a 20-acre estate in the heart of German wine country, Georg and Johanna Wiedemann grow riesling, gewurztraminer, pinot noir and other grapes, and make wine. So far so good. But then they turn the wine into vinegar. And some of their Weinessiggut Doktorenhof vinegars, like Burgundy soothed with orange blossom honey, are meant to be sipped as aperitifs: a palate wakeup call. Some of the mellow vinegars, like gewurztraminer wine vinegar, have herbal notes to flavor a soup or sauce. Others, enriched with honey, vanilla or berries, will deglaze a saute pan. Fairway, 2127 Broadway (74th Street) and 2328 12th Avenue (132d Street), has 17-ounce bottles of the wine vinegars for $22 each. The aperitif vinegars, in handblown glass flasks, are $85. The Wiedemanns also make jewel-like wine jellies, $9 for 8 ounces.

title: With Gentle Humor, Brennan Is Buried
description: William J. Brennan Jr., the son of an Irish laborer, thought of himself as a common man. When he was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1956, he described himself as a ''mule at the Kentucky Derby.''

title: Japan Calls Mercury-Poisoned Bay Safe Now
description: Four decades after horrible cases of mercury poisoning made Minamata Bay synonymous with environmental catastrophe, the regional government today declared the fish in the bay to be safe to eat.

title: Swiss Envoy Asks U.S. Judge To Dismiss a Suit Against Banks
description: The Swiss Ambassador to the United States is urging a Federal judge to dismiss a class-action lawsuit in a case to be heard on Thursday that accuses Swiss banks of retaining Holocaust victims' assets.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: SPECIALTY FOODS WANTS TO SELL STELLA, ITS CHEESE MAKER
description: The Specialty Foods Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking to sell Stella Foods, the fifth-largest cheese maker in the nation, as it focuses on baked goods and specialty meats. Stella, with about $800 million in sales, makes Stella, Lorraine and Frigo brand cheeses and has headquarters in Green Bay, Wis. Specialty Foods, a closely held company backed by the Bass family and based in Lincolnshire, Ill., bought Stella and seven other food businesses in 1993 from Beledia N.V. of the Netherlands for $1.1 billion. Specialty Foods agreed last year to sell some businesses for a combined $140 million.

title: Bear Stearns Says Earnings Were Flat in Latest Quarter
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that earnings were almost unchanged in its fiscal fourth quarter, although they were well above analysts' expectations.

title: Crabbing Moratorium Lifted
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman lifted a 60-day moratorium on horseshoe crabbing yesterday in waters other than ocean waters. Harvesting will be be permitted in bay waters only on Tuesdays and Thursdays during the mating season starting next May and June, state officials said, and will have to be done by hand. In addition, the catch will be restricted to 100 crabs for each fisherman each day, said Amy Collings, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Middle Class Dismissed
description: Liberals used to jeer at the working-class social conservatives who voted for Ronald Reagan; Mr. Reagan, they said, was exploiting working-class resentment of abortion and racial quotas, while delivering the economic goods to the rich. How could anyone be such a fool as to trade money for symbolism?

title: COMMITTEE IS TOLD A DONOR RECEIVED FOREIGNERS' CASH
description: Yah Lin Trie, a friend of President Clinton who is suspected of donating foreign money to the Democratic Party, received $1.4 million in wire transfers from abroad from 1994 through 1996, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today in the Senate inquiry on campaign finance practices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCLOUGHLIN, JOHN
description: McLOUGHLIN-John. In loving memory. On this third anniversary and every day you continue to be and always will be in our heart, in our lives. Always missed, always remembered, always loved. Vicky, Mike, and Chris

title: News Is Mixed For Companies
description: For tobacco companies, a 15-cent increase in the Federal excise tax on a pack of cigarettes could prove to be a mixed blessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIPP, HON. SAMUEL S.
description: TRIPP-Hon. Samuel S. Age 94, Counsel to our law firm for the past 24 years since mandatory retirement as Chief Law Assistant and Official Referee to the Queens County Supreme Court. Sam set an example of devotion to the law and unquenchable intellectual curiosity which in his memory we will seek to emulate. Immigrant from Austria in 1909, graduate with honors (in oratory) from Stuyvesant High School, from City College and from NYU Law School, author of the paradigm text on Motion Practice in New York, member of the Law Revision Commission on the CPLR, bar leader for decades, President of the Queens County Bar Association in 1951, and honoree in March of this year at the Nassau County Bar Association when we dedicated the LaLiberte Banner in his honor, Sam will live on as an inspiration to young lawyers-an expert strategist, a forceful advocate, a tireless teacher, a scrupulous draftsman and a wise counsellor. We have learned from him; we have loved him; we will miss him. The Partners, Associates, Counsel and Staff of, Farrell, Fritz, Caemmerer, Cleary, Barnosky & Armentano, P.C., Uniondale, NY

title: School Guidelines Criticized
description: New Jersey's new curriculum standards are too vague and unclear to provide teachers with the guidance they need to make sure that students will meet the requirements, a national teachers union said yesterday.

title: Lining Up for Hepatitis Shots
description: SOME adolescents may be adding three shots of the hepatitis B vaccine to their list of back-to-school necessities this fall.

title: Spending Plan Gives Priority To Education
description: The state budget agreement announced this evening contains some ambitious schools programs that together represent the largest investment in public education that New York has ever made, the product of an unusual confluence of financial abundance and political factors.

title: Closer for White Sox Is Being Discussed
description: With the trade deadline looming on Thursday, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips is searching for relief pitching, and he is talking to the Chicago White Sox about the closer Roberto Hernandez, according to baseball officials familiar with the discussions.

title: Barry L. Zaretsky, 47, Professor Of Law and Bankruptcy Scholar
description: Barry Lewis Zaretsky, a professor at Brooklyn Law School and a scholar in the fields of bankruptcy and commercial law, died on Monday, apparently in an explosion that destroyed his vacation home in Canaan, N.Y. He was 47 years old.

title: Settling In for the Long Run
description: Top runners flock to training meccas like Boulder, Colo., and Toluca, Mexico, where the high altitude, tangy air and soft forest trails beckon. But New York City, with its crowded streets and exhaust-choked air, does not rank high on their wish list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARNEY, THOMAS A.
description: CARNEY-Thomas A. Died peacefully in his home on July 28 in Belle Harbor, Queens, beloved husband of Margaret (nee Rochford) and the late Thelma (nee Steventon). Until his death he was Vice President of Operations and Management for the Mendik Realty Co. where he served for 28 years. Born in Brooklyn in 1919, he served in The New York State Assembly in the 1950's. Active in Brooklyn and Queens Republican political circles for over 50 years. Stationed in the European Theatre in W.W. II and participated in the Normandy Landing. Also survived by his dear stepchildren, Michael, Patricia, Dennis and Thomas, of New York, and Peggy Murphy, of Winnepeg, Manitoba, and proud grandfather of 8 grandchildren. Fond brother of the late Mary (Mae) Quinn. Visitation on Wednesday 7-10 PM, Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 9:45 A.M. at Saint Francis De Sales Church, Belle Harbor. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in his memory to The Sisters of Saint Joseph, Maria Regina Convent, Brentwood, New York 11717 or Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, NYC 10003.

title: Walk, Munch, Crunch, Slurp, Walk ...
description: YOU see them all over New York, the harried folks rushing hither and yon, gobbling a hot dog while the sauerkraut squooshes out of the bun and onto their shoes.

title: Legal Immigrants to Benefit Under New Budget Accord
description: President Clinton persuaded Congress to accept many of his proposals to undo the effects of the 1996 welfare law, but Congress rejected some of his requests.

title: In Chicago, Finding Hope in a Shopping Mall
description: No wars or riots or earthquakes scarred the Kenwood-Oakland section on the South Side. It just looked that way.

title: Son Settles S.E.C. Insider Case at AT&T
description: The son of a former executive of the AT&T Corporation has agreed to pay about $77,600 in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over his involvement in an insider ring at the company.

title: Norwegian Whalers Are Telling Fish Stories
description: To the Editor;

title: What Saved The Hotels? Not Just Tax Cuts
description: A few short years ago, New York hotel operators were cursing the darkness. About a third of the city's hotel rooms were empty -- the worst showing since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's -- and average room rates were flat or falling. Much of the blame was laid at the feet of the state and the city, which had raised the tax on hotel rooms to more than 21 percent, by far the highest rate in the nation. Convention organizers announced boycotts of New York and its outrageous room prices. Tourism, hoteliers declared, was endangered.

title: NEW YORK ATTAINS A BUDGET ACCORD THAT TRIMS TAXES
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the State Legislature announced a tentative agreement tonight on a budget of nearly $68 billion that includes billions of dollars for new school programs and school construction, billions more for property tax relief, and a state-financed cut in the New York City income tax.

title: Personal Health
description: FROM 1948 to 1971, nearly five million pregnant women in this country were treated with a synthetic estrogen-like drug, DES (short for diethylstilbestrol), in the mistaken belief that it would help prevent miscarriages and premature deliveries. The legacy of this misguided treatment for the girls born of such pregnancies has been well established through studies conducted over more than a quarter-century.

title: Holmes Survives Split Decision at Garden
description: If Larry Holmes thought this was a great buildup toward a heavyweight match with George Foreman, maybe he was right. If Foreman was watching Holmes fight Maurice Harris last night at the Theater in Madison Square Garden, he saw a boxer who is well past his prime and will not do much damage.

title: Charlie Trie's Tainted Money
description: With dispassionate thoroughness, an F.B.I. agent named Jerome Campane yesterday gave the Senate committee investigating campaign spending abuses the most detailed and easily the most arresting description so far of how foreign money was laundered into the 1994 elections and Bill Clinton's re-election campaign. This startling mosaic, involving an Asian developer named Ng Lap Seng and his industrious American agent, Yah Lin (Charlie) Trie, did not prove Senator Fred Thompson's suspicions that the Chinese Government sought to influence the American political system. But it did nothing to erase those suspicions, meanwhile showing how vulnerable that system is to manipulation.

title: Currency Speculators Are Not All Foreigners : Selectivity Fuels Attack By Malaysia
description: HONG KONG  As Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia condemns "criminal" international speculators for the currency turbulence in the region this month, he leaves out some important information: the role of locals in undermining their own currencies.

title: A Show of 44 Rarely Seen Paintings From a Mughal Book
description: About 1639 the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan of India, builder of the Taj Mahal, commissioned a great book to record the splendor of his reign. Meant to be illustrated with miniature paintings by the finest artists of the imperial atelier, it was titled, immodestly, the ''Padshahnama,'' or ''Chronicle of the King of the World.''

title: 2,000 Acres Burn in Fire in a New Jersey State Forest
description: A forest fire swept across more than 2,000 acres of Wharton State Forest in southern New Jersey yesterday, forcing more than 125 people from their homes in one village, officials said. Two minor injuries were reported.

title: Albany Charts New Congressional Map
description: Leaders of both houses of the State Legislature in Albany are crafting a plan that would shift the lines of four of the Congressional districts in New York City, making them more compact and reducing the Hispanic population in one that has been at the center of a court case, several legislative leaders said yesterday.

title: $100 Million Settlement Seen In Tenet Suits
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation has agreed to pay about $100 million to former patients who contended that the company and some affiliated doctors illegally imprisoned them in psychiatric hospitals in order to obtain their insurance benefits, people briefed on the financial arrangements said yesterday.

title: Discovery Zone Gets Aid
description: Discovery Zone Inc., an operator of indoor playgrounds, emerged today from bankruptcy protection today with a new ownership group and $100 million in private financing. Discovery Zone said its new ownership group was led by Wellspring Associates L.L.C., a privately held investment firm founded by the former chief executive of Paramount Communications Inc., Martin S. Davis. Discovery Zone, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., filed last year for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Fearing A Showcase In Outfield
description: THERE was terror all over the Oakland clubhouse last night. Carlos Reyes, the starting pitcher, was terrified because Jose Canseco was going to play right field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYLE, JOSEPH D.
description: RYLE-Joseph D. In memory of Uncle Joe, blithe spirit, loved by all who knew him. Dear Joe, May the road rise to meet you. May the wind be always at your back. May the sun shine warm upon your face, the rains fall soft upon your fields, and until we meet again, may God hold you in the palm of His hand. With love Kathy and John Slattery

title: Judgment Day for Pol Pot
description: The surreal trial of Pol Pot, held last week in a shed deep in the jungle of northern Cambodia, was the antithesis of justice. It was a show trial designed to demonstrate that the Khmer Rouge has broken with its old leader and is deserving of new legitimacy. Instead it showed how little the Khmer Rouge has changed. The rest of the world, however, has progressed in dispensing justice to men like Pol Pot. There are ways to give him the trial that he, and his million-plus Cambodian victims, deserve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, RHODA B.
description: MOKOTOFF-Rhoda B. At age 85 on July 27, 1997 after a long illness. Survived by her husband of 62 years, Harold; children Steffi and Robert Berne, John (Moke) and Hue Mokotoff; grandchildren Elizabeth Berne, Alexander Berne and Sophia Mokotoff; brother Mickey Becher. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY 11968, will be gratefully received.

title: New York Joins Inquiry Into River Damage
description: In a move that could lead to a protracted legal battle between New York State and one of the nation's largest industrial companies, the state will join a Federal effort to determine the costs of environmental damage to the Hudson River from toxic chemicals, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday.

title: So Why Shouldn't A Crime Writer Have Several aka's?
description: HAVING an identity crisis is bad enough. But having a crisis over somebody else's identity borders on the absurd.

title: A Tax Cut for the 90's, With Its Own Theme: All Things in Moderation
description: The country's last tax cut, pushed through Congress by President Ronald Reagan in 1981, was big by anybody's standards: by the time all its provisions had kicked in, the tax reductions amounted to roughly 3 percent of the country's gross domestic product.

title: 'Resettling' Slovak Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPEL, LOUIS
description: KARPEL-Louis. A loving, dedicated and generous person. When a community project had to be done Lou was always smiling and ready to oblige. We shall miss him as we have missed his Mollie. Mark Chase, President Oscawana Country Club

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLARSFELD, LEAH (NEE DOSTIS)
description: KLARSFELD-Leah (nee Dostis). On July 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Herman and Kenneth Klarsfeld and Elayne Mustalish. Service is on Thursday, at 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A System Gone Mad
description: While David Spence was on death row his mother, Juanita White, received a letter from an inmate who had testified against him. The inmate said he had committed perjury and begged for forgiveness. Ms. White, excited, turned the letter over to a lawyer, who alerted the police. Less than 48 hours after a police memorandum about the letter was disseminated, Ms. White was beaten to death.

title: Dollar Ends Little Changed After Early Gains Evaporate
description: The dollar gave back early gains to end little changed yesterday against the mark and the yen.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: J. P. Morgan Shifts Strategies To Buy a Stake In Fund Concern
description: Moving to shore up its lagging money management arm, J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it would invest $900 million for a 45 percent stake in the American Century Companies, the nation's 15th-largest mutual fund company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 3 Columbia/HCA Officials Are Indicted in Inquiry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ALEXANDER H., MD.
description: ROSENTHAL-Alexander H., MD. It is with deep sorrow that we note the passing of Alexander H. Rosenthal, M.D., Chairman Emertus of Obstetrics/Gynecology at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. During his tenure from 1954 until 1971, he pioneered teaching activities that included the development of a major residency program and a post-graduate course for area-wide positions. Today the community is richly endowed with physicians in this specialty due, in large measure, to his efforts. Clinician, teacher and scientist, Dr. Rosenthal was among the ''greats'' who chartered LIJ's future direction. We offer our deepest sympathy to his daughter, Jane Rosenthal Carlantonio and granddaughter Jenny. Roy Zuckerberg, Chairman David R. Dantzker, MD, President and CEO

title: Mattie Lou O'Kelley, 89, Georgia Folk Artist
description: Mattie Lou O'Kelley, who began painting as a hobby at the age of 60 and became a celebrated folk artist of rural Southern life, died on Saturday at her home in Decatur, Ga. She was 89.

title: Still in Love, and the Love Still Grows
description: ''I have a song here. . . .''

title: A Smorgasbord of Styles
description: A sense of magical discovery hovered over ''Unspoken Changes,'' presented by the Bridget Moore Dance troupe on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Ms. Moore is not only a stunning performer but a young modern dance choreographer of considerable promise as well. And Ms. Moore's eye for exciting dancers was evident in her company of six, all current or recently graduated dance majors at Ohio State University.

title: Ruralism Without the Kitsch
description: AT Picnic, a new cafe on Irving Place, the restaurant's name had only the subtlest impact on the development of the decor. ''We didn't want Ye Olde Vermont Inn with gingham napkins,'' said Chris Bundy, a furniture designer, who turned his hand to architecture and interior design at the request of Picnic's owners -- his wife, Meg Grosswendt, and Stephanie Goldberg.

title: Somebody Suspected Charlie Trie
description: Had Hillary Rodham Clinton and Harold Ickes listed to Michael Cardozo, the White House might have avoided at least one fund-raising embarrassment last year. Mr. Cardozo, the director of the Clintons' legal defense fund, warned them that there was something fishy about the contributions that Yah Lin (Charlie) Trie had offered the fund. Yet the White House and the Democratic National Committee continued to exploit Mr. Trie's money-raising skills for the Clinton re-election campaign, and the White House actually named him to a Federal advisory board.

title: Swimmer Can Sue, Court Says
description: Oceanfront communities may be liable for damages if they assume responsibility for protecting the public from rough surf but fail to provide adequate safeguards, a state appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: Seeking Special-Needs Status
description: The Plainfield school district today is to formally request inclusion on a list of special-needs schools that are eligible for extra aid from the state.

title: Theft From Ailing Gambler
description: A man who rushed to the aid of a gambler having a heart attack and pretended to be a doctor has admitted in court that he stole nearly $30,000 in chips from him.

title: Clinton Condemns Bombing
description: President Clinton called the bombings a ''barbarous act'' and asked the Palestinians to take concrete steps to fight terrorism. Page A10.

title: Sales of New Homes Up 6.1%, Showing Firmness for Housing
description: Sales of new single-family homes rose 6.1 percent in June, maintaining a level high enough to suggest that the housing market entered the third quarter on firm footing.

title: Laura Ashley Stock Drops After Resignation
description: The shares of Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. fell yesterday to their lowest level in more than six years after the company, a clothing retailer, said its design director, Basha Cohen, had resigned. She is the third executive to leave in two months.

title: 3 Executives of Hospital Chain Charged With Medicare Fraud
description: As part of a widening criminal investigation of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, a Federal grand jury has indicted three executives who have been top officers in the company's giant Florida market on charges of defrauding the Government, according to papers unsealed yesterday.

title: Pataki Vetoes Bill to Pay Disabled Care Outside State

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOPPELT, ELIZABETH J. (BEEBE)
description: DOPPELT-Elizabeth J. (Beebe). Age 51, a woman of exceptional warmth, imagination and courage, died July 29, after a twenty-one year battle with breast cancer. Born Elizabeth Beebe in Brooklyn, New York, Liz excelled at Lincoln High School and at Brooklyn College, and maintained a working knowledge of physics and chemistry. She spent every childhood summer at Camp Taconic in the Berkshire Mountains, building lifelong friendships there. Her early ambitions included becoming a ballerina or an astronaut. Instead, she became an entrepreneur, creating several successful businesses built on her fine eye for style and design. Liz's companies included Beaux Dangles (women's high-fashion accessories) and Really Lizzie (unique children's gifts). Most recently, she was the proprietor of GreenHouse of Winnetka, Illinois, an innovative shop specializing in antiques for rooms and gardens. She traveled the country pursuing unusual and fine objects for her customers and her home. Liz was generous to close friends and business acquaintances alike, and provided both knowledge and encouragement to many women who suffered with her disease. She was loving and wise for her children, Rachel and Adam; her husband, Neil, and her brother, Hank, all of whom survive her. She was unfailingly supportive to her family through every big and little crisis in their lives. Despite her illness, Liz had no bitterness or regrets about her own life, only good humor and enthusiasm for her next challenge. Her strength was extraordinary. With her courage, her ready wit and keen intellect, and especially her loving spirit, she enriched the lives of all who knew her.

title: Nine 'Nightline' Awards

And ABC News led all networks with 29 nominations (22 of them by its news magazine programs). PBS was second with 25, followed by NBC with 17 and CBS with 16 (9 for ''60 Minutes''). A variety of networks, among them HBO, TBS Discovery and CNN, split the remaining nominations. The winners of the 18th annual awards will be announced on Sept. 10.

title: TAKEOVER RUMORS LIFT SHARES OF FISHER SCIENTIFIC
description: The stock of Fisher Scientific International Inc. rose 5 percent yesterday amid rumors that the company was seeking a buyer to fend off an unsolicited $1 billion takeover bid from the Bass family. Fisher's shares rose $2.4375, to close at $48.8125, after reaching a new 52-week high of $49.625. At least one unspecified company is rumored to have made a bid that values Fisher about $1.5 billion, or close to $60 a share. The company, a maker of scientific equipment for hospitals, attracted the Basses' attention after its stock fell 19 percent earlier this year. The Basses, of Fort Worth, said they had made their bid of $48 a share to increase shareholder value. Officials of Fisher, of Hampton, N.H., said they were evaluating the Bass proposal.

Analysts and investors said the maker of computer networking equipment told them that profit margins and sales would pick up later this fiscal year. 3Com barred reporters from the briefing at the annual Network Connections conference, sponsored by companies that sell devices for transmitting information over computer networks. 3Com shares fell $2.25, to $55.75, in Nasdaq trading of 11 million shares.
