title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, ANDREW R.
description: BAER-Andrew R., of Armonk, New York, on July 28. Devoted son of Dr. Rudolf L. Baer; loving father of David and Jessica; cherished brother of John R. Baer; uncle of Alexandra and Abigail; and nephew of Eva Baer, Elizabeth and Henry Werner and Virginia and George Grumbach. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Friday, August 1, at 9:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: Rudolf L. Baer Foundation, C/O Dept. of Dermatology, New York University Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016-6402.

title: Defense Dept. Dismisses a Report on Iraqi Gas
description: The Pentagon today denounced a previously unpublicized top-secret report prepared for the Defense Department that found that hundreds, if not thousands, of marines might have been exposed to chemical weapons when they crossed Iraqi minefields into Kuwait in the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: Ex-Beauty Queen Slain, a New Riddle in Mexico's Drug Scandals
description: The police in Guadalajara are investigating the killing of a former Mexican beauty queen suspected of having ties to army officers and drug lords who was gunned down in her pickup truck on Tuesday night as she waited for a red light to change.

title: Japan Penalizes Nomura and Big Bank for Payoffs
description: In the strongest punitive action it has ever taken against major financial institutions, Japan's Finance Ministry ordered the Nomura Securities Company and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank today to suspend part of their operations for the rest of this year as punishment for making payments and loans to a racketeer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, LILIANA N. ROSSMAN (NEE MOROZOWSKI)
description: DIXON-Liliana N. Rossman (nee Morozowski), of New York City, Wednesday July 30 1997. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of Karl Dixon, dear sister of Jaime Morozowski, cherished daughter of Isaac and Rebecca Morozowski. Funeral services from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey on Friday, August 1, 1997 at 1:00 P.M. Interment Beth David Memorial Park, Kenilworth, New Jersey.

title: Celebrities Worth More?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Offense Idling In Land of Make-Believe
description: Sometimes football at a National Football League training camp is no different from play at school yards and backyards across the country. Bored people make up pretend games.

title: Accounts
description: * Carfax, Fairfax, Va., to Cadmus/ O'Keefe Marketing, Richmond, a division of Cadmus Marketing Group, as the first agency to handle advertising for the company, which provides history information on used cars. Billings were not disclosed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Pentagon Halts Drug Patrols After a Killing at the Border
description: Facing a storm of controversy over a United States Marine corporal's fatal shooting of a local teen-ager along the Rio Grande on the Texas-Mexico border, the Pentagon has abruptly suspended all anti-drug operations by military forces along the entire Mexican border, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Terror and Peace in Israel
description: The Middle East's terrorist bombers know all too well when violence is most likely to disrupt the delicate political chemistry required to move the peace effort ahead. The double suicide bombings in Jerusalem yesterday were clearly timed not only to block the planned resumption of negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians but to make it more difficult for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to take the risks required to make a permanent peace. Mr. Netanyahu must resist the understandable temptation to freeze the peace effort indefinitely in hopes of enhancing Israeli security and mollifying Cabinet colleagues opposed to further discussions with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

title: Leaving the Castle Well Defended While Riding Out
description: WORRY -- can you leave home without it?

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Disappointing Carrots

title: Inflows Show That Investors Are Still Bullish on Mutual Funds
description: As stock prices reached new heights in July, mutual fund investors celebrated by adding to their investments in equity funds.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Monday about the finish of the Tour de France bicycle race included an outdated reference to the anthem that was played in honor of the German winner. It is now known as ''Deutschlandlied'' (''The Germany Song''). The anthem ''Deutschland Uber Alles'' (''Germany Foremost'') was dropped after World War II. The melody, by Haydn, was reintroduced in 1952 without the anthem's first two verses.

title: Yet Despite the Decades, Dion Holds Tight to His Doo-Wop Roots
description: In the late 1950's and early 60's, Dion DiMucci was a one-man Bronx coalition. He had the melodic croon of Italian pop singers and the braggadocio of the blues, which he had learned from a building superintendent. He had also absorbed doo-wop and Chuck Berry's rock-and-roll, while Jewish songwriters provided some of his hits. Dion, now 58, doesn't live in the Bronx anymore, but in Boca Raton, Fla. But at Tramps on Tuesday night, the old Bronx lived on in Dion; his band and backup singers, he announced, were an ''Irish-Jewish-Italian contingent.''

title: Man Arrested In 2 Homicides, 27 Years Later
description: Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Manhattan District Attorney's office arrested a man yesterday whom they believed to have been responsible for a double killing that took place almost three decades ago in Manhattan, investigators said.

title: Larionov May Re-sign
description: The Detroit Red Wings are close to re-signing the free-agent center IGOR LARIONOV to a three-year contract worth at least $5.2 million, The Detroit Free Press reported yesterday.

title: Utility to Cut Rates Over Next 5 Years
description: The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it would cut electricity rates by $600 million through 2002 in a deregulation plan accepted by the New York Public Service Commission.

title: Mexican Fishermen Hail Senate Vote on Tuna Ban
description: The skippers of Mexican tuna boats and their crews rejoiced today at a vote in the United States Senate that repealed a ban on Mexican tuna that has kept many of the fishermen out of work for most of this decade.

title: On Death's Demise, The Living Party On
description: Death scenes have always been the mother's milk of grand opera, whether it is Marguerite ascending to heaven, Tosca plummeting to the pavement or Aida choking on bad air in the tomb. Life stinks and heaven awaits. The end of the operatic life is its vindication. We go home with a catch in the throat; Tristan goes to his reward.

title: M.T.A. Rejects Giuliani's Stand on Contract
description: Despite strong objections from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's appointees, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to award a $95 million data processing contract to a subsidiary of a company tied to previous corruption scandals.

title: A report shows how hard it is to break welfare dependency.
description: WASHINGTON is betting that last year's welfare legislation, mandating a five-year time limit on cash benefits, will end dependence as we know it. And the first signs have been encouraging: the combination of a strong job market and tougher eligibility rules has trimmed the welfare rolls by 800,000 in the last two years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NAOMI CAMPBELL, the model, has a new familial tie: NELSON MANDELA, the President of South Africa, has deemed her to be an ''honorary granddaughter.'' She has met with him five times, most recently last week in his office in Johannesburg.

title: In Search for 'Soft Money' Source, Few Hard Facts
description: At its most frustrating moments, the Senate inquiry into campaign funding abuses is offering a variation on the dictum that politics stops at the water's edge.

title: U.S. Lifts the Ban on Travel to Lebanon
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced today that she was lifting the 10-year ban on travel by Americans to Lebanon. But she said Lebanon remained very dangerous and urged United States citizens not to go there.

title: D'Amato Threatens Action Against Swiss Bank in Shredding Case
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato threatened today to seek to revoke the rights of a Swiss bank to operate in the United States if Switzerland continued the ''intimidation and prosecution'' of a security guard who disclosed the shredding of Nazi-era bank documents.

title: Chicago Council Enacts a Milestone: an Ethics Law It Must Obey
description: In an effort to clean up its long-entrenched image of corruption, the Chicago City Council today passed the first ethics ordinance that will apply to its own members.

title: Fake Con Ed Workers Rob Woman at Home
description: Three robbers posing as Con Ed workers talked their way into an elderly woman's home in Queens early yesterday and tied her up with a phone cord before fleeing with $100, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBLUM, MORGAN
description: GELBLUM-Morgan. The Board of Directors and staff of Lawyers for Children extend heartfelt condolences to our good friend and board member, Seth Gelblum, on the death of his daughter, Morgan. Our thoughts are with you, Orren, Madeleine, and Aiden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, CLARE G.
description: PINCUS-Clare G. Died peacefully at 95 on July 30 in her home in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Jonas Pincus. Devoted mother of Eleanor and Walter and mother-in-law of Louis Newman and Ann Pincus. Loving grandmother of Peter, Cathy, Barbara, Andrew, Ward, Adam and Battle, and great-grandmother of Joshua, Kate, Emma, Jenny, Kate and Martha. We will all miss her.

title: Yanks Have All the Help They Need
description: NOBODY wants to help the New York Yankees, the owner from Tampa, Fla., always says. Naturally, George Steinbrenner forgets that not all that long ago, the Yankees were handed on a Seattle platter Tino Martinez, who merely happens to be leading the major leagues in home runs and is second in runs batted in.

description: To the Editor:

title: Events: Flower Fiesta, Crafts Demonstrations
description: Flower Festival

title: MCI Profits Fell by 6.7% In 2d Quarter
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that earnings declined 6.7 percent in the second quarter as growth in long-distance operations, which provide almost all of the company's profits, slowed from the first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, BRO. ANDREW F.S.C.
description: O'CONNOR-Bro. Andrew F.S.C. July 28, 1997. Age 84. Professor of Romance Languages, Manhattan College. The Brothers will receive friends at the Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Road (West of Broadway at 242 Street, Bronx) on Wednesday, July 30, 1997 from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM and on Thursday, July 31, 1997 from 2-5 PM and 7-8 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Thursday evening July 31, 1997 at 8 PM in the Christian Brothers Center. Interment will take place on Friday, August 1, 1997 at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paul L. Miller, 77, Financier And Ex-President of First Boston
description: Paul L. Miller, an investment banker and a former president of the First Boston Corporation, died Saturday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 77.

title: New School Building Plan Is Challenged by History
description: Under the state budget agreement, New York City stands to gain more than $1 billion for school construction, but how many new classrooms would be built was unclear yesterday because the school system has routinely overestimated what it can accomplish, only to find construction dollars absorbed by cost overruns and, at times, outright corruption.

title: NASA Names a New Astronaut To Be Sent to Repair Mir Station
description: The next American astronaut in line for a tour aboard the troubled Russian space station Mir has been pulled from the mission because she is too small for the Russian space walk suits, NASA announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, PAUL L.
description: WHITE-Paul L., of Mystic, CT, formerly of NYC. Accomplished painter and artist. Funeral Friday 2 PM Dinoto Funeral Home, Mystic CT. Donations to Mystic Art Assoc., 9 Water Street, Mystic, CT. 06355.

title: All the Sturm und Drang! It's Not Just Umlauts
description: Just a year ago, it was all settled. A new generation of Germans would traverse its school years with no exposure to the last vestiges of Gothic spelling, entering a brave new world of orthography in which, for example, spaghetti would lose its H and ketchup would gain an S, and German -- the language that so befuddled Mark Twain -- would be, well, simple.

title: Budget Bill Passes, With Foes in House At Both Extremes
description: With the cries of victory from Democrats and Republicans alike still resounding, the House voted overwhelmingly yesterday for legislation to balance the Federal budget by 2002. On the other side of the Capitol, the Senate began debating the measure, for which it has shown even greater support.

title: Ailing Kia of South Korea Plans To Cut Assets, Jobs and Units
description: The Kia Group proposed today to shed $6.4 billion in assets, reduce the number of its subsidiaries by 80 percent and cut 8,800 jobs, or nearly 20 percent of its labor force, but creditors of the group, which is under bankruptcy protection, said they needed more details before they could sign off on the plan.

title: In Signing Messier, Canucks' Persistence Paid Off
description: It was Saturday, July 19, and Pat Quinn, the Vancouver Canucks' general manager, decided to take the initiative. The Canucks badly wanted to sign Mark Messier, so Quinn figured he would get a head start on other suitors by flying to Hilton Head Island to lobby the Messiers in person.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: CHRONICLE
description: CATHY GUISEWITE, the cartoonist who depicts the travails of the single woman, plans to marry. But her alter ego in the ''Cathy'' comic strip will remain single and continue playing the dating game.

title: Budget Bill Clears House as Senate Takes Up Its Debate
description: With both Republicans and Democrats claiming victory and credit, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to approve landmark legislation to balance the Federal budget by 2002.

title: Inequity Fixed In Proposal for Capital Gains
description: After hearing Wall Street scream and moan, Congressional and White House budget negotiators retreated yesterday from a plan that would have pushed capital gains taxes higher on some sales. That did not look good in a bill widely advertised as cutting such taxes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about the budget deal between the White House and Congressional Republicans referred incorrectly in some editions to the two people shown. They were Speaker Newt Gingrich and Representative John R. Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee -- not Senators Trent Lott, the majority leader, and Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.

description: To the Editor:

title: Water Parks Elicit Fears In Aftermath Of a Death
description: At a time new playgrounds are opening without monkey bars or seesaws for fear they will endanger children, water parks -- with their churning tides, charging rapids and impossibly steep slides -- seem a gloriously reckless chance for kids to be kids again.

title: Indian Novelist's Case Isn't Like Rushdie's
description: To the Editor:

title: J. B. HUNT SELLS FLATBED DIVISION FOR $40 MILLION
description: J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its flatbed division for $40 million in net cash proceeds to the division's management. The total value of the deal was not disclosed. The sale of the flatbed division, which has about $75 million in annual revenue, is part of the company's effort to shed underperforming businesses. The business, a maker of flatbed trailers, will be based in Springdale, Ark., and renamed Charger Inc., Jerry Walton, J. B. Hunt's chief financial officer, said. The unit employs about 850 workers. J. B. Hunt, of Lowell, Ark., transports truckloads of food, plastics, merchandise and other freight throughout the United States and three Canadian provinces. Its stock rose $1 a share, to $16.

title: If English Ban Fox Hunting, Don't Blame Blair
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Inquiry Takes Up Trie Offer to Defense Fund
description: The Senate committee investigating campaign financing focused today on mammoth donations that Yah Lin Trie, a main figure in the inquiry, offered last year to a private fund established to help President Clinton meet personal legal expenses.

title: The Subaru is not a Porsche, but new ads try to close the gap.
description: HOW is a Subaru like a Lamborghini?

title: Deal's Long-Term Effect Has Economists Uneasy
description: While Republicans and Democrats alike are congratulating themselves on a fiscal package that delivers on promises to cut taxes while still balancing the budget, economists are less sanguine about the long-term consequences of the Byzantine negotiation. For one thing, the hodgepodge of tax breaks in the deal complicates an already complex tax code, even as it erodes revenue.

title: Cohen to Cancel Promotion Of General in Saudi Bombing
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen plans to cancel the promotion of the Air Force general in charge of a housing complex in Saudi Arabia where 19 American airmen were killed by a truck bomb last year, Pentagon officials said tonight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPARTECH CORP., Clayton, Mo., a chemical compound maker, will buy the Preferred Plastic Sheet unit of Echlin Inc., Branford, Conn., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Colorado State University Is Still Reeling From a Flash Flood
description: Walking on a spongy, waterlogged carpet, Mario Caballero, a student adviser, pointed a flashlight into the basement gloom and shouted: ''There's the television camera over there! There's the editing equipment in there!''

title: 'On the Town' Delayed
description: The first preview of the Joseph Papp Public Theater/New York Shakespeare Festival production of the 1944 musical ''On the Town'' has been postponed from today until tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, because of lost rehearsal time from recent bad weather, a spokesman for the show said. The outdoor revival, which is free, runs through Aug. 31.

title: A fashion designer's loft, where rooms are merely subtle hints.
description: AS a fashion designer, Han Feng designs three collections a year for the New York runways. But it has taken decades for her to design her first home.

title: R.A. Jackson, the Cartoonist Jak, 70, Dies
description: Raymond Allen Jackson, who kept a good part of London chuckling, chortling and sometimes gasping in indignation during a three-decade run as Jak, the irreverent cartoonist for The Evening Standard, died on Sunday at his home in Wimbledon. He was 70.

title: Magic Johnson Project Shifts to Another Harlem Site
description: A movie theater chain partly owned by Magic Johnson has shifted its sights for a new 12-screen multiplex along 125th Street to Harlem Center, a state project at Lenox Avenue that is being developed by an arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and Forest City Ratner Companies, the chain's president said yesterday.

title: Ruling in Deaths of Four
description: More than six months after the bodies of DelFrances Bennett and her three daughters were found in their Montclair home, investigators have ruled that the 31-year-old mother killed her children with a .22-caliber pistol then turned the weapon on herself, officials said yesterday.

title: Army Inquiries Find a Wide Bias Against Women
description: Two Army investigations into the service's handling of sexual misconduct have found widespread evidence of discrimination by male commanders against female troops, staffing that left too few drill sergeants to supervise troops and a selection system that allowed wife-beaters to fill the prestigious job of drill sergeant, Army officials and lawmakers said today.

title: Ruiz Taken Off Ballot In Bronx President Race
description: The city's Board of Elections said yesterday that it had taken Israel Ruiz Jr., a Democratic candidate for Bronx borough president, off the ballot for the Sept. 9 primary, saying he had submitted forms improperly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, LOIS
description: LONDON-Lois. Beloved wife of the late Milton; devoted mother of Patricia and James Fingeroth and Hank London; cherished grandmother of Robert Fingeroth; loving sister of Irene and Maxwell Ingram, the late Jack Ferkin and Adolph Ferrin. She was loved and will be missed by all who knew her. Services 12 noon, Thursday, Plaza Mememorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stock-Fraud Survey
description: The New York State Attorney General's office has posted a survey on its Internet site, seeking investors who have been victims of stock fraud.

title: Germany's Work Ethic
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCESS BEYOND AND HAYES SET 'REVERSE ACQUISITION'
description: Access Beyond Inc. said yesterday that it would issue $267 million in stock for the closely held Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. in a ''reverse acquisition'' that would give Hayes shareholders 79 percent of the merged company. Following the deal, the combined entity will be renamed Hayes Communications Inc. Access Beyond's products connect users in a computer system. Hayes, a pioneer in computer modems, returns to the stock market after emerging last year from a bankruptcy reorganization. Access Beyond, based in Gaithersburg, Md., will issue 45 million shares for Hayes. Access Beyond's shares fell 81.25 cents yesterday, to $5.125.

title: From Festival Diversity, a Unified Vision and Even Metaphor
description: During ''Le Cercle Invisible,'' a haunting chamber circus that was one of the piquant highlights of Lincoln Center Festival '97, Jean-Baptiste Thierree strode onstage, his eyes bulging with wild enthusiasm. The suitcase he carried was covered in what appeared to be a swatch of medieval tapestry. His suit was also made from that wall hanging. So was his handkerchief.

title: Federal Aid Is Crucial to State Hospital Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspense Ads Focus On New Oldsmobile
description: Those who think going to the movies means they will not have to sit through advertising for anything but popcorn may be in for a surprise this summer. Two ads for the General Motors' Oldsmobile Intrigue sedan have been playing in 141 movie theaters nationwide this month as part of a contest that urges viewers to guess who makes the car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LEO, M.D.
description: STONE-Leo, M.D. Died July 29, 1997, in his 93rd year. Beloved husband and best friend of Marta. A loving brother, father, grandfather and great grandfather. He will be greatly missed. He was a kind and gentle spirit who touched us all. His memory will be cherished by family, friends, colleagues and patients forever. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Friday, August 1st, at 3:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, SYLVIA A.
description: BLANK-Sylvia A., of North Miami Beach, passed away July 30, 1997. Wife of the late Adolph Blank. Beloved mother of Phyllis Horowitz and Martin Blank. Loving grandmother of Debra Laufer, Barry Blank and Claudia Paradise. Adored great grandmother. Funeral services will be held in the chapel of Boulevard-Riverside, 310 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: WESTERN RESOURCES IN DEAL FOR 80% OF PROTECTION ONE
description: Western Resources Inc. said yesterday that it would exchange $320 million and its own security operations for 80.1 percent of Protection One Inc. The deal would make Protection One, whose headquarters are in Culver City, Calif., the second-largest United States burglar and fire-alarm company, with more than $1 billion in annual revenue. The deal follows a failed bid by Western Resources earlier this year to buy ADT Ltd. Protection One's shares rose $2.75, to $18, while Western Resources' rose 56.25 cents, to $34.5625. Protection One shareholders, who will get a one-time dividend of $7 a share after the transaction closes, will own 19.9 percent of the company.

title: Pol Pot Trial Far From Villagers' Minds
description: The subject was Pol Pot. ''Why have a trial?'' a young soldier said today, holding his rifle nonchalantly by the barrel. ''Just kill him.''

title: A Gallery Of Images At the Window
description: THE words ''elegance'' and ''recycling'' are rarely found in the same sentence. But Justin Kelly, a contractor in TriBeCa, has risen to the challenge, thanks to a client whose indoor shutters were crusted by a century's worth of paint. Mr. Kelly, 36, did not look forward to stripping the shutters and remembered that he had a couple of boxes of Victorian glass-lantern slides, small photographic plates. A second career and a dazzling special effect were born. Mr. Kelly's post-modern ''stained glass'' panels are mosaiclike color or black-and-white slides, sandwiched between plates of safety glass and framed in aluminum, architectural bronze or steel.
